Welcome to Practical Jetpack Compose

Welcome to Practical Jetpack Compose - this course is aimed to take you through 12 Jetpack Compose projects, aimed to get you building common UI patterns using this new UI framework for Android. By purchasing this course youâ€™ve made a great investment in your leaning journey - be it for professional or hobby purposes, my aim with this course is to get you building things with Jetpack Compose. After all, itâ€™s the future of UI development for Android Apps.

What this course is

Throughout the 12 projects in this course youâ€™ll be learning how to build common user interfaces using Jetpack Compose. Youâ€™ll be using a range of Compose APIs, managing state and also writing automated tests for the composables that we create. While there is some overlap in the different projects, the range of APIs and approaches covered will give you enough knowledge to be able to replicate common UI requirements in the apps that you build.

When it comes to the compose APIs, weâ€™ll be covering the follow topics across the 12 projects:

  • UI Composition: So that you can utilise composables, you'll need to learn the foundations of composing UI. Throughout the projects we'll introduce you to and guide you through UI composition, so you'll be confident in building your on compose apps from start to finish!
  • Laying out Compose UI: When it comes to laying our our composables, there are many different pieces of the layout APIs that provide support for this. Throughout the projects we build, we'll be covering all of the different parts of the layout APIs, so that you can learn how these can be used in to build Android layouts.
  • Material Design: Material Design plays a crucial part in the look and feel of Android Apps. We'll be using the Compose Material Components package throughout the projects, thoroughly using most of the components that it has to offer!
  • Architecture: The way in which we build apps is largely affected by the use of Jetpack Compose, and there are ways which can make working with Jetpack Compose much smoother! Throughout the projects we'll pay close attention to how we are architecting each features to learn how Jetpack Compose fits into Android projects.
  • Accessibility: So that you can sure your UI is accessible for your users, throughout the projects we will cover the different approaches we take to apply accessibility concepts to our composables
  • Theming: Theming allows you to declare a foundation set of properties that be applied to composabes throughout your project. We'll show you how you can do this within Jetpack Compose.
  • Animations: Animations can help to engage and delight your users. You'll learn how to create animations using Jetpack Compose during the project development!
  • Dependency Injection: Using Dependency Injection is a common use case in many projects, and things can look a little different with compose. We'll cover how you can use Hilt with Jetpack Compose and View Models.
  • Navigation: Within your apps you'll likely want to navigate between different composables. This can be done using the Compose navigation component, which you'll learn how to use thoroughly within the book!
  • Canvas Drawing: While Compose offers a lot of UI components, there are going to be times where we want to have complete control over the things we are drawing. For this we can create custom drawing and components using the canvas, which we'll learn all about throughout various projects!
  • Gestures: In all applications, user will be performing gestures against our UI. This works a little differently when it comes to Jetpack Compose but fear not, we cover all different types of gesture interactions in the projects.
  • Interoperability: Using Composables alongside the Android UI Toolkit (and vice versa) is going to be required in a range of scenarios. In the projects we will cover several scenarios on how to approach this and learn how to fully support interoperability in Compose projects.

What this course is not

This course is aimed to be the missing guide between the introduction of Jetpack Compose, to shipping features to users. There are plenty of informative guides for the foundations and intervals of Jetpack Compose, so this course does not try to replicate those. While we do touch on introductory level topics both in this chapter and throughout the projects, it would be worthwhile checking out the official getting started guides for Jetpack Compose if you are looking to cover more of the foundational topics.

This course is also not a deep dive into Jetpack Compose. As mentioned above, the aim is to get you using Jetpack Compose to build UI, giving you the confidence and knowledge to continue exploring the APIs for your own projects. If you are looking to learn more about deeper compose topics and how things are working under the hood, I would highly recommended checking out Jetpack Compose Internals by Jorge Castillo.

Throughout the book we touch on various Android Development and Kotlin concepts. If you are following this course then it is recommended that you have some knowledge of both of these topics. We will not be covering any introductory concepts for these things, so itâ€™s possible you will face some hurdles during the projects without any experience here.

Frequently Asked Questions

Will the course and project be kept up-to-date?

The project will be updated for this version of the course if there are any breaking issues or bugs that occur, but the release of this version of the course is only valid for Jetpack Compose v1.1. The project will not be updated to version Jetpack Compose 1.2.0 until there is a version 2 of this course released.

I purchased the beta release, when can I expect the finished release?

There is currently no set date for the finalised version, but you can expect it in early 2022. The remaining chapters will be released as and when they are finished - which will likely be every 3-4 weeks. I work on this course as a side-project and with life commitments, hard dates arenâ€™t easy to lay out.

Not happy with your purchase?

If you purchase this course and itâ€™s not quite what you had expected, you can get a full refund within 72 hours of your purchase date. No questions asked!

Can I use the code from this course in my own projects?

Both the code from the projects and the code samples in this book comes with the Apache License 2.0. Please be sure to read these licenses if you are going to be taking the code into some of your own projects.

Any more questions?

If you have any further questions on this course, please check the Practical Jetpack Compose website to see if theyâ€™ve already been answered. Otherwise, please feel free to reach out at contact@compose.academy

Approaching the Projects in this Book

With this coursebook you have also been given access to the corresponding Android Studio project, this contains the different projects that youâ€™ll be working on throughout this course. While the code for these projects is complete within the provided source code, youâ€™ll get the best learning experience by following the guide in the course book, using the provided source code as a reference where required.

The demo project contains the 12 different projects that are outlined throughout this course book. Each of these projects can be found within a corresponding module which will be clearly outlined within each chapter of this course. You will be able to select the module that you wish to run from the Android Studio Run menu, allowing you to individually launch a project.

Do I need to start from the first project?

Well, this depends! If you havenâ€™t built too many things with Jetpack Compose, then youâ€™ll get the best learning experience by starting from the first project in the book. The projects are ordered by complexity in terms of the APIs that are used, the UI that is built and the state being managed - this means that if you are new to Jetpack Compose, youâ€™ll be able to gain knowledge and experience in an iterative fashion. Starting too late in the projects will also likely result in a loss of information, which could cause some friction when trying to approach some of the later projects.

If you are already comfortable with compose, it might be the case that you want to build specific projects from the course to learn more about certain APIs. Each project has been documented with enough content and foundational content - so it is completely possible to start at whatever project you wish!

Should I build all of my apps like these projects?

When it comes to building software, there are many different ways of approaching the different concepts that come with it (such as architecture, layering, APIs etc). The approaches used in this book are not a one-size fits-all solution, so itâ€™s important to remember that if you are trying to transfer these approaches to your own projects. If you are looking at building onto the projects that exist in this course, then it might also be the case that the current solutions might not scale to these new requirements - which also serves as a good exercise for adjusting the current implementations.

Just like applying any other concept to your software projects; as a general guideline, use the current approaches in the context of the given projects, analysing the requirements of external projects before directly applying the learnings from this course.

A note on opinionated approaches

This project uses a collection of approaches that, as outlined above, are not a one-size fits-all. There are some things which will help to bring benefits to the development of applications, whereas there are other things which are used because they are standard Android APIs from Google - this helps us to cater for common experiences within the Android Development community.

For example, the use of a Single Source of Truth and Unidirectional Data Flow are things that bring many benefits to not only the developer experience of your project, but also the user experience from the finished product. While these could still be seen as a guideline, these could be classified under recommended practices to follow when building applications with Jetpack Compose.

On the other hand, using the View Model component or Hilt for dependency injection are not necessarily things that need to be used when it comes to building apps with Jetpack Compose. They have been used in these projects because they are standard Android libraries (therefore a common solution that developers will either be familiar with, or commonly encounter during their development experiences). Being official Android libraries means that these also come with good Jetpack Compose support out-of-the-box, allowing us to focus on building great UI rather than trying to get tools to work well together. As mentioned above though, these are not a necessity when it comes to building apps with Jetpack Compose.

Unit Testing

Throughout the projects we create a number of classes that can be unit tested, but we wonâ€™t be writing unit tests. The projects focus on the UI that is being built with Jetpack Compose - so while weâ€™ll be writing automated tests for these composables, writing unit tests for other classes (such as ViewModels) wonâ€™t be covered so that we are able to focus on the composables that we are creating. When it comes to your own projects that are using these classes, I would highly recommend exploring unit testing here.

Previewing Composables

Throughout the projects weâ€™ll be creating composable functions, each of which can be previewed directly within android studio using the @Preview annotation. Within the content of this coursebook we wonâ€™t be including the code for writing previews - each of the chapters is already quite large, so this is to keep the level of content down a bit. If youâ€™re looking to create previews then you can use the provided source code as a reference, or create your own preview functions using the @Preview annotation.

@Preview
@Composable
fun Preview_EmailInbox_Success() {
    MaterialTheme {
        EmailInbox(inboxState = InboxState(
            status = InboxStatus.SUCCESS
        ), handleEvent = { })
    }
}

Versioning

In the project level build.gradle file youâ€™ll find two version declarations - one for Kotlin and the other for compose. These are defined here so that they can be reused across the different modules within the project. If you are adding any additional related dependencies, be sure to use these version declarations to ease the updating of any versions in future.

ext {
    kotlin_version = '1.6.0'
    compose_version = '1.1.0-beta04'
}

Creating new project modules

When creating the modules for each project within this course, you can use the Android Studio wizard to help you do so - using this approach will configure most of the required compose dependencies for you. You can start this flow by right clicking on the base module of the project, selecting New followed by Module.

Youâ€™ll then be presented with the New Module wizard. From here youâ€™ll want to keep the Phone & Tablet option selected (this should be selected by default already). At this point you can give the module a corresponding name, clicking Next once you are done.

On the next step of the wizard youâ€™ll want to select the Empty Compose Activity option, as this will configure the project for use with Jetpack Compose.

Finally, the last step will give you the opportunity to name the activity being created. Before wrapping up this step youâ€™ll want to select Launcher Activity option so that the activity composing the UI is launched by default when you run the module.

Any other questions?

If you have any further questions on the projects from this course, please check the FAQ section on the Practical Jetpack Compose website to see if theyâ€™ve already been answered. Otherwise, please feel free to reach out at contact@compose.academy

Getting Started with Jetpack Compose

Throughout the projects in this book weâ€™ll be exploring the use of the approaches in more depth, but before we get started itâ€™ll be worthwhile for us to cover some introductory concepts for Jetpack Compose at a high level. While we do also touch on introductory level topics both in this chapter and throughout the projects, it would be worthwhile checking out the official getting started guides for Jetpack Compose if you are looking to cover these in more depth.

Building UI with Jetpack Compose

Jetpack Compose is a declarative UI framework. Previously the focus for android UI components has been done via the concept of the view system - this involves us manually manipulating the different view components by traversing the tree of widgets, allowing us to manipulate the internal state that these widgets are holding. While this has been the way to build Android UI for some time, it has always presented a range of complications. Needing to manually manipulate these widgets in such a way opens up room for many errors - not only from the developers side (such as forgetting to trigger a view update from one of many places), but also invalid states being created from asynchronous tasks triggering multiple updates on the same view reference.

Jetpack Compose allows us to define our UI via the use of what are known as Composable Functions. These functions take data that is used to represent the UI, followed by emitting the UI elements that are declared inside within the function.

@Composable
fun MyComposable(
	text: String
	handleButtonClick: () -> Unit
) {
	Button(
		onClick = handleButtonClick
	) {
		Text(text = text)
	}
}

Using the @Composable annotation declares this function as a composable annotation, stating that it will be used for the composition of our UI. We can see here that this function does not return anything, instead the body of the function is used to emit the UI for composition. In the case of this function, the Button and containing Text composables are being emitted into our UI. Using a range of the available compose APIs, UI components can be emitted to build the screens for our applications. Composable functions can contain a range of UI components, nesting composables as required to create different pieces of UI.

When defining composables, the composition of these can be manipulated via the use of Modifiers. These modifiers are used to apply constraints and styling to the composed content - many modifiers exist (we can also create our own!), weâ€™ll be exploring many that are available throughout the different projects.

@Composable
fun MyComposable(
	text: String
	handleButtonClick: () -> Unit
) {
	Text(
		modifier = Modifier.padding(16.dp),
		text = text
	)
}

To keep our composables reusable, itâ€™s good practice to allow modifiers to be passed into a composable function - this allows the calling point to have control over the composition within the current context. For example, we may wish to apply 8.dp padding in one scenario and 16.dp in another. We can then chain on any additional modifiers that are applicable to be defined inside of the composable function.

@Composable
fun MyComposable(
	modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
	text: String
	handleButtonClick: () -> Unit
) {
	Text(
		modifier = modifier.clickable {
			handleButtonClick()
		},
		text = text
	)
}

Recomposing UI Components

In the example above we can see that there are two arguments being provided to the MyComposable function, both of which are being used for the composition of the contained UI. At some point within our code we are going to be calling this MyComposable function, which will emit the contained UI - itâ€™s also likely at some point that this same calling point may be triggered again, but with a different value for the text value. When this happens, the MyComposable composable will be recomposed to reflect this change of data. Recomposition means that this changed piece of UI will be re-emitted to reflect this new information that the component is being composed with. This is made possible by us allowing the text argument to be provided to our MyComposable function, as we are passing data into the composable function that is being used to depict how that composable UI is being emitted. This is why it is good practice to pass state into our composable functions, allowing them to be kept reusable and dynamic for any changes to provided data.

When composables are composed for the first time, the initial composition will emit the UI components with the provided data. When this data changes and we reach this point of recomposition, the composable function is re-executed and the composables that have changed data will be re-emitted - this means that if there are composables that do not have changed information then they will not be executed again. The concept of recomposition is the only way to update the data being emitted for a composable, making this a very different approach to that of the Android View System.

Managing state

When it comes to the state that is represented within composables, this state needs to be able to trigger the automatic recomposition as and when it occurs. For recomposition to be triggered, state needs to be stored as composable state - if we want our composables to be recomposed when any information changes, we canâ€™t simply rely on primitive variables to manage the values that are provided to our composable functions. This is because the composable needs to be explicitly told that it needs to be recomposed. For examples sake, letâ€™s look at a composable that uses a variable for its composition - with this variable being updated when a Button is clicked.

@Composable
fun MyComposable() {
	var myTextValue = "Jetpack"
	Column {
    	Text(
        	text = myTextValue
    	)
      	Button(
           	onClick = {
				myTextValue = "Compose"
			}
       	) {
			Text(text = "Click me!")
		}
   }
}

While the initial composition will compose the value that we have assigned to the myTextValue variable, when this value is updated we will not see any recomposition occur - this is because we are not using composable state.

To be able to define state that will trigger recompositions, we need to utilise the expected State<T> type. While we can convert specific data streams to composable state (such livedata, flow, rxjava2), we can also build our own composable state to hold references to the various types of data that we want to manipulate. This can be done using MutableState<T> - this allows us to define a piece of composable state that can be observed by composables, triggering recompositions whenever the value of this state changes. 

var myTextValue = mutableStateOf("Jetpack")

While this defines a piece of composable state, we also need this to be stored into memory so that the values within these state objects are remembered across recompositions. To solve this we can utilise the remember composable, this wraps the content that we want to be stored during recompositions.

var myTextValue by remember { mutableStateOf("Jetpack") }

With this in place we can now slot this into our composable function, allowing our composable to trigger recompositions when its internal state changes.

@Composable
fun MyComposable() {
	var myTextValue by remember { mutableStateOf("Jetpack") }
	Column {
    	Text(
        	text = myTextValue
    	)
      	Button(
           	onClick = {
				myTextValue = "Compose"
			}
       	) {
			Text(text = "Click me!")
		}
   }
}

What weâ€™ve created here is a stateful composable - meaning that it holds state internally. While this is fine to do in applicable cases, it is also appropriate to create stateless composables - this is when state is passed into the composable function as opposed to the composable function holding any internal state. This approach allows us to create composables that are not only more reusable, but also lean into a Single Source of Truth (which weâ€™ll come onto in the next section of this chapter).

@Composable
fun MyComposable(myTextValue: String) {
	Column {
    	Text(
        	text = myTextValue
    	)
      	Button(
           	onClick = {
				...
			}
       	) {
			Text(text = "Click me!")
		}
   }
}

As well as state, composable functions may also need to handle some kind of event - in the example above we can see that we now have nothing handling the onClick lambda of the Button composable. In this situation, as well as passing state into our composable weâ€™re going to want to pass a lambda function that allows us to pass up events outside of our composable.

@Composable
fun MyComposable(
	myTextValue: String,
	handleClick: () -> Unit
) {
	Column {
    	Text(
        	text = myTextValue
    	)
      	Button(
           	onClick = {
				handleClick()
			}
       	) {
			Text(text = "Click me!")
		}
   }
}

Here, the handleClick lambda will be triggered which will be handled outside of our composable function. In this case itâ€™s likely that the implementation of that lambda will be used to update the state for the myTextValue reference, which would then trigger the recomposition of our MyComposable composable. This is also known as State Hoisting, which allows us to move the state management to the caller of the composable function, as opposed to within the composable itself - keeping our composable stateless.

Application State

Throughout the different projects in this course weâ€™re going to be working with what is known as State. Because this is a central topic to the development of these projects, itâ€™s important that we understand exactly what state is.

What is State?

State is a key concept when it comes to building applications. While this is not something that is specific to Jetpack Compose, itâ€™s going to be the concept that drives how our UI is presented to the user. But what exactly is state? The term itself is a pretty broad concept, but we can see this as any value that can be manipulated within the lifecycle of the app. The value of this state will then be used to render the content within each of the UI components for our app.

So for example, we could have various pieces of state that represent the content for the different UI components within a screen. These could be details such as:

  • The email address that has been input into a text field
  • Whether or not a button is currently enabled
  • The list of emails being displayed within an email inbox
  • The on/off status of a switch component

From these small examples, we can start to see how the different pieces of state can be used to manipulate the content of the UI components. When it comes to Jetpack Compose, this state is used for the composition of our UI - so as state changes, our UI will be recomposed to reflect the change of data.

In a lot of cases, youâ€™re likely to have multiple pieces of information that represent the state of a screen. With that in mind, itâ€™s important for us to think about how we can model this to allow our screens to be rendered from a source that represents this current state.

Single Source of Truth

When manipulating a User Interface via state, this state could be represented in a number of ways. For example, letâ€™s say we have several different UI components in our screen, each of which needs an individual piece of state to reflect its representation within our screen. When it comes to these different pieces of state, letâ€™s imagine that we had each of these as individual fields within a controller class (such as a ViewModel) - where each of these fields are being individually read/written by the UI.

With this arrangement we have multiple sources for our state - this means that we have state manipulations occurring in multiple places, rather than in an isolated location. The same also holds true for state reads, meaning that the both reading and writing is being carried out for multiple sources - even if these sources come from the same place, our screen is still going to be rendered from multiple streams of state. Alongside this, we can also never fully guarantee that our state is always going to be in sync. Because our UI is being rendered from multiple pieces of state, out-of-sync asynchronous tasks could easily result in results that arenâ€™t quite lined up. I terms of maintenance, it can also become difficult to maintain this kind of arrangement as we have no guarantee as to where our state is being both read and written from.

To resolve this issue we can shift towards what is known as a Single Source of Truth - this where our state comes from a single place, allowing us to ensure that the state we are rendering our UI for is

With this model we can already see the greater level of organisation that our state has. First up, our UI is no longer subscribing to multiple streams of data - there is a single state representation for our screen, meaning that the composition of our UI is happening from a single model as opposed to multiple pieces of individual data. When it comes to the writing of data, we also now know that this is all also happening at a single point - while multiple points in our UI can trigger operations in our controller (ViewModel), we are manipulating a single state representation as opposed to multiple streams.

Unidirectional Data Flow

At this point weâ€™ve touched on what state is and how it is used to manipulate the UI components of our application. We also mentioned how state can be manipulated so that our UI components can be recomposed to reflect these changes.

Often in applications we see a clear line of responsibility for the classes that exist within the flow of data. However, we often see there are many sources that are reading and writing data - for example, both the UI and controller (ViewModel) could be directly reading and writing application state. The issue with this is that the state of our application becomes far less predictable - as we have no guarantee where the recomposition was triggered from. This can not only result in unpredictable states for our users, but also make it hard for us to debug parts of our app.

To alleviate these concerns, we can lean into what is known as unidirectional data flow. This allows us to define a clear flow of operations between the UI and our state - we can see in the following diagram that data only flows in a single direction.

With unidirectional data flow, we not only know that all of the updates to our UI are coming from the same place (from the state), but also that our state is also being updated from a single place (the ViewModel). With this unidirectional flow of data we are able to enforce some predictability for the representation of our state, along with creating a form of state management that is easier for developers to maintain.

Throughout the projects in this book weâ€™ll be utilising the approaches that have been outline above. When it comes to working with State, weâ€™ll be encapsulating this inside of a Single Source of Truth, managing this state via the use of Unidirectional Data Flow.

Building a Settings Screen

In a lot of applications, there will be some aspects that will be configurable via a setting. For these cases, we often want to allow users to configure these various settings from within the application itself. A common approach to this is providing a settings screen that displays the available settings to the user, along with allowing a way to interact with or toggle the assigned value for a specific setting.

In this chapter, weâ€™re going to walk through an approach to building out a settings screen with Jetpack Compose. Weâ€™ll be creating the above settings screen, which covers a variety of setting options that you might be displayed inside of an application.

In this screen weâ€™ll need to handle four different settings items:

  • A setting that can be disabled / enabled using a Switch
  • A setting that can be turned on and off using a Checkbox
  • A setting that allows for one of the multiple choices to be selected, in the form of Radio Buttons
  • A setting item that can act as a link to a separate settings screen
  • A setting that can be used to trigger another kind of action (such as opening an external link)

With these, weâ€™ll cover most of the kinds of settings that are displayed inside of applications. This also gives us a chance to explore how we can represent the state of our settings as composable state, as well as recompose our UI whenever any of the settings values changes. With that, letâ€™s get started with building this settings screen!

Defining the Settings State

Within our settings screen, weâ€™re going to be dealing with a few different pieces of state that depict how the UI is going to be displayed to the user. This state will be used to compose our UI, allowing us to control how our composables look and behave. While weâ€™re showing a collection of settings in our screen, not all of them are dynamic - for example, some are static items that trigger some event when clicked. These static items will not need to be reflected in our state, as they will never need to be recomposed to reflect any state changes. However, there are some items in our settings that will need to be recomposed when the corresponding piece of state has changed.

  • Toggle Notifications: This setting shows the enabled state in the form of a switch. The state for this switch will be toggled between on/off when the user interacts with it.
  • Show Hints: This setting is similar to Toggle Notifications, except that the enabled state is represented in the form of a checkbox. This component will be toggled when the user interacts with it, managed by the state within our ViewModel.
  • Receive Marketing Emails: This setting allows the user to select an option from a radio group. The currently selected radio group will be a part of the state in our ViewModel, which will be updated when the user selects an option from the group
  • App Theme: This setting allows the user to select the current theme that should be used for the app. Again, because this setting can be changed, weâ€™ll need to keep a reference to it within our state

With the above set out, we can start to see that there are going to be several pieces of state that we need to hold. Letâ€™s start to take the above statements and build a class that will represent the state of our composable UI. Weâ€™ll start by creating a new class that will represent the state for our settings screen:

// SettingsState.kt
data class SettingsState()

Modelling the Notifications setting

To start us off, letâ€™s begin by taking a look at the Toggle Notifications setting. Because this is going to be represented by a Switch, the setting is going to be one of two values - on or off. This binary representation means that we can define this setting in the form of a boolean value - which weâ€™ll do in the form of notificationsEnabled:

data class SettingsState(
    val notificationsEnabled: Boolean = false
)

When notificationsEnabled is set as true, this will mean that the settings switch is ON and the notifications for our app are enabled. When the Switch is interacted with, we will update our notificationsEnabled value to represent false and the Switch will be recomposed to be marked as OFF.

Modelling the Hints setting

Moving onto the next settings item, Show Hints is also represented in a binary fashion - meaning that this setting is going to be handled in the same way as our notifications setting. We can now add a second value to our state object, a boolean in the form of a hintsEnabled variable.

data class SettingsState(
    val notificationsEnabled: Boolean = false,
    val hintsEnabled: Boolean = false
)

Modelling the Marketing setting

The next settings item, Receive Marketing Emails, allows the user to select an option for their email marketing settings. While weâ€™re going to initially be displaying two options on-screen, a boolean flag doesnâ€™t feel quite right for this setting item - as weâ€™re not working with a single toggleable component. So that we can have a typed representation of our marketing setting, weâ€™re going to create a new enum class that will be used to represent each of the possible options:

// MarketingOption.kt
enum class MarketingOption(val id: Int) {
    ALLOWED(0), NOT_ALLOWED(1)
}

Here we also assign an id value to each of our settings, that way we can use this within our UI to determine the currently selected item based on the position within our RadioGroup.

ðŸ’¡ Using an Enum class in this way allows us to have a strongly-typed representation of our MarketingOption values. This is not only safer for development, but it also makes it easier for developers to understand the represented value.

With this enum defined we can now add this to our SettingsState in the form of a MarketingOption. Weâ€™ll provide a default value here of MarketingOption.ALLOWED, which will be used as the initial state of this setting.

data class SettingsState(
    val notificationsEnabled: Boolean = false,
    val hintsEnabled: Boolean = false,
    val marketingOption: MarketingOption = MarketingOption.ALLOWED
)

Modelling the Theme setting

For the final dynamic settings item on our screen, we have the App Theme, which can be managed by the user. Similar to the marketing option setting, this is something that canâ€™t be handled by a boolean representation. Weâ€™re going to do a similar thing for this setting item and create a new enum class that will be used to represent the different theme options that are available for our app:

// Theme.kt
enum class Theme {
    LIGHT,
    DARK, 
    SYSTEM
}

At this point, we have the representation of our theme in the form of an enum, which can be used within our settings UI to determine the options available to the user. However, these Enum values are not in the form of user-friendly (or translatable) labels. So that we have some user-friendly values to display within our UI weâ€™re going to need to start by adding some strings to our module resources:

<string name="theme_light">Light</string>
<string name="theme_dark">Dark</string>
<string name="theme_system">System</string>

ðŸ’¡ While these strings could be hardcoded inside of the enum, string resources allow for localisation of text as well as keeping things nice and tidy!

We can then go ahead and modify our Theme enum so that each theme requires a label to be provided for it:

enum class Theme(@StringRes val label: Int)

Then, by using the string resources that we previously defined, we can state each of the theme labels that are to be used for the Theme types that we have defined:

enum class Theme(@StringRes val label: Int) {
    LIGHT(R.string.theme_light), 
    DARK(R.string.theme_dark), 
    SYSTEM(R.string.theme_system)
}

Now when we reference the Theme to be selected by the user, we also have access to a user-friendly label that can be displayed within the UI. With this defined we can go ahead and plug this last piece of the state into our SettingsState class. Weâ€™ll provide a default value here of SYSTEM, which will be overridden when the user selects a value.

data class SettingsState(
    val notificationsEnabled: Boolean = false,
    val hintsEnabled: Boolean = false,
    val marketingSettingsOption: Int = 0,
    val themeOption: Theme = Theme.SYSTEM
)

With all of the above in place, we now have a state reference for our Settings UI. This state class will also act as a single source of truth for our UI - this is because all of these values are stored within the same class, and they will always be provided as a single group to the UI.

Weâ€™ve only included some of the settings for our screen in this state reference because not all of our settings are dynamic. Because the other settings values display static content and do not change in any way (e.g from user interaction), we donâ€™t need to keep a reference to them within our SettingsState. Those static settings will be composed with the defined content in the composable function, never being recomposed with a change of content.

For the other settings (the ones that weâ€™ve defined within our state class), these are dynamic settings that change with user interaction. This is because these are settings that the user can modify to change the behaviour of the app. In a real-world scenario, these would be provided by some form of cache (such as preferences or data store), but when propagated to the UI layer they would still need to be declared in a state object to be used by our UI - so the only difference here is that weâ€™re not basing our state off of persisted data.

At this point, weâ€™re all set to start thinking about the ViewModel class that will be used to orchestrate this data to our UI.

Creating the Settings ViewModel

Now that weâ€™ve defined the contracts for supported settings in our application, we need to tackle the next step for settings - persisting and observing the settings values. Now, in real-world cases we would use Android Preferences, Data Store or a Database - but for our settings screen, weâ€™re going to persist the settings values within a view model. This is so that we can focus more on building the composable UI for our screen instead of the persistence of data which is very unrelated to Jetpack Compose! For this, weâ€™re going to use a ViewModel with a data stream to hold our settings, which can then be observed to compose our UI. So before we can get started here, weâ€™re going to add a new dependency to our project that will give us access to the Android Lifecycle ViewModel class:

implementation "androidx.lifecycle:lifecycle-viewmodel-compose:2.4.0"

ðŸ’¡ You arenâ€™t required to use a ViewModel when working with compose. For the sake of these exercises, it helps us to keep things simple and follow an approach that many developers are familiar with.

Weâ€™ll begin by creating a new ViewModel, called SettingsViewModel:

// SettingsViewModel.kt
class SettingsViewModel : ViewModel()

This ViewModel is going to need to hold a reference to the state of our screen. For this weâ€™re going to utilise StateFlow - this allows us to create a state-holder observable flow that will emit the default state we provide to it, along with any updates that occur during its lifetime. Here weâ€™ll create a new MutableStateFlow instance, providing a reference to our SettingsState class as the default value for our StateFlow:

class SettingsViewModel : ViewModel() {
    val uiState = MutableStateFlow(SettingsState())
}

With our state in place, we now want to provide some functions which can be called by external classes in-order to update our state. These are going to be quite small and simple functions that will update the value for the corresponding setting.

Setting the Notifications setting

Weâ€™ll start by creating the function to toggle the Notification Enabled settings:

fun toggleNotificationSettings() { }

For this setting, we are toggling the status between on and off (true and false), and because a switch simply toggles between these two states weâ€™re going to want to take the existing value within our state and flip it to the opposite. Once we have this value, weâ€™re going to use the copy() function on our state reference and replace the existing value for notificationsEnabled using the opposite of the value that is currently present.

fun toggleNotificationSettings() {
    uiState.value = uiState.value.copy(notificationsEnabled = !uiState.value.notificationsEnabled)
}

ðŸ’¡ The copy function in Kotlin copies the existing class reference, replacing any values that have been provided as arguments to the function.

We update the value of our StateFlow by setting its value property to the SettingsState reference that weâ€™ve copied and updated. This means that when our toggleNotificationSettings is called, our state will be updated with the notificationsEnabled flag toggled, followed by this updated state being emitted through our StateFlow reference.

Setting the Hints setting

Moving onto the next setting that we need to be able to change, the Show Hints setting has exactly the same behaviour as Notification Enabled. Weâ€™ll create a new toggle function for our hints setting and implement the same logic as the previous function, except this time updating the hintsEnabled value:

fun toggleHintSettings() {
    uiState.value = uiState.value.copy(hintsEnabled = !uiState.value.hintsEnabled)
}

Similar to before, now when we call the toggleHintSettings, our state will be updated to reflect the change of the hintsEnabled value and then this state will be emitted through our StateFlow reference.

Setting the Marketing Option setting

For our next function, weâ€™re going to implement the ability to set the value for the Marketing Options setting. We previously defined a MarketingOption enum, which our SettingsState class uses to keep a reference to the currently selected option. To be able to update this state, weâ€™re going to need to create a new function that allows for a MarketingOption reference to be provided to it:

fun setMarketingSettings(option: MarketingOption) { 

}

This function will be called from the external class, providing the option that has been selected in the UI so that the state can be updated. Inside of this function, weâ€™re going again to utilise the copy function on our state reference, providing an override for the marketingOption value in the form of the option argument that has been provided to our function.

fun setMarketingSettings(option: MarketingOption) {
    uiState.value = uiState.value.copy(
		marketingOption = option)
}

Once updated, our new state reference will be emitted and our UI can be recomposed to reflect the newly selected MarketingOption.

Setting the selected Theme setting

While the App Theme setting is a slightly different UI component, the approach to updating the setting is going to be the same as what we just implemented for the Marketing Options setting. We need to create a new function that takes the Theme instance that we wish to be reflected in our state, and then use this to override the current themeOption value in our state object.

fun setTheme(theme: Theme) {
	uiState.value = uiState.value.copy(themeOption = theme)
}

When emitted, our UI can be recomposed to reflect this change of state for the selected App Theme.

In this small amount of work, weâ€™ve created a new ViewModel that is holding a reference for the state of our UI, in the form of the SettingsState class. Whenever this state reference is updated, it is emitted from our StateFlow instance so that many observers can be aware of updates that need to be reflected within our UI. So that we can see this in action, letâ€™s move on and start building out the composes to represent the UI for our settings screen.

Creating the Settings UI

Now that we have all of the required logic in place to read and write the settings values for our application, we can move onto the main part of this sample project - displaying the UI for our settings using Jetpack Compose! Before we get started here weâ€™re going to need to go ahead and add a couple of dependencies to our project.

// provides access to the `ComponentActivity` class that can be used to compose UI components
implementation 'androidx.activity:activity-compose:1.4.0'

// provide functionality for accessing viewmodels within composable functions
implementation "androidx.lifecycle:lifecycle-viewmodel-compose:2.4.0"

// foundational classes from the Compose APIs
implementation 
	"androidx.compose.foundation:foundation:$compose_version"

// UI components from the Compose APIs
implementation "androidx.compose.ui:ui:$compose_version"

// Material Design components from the Compose APIs
implementation 
	"androidx.compose.material:material:$compose_version"

// Tooling functionality for Composables, such as previews
implementation "androidx.compose.ui:ui-tooling-preview:$compose_version"
debugImplementation "androidx.compose.ui:ui-tooling:$compose_version"

With these dependencies in place weâ€™re going to begin by building a root composable function, Settings, which will be used to house all of our Composable UI for the Settings screen. For this, weâ€™ll create a new Kotlin file called Settings.kt (to keep our composables nicely organised), followed by creating a new composable function, Settings:

// Settings.kt
@Composable
fun Settings() {

}

This composable is going to be the entry point to our Settings feature - so we donâ€™t want this function to have to take any arguments. The point of composition will be able to simply compose this function, and this composable itself will handle everything else such as the ViewModel and state. While you wonâ€™t see anything visual just yet, youâ€™ll want to compose this Settings composable within the setContent block of the activity that was created through the project wizard. Then as we build out the project, weâ€™ll be able to visualise the Settings when running the project.

Within this root level composable, for any composition that takes place weâ€™re going to want to apply our application theming, so weâ€™ll add a MaterialTheme composable declaration here.

@Composable
fun Settings() {
	MaterialTheme {

	}
}

ðŸ’¡Wrapping your composable hierarchy in a theme allows all components to be consistently styled. In most cases, this can happen at the highest point of composition - even within the setContent function of the parent activity that is composing the UI.

When it comes to the composition of our settings UI, weâ€™re going to need access to the state that we previously configured within our ViewModel. So that we can access this information, weâ€™re going to need to obtain an instance to this ViewModel inside of our composable. Here weâ€™ll use the viewModel function from the lifecycle-viewmodel-compose package. This will retrieve an instance of the desired ViewModel, creating one if it does not currently exist. Weâ€™ll define this desired type to be SettingsViewModel, which will give us access to this ViewModel from within our composable.

@Composable
fun Settings() {
	val viewModel: SettingsViewModel = viewModel()

	MaterialTheme {

	}
}

Weâ€™re then going to need to access this state within the composition of our UI, so weâ€™re going to want to access the uiState property that weâ€™ve defined within our ViewModel. With access to this state, weâ€™ll use collectAsState() to collect the emissions of our StateFlow reference from our ViewModel as composable state. This means that whenever any of the values within the state reference are changed, these events will be emitted to this observation, which will trigger the recomposition of our UI once things are plugged in.

@Composable
fun Settings() {
	val viewModel: SettingsViewModel = viewModel()

	MaterialTheme {
		val state = viewModel.uiState.collectAsState().value
	}
}

When it comes to this state, this is configured to be a Single Source of Truth - this allows us to ensure that our UI is always configured from the same source of data, increasing the predictability of the represented state within our UI. In the context of our settings screen, our state is represented by a list of Setting references. This state will need to be passed into a composable function so that the UI can be composed from it. For this, weâ€™ll start by defining a new Composable function called SettingsList that will take a state reference in the form of our Settings state. When defining this function, weâ€™ll allow a Modifier to be passed as an optional argument - this allows the parent composable to have some control over the composition of its child.

@Composable
fun SettingsList(
	modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
	state: SettingsState
)

ðŸ’¡ Itâ€™s good practice to allow a modifier to be passed into a composable, this means that the parent who is composing the child can control the composition to some extent. This also helps to keep your composable functions re-usable across your UI.

In this function, we now need to think about composing the different components that make up the Settings UI that we saw at the start of this chapter. To get a better understanding of the work involved here, weâ€™re going to need to break that down into a Composable representation.

From this structure, we can see that our composable hierarchy consists of:

  • A parent column to vertically display all of the child components
  • A Top App Bar to represent the app bar of the screen
  • Individual Row composables that represent each of the setting items
  • A collection of Divider and Spacer composables to create some separation between setting items

With the above in mind we can start building out our Composable UI to represent our settings screen. Weâ€™re going to build a collection of composable functions, all of which can be plugged together to create our entire screen.

Composing the Scrollable Settings Container

Weâ€™ll begin at the foundations of our composable, being the parent Column that will hold the entire settings UI.

// SettingsList.kt
@Composable
fun SettingsList(
	modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
	state: SettingsState
)

Weâ€™ll define a new reference to a Column composable here, as a Column is used to stack children composables in a vertical format. We can see from the diagram above that this is how the child composables are organized within the parent container.

@Composable
fun SettingsList(
	modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
	state: SettingsState
) {
	Column(modifier = modifier) {

	}
}

ðŸ’¡ When passing in a Modifier via the composable function, this should always be applied at the highest point within our composable (such as the parent within that child).

Now that we have the Column in place, weâ€™re going to make a small tweak to better support the different screens that our app might be used on. In our example, we only show several settings items on screen - weâ€™ll likely either want to launch with more configurable settings options for the user or support more settings items over time. As this list might grow a bit, likely, smaller screens might not get the best experience when it comes to our settings, with it even being the case that some items might not be accessible and appear off-screen. With this in mind, weâ€™re going to enable scrolling on our Column using the vertical scroll modifier. This modifier requires us to pass a reference to a ScrollState - this state class is used to configure and manage the state of the scrolling for our composable. We can utilise the rememberScrollState function to create and remember this for us, allowing the scroll state to be persisted across recompositions.

// SettingsList.kt
@Composable
fun SettingsList(
	modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
	state: SettingsState
) {
	Column(
  		modifier = modifier.verticalScroll(
      		rememberScrollState()
  		)
	) {

	}
}

ðŸ’¡ There are many remember functions in the jetpack compose APIs. These are all used to create and remember the desired class, allowing you to avoid redefining this logic every time you are looking to implement such behaviour in your project.

Now, if our settings list is too large vertically for some screens, scrolling will be enabled so that the list is accessible to all of our users.

Composing the Top App Bar

With the parent container composable in place, we can start to think about adding children to be composed inside of it. Weâ€™ll start here by composing an app bar at the top of our column, which will be used to create a header for our screen and display a title to the user. Weâ€™ll declare this as the first child within the content of the column composable:

// SettingsList.kt
Column(
  modifier = modifier.verticalScroll(
      rememberScrollState()
  )
) {
  TopAppBar {
  
  }
}

ðŸ’¡ The TopAppBar is a material component that allows you to display information and actions within the context of the current screen.

At this point, the TopAppBar will be displayed as an empty area in our screen - thatâ€™s because we havenâ€™t added any content to the composable. Here weâ€™re going to want to add an Up icon (that allows the user to go up to the previous screen), along with a title that signifies the current screen that the user is on. Weâ€™re going to provide these using the content argument of the TopAppBar. Internally, the content argument houses any content that we provide to it inside of a Row composable, so these will automatically be laid out next to each other on the horizontal axis.

Composing the navigation icon

Weâ€™ll start here by declaring an Icon composable to display the Up icon at the start of our TopAppBar

TopAppBar {
	Icon()
}

This wonâ€™t compile as it is, because weâ€™re missing two required arguments of the Icon composable. These are the image to be displayed, along with the content description that describes that image. Weâ€™ll go ahead and start by utilising the imageVector argument, passing one of the provided Icons from the compose packages, Icons.Default.ArrowBack:

Icon(
	imageVector = Icons.Default.ArrowBack
)

We also need to add a content description for this icon, so that the composable is accessible to those utilising talkback. Weâ€™ll start by adding new string resources to the strings.xml file within our application res directory. This resource will describe what the icon is used for, which in this case it will be describing that the icon is used to go back to the previous screen:

<string name="cd_go_back">
	Go back to previous screen
</string>

With this resource in place, we can go ahead and provide the string to the contentDescription argument of the Icon composable. To provide this as a string we need to use the stringResource composable function, which takes the ID of the resource that we just defined and retrieves the string value for it. The result of this operation will then be used as the content description for our icon.

Icon(
	imageVector = Icons.Default.ArrowBack,
	contentDescription = stringResource(id = R.string.cd_go_back)
)

ðŸ’¡ Providing a content description for supporting composables helps to ensure that these remain accessible for all users of our app. This description will be used by the screenreader to communicate the meaning of the visual element that is being composed.

With this in place we now have a TopAppBar that is displaying our Up icon:

Composing the Title

So that itâ€™s clear what screen the user is currently on, weâ€™re going to add a title to our TopAppBar. This is again done by adding a composable to the content area of the TopAppBar, which weâ€™ll do in the form of a Text composable. 

Row {
	Icon(
		imageVector = Icons.Default.ArrowBack,
		contentDescription = stringResource(id = R.string.cd_go_back)
    )
    Text(
        text = ...
   	)
}

ðŸ’¡ The ordering of composition within a container depicts how those children will be composed. In the case of this Row, the Icon will be composed first, followed by the Text to the end of it.

To satisfy the requirements of the Text composable, weâ€™ll need to add another string to our application resources. Weâ€™ll head on back over to the strings.xml file within the module for this project and add the following string declaration:

<string name="title_settings">Settings</string>

With this in place we can then again use the stringResource composable function to assign a string reference to our Text composable:

Row {
	Icon(
		imageVector = Icons.Default.ArrowBack,
		contentDescription = stringResource(id = R.string.cd_go_back)
    )
    Text(
        text = stringResource(id = R.string.title_settings)
   	)
}

At this point, we can now see our Up icon and Settings title at the top of our UI.

Adjusting the size of the Title

As we can see, the title is a little small within the app bar. Weâ€™re going to adjust the size of this title by overriding the fontSize that is being used for the Text composable. Here weâ€™ll pass in a value of 18sp, which will give our title a more prominent place in the app bar.

Icon(
	imageVector = Icons.Default.ArrowBack,
	contentDescription = stringResource(id = R.string.cd_go_back)
)
Text(
	text = stringResource(id = R.string.title_settings),
	fontSize = 18.sp
)

ðŸ’¡ The sp dimension are scalable pixels. Itâ€™s important to use sp for any values that are related to font sizes, as this ensures that text is scaled based on the density of the device and the preferences the user has set for font size.

With this in place, we can see that the title of our Settings screen is now much more presentable when being composed:

Creating some visual space between composables

To make another tweak here, weâ€™ll go ahead and utilise the Spacer composable to create some visible space between the two components. The Spacer can be seen as a blank composable area, whose size we can define via the use of modifiers. In this case, we are only creating space on the horizontal axis, so weâ€™ll go ahead and use the width modifier to create horizontal space between the Icon and Text composables.

Icon(
	imageVector = Icons.Default.ArrowBack,
	contentDescription = stringResource(id = R.string.cd_go_back)
)
Spacer(modifier = Modifier.width(16.dp))
Text(
	text = stringResource(id = R.string.title_settings),
	fontSize = 18.sp
)

With that in place, our Icon and Text composables now have a good amount of visual spacing between one another.

Styling the Top App Bar

By default, the TopAppBar is currently using the primarySurface color from the theme of our application. While a lot of applications use this to create a bold app bar at the top of the screen, weâ€™re going to modify the theming of our TopAppBar by overriding some of the colors that are used for it. Here weâ€™re going to override the background color of our TopAppbarvia the use of the backgroundColor attribute. Weâ€™ll again use the MaterialTheme class here to use a color from our theme, this time in the form of the surface.

TopAppBar(
	backgroundColor = MaterialTheme.colors.surface
)

ðŸ’¡ It is possible to use direct Color references when overriding color values, such as Color.White. However, using Theme references helps to ensure that your theming is compatible with light + dark modes, as well as making it easier to maintain theming in your application.

Applying content padding to the app bar

While weâ€™re here, weâ€™re also going to apply some padding to the start of our TopAppBar. Currently, the Up icon is pressed right against the edge of the container, so we can utilise the contentPadding argument to provide padding values to be applied to the content area.

TopAppBar(
	backgroundColor = MaterialTheme.colors.surface,
	contentPadding = PaddingValues(start = 12.dp)
)

ðŸ’¡ Under the hood, the PaddingValues class applies padding in the same way that you would do using the Padding modifier.

Now our TopAppBar has some additional spacing for the content, as well as appearing quite different visually:

Styling the app bar content

Now that weâ€™ve changed the styling of the TopAppBar, we can see that the content is no longer completely visible. This is because the content of the top app bar is themed for the default background color of the TopAppBar. To fix this, weâ€™ll need to override the color of the content inside of the TopAppBar. This can be done by overriding each of the foreground colors in the child composables. Weâ€™ll start by applying a color to the Text composable, which we can use the onSurface color for:

Text(
	text = stringResource(id = R.string.title_settings),
	color = MaterialTheme.colors.onSurface,
    fontSize = 18.sp
)

Next, weâ€™ll need to do the same thing for our Icon composable, this will be done in the form of the tint argument - again passing the onSurface color from our application theme.

Icon(
	tint = MaterialTheme.colors.onSurface,
	imageVector = Icons.Default.ArrowBack,
	contentDescription = stringResource(
		id = R.string.cd_go_back)
)

With this in place we now have a completed TopAppBar composable that should look something like the following:

TopAppBar(
	backgroundColor = MaterialTheme.colors.surface,
    contentPadding = PaddingValues(start = 12.dp)
) {
	Icon(
  	 	tint = MaterialTheme.colors.onSurface,
        imageVector = Icons.Default.ArrowBack,
        contentDescription = stringResource(
			id = R.string.cd_go_back)
    )
	Spacer(modifier = Modifier.width(16.dp))
   	Text(
		color = MaterialTheme.colors.onSurface,
		text = stringResource(id = R.string.title_settings),
		fontSize = 18.sp
	)
}

Within our composable preview we will now be able to see a styled TopAppBar with the composable content displayed inside of it:

Building the Notifications Setting Item

With the TopAppBar defined, we can now start thinking about each of the settings items that are going to make up our settings screen.

Creating the notifications setting composable

First off, weâ€™re going to start by creating the Enable Notifications setting item. This setting item allows the user to toggle notifications on and off, using a switch component to toggle this setting. Weâ€™ll start here by creating a new composable function.

// NotificationSettings.kt
@Composable
fun NotificationSettings(
	modifier: Modifier = Modifier
)

With this composable function defined, we can start to build out the settings items for notifications. Weâ€™re going to need to start by adding a parent level composable that will be used to hold the body of our settings item. For this, weâ€™ll use a Surface composable.

@Composable
fun NotificationSettings(
	modifier: Modifier = Modifier
) {
    Surface {
       
    }
}

The Surface composable will compose the provided body inside of a Box composable. It will also theme itself use the surface color from the application theme, which is what we want to be applied to our settings item in terms of styling.

ðŸ’¡ Using the Surface composable saves us from using a Box composable and applying a collection of styling ourselves, when this component already exists to do it for us.

So that the parent that is composing this NotificationSettings can apply some constraints, weâ€™re going to assign the provided Modifier as the modifier argument for our Surface composable.

@Composable
fun NotificationSettings(
	modifier: Modifier = Modifier
) {
    Surface(
        modifier = modifier
    ) {
       
    }
}

ðŸ’¡ Remember, it is the expected behaviour to apply the provided modifier to the highest-level composable within a composable function.

At this point, we now have a surface that can be interacted with by the user to update the value for the given setting item. However, we donâ€™t have any real visuals configured for this composable yet. For this setting item, weâ€™re going to want to show a label along with a switch, these will be displayed next to each other in a horizontal format. To display composables in such a way we can utilise the Row composable, which is used to stack composables horizontally. Weâ€™ll now compose a Row inside of our previously defined Surface composable:

Surface(
        modifier = modifier
) {
	Row {
	
	}
}

Composing the Label

With this Row in place, we now have a layout container that is added and configured to hold the components that make up our setting item. We can now go ahead and add these composables to our Row, so weâ€™ll start here by adding a Text composable to display the label for our setting item.

Surface(
        modifier = modifier
) {
	Row {
		Text(text = ...)
	}
}

For the Text composable weâ€™re required to add a value for the text argument. To satisfy this argument weâ€™re going to have this passed into our NotificationSettings function so that the title can be provided by the parent composable:

@Composable
fun NotificationSettings(
	modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
	title: String
)

ðŸ’¡ Having the title passed into our composable means that this switch setting item can be reused for other settings in future, rather than constraining it to that of the Notification Settings.

We can then use this string reference to apply a value to the required argument within the Text composable:

Row {
	Text(text = title)
}

At this point, youâ€™ll be able to see this text value composed within the declared Surface composable.

Composing the Switch

Now that we have the label in place, we can go ahead and add the key part of our settings item - the switch that will be used to toggle the setting on and off. For this weâ€™ll go ahead and use the Switch composable:

Row {
	Text(text = title)
	Switch(
        checked = ...,
        onCheckedChange = ...
    )
}

The Switch composable is from the Compose Material APIs and allows us to display a switch that can be used to toggle between two values, on and off. There are two required arguments when using the Switch composable, these are:

  • checked: states whether or not the Switch is currently on or off
  • onCheckedChange: a callback that provides the next value of the Switch when the toggle action is triggered

To keep our composable Switch stateless, weâ€™re going to pass these two values into our composable function. checked will be in the form of a boolean and will depict whether the Switch is currently checked, while the onCheckedChanged is a lambda that can be triggered to tell the parent composable that the setting value needs to be toggled.

@Composable
fun NotificationSettings(
	modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
	title: String,
    checked: Boolean,
    onCheckedChanged: (checked: Boolean) -> Unit
)

ðŸ’¡ Stateless refers to the fact that the composable has state passed into it, as opposed to having the composable manage the state itself. This allows us to adhere to the concept of a single source of truth.

We can keep our composable stateless because we are already storing the state of our screen inside of our SettingsState class within our ViewModel. For this reason our composable doesnâ€™t need to hold or manage its state, it can simply delegate that to the parent composable.

With those in place, we can then assign these two values to our Switch composable:

Row {
	Text(text = title)
	Switch(
        checked = checked,
        onCheckedChange = onCheckedChanged
    )
}

With this in place, we should now be able to view this addition and see the Text and Switch composables displayed alongside one another.

Improving the visual spacing

In terms of spacing and alignment, things donâ€™t look quite right here. While our setting row fills the maximum available width, our content currently looks like itâ€™s not making use of all the available space. Weâ€™re going to fix this by forcing our Text composable to utilise the redundant width on the screen, which weâ€™ll do using the weight modifier.

Row {
	Text(text = title, modifier = Modifier.weight(1f))
	Switch(
        checked = checked,
        onCheckedChange = onCheckedChanged
    )
}

The weight modifier allows us to apply weighting to our composable - this weights the composable relative to other composables within the Row. Because we havenâ€™t manually applied weighting to the Switch, this will force the Text to use up all of the remaining space in the Row.

Aligning the child composables

You might have noticed that the child composables arenâ€™t quite aligned on the vertical axis. We can fix this by using the verticalAlignment argument for the Row composable - this will align the content on the vertical axis using the provided Alignment value.

Row(
	verticalAlignment = Alignment.CenterVertically
) {
	Text(text = title, modifier = Modifier.weight(1f))
	Switch(
        checked = checked,
        onCheckedChange = onCheckedChanged
    )
}

With this applied, we can see that the content of our Row is now aligned in the center vertically.

Padding the setting item content

We can still improve things visually, especially in terms of spacing for our Row. Here weâ€™ll use the padding modifier to apply a padding value to the horizontal edges of the content area. This will create spacing at both the start and end of the Row composable, stopping the content from pressing against the edges.

Row(
	modifier = Modifier.padding(horizontal = 16.dp),
	verticalAlignment = Alignment.CenterVertically
) {
	Text(text = title, modifier = Modifier.weight(1f))
	Switch(
        checked = checked,
        onCheckedChange = onCheckedChanged
    )
}

We can see that with this padding in place, the composable has a nicer presentation away from the edges of the screen.

Improving the Switch Row Accessibility

At this point, we havenâ€™t plugged this into our UI yet but we do have a functional composable. Weâ€™re going to make some final tweaks before we go ahead with hooking it up in the form of improving the accessibility for our Switch row.

Currently, if you interact with the setting row via talkback on your device, each of the Text and Switch composables would focus on individually. While interaction is possible here, this adds a little bit of friction when navigating via talkback as the user might need to end up navigating through double the number of components on the screen.

Weâ€™re going to improve this by propagating the toggle functionality up to the setting Row, instead of having the Switch handle this. Weâ€™ll need to start by removing the onCheckedChange listener from our Switch composable.

Row(
	modifier = Modifier
		.padding(horizontal = 16.dp),
	verticalAlignment = Alignment.CenterVertically
) {
	Text(text = title, modifier = Modifier.weight(1f))
	Switch(
        checked = checked,
        onCheckedChange = null
    )
}

Next, we can utilise the toggleable modifier, allowing our Row to become a toggle-able component. The toggle modifier requires a couple of different arguments to be set:

  • value: the current value of toggle state. This will be a boolean value to represent whether the component is currently on or off.
  • onValueChange: this is the lambda that will be triggered when the component is toggled, allowing us to update our state accordingly.
  • role: the role of the toggle-able component (e.g switch, checkbox). This is used by the system accessibility services to describe elements or perform customisations.

Weâ€™ll populate these using the values that we currently have within our composable function. For the value and onValueChange arguments, we can simply switch out the values that we had assigned to our Switch. For the role weâ€™re going to want to apply the Role.Switch value, as our Row is going to represent the functionality of a Switch.

toggleable(
	value = checked,
	onValueChange = onCheckedChanged,
	role = Role.Switch
)

We can then take these values and apply them to our Row composable:

Row(
	modifier = Modifier
		.toggleable(
        	value = checked,
            onValueChange = onCheckedChanged,
            role = Role.Switch
        )
		.padding(horizontal = 16.dp),
	verticalAlignment = Alignment.CenterVertically
) {
	Text(text = title, modifier = Modifier.weight(1f))
	Switch(
        checked = checked,
        onCheckedChange = null
    )
}

With this in place, weâ€™ll now be able to see that the accessibility services recognise our Row as an individually toggle-able component, as opposed to each composable being an individually focusable item.

With the above in place, we now have a completed composable function in the form of NotificationSettings.

@Composable
fun NotificationSettings(
	modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    title: String,
    checked: Boolean,
    onCheckedChanged: (checked: Boolean) -> Unit
) {
    Surface(
        modifier = modifier
    ) {
        Row(
            modifier = Modifier
                .toggleable(
                    value = checked,
                    onValueChange = onCheckedChanged,
                    role = Role.Switch
                )
                .padding(horizontal = 16.dp),
            verticalAlignment = Alignment.CenterVertically
        ) {
            Text(text = title, modifier = Modifier.weight(1f))
            Switch(
                checked = checked,
                onCheckedChange = null
            )
        }
    }
}

When it comes to the accessibility of our notification setting, we can go one step further here by utilising the stateDescription semantic. This semantic allows us to control the description used by the accessibility services when describing the current state of the composable. In the context of our notification settings we are using a Switch which will have an on or off state - this will be read by the accessibility service as these values. We can improve things here by actually describing what that state represents - which is whether the notifications are currently enabled or disabled. For example, hearing the following string resources being read gives the user much more context on the current state of the component.

<string name="cd_notifications_enabled">
	Notifications Enabled
</string>
<string name="cd_notifications_disabled">
	Notifications Disabled
</string>

Within our NotificationSettings composable we can then use these strings resources to build a string reference based on the current checked flag that is provided to the composable function.

val notificationsEnabledState = if (checked) {
	stringResource(id = R.string.cd_notifications_enabled)
} else stringResource(id = R.string.cd_notifications_disabled)

Finally, we can assign this to the semantics of our composable using the semantics modifier.

Row(
	modifier = Modifier
		.toggleable(
        	value = checked,
            onValueChange = onCheckedChanged,
            role = Role.Switch
		)
        .semantics {
        	stateDescription = notificationsEnabledState
        }
        .padding(horizontal = 16.dp),
    verticalAlignment = Alignment.CenterVertically
)

With this in place, the accessibility services will now use this string resource to describe the current state of our composable. This provides a much greater level of context for the current state of the notifications setting.

Composing the notifications setting

At this point we have our composable function created, but itâ€™s not yet being composed within our UI. For this, weâ€™re going to hop on back over to our parent composable and compose the NotificationSettings composable. When composing this weâ€™re going to utilise the modifier argument to enforce the composable to fill the maximum width that is available to it - which weâ€™ll do so using the fillMaxWidth modifier.

MaterialTheme {
	Column {
		TopAppBar()
		NotificationSettings(
			modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth())
	}
}

While weâ€™re providing the modifier here, weâ€™re still missing the required arguments that we set up for the composable function. These are the title string, checked flag and onCheckedChanged lambda.

So that we can provide the title to our composable function, weâ€™re going to need to add a new string resource to our strings.xml file. This will be the string that we display within the settings row for our Enable Notifications setting.

<string name="setting_enable_notifications">
	Enable Notifications
</string>

We can then utilise the stringResource composable function to retrieve the string for our declared resource ID, providing this to our composable function for the title argument.

NotificationSettings(
	modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
	title = stringResource(id = R.string.setting_enable_notifications)
)

For the checked flag weâ€™re going to need to provide the current state for our notifications enabled setting. This is being stored in the SettingsState class from which is being accessed through our ViewModel. For this we can reference the state reference that is being passed into our composable function, accessing the notificationsEnabled from this and passing this for the checked flag.

NotificationSettings(
	modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
	title = stringResource(
		id = R.string.setting_enable_notifications),
	checked = state.notificationsEnabled
)

Finally, we need to provide the callback that will be triggered when the enabled notification setting is toggled between on and off. We previously created a function in our ViewModel, toggleNotificationSettings, that matches the structure of the lambda, so we can pass this directly to our composable function.

NotificationSettings(
	modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
	title = stringResource(
		id = R.string.setting_enable_notifications),
	checked = state.notificationsEnabled,
	onCheckedChanged = viewModel::toggleNotificationSettings
)

With those in place, our NotificationSettings composable is fully satisfied. Weâ€™ll wrap this up by adding a Divider composable to create some visual separation after our NotificationSettings composable.

MaterialTheme {
	Column {
		TopAppBar()
		NotificationSettings(
			title = stringResource(
				id = R.string.setting_enable_notifications),
			checked = state.notificationsEnabled,
			onCheckedChanged = viewModel::toggleNotificationSettings
		)
		Divider()
	}
}

We now have a NotificationSettings composable that allows the user to toggle between the on and off state for the notification setting. When this is toggled, we can see that our state is changed and the UI is recomposed to reflect this.

Reusing our Setting Item

The rest of the setting items that we create in this screen are going to be very similar visually to our Enable Notifications setting, with the key difference being the content within the composable. For this reason, weâ€™re going to create a common composable function that can be reused across each of our setting types. This allows us to:

  • Enforce similar constraints for each setting item. This allows us to ensure that the different constraints (such as height and widths) are represented equally
  • Enforce a similar visual representation through the use of a Surface
