While weâ€™re only reusing a small amount of code here, this allows us to learn how to create reusable components for our projects. Weâ€™ll start here by creating a new composable function called SettingItem. 

// SettingItem.kt
@Composable
fun SettingItem(
	modifier: Modifier = Modifier
)

Weâ€™ll add some body for our composable by copying over what we had previously defined as the body of our Enable Notifications setting. This consisted of a Surface composable that utilised the provided modifier to have some constraints applied to it.

@Composable
fun SettingItem(
	modifier: Modifier = Modifier
) {
    Surface(
        modifier = modifier
    ) {
    
	}
}

When it comes to most of our settings items, weâ€™re going to want them to all use the same height - unless they need to expand into a larger vertical area. So that can enforce some form of minimum height, weâ€™re going to go ahead and utilise the heightIn modifier and assign a value of 56.dp for the min argument. This means that the composable will have a height of at least 56.dp - using the heightIn modifier instead of the height modifier does not enforce a fixed size for our composable and instead allows it to grow should it need to.

@Composable
fun SettingItem(
	modifier: Modifier = Modifier
) {
    Surface(
        modifier = modifier
            .heightIn(min = 56.dp)
    ) {
    
	}
}

ðŸ’¡ Using minimum size modifiers instead of static sizing modifiers means that the composables can grow when they need to. This makes your UI more responsive across different screen sizes, and also helps to keep your UI accessible for users who might be adjusting text sizes via their system settings.

Finally, weâ€™re going to want to show some content inside of our SettingItem composable. Because this composable is reusable for each of our setting items, weâ€™re going to allow the passing of composable content into this composable via the use of a function argument. For this, weâ€™ll add a new argument to our function, in the form of a @Composable () -> Unit type. Within the body of our Surface composable, we can then invoke this composable function, allowing the provided composable content to be composed inside of our Surface.

@Composable
fun SettingItem(
	modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    content: @Composable () -> Unit
) {
    Surface(
        modifier = modifier
            .heightIn(min = 56.dp)
    ) {
        content()
    }
}

ðŸ’¡ When creating reusable composables function, allowing composable content to be provided into the function allows us to create flexible composables that can be utilised for different use cases.

With this composable in place, we can now hop back on over to our NotificationSettings composable. We can see what we currently have here represents the same structure as the Surface that we just defined for our SettingItem composable.

@Composable
fun NotificationSettings(
	modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    title: String,
    checked: Boolean,
    onCheckedChanged: (checked: Boolean) -> Unit
) {
    Surface(
        modifier = modifier
    ) {
        Row(...) {
            Text(...)
            Switch(...)
        }
    }
}

Weâ€™ll switch out this Surface composable, replacing it with the use of our SettingItem. We can see here now that we no longer need to worry about any specific constraints for the parent of the item, as that is now being handled by the generalised composable that we have created.

@Composable
fun NotificationSettings(
	modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    title: String,
    checked: Boolean,
    onCheckedChanged: (checked: Boolean) -> Unit
) {
    SettingItem(
		modifier = modifier
	) {
        Row(
           ...
        ) {
            Text(...)
            Switch(...)
        }
    }
}

While our composable does not look very different (other than the enforced minimum height), we can now reuse this for our other setting items and enforce some consistency across our UI components.

Reusing this logic allows us to ensure that our settings composables are not only styled in the same way but also behave consistently across the different declarations. It wonâ€™t always be appropriate to reuse these things across composables, but if you start to notice a pattern of repetitions, that can be a good indicator to centralise things for re-use.

Building the Show Hints Setting Item

Alongside the Enable Notifications setting item, weâ€™re also going to support a setting item that uses the Checkbox composable in the form of the Show Hints setting item. Both coming from the Material APIs, the Switch and Checkbox are very similar components but will be portrayed as having a different purpose by the user.

Creating the hints setting composable

These two setting items are going to be very similar in terms of their composable structure. Letâ€™s start here by creating a composable function for this Show Hints setting item.

// HintSettingsItem.kt
@Composable
fun HintSettingsItem(
	modifier: Modifier = Modifier
)

Similar to our previous settings item, weâ€™re going to need to pass in some additional information that will be used to compose our settings item here. This information is going to consist of:

  • title: the title to be displayed within the settings item
  • checked: whether the settings item is currently marked as on or off
  • onShowHintsToggled: a lambda used to trigger a callback whenever the settings item is toggled, allowing the parent composable to update the state for the setting item
@Composable
fun HintSettingsItem(
	modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
	title: String,
    checked: Boolean,
    onShowHintsToggled: (checked: Boolean) -> Unit	
)

Inside of this composable function weâ€™re going to start by defining the composable content, which weâ€™ll begin by using our newly created SettingItem composable:

SettingItem(
	modifier = modifier
) {


}

Weâ€™re then going to go ahead and define the Row composable that will be used to hold the content for our setting item. For the Enable Notifications setting item we defined a Text and Switch composable which were displayed next to each other using a Row, so weâ€™re going to be recreating the same layout here.

When creating the Enable Notifications Row we propagated the toggle state up to the Row composable instead of having it managed by the Switch composable. Weâ€™re going to take this approach and apply it directly to the Row of our Show Hints setting item, utilising the information that we are passing into our HintSettingsItem composable.

SettingItem(modifier = modifier) {
	Row(
		modifier = Modifier
            .toggleable(
                value = checked,
                onValueChange = { onShowHintsToggled() },
                role = Role.Checkbox
            )
    ) {
        
    }
}

One key difference here, when compared to the Enable Notifications, setting item is the role that is being used with the toggleable modifier. Because we are now going to be working with the Checkbox composable, weâ€™re instead using the Role.Checkbox value here so that the accessibility services are aware of the UI component being used. Other than that small difference, youâ€™ll notice that the above code is the same as our previously created setting item. Weâ€™ll then go ahead and apply the same padding values, along with aligning the content of our Row in the center on the vertical axis by utilising the Alignment.CenterVertically value for the verticalAlignment argument from the Row composable.

Row(
	modifier = Modifier
        .toggleable(
            value = checked,
            onValueChange = { onShowHintsToggled() },
            role = Role.Checkbox
        )
        .padding(horizontal = 16.dp),
    verticalAlignment = Alignment.CenterVertically
) {
        
}

The only thing missing now is the actual body of our composable, so weâ€™ll go ahead and copy the same structure that is used by our Enable Notifications composable. Except instead of using the Switch composable, weâ€™ll switch this out for the Checkbox composable.

Row(
	modifier = Modifier
        .toggleable(
            value = checked,
            onValueChange = { onShowHintsToggled() },
            role = Role.Checkbox
        )
        .padding(horizontal = 16.dp),
    verticalAlignment = Alignment.CenterVertically
) {
	Text(text = title, modifier = Modifier.weight(1f))
    Checkbox(
        checked = checked,
        onCheckedChange = null
    )  
}

Like the Switch composable, the Checkbox is also a toggle-able component. Youâ€™ll even notice that the checked and onCheckedChange types are also the same across both of these composables.

With this in place, we now have a composable function that allows the user to toggle the setting for displaying hints in our app.

@Composable
fun HintSettingsItem(
	modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    title: String,
    checked: Boolean,
    onCheckedChanged: (checked: Boolean) -> Unit
) {
    SettingItem(modifier = modifier) {
        Row(
            modifier = Modifier
                .toggleable(
                    value = checked,
                    onValueChange = onCheckedChanged,
                    role = Role.Switch
                )
                .padding(horizontal = 16.dp),
            verticalAlignment = Alignment.CenterVertically
        ) {
            Text(text = title, modifier = Modifier.weight(1f))
            Checkbox(
                checked = checked,
                onCheckedChange = null
            )
        }
    }
}

This will give us a composable UI component that displays the Show Hints title to the user, along with a Checkbox that can be used to toggle the setting on and off.

We didnâ€™t need to dive too deep into how this setting item was created, as we can see how similar it is to the previous Enable Notifications composable that we defined. We have however learned about the extra toggle-able component, the Checkbox, along with utilising our re-usable SettingItem composable that we defined in the previous section.

Improving the Hints Setting accessibility

When it comes to the accessibility of our hints setting, we can go one step further here by utilising the stateDescription semantic - similar to how we did for the notifications setting. We can improve things here by actually describing what that state represents - which is whether the notifications are currently enabled or disabled. For example, hearing the following string resources being read gives the user much more context on the current state of the component.

<string name="cd_hints_enabled">Hints Enabled</string>
<string name="cd_hints_disabled">Hints Disabled</string>

Within our HintSettingsItem composable we can then use these strings resources to build a string reference based on the current checked flag that is provided to the composable function.

val hintsEnabledState = if (checked) {
	stringResource(id = R.string.cd_hints_enabled)
} else stringResource(id = R.string.cd_hints_disabled)

Finally, we can assign this to the semantics of our composable using the semantics modifier.

Row(
	modifier = Modifier
		.toggleable(
        	value = checked,
            onValueChange = onCheckedChanged,
            role = Role.Switch
		)
        .semantics {
        	stateDescription = hintsEnabledState
        }
        .padding(horizontal = 16.dp),
    verticalAlignment = Alignment.CenterVertically
)

With this in place, the accessibility services will now use this string resource to describe the current state of our composable. This provides a much greater level of context for the current state of the notifications setting.

Composing the hints setting

With this created, we can now go ahead and plug this into the parent composable for our settings screen.

MaterialTheme {
	Column {
		TopAppBar()
		NotificationSettings()
		Divider()
		HintSettingsItem(modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth())
	}
}

Youâ€™ll notice at this point that other than the provided modifier, weâ€™re missing the required arguments that we setup for the composable function. This was the title, checked flag and onShowHintsToggled lambda.

So that we can provide the title to our composable function, weâ€™re going to need to add a new string resource to our strings.xml file. This will be the string that we display within the settings row for our Show Hints setting.

<string name="setting_show_hints">Show Hints</string>

We can then utilise the stringResource composable function to retrieve the string for our declared resource ID, providing this to our composable function for the title argument.

HintSettingsItem(
	modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
	title = stringResource(id = R.string.setting_show_hints)
)

For the checked flag weâ€™re going to need to provide the current state for our show hints setting. This is being stored in the SettingsState class from which is being accessed through our ViewModel. For this we can reference this state variable that is observing the state from our ViewModel, accessing the hintsEnabled from this and passing this for the checked flag.

HintSettingsItem(
	modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
	title = stringResource(id = R.string.setting_show_hints),
	checked = state.hintsEnabled
)

Finally, we need to provide the callback that will be triggered when the show hints setting is toggled between on and off. We previously created a function in our ViewModel, onShowHintsToggled, that matches the structure of the lambda - so we can pass this directly to our composable function.

HintSettingsItem(
	modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
	title = stringResource(id = R.string.setting_show_hints),
	checked = state.hintsEnabled,
	onShowHintsToggled = viewModel::toggleHintSettings
)

With those in place, our HintSettingsItem composable is fully satisfied. Weâ€™ll wrap this up by adding a Divider composable to create some visual separation after our HintSettingsItem composable.

MaterialTheme {
	Column {
		TopAppBar()
		NotificationSettings()
		Divider()
		HintSettingsItem(
			modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
			title = stringResource(id = R.string.setting_show_hints),
			checked = state.hintsEnabled,
			onCheckedChanged = viewModel::toggleHintSetting
		)
		Divider()
	}
}

With this in place, we now have a HintSettingsItem composable that allows the user to toggle between the on and off state for the show hints setting. When this is toggled we can see that our state is changed and the UI is recomposed to reflect this state change.

Building the Manage Subscription Setting Item

Now that we have both of the toggle settings items in place, weâ€™re going to create the next settings item - the Manage Subscription item.

Creating the manage subscription composable

This is going to be quite a minimal component that would be used to launch another screen of the app. While in this project we arenâ€™t going to be working with navigating to other parent composables (as in, screens), this setting item will give us a chance to explore some other concepts around composables. Weâ€™ll start here by creating a new composable, ManageSubscriptionSettingItem:

// ManageSubscriptionSettingItem.kt
@Composable
fun ManageSubscriptionSettingItem(
	modifier: Modifier = Modifier
)

And again, weâ€™ll make use of our SettingItem composable to define the foundations of our setting item.

@Composable
fun ManageSubscriptionSettingItem(
	modifier: Modifier = Modifier
) {
    SettingItem(modifier = modifier) {
        
    }
}

Inside of the SettingItem, weâ€™re then going to start building out the body of this composable. Similar to the other items, weâ€™re going to add a Row composable to allow us to layout composables along the horizontal axis.

SettingItem(modifier = modifier) {
	Row {
        
    }
}

At this point, you might be starting to notice a pattern of further similarity. Each of our composable setting items so far is using a Row inside of the SettingItem composable. So, why havenâ€™t we placed this Row inside of our setting item? The truth is, we could do! After this setting item, weâ€™re creating 3 more items - however, 2 of these do not need the concept of a Row. While there would be no harm in using a Row with a single child, weâ€™re going to avoid too much generalisation for our composable at this point.

ðŸ’¡ If you wish to explore further generalisation, it could be helpful to think about how you might structure these composables to allow for more code reuse. For example, most of the settings have a row containing a text label that fills the remaining space in a row. Exploring how we would remove some of the duplications there, without over-abstracting our settings, would be a good exercise to explore.

Composing the Title

With our Row in place, we can now start adding some of the content for the setting item. Weâ€™ll start here with the title, which weâ€™ll need to have passed into our composable function:

@Composable
fun ManageSubscriptionSettingItem(
	modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
	title: String
)

Weâ€™ll then go ahead and add a Text composable that will be used to display the label for our setting item Weâ€™ll again utilise the weight modifier to have this fill the available space in the width of the Row, along with assigning the title of the setting to the text argument of the composable.

SettingItem(modifier = modifier) {
	Row {
        Text(
			modifier = Modifier.weight(1f),
			text = title
		)
    }
}

Composing the action icon

Because this is a setting item that would be clicked to launch another screen, we want to make it clear to the user that this is the behaviour for the setting item. For this, weâ€™re going to add an arrow icon to the end of our row using the Icon composable.

SettingItem(modifier = modifier) {
	Row {
        Text(
			modifier = Modifier.weight(1f),
			text = title
		)
        Icon(
            imageVector = ...,
            contentDescription = ...
        )
    }
}

Here we havenâ€™t yet added values for the arguments that are required for the Icon declaration. Weâ€™ll fix this by starting with providing a value for the imageVector argument, similar to how we added an icon to the TopAppBar of the screen weâ€™ll utilise the Icons class from the compose packages. This time around weâ€™re going to use the KeyboardArrowRight icon to display an arrow at the end of the Row.

Icon(
	imageVector = Icons.Default.KeyboardArrowRight,
	contentDescription = ...
)

Weâ€™re not quite done here yet, as the Icon requires a contentDescription to be provided for the composable - this description will be used to describe the visual element to accessibility services. Weâ€™re going to start by adding a description for this icon to our strings.xml file. The description needs to describe the purpose of the icon, so weâ€™ll do this using the phrase â€œOpen Subscription Managementâ€.

// strings.xml
<string name="cd_open_subscription">
	Open Subscription Management
</string>

ðŸ’¡ If we were going to be reusing this setting item to launch other screens, it would be a good idea to have this content description passed into the composable function.

With this added to our resources, we can then use the stringResource composable function to retrieve the string value for this resource and pass the result directly to the contentDescription argument.

Icon(
	imageVector = Icons.Default.KeyboardArrowRight,
	contentDescription = stringResource(R.string.cd_open_subscription)
)

ðŸ’¡ Itâ€™s important to only provide content descriptions where they are going to be helpful for accessibility services. If a visual element is only being provided for decoration, then you can simply pass null for the description and the element will be ignored by the accessibility services.

With this in place, we now have our Manage Subscription setting item displaying the composables that weâ€™ve defined above.

Creating visual space between the child composables

Things look a little cramped in the settings row, so weâ€™ll add some padding to the Row composable to create some visual spacing around the edges of the item.

SettingItem(modifier = modifier) {
	Row(
		modifier = Modifier.padding(16.dp)
    ) {
        Text(
			modifier = Modifier.weight(1f),
			text = title
		)
        Icon(
            imageVector = Icons.Default.KeyboardArrowRight,
            contentDescription = stringResource(
				R.string.cd_open_subscription)
        )
    }
}

While our setting item is now being displayed, itâ€™s not yet interactable - meaning that when our user clicks on this item, nothing would happen. Before we go ahead and implement any form of click listener on our composable, weâ€™re going to take the same approach as our other setting items and pass in a lambda function into our composable. This will be used to pass up the click event to the parent composable.

@Composable
fun ManageSubscriptionSettingItem(
	modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
	title: String,
    onSettingClicked: () -> Unit
)

So that we can trigger this lambda function, weâ€™re going to need to make our Row clickable. For this weâ€™ll use the clickable modifier to support click events on our setting row, triggering our onSettingClicked lambda when this click event occurs.

SettingItem(modifier = modifier) {
	Row(
		modifier = Modifier
			.clickable { onSettingClicked() }
            .padding(16.dp)
    ) {
        Text(
			modifier = Modifier.weight(1f),
			text = title
		)
        Icon(
            imageVector = Icons.Default.KeyboardArrowRight,
            contentDescription = stringResource(
				R.string.cd_open_subscription)
        )
    }
}

ðŸ’¡ Here we place the clickable modifier before the padding modifier. This is because the ordering of modifiers matters, and this ensures that the whole padded area of the composable is clickable.

At this point, we have a functioning composable that support interaction events from our user. However, we can go one step further here and improve things in terms of accessibility. Our Row is clickable, but it isnâ€™t communicated to the accessibility services what that click event does - the only way of knowing would be to navigate into the Icon composable to read the contentDescription. What we can do here is utilise the onClickLabel argument of the clickable modifier - this allows us to describe the click event, enabling accessibility services to be able to communicate the purpose of the click action.

To utilise this click label support, weâ€™re going to move the content description of our Icon composable to the onClickLabel of our clickable modifier. We only need to have this content description in one place, and it makes more sense to place this at a higher level of this composable where the click event is managed.

SettingItem(modifier = modifier) {
	Row(
		modifier = Modifier
			.clickable(
                onClickLabel = stringResource(
					id = R.string.cd_open_subscription
				)
            ) { onSettingClicked() }
            .padding(16.dp)
    ) {
        Text(
			modifier = Modifier.weight(1f),
			text = title
		)
        Icon(
            imageVector = Icons.Default.KeyboardArrowRight,
            contentDescription = null
        )
    }
}

With this in place, we now have a composable for the Manage Subscription setting item completed and ready to be composed within our UI.

@Composable
fun ManageSubscriptionSettingItem(
	modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    title: String,
    onSettingClicked: () -> Unit
) {
    SettingItem {
        Row(
            modifier = Modifier
                .clickable(
                    onClickLabel = stringResource(
						id = R.string.cd_open_subscription, title
					)
                ) { onSettingClicked() }
                .padding(horizontal = 16.dp)
        ) {
            Text(
				modifier = Modifier.weight(1f),
				text = title
			)
            Icon(
                imageVector = Icons.Default.KeyboardArrowRight,
                contentDescription = null
            )
        }
    }
}

Composing the Manage Subscription setting

Now that the composable is created, we can go ahead and plug this into our settings screen. Weâ€™ll start by composing the ManageSubscriptionSettingItem composable within the parent settings composable.

MaterialTheme {
	Column {
		TopAppBar()
		NotificationSettings()
		Divider()
		HintSettingsItem()
		Divider()
		ManageSubscriptionSettingItem(
			modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth())
	}
}

Before we can continue weâ€™ll need to add the required arguments to the composable - the title String and onSettingClicked lambda.

So that we can provide the title to our composable function, weâ€™re going to need to add a new string resource to our strings.xml file. This will be the string that we display within the settings row for our Manage Subscription setting.

// strings.xml
<string name="setting_manage_subscription">
	Manage Subscription
</string>

We can then utilise the stringResource composable function to retrieve the string for our declared resource ID, providing this to our composable function for the title argument.

ManageSubscriptionSettingItem(
	modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
	title = stringResource(id = R.string.setting_manage_subscription)
)

Finally, we need to provide the callback that will be triggered when the Manage Subscription setting is clicked. As mentioned previously, weâ€™re not going to be handling the click event of this settings item as itâ€™s out of scope for this project - so weâ€™ll leave this blank for now.

ManageSubscriptionSettingItem(
	modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
	title = stringResource(id = R.string.setting_manage_subscription),
	onSettingClicked = {
		// Handle setting click
	}
)

With those in place, our ManageSubscriptionSettingItem composable is fully satisfied. Weâ€™ll wrap this up by adding a Divider composable to create some visual separation after our ManageSubscriptionSettingItem composable.

MaterialTheme {
	Column {
		TopAppBar()
		NotificationSettings()
		Divider()
		HintSettingsItem()
		Divider()
		ManageSubscriptionSettingItem(
			modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
			title = stringResource(id = R.string.setting_manage_subscription),
			onSettingClicked = {
				// Handle setting click
			}
		)
		Divider()
	}
}

With this in place, we now have a ManageSubscriptionSettingItem composable that allows us to display a clickable settings item to the user. This composable has no aspects that need to update the state of our screen, making it a stateless static item that does not change based on state.

Building a Spacer Item

So far weâ€™ve been using the Divider composable to separate most of our setting items. This has satisfied our requirements so far, but in some cases, we might want to create a more visual separation between different sections of our settings screen.

To support this weâ€™re going to create a new composable that can be used as a section spacer to create a visual gap. Weâ€™ll start by creating a new composable function, SectionSpacer.

// SectionSpacer.kt
@Composable
fun SectionSpacer(modifier: Modifier = Modifier)

This visual separator is going to essentially be a blank composable that has a couple of different properties assigned to it:

  • Weâ€™ll want to fix the height of the section spacer. Itâ€™ll be fine for us to use a fixed size here, thereâ€™s going to be no content inside of the composable so we wonâ€™t need to worry about anything being cut-off.
  • Weâ€™ll want the spacer to fill the maximum available width - similar to how we enforce the max-width for our other setting items.
  • Weâ€™ll want to apply a background color to our composable. For this, weâ€™ll want to use an existing color from our theme, allowing us to ensure that the color remains correct across any theming changes.

With the above in mind, we end up with something that looks like the following:

@Composable
fun SectionSpacer(modifier: Modifier = Modifier) {
    Box(
        modifier = modifier
            .height(48.dp)
            .background(MaterialTheme.colors.onSurface.copy(
				alpha = 0.12f))
    )
}

To satisfy the different points from above:

  • We use the height modifier to set a fixed height of 48.dp for the composable.
  • We use the fillMaxWidth modifier to force the composable to use all of the available width.
  • For the background modifier, we take the onSurface color from our theme and modify the alpha value for the color. The onSurface color itself is way too dark for what weâ€™re looking for, so weâ€™ll apply an alpha to achieve a more subtle color for use.

With this in place, we can now compose this within our settings list, resulting in a component that allows us to create a clear visual separation between settings sections on our screen.

MaterialTheme {	
	Column {
		TopAppBar()
		NotificationSettings()
		Divider()
		HintSettingsItem()
		Divider()
		ManageSubscriptionSettingItem()
		SectionSpacer(modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth())
	}
}

Building the Marketing Options Setting Item

Next up on our settings list is the Marketing Options setting item - this is used by the user to select their preference for any marketing content that they can receive from our app.

Creating the Marketing Options setting item

For this weâ€™re going to explore the use of radio buttons - the RadioButton is a component from the Material APIs that allows the user to select an option from a presented set. Weâ€™ll again start here by creating a new composable function, placing our SettingItem composable inside of it.

// MarketingSettingItem.kt

@Composable
fun MarketingSettingItem(
	modifier: Modifier = Modifier
) {
	SettingItem(modifier = modifier) {

	}
}

Weâ€™re going to be displaying two options to the user inside of our composable, one for opting into marketing emails and another for requesting to not receive emails. Before we can add these options to our UI, weâ€™ll add the required strings for these to our strings.xml resources file:

<string-array name="setting_options_marketing_choice">
	<item>Opt-in for marketing emails</item>
    <item>Don\'t send me emails</item>
</string-array>

Weâ€™ll then need to access these from our composable function. Weâ€™ll do this by utilising the stringArrayResource composable function - this works similarly to the stringResource function that weâ€™ve previously been using, except this is used for retrieving string arrays from our resource files. For now, weâ€™ll assign this to a variable for later use.

@Composable
fun MarketingSettingItem(
	modifier: Modifier = Modifier
) {
	val options = stringArrayResource(id = 	
		R.array.setting_options_marketing_choice)
	SettingItem(modifier = modifier) {

	}
}

Now we need to start building out the visuals of our settings item. Because weâ€™re showing a title followed by selectable items, weâ€™ll need to use a Column composable to allow us to stack these composables vertically. 

@Composable
fun MarketingSettingItem(
	modifier: Modifier = Modifier
) {
	val options = stringArrayResource(id = 	
		R.array.setting_options_marketing_choice)
	SettingItem(modifier = modifier) {
		Column {


		}
	}
}

Composing the setting Title

Now that we have a container for our child composables to be added to, weâ€™ll next add the title for the setting item to our strings.xml resource file:

// strings.xml
<string name="setting_option_marketing">
	Receive marketing emails?
</string>

Weâ€™ll then add a Text composable to our Column using the string resource that we just added to our resources file, again using the stringResource function to do so.

@Composable
fun MarketingSettingItem(
	modifier: Modifier = Modifier
) {
	val options = stringArrayResource(id = 	
		R.array.setting_options_marketing_choice)
	SettingItem(modifier = modifier) {
		Column {
			Text(text = stringResource(
				id = R.string.setting_option_marketing))
		}
	}
}

At this point we now have this title displaying inside of our setting item:

We can see here that things look a little bit cramped around the edges of the setting item. To improve things here weâ€™re going to add some padding to our composable, using the padding modifier to do so.

@Composable
fun MarketingSettingItem(
	modifier: Modifier = Modifier
) {
	val options = stringArrayResource(id = 	
		R.array.setting_options_marketing_choice)
	SettingItem(modifier = modifier) {
		Column(
			modifier = Modifier.padding(16.dp)
		) {
			Text(text = stringResource(
				id = R.string.setting_option_marketing))
		}
	}
}

Composing the selectable options

With the title in place, we can now think about adding the selectable marketing options to our setting item. Weâ€™re going to loop through the array of strings that we previously retrieved, building a selectable item for each one - letâ€™s start by setting up this loop.

Column(
	modifier = Modifier.padding(16.dp)
) {
	Text(text = title)
	options.forEachIndexed { index, option ->

	}
}

Inside of this loop, weâ€™re now going to construct a selectable item that consists of a RadioButton composable, along with a label in the form of a Text composable. Weâ€™ll be displaying these horizontally next to one another, so weâ€™ll start by adding a Row here. Because weâ€™re looping through our array of options, this will cause a Row to be composed for each item in that array.

options.forEachIndexed { index, option ->
	Row {
		     
	}
}

With the Row in place, we can now compose a RadioButton - this is a toggle-able component that works in the same way as the Checkbox and Switch composables that weâ€™ve previously worked with. The main difference here is that the behaviour of a RadioButton group is slightly different as one item must always be selected, which is something we have already configured to be the case within our state. Weâ€™ll go ahead and add this composable to our Row.

Row {
	RadioButton(
		selected = ...,
		onClick = ...
	)      
}

Youâ€™ll notice here that there are two required arguments here:

  • selected: whether the RadioButton is currently selected
  • onClick: callback triggered when the composable is clicked

Within our composable, we donâ€™t currently have the concept of either of these things. Similar to the other composables that weâ€™ve created in this chapter, weâ€™re going to pass these in from the parent. Weâ€™ll go ahead and add arguments to our MarketingSettingItem function to satisfy the requirements of the selected and onClick values from above.

@Composable
fun MarketingSettingItem(
	modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
	selectedOption: MarketingOption,
	onOptionSelected: (option: MarketingOption) -> Unit
)

With these values now available to our composable function we can slot them into our RadioButton, starting with the selected argument. Each MarketingOption has an id value which we created to match the index within the list of options. Because this is the case we can simply check if the id of the selected option is equal to the current index in our loop, assigning the result of this check to the selected argument. 

Row {
	RadioButton(
		selected = selectedOption.id == index,
		onClick = ...
	)      
}

ðŸ’¡ Using the index as the ID of our item isnâ€™t the most scalable approach, but it helps to keep things simple for the sake of this example. If building this for production, it would be worth thinking about having the ID represented by something that didnâ€™t rely on the index of a list.

With our selected argument now satisfied, we can satisfy the onClick argument. The listener that has been provided to our composable requires us to pass back the item that has been selected. Because weâ€™re working with a string array we again need to utilise the index from our loop here. We can again keep this simple by returning either the MarketingOption ALLOWED or NOT_ALLOWED value based on the index of the clicked item. Once weâ€™ve calculated this we can pass the result back using the onOptionSelected callback.

Row {
	RadioButton(
		selected = selectedOption.id == index,
		onClick = {
			val marketingOption = if (index == MarketingOption.ALLOWED.id) {
                	MarketingOption.ALLOWED
                } else MarketingOption.NOT_ALLOWED
            onOptionSelected(marketingOption)
		}
	)      
}

At this point, weâ€™ll be able to see our RadioButton composed within our UI.

Things are looking a bit blank here though, it also isnâ€™t very clear what RadioButton is which! Weâ€™ll go ahead and add a Text composable to represent the label - passing the current option for the text argument of the composable. Weâ€™ll also go ahead and add some padding to the start of the Text composable so that it isnâ€™t pressed right against our Radiobutton.

Row {
	RadioButton(
		selected = selectedOption.id == index,
		onClick = {
			val marketingOption = if (index == MarketingOption.ALLOWED.id) {
                	MarketingOption.ALLOWED
                } else MarketingOption.NOT_ALLOWED
            onOptionSelected(marketingOption)
		}
	)
	Text(
		modifier = Modifier.padding(
			start = 18.dp
		),
		text = option
	)   
}

Now we have a label that describes the purpose of each marketing option:

Creating visual space

Now that this is being composed in our UI, we can see two things that donâ€™t feel quite right visually:

  • When clicking the composable function, the touch state does not expand the full width of the settings area. This feels a little odd and results in the items looking like they are different lengths on click events
  • The items are very close together, making it difficult to interact with each item individually

To solve these concerns weâ€™re going to add two modifiers to the Row that holds the RadioButton and the supporting Text composable. First of all, the fillMaxWidth modifier will force the composable to fill the maximum available space - while this doesnâ€™t look any different at first visually, the touch state of the composable will now fill the entire width of the setting area.

Weâ€™ll also utilise the padding composable to create some visual spacing for our composable - the will prevent the items from being pressed so closely together, removing any friction when trying to interact with them individually.

Row(modifier = Modifier
	.fillMaxWidth()
	.padding(10.dp)
) {
	RadioButton(
		selected = selectedOption.id == index,
		onClick = {
			val marketingOption = if (index == MarketingOption.ALLOWED.id) {
                	MarketingOption.ALLOWED
                } else MarketingOption.NOT_ALLOWED
            onOptionSelected(marketingOption)
		}
	)
	Text(
		modifier = Modifier.padding(
			start = 18.dp
		),
		text = option
	)      
}

With this in place, we can see that things are looking much nicer visually.

The title of the marketing options is also very close to the selectable options, so weâ€™ll go ahead and use the Spacer composable to create some visual spacing between these two parts of the setting item.

Column(
	modifier = Modifier.padding(16.dp)
) {
	Text(text = title)
	Spacer(modifier = Modifier.height(8.dp))
	options.forEachIndexed { index, option ->
		...
	}
}

Improving the selectable option interactions

At this point, we have a functioning setting item that allows the user to select their desired marketing options. When interacting with the setting item, you might notice that only clicking the RadioButton composable triggers the selection of the marketing option. This isnâ€™t very accessible for the user, so weâ€™re going to lift the click listener and instead apply it to the container for our marketing option row. Weâ€™ll start here by removing the existing listener from our RadioButton composable.

Row(modifier = Modifier
	.fillMaxWidth()
	.padding(10.dp)
) {
	RadioButton(
    	selected = selectedOption.id == index,
    	onClick = null
	)
	Text(
		modifier = Modifier.padding(start = 18.dp),
		text = option
	)
}

Now we take the previous listener that we had in place and instead assign it to our marketing option row using the clickable modifier. This way when the Row is clicked, the onOptionSelected callback will be triggered. While adding the modifier weâ€™ll also provide an onClickLabel for the Row in the form of the current option - that way our Row has a description for its click action.

Row(modifier = Modifier
	.fillMaxWidth()
    .clickable(
		onClickLabel = option
	) {
		val marketingOption = if (index == 		
			MarketingOption.ALLOWED.id) {
				MarketingOption.ALLOWED
            } else MarketingOption.NOT_ALLOWED
                onOptionSelected(marketingOption)
            }
	}
    .padding(10.dp)
) {
    RadioButton(
        selected = selectedOption.id == index,
        onClick = null
    )
    Text(
        modifier = Modifier.padding(start = 18.dp),
        text = option
    )
}

ðŸ’¡ Outside of accessibility services, this improves the usability of the component for all users of our app - as the row can be clicked as a complete item, rather than relying on individual component interactions.

With this in place, we now have a complete MarketingSettingItem composable function that is accessible to our users and allows the user to select a marketing option.

@Composable
fun MarketingSettingItem(
	modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    selectedOption: MarketingOption,
    onOptionSelected: (position: MarketingOption) -> Unit
) {
    val options = stringArrayResource(id = 	
		R.array.setting_options_marketing_choice)
    SettingItem(modifier = modifier) {
        Column(
            modifier = Modifier.padding(16.dp)
        ) {
            Text(text = title)
            Spacer(modifier = Modifier.height(8.dp))
            options.forEachIndexed { index, option ->
                Row(modifier = Modifier
                    .fillMaxWidth()
                    .clickable(
						onClickLabel = option
					) {
                        val marketingOption = if (index == 							MarketingOption.ALLOWED.id) {
                            MarketingOption.ALLOWED
                        } else MarketingOption.NOT_ALLOWED
                        onOptionSelected(marketingOption)
                    }
                    .padding(10.dp)
                ) {
                    RadioButton(
                        selected = selectedOption.id == index,
                        onClick = null
                    )
					Spacer(modifier = Modifier.width(10.dp))
                    Text(
                        modifier = Modifier.padding(
							start = 18.dp
						),
                        text = option
                    )
                }
            }
        }
    }
}

Improving the selectable option accessibility

While in the above step we pulled up the listener to the parent of the selectable option to improve the interaction with the item, weâ€™re going to go one step further here and lean into a more native approach. Weâ€™re instead going to use the selectable modifier to make our whole Row a selectable item, as opposed to it being a clickable item. When it comes to accessibility services, this makes quite a bit of difference as a clickable item does not represent any state to mark it as selected. When it comes to this setting item, one of the radio options is always going to be selected, so this needs to be reflected to the user.

The selectable modifier takes a collection of arguments:

  • selected: This is the currently selected state of the item. For this, weâ€™re going to use the same logic that is being used for the selected value of the nested RadioButton
  • onClick: This is the lambda that is triggered when the item is clicked. We can use the same logic that we declared for the clickable modifier that was previously in use, passing up the click event to be handled by the parent
  • role: The Role used by the accessibility services to depict the component type. Here weâ€™ll declare the RadioButton type.

With this information in place, we can now switch out the clickable modifier for the selectable modifier, applying the logic described in the points above.

Row(modifier = Modifier
	.selectable(
		selected = selectedOption.id == index,
		onClick = {
			val marketingOption = if (index == MarketingOption.ALLOWED.id) {
				MarketingOption.ALLOWED
			} else MarketingOption.NOT_ALLOWED
			onOptionSelected(marketingOption)
		},
		role = Role.RadioButton
	)
    .fillMaxWidth()
	.padding(10.dp)
) {
	RadioButton(
		selected = selectedOption.id == index,
		onClick = null
	)
	Text(
		modifier = Modifier.padding(start = 18.dp),
		text = option
	)
}

We can see that the configuration of this modifier is very similar to the toggleable modifier that we previously utilised in this chapter. Now that we are working with a RadioButton, this corresponds more to a selectable state as opposed to a toggleable state.

Composing the Marketing Options setting item

We next need to compose this setting item within our UI, so weâ€™ll slot it in beneath the previous items that we added.

MaterialTheme {
	Column {
		TopAppBar()
		NotificationSettings()
		Divider()
		HintSettingsItem()
		Divider()
		ManageSubscriptionSettingItem()
		Spacer()
		MarketingSettingItem(
			modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth())
	}
}

Here weâ€™re still missing the required arguments that we setup for the composable function. These are the selectedOption and onOptionSelected lambda arguments.

For the selectedOption flag weâ€™re going to need to provide the current state for our marketing option setting. This is being stored in the SettingsState class from which is being provided to our settings composable. For this we can access the marketingOption value from this state, passing the value for the selectedOption flag of our MarketingSettingItem composable.

MarketingSettingItem(
	modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
	selectedOption = state.marketingOption
)

Finally, we need to provide the callback that will be triggered when a marketing option is selected. We previously created a function in our ViewModel, setMarketingSettings that matches the structure of the required lambda, so we can pass this directly to our composable function.

MarketingSettingItem(
	modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
	selectedOption = state.marketingOption
	onOptionSelected = viewModel::setMarketingSettings
)

With those in place, our MarketingSettingItem composable is fully satisfied. Weâ€™ll wrap this up by adding a Divider composable to create some visual separation after our MarketingSettingItem composable.

MaterialTheme {
	Column {
		TopAppBar()
		NotificationSettings()
		Divider()
		HintSettingsItem()
		Divider()
		ManageSubscriptionSettingItem()
		Spacer()
		MarketingSettingItem(
			modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
			selectedOption = state.marketingOption
			onOptionSelected = viewModel::setMarketingSettings
		)
		Divider()
	}
}

With this in place, we now have a MarketingSettingItem composable that allows us to display selectable marketing options to the user. When interacting with the options that are composed here, weâ€™ll be able to see the UI update based on the state changes.

Building the Theme Selection Setting Item

For the next item within our settings UI, we allow the user to change the theme that is being used to style the components within the application. We arenâ€™t going to be triggering a theme change here, but exploring the UI components that can be used to display these options to the user.

Creating the Theme Selection setting composable

This setting item is going to show a Dropdown menu that the user can select a theme from, which is then saved to our settings state. Weâ€™ll start here by creating a new composable function, ThemeSettingItem.

// ThemeSettingItem.kt
@Composable
fun ThemeSettingItem(
	modifier: Modifier = Modifier
)

Similar to the last setting composable that we created, this composable function is also going to need to know what option is currently selected, as well as know when any of the options are selected by the user. In the case of our application theme, weâ€™ll pass in the selected theme in the form of a Theme reference, along with an onOptionSelected lambda that allows a Theme reference to be passed up to update the state.

@Composable
fun ThemeSettingItem(
	modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    selectedTheme: Theme,
    onOptionSelected: (option: Theme) -> Unit
)

Weâ€™ll then follow the same pattern as our other composables - adding a SettingItem composable, follow by a Row composable that will be used to hold the composables used for the label and currently selected item.

@Composable
fun ThemeSettingItem(
	modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    selectedTheme: Theme,
    onOptionSelected: (option: Theme) -> Unit
) {
    SettingItem {
        Row {

        }
    }
}

Weâ€™ll then display this label and the currently selected item in our Row by using two Text composables. Before we can do that though, weâ€™ll need to add a new string to our strings.xml resources file.

// strings.xml
<string name="setting_option_theme">Theme</string>

Weâ€™ll then use this string for the first Text composable that weâ€™re going to add to our Row, assigning the value to the text argument. Weâ€™ll also declare this in the same way that weâ€™ve defined the expanding labels in the rest of our setting items, utilising the weight modifier to force the composable to fill the width of the settings area. For the second Text composable weâ€™ll use the label property from the selectedTheme.label value that is provided to the composable function. This label represents the string resource for the corresponding theme, which we can retrieve the string value for using the stringResource function.

SettingItem(modifier = modifier) {
	Row {
        Text(
            modifier = Modifier.weight(1f),
            text = stringResource(id = 			
				R.string.setting_option_theme)
        )
        Text(text = stringResource(id = selectedTheme.label))
    }
}

With this in place, we can see the selected theme displayed in our UI.

We can see here that our composable is being pushed against the edges of its bounds, so weâ€™ll utilise the padding modifier to create some visual spacing for the content of the composable.

SettingItem(modifier = modifier) {
	Row(
        modifier = Modifier.padding(16.dp)
    ) {
        Text(
            modifier = Modifier.weight(1f),
            text = stringResource(id = 			
				R.string.setting_option_theme)
        )
        Text(text = stringResource(id = selectedTheme.label))
    }
}

With this modifier in place, our setting item is now looking a bit more presentable when composed.

Composing the Dropdown Menu

Now that the currently selected item is being displayed, weâ€™re going to want to implement the theme selector that allows the user to select a theme - weâ€™ll do this in the form of a selector menu, using the DropdownMenu composable. This composable allows us to display a menu of selectable items in the form of a dropdown menu. Weâ€™ll start by adding the composable declaration to our function.

SettingItem(modifier = modifier) {
	Row(
        modifier = Modifier.padding(16.dp)
    ) {
        Text(
            modifier = Modifier.weight(1f),
            text = title
        )
        Text(text = stringResource(id = selectedTheme.label))
    }
	DropdownMenu(
        expanded = ...
    ) {
        
    }
}

There are two required arguments for the DropdownMenu composable - the expanded state and the content for the menu. This isnâ€™t going to be a part of our global screen state, so weâ€™ll begin by implementing the required expanded state for the menu. Weâ€™re not making this a part of our global state and passing it into the composable because our screen does not need to know about the state of the DropdownMenu, so weâ€™ll keep this scoped to our composable function.

For this piece of state, weâ€™re going to create a new piece of mutable state and wrap it in a remember block. There are two parts to this:

  • We create a piece of mutable state using the mutableStateOf function. This allows us to create a value that can be observed as state by composed. By default our DropdownMenu will be collapsed, so weâ€™ll default this expanded flag to false.
  • Wrapping this state in the remember declaration will mean that the state will be persisted across recompositions. Without this, the reference will be recreated when recomposition occurs, meaning that now we have a state value that will survive across compositions.
var expanded by remember { mutableStateOf(false) }

With this state in place, we can now assign this expanded value to the expanded argument for our DropdownMenu composable.

var expanded by remember { mutableStateOf(false) }
SettingItem(modifier = modifier) {
	Row(
        modifier = Modifier.padding(16.dp)
    ) {
        Text(
            modifier = Modifier.weight(1f),
            text = title
        )
        Text(text = stringResource(id = selectedTheme.label))
    }
	DropdownMenu(
        expanded = expanded
    ) {
        
    }
}

ðŸ’¡ This is a good example of state that can be kept local to a composable function. The rest of our screen does not need to know about this state, so containing it locally keeps its responsibility clearly defined.

At this point though, the expanded flag is not yet being toggled to actually expand our dropdown menu, so weâ€™ll assign a click listener to the Row of our setting item to detect when the user is requesting the dropdown menu. Using the clickable modifier, we toggle the expanded flag to the opposite of the current value, along with providing a click label to describe the action that is triggered from the click event.

<string name="cd_select_theme">Select theme</string>
Row(
	modifier = Modifier
      	.clickable(
        	onClick = { expanded = !expanded },
          	onClickLabel = stringResource(
				id = R.string.cd_select_theme)
        )
        .padding(16.dp)
)

ðŸ’¡ Remember, the ordering of modifiers matters! We place the clickable modifier before the padding here for a reason. If the padding was applied before, then the touch indicator for the click event would not expand to fill the padded area. Applying the padding after the clickable modifier ensures that the indicator will spread to the padded edges of the composable.

Aside from expanding the dropdown menu, weâ€™ll also want to ensure that the dropdown menu is collapsed when dismissal is requested. The DropdownMenu allows you to provide a lambda which is triggered upon dismiss requests, in the form of onDismissRequest. In this lambda weâ€™re going to simply set our expanded value to false - so when the dismiss request takes place, our dropdown menu will be collapsed.

DropdownMenu(
    expanded = expanded,
    onDismissRequest = { expanded = false }
)

With the foundations of our DropdownMenu in place, we can now think about adding the items that will make up the content of the menu. For this, weâ€™re going to take our existing Theme enum and loop through the declared values. During this looping, weâ€™ll declare the composition of a DropdownMenuItem composable. This composable is an item that is to be displayed inside of a DropdownMenu, requiring us to implement an onClick callback along with composable content.

DropdownMenu(
    expanded = expanded,
    onDismissRequest = { expanded = false }
) {
   Theme.values().forEach { theme ->
        DropdownMenuItem(onClick = {
            ...
        }) {
            ...
        }
    }  
}

For the content body, weâ€™re just going to show the name of the theme that can be selected. Weâ€™ll do this using a Text composable, setting the text argument using the string resource to the theme that we are currently at during the values loop.

DropdownMenuItem(onClick = {
	...
}) {
	Text(text = stringResource(id = theme.label))
}

Weâ€™ll next need to implement the action that is to be triggered when a click event occurs on our menu item. When this occurs weâ€™re going to want to do two things:

  • Utilise the onOptionSelected callback that was passed to the composable function. This allows us to notify the parent composable about the theme that has been selected
  • When an option is selected we want to dismiss the dropdown, so we will set the expanded flag to false
DropdownMenuItem(onClick = {
	onOptionSelected(theme)
	expanded = false
}) {
	Text(text = stringResource(id = theme.label))
}

At this point, we now have a dropdown menu that displays selectable theme options to the user.

Weâ€™re going to utilise the offset argument to allow us to offset the dropdown menu slightly, this will allow us to shift the menu away from the edge of the screen slightly.

DropdownMenu(
    expanded = expanded,
    onDismissRequest = { expanded = false },
	offset = DpOffset(16.dp, 0.dp)
)

Now our dropdown menu sits a little nicer on screen.

With this in place, we have a completed composable function that allows the user to select a theme for our application.

@Composable
fun ThemeSettingItem(
	modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    selectedTheme: Theme,
    onOptionSelected: (option: Theme) -> Unit
) {
    var expanded by remember { mutableStateOf(false) }
    SettingItem {
        Row(
            modifier = Modifier
                .clickable(
                    onClick = { expanded = !expanded },
                    onClickLabel = stringResource(
						id = R.string.cd_select_theme)
                )
                .padding(16.dp)
        ) {
            Text(
                modifier = Modifier.weight(1f),
                text = title
            )
            Text(text = stringResource(
				id = selectedTheme.label))
        }
        DropdownMenu(
            expanded = expanded,
            onDismissRequest = { expanded = false },
            offset = DpOffset(16.dp, 0.dp),
            properties = PopupProperties(
                usePlatformDefaultWidth = true
            )
        ) {
            Theme.values().forEach { theme ->
                DropdownMenuItem(onClick = {
                    onOptionSelected(theme)
                    expanded = false
                }) {
                    Text(text = stringResource(
						id = theme.label))
                }
            }
        }
    }
}

Composing the Theme Selection setting

We next need to add the composable to our settings UI, so weâ€™ll slot it in beneath the previous items that we added.

MaterialTheme {
	Column {
		TopAppBar()
		NotificationSettings()
		Divider()
		HintSettingsItem()
		Divider()
		ManageSubscriptionSettingItem()
		Spacer()
		MarketingSettingItem()
		Divider()
		ThemeSettingItem(
			modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth())
	}
}

Here we now need to provide the required arguments that we setup for the composable function. These are the selectedTheme and onOptionSelected lambda values.

For the selectedTheme flag weâ€™re going to need to provide the current state for our theme setting. This is being stored in the SettingsState class which is being provided to our composable function. For this value, we can access the themeOption from this state and pass its value for the selectedTheme flag.

ThemeSettingItem(
	modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
	selectedTheme = state.themeOption
)

Finally, we need to provide the callback that will be triggered when a theme option is selected. We previously created a function in our ViewModel, onOptionSelected, that matches the structure of the lambda. We can pass this directly to our composable function to be triggered when the toggle occurs.

ThemeSettingItem(
	modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
	selectedTheme = state.themeOption,
	onOptionSelected = viewModel::setTheme
)

With those in place, our ThemeSettingItem composable is fully satisfied. Weâ€™ll wrap this up by adding a Divider composable to create some visual separation after our ThemeSettingItem composable.

MaterialTheme {
	Column {
		TopAppBar()
		NotificationSettings()
		Divider()
		HintSettingsItem()
		Divider()
		ManageSubscriptionSettingItem()
		SectionSpacer()
		MarketingSettingItem()
		Divider()
		ThemeSettingItem()
		SectionSpacer(modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth())
	}
}

With this in place, we now have a ThemeSettingItem composable that allows us to display selectable theme options to the user.

Building the App Version Setting Item

For our last settings item, weâ€™re going to take aRow that will display the current version of the app. Weâ€™ve created quite a few of these settings items now, so weâ€™re not going to dive too deep into the breakdown of how this is made up.

Creating the App Version setting composable

Weâ€™ll start here by adding a new string to our strings.xml resource file that will represent the label for our setting item.

// strings.xml
<string name="setting_app_version_title">
	App Version
</string>

With this in place, we now have a label to be used for our settings item. We can now go ahead and create the composable for our App Version item.

// AppVersionSettingItem.kt

@Composable
fun AppVersionSettingItem(
	modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    appVersion: String
) {
    SettingItem(modifier = modifier) {
        Row(
			modifier = Modifier.padding(horizontal = 16.dp),
            verticalAlignment = Alignment.CenterVertically
        ) {
            Text(
                modifier = Modifier.weight(1f),
                text = title
            )
            Text(
                text = appVersion
            )
        }
    }
}

Most of the above we have covered throughout this section already, but letâ€™s brush over the composable to clarify what is going on here:

  • We start by creating a composable function, AppVersionSettingItem. We define an argument here for the app version, this will be passed in by the parent composable.
  • Next, we reuse our SettingItem composable to hold the setting item content.
  • We then define a Row to hold the label and app version, utilise modifiers to apply some padding on either side of the item - along with aligning the content on the vertical axis using the verticalAlignment argument.
  • Finally, we add the Text composables which will be used to display the label and app version content.

With this all in place, we have a composable which will display a setting item that presents the current version of the app to the user.

Improving screen reader navigation

We can make a small tweak here to improve the navigation through our UI via a screenreader. Currently, if the user is navigating through the setting items using accessibility services, the two Text composables will be read as separate items. In this case, it feels like it makes more sense for these to be read as a single item. For example, if the user is read â€œApp Versionâ€ then they would expect to also hear the version of the app - whereas currently, they would need to navigate further to the next item to find that out. To improve things here, we can utilise the semantics modifier to merge the descriptions of these two Text composables. This is done via the mergeDescendants flag within the semantics modifier - passing this as true will merge these two Text composables so that they will be focused as a single node by the screen reader.

@Composable
fun AppVersionSettingItem(
	modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    appVersion: String
) {
    SettingItem(modifier = modifier) {
        Row(
            modifier = Modifier.padding(horizontal = 16.dp)
                .semantics(mergeDescendants = true) {},
            verticalAlignment = Alignment.CenterVertically
        ) {
            Text(
                modifier = Modifier.weight(1f),
                text = stringResource(id =
	 				R.string.setting_app_version_title)
            )
            Text(
                text = appVersion
            )
        }
    }
}

ðŸ’¡ It might not always make sense to merge the descriptions of child composables, hence why it is not the default behaviour. Before merging descriptions, be sure that would be an expected behaviour for the user.

Composing the App Version setting

As the final step for our App Version Settings item, weâ€™re going to need to compose it within our Settings UI.

MaterialTheme {
	Column {
		TopAppBar()
		NotificationSettings()
		Divider()
		HintSettingsItem()
		Divider()
		ManageSubscriptionSettingItem()
		SectionSpacer()
		MarketingSettingItem()
		Divider()
		ThemeSettingItem()
		SectionSpacer()
		AppVersionSettingItem(
			modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth())
	}
}

Youâ€™ll notice at this point that the project wonâ€™t compile, this is because weâ€™re missing the required appVersion argument that we setup for the composable function. This is the only single required argument for our composable, for which weâ€™ll first need to add a new resource to our strings.xml file. 

// strings.xml
<string name="setting_app_version">v1.1</string>

In a real scenario, we would likely fetch/calculate the application version and pass that into the composable function. For the sake of simplicity, weâ€™ll use a string resource here. With this in place, we can now pass the string value for this resource directly to our composable, via the use of the stringResource function.

AppVersionSettingItem(
	modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
	appVersion = stringResource(id = R.string.setting_app_version)
)

With those in place, our AppVersionSettingItem composable is fully satisfied. Weâ€™ll wrap this up by adding a Divider composable to create some visual separation after our AppVersionSettingItem composable.

MaterialTheme {
	Column {
		TopAppBar()
		NotificationSettings()
		Divider()
		HintSettingsItem()
		Divider()
		ManageSubscriptionSettingItem()
		SectionSpacer()
		MarketingSettingItem()
		Divider()
		ThemeSettingItem()
		SectionSpacer()
		AppVersionSettingItem(
			modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
			appVersion = stringResource(id = R.string.setting_app_version)
		)
		Divider()
	}
}

With this in place, we now have an AppVersionSettingItem composable that allows us to display selectable theme options to the user.

Wrapping Up

At this point, we now have a completed settings screen, built up of the composables that weâ€™ve defined throughout this section. These are being composed from the state that weâ€™ve defined in the previous sections for this project, which all comes together to render our UI.

With all this in place, our UI is functional, but we can go one step further here to ensure that it remains this way over time. In the next section, weâ€™ll continue to work on this screen, adding automated tests to perform assertions on our composable UI.

Testing the Settings UI

Now that weâ€™ve built our settings screen, weâ€™re going to take a look at how we can write some automated tests for our composables. Weâ€™re going to be writing some instrumentation tests using the compose ui-test-junit package - allowing us to verify that our composables are displayed and functioning as expected.

Before we can get started with our tests, weâ€™re going to need to add a couple of compose test specific dependencies to our project:

androidTestImplementation(
	"androidx.compose.ui:ui-test-junit4:$compose_version")
debugImplementation(
	"androidx.compose.ui:ui-test-manifest:$compose_version")

Weâ€™re also going to need to utilise mocks to our test - this allows us to easily provide mock references to any listeners that are provided to our composable functions, allowing us to easily verify they are triggered when expected.

androidTestImplementation(
	"org.mockito.kotlin:mockito-kotlin:3.2.0")
androidTestImplementation("org.mockito:mockito-android:3.12.4")

With these in place, we now have access to the required rules and functionality that allow us to test our composable UI. However, alongside these dependencies, weâ€™re also going to need to add some rules to our build.gradle file that will fix some of the compilation errors that weâ€™d currently see when trying to run our tests. Here weâ€™ll add some packagingOptions that will exclude certain packages from the added dependencies. We wonâ€™t dive too much into this concept and itâ€™s usually dependant on the versions of dependencies that are being used, so this may be redundant if you come to updating versions.

android {
	packagingOptions {
		exclude "**/attach_hotspot_windows.dll"
		exclude "META-INF/AL2.0"
		exclude "META-INF/LGPL2.1"
		exclude "META-INF/licenses/ASM"
	}
}

Setting up the test class

Weâ€™ll start here by creating a new class, SettingsTest - this class will be used to contain the different tests that weâ€™re going to write. Youâ€™ll need to create this class inside of the androidTest directory of the module.

// SettingsTest.kt

class SettingsTest {

}

Inside of this class, we now need to define a reference to the ComposeContentTestRule class - this is what weâ€™re going to use to set the composable content on screen, allowing us to perform interactions and assertions from within our tests. 

@get:Rule
val composeTestRule = createComposeRule()

When using this rule, we donâ€™t need to specify any form of activity for our composables to be launched in, the test rule will handle that for us. So using this rule we will set the composable content to be composed, the test will then launch a host activity which will be used to compose our provided content inside of. With this in place, weâ€™re now ready to start writing some tests!

class SettingsTest {

    @get:Rule
    val composeTestRule = createComposeRule()

}

Testing the Settings Composable

At the root of our feature is the Settings composable. What makes this different from our lower level composables (such as each setting item composable), is that this composable allows us to interact with elements to trigger state updates and recomposition of our UI. This means that with the tests for the Settings composable we can assert not only that the expected UI components are displayed, but also that interactions with them result in the expected state changes.

With that in mind, weâ€™re going to start with some simple tests to ensure that the expected composables are shown on screen. To start with, our Settings composable displays a collection of settings items - weâ€™ll write some tests to ensure that these are displayed as expected. Weâ€™ll start with the Enable Notifications setting item, for which weâ€™ll create a new test function.

@Test
fun Enable_Notifications_Setting_Is_Displayed()

Inside of this test, weâ€™re going to need to start by setting the composable content that is to be displayed on screen for us to assert against. Here weâ€™ll use the test rule that we previously defined, along with its setContent function. This function takes a composable function as an argument, allowing us to define what is to be composed on screen for our tests. Because weâ€™re wanting to test the Settings Composable that we defined in the previous sections of this chapter, weâ€™ll go ahead and pass the Settings composable function for this composable argument.

@Test
fun Enable_Notifications_Setting_Is_Displayed() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        Settings()
    }
}

While we arenâ€™t yet performing any assertions, running this test will launch an activity that displays the content of our Settings composable. With this now being displayed, we can next perform the required assertions to ensure that the Enable Notifications setting is being displayed within our composable UI. Weâ€™ll do this by utilising the onNodeWithText function on our test rule reference.

The onNodeWithText function can be used to locate a composable that is displaying the text that we have provided to the function. Composables will be located in the form of a semantic node. Because our composables are represented via semantics, in our tests we are going to be locating nodes within our semantic tree. In this case, this is done using the onNodeWithText function, which will return us with a SemanticsNodeInteraction reference to perform assertions against. 

@Test
fun Enable_Notifications_Setting_Is_Displayed() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        Settings()
    }
    composeTestRule.onNodeWithText(
		InstrumentationRegistry.getInstrumentation()
			.targetContext.getString(
				R.string.setting_enable_notifications)
    )
}

For this test we want to assert that this node is being displayed within our composed UI, so weâ€™re going to go ahead and utilise the assertIsDisplayed function. This is one of the assertions available on the SemanticsNodeInteraction class, allowing us to assert whether this node is being displayed on the screen.

@Test
fun Enable_Notifications_Setting_Is_Displayed() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        Settings()
    }
    composeTestRule.onNodeWithText(
		InstrumentationRegistry.getInstrumentation()
			.targetContext.getString(
				R.string.setting_enable_notifications)
    ).assertIsDisplayed()
}

With this pieced together, we now have a test that:

  • Uses the Settings composable to set the UI to be displayed on the screen.
  • Locates a node within our composable UI, using a String from our application resources.
  • Asserts that the retrieved node is displayed within our UI.

If you run this test within your IDE, youâ€™ll not only see the UI spin up inside of the connected device / emulator, but the tests should also be passing due to the required string being composed within the UI.

Weâ€™re next going to write similar tests for each of our other settings items so that we can assert that they are displayed within our UI. Because the tests are going to look the same, weâ€™re going to start by refactoring the test we just wrote into a reusable function. This function, assertSettingIsDisplayed, is going to look the same as the test we just wrong. The key difference here is that instead of asserting a hardcoded string resource reference, itâ€™ll take a string resource as an argument of the function.

private fun assertSettingIsDisplayed(
	@StringRes title: Int
) {
	composeTestRule.setContent {
		Settings()
	}
	composeTestRule.onNodeWithText(
		InstrumentationRegistry.getInstrumentation()
			.targetContext.getString(title)
    ).assertIsDisplayed()
}

With this in place, we can now replace the code that we had initially written for our text - calling this function to run the assertion against our Settings composable.

@Test
fun Enable_Notifications_Setting_Is_Displayed() {
    assertSettingIsDisplayed(
		R.string.setting_enable_notifications)
}

We can now do the same again for the rest of the setting items that are expected to be composed inside of our Settings composable - asserting that the setting items are displayed on the screen. The key difference here is the string resource that we are using the locate each of the nodes, which will be passed into the assertSettingIsDisplayed within each test.

@Test
fun Show_Hints_Setting_Is_Displayed() {
	assertSettingIsDisplayed(
		R.string.setting_show_hints)
}

@Test
fun View_Subscription_Setting_Is_Displayed() {
	assertSettingIsDisplayed(
		R.string.setting_manage_subscription)
}

@Test
fun App_Version_Setting_Is_Displayed() {
    assertSettingIsDisplayed(
    	R.string.setting_app_version_title)
}

@Test
fun Theme_Setting_Is_Displayed() {
    assertSettingIsDisplayed(
		R.string.setting_option_theme)
}

@Test
fun Marketing_Options_Setting_Is_Displayed() {
    assertSettingIsDisplayed(
		R.string.setting_option_marketing)
}

Testing the Enable Notification state

When it comes to our Enable Notifications setting, it is of the Toggle Setting type - meaning that it displays a switch that can be used to toggle the setting on and off. Weâ€™ll want to perform some assertions here to ensure that the switch correctly reflects its new state within the UI. Because our composable function handles interactions by updating the state via event callbacks, having tests for these ensures that those connections are working as expected. Weâ€™ll write a test here, Enable_Notifications_Toggles_Selected_State, that will compose our Settings composable, click on the Enable Notifications setting item, followed by performing the assertion that the switch is marked as on. 

@Test
fun Enable_Notifications_Toggles_Selected_State() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        Settings()
    }
}

Next, weâ€™re going to locate the node within our composable hierarchy so that we can perform interactions and assertions on it. Here weâ€™ll utilise the onNodeWithText function, providing the label of our settings item to locate the node.

@Test
fun Enable_Notifications_Toggles_Selected_State() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        Settings()
    }
	composeTestRule.onNodeWithText(
        InstrumentationRegistry.getInstrumentation()
			.targetContext.getString(
                R.string.setting_enable_notifications)
}

At this point, the onNodeWithText function will return us with a SemanticsNodeInteraction reference which we can perform assertions against. For this interaction weâ€™re going to use the performClick function, this is a gesture action that is available on the SemanticsNodeInteraction class, allowing us to perform a click gesture on the specified node.

@Test
fun Enable_Notifications_Toggles_Selected_State() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        Settings()
    }
	composeTestRule.onNodeWithText(
        InstrumentationRegistry.getInstrumentation()
			.targetContext.getString(
                R.string.setting_enable_notifications)
    ).performClick()
}

Once the performClick gesture has been performed, we to check that the state is correctly reflected for our Enable Notifications switch.

So that we can perform assertions on our switch, weâ€™re going to need to be able to locate it. Unlike the previous tests where we used text values to locate nodes within our composable UI, a switch does not have any uniquely identifiable data that we can use to locate it within our UI. For this reason, weâ€™re going to need to add a tag to the switch composable, this tag can then be used to locate our composable within our tests. Weâ€™ll need to start here by defining a tag reference that can be accessed from both our tests and our composable.

// Tags.kt

object Tags {
    const val TAG_TOGGLE_ITEM = "toggle_item"
}

With this tag defined, weâ€™ll need to assign it to our composable - this assignment means that we can then retrieve nodes in our UI that have the corresponding tag. Weâ€™ll do this by utilising the testTag modifier to assign our tag to the switch composable.

// NotificationSettings.kt

Row(
	modifier = Modifier
		.testTag(TAG_TOGGLE_ITEM)
		.toggleable(
			...
		)
		.padding(horizontal = 16.dp),
	...
) { ... }

When this testTag modifier is applied, the provided tag is set as a semantic property on the node. This is not visible to users but will be used by testing and accessibility services to locate composables via a tag identifier.

Now that our composable has a tag assigned to it, we can now use the onNodeWithTag function within our tests to locate composables whose tag match the requested tag. This operates in the same way that the previously used onNodeWithText function operates, but by using a tag instead of textual content.

composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(
    TAG_TOGGLE_ITEM
)

Now that the tag is in place, we can locate the node to perform assertions on. To perform these assertions we can use the assertIsOn function - this is one of the assertions available on the SemanticsNodeInteraction class, allowing us to assert whether this node is marked as being on.

@Test
fun Enable_Notifications_Toggles_Selected_State() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        Settings()
    }
    
	composeTestRule.onNodeWithText(
        InstrumentationRegistry.getInstrumentation()
			.targetContext.getString(
                R.string.setting_enable_notifications)
    ).performClick()

    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(
        TAG_TOGGLE_ITEM
    ).assertIsOn()
}

Testing the Show Hints state changes

With the above tests in place, weâ€™re now going to test the same concepts for the Show Hints setting item and that its state is reflected within the Settings composable. Before we can test this, weâ€™ll again need to add a new tag to be used within our tests for the Show Hints item.

// Tags.kt

object Tags {
    ...
    const val TAG_CHECK_ITEM = "check_item"
}
