This function allows us to provide a collection of different arguments, each of which is specific to the destination that I being defined.

public fun NavGraphBuilder.composable(
    route: String,
    arguments: List<NamedNavArgument> = emptyList(),
    deepLinks: List<NavDeepLink> = emptyList(),
    content: @Composable (NavBackStackEntry) -> Unit
)

Currently, weâ€™re only going to be defining the required argument of this function, the route. Weâ€™ll start by doing this for the first destination of our bottom navigation, the Feed. Here weâ€™ll utilise the composable extension function, providing a reference to the path of our Feed destination that we previously defined. We wonâ€™t define anything for the composable content of this destination yet, for now, we just want to get the foundations of our graph in place.

NavHost(
	modifier = modifier,
  	navController = navController, 
  	startDestination = Destination.Feed.path
) {
        
  composable(Destination.Feed.path) { }
     
}

Now that we have the Feed destination defined, weâ€™ll go ahead and do the same for the other destinations in our bottom navigation - the Contacts and Calendar destinations.

NavHost(
	modifier = modifier,
  	navController = navController, 
  	startDestination = Destination.Feed.path
) {
        
  composable(Destination.Feed.path) { }

  composable(Destination.Contacts.path) { }

  composable(Destination.Calendar.path) { }
     
}

With the above in place, we now have the Navigation Graph defined for our bottom navigation bar, with each of the required destinations defined within our graph. At this point though, none of them will be navigating to any composables. In the last chapter we created a ContentArea composable to render some basic UI for a given Destination - weâ€™ll use this here to allow navigation between composables. For each of our NavGraphBuilder.composable declarations, weâ€™re going to compose a ContentArea. When composing this we will need to provide a reference to a given Destination, along with a modifier to declare how this show be composed within our UI. 

NavHost(
    modifier = modifier,
	navController = navController,
	startDestination = Destination.Feed.path
) {
  	composable(route = Destination.Feed.path) {
		ContentArea(
			modifier = Modifier.fillMaxSize(),
			destination = Destination.Feed
		)
    }
    composable(route = Destination.Contacts.path) {
        ContentArea(
			modifier = Modifier.fillMaxSize(),
			destination = Destination.Contacts
		)
    }
    composable(route = Destination.Calendar.path) {
        ContentArea(
			modifier = Modifier.fillMaxSize(),
			destination = Destination.Calendar
		)
    }
}

ðŸ’¡Remember, itâ€™s good to allow parent composables to control how the child composable is being composed in terms of layout constraints. This keeps layout logic outside of our child composables, allowing them to be reusable across different scenarios in our application.

With the above in place, we now have a complete Navigation composable that defines the graph for our navigation, allowing us to support navigation between different composables.

@Composable
fun Navigation(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    navController: NavHostController
) {
    NavHost(
        modifier = modifier,
        navController = navController,
		startDestination = Destination.Feed.path
    ) {
    	composable(route = Destination.Feed.path) {
			ContentArea(destination = Destination.Feed)
        }
        composable(route = Destination.Contacts.path) {
            ContentArea(destination = Destination.Contacts)
        }
        composable(route = Destination.Calendar.path) {
            ContentArea(destination = Destination.Calendar)
        }
    }
}

Hopping back over to our Home composable, we can now compose this Navigation within the content of our Scaffold. Weâ€™ll first need to

obtain a reference to a NavHostController, as this is a required argument for our Navigation composable. For this we can use the rememberNavController() function that is provided by compose navigation package. This will create an instance of a NavHostController and persist it across recompositions.

val navController = rememberNavController()

We can then use this reference to compose our Navigation within the Scaffold content.

@Composable
fun Home(modifier: Modifier = Modifier) {
	val navController = rememberNavController()
	val scaffoldState = rememberScaffoldState()
	Scaffold(
  		modifier = modifier,
  		topBar = {
    		TopAppBar(
      			title = {
        			Text(text = "Home")
      			}
    		)
  		}
	) {
		Navigation(
            modifier = modifier,
            navController = navController
        )
	}
}

When viewing this composable, you should now be able to see the start destination of our navigation graph, the Feed.

Creating a Bottom Navigation Bar

Now that we have our navigation graph defined, a natural next step is to create the UI component that can be used to trigger those navigation events for our graph. Weâ€™re going to create a new composable function, BottomNavigationBar, that will need a couple of different arguments applied to it:

  • modifier: the modifier used by the parent composable to control how the bottom navigation bar is composed
  • currentDestination: the currently selected destination in the navigation graph. This is so that we can highlight that item within the bottom navigation bar
  • onNavigate: a lambda function that will allow us to pass navigation events up to the parent composable so that they can be handled accordingly
@Composable
fun BottomNavigationBar(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    currentDestination: Destination,
    onNavigate: (destination: Destination) -> Unit
)

ðŸ’¡ The Bottom Navigation Bar allows for top-level navigation via a horizontal navigation bar to be shown at the bottom of a screen. This should be used to display between 3 and 5 navigation items.

Weâ€™ll start by composing a BottomNavigation - this is a composable from the compose material APIs that allows us to compose a collection of navigation items for the user to move between different destinations of our app. When composing this, weâ€™ll pass the modifier argument from our composable function, because the BottomNavigation is going to be the top-level composable in our function.

@Composable
fun BottomNavigationBar(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    currentDestination: Destination,
    onNavigate: (destination: Destination) -> Unit
) {
    BottomNavigation(
        modifier = modifier
    ) {
        
    }
}

When it comes to the navigation items within our bottom navigation, weâ€™re going to want to show one for each of the destinations that are currently defined in the navigation graph. Weâ€™ll create a list of these Destination references and then use the Kotlin forEach operator to allow us to loop through these and compose a navigation item for each one.

BottomNavigation(
    modifier = modifier
) {
    listOf(
        Destination.Feed,
        Destination.Contacts,
        Destination.Calendar
    ).forEach {
            
    }
}

When it comes to the navigation item that weâ€™re going to be displaying in this bottom bar, weâ€™ll be composing this with the use of the BottomNavigationItem composable. This is again from the compose material APIs, allowing us to display an item for a destination within our bottom bar. Letâ€™s start building our BottomNavigationItem piece by piece, starting with the required selected argument. This argument tells the item whether it is the currently selected destination, allowing the composable to be styled accordingly. Weâ€™ll provide this selected flag by using the currentDestinationthat is being passed into the composable function - comparing the path property of this with the path of the destination within our forEach loop.

BottomNavigationItem(
	selected = currentDestination.path == it.path
)

Next up weâ€™ll add the implementation for another required argument, the icon. For this, weâ€™ll take a similar approach as when we created the ContentArea composable - composing an Icon if there is an icon available for the given Destination.

BottomNavigationItem(
	selected = currentDestination.path == it.path,
    icon = {
        it.icon?.let { image ->
            Icon(
				imageVector = image, 
				contentDescription = it.path
			)
        }
    }
)

ðŸ’¡ We check for the null status of the icon here as our Destination class has a nullable icon value. While we should expect an icon here, we lean into conditional composition to allow for situations where that might not be the case.

The final required argument is onClick - this requires us to implement a lambda function that will be used to handle click events on the navigation item. When creating our composable function, BottomNavigationBar, we defined an onNavigate lambda that is provided to our composable. Here weâ€™ll simply want to trigger this lambda, pass the destination that we are currently composing the BottomNavigationItem for.

BottomNavigationItem(
	selected = currentDestination.path == it.path,
    icon = {
        it.icon?.let { image ->
            Icon(
				imageVector = image, 
				contentDescription = it.path
			)
        }
    },
	onClick = {
        onNavigate(it)
    }
)

Weâ€™ll wrap up the composition of our BottomNavigationItem by implementing one of its optional arguments, label. For this weâ€™ll simply compose a Text, using the title of the destination that we are currently composing the BottomNavigationItem for.

BottomNavigationItem(
	selected = currentDestination.path == it.path,
    icon = {
        it.icon?.let { image ->
            Icon(
				imageVector = image, 
				contentDescription = it.path
			)
        }
    },
	onClick = {
        onNavigate(it)
    },
    label = {
        Text(text = it.title)
    }
)

With this in place, we now have our BottomNavigationBar composable implemented and ready to use.

@Composable
fun BottomNavigationBar(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    currentDestination: Destination,
    onNavigate: (destination: Destination) -> Unit
) {
    BottomNavigation(
        modifier = modifier
    ) {
        listOf(
            Destination.Feed,
            Destination.Contacts,
            Destination.Calendar
        ).forEach {
            BottomNavigationItem(
                selected = currentDestination.path == it.path,
                onClick = {
                    onNavigate(it)
                },
                icon = {
                    it.icon?.let { image ->
                        Icon(
							imageVector = image, 
							contentDescription = it.path
						)
                    }
                },
                label = {
                    Text(text = it.title)
                }
            )
        }
    }
}

As we can see, we havenâ€™t been required to do too much customisation here, giving us a BottomNavigation implementation that should look a little something like so:

Composing the Bottom Navigation Bar

Now that we have this BottomNavigationBar composable, weâ€™re going to want to compose it in our UI so that it can be used to navigate across the destinations of our app. However, our BottomNavigationBar composable requires a Destination to be passed to it, so that it knows the currently selected destination in the graph. At this point within our Home composable, we donâ€™t have a reference to this. To be able to provide this to our bottom navigation, weâ€™re going to need some way to observe the current destination of the graph as composable state - that will allow us to perform recompositions whenever the navigation graph is interacted with.

For this scenario, we can utilise the currentBackStackEntryAsState NavController extension function - this allows us to retrieve a NavBackStackEntry instance in the form of composable state, allowing us to trigger recompositions whenever this changes.

val navBackStackEntry = navController.currentBackStackEntryAsState()

This navBackStackEntry is now a piece of state within our Home composable, meaning that we can recompose parts of our UI as required. This reference will reflect the current destination of our navigation graph, in the form of a NavBackStackEntry. The only thing is that our BottomNavigationBar requires the Destination type that we have defined in our project.

When it comes to a NavBackStackEntry, we have access to the route of the destination, this will match what weâ€™ve defined in each of the supported Destination types. This means that we can use this string route to map to an instance of a Destination. Hopping back over to our Destination class we can add a new fromString function to its companion object, allowing us to take a provided route and return the corresponding Destination for it.

// Destination.kt
sealed class Destination(
    val path: String,
    val icon: ImageVector? = null,
    val isRootDestination: Boolean = true
) {

    companion object {

        fun fromString(route: String): Destination {
            return when (route) {
                Feed.path -> Feed
                Calendar.path -> Calendar
                Contacts.path -> Contacts
                else -> Home
            }
        }
    }
}

With that in place, we can now take the current NavBackStackEntry and use it to build a Destination. The route within a NavBackStackEntry is nullable, so weâ€™ll need to provide a default for this in these scenarios.

navBackStackEntry.value?.destination?.route?.let {
	Destination.fromString(it)
} ?: run {
	Destination.Home
}

The only thing here now is that we need this Destination calculation to adhere to two pieces of behaviour:

  • We need it to represent composable state, allowing us to recompose UI components whenever their value is changed
  • We need it to be recalculated whenever the current NavBackStackEntry is changed

To achieve this, weâ€™re going to utilise the derivedStateOf function, this will allow us to create a state object based on the calculation of our Destination. The internals of derivedStateOf allows our result to be cached, meaning that the value will not be recalculated across compositions unless the value of the navBackStackEntry reference changes.

val currentDestination by derivedStateOf {
	navBackStackEntry.value?.destination?.route?.let {
      	Destination.fromString(it)
   	} ?: run {
        Destination.Home
    }
}

With this defined, we can now plug this new piece of state into our Home composable.

@Composable
fun Home(modifier: Modifier = Modifier) {
	val navController = rememberNavController()
	val scaffoldState = rememberScaffoldState()
	val navBackStackEntry = navController.currentBackStackEntryAsState()

	val currentDestination by remember(navBackStackEntry) {
		derivedStateOf {
			navBackStackEntry.value?.destination?.route?.let {
        		Destination.fromString(it)
    		} ?: run {
            	Destination.Home
        	}
    	}
	}

	Scaffold(
  		...
	) {
		Navigation(
            modifier = modifier,
            navController = navController
        )
	}
}

With this in place, we now have what is required to compose our BottomNavigationBar, which we will provide for the composition of the Scaffold bottomBar argument - passing the currentDestination state that we defined above. 

@Composable
fun Home(modifier: Modifier = Modifier) {
	val navController = rememberNavController()
	val scaffoldState = rememberScaffoldState()
	val navBackStackEntry = navController.currentBackStackEntryAsState()

	val currentDestination by remember(navBackStackEntry) {
		derivedStateOf {
			navBackStackEntry.value?.destination?.route?.let {
        		Destination.fromString(it)
    		} ?: run {
            	Destination.Home
        	}
    	}
	}

	Scaffold(
  		...
		bottomBar = {
			BottomNavigationBar(
				currentDestination = currentDestination,
				onNavigate = {
					
                }
            )
		}
	) {
		Navigation(
            modifier = modifier,
            navController = navController
        )
	}
}

With our BottomNavigationBar, we can see that above we have implemented the lambda function, but weâ€™re not currently doing anything in this block. Here weâ€™ll need to handle the navigation event, allowing this trigger to be communicated with our navigation graph. We can trigger this using the navigate function on our navController reference, providing the path of theDestination that we receive from the onNavigate lambda.

navController.navigate(it.path)

However, when navigating via bottom navigation, we can do a few further things to improve this. The navigate function also takes a builder argument that allows us to provide some configuration for the navigation that is taking place. Weâ€™ll start here by utilising popUpTo, which will pop the back stack up until a defined destination, which allows us to avoid building up a large collection of entries within our back stack. When it comes to this, we can access the start destination from our graph via the use of the findStartDestination() function, passing its id to the popUpTo function. This means that when navigation is performed, all back stack entries will be cleared.

navController.navigate(it.path) {
	popUpTo(navController.graph.findStartDestination().id) {
		saveState = true
	}
}

Next we will set the launchSingleTop flag to true. This means that each destination can only have one back stack entry, this avoids duplicate copies existing in our back stack should a destination be reselected.

navController.navigate(it.path) {
	popUpTo(navController.graph.findStartDestination().id) {
		saveState = true
	}
	launchSingleTop = true
}

Finally, weâ€™ll set the restoreState flag to true - this means that if a previously selected item is reselected, its state will be restored.

navController.navigate(it.path) {
	popUpTo(navController.graph.findStartDestination().id) {
		saveState = true
	}
	launchSingleTop = true
	restoreState = true
}

With this all defined, we can now plug this navigation logic into the onNavigate lambda of our BottomNavigationBar composable.

@Composable
fun Home(modifier: Modifier = Modifier) {
	val navController = rememberNavController()
	val scaffoldState = rememberScaffoldState()
	val navBackStackEntry = navController.currentBackStackEntryAsState()

	val currentDestination by remember(navBackStackEntry) {
		derivedStateOf {
			navBackStackEntry.value?.destination?.route?.let {
        		Destination.fromString(it)
    		} ?: run {
            	Destination.Home
        	}
    	}
	}

	Scaffold(
  		...
		bottomBar = {
			BottomNavigationBar(
				currentDestination = currentDestination,
				onNavigate = {
					navController.navigate(it.path) {
						popUpTo(
							navController.graph
								.findStartDestination().id
						) {
							saveState = true
						}
                        launchSingleTop = true
                        restoreState = true
                    }
                }
            )
		}
	) {
		Navigation(
            modifier = modifier,
            navController = navController
        )
	}
}

With this composition in place, at this point, we will be able to use the bottom navigation bar to navigate between the three destinations that are defined in our navigation graph.

Displaying Snackbars

Now that our Scaffold is in place and functional, letâ€™s take a look at what else can be done with the Scaffold. Weâ€™ll start here by exploring the use of Snackbars - these are floating bars that can be used to display short messages within our UI. These can be pretty handy to implement in applications, so letâ€™s take a look at how we can compose these within our UI.

Hopping back over to our Home composable, weâ€™re going to configure our Scaffold so that we can show a Snackbar from within one of our navigation destinations. Weâ€™ll add an action to our TopAppBar that when clicked displays a Snackbar within the Scaffold. Weâ€™ll start here by adding a composable block for the actions argument of the TopAppBar composable. As an example of how we can also configure this to only show for certain destinations, weâ€™ll also configure this so that we only show this menu item when the current destination is not Feed. This means that we can continually compose the actions based on the currentDestination state that we previously defined.

// Home.kt
topBar = {
	TopAppBar(
		title = {
			Text(text = Destination.Home.title)
		},
		actions = {
			if (currentDestination != Destination.Feed) {
				
            }
        }
	)
}

The actions argument takes a composable conformed to the RowScope - this means that the composables you provide will be presented in a horizontal stack. Weâ€™re only going to provide a single action here, which weâ€™ll do so in the form of an IconButton.

topBar = {
	TopAppBar(
		title = {
			Text(text = Destination.Home.title)
		},
		 actions = {
			if (currentDestination != Destination.Feed) {
				IconButton(onClick = {

                }) {
                    
                }
            }
        }
	)
}

ðŸ’¡ The Icon button has the expected touch targets already applied to it, making it a more accessible component over an Icon that has an assigned clickable modifier.

Inside of this IconButton weâ€™re going to display an Icon for a visual representation of our action. Weâ€™ll first define a content description for this within our strings.xml file.

<string name="cd_more_information">
	More information
</string>

Followed by composing an Icon using the Icons.Default.Info icon from the material icons package, passing the string representation for the resource that we just defined.

topBar = {
	TopAppBar(
		title = {
			Text(text = Destination.Home.title)
		},
		 actions = {
			if (currentDestination != Destination.Feed) {
				IconButton(onClick = {

                }) {
                    Icon(
                        imageVector = Icons.Default.Info,
                        contentDescription = stringResource(
							id = R.string.cd_more_information)
                    )
                }
            }
        }
	)
}

With this in place, we now have a menu item that is displayed when either the Calendar or Contacts destinations are displayed. With this in place, we can now use this to trigger the display of a snackbar.

When it comes to showing Snackbars, we can display these through the ScaffoldState that we are providing to our Scaffold composable. The ScaffoldState contains a SnackbarHostState reference, whose showSnackbar function we can use to display Snackbars within our Scaffold. The only thing is that this is a suspending function, meaning that it needs to be launched within a coroutine. When it comes to launching coroutines within composables, weâ€™re going to need somewhere to launch those coroutines - this will take the form of a CoroutineScope, which we can achieve via the rememberCoroutineScope function. As per the documentation, this function will:

Return a CoroutineScope bound to this point in the composition using the optional CoroutineContext provided by getContext.

val coroutineScope = rememberCoroutineScope()

We can then utilise this scope to launch our suspending function.

coroutineScope.launch {
	scaffoldState.snackbarHostState.showSnackbar(...)
}

The above code isnâ€™t going to quite work yet, as we need to provide a string to be displayed inside of our Snackbar. For this weâ€™ll add a new string resource to our strings.xml file that simply indicates that the requested feature is not available yet.

<string name="not_available_yet">Not available yet</string>

Weâ€™ll then retrieve this resource using the stringResource composable, followed by passing the retrieved string to our showSnackbar function call.

topBar = {
	val snackbarMessage = stringResource(
		id = R.string.not_available_yet)
	TopAppBar(
		title = {
			Text(text = Destination.Home.title)
		},
		 actions = {
			if (currentDestination != Destination.Feed) {
				IconButton(onClick = {
                    coroutineScope.launch {
                    	scaffoldState.snackbarHostState
							.showSnackbar(snackbarMessage)
                    }
                }) {
                    Icon(
                        imageVector = Icons.Default.Info,
                        contentDescription = stringResource(
							id = R.string.cd_more_information)
                    )
                }
            }
        }
	)
}

At this point, weâ€™ll now be able to see an action within our TopAppBar, which when clicked will display a Snackbar within our Scaffold.

Creating the Drawer Navigation Graph

For the next UI addition, weâ€™re going to add a navigation drawer to our UI. This will allow users to pull out a navigation drawer from the side of a scaffold, followed by performing navigation to a destination within our graph. The only thing at this point is that we only have 3 destinations in our graph, and those are currently being navigated to via the bottom navigation. In this chapter, weâ€™re going to add some more destinations to our graph so that we can support navigation from our drawer.

When it comes to navigation, we previously defined all of our composable destinations in a single navigation graph.

// Navigation.kt

@Composable
fun Navigation(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    navController: NavHostController
) {
    NavHost(
        modifier = modifier,
        navController = navController,
		startDestination = Destination.Feed.path
    ) {
    	composable(route = Destination.Feed.path) {
			ContentArea(destination = Destination.Feed)
        }
        composable(route = Destination.Contacts.path) {
            ContentArea(destination = Destination.Contacts)
        }
        composable(route = Destination.Calendar.path) {
            ContentArea(destination = Destination.Calendar)
        }
    }
}

The NavHost also supports nested navigation graphs, which allows us to group sets of related destinations together. This not only means we can perform navigation to a feature as a whole, but it also breaks our navigation graph up into a more understandable structure. To see this in action, letâ€™s take our previously defined navigation graph and place it inside of a nested graph.

For this, we need to use the NavGraphBuilder extension function, navigation. This function takes 3 arguments:

  • startDestination: the starting destination for the nested graph. This needs to be one of the destinations contained within the nested graph.
  • route: the route used to navigate to the nested graph.
  • builder: the NavGraphBuilder that represents the destinations of the nested graph.

Weâ€™ll start by wrapping our existing destinations using this navigation function.

navigation(
	startDestination = ...,
	route = ...
) {
	composable(route = Destination.Feed.path) {
    	ContentArea(
            modifier = Modifier.fillMaxSize(),
            destination = Destination.Feed
        )
    }
	composable(route = Destination.Contacts.path) {
		ContentArea(
			modifier = Modifier.fillMaxSize(),
			destination = Destination.Contacts
		)
	}
	composable(route = Destination.Calendar.path) {
		ContentArea(
			modifier = Modifier.fillMaxSize(),
			destination = Destination.Calendar
		)
    }
}

Even though weâ€™ve provided the destinations here for the builder argument of the function, youâ€™ll notice here that we need to provide values for the startDestination and route arguments. When we previously defined the graph for our NavHost, we set the Destination.Feed as the starting destination for our graph. Weâ€™re going to do the same here and set this as the starting destination for our nested graph.

Weâ€™ll also need to provide a route for our nested graph, this is so that our nested graph can be navigated to. Weâ€™re going to need to add a new Destination type to our destination class, which weâ€™ll call Home. This will be used for the root level destinations within our scaffold - the feed, calendar and contacts.

object Home : Destination("home")

With this in place, we can now provide the path of this as the route of our nested graph.

navigation(
	startDestination = Destination.Feed.path,
	route = Destination.Home.path
) {
	composable(route = Destination.Feed.path) {
    	ContentArea(
            modifier = Modifier.fillMaxSize(),
            destination = Destination.Feed
        )
    }
	composable(route = Destination.Contacts.path) {
		ContentArea(
			modifier = Modifier.fillMaxSize(),
			destination = Destination.Contacts
		)
	}
	composable(route = Destination.Calendar.path) {
		ContentArea(
			modifier = Modifier.fillMaxSize(),
			destination = Destination.Calendar
		)
    }
}

Now that the Feed destination is within a nested graph, we need to update the startDestination of our NavHost to reflect a top-level destination route. For this, weâ€™ll use the Home destination that we set as the route of our nested navigation graph. We were previously using the Feed as the startDestination of our NavHost, using this Home destination will have the same effect as we are now referencing the nested navigation graph which in turn has the Feed as its starting destination.

@Composable
fun Navigation(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    navController: NavHostController
) {
    NavHost(
        modifier = modifier,
        navController = navController,
        startDestination = Destination.Home.path
    ) {
        navigation(
            startDestination = Destination.Feed.path,
            route = Destination.Home.path
        ) {
            composable(route = Destination.Feed.path) {
                ContentArea(
                    modifier = Modifier.fillMaxSize(),
                    destination = Destination.Feed
                )
            }
            composable(route = Destination.Contacts.path) {
                ContentArea(
                    modifier = Modifier.fillMaxSize(),
                    destination = Destination.Contacts
                )
            }
            composable(route = Destination.Calendar.path) {
                ContentArea(
                    modifier = Modifier.fillMaxSize(),
                    destination = Destination.Calendar
                )
            }
        }
    }
}

With the above in place, we can now add two new destinations that will be navigated to from our navigation drawer - Settings and Upgrade. Weâ€™ll add new declarations for these inside of our Destination class.

object Settings : Destination("settings", Icons.Default.Settings)
object Upgrade : Destination("upgrade", Icons.Default.Star)

Weâ€™ll also need to add support for these within our fromString function.

companion object {

	fun fromString(label: String): Destination {
        return when (label) {
            Feed.path -> Feed
            Calendar.path -> Calendar
            Contacts.path -> Contacts
            Upgrade.path -> Upgrade
            Settings.path -> Settings
            else -> Home
        }
    }
}

Now that we have these destinations available, we can add these as composable routes to our navigation graph. Even though we converted the initial destinations to be within a nested graph, these two new destinations are not going to be part of a nested graph - theyâ€™re just going to sit at the top level. Either way of approaching this here would be an acceptable approach - however, not only does leaving these at the top-level allow us to demonstrate how to use top-level and nested destinations together, these destinations are not related in any way so it feels appropriate to keep them individual for now.

Weâ€™ll add these to the graph in the same way that weâ€™ve added the other composable destinations with their corresponding ContentArea composables, using the corresponding Destination classes to compose the UI.

@Composable
fun Navigation(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    navController: NavHostController
) {
    NavHost(
        modifier = modifier,
        navController = navController,
        startDestination = Destination.Home.path
    ) {
        navigation(
            startDestination = Destination.Feed.path,
            route = Destination.Home.path
        ) {
            composable(route = Destination.Feed.path) {
                ContentArea(
                    modifier = Modifier.fillMaxSize(),
                    destination = Destination.Feed
                )
            }
            composable(route = Destination.Contacts.path) {
                ContentArea(
                    modifier = Modifier.fillMaxSize(),
                    destination = Destination.Contacts
                )
            }
            composable(route = Destination.Calendar.path) {
                ContentArea(
                    modifier = Modifier.fillMaxSize(),
                    destination = Destination.Calendar
                )
            }
        }

        composable(route = Destination.Upgrade.path) {
            ContentArea(
                modifier = Modifier.fillMaxSize(),
                Destination.Upgrade
            )
        }

        composable(route = Destination.Settings.path) {
            ContentArea(
                modifier = Modifier.fillMaxSize(),
                Destination.Settings
            )
        }
    }
}

With this in place, we now have support for additional destinations within our navigation graph. In the next chapter, weâ€™ll look at implementing the navigation drawer, allowing us to trigger navigation to these destinations.

Adding a Navigation Drawer

Now that we have the additions in place for our navigation graph, we can go ahead and implement the navigation drawer that will be used to trigger the navigation events to these new destinations. For this, weâ€™re going to create a composable function that can be used as the content for the drawerContent argument of the Scaffold composable.

drawerContent: @Composable (ColumnScope.() -> Unit)? = null

We can notice one key thing here for the drawerContent argument, the declaration of the ColumnScope - this means that the composable content that we provide will adhere to this scope, which is because the drawer represents a vertically stacked space. With that in mind, weâ€™ll go ahead and create a new ColumnScope composable.

@Composable
fun ColumnScope.DrawerContent()

ðŸ’¡ Scopes are a great way of enforcing composition behaviour to your composable functions.

The content of this composable is going to be quite simple, as per the design. Weâ€™re going to start by creating a heading section that displays an account name and email - which weâ€™ll need to add some new string resources for.

<string name="label_name">Compose Academy</string>
<string name="label_email">contact@compose.academy</string>

We can now configure a couple of Text composables using these new string resources.

@Composable
fun ColumnScope.DrawerContent() {
    Text(
        modifier = Modifier.padding(16.dp),
        text = stringResource(id = R.string.label_name),
        fontSize = 20.sp
    )
    Spacer(modifier = Modifier.height(8.dp))
    Text(
        modifier = Modifier.padding(16.dp),
        text = stringResource(id = R.string.label_email),
        fontSize = 16.sp
    )
}

Weâ€™ll also add the use of the Divider composable so that we can create some visible separation between the header of our navigation drawer, and the items that will follow it. Weâ€™ll use the fillMaxWidth modifier to ensure the divider fills the width of the drawer, along with the padding modifier to create some spacing between the edges of the drawer and the divider, as well as some visual space between any composables above and below it.

@Composable
fun ColumnScope.DrawerContent() {
	Text(
        modifier = Modifier.padding(16.dp),
        text = stringResource(id = R.string.label_name),
        fontSize = 20.sp
    )
    Spacer(modifier = Modifier.height(8.dp))
    Text(
        modifier = Modifier.padding(16.dp),
        text = stringResource(id = R.string.label_email),
        fontSize = 16.sp
    )

    Divider(
        modifier = Modifier
            .fillMaxWidth()
            .padding(horizontal = 16.dp, vertical = 8.dp)
    )
}

Next, weâ€™re going to add some items which will be used to trigger events from our navigation drawer. Here weâ€™re going to have three items:

  • Settings: this will be used to navigate to the settings composable.
  • Upgrade: this will be used to navigate to the upgrade composable.
  • Logout: this will be used to logout from the application. We wonâ€™t be implementing any logout logic, this will be purely for example purposes.

All of these three items in the drawer are going to be represented in the same way, so letâ€™s create a new composable function inside of our Drawer.kt file, DrawerItem. Each drawer item is going to have some same properties that are used in its representation:

  • modifier: used to control the visual constraints of the composable
  • label: used to display a textual label
  • onClicked: used to receive click events from the composable
@Composable
fun DrawerItem(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    label: String,
    onClick: () -> Unit
)

Within this composable, weâ€™re going to define a single Text composable. Weâ€™ll use the label to set the text of our composable function, replacing the first character of this label with the uppercase equivalent in the process.

@Composable
fun DrawerItem(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    label: String,
    onClick: () -> Unit
) {
    Text(
        text = label.replaceFirstChar {
            it.titlecase(Locale.getDefault())
        }
    )
}

Weâ€™ll also need to set some modifiers for the composable. Weâ€™ll start by adding the clickable modifier so that we can trigger the onClick lambda that is being provided to our DrawerItem composable. This allows us to pass click events up to any parent composable. 

@Composable
fun DrawerItem(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    label: String,
    onClick: () -> Unit
) {
    Text(
        text = label.replaceFirstChar {
            it.titlecase(Locale.getDefault())
        },
        modifier = modifier
            .clickable {
                onClick()
            }
    )
}

Currently, though, the touch target for our composable isnâ€™t very accessible. The composable content is also pressed closely against the edge of the content area.

To improve this weâ€™ll also apply the padding modifier. This will not only increase the touch target of our composable but also give it sufficient spacing from the edge of its bounds.

@Composable
fun DrawerItem(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    label: String,
    onClick: () -> Unit
) {
    Text(
        text = label.replaceFirstChar {
            it.titlecase(Locale.getDefault())
        },
        modifier = modifier
            .clickable {
                onClick()
            }
			.padding(16.dp)
    )
}

With this DrawerItem composable in place, we can now compose it inside of our DrawerContent composable. For this first instance, weâ€™re going to create a drawer item for the Upgrade destination. This means that weâ€™ll pass the Upgrade path for the label argument of the DrawerItem. Weâ€™ll also use the fillMaxWidth to enforce our composable to fill the maximum available width from the drawer.

@Composable
fun ColumnScope.DrawerContent(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier
) {
    ...
    DrawerItem(
        modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
        label = Destination.Upgrade.path
    ) {

    }
}

Youâ€™ll notice here that we havenâ€™t yet implemented any logic inside of the onClick lambda. Here weâ€™ll want to pass the event up to the parent composable so that the selected Destination can be navigated to. For this weâ€™ll need to add a new argument to our composable function, this will be in the form of a lambda function that has a Destination as a parameter.

onNavigationSelected: (destination: Destination) -> Unit

With this we can then trigger this lambda within the onClick implementation, using the Upgrade destination as the destination type.

@Composable
fun ColumnScope.DrawerContent(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    onNavigationSelected: (destination: Destination) -> Unit
) {
    ...
    DrawerItem(
        modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
        label = Destination.Upgrade.path
    ) {
        onNavigationSelected(Destination.Upgrade)
    }
}

Now that weâ€™ve implemented this DrawerItem composable for the Upgrade destination, we can do the same for the Settings destination. After composing a Spacer to create some visual space, weâ€™ll go ahead and compose another DrawerItem for the Settings destination.

@Composable
fun ColumnScope.DrawerContent(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    onNavigationSelected: (destination: Destination) -> Unit
) {
    ...
    DrawerItem(
        modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
        label = Destination.Upgrade.path
    ) {
        onNavigationSelected(Destination.Upgrade)
    }
	Spacer(modifier = Modifier.height(8.dp))
    DrawerItem(
        modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
        label = Destination.Settings.path
    ) {
        onNavigationSelected(Destination.Settings)
    }
}

Alongside the navigation to these two destinations, weâ€™re also going to add support for logging out of the application from our navigation drawer. Weâ€™ll also need another callback for this, so weâ€™ll add a onLogout lambda as an argument for our composable function.

@Composable
fun ColumnScope.DrawerContent(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    onNavigationSelected: (destination: Destination) -> Unit,
    onLogout: () -> Unit
)

Weâ€™ll also need to add another string to our strings.xml resource file.

<string name="log_out">Log Out</string>

With that in place we can now compose another DrawerItem - passing the string that was just defined for the label argument, along with triggering our onLogout() lambda from within the onClick callback.

@Composable
fun ColumnScope.DrawerContent(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    onNavigationSelected: (destination: Destination) -> Unit,
    onLogout: () -> Unit
) {
    ...
    DrawerItem(
        modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
        label = Destination.Upgrade.path
    ) {
        onNavigationSelected(Destination.Upgrade)
    }
	Spacer(modifier = Modifier.height(8.dp))
    DrawerItem(
        modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
        label = Destination.Settings.path
    ) {
        onNavigationSelected(Destination.Settings)
    }
    DrawerItem(
		modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
        label = stringResource(id = R.string.log_out)
    ) {
        onLogout()
    }
}

Currently, with this logout item, it looks a little odd how this is positioned in our navigation drawer.

Instead, we can push this item to the bottom of our drawer to ensure that it is separated from the rest of our navigation items. Weâ€™ll start by composing a Spacer above our logout item, applying a weight of 1 via the weight modifier - this will force the Spacer to use all of the remaining vertical space, pushing the logout item to the bottom of the drawer. Weâ€™ll also add a Spacer beneath the logout item, just to create some visual space at the bottom of the drawer.

@Composable
fun ColumnScope.DrawerContent(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    onNavigationSelected: (destination: Destination) -> Unit,
    onLogout: () -> Unit
) {
    ...
    DrawerItem(
        modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
        label = Destination.Upgrade.path
    ) {
        onNavigationSelected(Destination.Upgrade)
    }
	Spacer(modifier = Modifier.height(8.dp))
    DrawerItem(
        modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
        label = Destination.Settings.path
    ) {
        onNavigationSelected(Destination.Settings)
    }
	Spacer(
        modifier = Modifier
            .weight(1f)
    )
    DrawerItem(
		modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
        label = stringResource(id = R.string.log_out)
    ) {
        onLogout()
    }
    Spacer(modifier = Modifier.height(8.dp))

}

With this in place, we now have the content for our navigation drawer implemented:

Add the navigation drawer to our scaffold

Before we go ahead and compose the navigation drawer content, we need to enable drawer functionality within our scaffold. For this, weâ€™ll hop back over to our Home composable to make a few modifications. To configure and control the navigation drawer within our Scaffold, weâ€™re going to need to obtain an instance to a DrawerState - weâ€™ll want to have the ability to open and close the drawer on request, which is what weâ€™ll use this class for. From the compose material package, we can utilise the rememberDrawerState function to obtain a reference to this class that will be persisted across recompositions. When using this function we can also provide a default state to be used for the drawer, which weâ€™ll do so in the form of DrawerValue.Closed - meaning that the drawer of our scaffold will be closed by default.

val drawerState = rememberDrawerState(DrawerValue.Closed)

With this in place within our Home composable, weâ€™ll then need to provide this reference when using rememberScaffoldState to obtain a reference to a ScaffoldState.

val scaffoldState = rememberScaffoldState(drawerState)

At this point, our Scaffold is configured to contain a navigation drawer, but we donâ€™t have any way of displaying it. For this weâ€™re going to add a drawer icon to our top app bar, using this to trigger an open even on our DrawerState.

Within our TopAppBar weâ€™ll use the navigationIcon argument to provide an Icon that can be used to trigger this open event. Here weâ€™ll provide an IconButton composable that will be used to trigger the suspending open function from our DrawerState reference.

topBar = {
	val snackbarMessage = stringResource(
		id = R.string.not_available_yet)
	TopAppBar(
		title = {
			Text(text = Destination.Home.title)
		},
		navigationIcon = {
            IconButton(onClick = {
                coroutineScope.launch {
                	drawerState.open()
                }
            }) {
                
            }
        },
		actions = {
			if (currentDestination != Destination.Feed) {
				IconButton(onClick = {
                    coroutineScope.launch {
                    	scaffoldState.snackbarHostState
							.showSnackbar(snackbarMessage)
                    }
                }) {
                    Icon(
                        imageVector = Icons.Default.Info,
                        contentDescription = stringResource(
							id = R.string.cd_more_information)
                    )
                }
            }
        }
	)
}

Weâ€™ll also need to add an Icon for the content of our IconButton, so weâ€™ll first add a content description string to our resources.

<string name="cd_open_menu">Open Menu</string>

And then compose an Icon for the content of our IconButton, using the Icons.Default.Menu for the icon of our composable.

topBar = {
	val snackbarMessage = stringResource(
		id = R.string.not_available_yet)
	TopAppBar(
		title = {
			Text(text = Destination.Home.title)
		},
		navigationIcon = {
            IconButton(onClick = {
                coroutineScope.launch {
                	drawerState.open()
                }
            }) {
                Icon(
                    imageVector = Icons.Default.Menu,
                    contentDescription = stringResource(
						id = R.string.cd_open_menu)
                )
            }
        },
		actions = {
			if (currentDestination != Destination.Feed) {
				IconButton(onClick = {
                    coroutineScope.launch {
                    	scaffoldState.snackbarHostState
							.showSnackbar(snackbarMessage)
                    }
                }) {
                    Icon(
                        imageVector = Icons.Default.Info,
                        contentDescription = stringResource(
							id = R.string.cd_more_information)
                    )
                }
            }
        }
	)
}

With this in place, we now have a navigation icon within our TopAppBar that when clicked will open the navigation drawer.

Adding the drawer content to the scaffold

Whatâ€™s left for us to do now is to slot this into our Scaffold so that we can view our drawer content, this will be done using the Scaffold drawerContent argument. When composing this, weâ€™ll use the fillMaxWidth modifier to ensure that our drawer uses the available width, along with adding some empty blocks for the onNavigationSelected and onLogout arguments. 

Scaffold(
	...,
 	drawerContent = {
		DrawerContent(
			modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
			onNavigationSelected = {
				
			},
			onLogout = {
				// handle logout
			}
		)
  	}
) {
  ...
}

As previously mentioned, weâ€™re not going to be handling the logout functionality, so weâ€™ll leave this comment in place. However, we do need to support navigation - within the onNavigationSelected implementation weâ€™ll need to use our navController reference to trigger its navigate function. Here weâ€™ll pass the path of the Destination that the lambda provides us with, which will trigger navigation to the corresponding composable in our navigation graph.

onNavigationSelected = { destination ->
	navController.navigate(destination.path)
}

At this point weâ€™ll also want to close the navigation drawer, this is because the user has navigated to a new destination - so it doesnâ€™t make sense to keep this in view. The DrawerState that we previously created a reference to contains a close function that we can trigger here, but this will need to be done within a CoroutineScope because close is a suspending function. Here weâ€™ll use our previously defined coroutineScope to launch our close operation.

onNavigationSelected = {
	navController.navigate(it.path)
	coroutineScope.launch {
		drawerState.close()
	}
}

With this in place, we now have a navigation drawer that can be opened from the navigation icon in the top app bar, using it to navigate to different destinations in our app.

Scaffold(
	...,
 	drawerContent = {
		DrawerContent(
			modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
			onNavigationSelected = {
				navController.navigate(it.path)
				coroutineScope.launch {
					drawerState.close()
				}
			},
			onLogout = {
				// handle logout
			}
		)
  	}
) {
  ...
}

Supporting multiple navigation bar types

Now that weâ€™ve added the ability to navigate to destinations from the navigation drawer, we might notice some unexpected visuals in our TopAppBar. In the last section, we added the drawer icon to the TopAppBar - this allows the user to open the navigation drawer to select a navigation item from. However, this should only be visible from the root destinations, when the bottom navigation bar is displayed. As soon as a user navigates to a higher level destination (such as the settings or upgrade composables), weâ€™ll not want this drawer icon to be composed. To be able to compose based on these properties, weâ€™ll need to know what is a root destination and what isnâ€™t. To be aware of this we can modify our Destination class to include a boolean flag, isRootDestination. We can then provide a value here for each Destination and avoid having to check for specific Destination types within our code.

sealed class Destination(
    val path: String,
    val icon: ImageVector? = null,
    val isRootDestination: Boolean = true
)

Weâ€™ll then need to update the different types of Destination that we have. Weâ€™ve set the default value to true, so weâ€™ll need to specify here what Destination types are not root destinations.

object Home : Destination(path = "home")

object Feed : Destination(
	path = "feed", 	
	icon = Icons.Default.List
)

object Contacts : Destination(
	path = "contacts", 
	icon = Icons.Default.Person
)

object Calendar : Destination(
	path = "gallery",
	icon = Icons.Default.DateRange
)

object Settings : Destination(
	path = "settings", 
	icon = Icons.Default.Settings, 
	isRootDestination = false
)

object Upgrade : Destination(
	path = "upgrade", 
	icon = Icons.Default.Star, 
	isRootDestination = false
)

With this in place, weâ€™ve now marked all destinations that are not the Feed, Calendar or Contacts as not being root destinations. We can use this isRootDestination flag within our code to determine whether the Destination is currently at the root or not.

Creating a level-specific app bar

Now that we have this isRootDestination flag available, we can use this to compose a TopAppBar that is specific to the Destination level. While we could have a single TopAppBar, these are going to be quite different - so it will be cleaner and easier to understand if we have separate composables for these. First, weâ€™ll focus on the TopAppBar for the root destination of the project. For this, weâ€™re essentially going to be taking the TopAppBar that we had previously created and placing it inside of its own composable function. 

topBar = {
	val snackbarMessage = stringResource(
		id = R.string.not_available_yet)
	TopAppBar(
		title = {
			Text(text = Destination.Home.title)
		},
		navigationIcon = {
            IconButton(onClick = {
                coroutineScope.launch {
                	drawerState.open()
                }
            }) {
                Icon(
                    imageVector = Icons.Default.Menu,
                    contentDescription = stringResource(
						id = R.string.cd_open_menu)
                )
            }
        },
		actions = {
			if (currentDestination != Destination.Feed) {
				IconButton(onClick = {
                    coroutineScope.launch {
                    	scaffoldState.snackbarHostState
							.showSnackbar(snackbarMessage)
                    }
                }) {
                    Icon(
                        imageVector = Icons.Default.Info,
                        contentDescription = stringResource(
							id = R.string.cd_more_information)
                    )
                }
            }
        }
	)
}

The only thing that will be different here is that we wonâ€™t have access to everything that we have in the Home composable, so weâ€™re going to need to pass in some things via the function arguments. These arguments will need to be:

  • modifier: similar to previous composables weâ€™ve created, we want to allow the parent composable to provide modifiers to the composable to enforce certain constraints.
  • currentDestination: the current destination is used to filter out specific things from being composed, so weâ€™ll need access to this within our composable.
  • openDrawer: within the navigationIcon composable argument we trigger the opening of the navigation drawer. To avoid passing in the coroutine scope and the drawer state, weâ€™ll pass this event up so that the parent composable can handle it.
  • showSnackbar: within the actions composable argument we trigger the display of a snacker. To avoid having to pass in the coroutine scope and the scaffold state, weâ€™ll pass this event up so that the parent composable can handle it.
// RootDestinationTopBar.kt
@Composable
fun RootDestinationTopBar(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    currentDestination: Destination,
    openDrawer: () -> Unit,
    showSnackbar: (message: String) -> Unit
)

We can then plug our existing TopAppBar composable into this composable function.

@Composable
fun RootDestinationTopBar(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    currentDestination: Destination,
    openDrawer: () -> Unit,
    showSnackbar: (message: String) -> Unit
) {
    TopAppBar(
        modifier = modifier,
        title = {
            Text(text = Destination.Home.title)
        },
        navigationIcon = {
            IconButton(onClick = {
                openDrawer()
            }) {
                Icon(
                    imageVector = Icons.Default.Menu,
                    contentDescription = stringResource(
						id = R.string.cd_open_menu)
                )
            }
        },
        actions = {
            if (currentDestination != Destination.Feed) {
                val snackbarMessage = stringResource(
					id = R.string.not_available_yet)
                IconButton(onClick = {
                    showSnackbar(snackbarMessage)
                }) {
                    Icon(
                        imageVector = Icons.Default.Info,
                        contentDescription = stringResource(
							id = R.string.cd_more_information)
                    )
                }
            }
        }
    )
}

Here we now use the openDrawer lambda inside of the navigationIcon composable - this is instead of directly using the coroutine scope and drawer state. This lambda function is used to pass the event up to the parent composable. We also now use the showSnackbar lambda function within the actions composable - again, avoiding us passing in various state references to our composable function. Aside from these, our composable is the same as we had it previously - itâ€™s just now defined in its own composable function.

Creating the higher level Top App Bar

Now that we have a TopAppBar defined for use in our root destinations, we now need to think about the app bar that is going to be used for destinations that are not root destinations. For this weâ€™ll create a new composable, ChildDestinationTopBar.

// ChildDestinationTopBar.kt
@Composable
fun ChildDestinationTopBar(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier
    title: String
)

Here we provide a modifier argument for our composable function along with its default value, as well as a title in the form of a string - this will be used to show the name of the destination that has been navigated to. Using these we can now compose a TopAppBar, along with a Text composable to be used for the title of the bar.

@Composable
fun ChildDestinationTopBar(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier
    title: String
) {
    TopAppBar(
        modifier = modifier,
        title = {
            Text(text = title)
        }
    )
}

Because weâ€™re in a higher level destination than that of a root, weâ€™re going to want to provide a way for users to navigate â€˜upâ€™ to the previous destination (which will be the root of our app). In the same way, as we handle other events in our child composables, weâ€™re going to pass this event up to the parent. So weâ€™ll need to start by adding a new argument to our composable function in the form of a lambda.

@Composable
fun ChildDestinationTopBar(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    onNavigateUp: () -> Unit,
    title: String
)

With this in place, we can now compose an IconButton within the navigationIcon block of our TopAppBar. This IconButton will be used to trigger our onUpClicked lambda, along with composing an Icon within its content area using the Icons.Default.ArrowBack icon.

@Composable
fun ChildDestinationTopBar(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    onNavigateUp: () -> Unit,
    title: String
) {
    TopAppBar(
        modifier = modifier,
        title = {
            Text(text = title)
        },
        navigationIcon = {
            IconButton(onClick = {
                onNavigateUp()
            }) {
                Icon(
                    imageVector = Icons.Default.ArrowBack,
                    contentDescription = ...
                )
            }
        }
    )
}

To finalise our Icon weâ€™ll need to add a content description, starting with adding a new string to our strings.xml resources.

<string name="cd_navigate_up">Go back Home</string>

Followed by using the stringResource function to assign this to the contentDescription of our Icon.

@Composable
fun ChildDestinationTopBar(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    onNavigateUp: () -> Unit,
    title: String
) {
    TopAppBar(
        modifier = modifier,
        title = {
            Text(text = title)
        },
        navigationIcon = {
            IconButton(onClick = {
                onNavigateUp()
            }) {
                Icon(
                    imageVector = Icons.Default.ArrowBack,
                    contentDescription = stringResource(
						id = R.string.cd_navigate_up)
                )
            }
        }
    )
}

Composing the Top App Bar

At this point we have our two individual app bars, we just need to compose one based on the current destination within the navigation graph. For this, weâ€™re going to create another composable function that will be responsible for composing the app bar based on the current root status. This composable function is going to take a combination of the arguments that we defined for our individual app bar functions, this is so that it can pass those arguments into the corresponding composable functions.

@Composable
fun DestinationTopBar(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    destination: Destination,
	onNavigateUp: () -> Unit,
    onOpenDrawer: () -> Unit,
    showSnackbar: (message: String) -> Unit
)

At this point we have a reference to the current Destination reference, so weâ€™re going to use this to depict what app bar should be composed. Here we will use a simple if statement to determine whether we are going to compose the RootDestinationTopBar or the ChildDestinationTopBar.

@Composable
fun DestinationTopBar(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    destination: Destination,
    onNavigateUp: () -> Unit,
    onOpenDrawer: () -> Unit,
    showSnackbar: (message: String) -> Unit
) {
    if (destination.isRootDestination) {
        RootDestinationTopBar(
            modifier,
            destination = destination,
            openDrawer = onOpenDrawer,
            showSnackbar = showSnackbar
        )
    } else {
        ChildDestinationTopBar(
            modifier,
            onNavigateUp,
            destination.title
        )
    }
}

With this composable now in place, we can head back over to our Home composable and adjust the composition of the topBar within our Scaffold. Here weâ€™re now going to compose our DestinationTopBar composable, implementing each of its required arguments.

  • destination: for the destination, we can simply pass the currentDestination reference that is being calculated based on the current destination of our navigation graph.
  • onNavigateUp: within this lambda implementation we will use our navController reference to trigger the popBackStack function. From a composable that has been navigated to, this will take the user back â€˜upâ€™ to our root composable.
  • onOpenDrawer: here we want to open the navigation drawer, so weâ€™ll handle this in the same way that we were previously - using the coroutineScope and drawerState references.
  • showSnackbar: to show the Snackbar weâ€™ll also handle this in the same way that we were before, using the coroutineScope and scaffoldState references.
topBar = {
	DestinationTopBar(
		destination = currentDestination,
		onNavigateUp = {
			navController.popBackStack()
		},
		onOpenDrawer = {
			coroutineScope.launch {
				drawerState.open()
			}
		},
		showSnackbar = {
			coroutineScope.launch {
				scaffoldState.snackbarHostState
					.showSnackbar(it)
            }
        }
    )
}

Here we now have our new Top Bar implementation that is being used to compose a TopAppBar depending on the current destination of our navigation graph. When running the project weâ€™ll now be able to see that the app bar implementation provides expected results based on whether the user is at the root of our app, or has navigated to a composable outside of the Home graph.

Supporting FAB interactions

Within our Scaffold we had added a FloatingActionButton, but this is not currently triggering anything within our project. Weâ€™re going to trigger another feature of our app here, allowing us to add another nested graph to our navigation setup. Weâ€™ll call this feature Creation, for which weâ€™ll need to define a new Destination. 

object Creation : Destination(
	path = "creation", 
	isRootDestination = false
)

Creation is only the feature for this nested graph, it does not relate to the actual destinations contained within it, so weâ€™ll need to define an actual destination within Creation. Here weâ€™re going to launch a placeholder screen that would allow our user to create some content within our app - weâ€™ll only define a single destination within this feature, Add.

For this, weâ€™ll use the Icons.Default.Add icon from the material package, along with setting the isRootDestination flag to false - as this is not going to be a feature at the root of our navigation graph.

object Add : Destination(
	path = "add", 
	icon = Icons.Default.Add, 
	isRootDestination = false
)

Weâ€™ll also need to update the fromString function to account for this additional Destination.

companion object {

	fun fromString(label: String): Destination {
        return when (label) {
            Feed.path -> Feed
            Calendar.path -> Calendar
            Contacts.path -> Contacts
            Upgrade.path -> Upgrade
            Settings.path -> Settings
			Add.path -> Add
			Creation.path -> Creation
            else -> Home
        }
    }
}

With this in place, we now need to add this destination to our navigation graph. For this weâ€™re going to utilise a nested graph, in the same way, that we have done for the Home nested graph. In a real scenario, this would likely be a feature that would have multiple destinations contained within it, so this nested graph sets us up in a good position for that. Weâ€™ll use the Creation destination as the route for the nested graph, using the Add destination for the composable contained inside of the graph.

navigation(
	startDestination = Destination.Add.path,
	route = Destination.Creation.path
) {
	composable(route = Destination.Add.path) {
		ContentArea(
			modifier = Modifier.fillMaxSize(),
			destination = Destination.Add
		)
	}
}

With this defined, we can now navigate to this destination within our graph. We already have most of the FloatingActionButton configured within our Home, so weâ€™ll now need to trigger the navigation to our Creation feature. Here weâ€™ll use our navController to trigger the navigation command, passing in the path to our Creation destination.

floatingActionButton = {
	if (currentDestination == Destination.Feed) {
		FloatingActionButton(,
			onClick = {
            	navController.navigate(
					Destination.Creation.path)
			}
        ) {
			Icon(
				imageVector = Icons.Default.Add,
                contentDescription = 		
					stringResource(R.string.cd_create_item)
            )
        }
    }
}

Within our graph, we defined the Add destination as the starting point for the nested Creation graph. So when this navigation is triggered, the Add destination will be navigated to.

Supporting multiple device orientations

Now that most of our UI and navigational logic is in place, weâ€™re going to explore how we can support different kinds of devices and representations of what we have built. Currently, our UI is using a fixed portrait format - this means that if the user is on a larger device or are using their device in landscape mode, then the UI wonâ€™t be providing an optimised experience.

In this section, weâ€™re going to take a look at how we can optimise the UI for these different experiences. One key part of this is going to be how the device behaves in providing a better landscape representation, as this will handle a range of experiences from mobile to desktop devices. For this, weâ€™re going to explore conditionally replacing the Bottom Navigation that we previously implemented, using a Navigation Rail in its place for devices using landscape modes.

Generalising Navigation Items

Before we start to create the second type of navigation bar that is supported in our app, weâ€™re going to look at how we can refactor the existing implementation so that its logic is reusable. Currently, our BottomNavigationBar is looking a little something like this:

@Composable
fun BottomNavigationBar(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    currentDestination: Destination,
    onNavigate: (destination: Destination) -> Unit
) {
    BottomNavigation(
        modifier = modifier.testTag(Tags.TAG_NAVIGATION_BAR)
    ) {
        listOf(
            Destination.Feed,
            Destination.Contacts,
            Destination.Calendar
        ).forEach {
            BottomNavigationItem(
                selected = currentDestination.path == it.path,
                onClick = {
                    onNavigate(it)
                },
                icon = {
                    it.icon?.let { image ->
                        Icon(
							imageVector = image, 
							contentDescription = it.path
						)
                    }
                },
                label = {
                    Text(text = it.title)
                }
            )
        }
    }
}

When it comes to the navigation rail, weâ€™re still going to display those same navigation items - and the logic for that display is going to look the same, so weâ€™ll want to pull that out into a reusable piece of code. Weâ€™re going to start there by creating a new function, buildNavigationBarItems - this function is going to be responsible for building the different navigation destinations for our navigation bars.

fun buildNavigationBarItems() {

}

What we would want to do here ideally is compose the navigation items - however, because weâ€™re going to be sharing this between a BottomNavigation and NavigationRail, sharing composition is not so simple. When it comes to the BottomNavigation composable, its content uses the RowScope which gives us access to the BottomNavigationItem composable. However, the NavigationRail content uses the ColumnScope, meaning that if we were to share composition between these two composables, we would be unable to use scoped composables such as the BottomNavigationItem. Instead what weâ€™ll do is use this function to build the common requirements for a destination, returning that information for the parent composable to use for composition. This means that the BottomNavigation and NavigationRail will be responsible for composing the navigation items, using the common information that is provided to them.

For this common data, weâ€™re going to create a new class called NavigationBarItem. This class will be used to represent each of the navigation items that need to be displayed inside of the navigation bars.

class NavigationBarItem(
    val selected: Boolean,
    val onClick: () -> Unit,
    val icon: @Composable () -> Unit,
    val label: @Composable () -> Unit
)

With this class defined, we now have a contract for the data types that are going to be returned from our function.

fun buildNavigationBarItems(): List<NavigationBarItem>

Now, using the previously defined Destinations that are being displayed inside of the current bottom navigation, weâ€™re going to want to map these to an equivalent NavigationBarItem representation. 

fun buildNavigationBarItems(): List<NavigationBarItem> {
    return listOf(
        Destination.Feed,
        Destination.Contacts,
        Destination.Calendar
    ).map {
        NavigationBarItem(
            ...
        )
    }
}

The NavigationBarItem has four different properties that need to be provided in-order to provide a completed representation of the class. Weâ€™ll start here with the label that is used to display textual context for a given destination. For this, weâ€™ll provide a Text composable that will be used to represent this label, we just need to provide a value for its text. Here weâ€™ll take the path property of the given Destination, converting the first character of the word to uppercase.

fun buildNavigationBarItems(): List<NavigationBarItem> {
    return listOf(
        Destination.Feed,
        Destination.Contacts,
        Destination.Calendar
    ).map {
        NavigationBarItem(
            label = {
                Text(text = it.path.replaceFirstChar { char ->
                    char.titlecase(Locale.getDefault())
                })
            }
        )
    }
}

Next up we have the icon, this is also going to be displayed within the destination for the navigation bar. If the Destination has an icon available, then here weâ€™ll want to compose an Icon using this available icon. We donâ€™t need to provide a content description here because we already have the path of the Destination that is providing navigational context.

fun buildNavigationBarItems(): List<NavigationBarItem> {
    return listOf(
        Destination.Feed,
        Destination.Contacts,
        Destination.Calendar
    ).map {
        NavigationBarItem(
       		icon = {
                it.icon?.let { image ->
                    Icon(
						imageVector = image, 
						contentDescription = null
					)
                }
            },
            label = {
                Text(text = it.path.replaceFirstChar { char ->
                    char.titlecase(Locale.getDefault())
                })
            }
        )
    }
}

Next, we have the selected property - this will depict whether the giving Destination is currently selected within the navigation bar. For this, the function is going to need a little more information about what is the currently selected Destination, so weâ€™ll add this as an argument to the function. 

fun buildNavigationBarItems(
    currentDestination: Destination
)

With this in place, we can now use this to calculate the selected value. If here the path of the currentDestination is equal to the path of the Destination that we are currently building a NavigationBarItem for, then the item is to be recognised as selected. We can represent this by checking for equality against these two values.

fun buildNavigationBarItems(
    currentDestination: Destination
): List<NavigationBarItem> {
    return listOf(
        Destination.Feed,
        Destination.Contacts,
        Destination.Calendar
    ).map {
        NavigationBarItem(
            selected = currentDestination.path == it.path,
            icon = {
                it.icon?.let { image ->
                    Icon(
						imageVector = image, 
						contentDescription = null
					)
                }
            },
            label = {
                Text(text = it.path.replaceFirstChar { char ->
                    char.titlecase(Locale.getDefault())
                })
            }
        )
    }
}

For the last property, we have the onClick property. This is going to be used as a callback to be triggered whenever the navigation item is clicked, which is something weâ€™re going to want to pass up to the parent composable to handle navigation. For this weâ€™ll want to define another function argument, allowing us to pass up the Destination that is being navigated to. 

fun buildNavigationBarItems(
    currentDestination: Destination,
    onNavigate: (destination: Destination) -> Unit
)

With this in place, we can now trigger this onNavigate lambda from within the onClick handler of the NavigationBarItem.

fun buildNavigationBarItems(
    currentDestination: Destination,
    onNavigate: (destination: Destination) -> Unit
): List<NavigationBarItem> {
    return listOf(
        Destination.Feed,
        Destination.Contacts,
        Destination.Calendar
    ).map {
        NavigationBarItem(
            selected = currentDestination.path == it.path,
            onClick = {
                onNavigate(it)
            },
            icon = {
                it.icon?.let { image ->
                    Icon(
						imageVector = image, 
						contentDescription = null
					)
                }
            },
            label = {
                Text(text = it.path.replaceFirstChar { char ->
                    char.titlecase(Locale.getDefault())
                })
            }
        )
    }
}

Now that we have this buildNavigationBarItems function in place, we can tweak the implementation of our BottomNavigationBar to account for this change. So now instead of declaring the different navigational aspects inside of this composable, weâ€™re instead going to use the result of the buildNavigationBarItems function call to compose each of the BottomNavigationItem that is to be displayed inside of our navigation bar.

@Composable
fun BottomNavigationBar(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    currentDestination: Destination,
    onNavigate: (destination: Destination) -> Unit
) {
    BottomNavigation {
        buildNavigationBarItems(
            currentDestination,
            onNavigate = onNavigate
        ).forEach {
            BottomNavigationItem(
                selected = it.selected,
                onClick = it.onClick,
                icon = { it.icon() },
                label = { it.label() }
            )
        }
    }
}

So here, the BottomNavigation content is being composed based on the result of the buildNavigationBarItems function. For each item inside of this result, weâ€™re composing a BottomNavigationItem and assigning each property of the item to the corresponding property of the BottomNavigationItem composable.

With the declaration of our navigation items now being defined inside of this buildNavigationBarItems function, weâ€™re able to reuse this across the different navigation bars that we are going to support - allowing us to remove any duplication of code, as well as ensuring that the maintenance of these only needs to occur in one place.

Building the Navigation Rail

Now that we have our shared navigation items in place, we can utilise this to build out the NavigationRail thatâ€™s going to be used for landscape orientations of our layout. Similar to how we approached the BottomNavigationBar composable, weâ€™re going to create a new composable function RailNavigationBar. This is going to take the same arguments that we used for the BottomNavigationBar composable.

@Composable
fun RailNavigationBar(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    currentDestination: Destination,
    onNavigate: (destination: Destination) -> Unit
)

Weâ€™re then going to compose a NavigationRail inside of this, passing the modifier that was provided to our composable function. Similar to the buildNavigationBarItems usage inside of the BottomNavigationBar composable, weâ€™ll then use the result of this to compose the navigation items to be shown in the bar. The key difference here is the use of the NavigationRailItem composable, assigning the corresponding properties to the constructor.

@Composable
fun RailNavigationBar(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    currentDestination: Destination,
    onCreateItem: () -> Unit,
    onNavigate: (destination: Destination) -> Unit
) {
    NavigationRail(
        modifier = modifier
    ) {
        buildNavigationBarItems(
            currentDestination = currentDestination,
            onNavigate = onNavigate
        ).forEach {
            NavigationRailItem(
                selected = it.selected,
                onClick = it.onClick,
                icon = { it.icon() },
                label = { it.label() }
            )
        }
    }
}

While at this point the navigation items are being composed, weâ€™re going to want to utilise an extended feature of the NavigationRail composable - the ability to display a header item, which is often done in the form of a floating action button. For this weâ€™re going to compose a button that allows the user to navigate to the creation screen, which we defined in the previous chapter - this is the same behaviour as the floating action button within our scaffold.

For this weâ€™ll need to start by adding a new lambda function to the constructor of our composable, onCreateItem - this will be used to trigger the event from the header item.

@Composable
fun RailNavigationBar(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    currentDestination: Destination,
    onNavigate: (destination: Destination) -> Unit,
	onCreateItem: () -> Unit
)

Next, we can look at composing a FloatingActionButton inside of the header of the NavigationRail.
