You might notice that this implementation looks the same as what we have inside of the Scaffold for our screen - we compose an Icon for the button using the Icons.Default.Add for the imageVector, along with the cd_create_item resource for the content description. Finally, we trigger the onCreateItem lambda within the onClick handler for the FloatingActionButton.

@Composable
fun RailNavigationBar(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    currentDestination: Destination,
    onNavigate: (destination: Destination) -> Unit,
	onCreateItem: () -> Unit
) {
    NavigationRail(
        header = {
            FloatingActionButton(
                onClick = {
                    onCreateItem()
                }
            ) {
                Icon(
                    imageVector = Icons.Default.Add,
                    contentDescription = stringResource(
						R.string.cd_create_item)
                )
            }
        }
    ) {
        buildNavigationBarItems(
            currentDestination = currentDestination,
            onNavigate = onNavigate
        ).map {
            NavigationRailItem(
                selected = it.selected,
                onClick = it.onClick,
                icon = { it.icon() },
                label = { it.label() }
            )
        }
    }
}

With this in place, we now have the composition for a NavigationRail that displays the different Destinations that are available for our application. Here we are reusing the same declarations that the BottomNavigationBar composable is using, ensuring consistency and reuse across the different navigation bars that our apps support.

Composing the Navigation Rail

Now that weâ€™ve built out the composable for our NavigationRail, weâ€™re going to want to compose it within our UI. When it comes to this NavigationRail, itâ€™s going to be composed in a different location within our Scaffold. This is because the Scaffold provides a block for the composition of abottomBar to be declared, but this is not the place that we compose the NavigationRail - there is also no specific block for this component. The NavigationRail is going to be composed inside of the content block, which is currently where Navigation is being composed.

Scaffold(
	...
) {
	Navigation(
    	modifier = modifier,
        navController = navController
    )
}

Weâ€™re going to want to conditionally compose the NavigationRail alongside this Navigation, so to keep things tidy weâ€™re going to start by splitting out this Navigation into its own composable function - passing the required arguments that that Navigation composable is currently utilising.

@Composable
fun Body(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    navController: NavHostController
) {
	Navigation(
    	modifier = modifier,
        navController = navController
    )
}

When displaying the NavigationRail, this is going to be composable to the start of the Navigation - so these are going to be composed horizontally. To set this up, weâ€™ll start by wrapping the existing Navigation inside of a Row composable. The only thing that weâ€™ll change here is setting the provided modifier to the parent Row composable, now manually providing a modifier to the Navigation composable.

@Composable
fun Body(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    navController: NavHostController
) {
    Row(modifier = modifier) {
        Navigation(
			modifier = Modifier.fillMaxSize(),
            navController = navController
        )
    }
}

With this in place, we can now start working on composing the NavigationRail. Weâ€™re only going to want to compose this NavigationRail when the device is in landscape, so weâ€™re going to need to provide two further arguments to our Body composable. This will be a Destination to represent the current destination, along with an orientation value - using these two arguments we can then prepare a conditional statement block. We only want to display the navigation for the app if we are at a root destination, so weâ€™ll use a combination of checking that the provided Destination is a root destination, along with checking that the provided orientation is in fact ORIENTATION_LANDSCAPE.

@Composable
fun Body(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    navController: NavHostController,
	destination: Destination,
    orientation: Int
) {
    Row(modifier = modifier.fillMaxSize()) {
        if (destination.isRootDestination &&
            orientation == Configuration.ORIENTATION_LANDSCAPE
        ) {
            
        }
        Navigation(
			modifier = Modifier.fillMaxSize(),
            navController = navController
        )
    }
}

With this conditional block in place, all thatâ€™s left for us to do inside of this function is compose the RailNavigationBar. To compose this, weâ€™re going to need to further arguments that can be provided to our RailNavigationBar - these are the onCreateItem and onNavigate lambdas. Weâ€™ll want to pass these up to the parent composable to handle, so weâ€™ll provide these as arguments to the Body composable.

@Composable
fun Body(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    navController: NavHostController,
	destination: Destination,
    orientation: Int,
	onCreateItem: () -> Unit,
    onNavigate: (destination: Destination) -> Unit
)

With these in place, we now have all of the required arguments available to compose the RailNavigationBar inside of our conditional block.

@Composable
fun Body(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    navController: NavHostController,
	destination: Destination,
    orientation: Int,
	onCreateItem: () -> Unit,
    onNavigate: (destination: Destination) -> Unit
) {
    Row(modifier = modifier.fillMaxSize()) {
        if (destination.isRootDestination &&
            orientation == Configuration.ORIENTATION_LANDSCAPE
        ) {
            RailNavigationBar(
                modifier = modifier,
                currentDestination = destination,
                onCreateItem = onCreateItem,
                onNavigate = onNavigate
            )
        }
        Navigation(
			modifier = Modifier.fillMaxSize(),
            navController = navController
        )
    }
}

Now that our Body composable is complete, we can now compose this inside of the content block of the Scaffold. When doing this, weâ€™re going to need to provide the various arguments that the Body requires for composition.

  • For the modifier we want this to fill the maximum size that is available to it, so weâ€™ll provide the fillMaxSize modifier here
  • The destination, orientation and navController are all arguments that we have values available for. Weâ€™ll pass these directly into our Body composable for the corresponding arguments
  • For the onCreateItem lambda, weâ€™re going to need to handle the navigation to the Add destination. Here weâ€™ll do the same as we do for the FloatingActionButton that is within our Scaffold, utilising the navigate function of our navController to trigger navigation to the Add destination.
  • Next, weâ€™ll need to handle the onNavigate block - this will be used to handle the selection of any navigation items inside of the contained NavigationRail. For this, weâ€™re going to provide the same implementation that is being used for the BottomNavigationBar, using the navController reference to handle navigation for the bar
Scaffold(...) {

	Body(
		modifier = Modifier.fillMaxSize(),
		destination = currentDestination,
        orientation = orientation,
        navController = navController,
        onCreateItem = {
            navController.navigate(Destination.Add.path)
        },
        onNavigate = {
            navController.navigate(it.path) {
                popUpTo(Destination.Home.path) {
                    saveState = true
                }
                launchSingleTop = true
                restoreState = true
            }
        }
    )
}

With this in place, we now have a Body composable which will compose its content based on the orientation of the device and current destination. This allows for the NavigationRail to be composed when the device is in landscape and the current destination represents a root destination, followed by the Navigation being composed alone otherwise.

Hiding the Bottom Bar in landscape mode

Currently, the BottomNavigationBar within the Scaffold is being displayed in any orientation, representing the composition for the bottomBar content.

Scaffold(
  	...,
	bottomBar = {
		BottomNavigationBar(
			currentDestination = currentDestination,
           	onNavigate = {
            	navController.navigate(it.path) {
    	            popUpTo(navController.graph
						.findStartDestination().id) {
                    	saveState = true
                    }
                    launchSingleTop = true
                    restoreState = true
                }
            }
        )
    }
)

While this is fine to be composed when the device is in portrait, this isnâ€™t going to look quite right when in landscape mode. This is because when in landscape we are composing the NavigationRail, meaning that both navigation bars will be displayed. Because of this, weâ€™re not going to want to compose the BottomNavigationBar for our Scaffold in the landscape scenario. Here weâ€™ll simply add an if statement to check the current orientation, meaning that theBottomNavigationBar will only be composed if the orientation is not that of ORIENTATION_LANDSCAPE.

Scaffold(
  	...,
	bottomBar = {
        if (orientation != Configuration.ORIENTATION_LANDSCAPE 		&& currentDestination.isRootDestination
        ) {
            BottomNavigationBar(
                currentDestination = currentDestination,
                onNavigate = {
                    navController.navigate(it.path) {
                        popUpTo(navController.graph
							.findStartDestination().id) {
                            saveState = true
                        }
                        launchSingleTop = true
                        restoreState = true
                    }
                }
            )
        }
    }
)

Weâ€™ll be able to see here now that when the device is in portrait, the BottomNavigationBar is composed. But when in landscape, the composition does not occur here and we rely on the NavigationRail that is composed at the starting side of the screen.

Hiding the FAB in landscape mode

Currently, the FloatingActionButton within our Scaffold is being displayed when the user is currently at the Feed Destination. This button is used to navigate to the Add Destination.

Scaffold(
	...,
  	floatingActionButton = {
		if (navController.currentDestination!!.route == Destination.Feed.path
		) {        
			FloatingActionButton(onClick = {
              	navController.navigate(
					Destination.Add.path)
            }) {
               	Icon(
                   	imageVector = Icons.Default.Add,
                   	contentDescription = stringResource(
						R.string.cd_create_item)
               	)
            }
        }
    }
)

The thing is when in the landscape orientation and the NavigationRail is composed, that rail displays its own button to launch the Add Destination. Because of this, weâ€™re going to want to hide the FloatingActionButton that is composed in our Scaffold. Here weâ€™ll simply add to the if statement that is already being used to check the current destination. Here weâ€™ll also check the current orientation, meaning that the button will only be composed if the orientation is not that of ORIENTATION_LANDSCAPE.

Scaffold(
	...,
  	floatingActionButton = {
		if (orientation !=
			Configuration.ORIENTATION_LANDSCAPE && 
			navController.currentDestination!!.route == Destination.Feed.path
		) {  
			FloatingActionButton(onClick = {
              	navController.navigate(Destination.Add.path)
            }) {
               	Icon(
                   	imageVector = Icons.Default.Add,
                   	contentDescription = stringResource(
						R.string.cd_create_item)
               	)
            }
        }
    }
)

Weâ€™ll be able to see here now that when the device is in portrait, the FloatingActionButton is composed. But when in landscape, the composition does not occur here and we rely on the NavigationRail header for this action.

Wrapping Up

With all of the above in place, weâ€™ve been able to make some modifications so that our UI is conditionally composed based on the current orientation of the device. This allows us to build experiences that are optimised for a wider range of devices, providing a better user experience from our app.

Testing the Home Screen UI

Now that weâ€™ve built our Home screen, weâ€™re going to take a look at how we can write tests for our composables. Weâ€™re going to be writing some instrumentation tests using the compose ui-test-junit package - allowing us to verify that our composables are displayed and functioning as expected.

Before we can get started with our tests, weâ€™re going to need to add a couple of test specific dependencies to our project:

androidTestImplementation(
	"androidx.compose.ui:ui-test-junit4:$compose_version")
debugImplementation(
	"androidx.compose.ui:ui-test-manifest:$compose_version")

Weâ€™re also going to need to add mocks to our test - this allows us to easily provide mock references to any listeners that are provided to our composable functions, allowing us to easily verify they are triggered whenever expected.

androidTestImplementation(
	"org.mockito.kotlin:mockito-kotlin:3.2.0")
androidTestImplementation("org.mockito:mockito-android:3.12.4")

With these in place, we now have access to the required rules and functionality that allow us to test our composable UI. However, alongside these dependencies, weâ€™re also going to need to add some rules to our build.gradle file that will fix some of the compilation errors that weâ€™d currently see when trying to run our tests. Here weâ€™ll add some packagingOptions that will exclude certain packages from the added dependencies. We wonâ€™t dive too much into this concept and itâ€™s usually dependant on the versions of dependencies that are being used, so this may be redundant if you come to updating versions.

android {
	packagingOptions {
		exclude "**/attach_hotspot_windows.dll"
		exclude "META-INF/AL2.0"
		exclude "META-INF/LGPL2.1"
		exclude "META-INF/licenses/ASM"
	}
}

Testing the Top Bars

Weâ€™re going to start by writing some tests for the different top bars that are displayed within our UI.

Testing the Child Top Bar

Weâ€™ll start here by creating a new class, ChildDestinationTopBarTest - this class will be used to contain the different tests that weâ€™re going to write.

class ChildDestinationTopBarTest {

}

Inside of this class, we now need to define a reference to the ComposeContentTestRule class - this is what weâ€™re going to use to set the composable content on screen, allowing us to perform interactions and assertions from within our tests. 

@get:Rule
val composeTestRule = createComposeRule()

When using this rule, we donâ€™t need to specify any form of activity for our composables to be launched in, the test rule will handle that for us. So using this rule we will set the composable content to be composed, the test will then launch a host activity which will be used to compose our provided content inside of.

Weâ€™ll start here by testing that the title is displayed within the ChildDestinationTopBar composable. To test this, weâ€™ll want to create a reference to a title, passing this in for the title argument during composition.

@Test
fun Title_Displayed() {
    val title = Destination.Feed.title
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        ChildDestinationTopBar(
            onUpClicked = { },
            title = title
        )
    }
}

With this now being displayed, we can next perform the required assertions to ensure that the expected title is being displayed within our composable UI. Weâ€™ll do this by utilising the onNodeWithText function from our test rule reference.

The onNodeWithText function can be used to locate a composable that is displaying the text that we have provided to the function. Composables will be located in the form of a semantic node. Because our composables are represented via semantics, in our tests we are essentially going to be locating nodes within our semantic tree. In this case, this is done using the onNodeWithText function, which will return us with a SemanticsNodeInteraction reference to perform assertions against.

For this test we want to assert that this node is being displayed within our composed UI, so weâ€™re going to go ahead and utilise the assertIsDisplayed function. This is one of the assertions available on the SemanticsNodeInteraction class, allowing us to assert whether this node is being displayed on the screen.

@Test
fun Title_Displayed() {
    val title = Destination.Feed.title
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        ChildDestinationTopBar(
            onUpClicked = { },
            title = title
        )
    }
    composeTestRule.onNodeWithText(
        title
    ).assertIsDisplayed()
}

Next, weâ€™re going to check that the navigation icon within the top bar is displayed as expected. Weâ€™ll need to start here by composing the ChildDestinationTopBar, providing values for both of the required arguments. We donâ€™t care what the values of these are within this test, so weâ€™ll pass an empty lambda for the onUpClicked argument, along with a string value using the Feed Destination for the title argument.

@Test
fun Navigation_Icon_Displayed() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        ChildDestinationTopBar(
            onUpClicked = { },
            title = Destination.Feed.title
        )
    }
}

Next, we want to assert that the expected icon is displayed within the top bar. For this weâ€™re going to use the onNodeWithContentDescription function - this allows us to provide a string that will be used to find a node whose content description semantic matches the provided value. For this assertion, weâ€™ll use the cd_navigate_up string resource, followed by asserting this icon is displayed using the assertIsDisplayed assertion function.

@Test
fun Navigation_Icon_Displayed() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        ChildDestinationTopBar(
            onUpClicked = { },
            title = Destination.Feed.title
        )
    }

    composeTestRule.onNodeWithContentDescription(
        InstrumentationRegistry.getInstrumentation().context
            .getString(R.string.cd_navigate_up)
    ).assertIsDisplayed()
}

Now that we know the icon is being displayed, weâ€™re going to want to assert that the provided lambda function is triggered when the icon is clicked. Here weâ€™re going to use mockito to provide a mock implementation of this callback - allowing us to verify that it is triggered as expected. Weâ€™ll pass in this mock implementation to the onUpClicked argument of the composable function.

@Test
fun Navigation_Icon_Triggers_Callback() {
    val onUpClicked: () -> Unit = mock()
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        ChildDestinationTopBar(
            onUpClicked = onUpClicked,
            title = Destination.Feed.title
        )
    }   
}

Now that this mock implementation is being provided for our composition, we can go ahead and perform the required operation that would trigger that callback. In a previous test, we performed an assertion on the visibility of the navigation icon - weâ€™ll need to locate the same node here using the cd_navigate_up resource, this time using the performClick function to perform an action instead of an assertion.

@Test
fun Navigation_Icon_Triggers_Callback() {
    val onUpClicked: () -> Unit = mock()
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        ChildDestinationTopBar(
            onUpClicked = onUpClicked,
            title = Destination.Feed.title
        )
    }
    composeTestRule.onNodeWithContentDescription(
        InstrumentationRegistry.getInstrumentation().context
            .getString(R.string.cd_navigate_up)
    ).performClick()
}

When this icon is clicked, it would be expected that the lambda we provided would be triggered. We have a mock implementation of this callback in place, so we can use this to verify interactions. For this weâ€™re going to utilise the mockito verify functionality - this allows us to assert that our callback has been triggered within the scope of our test.

@Test
fun Navigation_Icon_Triggers_Callback() {
    val onUpClicked: () -> Unit = mock()
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        ChildDestinationTopBar(
            onUpClicked = onUpClicked,
            title = Destination.Feed.title
        )
    }
    composeTestRule.onNodeWithContentDescription(
        InstrumentationRegistry.getInstrumentation().context
            .getString(R.string.cd_navigate_up)
    ).performClick()

    verify(onUpClicked).invoke()
}

With this in place, weâ€™re now able to assert that the navigation icon is successfully triggering the action that has been provided via the composable function.

Testing the Root Navigation Top Bar

While we have tests in place for the ChildDestinationTopBar composable, weâ€™re now also going to add some quick tests for the RootDestinationTopBar. These wonâ€™t differ too much from the tests that weâ€™ve already implemented, but allow us to reinforce our learnings and also add some coverage for this additional top bar. Weâ€™ll start here by defining a new test class to hold these tests, RootDestinationTopBarTest.

class RootDestinationTopBarTest {

    @get:Rule
    val composeTestRule = createComposeRule()

}

Testing the title display

Weâ€™ll want to start here by asserting that the expected title is displayed in the RootDestinationTopBar composable. This is important because this top bar should always display the Destination.Home title, so weâ€™ll test here that this is the case. Weâ€™ll need to begin by composing the RootDestinationTopBar.

@Test
fun Title_Displayed() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        RootDestinationTopBar(
            destination = Destination.Home,
            openDrawer = { },
            showSnackbar = { }
        )
    }
}

Next, weâ€™ll locate a node with the composable using the onNodeWithText function - this will find a node that has the corresponding text semantic property. For this value weâ€™ll pass the title for the Home destination, followed by performing the assertIsDisplayed assertion, allowing us to test that a node with this text content is being displayed within the composable.

@Test
fun Title_Displayed() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        RootDestinationTopBar(
            destination = Destination.Home,
            openDrawer = { },
            showSnackbar = { }
        )
    }
    composeTestRule.onNodeWithText(
        Destination.Home.title
    ).assertIsDisplayed()
}

Testing the menu icon display

Next, weâ€™re going to check that the navigation icon within the top bar is displayed as expected. Weâ€™ll need to start here by composing the RootDestinationTopBar , providing values for both of the required arguments. We donâ€™t care what the values of these are within this test, so weâ€™ll pass empty lambdas for the openDrawer and showSnackbar arguments, along with a destination in the form of Home.

@Test
fun Menu_Icon_Displayed() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        RootDestinationTopBar(
            destination = Destination.Home,
            openDrawer = { },
            showSnackbar = { }
        )
    }
}

Next, we want to assert that the expected icon is displayed within the top bar. For this weâ€™re going to use the onNodeWithContentDescription function - this allows us to provide a string that will be used to find a node whose content description semantic matches the provided value. For this assertion, weâ€™ll use the cd_open_menu string resource, followed by asserting this icon is displayed using the assertIsDisplayed assertion function.

@Test
fun Menu_Icon_Displayed() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        RootDestinationTopBar(
            destination = Destination.Home,
            openDrawer = { },
            showSnackbar = { }
        )
    }
    composeTestRule.onNodeWithContentDescription(
        InstrumentationRegistry.getInstrumentation().context
            .getString(R.string.cd_open_menu)
    ).assertIsDisplayed()
}

Testing the menu icon callback

Now that we know the icon is being displayed, weâ€™re going to want to assert that the provided lambda function is triggered when the icon is clicked. Here weâ€™re going to use mockito to provide a mock implementation of this callback - allowing us to verify that it is triggered as expected. Weâ€™ll pass in this mock implementation to the openDrawer argument of the composable function.

@Test
fun Menu_Icon_Triggers_Callback() {
    val openDrawer: () -> Unit = mock()
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        RootDestinationTopBar(
            destination = Destination.Home,
            openDrawer = openDrawer,
            showSnackbar = { }
        )
    }
}

Now that this mock implementation is being provided for our composition, we can go ahead and perform the required operation that would trigger that callback. In a previous test, we performed an assertion on the visibility of the navigation icon - weâ€™ll need to locate the same node here using the cd_open_menu resource, this time using the performClick function to perform an action instead of an assertion.

@Test
fun Menu_Icon_Triggers_Callback() {
    val openDrawer: () -> Unit = mock()
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        RootDestinationTopBar(
            destination = Destination.Home,
            openDrawer = openDrawer,
            showSnackbar = { }
        )
    }
    composeTestRule.onNodeWithContentDescription(
        InstrumentationRegistry.getInstrumentation().context
            .getString(R.string.cd_open_menu)
    ).performClick()
}

When this icon is clicked, it would be expected that the lambda we provided would be triggered. We have a mock implementation of this callback in place, so we can use this to verify interactions. For this weâ€™re going to utilise the mockito verify functionality - this allows us to assert that our callback has been triggered within the scope of our test.

@Test
fun Menu_Icon_Triggers_Callback() {
    val openDrawer: () -> Unit = mock()
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        RootDestinationTopBar(
            destination = Destination.Home,
            openDrawer = openDrawer,
            showSnackbar = { }
        )
    }
    composeTestRule.onNodeWithContentDescription(
        InstrumentationRegistry.getInstrumentation().context
            .getString(R.string.cd_open_menu)
    ).performClick()

    verify(openDrawer).invoke()
}

Testing the info icon display

Within this app bar, we are also displaying an action icon - this icon also triggers a callback, so weâ€™ll add a couple of tests to assert that this is displayed as expected and can be interacted with by the user. Weâ€™ll start here by testing that the action is displayed, for which weâ€™ll need to compose a RootDestinationTopBar within our test. When composing this weâ€™ll need to provide a destination value that supports the action within the app bar, which is any value other than the Feed destination.

@Test
fun Info_Icon_Displayed() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        RootDestinationTopBar(
            destination = Destination.Contacts,
            openDrawer = { },
            showSnackbar = { }
        )
    }
}

This composable is using a content description to describe its purpose to accessibility services, in the form of the cd_more_information resource. Within our test weâ€™ll use this to locate the desired node, using the onNodeWithContentDescription function. Once this node has been located we can trigger the assertIsDisplayed function to assert that this node is being displayed within our composable.

@Test
fun Info_Icon_Displayed() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        RootDestinationTopBar(
            destination = Destination.Contacts,
            openDrawer = { },
            showSnackbar = { }
        )
    }
    composeTestRule.onNodeWithContentDescription(
        InstrumentationRegistry.getInstrumentation().context
            .getString(R.string.cd_more_information)
    ).assertIsDisplayed()
}

As previously mentioned, the info action is only displayed when the Feed destination is not provided to the composable function. This composable contains logic that depicts if the action should be displayed, so weâ€™re going to add a quick test to have some coverage for this logic - allowing us to assert that this icon is not displayed when the Feed destination is provided. Weâ€™ll want to start here by composing the RootDestinationTopBar, providing the Feed destination.

@Test
fun Info_Icon_Displayed_Never_Displayed_For_Feed() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        RootDestinationTopBar(
            destination = Destination.Feed,
            openDrawer = { },
            showSnackbar = { }
        )
    }
}

Next, weâ€™ll want to assert that this action icon is not being displayed within the app bar. Here weâ€™ll again attempt to locate a node using the cd_more_information content description, this time asserting that such a node does not exist using the assertDoesNotExist function.

@Test
fun Info_Icon_Displayed_Never_Displayed_For_Feed() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        RootDestinationTopBar(
            destination = Destination.Feed,
            openDrawer = { },
            showSnackbar = { }
        )
    }
    composeTestRule.onNodeWithContentDescription(
        InstrumentationRegistry.getInstrumentation().context
            .getString(R.string.cd_more_information)
    ).assertDoesNotExist()
}

This allows us to assert that when composition occurs for the Feed destination, the expected state would be that the action is not displayed within the app bar.

Testing the action icon callback

In the cases where the action is displayed within the composable, the user can interact with this to trigger the showSnackbar lambda function. To ensure that this is being triggered when expected, weâ€™re going to add a quick test. Weâ€™ll need to again compose the RootDestinationTopBar, providing a mock implementation for the showSnackbar lambda.

@Test
fun Info_Icon_Triggers_Callback() {
    val showSnackbar: (message: String) -> Unit = mock()
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        RootDestinationTopBar(
            destination = Destination.Home,
            openDrawer = { },
            showSnackbar = showSnackbar
        )
    }
}

With this composition in place, we can now perform the required actions and assertions on our composable to ensure that it is behaving as expected. Weâ€™ll use the onNodeWithContentDescription function on our test rule to retrieve the node with the provided content description. Weâ€™ll provide the content description that is being used for this icon, cd_more_information, to locate this - followed by the performClick function to trigger a click event on the composable.

When this click event occurs, it is expected that the not_available_yet message is passed up via theshowSnackbar lambda. Weâ€™ll use the verify function from mockito to perform this assertion - allowing us to ensure that this lambda is invoked, passing the expected message when done so.

@Test
fun Info_Icon_Triggers_Callback() {
    val showSnackbar: (message: String) -> Unit = mock()
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        RootDestinationTopBar(
            destination = Destination.Home,
            openDrawer = { },
            showSnackbar = showSnackbar
        )
    }
    composeTestRule.onNodeWithContentDescription(
        InstrumentationRegistry.getInstrumentation().context
            .getString(R.string.cd_more_information)
    ).performClick()

    verify(showSnackbar).invoke(
		InstrumentationRegistry.getInstrumentation().context
            .getString(R.string.not_available_yet)
	)
}

Testing the Destination Top Bar

Next up we have the DestinationTopBar composable, this is used to handle the composition of a top bar, depending on the destination that is provided to it - this will be either the RootDestinationTopBar or ChildDestinationTopBar, which we individually wrote tests for in the last section. Here weâ€™ll want to test that:

  • The RootDestinationTopBar composable is displayed when a root destination is provided to it
  • The ChildDestinationTopBar composable is displayed when a non-root composable is provided to it

Weâ€™ll start here by creating a new test class, DestinationTopBarTest, configuring the required test rule inside of it.

class DestinationTopBarTest {

    @get:Rule
    val composeTestRule = createComposeRule()

}

Weâ€™ll start here by writing a test that will assert that the RootDestinationTopBar is displayed when a root Destination is provided to it. Weâ€™ll compose a DestinationTopBar here, passing the Home destination for the destination argument.

@Test
fun Root_Destination_Top_Bar_Displayed() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        DestinationTopBar(
            destination = Destination.Home,
            onNavigateUp = { },
            onOpenDrawer = { },
            showSnackbar = { }
        )
    }
}

So that we can perform the desired assertion, weâ€™ll next need to add a tag to the top bar composable. Weâ€™ll create a new object, Tags, and define a new tag that can be assigned to our RootDestinationTopBar.

// Tags.kt
object Tags {
    const val TAG_ROOT_TOP_BAR = "root_top_bar"
}

With these tags defined we can now use the testTag function to assign this tag to our RootDestinationTopBar composable.

// RootDestinationTopBar.kt
RootDestinationTopBar(
	modifier = modifier.testTag(TAG_ROOT_TOP_BAR),
	...
)

With this tag in place, it can now be used to locate a node within our composable hierarchy using the onNodeWithTag function. On this node, we can then use the assertIsDisplayed function to assert that this composable is being displayed, as expected, within the composed UI.

@Test
fun Root_Destination_Top_Bar_Displayed() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        DestinationTopBar(
            destination = Destination.Home,
            onNavigateUp = { },
            onOpenDrawer = { },
            showSnackbar = { }
        )
    }
    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(
        TAG_ROOT_TOP_BAR
    ).assertIsDisplayed()
}

On the flip side, weâ€™re going to also want to check that when a root Destination is being composed, the ChildDestinationTopBar is not displayed within the UI. To be able to assert this, weâ€™ll again need to add a tag to be able to locate this node.

// Tags.kt
object Tags {
    const val TAG_ROOT_TOP_BAR = "root_top_bar"
	const val TAG_CHILD_TOP_BAR = "child_top_bar"
}

Weâ€™ll then need to again assign this to the corresponding composable, which in this case is the ChildDestinationTopBar.

// ChildDestinationTopBar.kt
ChildDestinationTopBar(
	modifier = modifier.testTag(TAG_CHILD_TOP_BAR),
	...
)

With this tag in place, we can now locate this node within our tests. Here weâ€™ll compose the same DestinationTopBar as the previous test, except this time weâ€™ll use the TAG_TOP_BAR tag to assert that the node with that tag does not currently exist within the composition.

@Test
fun Top_Bar_Never_Displayed() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        DestinationTopBar(
            destination = Destination.Home,
            onNavigateUp = { },
            onOpenDrawer = { },
            showSnackbar = { }
        )
    }
    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(
        TAG_TOP_BAR
    ).assertDoesNotExist()
}

With the above tests in place, weâ€™re able to assert that the expected UI is composed when a root Destination is provided to our DestinationTopBar composable. Weâ€™re now going to write some tests to assert that the expected state is also composed for the UI when a non-root destination is provided to our DestinationTopBar composable.

Weâ€™ll start here by composing a DestinationTopBar, this time providing a non-root Destination in the form of Destination.Add. When a non-root destination is provided we expect that the ChildDestinationTopBar is composed - so here weâ€™ll want to assert that the composable with the TAG_TOP_BAR tag is displayed within our UI.

@Test
fun Top_Bar_Displayed() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        DestinationTopBar(
            destination = Destination.Add,
            onNavigateUp = { },
            onOpenDrawer = { },
            showSnackbar = { }
        )
    }
    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(
        TAG_TOP_BAR
    ).assertIsDisplayed()
}

When this is the case and the ChildDestinationTopBar is composed, we would expect that the RootDestinationTopBar is not composed. In this next test, weâ€™ll configure the same composition as the previous test, except this time weâ€™ll assert that the RootDestinationTopBar does not exist within our composition.

@Test
fun Root_Destination_Top_Bar_Never_Displayed() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        DestinationTopBar(
            destination = Destination.Add,
            onNavigateUp = { },
            onOpenDrawer = { },
            showSnackbar = { }
        )
    }
    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(
        TAG_ROOT_TOP_BAR
    ).assertDoesNotExist()
}

Testing Bottom Navigation

Now that weâ€™ve got all of the tests in place for the top app bars within our UI, weâ€™re next going to move on to testing the composition of the BottomNavigationBar composable. Here weâ€™re going to want to write some tests that allow us to assert that:

  • The bottom navigation bar is displayed
  • The navigation items are displayed within the bottom navigation bar
  • The navigation callback is triggered upon item select
  • The currently selected item is marked as selected

With these test requirements in mind, weâ€™re going to go ahead and write a new test class, BottomNavigationTest, configuring the compose test rule in the process.

class BottomNavigationTest {

    @get:Rule
    val composeTestRule = createComposeRule()

}

Weâ€™re going to start here by writing a test to assert that the bottom navigation composable is displayed within the composed UI. Weâ€™re going to start here by writing a new test, Bottom_Navigation_Displayed, composing a BottomNavigationBar in the process. Here weâ€™ll pass a Destination, along with an empty lambda for the onNavigate - this is because we donâ€™t need the lambda implemented for this test.

@Test
fun Bottom_Navigation_Displayed() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        BottomNavigationBar(
            currentDestination = Destination.Feed,
            onNavigate = {}
        )
    }
}

So that we can locate this composable with our tests weâ€™re going to need to utilise a test tag. Weâ€™ll add a new tag to our Tags.kt file:

// Tags.kt
object Tags {
    const val TAG_BOTTOM_NAVIGATION = "bottom_navigation"
}

Followed by assigning this tag to the BottomNavigation composable using the testTag modifier.

// BottomNavigation.kt
BottomNavigation(modifier = modifier.testTag(TAG_BOTTOM_NAVIGATION))

Using this tag we can then locate the bottom navigation node using the onNodeWithTag function, followed by asserting that it is being displayed using the assertIsDisplayed function.

@Test
fun Bottom_Navigation_Displayed() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        BottomNavigationBar(
            currentDestination = Destination.Feed,
            onNavigate = {}
        )
    }
    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(
        TAG_BOTTOM_NAVIGATION
    ).assertIsDisplayed()
}

Now that we have asserted that the bottom navigation is being displayed, we can put together a test that will assert that the items within the bottom navigation bar are being displayed as expected. Weâ€™ll start here by creating a new test, composing the BottomNavigationBar as we had done in the previous test.

@Test
fun Bottom_Navigation_Items_Displayed() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        BottomNavigationBar(
            currentDestination = Destination.Feed,
            onNavigate = {}
        )
    }

}

Next, weâ€™re going to want to take each of the navigation items that are expected to be displayed, performing assertions to ensure this is the case. Weâ€™ll first want to take the expected items which in this case are the Feed, Contacts and Calendar.

listOf(
	Destination.Feed, 
	Destination.Contacts, 
	Destination.Calendar
)

With these Destination references, we can now loop through each one and use the title of each destination to locate a node using the onNodeWithText function. With this node located we can then assert that this is being displayed as expected - this will then test that each of the expected navigation items is being correctly displayed inside of the bottom navigation.

@Test
fun Bottom_Navigation_Items_Displayed() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        BottomNavigationBar(
            currentDestination = Destination.Feed,
            onNavigate = {}
        )
    }

    listOf(
		Destination.Feed, 
		Destination.Contacts, 
		Destination.Calendar
	).forEach {
        composeTestRule.onNodeWithText(
            it.title
        ).assertIsDisplayed()
    }
}

While we now know that the navigation items are being displayed inside of our bottom navigation bar, we can go one step further here and assert that the expected item is being composed as a selected navigation item. Weâ€™re going to start here by again composing the BottomNavigationBar, providing a Destination reference for the currently selected item. Weâ€™ll keep this in a variable reference so that we can later use it when performing assertions.

@Test
fun Current_Destination_Selected() {
    val destination = Destination.Contacts
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        BottomNavigationBar(
            currentDestination = destination,
            onNavigate = {}
        )
    }
}

With this being composed, weâ€™re now going to want to assert the selected states of each Destination that is being composed inside of our bottom navigation. In the previous test, we used the title of each destination to assert that the Destination was being composed within the bottom navigation bar. Here weâ€™re going to use the same approach with onNodeWithText to locate the given Destination using its title, but this time assert the selected state.

Using the Destination reference that we provided to the currentDestination argument during composition, weâ€™ll locate the corresponding node for this destination and use the assertIsSelected function to assert that this node is marked as selected.

@Test
fun Current_Destination_Selected() {
    val destination = Destination.Contacts
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        BottomNavigationBar(
            currentDestination = destination,
            onNavigate = {}
        )
    }

    composeTestRule.onNodeWithText(destination.title)
        .assertIsSelected()
}

While weâ€™re here, weâ€™ll also add two more assertions for the other destinations that we know are being composed. We could have these as separate tests, but weâ€™ll assert these here for simplicity sake. Using both the Feed and Calendar destinations, weâ€™ll locate the corresponding nodes for these and assert that they are not marked as selected using assertIsNotSelected.

@Test
fun Current_Destination_Selected() {
    val destination = Destination.Contacts
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        BottomNavigationBar(
            currentDestination = destination,
            onNavigate = {}
        )
    }

    composeTestRule.onNodeWithText(destination.title)
        .assertIsSelected()
    composeTestRule.onNodeWithText(Destination.Feed.title)
        .assertIsNotSelected()
    composeTestRule.onNodeWithText(Destination.Calendar.title)
        .assertIsNotSelected()
}

Now that we know the bottom navigation is being composed as expected, weâ€™re going to want to assert that the provided lambda function is triggered when a destination is clicked. Here weâ€™re going to use mockito to provide a mock implementation of this callback - allowing us to verify that it is triggered as expected. Weâ€™ll pass in this mock implementation to the onNavigate argument of the composable function.

@Test
fun Bottom_Navigation_Callback_Triggered() {
    val destination = Destination.Contacts
    val onNavigate: (destination: Destination) -> Unit = mock()
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        BottomNavigationBar(
            currentDestination = Destination.Feed,
            onNavigate = onNavigate
        )
    }
}

Now that this mock implementation is being provided for our composition, we can go ahead and perform the required operation that would trigger that callback. Similar to the previous test, weâ€™ll need to locate the same node here using the Destination title, this time using the performClick function to perform an action instead of an assertion.

@Test
fun Bottom_Navigation_Callback_Triggered() {
    val destination = Destination.Contacts
    val onNavigate: (destination: Destination) -> Unit = mock()
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        BottomNavigationBar(
            currentDestination = Destination.Feed,
            onNavigate = onNavigate
        )
    }

    composeTestRule.onNodeWithText(
        destination.title
    ).performClick()
}

When this icon is clicked, it would be expected that the lambda we provided would be triggered. We have a mock implementation of this callback in place, so we can use this to verify interactions. For this weâ€™re going to utilise the mockito verify functionality - this allows us to assert that our callback has been triggered within the scope of our test.

@Test
fun Bottom_Navigation_Callback_Triggered() {
    val destination = Destination.Contacts
    val onNavigate: (destination: Destination) -> Unit = mock()
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        BottomNavigationBar(
            currentDestination = Destination.Feed,
            onNavigate = onNavigate
        )
    }

    composeTestRule.onNodeWithText(
        destination.title
    ).performClick()

    verify(onNavigate).invoke(destination)
}

With this in place, weâ€™re now able to assert that the navigation icon is successfully triggering the action that has been provided via the composable function.

Testing the Rail Navigation

Now that weâ€™ve got all of the tests in place for the bottom navigation, weâ€™re next going to move on to testing the composition of the RailNavigationBar composable. Here weâ€™re going to want to write some tests that allow us to assert that:

  • The rail navigation bar is displayed
  • The navigation items are displayed within the rail navigation bar
  • The navigation callback is triggered upon item select
  • The currently selected item is marked as selected

With these test requirements in mind, weâ€™re going to go ahead and write a new test class, RailNavigationTest, configuring the compose test rule in the process.

class RailNavigationTest {

    @get:Rule
    val composeTestRule = createComposeRule()

}

Weâ€™re going to start here by writing a test to assert that the rail navigation composable is displayed within the composed UI. Weâ€™re going to start here by writing a new test, Navigation_Rail_Displayed, composing a RailNavigationBar in the process. Here weâ€™ll pass a Destination, along with an empty lambda for the onCreateItem and onNavigate lambdas - this is because we donâ€™t need the lambdas implemented for this test.

@Test
fun Navigation_Rail_Displayed() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        RailNavigationBar(
            currentDestination = Destination.Feed,
            onCreateItem = {},
            onNavigate = {}
        )
    }
}

So that we can locate this composable with our tests weâ€™re going to need to utilise a test tag. Weâ€™ll add a new tag to our Tags.kt file:

// Tags.kt
object Tags {
    const val TAG_RAIL_NAVIGATION = "rail_navigation"
}

Followed by assigning this tag to the RailNavigationBar composable using the testTag modifier.

// RailNavigation.kt
NavigationRail(
	modifier = modifier.testTag(TAG_RAIL_NAVIGATION),
	...
)

Using this tag we can then locate the rail navigation node using the onNodeWithTag function, followed by asserting that it is being displayed using the assertIsDisplayed function.

@Test
fun Navigation_Rail_Displayed() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        RailNavigationBar(
            currentDestination = Destination.Feed,
            onCreateItem = {},
            onNavigate = {}
        )
    }
    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(
        TAG_NAVIGATION_RAIL
    ).assertIsDisplayed()
}

Now that we have asserted that the rail navigation is being displayed, we can put together a test that will assert that the items within the rail navigation bar are being displayed as expected. Weâ€™ll start here by creating a new test, composing the RailNavigationBar as we had done in the previous test.

@Test
fun Navigation_Rail_Items_Displayed() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        RailNavigationBar(
            currentDestination = Destination.Feed,
            onCreateItem = {},
            onNavigate = {}
        )
    }
}

Next, weâ€™re going to want to take each of the navigation items that are expected to be displayed, performing assertions to ensure this is the case. Weâ€™ll first want to take the expected items which in this case are the Feed, Contacts and Calendar.

listOf(
	Destination.Feed, 
	Destination.Contacts, 
	Destination.Calendar
)

With these Destination references, we can now loop through each one and use the title of each destination to locate a node using the onNodeWithText function. With this node located we can then assert that this is being displayed as expected - this will then test that each of the expected navigation items is being correctly displayed inside of the bottom navigation.

@Test
fun Navigation_Rail_Items_Displayed() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        RailNavigationBar(
            currentDestination = Destination.Feed,
            onCreateItem = {},
            onNavigate = {}
        )
    }

    listOf(
		Destination.Feed, 
		Destination.Contacts, 
		Destination.Calendar
	).forEach {
        composeTestRule.onNodeWithText(
            it.title
        ).assertIsDisplayed()
    }
}

While we now know that the navigation items are being displayed inside of our rail navigation bar, we can go one step further here and assert that the expected item is being composed as a selected navigation item. Weâ€™re going to start here by again composing the RailNavigationBar, providing a Destination reference for the currently selected item. Weâ€™ll keep this in a variable reference so that we can later use it when performing assertions.

@Test
fun Current_Destination_Selected() {
    val destination = Destination.Contacts
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        RailNavigationBar(
            currentDestination = destination,
            onCreateItem = {},
            onNavigate = {}
        )
    }
}

With this being composed, weâ€™re now going to want to assert the selected states of each Destination that is being composed inside of our bottom navigation. In the previous test, we used the title of each destination to assert that the Destination was being composed within the bottom navigation bar. Here weâ€™re going to use the same approach with onNodeWithText to locate the given Destination using its title, but this time assert the selected state.

Using the Destination reference that we provided to the currentDestination argument during composition, weâ€™ll locate the corresponding node for this destination and use the assertIsSelected function to assert that this node is marked as selected.

@Test
fun Current_Destination_Selected() {
    val destination = Destination.Contacts
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        RailNavigationBar(
            currentDestination = destination,
            onCreateItem = {},
            onNavigate = {}
        )
    }

    composeTestRule
		.onNodeWithText(destination.title)
        .assertIsSelected()
}

While weâ€™re here, weâ€™ll also add two more assertions for the other destinations that we know are being composed. We could have these as separate tests, but weâ€™ll assert these here for simplicity sake. Using both the Feed and Calendar destinations, weâ€™ll locate the corresponding nodes for these and assert that they are not marked as selected using assertIsNotSelected.

@Test
fun Current_Destination_Selected() {
    val destination = Destination.Contacts
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        RailNavigationBar(
            currentDestination = destination,
            onCreateItem = {},
            onNavigate = {}
        )
    }

    composeTestRule
		.onNodeWithText(destination.title)
        .assertIsSelected()
    composeTestRule
		.onNodeWithText(Destination.Feed.title)
        .assertIsNotSelected()
    composeTestRule
		.onNodeWithText(Destination.Calendar.title)
        .assertIsNotSelected()
}

Now that we know the rail navigation is being composed as expected, weâ€™re going to want to assert that the provided lambda function is triggered when a destination is clicked. Here weâ€™re going to use mockito to provide a mock implementation of this callback - allowing us to verify that it is triggered as expected. Weâ€™ll pass in this mock implementation to the onNavigate argument of the composable function.

@Test
fun Navigation_Callback_Triggered() {
    val destination = Destination.Contacts
    val onNavigate: (destination: Destination) -> Unit = mock()
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        RailNavigationBar(
            currentDestination = Destination.Feed,
            onCreateItem = {},
            onNavigate = onNavigate
        )
    }
}

Now that this mock implementation is being provided for our composition, we can go ahead and perform the required operation that would trigger that callback. Similar to the previous test, weâ€™ll need to locate the same node here using the Destination title, this time using the performClick function to perform an action instead of an assertion. Weâ€™ll then use the verify functionality to assert that the callback is triggered when expected.

@Test
fun Navigation_Callback_Triggered() {
    val destination = Destination.Contacts
    val onNavigate: (destination: Destination) -> Unit = mock()
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        RailNavigationBar(
            currentDestination = Destination.Feed,
            onCreateItem = {},
            onNavigate = onNavigate
        )
    }

    composeTestRule.onNodeWithText(
        destination.title
    ).performClick()

    verify(onNavigate).invoke(destination)
}

Alongside the navigation items, the rail is also expected to contain a floating action button that is used to trigger the item creation flow. To wrap up the tests for the rail navigation bar weâ€™re going to assert that this button is displayed and that it triggered the expected callback.

Weâ€™ll start here by creating a new test, Floating_Action_Button_Displayed, that will be used to assert that the floating action button is being displayed. Before we can do this, weâ€™ll need to add a new tag to our Tags.kt file:

// Tags.kt
object Tags {
    const val TAG_RAIL_CREATE = "rail_create"
}

Followed by assigning this tag to the FloatingActionButton composable within the rail navigation bar, using the testTag modifier.

// RailNavigation.kt
FloatingActionButton(
	modifier = Modifier.testTag(TAG_RAIL_CREATE),
	...
)

Using this tag we can then locate the button node using the onNodeWithTag function, followed by asserting that it is being displayed using the assertIsDisplayed function.

@Test
fun Floating_Action_Button_Displayed() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        RailNavigationBar(
            currentDestination = Destination.Feed,
            onCreateItem = {},
            onNavigate = {}
        )
    }
    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(
        TAG_RAIL_NAV_CREATE
    ).assertIsDisplayed()
}

Alongside this button being displayed, weâ€™ll want to assert that the provided lambda, onCreateItem, is triggered when expected. Similar to the previous tests that we wrote to assert that the onNavigate lambda is being triggered as expected, weâ€™ll want to go ahead and do the same here.

Weâ€™ll create a mock reference for the onCreateItem lambda and pass this when composing the RailNavigationBar. Then, using the tag that we defined for the last test, weâ€™ll perform a click action on the floating action button, followed by asserting that the lambda was invoked as expected.

@Test
fun Create_Item_Callback_Triggered() {
    val onCreateItem: () -> Unit = mock()
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        RailNavigationBar(
            currentDestination = Destination.Feed,
            onCreateItem = onCreateItem,
            onNavigate = {}
        )
    }

    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(
        TAG_RAIL_NAV_CREATE
    ).performClick()

    verify(onCreateItem).invoke()
}

Testing the Home Body

Now that we have tests in place for the different navigation bars within our project, weâ€™re going to explore writing some tests to assert that these components are composed as expected within the dashboard of the app when the Home composable is composed. Here weâ€™ll want to assert that:

  • The Navigation Rail is displayed in landscape mode
  • The Navigation Rail is not displayed in portrait mode
  • The Navigation Rail is not shown for a non-root destination
  • The Bottom Navigation is displayed in portrait mode
  • The Bottom Navigation is not displayed in landscape mode
  • The Bottom Navigation is not shown for a non-root destination

With these test requirements in mind, weâ€™re going to go ahead and write a new test class, HomeTest, configuring the compose test rule in the process.

class HomeTest {

    @get:Rule
    val composeTestRule = createComposeRule()


}

Testing the Rail is displayed in Landscape

Weâ€™re going to start with the first test case from above, the NavigationRail being displayed when the UI is composed for a landscape layout. Weâ€™ll want to start here by composing the Home composable, providing the Configuration.ORIENTATION_LANDSCAPE value for the orientation argument of the composable function.

@Test
fun Navigation_Rail_Displayed_In_Landscape() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
    	Home(orientation = Configuration.ORIENTATION_LANDSCAPE)
    }
}

With this being composed, we can now go ahead and perform the assertion for the NavigationRail. Here weâ€™ll want to use the TAG_NAVIGATION_RAIL tag that we previously defined to locate the desired node, followed by using the assertIsDisplayed function to assert that the rail is being displayed.

@Test
fun Navigation_Rail_Displayed_In_Landscape() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
    	Home(orientation = Configuration.ORIENTATION_LANDSCAPE)
    }
    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(
        TAG_NAVIGATION_RAIL
    ).assertIsDisplayed()
}

Testing the Rail is not displayed in Portrait

Now that we know the rail is being displayed in landscape mode, weâ€™ll want to test for the rail not being displayed when in portrait mode. For this we can simply compose the Home composable, relying on the default orientation value to enforce portrait mode. Then again using the tag for the navigation rail, we can use the assertDoesNotExist function to assert that the node does not currently exist in the composed UI.

@Test
fun Navigation_Rail_Not_Displayed_In_Portrait() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        Home()
    }
    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(
        TAG_NAVIGATION_RAIL
    ).assertDoesNotExist()
}

Testing the Rail is not displayed for a non-root destination

Aside from the orientation being used to depict how the rail is going to be composed, the composition is also based on the current destination. When the current destination is not a root destination (as in, it is not within the Home nested graph), the navigation rail should not be composed. Weâ€™ll want to assert this through some tests, so weâ€™ll start by writing a new test and composing Home.

@Test
fun Navigation_Rail_Not_Displayed_For_Non_Root_Destination() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        Home()
    }
}

Next, weâ€™ll use the TAG_RAIL_CREATE tag to perform a click action on the floating action button, triggering a navigation event to the Create graph. When this is triggered, we will not be at a root destination - so the navigation rail should not exist. Once this interaction has taken place, we can locate the rail node using the TAG_NAVIGATION_RAIL tag, followed by performing the assertion via the assertDoesNotExist function.

@Test
fun Navigation_Rail_Not_Displayed_For_Non_Root_Destination() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        Home()
    }

    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(
        TAG_RAIL_CREATE
    ).performClick()

    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(
        TAG_NAVIGATION_RAIL
    ).assertDoesNotExist()
}

Testing the Bottom Navigation is displayed in Portrait

Above we wrote a test to assert that the Navigation Rail is displayed when Home is composed in Landscape mode. On the flip side, weâ€™re going to want to assert that the Bottom Navigation is displayed when Home is composed in Portrait mode. Similar to the test for the Navigation Rail, weâ€™ll then compose Home, followed by using the TAG_BOTTOM_NAVIGATION tag to locate the desired node and assert that it is displayed using the assertIsDisplayed function.

@Test
fun Bottom_Navigation_Displayed_In_Portrait() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        Home()
    }
    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(TAG_BOTTOM_NAVIGATION)
        .assertIsDisplayed()
}

Testing the Bottom Navigation is not displayed in Landscape

While we want the Bottom Navigation to be composed in Portrait mode, we donâ€™t want it to be composed in Landscape mode. This time weâ€™ll compose Home and pass in the Configuration.ORIENTATION_LANDSCAPE value for the orientation argument, followed by using the assertDoesNotExist function to assert that the Bottom Navigation has not been composed.

@Test
fun Bottom_Navigation_Not_Displayed_In_Landscape() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        Home(orientation = Configuration.ORIENTATION_LANDSCAPE)
    }
    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(TAG_BOTTOM_NAVIGATION)
        .assertDoesNotExist()
}

Testing the Bottom Navigation is not displayed for a non-root destination

Aside from the orientation being used to depict how the Bottom Navigation is going to be composed, the composition is also based on the current destination. When the current destination is not a root destination (as in, it is not within the Home nested graph), the Bottom Navigation should not be composed. Weâ€™ll want to assert this through some tests, so weâ€™ll start by writing a new test and composing Home.

@Test
fun Bottom_Navigtion_Not_Displayed_For_Non_Root_Destination() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        Home()
    }
}

Next, weâ€™ll use the TAG_RAIL_CREATE tag to perform a click action on the floating action button, triggering a navigation event to the Create graph. When this is triggered, we will not be at a root destination - so the Bottom Navigation should not exist. Once this interaction has taken place, we can locate the rail node using the TAG_BOTTOM_NAVIGATION tag, followed by performing the assertion via the assertDoesNotExist function.

@Test
fun Bottom_Navigtion_Not_Displayed_For_Non_Root_Destination() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        Home()
    }

    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(
        TAG_RAIL_CREATE
    ).performClick()

    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(TAG_BOTTOM_NAVIGATION)
        .assertDoesNotExist()
}

Testing the Content Area

Now that we have tests in place for the composable that houses the content of the dashboard, weâ€™re going to write some tests for the ContentArea composable that is used to show content in the content area of the dashboard. Weâ€™ll start by creating a new test class, ContentAreaTest, configuring the test rule within this.

class ContentAreaTest {

    @get:Rule
    val composeTestRule = createComposeRule()

}

Testing the composed destination

For the first test, weâ€™re going to want to assert that the expected Destination is composed within the ContentArea. When composing the ContentArea, the Destination is passed to it so that the content for the composable can be set. Weâ€™ll want to start here by composing the ContentArea for our test, followed by passing the Destination.Feed. Weâ€™ll store this Destination reference as a variable so that we can use it in the next steps of the test.

@Test
fun Destination_Displayed() {
    val destination = Destination.Feed
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        ContentArea(destination = destination)
    }
}

Now that the ContentArea is being composed, weâ€™ll next want to assert the content that is being composed. To do this, weâ€™re going to set a tag on the parent container within the composable. For this we can use the path of the Destination that is passed to the ContentArea, using the testTag function to set this tag on the Column container.

// ContentArea.kt
@Composable
fun ContentArea(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    destination: Destination
) {
	Column(
		modifier = modifier.testTag(destination.path),
		...
	)
	...
}

With this in place, we can now use the onNodeWithTag function to locate the node using the path of our Destination.Feed reference, followed by using the assertIsDisplayed function to assert that the composable is currently being displayed.

@Test
fun Destination_Displayed() {
    val destination = Destination.Feed
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        ContentArea(destination = destination)
    }
    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(
        destination.path
    ).assertIsDisplayed()
}

Testing the destination title

Now that we know the expected destination is being composed within the ContentArea, weâ€™re going to go ahead and perform some checks on the various composables that are contained within the parent ContentArea. Weâ€™ll start by asserting the expected title is being displayed - for this, weâ€™ll need to write a new test, Content_Title_Displayed, composing the ContentArea with a specified Destination.

@Test
fun Content_Title_Displayed() {
    val destination = Destination.Calendar
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        ContentArea(destination = destination)
    }
}

So that we can locate this composable with our tests weâ€™re going to need to utilise a test tag. Weâ€™ll add a new tag to our Tags.kt file:

// Tags.kt
object Tags {
    const val TAG_CONTENT_TITLE = "content_title"
}

Followed by assigning this tag to the title within ContentArea composable using the testTag modifier.

// Content.kt
Text(
	modifier = Modifier.testTag(TAG_CONTENT_TITLE),
	...
)

With this tag in place, we can now locate the node for the title, using the assertTextEquals function to perform the assertion for the title of the provided Destination.

@Test
fun Content_Title_Displayed() {
    val destination = Destination.Calendar
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        ContentArea(destination = destination)
    }
    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(
        TAG_CONTENT_TITLE
    ).assertTextEquals(destination.title)
}

Testing the destination icon

With the title being asserted, weâ€™re going to wrap up the tests for the ContentArea by asserting that the expected icon is being composed. So that we can check the icon within our tests, weâ€™re going to need to add another tag that can be used in our tests.

// Tags.kt
object Tags {
    const val TAG_CONTENT_ICON = "content_icon"
}

Weâ€™ll then assign this tag to the Icon composable, using the testTag modifier.

// Content.kt
Icon(
	modifier = Modifier.size(80.dp).testTag(TAG_CONTENT_ICON),
	...
)

With this tag in place, we can now locate the node using the TAG_CONTENT_ICON tag. Within our composable, weâ€™re assigning the title of the provided Destination as the content description for the Icon composable. To assert the Icon is being composed as expected for the given Destination, weâ€™ll utilise the assertContentDescriptionEquals function to assert that the expected content description is being set based on the Destination that is provided to the ContentArea composable.

@Test
fun Content_Icon_Displayed() {
    val destination = Destination.Contacts
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        ContentArea(destination = destination)
    }
    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(
        TAG_CONTENT_ICON
    ).assertContentDescriptionEquals(destination.title)
}

Testing the Composable Navigation

Now that we have tests for most of the UI components within our screen, weâ€™re going to write some tests to assert that our navigation graphs are working as expected. This means that we can assert the expected destinations are navigated to when certain actions are triggered within our UI. Weâ€™ll start by creating a new test class, NavigationTest, configuring the test rule within this.

class NavigationTest {

    @get:Rule
    val composeTestRule = createComposeRule()

}

Weâ€™re going to start here by performing an assertion that the Feed Destination is displayed by default, as this is the start destination within our navigation graph. Here weâ€™re going to need to start by composing the Navigation composable, providing the required NavHostController reference when doing so. At this point, the Destination.Feed should be loaded as the current destination of the graph. We previously configured the ContentArea composable to use the path of the given Destination as the test tag, so weâ€™ll use the onNodeWithTag function to retrieve the node using the destination path. We can then use the assertIsDisplayed function to assert that this composable is being displayed, which if satisfied will mean that the Destination.Feed has been loaded and is the current destination of the graph.

@Test
fun Feed_Displayed_By_Default() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        Navigation(
            navController = rememberNavController()
        )
    }

	composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(Destination.Feed.path)
		.assertIsDisplayed()
}

Weâ€™re now going to want to test that the expected Destination is navigated to when the corresponding navigation is triggered via the use of the path. There are 5 other destinations that we want to test are navigated to as expected, so weâ€™re going to create a helper function that will be used to execute all of the required logic for these tests.

In this assertNavigation function, weâ€™re going to want to compose the same Navigation composable as in the previous test. However, weâ€™re going to need to accept a Destination argument for the function, this will be used to trigger a navigation event using the path of that provided Destination. After this composition, weâ€™ll then want to perform the same check as previously defined, using the path of the destination to locate a node, followed by asserting that the node is being displayed. Most of this logic is the same as the initial test that we wrote above, with the difference of the Destination being provided to trigger the navigate function on the controller reference.

private fun assertNavigation(destination: Destination) {
	composeTestRule.setContent {
		val navController = rememberNavController()
		Navigation(navController = navController)
		navController.navigate(destination.path)
	}
    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(destination.path)
        .assertIsDisplayed()
}

With this function in place, we can now put together a test for each of the destinations that are implemented within our graph. Within each of these tests, we can simply call our assertNavigation function, passing the Destination that weâ€™re wishing to test the navigation for.

@Test
fun Contacts_Displayed() {
    assertNavigation(Destination.Contacts)
}

@Test
fun Calendar_Displayed() {
    assertNavigation(Destination.Calendar)
}

@Test
fun Create_Displayed() {
    assertNavigation(Destination.Add)
}

@Test
fun Upgrade_Displayed() {
    assertNavigation(Destination.Upgrade)
}

@Test
fun Settings_Displayed() {
    assertNavigation(Destination.Settings)
}

With all of these tests in place, weâ€™ve covered a lot of different cases that help to ensure our UI is working as expected. Weâ€™ve not only tested that composables are being composed based on the information that they are provided with, but also that they triggered the expected callbacks and trigger state manipulations within our composables. While the tests here arenâ€™t extensive, weâ€™ve been able to learn not only what options are available to us while testing composables, but also the approaches that we can take when doing so.

Building an Email Inbox

A common theme for mobile apps is some form of content feed, quite often a list that displays a list of items to the user. These types of UI will usually be made up of a single UI component (or even a variation of UI components) repeated multiple times, each representing the piece of content that they are assigned to display information on. These UI components in the feed may represent things such as a social media update, a track from an album, an email in your inbox or a person in your contact list.

With this in mind, weâ€™re going to build out a screen displaying a content feed using jetpack compose - for this we will replicate a minimal email inbox. Building this will give us a chance to build a common UI pattern in mobile development, while also diving into more of the available functionality from the Compose framework.

At a first glance, an email inbox doesnâ€™t feel like there is too much going on - we have a parent container that needs to display a list of email UI components. Outside of displaying that list, we need to also configure the rest of the state for that screen. This state will allow us to depict the type of UI that we are displaying to the user - whether it is a list of content items, an empty state or an error state. Once those items are in place we can then start to explore some extended functionality for our list - such as performing actions on those items using buttons and swipe actions. So when it comes to this screen, we need to configure and handle several different things.

  • Build out the state for our screen that represents the items that make up that list
  • Create a view model that will be used to orchestrate data to and from the UI
  • Build the UI component for the individual email inbox items
  • Build the UI for the parent of the content items
  • Handle the state when the inbox is loading
  • Handle the state when the inbox is empty
  • Handle the state when the inbox fails to load
  • Provide support for the list to be manually refreshed by the user
  • Provide support for the user to delete email items via a swipe-to-dismiss gesture

Defining the Inbox State

Within our inbox, weâ€™re going to be displaying a list of email items - each item will represent the same email UI component but have data that is specific to that instance of an item. Each one of these items will then be used to represent an email within our inbox, containing just the data that is required to display details on that email within the inbox. With this in mind, our inbox state is going to be made up of:

  • A list of items that represent that emails within the inbox
    • Each of these items will then consist of a title and message preview
  • The current state of the screen. For example, is the screen currently loading.

With the above pieces, we can see that there is not too much separate state that we need to think about - we can break this down into either there being a feed of content, a loading state, or a no-content state. Letâ€™s start to take the above requirements and build out a class that will represent the state of our composable UI. Weâ€™ll start by creating a new class to hold the state of our screen:

//InboxState.kt
data class InboxState(

)

Defining the Inbox Status

As mentioned above, weâ€™re going to need to handle a collection of states that the screen can represent. To simplify our state model, weâ€™re going to create a new enum that will indicate a higher-level state that our screen is in. While we could use boolean flags for this, having this typed state reduces the complexity of our state model, keeping it simpler to understand. Weâ€™ll create this enum class with the name of InboxStatus:

enum class InboxStatus {
  LOADING, HAS_EMAILS, ERROR, EMPTY
}

Here we can see four different states that our inbox can be in:

  • Loading: The inbox is currently loading the list of emails
  • Has Emails: The inbox has loaded a list of emails
  • Error: There has been an error while loading the list of emails
  • Empty: The inbox is empty and there are no emails to display

With these different InboxStatus values in place, we can go ahead and add a status property to our InboxState class - this allows the high-level state of our inbox to be represented by a single field. Weâ€™ll set the default value of this to LOADING, so that when our screen is initialised the loading state is displayed by default.

data class InboxState(
  val status: InboxStatus = InboxStatus.LOADING
)

Defining the Email item

With this status in place, we can start thinking about the second part of our state - the lower level piece of our screen in the form of the email list. When it comes to this list of emails to be displayed on our screen, weâ€™re going to need to represent this in our state using a list of models that hold the details for each of those emails. For this weâ€™ll create a new class, Email:

data class Email(
  val id: String,
  val title: String,
  val description: String
)

Here we can see three different pieces of information that are to be represented within each of the email items.

  • id: The unique identifier used to represent an email
  • title: The title of the email message
  • description: The description that represents a portion of the email content

This class will represent an email within our Inbox, holding the various properties which can be used to display information within each of our email UI components. With this model in place, we can then go ahead and modify our InboxState so that our email inbox is reflected here. Weâ€™ll do this by defining a content property that represents a list of these Email models.

data class InboxState(
  val status: InboxStatus = InboxStatus.LOADING,
  val content: List<Email>? = null
)

With this in place, we now have the required data that can be used to make up the state of our screen.

Creating the Inbox ViewModel

Now that we have the state modelled for our Inbox, we can start thinking about the ViewModel that will be used to manage this state and provide a way to orchestrate information to the user interface.

Setting up the ViewModel

Before we can get started here, weâ€™re going to add a new dependency to our project that will give us access to the Android Lifecycle ViewModel class:

implementation "androidx.lifecycle:lifecycle-viewmodel-compose:2.4.0"

ðŸ’¡ You arenâ€™t required to use a ViewModel when working with compose. For the sake of these exercises, it helps us to keep things simple and follow an approach that many developers are familiar with.

Weâ€™ll begin by creating a new ViewModel, called InboxViewModel.

// InboxViewModel.kt
class InboxViewModel : ViewModel() {

}

This ViewModel is going to need to hold a reference to the state of our screen. For this weâ€™re going to utilise StateFlow - this allows us to create a state-holder observable flow that will emit the default state we provide to it, along with any updates that occur during its lifetime. Here weâ€™ll create a new MutableStateFlow instance, providing a reference to our InboxState class as the default value for our StateFlow:

class InboxViewModel : ViewModel() {
	val uiState = MutableStateFlow(InboxState())
}
