With this in place, we now have a StateFlow reference that is holding a reference to our InboxState, initialising it with a new instance of the state class and relying on the defaults that the constructor provides.

Loading the Inbox Data

Because weâ€™re not working with real data for our screen, weâ€™re going to start by building a Factory class that will be used to create a list of mock Emails for our Inbox. It would be possible for us to create some way of generating random information - but for simplicity sake, weâ€™re going to create a simple makeEmailList function that will provide us with a list of Email instances.

object EmailFactory {

  fun makeEmailList(): List<Email> {
    return listOf(
      Email(
        "1",
        "Did you get my email?",
        "Hey, I just wanted to check that you got my last email    
        - I know you're pretty busy these days!"
      ),
      Email(
        "2",
        "Welcome!",
        "Thanks for signing up to our mailing list. You'll need  
        to confirm your email address to receive future 
        emails from us."
      ),
      Email(
        "3",
        "Thanks for your order!",
        "Your order is on its way! Keep an eye on its progress 
        using our tracking system."
      ),
      Email(
        "4",
        "Join our team? :)",
        "Thanks for spending the time to interview with us over 
        the last few weeks - we'd love to invite you to join 
        our team!"
      ),
      Email(
        "5",
        "RE: Coffee",
        "Was great to bump into your last week - I'd love to  
        catch-up properly, maybe we could meet at the weekend? 
        There's a lovely new coffee bar on my street!"
      ),
      Email(
        "6",
        "You didn't win this time",
        "Thanks for entering our competition. Unfortunately you 
        didn't win this time! Please try again soon, you might    
        have better luck in future :)"
      )
    )
  }
}

With this sample data in place, we now have some instances of the Email class which can be used to display content for our Inbox. To get this data into our state, weâ€™ll need to create a new function inside of our ViewModel which will simulate the loading of our Inbox content. Weâ€™ll start here by creating a new function called loadContent:

// InboxViewModel.kt
fun loadContent() {
  
}

With this function in place, weâ€™re going to want to simulate what would happen if this function was going to be triggering an asynchronous request (e.g making a request to an API to retrieve the Inbox data). For this reason, weâ€™re going to want to display the loading state inside of our Inbox UI. Weâ€™ll do this by updating our state to reflect that it should currently be represented as loading.

fun loadContent() {
	uiState.value = uiState.value.copy(
		status = InboxStatus.LOADING
	)
}

Now that we are emitting a loading state, we can now we can go ahead and utilise our email factory to create the list of content for our inbox, emitting it as the content property within our InboxState. At the same time, weâ€™ll switch our inbox status from Loading to Success, indicating that we are no longer in a state of loading content and the UI can reflect that we have successfully loaded the required data.

fun loadContent() {
	uiState.value = uiState.value.copy(
		status = InboxStatus.LOADING
	)
    uiState.value = uiState.value.copy(
		status = InboxStatus.SUCCESS,
		emails = EmailFactory.makeContentList()
	)
}

ðŸ’¡ While this loading state will be replaced almost instantly, this mimics what we would expect to see in a real data loading scenario.

Handling State Events

From our inbox, there are going to be a collection of user-triggered events, and when these occur weâ€™re going to need to handle them inside of our ViewModel so that the state can be updated accordingly. With these handled by our ViewModel, this allows us to have a single way of our composable UI communicating with the ViewModel, rather than needing to pass the entire ViewModel or many references to separate functions which could be used to trigger state changes. Instead, we can pass a single function reference to our composable UI which can then be used to trigger these events in the ViewModel. For these events weâ€™re going to need to define different types that can be triggered, so weâ€™ll go ahead and create a new sealed class to represent these.

sealed class InboxEvent {

}

With this sealed class in place, we can start to think about using it to represent the different events that can occur. Weâ€™re going to start by handling the scenario where the user might trigger a refresh of the screen (for example, when the inbox is displayed as empty). For this, weâ€™ll create a new event called RefreshContent.

sealed class InboxEvent {

    object RefreshContent: InboxEvent()

}

With this event in place, this can now be triggered from our composable UI to cause a state change within our view model. For that to happen though, we need to write this logic inside of our ViewModel. For this weâ€™ll add a handleEvent function to our ViewModel, taking an instance of the ContentEvent type as an argument. This function can then be called whenever an event is triggered and needs to be handled.

fun handleEvent(contentEvent: ContentEvent) {
  when (contentEvent) {
    
  }
}

Within this function, we have a when block in place that will allow us to individually handle any triggered ContentEvent types. Within this block, weâ€™ll want to handle the RefreshContent event type and when that occurs, weâ€™ll need to reload the content of the Inbox using the previously created loadContent function.

fun handleEvent(contentEvent: ContentEvent) {
  when (contentEvent) {
    is InboxEvent.RefreshContent -> loadContent()
  }
}

Other than refreshing the content of the Inbox, the only thing that we need to support is the ability to delete an email via the swipe-to-delete gesture. When this action is performed weâ€™ll want to trigger a corresponding event, so weâ€™ll create another ContentEvent type called DeleteContent. This type will need to take an argument that represents the ID of the email to be deleted, this can then be used to remove the corresponding email item from the inbox state.

sealed class InboxEvent {

    object RefreshContent: InboxEvent()

    class DeleteEmail(val id: String): InboxEvent()

}

At this point, weâ€™re able to trigger this event, but itâ€™s not being handled yet by our ViewModel. Weâ€™ll need to start here by creating some logic that will remove the email with the given ID from our list of emails. In a real app, weâ€™d be hitting an API here, but because weâ€™re dealing with our mock data weâ€™ll simply remove the email from the list and have this reflected in our Inbox state. Here weâ€™ll create a new function, deleteEmail, passing in the email ID. Within this, weâ€™ll filter out any emails with that ID from our list and then assign this list to the state of our Inbox.

private fun deleteEmail(id: String) {
  uiState.value = uiState.value.build {
    content = this.content?.filter { 
      it.id != id
    }
  }
}

When this function is called with the ID of the mail to remove, our state will be updated to reflect the new Inbox without the deleted email. And now that we have this function implemented, we can go ahead and adjust our handleEvent function so that this deleteEmail function is called when an DeleteEmail event is triggered.

fun handleEvent(contentEvent: ContentEvent) {
  when (contentEvent) {
    is InboxEvent.RefreshContent -> loadContent()
   	is InboxEvent.DeleteEmail -> deleteEmail(inboxEvent.id)
  }
}

With this final addition in place, our ViewModel is now capable of handling these two different event types. This allows our user to trigger the refreshing and deletion of content while interacting with our composable UI.

Creating the Inbox UI

With the view model and state management all in place, weâ€™re ready to move on and start implementing the composable UI for our Inbox. Using the InboxState that we defined in the previous sections, weâ€™ll compose a User Interface that represents the current state of our screen. This state will then be manipulated through the InboxViewModel.

This UI will give our users a screen displaying the Inbox for a mock email account - alongside displaying a list of emails, the UI will provide the ability to delete emails via swipe gestures. While building this UI weâ€™ll dive into the specifics of how various composables can be configured and used, along with adding some nice touches to improve the User Experience of our Email Inbox in the form of Accessibility and Animations.

Setting up the entry point

Before we can get start building our project, weâ€™re going to need to add a couple of dependencies that weâ€™re going to need. Weâ€™ll start here by adding these to the build.gradle file for our new project:

// provides access to the `ComponentActivity` class that can be used to compose UI components
implementation 'androidx.activity:activity-compose:1.4.0'

// foundational classes from the Compose APIs
implementation 
	"androidx.compose.foundation:foundation:$compose_version"

// UI components from the Compose APIs
implementation "androidx.compose.ui:ui:$compose_version"

// Material Design components from the Compose APIs
implementation 
	"androidx.compose.material:material:$compose_version"

// Provides an extended collection of Material Iconography
implementation 
	"androidx.compose.material:material-icons-extended:$compose_version"

// Tooling functionality for Composables, such as previews
implementation "androidx.compose.ui:ui-tooling-preview:$compose_version"
debugImplementation "androidx.compose.ui:ui-tooling:$compose_version"

The current release of this book is building against 1.1.0 of compose - be sure to check compatibly if using a newer version.

With these added to our project, weâ€™re now ready to start building out our UI. Weâ€™re going to start here by building the access point to our feature - this is how the messaging feature will initially be composed within our user interface.

Here weâ€™ll begin by building a root composable function, Inbox that will be used to house all of our Composable UI for the Email Inbox screen. For this, weâ€™ll create a new Kotlin file called Inbox.kt (to keep our composables nicely organised), followed by creating a new composable function, Inbox:

// Inbox.kt
@Composable
fun Inbox() { }

This composable is going to be the entry point to our Email Inbox screen - so we donâ€™t want this function to have to take any arguments. The point that is navigating to the inbox will be able to just compose this function, and this composable will handle everything else. While you wonâ€™t see anything visual just yet, youâ€™ll want to compose this Inbox composable within the setContent block of the activity that was created through the project wizard. Then as we build out the project, weâ€™ll be able to visualise the Inbox when running the project.

Within this root level composable weâ€™re going to want to force our application theme on the composables that are contained inside of it, so weâ€™ll add a MaterialTheme composable declaration here.

@Composable
fun Inbox() {
    MaterialTheme {
        
    }
}

ðŸ’¡Wrapping your composable hierarchy in a theme allows all components to be consistently styled. In most cases, this can happen at the highest point of composition - even within the setContent function of the parent activity that is composing the UI.

This now means that for any of the composables that are composed in the content block of our MaterialTheme, these will be themed according to the colors and styles that are declared within our theme.

Saying that though, we donâ€™t currently have any composables that are going to make up the content of our email inbox. Weâ€™ll go ahead and create a new composable function here, EmailInbox. The difference here is that this composable is going to be responsible for composing our UI based on the state of the screen, meaning that this function is going to take some form of argument. Because itâ€™s composing UI based on our state, itâ€™s also going to need to propagate any events so that the state can be updated accordingly. For this reason, itâ€™s also going to need to be able to handle the InboxEvent types that we previously defined. Weâ€™ll need to define two additional arguments for our composable to satisfy these requirements.

// EmailInbox.kt
@Composable
fun EmailInbox(
	modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    inboxState: InboxState,
    inboxEventListener: (inboxEvent: InboxEvent) -> Unit
) {

}

ðŸ’¡ Itâ€™s good practice to allow a modifier to be passed into a composable, this means that the parent who is composing the child can control the composition to some extent. This also helps to keep your composable functions re-usable across your UI.

This composable will take an InboxState that represents the state of our screen, along with an event handler that allows us to pass up InboxState instances when they are triggered.

So, why canâ€™t this just be the entry point to our email inbox screen? One clear thing here is that this decouples the composable with being concerned about how the state is provided - passing in the state via an argument makes it simpler, as in, it gets passed a state and composes UI based on it. This also makes it much easier to write tests our composable - because we can simply pass it a state object and perform assertions based on that, rather than needing to simulate user actions and perform mocking to produce expected states.

With this composable defined, we can then hop up to the root Inbox that we defined and compose the EmailInbox within our theme block.

@Composable
fun Inbox() {
    MaterialTheme {
        EmailInbox(
			modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
            inboxState = ...,
            handleEvent = ...
        )
    }
}

Things arenâ€™t quite satisfied here yet though, we need to provide both the state and event handler to our EmailInbox. Weâ€™ll be using our InboxViewModel that we created in the previous sections to satisfy these arguments, so weâ€™ll first need to retrieve an instance of this. So that we can access this information, weâ€™re going to need to obtain an instance to this ViewModel inside of our composable. Here weâ€™ll use the viewModel function from the lifecycle-viewmodel-compose package. This will retrieve an instance of the desired ViewModel, creating one if it does not currently exist. 

val viewModel: InboxViewModel = viewModel()

We can then use this ViewModel within our root composable for our required arguments.

  • Weâ€™ll use collectAsState() to collect the emissions of our StateFlow reference from our ViewModel as composable state. Weâ€™ll then pass the value of this emission as the state reference to our composable.
  • For event handling, our ViewModel contains a function that matches the requirements of our lambda function argument. We can pass this function reference directly to our composable using viewModel::handleEvent.
@Composable
fun Inbox() {
    val viewModel: InboxViewModel = viewModel()
    MaterialTheme {
        EmailInbox(
			modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
            inboxState = viewModel.uiState
				.collectAsState().value,
            handleEvent = viewModel::handleEvent
        )
    }
}

As a final tweak, weâ€™re going to want to ensure that the email inbox content is loaded upon the initial composition. Here weâ€™ll use the LaunchedEffect side-effect - this is a block of code that will only be run based on the key that is provided to it (so if the key changes, the block will be re-run). In our case we can simply provide a Unit as the key, meaning that the block will only be run on the initial composition. This means that the loadContent function will only be run on the initial composition of our UI.

@Composable
fun Inbox() {
    val viewModel: InboxViewModel = viewModel()
    MaterialTheme {
        EmailInbox(
            inboxState = viewModel.uiState.collectAsState().value,
            handleEvent = viewModel::handleEvent
        )
    }
    LaunchedEffect(Unit) {
        viewModel.loadContent()
    }
}

With this in place, we have a composable function that will house the composables making up our email inbox UI. When we initially created the InboxState class we only actually built it out using two different properties - a high-level state of the screen, along with a list of emails to display in the inbox. While there are only two properties here, the different types represented by that high-level state each compose a different piece of UI. Alongside the general structure of our composable UI for the Inbox, there are going to be a few different pieces that will be used to compose what we need here:

With the above in mind, we can start building out a collection of composable functions to build out the Composable UI representing our Inbox.

Defining the Screen Scaffold

Because of the defined layout for our screen, we have two clear sections of our UI - the title and content areas. With this in mind, this is a great use case for the Scaffold composable.

// EmailInbox.kt
@Composable
fun EmailInbox(
	modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    inboxState: InboxState,
    inboxEventListener: (inboxEvent: InboxEvent) -> Unit
) {
	Scaffold(
		modifier: modifier
	) {

	}
}

Creating the Top App Bar

Weâ€™re going to start by creating the title area for our composable UI, this will be represented by a TopAppBar composable. This will be provided as the argument for the topBar property of the Scaffold composable. For our TopAppBar, weâ€™re going to override a couple of the default properties.

We want the background color of the bar to be the same as the surface color of our application, this is so that it matches the background color of our inbox area. To blend these two elements even further, weâ€™ll go ahead and remove the elevation of the TopAppBar by setting this property to 0dp.

// emailInbox.kt
Scaffold(
	modifier: modifier,
	topBar = {
		TopAppBar(
	  		backgroundColor = MaterialTheme.colors.surface,
	  		elevation = 0.dp
		)
  	}
)

At this point, we have a TopAppBar that is themed to the surface color of our application, without any kind of floating appearance due to the removed elevation. However, our TopAppBar is not currently displaying any content on the screen to the user. Next, weâ€™ll go ahead and add a title to our TopAppBar, utilising the Text composable to do so.

Scaffold(
	modifier: modifier,
  	topBar = {
		..
		Text(
  			modifier = Modifier
    		.fillMaxWidth()
    		.padding(top = 8.dp),
  		fontWeight = FontWeight.Bold,
  		textAlign = TextAlign.Center,
  		text = stringResource(id = R.string.title_inbox, 
			inboxState.emails.count()
  		)
)

For our Text composable weâ€™ve styled e a couple of different things:

  • Weâ€™ll want the title to be displayed in the center of the TopAppBar. To achieve this we use the fillMaxWidth() modifier, along with setting the textAlign property to TextAlign.Center.
  • So that our title stands out a bit more, weâ€™ve set the fontWeight to FontWeight.Bold.
  • We assign a title to the TopAppBar using a string resource defined in our project.
<string name="title_inbox">Inbox (%s)</string>

Using the stringResource function we also provide a value to replace the %s declaration in our string resource. This represents the count for the number of emails in the user inbox.

With this Text composable in place, we can now assign this to the title argument of our Scaffold.

Scaffold(
	modifier: modifier,
	topBar = {
		TopAppBar(
	  		backgroundColor = MaterialTheme.colors.surface,
	  		elevation = 0.dp,
	  		title = {
        		Text(
          			modifier = Modifier
            			.fillMaxWidth()
            			.padding(top = 8.dp),
          			fontWeight = FontWeight.Bold,
          			textAlign = TextAlign.Center,
          			text = stringResource(
						id = R.string.title_inbox, 
						inboxState.emails.count()
		  			)
        		)
      		}
		)
  	}
)

With this title in place, we will now have a title displayed at the top of our scaffold - representing the heading for our screen, and a currently empty content area.

Setting up the Content Area

With our title in place, we can now move on to displaying some composables inside of the content area for our Inbox scaffold. Within this content area, we are going to be working with several different states - loading, error, empty and the email collection itself. Each of these states is going to be represented by single composable functions, which weâ€™ll want to house in some form of parent container. For this container, weâ€™ll go ahead and use the Box composable.

Scaffold(
	modifier: modifier,
 	topAppBar = ...
) {
  	Box {
	
  	}
}

By default, the Box will wrap the size of its children, aligning them at the top/start of itself. We want all of these children composable to represent the full content area of our scaffold, giving us the full-screen estate for each of these children and allowing them to handle their alignment within that available space. Weâ€™ll go ahead and use the fillMaxSize() modifier to allow the Box to fill the entire available content area of our Scaffold, along with setting the contentAlignment to Alignment.Center - that way any children who do not fill the entire box will be position in the center of the container.

Scaffold(
  topAppBar = ...
) {
  Box(
	modifier = Modifier.fillMaxSize(),
	contentAlignment = Alignment.Center
  ) {

  }
}

Handling the loading state

At this point we have an empty Box composable, acting as the container for the content of our Inbox. Weâ€™re going to start populating this by first satisfying the loading state of our Inbox, creating a new composable function to hold a reference to a CircularProgressIndicator composable.

// loading.kt
@Composable
fun Loading() {
    CircularProgressIndicator()
}

The CircularProgressIndicator will compose an indeterminate circular progress, resulting in a spinning indicator that will spin for the entirety of its composition within our UI.

Weâ€™ll want to show this when the status of our inbox state represents the InboxStatus.LOADING that we defined in the previous section of this chapter. To handle this, weâ€™ll go ahead and add a check for this within our box.

Box(
	...
) {
	if (inboxState.status == InboxStatus.LOADING) {
	  Loading()
	}
}

Because our UI is being recomposed whenever our InboxState reference changes, we can now use the status flag to compose our Loading composable whenever this flag represents the InboxStatus.LOADING state.

Handling the error state

Now that we have a loading indicator displaying within our UI, weâ€™re going to want to handle some of the different cases that could occur within our state. One of these states is going to be that something didnâ€™t go quite right while our inbox was being loaded, and in these cases, weâ€™re going to want to portray this error to the user. For this, weâ€™re going to create a new composable to represent this error state.

@Composable
fun ErrorState(
	modifier: Modifier = Modifier
) {

}

Within this composable weâ€™re going to compose two children - one will represent a message to display to the user, with the other being a button that can be used to attempt to reload the inbox content. Because we are working with multiple composables here, weâ€™re going to first declare a parent container. Weâ€™ll use the Column composable here so that we can stack these two children vertically.

@Composable
fun ErrorState(
	modifier: Modifier = Modifier
) {
	Column(modifier = modifier) {

  	}
}

So that we can display an error message to the user, weâ€™re going to need to add this message to the resources of our application. Weâ€™ll go ahead and declare a new string resource that represents a generic error message for our inbox.

<string name="message_content_error">
	Whoops, there was a problem loading the content.
</string>

We can then go ahead and define a Text composable, providing this string resource as the textual content to be displayed for the body of the composable - using the stringResource function to access this string resource.

@Composable
fun ErrorState(
	modifier: Modifier = Modifier
) {
  	Column(modifier = modifier) {
		Text(text = stringResource(
	  		id = R.string.message_content_error)
		)
  	}
}

Because we want the user to be able to recover from this error, weâ€™re going to next add an action button that allows the user to refresh the inbox data. Weâ€™ll start by adding a string resource for the message that will be displayed in this button:

<string name="label_try_again">Try again?</string>

Along with this resource, weâ€™re going to add the Button composable to our Column - supported by the Spacer composable to create some visual space between these two items. For the content of our Button, weâ€™ll use a Text composable, displaying the string resource that we defined above.

@Composable
fun ErrorState(
	modifier: Modifier = Modifier
) {
  Column(modifier = modifier) {
	Text(text = stringResource(
	  id = R.string.message_content_error)
	)

	Spacer(modifier = Modifier.height(12.dp))

    Button(onClick = {
      
    }) {
      Text(text = stringResource(
		id = R.string.label_try_again))
    }
  }
}

At this point though, our button isnâ€™t doing anything. To resolve this, weâ€™re going to need to allow our button to trigger the inbox refresh function that is located within our view model. To avoid us passing our ViewModel directly into this error composable, weâ€™re instead going to pass a reference to the function which can be triggered. Using the specific InboxEvent, the onClick handler of our Button can be used to trigger the refresh our inbox to recover from the error state.

@Composable
fun ErrorState(
	modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
  	inboxEventListener: (inboxEvent: InboxEvent) -> Unit
) {
  	Column(modifier = modifier) {
		Text(text = stringResource(
	  		id = R.string.message_content_error)
		)

		Spacer(modifier = Modifier.height(12.dp))

    	Button(onClick = {
      		inboxEventListener(InboxEvent.RefreshInbox)
    	}) {
      		Text(text = stringResource(
				id = R.string.label_try_again))
    	}
  	}
}

At this point, our Error composable looks a little off - things arenâ€™t quite lined up properly. This is because, by default, children of a column will be aligned to the Start of the container. To improve how things appear visually here, weâ€™re going to align the content of our column in the horizontal center. Weâ€™ll do this by setting the horizontalAlignment of our Column to CenterHorizontally.

@Composable
fun ErrorState(
	modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
	inboxEventListener: (inboxEvent: InboxEvent) -> Unit
) {
  Column(
	modifier = modifier,
    horizontalAlignment = Alignment.CenterHorizontally
  ) {
	...
  }
}

With some alignment now set for our content, we can see that things are being displayed nicely in the center of our error composable.

So that things arenâ€™t so cramped here, weâ€™ll go ahead and use the padding modifier to create some visual spacing between the edges of the content and the container.

@Composable
fun ErrorState(
	modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
	inboxEventListener: (inboxEvent: InboxEvent) -> Unit
) {
  Column(
	modifier = modifier.padding(16.dp),
    horizontalAlignment = Alignment.CenterHorizontally
  ) {
	...
  }
}

We can see with this padding in place, there is a better visual spacing within our composable.

Finally, weâ€™re going to need to ensure that this error state is composed when required, so weâ€™ll go ahead and add to the if block within our Box composable. Here weâ€™ll want to compose our error state if our Inbox State reference has its status flag assigned as the InboxStatus.ERROR value.

Box(
  ...
) {
  if (inboxState.status == InboxStatus.LOADING) {		Loading()
  } else if (inboxState.status == InboxStatus.ERROR) {
	ErrorState {
      inboxEventListener(InboxEvent.RefreshInbox)
    }
  }
}

With this in place, we are now composing our error composable when an error has occurred loading the inbox - allowing the user to recover from this scenario via the provided action.

Composing the empty state

Aside from an error occurring, it might be the case that there are no emails returned for the userâ€™s inbox - itâ€™s never a bad thing to reach inbox zero after all! For this, weâ€™re going to want to display some form of empty state to the user - this is going to look very similar to the Error composable that we previously created.

We could create some form of composable that can be used for both error/empty states, but to keep things simpler for examples sake we will create a new composable called EmptyState which look pretty much the same as our existing ErrorState. The main difference here will be the use of two different string resources for the title and action composables:

<string name="message_empty_content">
	Nothing to show here yet.
</string>
<string name="label_check_again">Check again</string>

With these in place, we can go ahead and copy our ErrorState composable, switching out the string resources being used within the child composables.

@Composable
fun EmptyState(
	modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
  	inboxEventListener: (inboxEvent: InboxEvent) -> Unit
) {
  	Column(
		modifier = modifier.padding(16.dp),
    	horizontalAlignment = Alignment.CenterHorizontally
  	) {
    	Text(text = stringResource(id = 
      		R.string.message_empty_content))
    	Spacer(modifier = Modifier.height(12.dp))

    	Button(onClick = {
      		inboxEventListener(InboxEvent.RefreshInbox)
    	}) {
      		Text(text = stringResource(id =
        		R.string.label_check_again))
    	}
  	}
}

With this EmptyState composable in place, weâ€™re now ready for it to be composed within our UI. Weâ€™ll hope back over to the Box composable within our Scaffold content area, modifying the if clause to handle the Empty state. What weâ€™ll do here is place the EmptyState within the else block - that way if something hasnâ€™t gone wrong and our screen isnâ€™t loading, we can assume that at this point, the response is going to be that of an empty one (which also gives us something to fall back on).

Box(
  ...
) {
  if (inboxState.status == InboxStatus.LOADING) {		Loading()
  } else if (inboxState.status == InboxStatus.ERROR) {
	ErrorState {
      inboxEventListener(InboxEvent.RefreshInbox)
    }
  } else {
    EmptyState {
      inboxEventListener(InboxEvent.RefreshInbox)
    }
  }
}

Displaying the Email Inbox

At this point, weâ€™ve handled most of the different states that can be represented by our Inbox. The remaining state however is probably the most important one for our UI, being the actual list of emails that allows the user to view their inbox. So that we can get started within implementing this part of our UI, weâ€™ll go ahead and create a new composable function, EmailList, that takes a collection of Email items from our Inbox State reference.

@Composable
fun EmailList(
	modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    emails: List<Email>
) {

}

Inside of this composable weâ€™re going to need to display a list of emails - while we are hardcoding these emails within our state, in a real scenario we wonâ€™t know exactly how many email items will come back for us to display. For this reason, weâ€™re going to utilise the LazyColumn composable, which will only compose its children as they are required - making it much more efficient than composing everything at the same time when it might not even be visible to the user.

LazyColumn(
  modifier = modifier
) {

}

Weâ€™re going to need to add support for the items that make up our LazyColumn. The items provided here need to be composed using the item function provided through the LazyListScope - this is so that a unique key can be provided for each item being composed, allowing the LazyColumn to correctly manage the current scroll position on the screen.

With that said, weâ€™ll go ahead and utilise the items function - this allows us to provide a list that we wish to compose items from, along with defining how the key for that item should be generated. When it comes to key generation, weâ€™re going to want to use the id from the Email class - each of our emails has a unique ID, so this will satisfy the key requirements for the LazyColumn items. Along with this key generation being called for each item, the itemContent block will also be called - this is where we will declare the composition for each item that is being composed within our UI.

LazyColumn(
  modifier = modifier
) {
	items(emails, key = { item -> item.id }) { email ->

	}
}

Setting up Swipe-to-Dismiss

At this point, weâ€™re ready to define the composable content that represents the body of each email in our list. Because weâ€™re supporting swipe-to-dismiss within our inbox, this is going to be a bit more involved than if we were simply displaying an Email composable. For this reason, each Email within our LazyColumn is going to be represented by the SwipeToDismiss composable. This allows us to support the swipe-to-dismiss behaviour, provided out-of-the-box by the Compose APIs.

items(...) {
	SwipeToDismiss(
  
	)
}

When it comes to the SwipeToDismiss composable, there are going to be a couple of things that we need to configure which will control the behaviour of our composable. The first behaviour we want to control here is the supported directions of the swipe-to-dismiss gesture, with the supported values being DismissDirection.StartToEnd and DismissDirection.EndToStart. Weâ€™re only going to support StartToEnd within our LazyColumn meaning that users will be able to dismiss an item by swiping the item from the start to the end, so weâ€™ll go ahead and declare this using the directions argument of the SwipeToDismiss composable.

SwipeToDismiss(
	directions = setOf(
  		DismissDirection.StartToEnd
  	)
)

When swiping an item to perform a dismiss gesture, we might want to control the position at which the gesture becomes a dismissal. For example, we might not want the dismiss action to be triggered until the item has been swiped to the halfway point of the swappable row. To control this we can utilise the dismissThresholds property of the SwipeToDismiss composable. For this, we will need to provide an instance of the FractionalThreshold class, which is used to define a point between two anchors at which the specified concept should be triggered. In the case of swipe to dismiss, we are anchoring between 0f and 1f - where 0f is the start of the item and 1f is the end. The value we define for the FractionalThreshold will depict the swipe position at which the item will become dismissed. Weâ€™ll go ahead and define a value here in the form of 0.15f, meaning that the dismissal will be activated once the email has been swiped 15% of the way across the screen.

SwipeToDismiss(
  	directions = setOf(
    	DismissDirection.StartToEnd
  	),
  	dismissThresholds = {
    	FractionalThreshold(0.15f)
  	}
)

Now that weâ€™ve configured some initial setup for our SwipeToDismiss composable, weâ€™re going to need to set up the actual content to be used for the items. When it comes to the SwipeToDismiss there are two parts that come into play here - the foreground of the item (which is initially displayed to the user), followed by the background of the item (which is revealed once the swipe gesture is performed).

Weâ€™re going to need to define a composable for each of these foreground and background states, both of which will be provided to our SwipeToDismiss reference.

Defining the item foreground

As mentioned previously, the foreground of the item is the state which is displayed to the user when the item is undismissed - which will be the initial state when our UI is composed. In this case of our email inbox, this foreground is going to represent the content of the Email. Weâ€™re going to go ahead and create a new composable which will be used to display information for each email.

@Composable
fun EmailItem(
	modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    email: Email
) {

}

This composable takes an individual instance of an Email class, which will be used to populate the child composables of the EmailItem. The foreground of each email item is going to be composed to represent the title and body of the email:

While this looks pretty minimal at a first glance, this is going to consist of a couple of composables. Weâ€™ll start here by defining a Card composable - this will be used to hold the entire content of the Email class, displaying the body inside of a Card parent. We use the fillMaxSize modifier for the card so that the card fills the available space, but so that the card is not pressed to the sides of the screen (and against the other cards within the list) weâ€™re also going to apply the padding modifier with a value of 16dp.

Card(
	modifier = modifier.padding(16.dp)
) {

}

While there is no content body that weâ€™ve yet defined, our card will be filling the available space for the LazyColumn item, along with using the assigned padding to create space around its outside area.

When it comes to the Email reference that this card has, weâ€™re going to want to display the title and description fields inside of the email item card. However, the Card composable only allows a single child to be placed inside of its content area - so weâ€™re going to need to declare a child of the card which will be used to hold the composables for the title and description fields of our Email reference.

Because we want to vertically stack the title and description of the Email, for this weâ€™re going to utilise the Column composable. Along with defining this Column, weâ€™re going to assign some modifiers 

Column(
	modifier = Modifier
    	.padding(16.dp)
		.fillMaxWidth()
) {

}

Assigning some padding here will create some spacing so that our column is not pressed against the edges of the card. Along with this, fillMaxWidth will allow the Column to take up the whole available width within the card - ensuring that the textual content of the composables we are going to provide uses all of the available space. With this Column in place, we can start thinking about the children that we can add here.

Weâ€™ll start here with the title of the email - weâ€™ll display this using a Text composable. We wonâ€™t need to customise much here, weâ€™ll assign the title of the email using the text property of the composable, along with setting the fontWeight to the value of Bold.

Column(
	modifier = Modifier
    	.padding(16.dp)
    	.fillMaxWidth()
) {
	Text(
    	text = email.title,
    	fontWeight = FontWeight.Bold
  	)
}

With this in place, we have the title of our Email displaying within our card item.

Alongside the title, weâ€™re going to want to display the description of the email - this will act as a short preview of the email content.

For this, weâ€™re going to use another Text composable to display the email preview content to the user. Before we add this though, weâ€™re going to add another composable in the form of a Spacer - this will create some visual space between the title and the description

Column(
	modifier = Modifier
    	.padding(16.dp)
    	.fillMaxWidth()
) {
  	...

  	Spacer(modifier = Modifier.height(8.dp))
}

Next, weâ€™ll add a Text composable to represent the content of our email reference. Weâ€™ll assign a couple of different properties here:

  • fontSize: this will be set to 14sp, making it appear slightly smaller than the title of the email
  • maxLines: setting this value ensures that our Text composable will not have unlimited height available - weâ€™ll cap this at 2 lines.
  • overflow: because weâ€™ve capped the maxLines for the composable, weâ€™re going to declare that any overflow that extends these 2 lines will be handled by the display of ellipsis.
Column(
  	modifier = Modifier
    	.padding(16.dp)
    	.fillMaxWidth()
) {
  	...

  	Text(
    	text = email.description,
    	fontSize = 14.sp,
    	maxLines = 2,
    	overflow = TextOverflow.Ellipsis
  	)
}

Adding this second Text composable results in our email card item being fully populated.

We can next go ahead and provide this EmailItem composable to the dismissContent argument of our SwipeToDismiss composable - passing the reference to the current Email item.

SwipeToDismiss(
  	directions = setOf(
    	DismissDirection.StartToEnd
  	),
  	dismissThresholds = {
    	FractionalThreshold(0.15f)
  	},
  	dismissContent = {
    	EmailItem(
			modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
      		email = email
    	)
  	}
)

With this in place, weâ€™ll be able to see the provided email content within the body of our card, with this being swipeable from the start to the end of the dismiss row.

Defining the item background

Now that we have the foreground for our email item created, we can perform the swipe-to-dismiss gesture on an email within our inbox. However, when we perform this gesture there is currently no indication to the user around what that action will result in. For this purpose, weâ€™re going to implement the background argument of the SwipeToDismiss composable - allowing us to provide a composable to be used for the background of the row.

Weâ€™ll start here by creating a new composable function that will represent the background of our email item.

@Composable
fun EmailItemBackground(
	modifier: Modifier = Modifier
) {

}

Within this composable, weâ€™re only going to need to display an Icon composable to the user. However, weâ€™re going to want to provide some customisations for this background in the next part of this chapter - so with that in mind, weâ€™re going to wrap the content of our background in a Box composable.

The Box composable allows us to contain any number of children, aligning them using the specified alignment configuration. Before we start adding children here, weâ€™re going to add a couple of modifiers to our Box. Weâ€™ll use the fillMaxSize modifier to declare that the composable should use all of the available space that it has, along with adding some padding - this will ensure that the contents of the composable have sufficient spacing between themselves and the inside edge of the Box.

Box(
  	modifier = modifier.padding(horizontal = 20.dp)
) {

}

Now that we have this composable configured, we can move on to populating the content that it can hold.

Here weâ€™re going to add an Icon composable to the content area of our Box. This icon will be used to display a trash bin, signifying that the swipe action is going to delete the specified email.

Box(
  	...
) {
  	Icon(
    	imageVector = Icons.Default.Delete
  	)
}

Alongside this, weâ€™re also going to add a content description to our icon, for which weâ€™ll need to add a string resource to our project.

<string name="cd_delete_email">Delete Email</string>

We can then assign this description to the contentDescription argument of the Icon composable, using the stringResource function to access this string from our resources.

Icon(
  	imageVector = Icons.Default.Delete,
  	contentDescription = stringResource(id =
      	R.string.cd_delete_email)
)

At this point, our Icon will be visible within our Box - however, things donâ€™t look quite right.

To improve this visual representation, we need to align the Icon within our box. Here weâ€™ll use the align modifier to apply the CenterStart alignment to the icon - positioning the icon at the start of the box, centered vertically.

Icon(
  	modifier = Modifier.align(Alignment.CenterStart),
  	imageVector = Icons.Default.Delete,
  	contentDescription = stringResource(id =
      	R.string.cd_delete_email)
)

With this composable in place, weâ€™re now able to provide our EmailItemBackground composable as the body for the background argument of our SwipeToDismiss composable.

SwipeToDismiss(
  	directions = setOf(
    	DismissDirection.StartToEnd
  	),
  	dismissThresholds = {
    	FractionalThreshold(0.15f)
  	},
  	background = {
    	EmailItemBackground()
  	},
  	dismissContent = {
    	EmailItem(email)
  	}
)

Handling item deletion

With our SwipeToDismiss implementation, weâ€™re able to swipe away items - but we may notice at this point nothing happens once weâ€™ve swiped the item to the end. The background for our item remains in place, and the email is not removed from our inbox (as we should be able to see the inbox count does not change). In this section, weâ€™re going to handle the dismissal of the email items, while also adding some animations to improve the visual representation of item deletion. With this in mind, we need to:

  • Listen for when an item is dismissed action is triggered
  • Trigger an animation for the item removal
  • Update our Inbox State to remove the email from the inbox

Taking the first point into account, the SwipeToDismiss composable allows for a state reference to be passed in the form of a DismissState reference - this allows us to monitor the state of item dismissal. So that we can provide a reference to our composable, weâ€™re going to need to create a reference to a DismissState. We can do this using the rememberDismissState function.

val dismissState = rememberDismissState(
  	confirmStateChange = {

    	true
  	}
)

Here we can utilise the confirmStateChange callback to monitor when a state change has been triggered - i.e when an item dismissal has taken place. We return true from this callback, as we always want to allow the user to dismiss an email, so this is us confirming the action is allowed. The key here is what else we can do in this callback, which in our case is the actual dismissal of the item from our state.

Now before we change our Inbox state and remove the item, we want to perform an animation of the item removal. If we update our state from this confirmStateChange callback, our state will change before we can perform an animation. So instead, weâ€™re going to use this callback to trigger the animation, and then we can trigger the change of our state once that animation has been completed.

When it comes to animations, weâ€™re going to start by animating the height of our email row. So when our email item is dismissed, weâ€™ll collapse the height of the email before removing it from the state of our screen. To be able to achieve this, we need to create a boolean flag for the current email item which will depict whether the email should currently be visible or not.

var isEmailItemDismissed by remember { mutableStateOf(false) }

With this flag in place, we can now animate the state of our composables based on whether the email item is being dismissed. But before that can happen, weâ€™ll need to toggle this value to true whenever the email item is being dismissed from the list. For this, weâ€™ll update our confirmStateChange callback to toggle this value whenever an item is being dismissed to the end of the row.

val dismissState = rememberDismissState(
	confirmStateChange = {
    	if (it == DismissValue.DismissedToEnd) {
      	isEmailItemDismissed = true
    	}
    	true
  	}
)

With this DismissState reference in place, we can now apply this to our SwipeToDismiss composable. Now, the confirmStateChange will be triggered whenever a dismiss action is triggered within the inbox.

SwipeToDismiss(
  	state = dismissState,
  	...
)

With this callback now being triggered and our dismissal flag being toggled, weâ€™re in a good position to start adding some animations to dismiss our item. Using the animateDpAsState function, weâ€™ll define the values which should be applied for our email height based on the isEmailItemVisible flag.

val emailHeightAnimation by animateDpAsState(
	targetValue = if (isEmailItemVisible) 120.dp 
		else 0.dp
)

With this target value configured, these dp values will be automatically animated between based on the value of our isEmailItemVisible. So for the default state of our flag as true, a height of 120dp will be set for our email items. But when this flag is toggled to false, the height will be animated from 120dp to 0dp - having this animated dp value means that we can apply this directly to our composable and the height of our composable will be animated with this value. Before we go and apply this to our email item, weâ€™re going to make a few adjustments to our animation.

To start with, the spring animation will be applied by default to our email item. This is a pretty quick animation and doesnâ€™t make the dismissal feel too smooth - so instead, weâ€™re going to override this using the animationSpec argument. Here weâ€™ll create a new tween animation, setting a delay before the animation is started. This will allow our email to be swiped, followed by the animation being triggered shortly after. If you run this and perform the animation youâ€™ll see that the dismissal feels very smooth, performed in a good time after the swipe gesture has been performed.

val emailHeightAnimation by animateDpAsState(
	targetValue = if (isEmailItemVisible) 120.dp 
		else 0.dp,
  	animationSpec = tween(delayMillis = 300)
)

Alongside this animationSpec, weâ€™re going to utilise the finishedListener callback to detect when the dp animation has been completed. When this happens, itâ€™s safe for us to update our Inbox state and remove the email - we wonâ€™t experience any jank here, as the animation would have been completed before the body of finishedListener is called.

val emailHeightAnimation by animateDpAsState(
  	targetValue = if (isEmailItemVisible) 120.dp 
		else 0.dp,
  	animationSpec = tween(delayMillis = 300),
  	finishedListener = {
    	inboxEventListener(InboxEvent.DeleteEmail(email.id))
  	}
)

At this point, we have created a custom animation that will animate the height of our email row, followed by triggering the removal of the email from our state once the animation has been completed. With this done, we now need to apply this to both the email foreground and background for each item within our inbox, which will be done using the height modifier. To be able to do this, weâ€™re going to modify the EmailItem and EmailItemBackground composable functions to accept a modifier as an argument.

@Composable
fun EmailItem(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    email: Email,
    dismissState: DismissState
)
@Composable
fun EmailItemBackground(
  modifier: Modifier = Modifier
)

We can then utilise the height modifier to apply the emailHeightAnimation reference that we defined, which will compose and recompose the specific composable using the height which the state is currently holding.

SwipeToDismiss(
  	...,
  	dismissContent = {
    	EmailItem(
    		modifier = Modifier
				.fillMaxWidth()
				.height(emailHeightAnimation),
      		email = email
    	)
  	},
  	background = {
    	EmailItemBackground(
      		modifier = Modifier
				.fillMaxWidth()
				.height(emailHeightAnimation),
    	)
  	}
)

At this point, weâ€™re passing in the height modifier, by we havenâ€™t applied it to the composables. Weâ€™ll start at the EmailItem composable where weâ€™ll replace the direct Modifier declaration with the modifier reference that we are now providing to the composable function. This means that our custom height will be applied to the Card, along with the padding which is being chained on.

Card(
  	modifier = modifier.padding(16.dp)
)

Hopping over to the EmailItemBackground composable weâ€™ll do the same thing, applying the provided modifier to the Box composable - keeping the previously defined modifiers in place, chained onto our provided reference.

Box(
  	modifier = modifier.padding(horizontal = 20.dp)
)

With this height modifier in place, running the code so far should allow you to perform the swipe gesture and see the animation play out while the item is being dismissed. Once the animation has been completed, the item will be completely dismissed from the inbox - with the inbox count in the top app bar reflecting the new count after the dismissal.

Animating the background color

When triggering the swipe gesture on our email item, itâ€™s not super clear that a deletion is going to take place - the delete icon feels very subtle. With deletion being a destructive process, we want to make it clear to the user that a deletion is going to take place. To improve this, weâ€™re going to add a background color to our email background, having this animate into view once the dismiss gesture is triggered.

To be able to know when a dismissal is taking place (and that we should set the background color), our background composable is going to need to know the current dismissal state. For this, weâ€™re going to need to provide the DismissState to the composable function as an argument.

@Composable
fun EmailItemBackground(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    dismissState: DismissState
)

Now that we have access to the dismissal state inside our background composable, we can go ahead and define an animation to use for the background color. Similar to how we created an animation for the height of the email row, weâ€™re going to utilise the animateColorAsState function to animate between two colors for the background.

When the item is in the DismissedToEnd state (as in, the item is being dismissed), weâ€™re going to want to set the background color to the error state of our theme. With the error color of our theme usually representing an error related color, this feels appropriate to apply here. When the dismiss state does not represent a dismissal, weâ€™re going to use the same theme color that is being used for the background of our UI, represented by the background from our theme.

val backgroundColor by animateColorAsState(
  	targetValue = when (dismissState.targetValue) {
    	DismissValue.DismissedToEnd -> 		
			MaterialTheme.colors.error
    	else -> MaterialTheme.colors.background
  	}
)

Because the DismissState reference being provided to this composable function will change based on the state of the email item, the targetValue of our animation will use the color based on that. When this state changes, the colors will be animated between. Weâ€™ll make a small tweak to improve the animation here, using the animationSpec to override the default animation and apply the tween animation instead.

val backgroundColor by animateColorAsState(
  	targetValue = when (dismissState.targetValue) {
    	DismissValue.DismissedToEnd -> 		
			MaterialTheme.colors.error
    	else -> MaterialTheme.colors.background
  	},
  	animationSpec = tween(),
)

With this animation in place, we can apply this as the background for our Box composable.

Box(
  	modifier = modifier
    	.background(backgroundColor)
    	.padding(horizontal = 20.dp)
)

With this applied, performing the dismiss gesture on an item will animate the background color of the email row from the background color of our theme, to the error color of our theme.

Animating the Delete icon

While the background animation adds a nice touch to our UI, you might have noticed that now the trash icon doesnâ€™t quite play well when itâ€™s dismissed. Because our email row is collapsing, we want to hide the trash icon once the swipe gesture has been performed - we could do something fancy here with the animations, but the trash icon does not serve a purpose once the gesture has been performed. Instead, weâ€™ll adjust the declaration in our Box composable to only compose the Icon when the dismissed state is the Default value. This way when the item is being dismissed, the trash icon will not be composed as part of our UI.

Box(...) {
  	if (dismissState.currentValue = DismissValue.Default) {
    	Icon(...)
  	}
}

While this makes the dismissal play out a bit smoother, the icon still doesnâ€™t sit quite right in our email row. Now that we have the background color applied to our row, the black Icon looks a bit harsh against our error color. To improve this, weâ€™re going to define another animated color state that we will apply to the color of our icon. This time weâ€™ll want to mirror the colors that we previously used, so weâ€™ll use the onError value from our theme for when the email is being dismissed, along with the onSurface color for the stationary value.

val iconColor by animateColorAsState(
  	targetValue = when (dismissState.targetValue) {
    	DismissValue.DismissedToEnd -> 
			MaterialTheme.colors.onError
    	else -> MaterialTheme.colors.onSurface
  	},
  	animationSpec = tween(),
)

We can now apply this to our icon using the tint argument. Now when the email dismissal state is triggered, the color of our icon will be animated from the onSurface to onError (and vice versa).

Icon(
  	...,
  	tint = iconColor
)

If we perform the swipe gesture, weâ€™ll be able to see the Delete icon animate between these two colors.

As a final last touch for our Delete icon, weâ€™re going to change the scale when the dismiss state kicks in - this will add some emphasis to the icon when the state change occurs. For this weâ€™ll utilise the animateFloatAsState function - similar to how weâ€™ve animated color and dp values, weâ€™ll now animate between two float values. By default weâ€™ll scale our Delete Icon by 0.75f, scaling it to its full size when the state is toggled to DismissedToEnd.

val scale by animateFloatAsState(
	targetValue = if (dismissState.targetValue == 
    	DismissValue.DismissedToEnd) {
    	1f
  	} else 0.75f
)

Weâ€™ll then apply this scale to our Icon composable using the scale modifier.

Icon(
  	modifier = Modifier
    	.align(Alignment.CenterStart)
    	.scale(scale),
  	...
)

If we again transition between these states, weâ€™ll be able to see that the icon scale changes based on the dismiss state that is currently represented for our email item.

Emphasising the Email Card

Currently, our email Card is always elevated, which is the default behaviour for this composable. However, it might look quite nice if we only apply the elevation when the card is being swiped. That way by default, the card will appear flat with the row and then floating once being interacted with. To implement this behaviour weâ€™re going to need to provide the DismissState reference to our EmailItem composable.

@Composable
fun EmailItem(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    email: Email,
    dismissState: DismissState
)

Next, weâ€™ll create another animation, using the animateDpAsState to animate between two dp values. Weâ€™ll apply 0dp elevation by default, animating this to 4dp when there is a dismissDirection present within our dismiss state (meaning that the card is being swiped).

val cardElevation = animateDpAsState(
  	if (dismissState.dismissDirection != null) {
    	4.dp
  	} else 0.dp
).value

Well then apply this elevation to our card so that we can animate the elevation based on the current dismiss state of the email item.

Card(
  	elevation = cardElevation,
  	...
)

With this elevation applied, weâ€™ll be able to see the elevation of our Card composable animate between values, based on the current dismiss state.

Displaying item dividers

Now that our email inbox is mostly implemented, weâ€™re going to add a final visual touch to the User Interface by adding some simple dividers between each of the email items. For this, weâ€™ll utilise the Divider composable and add it beneath the SwipeToDismiss composable within the layout hierarchy.

Divider()

We can improve the appearance of this slightly by adding some horizontal padding to the divider, creating some space at both the start and end. Weâ€™ll use the padding modifier for this, along with the horizontal argument to only apply the padding on the horizontal axis.

Divider(
  	modifier = Modifier
    	.padding(horizontal = 16.dp)
)

With this divider showing, it will automatically be removed once the corresponding email item is removed from the list. However, since we added animations to the rest of the email row items, weâ€™re going to do the same for the divider. Weâ€™ll add an animation for the alpha of the divider, allowing it to appear as though it is vanishing as the email item is swiped.

For this, weâ€™ll need to start by defining a new animation, similar to the previous ones that we defined in this chapter. Weâ€™ll use the animateFloatAsState to create an animatable float value that will be used for the alpha of our divider.

val dividerVisibilityAnimation by animateFloatAsState(
  	targetValue = if (dismissState.targetValue ==
   		DismissValue.Default) {
    	1f
  	} else 0f,
  	animationSpec = tween(delayMillis = 300)
)

By default, the alpha of our divider will be 1f, meaning that it will be completely visible. However, when the email item is being dismissed, weâ€™ll animate to the value of 0f - meaning that our divider will eventually become invisible to the user. With this implemented, we can apply this to our Divider by using the alpha modifier.

Divider(
  	modifier = Modifier
    	.padding(horizontal = 16.dp)
    	.alpha(dividerVisibilityAnimation)
)

With this in place, weâ€™ll be able to perform the dismiss gesture on our email item and see that the divider animates out of view as the swipe gesture is triggered.

Adding accessibility actions

Currently, the only way to be able to delete an email from our inbox is by performing a swipe action on the email item. If the user has talkback turned on, thereâ€™s going to be some friction when interacting with this feature of our email inbox. When talkback is enabled, the user will be able to highlight each email item - we just need to provide a way to remove some of the friction

To achieve this, weâ€™re going to add a custom accessibility action to the email item. This is done by using the customActions semantic, providing a CustomAccessibilityAction for each of the custom actions that we want to support. Weâ€™re going to add a Delete Email action that will hook into the talkback actions API, allowing the user to delete an email via the native accessibility services.

To add an action weâ€™re going to need to provide a label - weâ€™ll define a label in our application resources, followed by accessing this resource using the stringResource function.

<string name="cd_delete_email">Delete Email</string>
val deleteEmailLabel = stringResource(id = R.string.cd_delete_email)

With this, we can now create our action using the CustomAccessibilityAction class. Weâ€™ll create a new reference to this, passing in our retrieve string value for the label.

CustomAccessibilityAction(deleteEmailLabel)

Weâ€™ll also need to implement the action handler, this is where weâ€™ll need to perform the action deletion of the email from the inbox. Here weâ€™ll utilise our inboxEventListener reference to trigger the DeleteEmail event, using the id of the email that is to be deleted. This handler needs to return a boolean flag to indicate whether the action was handled - weâ€™ll return true here as weâ€™re triggering our listener to delete the email.

CustomAccessibilityAction(deleteEmailLabel) {
  inboxEventListener(InboxEvent.DeleteEmail(email.id))
  true
}

With this action in place, we can go ahead and apply this to our swipe item, which weâ€™ll do so using the semantics modifier. Within this modifier we need to use the customActions semantic, providing a list of the actions that we want to support. Weâ€™re only supporting our single action here, so weâ€™ll add this to the semantic within the required list format.

SwipeToDismiss(
  	modifier = Modifier.semantics {
    	customActions = listOf(
      		CustomAccessibilityAction(deleteEmailLabel) {
        		inboxEventListener
					(InboxEvent.DeleteEmail(email.id))
        		true
      		}
    	)
  	},
  	...
)

With this in place, the user will be able to launch the actions menu for each of the email items (this is achieved by performing a three-finger tap on the email item.

At this point, the user can then double-tap on the Actions option to learn about the actions that are available for this item.

The user can again perform a double-tap gesture, this time on the Delete Email option. When this is performed, the delete email flow will be triggered and the email removed from the inbox. With this in place, we now have native accessibility support for our email inbox - creating an inclusive experience.

With all of the above in place, we now have a functional email inbox that allows us to load a collection of email items. Alongside this, we can perform swipe gestures on each of the items to dismiss them from the list - all of which is executed with some pleasant animations.

Now that we have this UI in place, letâ€™s move on to learn how we can write some automated tests to assert these various pieces of functionality!

Testing the Inbox Feed UI

Now that weâ€™ve built our Inbox Feed, weâ€™re going to take a look at how we can write tests for our composables. Weâ€™re going to be writing some instrumentation tests using the compose ui-test-junit package - allowing us to verify that our composables are displayed and functioning as expected.

Before we can get started with our tests, weâ€™re going to need to add a couple of test specific dependencies to our project:

androidTestImplementation(
	"androidx.compose.ui:ui-test-junit4:$compose_version")
debugImplementation(
	"androidx.compose.ui:ui-test-manifest:$compose_version")

Weâ€™re also going to need to add mocks to our test - this allows us to easily provide mock references to any listeners that are provided to our composable functions, allowing us to easily verify they are triggered whenever expected.

androidTestImplementation(
	"org.mockito.kotlin:mockito-kotlin:3.2.0")
androidTestImplementation("org.mockito:mockito-android:3.12.4")

With these in place, we now have access to the required rules and functionality that allow us to test our composable UI. However, alongside these dependencies, weâ€™re also going to need to add some rules to our build.gradle file that will fix some of the compilation errors that weâ€™d currently see when trying to run our tests. Here weâ€™ll add some packagingOptions that will exclude certain packages from the added dependencies. We wonâ€™t dive too much into this concept and itâ€™s usually dependant on the versions of dependencies that are being used, so this may be redundant if you come to updating versions.

android {
	packagingOptions {
		exclude "**/attach_hotspot_windows.dll"
		exclude "META-INF/AL2.0"
		exclude "META-INF/LGPL2.1"
		exclude "META-INF/licenses/ASM"
	}
}

Testing the Email Inbox

At a high level of our feature is the EmailInbox composable. While we have a collection of focused composables that are responsible for specific parts of our UI, this composable acts as the parent container - deciding whether the user should be shown the email inbox, empty state, error state and so on. For this reason, weâ€™re going to write a collection of tests that will perform asserts to ensure the correct composables are displayed as expected. Weâ€™ll start here by creating a new test class, EmailInboxTest.

class EmailInboxTest {

}

Inside of this class, we now need to define a reference to the ComposeContentTestRule class - this is what weâ€™re going to use to set the composable content on screen, allowing us to perform interactions and assertions from within our tests. 

@get:Rule
val composeTestRule = createComposeRule()

When using this rule, we donâ€™t need to specify any form of activity for our composables to be launched in, the test rule will handle that for us. So using this rule we will set the composable content to be composed, the test will then launch a host activity which will be used to compose our provided content inside of.

Testing the Inbox Title

To start with, our EmailInbox composable displays a collection of email items - weâ€™ll write some tests to ensure that these are displayed as expected. Weâ€™ll start with the title of the inbox, for which weâ€™ll create a new test function.

@Test
fun Inbox_Title_Displayed()

Inside of this test, weâ€™re going to need to start by setting the composable content that is to be displayed on screen for us to assert against. Here weâ€™ll use the test rule that we previously defined, along with its setContent function. This function takes a composable function as an argument, allowing us to define what is to be composed on screen for our tests. Because weâ€™re wanting to test the EmailInbox Composable that we defined in the previous sections of this chapter, weâ€™ll go ahead and pass the EmailInbox composable function for this composable content.

@Test
fun Inbox_Title_Displayed() {
    val inboxState = InboxState(
		emails = EmailFactory.makeContentList())

    composeTestRule.setContent {
        EmailInbox(inboxState) { }
    }
}

While we arenâ€™t yet performing any assertions, running this test will launch an activity that displays the content of our EmailInbox composable. With this now being displayed, we can next perform the required assertions to ensure that the title is being displayed within our composable UI. Weâ€™ll do this by utilising the onNodeWithText function from our test rule reference.

The onNodeWithText function can be used to locate a composable that is displaying the text that we have provided to the function. Composables will be located in the form of a semantic node. Because our composables are represented via semantics, in our tests we are going to be locating nodes within our semantic tree. In this case, this is done using the onNodeWithText function, which will return us with a SemanticsNodeInteraction reference to perform assertions against. 

@Test
fun Inbox_Title_Displayed() {
    val inboxState = InboxState(
		emails = EmailFactory.makeContentList())

    composeTestRule.setContent {
        EmailInbox(inboxState) { }
    }

    composeTestRule.onNodeWithText(
    	InstrumentationRegistry.getInstrumentation()
			.targetContext.getString(R.string.title_inbox, inboxState.emails.count())
    )
}

For this test we want to assert that this node is being displayed within our composed UI, so weâ€™re going to go ahead and utilise the assertIsDisplayed function. This is one of the assertions available on the SemanticsNodeInteraction class, allowing us to assert whether this node is being displayed on the screen.

@Test
fun Inbox_Title_Displayed() {
    val inboxState = InboxState(
		emails = EmailFactory.makeContentList())

    composeTestRule.setContent {
        EmailInbox(inboxState) { }
    }

    composeTestRule.onNodeWithText(
    	InstrumentationRegistry.getInstrumentation()
			.targetContext.getString(R.string.title_inbox, inboxState.emails.count())
    ).assertIsDisplayed()
}

With this pieced together, we now have a test that:

  • Uses theEmailInbox composable to set the UI to be displayed on the screen
  • Locates a node within our composable UI, using a String from our application resources
  • Asserts that the retrieved node is displayed within our UI

If you run this test within your IDE, youâ€™ll not only see the UI spin up inside of the connected device / emulator, but the tests should also be passing due to the required string being composed within the UI.

Testing the Loading State

With the title of our composable being tested, weâ€™re now going to assert that the expected composables are displayed when the status property of our InboxState represents the InboxStatus.LOADING value. Weâ€™re going to start here by creating a new test and composing the EmailInbox, providing a reference to the InboxState class that has the LOADING for its status property.

@Test
fun Loading_State_Displayed() {
	composeTestRule.run {
		setContent {
			EmailInbox(
				inboxState = InboxState(
					status = InboxStatus.LOADING
				)
			) { }
        }
    }
}

Here we use the kotlin run scope function - this is because we are going to be performing multiple operations against our test rule reference, so this simplifies things by removing the need for us to use . notation for every call that we wish to make. This means that now, we can utilise multiple onNodeWithTag function calls inside of this run block. Before we can do that though, we need to be able to locate those nodes.

With this test, weâ€™re going to want to check a couple of different composable states for when the InboxStatus.LOADING status is applied.

  • Assert that the loading composable is displayed
  • Assert that the email list does not exist
  • Assert that the empty state does not exist
  • Assert that the error state does not exist

So that we can perform assertions for these different states, weâ€™re going to need to be able to locate it. Unlike the previous test where we used text values to locate nodes within our composable UI, we donâ€™t care for the nested details within the composables that weâ€™re going to check for here. For this reason, weâ€™re going to need to apply some tags to these composables, these tags can then be used to locate our composable within our tests. Weâ€™ll need to start here by defining some tag references that can be accessed from both our tests and our composable. These will live inside of a file called Tags.kt

// Tags.kt

object Tags {
    const val TAG_CONTENT = "content"
    const val TAG_PROGRESS = "progress"
    const val TAG_EMPTY = "empty"
    const val TAG_ERROR = "error"
}

With these tags defined, weâ€™ll need to assign them to our composables - this assignment means that we can then retrieve nodes in our UI that have the corresponding tag. Weâ€™ll do this by utilising the testTag modifier to assign our tags - starting with the Loading composable.

// Loading.kt

CircularProgressIndicator(
	modifier = modifier.testTag(Tags.TAG_PROGRESS)
)

When this testTag modifier is applied, the provided tag is set as a semantic property on the node. This is not visible to users but will be used by testing and accessibility services to locate composables via a tag identifier.

Similar to how weâ€™ve applied the corresponding tag to the Loading composable, weâ€™ll need to do the same for the parent nodes within the EmptyState, ErrorState and EmailList composables.

// EmptyState.kt

Column(
	modifier = modifier.testTag(Tags.TAG_EMPTY),
	horizontalAlignment = Alignment.CenterHorizontally
)
// ErrorState.kt

Column(
	modifier = modifier.testTag(Tags.TAG_ERROR),
	horizontalAlignment = Alignment.CenterHorizontally
)
// EmailList.kt

LazyColumn(
	modifier = modifier.testTag(Tags.TAG_CONTENT)
)

Now that our composables have tags assigned to them, we can now use the onNodeWithTag function within our tests to locate the composable whose tag matches the requested tag. This operates in the same way that the previously used onNodeWithText function operates, but by using a tag instead of textual content.

@Test
fun Loading_State_Displayed() {
	composeTestRule.run {
		setContent {
			EmailInbox(
				inboxState = InboxState(
					status = InboxStatus.LOADING)
			) { }
        }
            
        onNodeWithTag(TAG_PROGRESS)
        onNodeWithTag(TAG_CONTENT)
        onNodeWithTag(TAG_ERROR)
        onNodeWithTag(TAG_EMPTY)
    }
}

Now that these tags are in place, we can locate the node to perform assertions on. To perform these assertions weâ€™re going to need to use a variety of assertion functions to test the different scenarios that we previously defined. Because in this case the progress composable should be displayed, weâ€™ll utilise the assertIsDisplayed which is a SemanticsNodeInteraction extension function. This assertion will check whether the bounds of the composable are currently visible, which would be expected of the Loading composable when the loading state is in place.

Alongside this, weâ€™ll also want to assert that the other three composables do not exist within our composition - this is because when the Loading composable is displayed, none of the other composables should exist. While there is an assertIsNotDisplayed assertion function, we donâ€™t even want the remaining composable to exist in our composable hierarchy. For this reason, weâ€™ll utilise the assertDoesNotExist function on each of the remaining nodes.

@Test
fun Loading_State_Displayed() {
	composeTestRule.run {
		setContent {
			EmailInbox(
				inboxState = InboxState(
					status = InboxStatus.LOADING)
			) { }
        }
            
        onNodeWithTag(TAG_PROGRESS).assertIsDisplayed()
        onNodeWithTag(TAG_CONTENT).assertDoesNotExist()
        onNodeWithTag(TAG_ERROR).assertDoesNotExist()
        onNodeWithTag(TAG_EMPTY).assertDoesNotExist()
    }
}

ðŸ’¡ When you are expecting a composable to have not been composed, use the assertDoesNotExist. This behaves different from assertIsNotDisplayed, as that function is focused on the visibility of the composable rather than the presence within the hierarchy.

Testing the Empty State

Now that weâ€™re testing the loading state of our composable, weâ€™re going to test the next scenario - the state where the email inbox is empty. This is going to look very similar to the previous test that we wrote for the loading state - the difference here is that weâ€™re going to start bypassing the InboxStatus.EMPTY value for the status of the InboxState that we provide to the composable.

Weâ€™re also going to tweak the assertions that are being performed. In this scenario we are expecting that:

  • Assert that the empty composable is displayed
  • Assert that the email list composable does not exist
  • Assert that the loading composable does not exist
  • Assert that the error composable does not exist

With those expectations in mind, we can represent this via the following assertions.

@Test
fun Empty_State_Displayed() {
    composeTestRule.run {
        setContent {
            EmailInbox(
                inboxState = InboxState(
					status = InboxStatus.EMPTY
				),
                handleEvent = { }
            )
        }
        onNodeWithTag(TAG_PROGRESS).assertDoesNotExist()
   	    onNodeWithTag(TAG_CONTENT).assertDoesNotExist()
        onNodeWithTag(TAG_ERROR).assertDoesNotExist()
        onNodeWithTag(TAG_EMPTY).assertIsDisplayed()
    }
}

Testing the Error State

Next, weâ€™re going to test the state where an error has occurred while loading the email inbox. This is going to look very similar to the previous test that weâ€™ve written here - the difference is that weâ€™re going to start bypassing the InboxStatus.ERROR value for the status of the InboxState that we provide to the composable.

Weâ€™re also going to tweak the assertions that are being performed. In this scenario we are expecting that:

  • Assert that the error composable is displayed
  • Assert that the email list composable does not exist
  • Assert that the loading composable does not exist
  • Assert that the empty composable does not exist

With those expectations in mind, we can represent this via the following assertions.

@Test
fun Error_State_Displayed() {
    composeTestRule.run {
        setContent {
            EmailInbox(
                inboxState = InboxState(
					status = InboxStatus.ERROR
				),
                handleEvent = { }
            )
        }
        onNodeWithTag(TAG_PROGRESS).assertDoesNotExist()
   	    onNodeWithTag(TAG_CONTENT).assertDoesNotExist()
        onNodeWithTag(TAG_ERROR).assertIsDisplayed()
        onNodeWithTag(TAG_EMPTY).assertDoesNotExist()
    }
}

Testing the Content State

Last up, weâ€™re going to test the state where content has loaded for the email inbox. This is going to look very similar to the previous tests that weâ€™ve written here - the difference is that weâ€™re going to start bypassing the InboxStatus.SUCCESS value for the status of the InboxState that we provide to the composable.

Weâ€™re also going to tweak the assertions that are being performed. In this scenario we are expecting that:

  • Assert that the content composable is displayed
  • Assert that the error composable does not exist
