  • Assert that the loading composable does not exist
  • Assert that the empty composable does not exist

With those expectations in mind, we can represent this via the following assertions.

@Test
fun Content_State_Displayed() {
    composeTestRule.run {
        setContent {
            EmailInbox(
				inboxState = InboxState(
					status = InboxStatus.SUCCESS
				),
                handleEvent = { }
            )
        }
        onNodeWithTag(TAG_PROGRESS).assertDoesNotExist()
        onNodeWithTag(TAG_CONTENT).assertIsDisplayed()
        onNodeWithTag(TAG_ERROR).assertDoesNotExist()
        onNodeWithTag(TAG_EMPTY).assertDoesNotExist()
    }
}

With these different state-related tests in place, weâ€™re now able to have confidence that the expected composition takes place based on the status value within the provided InboxState.

Testing Item Dismissal

Now that weâ€™ve covered the different states that can be represented with our EmailInbox composable, weâ€™re going to write a couple of higher-level tests for the Inbox composable. What makes this different from our lower level composables (such as the empty state or email inbox), is that this composable is our argument less constructor - meaning that from our tests we can trigger state updates and recomposition of our UI. This means that with the tests for the Inbox composable we can assert that interactions with it result in the expected state changes. For these tests, weâ€™re going to focus on the dismissal of the email items within the inbox.

For the first test weâ€™re going to assert that when an item is dismissed from the inbox (as in, when it is swiped away), the list represents that an item has been removed. Within this test, weâ€™re not going to care exactly what item is dismissed (that will be for tests within the lower level composable), just that the list count has been updated to reflect the state change. Weâ€™re going to need to start here by composing the Inbox inside of a new test.

@Test
fun Item_Dismissed_When_Swiped() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        Inbox()
    }
}

Next, weâ€™re going to want to trigger the dismissal of an item within the inbox. When this happens, the item will be removed from our state (through the ViewModel) and the list will be updated to reflect that change. First, though, weâ€™ll need to swipe away an item from our list. Within our test, this is going to involve a couple of steps.

  • Weâ€™ll first need to find the node that represents the email list. Here weâ€™ll utilise the onNodeWithTag function, using the previously defined TAG_CONTENT to locate our composable.
  • Next, weâ€™ll need to perform a swipe interaction with a child from the node that weâ€™ve just located. Here we can use the onChildAt function that will return us a single SemanticsNode that we can perform assertions and interactions on.
  • Now that we have this child reference, we can now perform our swipe interaction. For this weâ€™ll use the performTouchInput - within the block of this function, we can perform any actions that are scoped by TouchInjectionScope. Within this scope, the swipeRight function is available - this allows us to perform a right swipe gesture on the child node that weâ€™ve located.
@Test
fun Item_Dismissed_When_Swiped() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        Inbox()
    }

    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(TAG_CONTENT)
    	.onChildAt(0)
        .performTouchInput {
            swipeRight()
        }
}

Next, weâ€™ll need to assert that the size of the email list has changed based on our previous interaction. When our state is initialised, we use EmailFactory.makeContentList() to load up a default set of emails into the inbox. Here weâ€™re going to want to assert that the count of our list is now 1 item smaller than when it was initialised.

Here weâ€™ll again use the onNodeWithTag function to retrieve the node that represents our content list, using the TAG_CONTENT tag. This node will again represent the list of emails that are being composed, so weâ€™ll want to retrieve the children that are making up this list. Using the onChildren function, this will give us a SemanticsNodeInteractionCollection that represents the list of nodes that makes up the composable. With this collection available, we can now perform an assertion on the expected size. When an item has been dismissed, this size is going to be 1 item less than the initially created email list - so we can use the assertCountEquals function to assert this.

@Test
fun Item_Dismissed_When_Swiped() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        Inbox()
    }

    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(TAG_CONTENT)
        .onChildAt(0)
        .performTouchInput {
            swipeRight()
        }

	val emails = EmailFactory.makeContentList()
    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(TAG_CONTENT)
        .onChildren()
        .assertCountEquals(emails.count() - 1)
}

Aside from the dismissal of items, weâ€™re also going to check that all of the items which shouldnâ€™t have been dismissed are still in place - this allows us to assert that only the swiped item has been removed. Weâ€™ll start by writing a new test, composing the Inbox for the test content.

@Test
fun Remaining_Items_Displayed_When_Another_Dismissed() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        Inbox()
    }
}

Within this test weâ€™re again going to want to swipe an email item from the list, this means that weâ€™ll be able to perform the assertion that the email list contains the remaining items from the list. As we did in the previous test, weâ€™ll perform the swipeRight action on the first item within the email list.

@Test
fun Remaining_Items_Displayed_When_Another_Dismissed() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        Inbox()
    }

    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(TAG_CONTENT)
        .onChildAt(0)
        .performTouchInput {
            swipeRight()
        }
}

Next, weâ€™re going to need to take the items that are in the email, aside from the first one (as we dismissed that above), and assert that they are still in place within the list. The above test asserts that the count of the emails is one less than the initialised list, this test will assert that those items represent the expected emails.

Here weâ€™re going to start by using the takeLast operation to take the last N items of our list - we will want this to be all items except for the first one. For each item within this collection, weâ€™re going to want to check that it matches the expected content. For this weâ€™re going to assign a new tag to each email item so that we can easily assert this within our tests - for this weâ€™ll need to start by adding a new tag that can be applied to our composable. For this tag weâ€™re going to end this with an underscore character, allowing us to append the id of an email, creating a unique tag for each email item within the list.

object Tags {
    const val TAG_EMAIL = "email_"
}

With this tag defined, we can now assign this to the dismissible email item. Here weâ€™ll utilise the testTag modifier to apply the tag to the composable - for this weâ€™ll use the TAG_EMAIL tag, appending the id of the corresponding email to it.

// EmailList.kt

SwipeToDismiss(
	modifier = Modifier
		.semantics {
        	...
        }
        .testTag(TAG_EMAIL + email.id),
	...
)

With this tag in place, we can now use this within our tests to perform interactions and assertions with the email items. While looping through the email items within the collection (apart from the first one, because that has been dismissed as per our previous test), weâ€™re going to need to perform the following actions:

  • Using the onNodeWithTag function, locate the node that represents the list of emails using the TAG_CONTENT tag
  • Retrieve the child node at the current index of the loop
  • Trigger the performScrollTo function which will scroll to the child node that weâ€™ve just located. This is to ensure that the composable is currently on view within the window
  • Assert that the node has the expected tag that represents the id of the current email in our loop
@Test
fun Remaining_Items_Displayed_When_Another_Dismissed() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        Inbox()
    }

    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(TAG_CONTENT)
        .onChildAt(0)
        .performTouchInput {
            swipeRight()
        }

    val emails = EmailFactory.makeContentList()
    emails.takeLast(emails.count() - 1)
		.forEachIndexed { index, email ->
        	composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(TAG_CONTENT)
                .onChildAt(index)
                .performScrollTo()
                .assert(hasTestTag(TAG_EMAIL + email.id))
    	}
}

ðŸ’¡ The assert function allows us to provide a SemanticsMatcher that is used to perform the assertion. This is a lower-level function that is useful when you need to perform assertions on SemanticsNodeInteraction instances.

With this test in place, we are now asserting that each of the remaining items within the email list has the expected tag, represented by the id of the corresponding email.

Testing the Email List

In the previous tests, weâ€™ve looked at performing assertions on the email list based on the swipe dismissals that have been performed on the email list. For this section, weâ€™re going to focus on testing the email list itself, based on the information that is provided to the composable function. Weâ€™ll set ourselves up here by creating a new test class, EmailListTest.

class EmailListTest {

    @get:Rule
    val composeTestRule = createComposeRule()

}

Weâ€™re going to start here by writing a new test that will assert all of the expected email items are being displayed in the list. Within this test weâ€™re going to need to start by composing an EmailList, passing in a collection of emails that are being created using our EmailFactory. Weâ€™ll need this variable reference so that we can soon perform assertions on our items.

@Test
fun Email_Items_Displayed() {
    val emails = EmailFactory.makeContentList()
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        EmailList(
            emails = emails,
            deleteEmail = { }
        )
    }
}

Now that the email list is being composed, weâ€™re going to need to loop through each of the items in this list of emails, asserting that the expected composables are being displayed. This is going to look very similar to the previous test that we wrote for the swipe interactions. For each item within the list of emails weâ€™ll need to:

  • Use the onNodeWithTag function to locate the node that represents the list of emails using the TAG_CONTENT tag
  • Retrieve the child node at the current index of the loop
  • Trigger the performScrollTo function which will scroll to the child node that weâ€™ve just located. This is to ensure that the composable is currently on view within the window
  • Assert that the node has the expected tag that represents the id of the current email in our loop

The key difference here is that we are now doing this for all email items, instead of the expected state after a dismissal. We are testing this here to ensure that the EmailList is composing the expected list of emails - while the previous test for our Inbox composable was also testing a similar state (and we could also have had another test there), this allows us to keep this extra test case close to the composable that is implementing composable logic.

@Test
fun Email_Items_Displayed() {
    val emails = EmailFactory.makeContentList()
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        EmailList(
            emails = emails,
            deleteEmail = { }
        )
    }

    emails.forEachIndexed { index, email ->
        composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(TAG_CONTENT)
            .onChildAt(index)
            .performScrollTo()
            .assert(hasTestTag(TAG_EMAIL + email.id))
    }
}

Now that weâ€™ve been able to assert that all of the email items are being displayed, weâ€™re going to want to test that the deleteEmail lambda is correctly called when expected. While we have a test previously written for the Inbox composable, these lower-level tests allow us to assert that the callback is triggered for the expected email id.

Weâ€™re going to start by writing a new test, composing the EmailList. Aside from passing a list of emails to the emails argument, weâ€™ll also need to pass in a mock lambda function for the deleteEmail argument. This means that we can use this mock to verify that interactions have taken place based on composable events.

@Test
fun Delete_Email_Triggered() {
    val emails = EmailFactory.makeContentList()
    val deleteEmail: (id: String) -> Unit = mock()
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        EmailList(
            emails = emails,
            deleteEmail = deleteEmail
        )
    }
}

Now the EmailList is being composed, we can add some logic that will be used to trigger the dismiss action on one of our email items. Similar to the swipe actions that we performed in previous tests, weâ€™ll locate a specific child within the TAG_CONTENT node, followed by performing the swipeRight operation on it. Youâ€™ll notice here that weâ€™re also keeping a reference to the index of the email item that weâ€™re interacting with, indexToDelete. This is so that we can later use it in the following assertions.

@Test
fun Delete_Email_Triggered() {
    val emails = EmailFactory.makeContentList()
    val deleteEmail: (id: String) -> Unit = mock()
    val indexToDelete = 2

    composeTestRule.setContent {
        EmailList(
            emails = emails,
            deleteEmail = deleteEmail
        )
    }

    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(TAG_CONTENT)
        .onChildAt(indexToDelete)
        .performScrollTo()
        .performTouchInput {
            swipeRight()
        }
}

With the swipe interaction now taking place, we can perform the assertion on our lambda function. We can verify this within our test by using mockito and its verify function to assert that the lambda has been invoked. If this is the case, the test will succeed - otherwise, the lambda not being triggered will mean that our verification will not be satisfied and the test will fail. When utilising verify here, weâ€™re going to want to assert this using the id of the email item located at the index we defined for indexToDelete.

@Test
fun Delete_Email_Triggered() {
    val emails = EmailFactory.makeContentList()
    val deleteEmail: (id: String) -> Unit = mock()
    val indexToDelete = 2
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        EmailList(
            emails = emails,
            deleteEmail = deleteEmail
        )
    }

    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(TAG_CONTENT)
        .onChildAt(indexToDelete)
        .performScrollTo()
        .performTouchInput {
            swipeRight()
        }
    verify(deleteEmail).invoke(emails[indexToDelete].id)
}

If you run this test, youâ€™ll notice that it wonâ€™t be passing. While we will be able to see in the automated test that the email item is swiped, youâ€™ll notice that the dismissal is never triggered. The reason for this is because we have an animated dp value that animates based on the value of isEmailItemVisible - it is only once this animation completes that we trigger the deleteEmail callback.

val emailHeightAnimation by animateDpAsState(
	targetValue = if (isEmailItemVisible) {
		120.dp
	} else {
		0.dp
	},
	animationSpec = tween(delayMillis = 300),
	finishedListener = {
		deleteEmail(email.id)
	}
)

But why is this an issue? Well, when the compose tests are run, our tests are run in synchronisation with the compose UI. The issue in this specific case is that it means our animation will not run through to the end, which means that the finishedListener callback will never be triggered. What we can do here is utilise our test rule to wait until the UI is in an idle state, meaning that the animation execution would have been completed and the finishedListener would be triggered.

composeTestRule.waitForIdle()

We can slot this into our test after the swipe interaction has been performed, waiting for the idle state before the verification of the deleteEmail takes place.

@Test
fun Delete_Email_Triggered() {
    val emails = EmailFactory.makeContentList()
    val deleteEmail: (id: String) -> Unit = mock()
    val indexToDelete = 2
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        EmailList(
            emails = emails,
            deleteEmail = deleteEmail
        )
    }

    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(TAG_CONTENT)
        .onChildAt(indexToDelete)
        .performScrollTo()
        .performTouchInput {
            swipeRight()
        }
    composeTestRule.waitForIdle()
    verify(deleteEmail).invoke(emails[indexToDelete].id)
}

Testing the Empty State

Now that weâ€™ve got tests in place for the email content composable, weâ€™re going to add a quick test for the empty state composable. Our empty composable contains an action that can be used to refresh the inbox, so weâ€™ll want to assert that this is triggering the expected action. Weâ€™ll start here by creating a new test class with supporting rule.

class EmptyStateTest {

    @get:Rule
    val composeTestRule = createComposeRule()

}

Weâ€™ll now need to compose the EmptyState. This only takes a single argument, onRefresh, which takes the form of a lambda function. Here, weâ€™ll pass in a mock lambda function for the onRefresh argument. This means that we can use this mock to verify that interactions have taken place based on composable events.

@Test
fun Refresh_Triggered() {
    val onRefresh: () -> Unit = mock()
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        EmptyState(onRefresh = onRefresh)
    }
}

With this in place, we now need to perform the action that will trigger the lambda function. The EmptyState is expected to contain an action that is using the label_check_again string resource, this is also what should trigger the refresh event when interacted with. Here, weâ€™ll use the performClick function to click on the node after locating it used the expected string resource.

@Test
fun Refresh_Triggered() {
    val onRefresh: () -> Unit = mock()
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        EmptyState(onRefresh = onRefresh)
    }

    composeTestRule
        .onNodeWithText(
            InstrumentationRegistry.getInstrumentation()
				.targetContext
				.getString(R.string.label_check_again)
		).performClick()
}

With this in place, we can now use the verify function to assert that the onRefresh lambda has been invoked.

@Test
fun Refresh_Triggered() {
    val onRefresh: () -> Unit = mock()
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        EmptyState(onRefresh = onRefresh)
    }

    composeTestRule
        .onNodeWithText(
            InstrumentationRegistry.getInstrumentation()
				.targetContext
				.getString(R.string.label_check_again)
		).performClick()

    verify(onRefresh).invoke()
}

Testing the Error State

To wrap up our testing work, weâ€™re going to next test the error state composable. Our error composable contains an action that can be used to refresh the inbox after an error has occurred, so weâ€™ll want to assert that this is triggering the expected action. Weâ€™ll start here by creating a new test class with supporting rule. This test is going to look almost the same as the previous test we wrote for the EmptyState composable, except here we compose the ErrorState and use the label_try_again resource for the node interaction.

class ErrorStateTest {

    @get:Rule
    val composeTestRule = createComposeRule()

	@Test
	fun Refresh_Triggered() {
    	val onRefresh: () -> Unit = mock()
    	composeTestRule.setContent {
        	ErrorState(onRefresh = onRefresh)
    	}

    	composeTestRule
			.onNodeWithText(
        		InstrumentationRegistry.getInstrumentation()
					.targetContext.getString(
						R.string.label_try_again)
        	).performClick()

    	verify(onRefresh).invoke()
	}
}

With all of these tests in place, weâ€™ve covered a lot of different cases that help to ensure our UI is working as expected. Weâ€™ve not only tested that composables are being composed based on the information that they are provided with, but also that they triggered the expected callbacks and trigger state manipulations within our composables. While the tests here arenâ€™t extensive, weâ€™ve been able to learn not only what options are available to us while testing composables, but also the approaches that we can take when doing so.

Building a Video Player

When working on Android projects, weâ€™re likely going to be defaulting to using Jetpack Compose when building UI. While that may be the case, it might not always be possible. For example, we may have existing classes that are written using the Android View system, which might not make sense for us to convert to compose at this time. There might also be some things built in the Android View system that just isnâ€™t supported by Jetpack Compose yet.

Whatever the reason, weâ€™re bound to find ourselves in scenarios where we either need to or it makes sense for us to use Android View system components. For these situations, Jetpack Compose has several interoperability features that allow us to use Composable UI inside of existing Android Layouts, as well as tools for using Android View classes inside of Composable UI. In this chapter, weâ€™re going to utilise some of these features to create a Video Player that uses a mixture of Jetpack Compose concepts and Android View classes.

When it comes to building out this screen, over the rest of the chapter weâ€™re going to be tackling a collection of tasks:

  • Build out a Video player that streams a video from a given URL
  • Use interoperability features to utilise existing Android Views inside of a composable UI
  • Create controls that allow the status of the video player to be managed
  • Use animations to handle the display of the video player controls, allowing them to be auto-dismissed when not being interacted with
  • Define a manageable state that will be used to control how the UI is composed
  • Utilise Side Effects to manage the state of the video player based on external constraints

Once all of the above is complete, weâ€™ll have a working Video Player implementation. Weâ€™ll have a video being displayed and played using an Android View class, with the controls and state-defined using Jetpack Compose.

Defining the Video player State

Within our Video Player, weâ€™re going to be dealing with a couple of different pieces of state that depict how the UI is going to be displayed to the user. Thereâ€™s not going to be too many different scenarios that the screen is going to be in, but these different states will be represented in the following forms:

  • A video that will automatically be played once it has finished loading
  • An error state that is displayed when the video fails to load
  • A control bar that:
    • will only be enabled once the video has finished loading
    • will allow the user to either Play or Pause the video
    • will dismiss once it is no longer being interacted with

With the above set out, we can start to see that there are going to be several pieces of state that we need to hold. With that in mind, letâ€™s start to take the above statements and build a class that will represent the state of our composable UI. Weâ€™ll start by creating a new class:

data class VideoState()

With the scenarios stated above, weâ€™re going to need to handle a couple of states that the screen can represent.

Playback State

Weâ€™re going to start by adding a definition for the current state of the video player - this will tell our UI whether the video is current loading, or if it is in another state that can be controlled via the video player controls. To help keep our VideoState class simple, weâ€™re going to represent this state using an enum class - this not only adds better clarity to the current state of our player, but it helps us to avoid using a collection of boolean flags (or other means) to represent this part of our state. To tackle this weâ€™ll create a new enum class called PlayerStatus and populate it with some values that it can represent.

enum class PlayerStatus {
    PLAYING, PAUSED, LOADING, IDLE, ERROR
}

For our PlayerStatus weâ€™ve defined five different values which can be represented, these are:

  • Playing: The video is currently being played
  • Paused: The video playback is currently paused
  • Loading: The video is currently being loaded, meaning it is not ready to play yet
  • Idle: The video has been loaded but is not currently in a playback state
  • Error - The video has failed to load

With this in place, we can then go ahead and add this to our state class.

data class VideoState(
    val playerStatus: PlayerStatus = PlayerStatus.LOADING
)

Now when composing our UI, we can perform composition using this state - meaning our UI can now react to changes on the PlayerStatus, such as when it moves from PLAYING to PAUSED. When the video player is launched, weâ€™re going to do need to load the video - so by default, our player will always need to start in the loading state. For that reason, weâ€™ll give our playerStatus variable a default value of LOADING.

data class VideoState(
    val playerStatus: PlayerStatus = PlayerStatus.LOADING
)

For now, that is the only state that our screen state is going to hold. If you wish to simplify things, you can remove the use of the data class and directly access a PlayerStatus reference. If you wish to build on this feature and add to the state, then this VideoState class gives you a good starting point to do so!

Creating the Video Player View Model

Now that we have the state modelled for our video player, we can start thinking about the ViewModel that will be used to manage that state and provide a way to orchestrate it to the user interface.

Setting up the ViewModel

While we donâ€™t have a complex state setup for our video player, there is going to be a small amount of logic that will be used to manipulate this. For this reason, itâ€™ll be helpful for us to have a ViewModel that can encapsulate this logic from our User Interface. Weâ€™ll start by creating a new ViewModel class for our Video Player:

class VideoViewModel : ViewModel() {

}

So that we can orchestrate state to our User Interface, weâ€™ll need to define a data stream that allows for subscription to state changes. For this, weâ€™ll go ahead and define a global MutableStateFlow reference that can be used to emit state events, as well as observed by our UI layer.

class VideoViewModel : ViewModel() {

    val uiState = MutableStateFlow(VideoState())

}

With this in place, we have a state stream that will emit a default state of our VideoState class. When we created this state class we configured the playerStatus with a default value, LOADING - this means that currently the UI will always be composed as if our video was always loading. To resolve this, weâ€™ll need to go ahead and configure some state change logic within our ViewModel so that this playerStatus can be configured based on the events that occur within our video player.

Handling Video Player Events

From our User Interface, weâ€™re going to want to manipulate the state that has been configured within our ViewModel - this is going to be specifically whenever the PlayerStatus is changed. This will be either when:

  • The status is manually toggled by the user
  • The video has finished loading and is ready to play
  • The video has failed to load and cannot be played

So that we have these represented by some form of model (as well as leave some room for future event additions), weâ€™re going to define a new sealed class, VideoEvent. This class will be used to define the different events that can be triggered from our UI:

sealed class VideoEvent {

    object ToggleStatus: VideoEvent()

    object VideoLoaded: VideoEvent()

	object VideoError: VideoEvent()

}

With these now defined, we need to have our ViewModel handle these, configuring the state based on the event that has been triggered. To receive these events from our UI layer, weâ€™ll go ahead and add a new function to our ViewModel, handleEvent:

fun handleEvent(videoEvent: VideoEvent) {

}

Handle Video Loading

Weâ€™ll start by handling the VideoLoaded event - when this is triggered we want to update our playerStatus to reflect this event from our UI, signifying that the video has been loaded is ready to be played. Weâ€™ll add a new when block to our function and start by handling the VideoLoaded event. 

fun handleEvent(videoEvent: VideoEvent) {
	when (videoEvent) {
		VideoEvent.VideoLoaded -> {
			uiState.value = uiState.value.copy(
				playerStatus = PlayerStatus.IDLE
			)
		}
	}
}

When this event occurs, weâ€™re going to want to update the value of our uiState reference to reflect that the video is ready to play. Here, weâ€™ll use the copy function on our existing state value, assigning a new value to the playerStatus property. Now that the video has finished loading, weâ€™ll assign this value as IDLE so that any observers to our state know that the video player is no longer in the LOADING state.

Handle Video Errors

Sometimes the loading of the video wonâ€™t go quite as planned, and in these cases, weâ€™re going to want to make sure we portray the error to the user. To be able to do so, this is going to need to be reflected within our state object - we already have the VideoError class type, so weâ€™re going to modify our handleEvent function to handle this kind of event. When this occurs weâ€™ll need to modify our VideoState reference so that the playerStatus reflects an error state, which we can do so using the PlayerStatus.ERROR type.

fun handleEvent(videoEvent: VideoEvent) {
	when (videoEvent) {
		...
		VideoEvent.VideoError -> {
        	uiState.value = uiState.value.copy(
            	playerStatus = PlayerStatus.ERROR
            )
        }
	}
}

Now whenever the error event is triggered from our UI, our view model will be able to have this reflected within our VideoState - meaning that our UI will be able to portray this state to the user when recomposed.

Handle Video Playback

Alongside the loading and error events, our VideoState can represent the current playback status of the video in the form of Playing or Paused. When the user interacts with the playback state from the UI, weâ€™re going to want to toggle the current state so that it represents the opposite of the current set value. For this, weâ€™ll create a new function, togglePlayerStatus, that will be used to switch between the Playing and Paused states.

private fun togglePlayerStatus() {
	
}

In this function, weâ€™re going to need to write a small bit of logic that switches between the Playing and Paused state. To put this in place weâ€™ll need to:

  • Get the current PlayerStatus value
  • Calculate the new PlayerStatus value based on the current one
  • Set the new PlayerStatus value to our VideoState

For the first point, weâ€™ll simply begin by using our state reference to retrieve the current value of our playerStatus property:

val playerStatus = uiState.value.playerStatus

Next, weâ€™ll use this value to define a new PlayerStatus reference. Because weâ€™re only currently flipping between the Playing and Paused state we can keep this simple for now. So if our current reference does not indicate a Playing state then weâ€™ll toggle our state to be Playing, otherwise, weâ€™ll mark the playerStatus as being Paused.

val newPlayerStatus = if (
	playerStatus != PlayerStatus.PLAYING
) {
	PlayerStatus.PLAYING
} else {
    PlayerStatus.PAUSED
}

Finally, weâ€™ll take the above and use it to assign our new PlayerStatus value to our VideoState reference:

uiState.value = uiState.value.copy(
	playerStatus = newPlayerStatus
)

With all the above in place, we can piece them together into our togglePlayerStatus function to give us something that looks like so:

private fun togglePlayerStatus() {
	val playerStatus = uiState.value.playerStatus
	val newPlayerStatus = if (
		playerStatus != PlayerStatus.PLAYING
	) {
        PlayerStatus.PLAYING
    } else {
        PlayerStatus.PAUSED
    }
	uiState.value = uiState.value.copy(
		playerStatus = newPlayerStatus
	)
}

With this function now implemented, we can trigger it whenever the ToggleStatus event is triggered from our UI. Within our handleEvent function weâ€™ll go ahead and call our new togglePlayerStatus() function whenever the ToggleStatus event is triggered.

fun handleEvent(videoEvent: VideoEvent) {
	when (videoEvent) {
		...
		VideoEvent.ToggleStatus -> togglePlayerStatus()
	}
}

With this in place, our user can now toggle between the Playing and Paused PlayerStatus values, allowing the playback state to be reflected within our UI.

Creating the Video Player UI

With the view model and state management all in place, weâ€™re ready to move on and start implementing the composable UI for our View Player.

When weâ€™re finished building this UI, weâ€™re going to end up with something that looks like the following:

This UI will allow our users to view a full-screen video experience from within our app, while also providing some minimal management to control the playback of the video. While building this UI weâ€™ll dive into several compose topics - one of the main things for this project being interoperability between the Android View System and Composable UI. Weâ€™ll also touch on foundational concepts for Jetpack Compose apps, as well as some animation and accessibility focused topics. With that said, letâ€™s get building!

Adding the internet permission

Weâ€™re going to be loading a video from the internet, so weâ€™ll need to add the INTERNET permission to our manifest file. This can be placed above the application tag within the manifest file for the module.

<uses-permission android:name="android.permission.INTERNET" />

Setting up the Video Player UI

To start, weâ€™re going to begin by building a root composable function, VideoPlayer that will be used to house all of our Composable UI for the Video Player. For this, weâ€™ll create a new Kotlin file called VideoPlayer.kt (to keep our composables nicely organised), followed by creating a new composable function, VideoPlayer:

// VideoPlayer.kt

@Composable
fun VideoPlayer() {

}

At this point, our VideoPlayer composable isnâ€™t going to be able to do too much. In previous sections, we spent some time defining our VideoState reference, along with some details in our VideoViewModel that enable the orchestration of data between our ViewModel and UI. So that we can eventually plugin our VideoPlayer to these details, weâ€™re going to add arguments to our composable:

  • Weâ€™ll add a VideoState reference so that the state from our ViewModel can be passed into this composable function. That way, our UI can be composed based on the state coming from our ViewModel reference.
  • Weâ€™ll add an event callback, allowing us to pass up the event for the parent composable to handle. This allows us to avoid passing a direct reference to our ViewModel into the composable function - simplifying things when we come to writing tests for our composables.

With the above said, we end up with something that looks like the following, our VideoPlayer composable with a VideoState reference and event callback:

@Composable
fun VideoPlayer(
    videoState: VideoState,
    handleEvent: (event: VideoEvent) -> Unit
) {

}

With this in place, we have a composable function that can be used to compose the UI for our video player, but this isnâ€™t something that could easily act as an entry point to our player. For example, if we wanted to navigate to this composable in our app, weâ€™d need to provide both a VideoState reference and an event callback - I imagine you might also want to be testing your composable as we work through this chapter! Before we go any further here, weâ€™ll go ahead and create an entry-point composable for our screen. Here, weâ€™ll go ahead and create a new Video composable inside of a new Kotlin file, Video.kt:

// Video.kt

@Composable
fun Video() {

}

Because this composable doesnâ€™t require any arguments, it makes its contents encapsulated - allowing us to launch this from anywhere in our app without needing to worry about any of its requirements. While you wonâ€™t see anything visual just yet, youâ€™ll want to compose this Video composable within the setContent block of the activity that was created through the project wizard. Then as we build out the project, weâ€™ll be able to visualise the Video when running the project.

This entry point is going to need to compose the previous composable that we defined, VideoPlayer, which we can go ahead and add into our composable function:

@Composable
fun Video() {
    VideoPlayer(
        videoState = ...,
        handleEvent = ...
    )
}

But at this point, you might notice that things arenâ€™t going to compile - this is because our VideoPlayer composable required a VideoState reference and event callback. To be able to provide these, weâ€™re going to need a reference to our VideoViewModel. To make things easier for us here, weâ€™ll need to add the lifecycle-viewmodel-compose dependency project. This will allow us to retrieve an instance of the desired ViewModel, creating one if it does not currently exist. 

implementation "androidx.lifecycle:lifecycle-viewmodel-compose:1.0.0-alpha07"

With this in place we can now retrieve a reference to our ViewModel using the provided viewModel() function:

@Composable
fun Video() {
    val viewModel: VideoViewModel = viewModel()

    VideoPlayer(
        videoState = ...,
        handleEvent = ...
    )
}

Now that we have access to ourVideoViewModel we can provide the required properties to our VideoPlayer composable.

For our VideoState reference weâ€™re going to use the collectAsState() function on our state Flow reference - this allows us to observe our data stream as a composable state object. This means that while weâ€™ll receive updates to our state object, weâ€™ll receive them as composable state - meaning that our UI can be recomposed whenever that state change is received. We donâ€™t want to pass the State<VideoState> reference directly into our VideoPlayer composable, so instead weâ€™ll use the value of this state reference which will give us the contained value of our State, VideoState.

For our event handler, we can pass a reference to the handleEvent function that we created within our VideoViewModel. Weâ€™ll do this in the form of viewModel::handleEvent, meaning that our VideoPlayer composable now has a reference to an event handler that can be triggered whenever events occur within our Composable UI.

@Composable
fun Video() {
    val viewModel: VideoViewModel = viewModel()

    VideoPlayer(
        videoState = viewModel.uiState.collectAsState().value,
        handleEvent = viewModel::handleEvent
    )
}

At this point we now have two composable functions:

  • A Video composable that can be used as an entry point to our Video Player, not requiring any arguments to be composed
  • A VideoPlayer composable that takes the provided VideoState and composes UI based on the current state representation

Together these two composables provide us with a way to launch our Video Player and compose the UI for it based on the current state. With those in place, we can move on to creating the UI components that represent our Video Player.

Setting up ExoPlayer

So that we can play videos in our app, weâ€™re going to need a component that allows us to support media playback. Thatâ€™s a lot of work to build ourselves, so weâ€™re going to rely on existing implementations - thereâ€™s just one problem, there isnâ€™t a composable that supports media playback. But thatâ€™s OK because Jetpack Compose contains interoperability APIs that allow us to use existing Android View classes inside of composable functions. This means that we can use existing media player implementations inside of our video screen, which we will do so using ExoPlayer.

If you havenâ€™t used ExoPlayer before, thatâ€™s OK - weâ€™re not going to deep dive into what it provides, weâ€™ll just touch the surface and get a video playing with it. ExoPlayer is built by Google and is a pretty stable media solution, so itâ€™s a great tool to be aware of! Before we can start, weâ€™ll need to add two dependencies to our project:

implementation 
	"com.google.android.exoplayer:exoplayercore:$exoplayer_version"
implementation 
	"com.google.android.exoplayer:exoplayer-ui:$exoplayer_version"

Exoplayer-core contains the core offerings of the library, while exoplayer-ui contains the visual components that we need for video playback. We have these added to our project we can start to think about how we can slot in media playback functionality. In the last section we created the VideoPlayer composable, so letâ€™s head back over to that composable:

@Composable
fun VideoPlayer(
    videoState: VideoState,
    handleEvent: (event: VideoEvent) -> Unit
) {

}

Weâ€™re going to create a separate composable in the following section that will be responsible for the actual video playback, but what we want to do before then is setup the driver for that video playback - this is the class that will be responsible for the configuration of the video we are playing. This is because we want to keep this outside of our actual player implementation, decoupling the configuration details and allowing that composable to just focus on displaying the media, rather than having to configure it also.

Weâ€™ll start here by creating a new remember block, using the name exoPlayer. This is used so that the created value can be stored during composition, reused across recompositions - avoiding the ExoPlayer being recreated every single time. Because we are going to be using the same URL for the entire video player, we donâ€™t need to reconfigure the player in any way.

val exoPlayer = remember {

}

Next, weâ€™re going to define a new MediaItem. In ExoPlayer, this represents the media that is t be loaded up into our player reference. Weâ€™re going to create a MediaItem using its fromUri function, providing a URL of a video to be loaded. For this weâ€™re going to use a URL pointing to the famous Big Bunny video - you may have seen this video before, itâ€™s used for a lot of open-source project examples.

val exoPlayer = remember {
	val media: MediaItem =
		MediaItem.fromUri("https://commondatastorage.googleapis.com/gtv-videos-bucket/sample/BigBuckBunny.mp4")
}

With that in place, we can now create an ExoPlayer reference that can be used to manage the playback of our video. For this weâ€™re going to use the SimpleExoPlayer class - this â€˜simpleâ€™ player uses a collection of default configurations, removing the need for us to set a lot of these things up and just focus on playing media. Weâ€™ll use the class Builder to create a new reference to this class, for which weâ€™ll need a Context reference. Weâ€™ll use the current value of LocalContext to retrieve a context reference, followed by passing this into the Builder of the SimpleExoPlayer.

val context = LocalContext.current
val exoPlayer = remember {
	val media: MediaItem =
		MediaItem.fromUri("https://commondatastorage.googleapis.com/gtv-videos-bucket/sample/BigBuckBunny.mp4")
	val exoPlayer = SimpleExoPlayer.Builder(context).build()
}

Finally, we need to tell our SimpleExoPlayer about the media that we want it to play. Weâ€™ll use the setMediaItem function to provide our previously defined MediaItem, meaning that now our ExoPlayer reference knows about the bunny video that we want it to play.

val context = LocalContext.current
val exoPlayer = remember {
	val media: MediaItem =
		MediaItem.fromUri("https://commondatastorage.googleapis.com/gtv-videos-bucket/sample/BigBuckBunny.mp4")
	SimpleExoPlayer.Builder(context).build().apply {
		setMediaItem(media)
	}
}

Now that we have an ExoPlayer reference, weâ€™re ready to start defining the logic and composables that will be used to orchestrate media playback. Weâ€™re going to add one last modification to our ExoPlayer reference before we move forward with any playback implementation.

When we defined the state and events for our video player, we defined a VideoLoaded event - with the intention for this to be used for signifying when our video had been loaded and was ready for playback. Because ExoPlayer is going to take our MediaItem and load the video from our provided URL, ExoPlayer is going to be the one to let us know when that video has loaded. So that we know when this event has occurred weâ€™re going to set a playback state listener on our exoplayer reference, using the addListener function:

val context = LocalContext.current
val exoPlayer = remember {
	val media: MediaItem =
		MediaItem.fromUri("https://commondatastorage.googleapis.com/gtv-videos-bucket/sample/BigBuckBunny.mp4")
	SimpleExoPlayer.Builder(context).build().apply {
		setMediaItem(media)
		addListener(object : Player.Listener {
			override fun onPlaybackStateChanged(state: Int) {
				super.onPlaybackStateChanged(state)
				if (state == Player.STATE_READY) { 
					handleEvent(VideoEvent.VideoLoaded)
				}
            }
        })
	}
}

Here we set a new Player.Listener on our exoplayer reference, listening for when the Player has reached the STATE_READY value. When this is the case, we want to let the parent composable know that the video has been loaded so that our state can be updated to reflect this. To trigger this weâ€™ll use the handleEvent function that has been passed into our composable function, triggering the VideoLoaded event in the process. This now means that when our video has been loaded we can let the parent composable know, having this ready state reflected within the state of our screen - which will eventually influence how other composables behave.

With this all in place, we now have an ExoPlayer reference that can be used to manage the media playback for our video player. This will take on the responsibility of not only loading our desired video but also manage the playback of the video - allowing us to focus on building the composables that will be used to display and manipulate the video playback.

Creating the Player

So that we can display videos inside of our composable UI, weâ€™re going to need to create the UI component that will act as the player for the video. This composable is going to be focused on holding the ExoPlayer view that will handle the playback of our media, which when implemented can be placed directly inside of the parent containers that we created in the previous sections.

Weâ€™ll begin by creating a new file, Player.kt, along with a new composable function that will be used to hold our ExoPlayer view.

// Playback.kt

@Composable
fun Playback() {

}

To keep our player implementation simple (and not have it have to worry about video-related events), weâ€™re going to pass an ExoPlayer instance into our composable, as opposed to instantiating the instance inside of it. This also helps to keep our composable a bit more lightweight and focused on just composing the UI based on what is provided to it.

// Playback.kt

@Composable
fun Playback(
    exoPlayer: ExoPlayer
) {

}

Now that we have our ExoPlayer reference, weâ€™re going to start by making sure that itâ€™s ready for us to use. For this weâ€™re going to use the prepare function - this will prepare the player ready for us to use, allowing us to start media playback once it is ready.

The thing is, we only want to run this prepare function on the initial composition of our composable - if our composable is recomposed and our ExoPlayer reference has not changed, there is no need for us to re-prepare the player. So that we only prepare the player as required, weâ€™re going to make use of a compose side-effect known as LaunchedEffect.

@Composable
fun Playback(
    exoPlayer: ExoPlayer
) {
	LaunchedEffect(exoPlayer, block = {
        exoPlayer.prepare()
    })
}

The LaunchedEffect side-effect allows us to execute a function based on the scope of the composable, launching a coroutine to execute the provided block. When composition happens, the side-effect block will be executed and if the LaunchedEffect leaves the composition, then the coroutine will be cancelled. Subsequent compositions will only trigger the side-effect block if the provided key is changed (in our case, the ExoPlayer reference). If the key is changed at any point, then the existing coroutine will be cancelled, with a new coroutine execution taking its place. Using this side-effect we can prepare our ExoPlayer reference on initial composition and only as required.

With our ExoPlayer reference prepared, we can now start thinking about how we are going to use that to display video playback. To handle video playback weâ€™re going to utilise the player that is provided by ExoPlayer, the PlayerView - the only issue here is that the PlayerView is an Android View class and weâ€™re working with composables. Luckily for us, Jetpack Compose offers so interoperability features that allow us to use Android View classes inside of Composable functions - this functionality is offered in the form of the AndroidView composable. This composable function features two key arguments which are used to offer interoperability - these arguments are function blocks call factory and update.

@Composable
fun VideoView(
    exoPlayer: ExoPlayer
) {

	LaunchedEffect(exoPlayer, block = {
        exoPlayer.prepare()
    })

    AndroidView(
        factory = {
            
        },
        update = {
            
        }
	)
}

The factory block will be called a single time on the UI thread when the AndroidView is initially composed. Because this ensures that the View will only be instantiated a single time, you can also use this block to perform any other related initialisations that only need to happen a single time. When this factory block is called, a reference to this view will be stored against a view holder so that it can be composed when required.

When it comes to the update block - this is a callback that is triggered once the layout within the factory block has been inflated. This block will be triggered after the factory block has completed, and then every single time state is changed - allowing you to ensure that the AndroidView reflects the current state of your data.

Weâ€™ll start with implementing the body of our AndroidView using the factory. Within this we simply want to instantiate a new reference to a PlayerView, for this, weâ€™ll need a content reference so weâ€™ll also add this as a required argument to the Player composable function.

@Composable
fun Playback(
	modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    exoPlayer: ExoPlayer,
	context: Context
) {

	...

    AndroidView(
    	modifier = modifier,
        factory = {
            PlayerView(context)
        },
        update = {
            
        }
	)
}

At this point, we have a composable function that will compose an AndroidView, which in turn will display our ExoPlayer PlayerView. When working with Android View classes inside of our AndroidView, we can interact with them just like we would inside of non-compose scenarios. Letâ€™s modify some of the display properties for our PlayerView, configuring the layout parameters to fill the maximum available dimensions for both the width and height:

PlayerView(context).apply {
	layoutParams = ViewGroup.LayoutParams(
		ViewGroup.LayoutParams.MATCH_PARENT,
		ViewGroup.LayoutParams.MATCH_PARENT
    )
}

Weâ€™ll also want to configure some PlayerView specific properties. Weâ€™ll need to start by assigning a player to the PlayerView, this is so that video playback will function - we can use the ExoPlayer reference that is provided to our composable function for this.

PlayerView(context).apply {
	layoutParams = ViewGroup.LayoutParams(
		ViewGroup.LayoutParams.MATCH_PARENT,
		ViewGroup.LayoutParams.MATCH_PARENT
    )
	player = exoPlayer
}

Finally, we donâ€™t want our PlayView to display any playback controls - this is because we are going to be implementing our own controls using Composable UI. So that we can use our own controls and the stock ones do not display, weâ€™ll use thehideController function, as well as disable the default controller using useController.

PlayerView(context).apply {
	layoutParams = ViewGroup.LayoutParams(
		ViewGroup.LayoutParams.MATCH_PARENT,
		ViewGroup.LayoutParams.MATCH_PARENT
    )
	player = exoPlayer
	hideController()
	useController = false
}

With this in place, we now have a PlayerView wrapped by the AndroidView composable, allowing us to display the video playback view directly inside of our composable UI.

@Composable
fun Playback(
	modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    exoPlayer: ExoPlayer,
	context: Context
) {

	LaunchedEffect(exoPlayer, block = {
        exoPlayer.prepare()
    })

    AndroidView(
    	modifier = modifier,
        factory = {
            PlayerView(context).apply {
            	layoutParams = ViewGroup.LayoutParams(
                    ViewGroup.LayoutParams.MATCH_PARENT, 					ViewGroup.LayoutParams.MATCH_PARENT
                )
                hideController()
                useController = false
                player = exoPlayer
            }
        },
        update = {

        }
	)
}

At this point weâ€™ve configured the factory block of the AndroidView, allowing our PlayView to be configured and displayed on the screen. However, our view currently isnâ€™t going to be reflecting the latest playback status from our UI state. So that we can come our Player based on our UI state, weâ€™re going to need to provide the current PlayerStatus to our composable:

@Composable
fun Playback(
	modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
	state: PlayerStatus = PlayerStatus.IDLE,
    exoPlayer: ExoPlayer,
	context: Context
)

Now that our Player composables knows the current PlayerStatus we can reflect this status with our ExoPlayer PlayerView. Whenever our Player is recomposed to reflect this state change, we want to ensure that our AndroidView is also updated accordingly. For this weâ€™re going to utilise the update block - this will allow us to update any properties of our PlayerView from the factory block based on these state changes.

Here weâ€™re going to configure the player of our PlayerView (the one that we assigned using our ExoPlayer reference) based on the current PlayerStatus within our composable.

@Composable
fun Playback(
	modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
	state: PlayerStatus = PlayerStatus.PAUSED,
    exoPlayer: ExoPlayer,
	context: Context
) {

	...

    AndroidView(
    	modifier = modifier,
        factory = {
            ...
        },
        update = {
			when (state) {
            	PlayerStatus.PLAYING -> {
                    playerView.player?.play()
                }
                PlayerStatus.PAUSED -> {
                    playerView.player?.pause()
                }
            }
        }
	)
}

If our PlayerStatus currently represents the PLAYING state, then we want to trigger the play function on our player, otherwise, if it represents PAUSED then weâ€™ll trigger pause. With this in place, it means that the parent composable will be able to pass in any state changes for the current playback status of our Video Player, with our AndroidView utilising this state to ensure that our ExoPlayer reference is in the corresponding playback state.

With the above in place, we have a PlayerView that can be used in our composable UI to display video playback. The only issue at this point is that our Player composable is not reacting to any lifecycle change events - this means that if the composable is torn down (such as our app being moved away from and put into the background) the PlayerView reference is not adapting to this new state - meaning that video playback will continue in the background. What we want to do is release the player reference so that playback is stopped when our composable is torn down.

For this weâ€™re going to explore using another composable side-effect, this time in the form of a DisposableEffect. The DisposableEffect is a side-effect that takes a key and an effect block:

@Composable
@NonRestartableComposable
fun DisposableEffect(
    key1: Any?,
    effect: DisposableEffectScope.() -> DisposableEffectResult
)

The key is used to determine if the composable needs to be cleaned up - if the key-value changes, then the composable is registered as needing to be disposed of so it is reset and the effect is called again. In the case of the composable leaving composition, the composable is just decomposed.

With the effect block, we will utilise the onDispose clause to perform the required cleanup of our ExoPlayer reference. Because our composable is being decomposed, our DisposableEffect is aware of this so the onDispose clause will be called accordingly. Within this onDispose we will want to call the release function on our ExoPlayer reference, meaning that when our composable is decomposed our ExoPlayer reference will be cleaned up in the process.

@Composable
fun Playback(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    state: PlayerStatus = PlayerStatus.PAUSED,
    context: Context,
    exoPlayer: ExoPlayer
) {

	LaunchedEffect(exoPlayer, block = {
        exoPlayer.prepare()
    })

	DisposableEffect(
        AndroidView(
            ...
		)
    ) {
        onDispose {
            exoPlayer.release()
        }
    }

}

While at this point weâ€™re handling the disposable of our composable, we still need to take care of some of the Android Lifecycle events. For example, if the onPause lifecycle event is triggered (as in, the user moves to another application and moves ours to the background) then weâ€™ll want to pause the video, resuming it once then return and the onResume lifecycle event is triggered. For this, weâ€™ll need to be able to observe the current lifecycle for our application from within our composable function - meaning weâ€™ll need access to a LifecycleOwner reference. Weâ€™ll add a new argument for this to our Playback composable function, providing a default value of LocalLifecycleOwner.current if this is not provided - which gives us the nearest LifecycleOwner that has invoked the composable function.

@Composable
fun Playback(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    lifecycleOwner: LifecycleOwner = 	
		LocalLifecycleOwner.current,
    state: PlayerStatus,
    context: Context,
    exoPlayer: ExoPlayer
)

Now that we have this LifecycleOwner reference, weâ€™re going to want to observe its state so that we can react accordingly. Weâ€™re going to start by declaring another DisposableEffect composable, providing the LifecycleOwner reference as the key - this means that if this reference changes, then the DisposableEffect will be called again. Within this side-effect weâ€™ll create a new LifecycleEventObserver so that we can observe the lifecycle events that occur for the given LifecycleOwner, followed by registering this listener against our LifecycleOwner reference, removing it during the onDispose block of the DisposableEffect.

DisposableEffect(lifecycleOwner) {
	val observer = LifecycleEventObserver { _, event ->
		
    }

    lifecycleOwner.lifecycle.addObserver(observer)

    onDispose {
        lifecycleOwner.lifecycle.removeObserver(observer)
    }
}

Now that this listener has been registered, weâ€™re going to want to manage the provided ExoPlayer reference based on the emitted lifecycle event. Here weâ€™ll use conditional checks to trigger play on our ExoPlayer reference when the triggered lifecycle event is Lifecycle.Event.ON_RESUME, triggering pause when the Lifecycle.Event.ON_PAUSE event is received. Weâ€™ll only want to respond to these events when the current PlayerStatus is equal to PlayerStatus.PLAYING (which means our video is currently being played), as we wonâ€™t want to fire these events when the user is not currently playing the provided media.

DisposableEffect(lifecycleOwner) {
	val observer = LifecycleEventObserver { _, event ->
		if (state == PlayerStatus.PLAYING) {
			if (event == Lifecycle.Event.ON_RESUME) {
				exoPlayer.play()
			} else if (event == Lifecycle.Event.ON_PAUSE) {
                exoPlayer.pause()
            }
        }
    }

    lifecycleOwner.lifecycle.addObserver(observer)

    onDispose {
        lifecycleOwner.lifecycle.removeObserver(observer)
    }
}

With this in place, we have an observer that will listen to and react to lifecycle events that occur within our composable. However, things arenâ€™t going to quite work as expected yet - this is because the PlayerStatus value that we are utilising within the observer wonâ€™t reflect the latest values that are provided through recomposition. So that we can ensure the latest value provided to the composable function is always used within our observer, weâ€™re going to need to use the rememberUpdatedState function. As per the documentation:

rememberUpdatedState should be used when parameters or values computed during composition are referenced by a long-lived lambda or object expression. Recomposition will update the resulting State without recreating the long-lived lambda or object, allowing that object to persist without cancelling and resubscribing, or relaunching a long-lived operation that may be expensive to recreate and restart. This may be common when working with DisposableEffect or LaunchedEffect,

With that in mind, weâ€™ll create a new reference here using the rememberUpdatedState function and providing our PlayerStatus reference. Now, whenever our composable is recomposed, the latest value will always be utilised within the lifecycle observer.

val currentPlayerStatus by rememberUpdatedState(state)
DisposableEffect(lifecycleOwner) {
	val observer = LifecycleEventObserver { _, event ->
		if (currentPlayerStatus == PlayerStatus.PLAYING) {
			if (event == Lifecycle.Event.ON_RESUME) {
				exoPlayer.play()
			} else if (event == Lifecycle.Event.ON_PAUSE) {
                exoPlayer.pause()
            }
        }
    }

    lifecycleOwner.lifecycle.addObserver(observer)

    onDispose {
        lifecycleOwner.lifecycle.removeObserver(observer)
    }
}

While we have provided a default value for the LifecycleOwner that is being provided to our composable function, weâ€™re going to go ahead and propagate this value down from the activity that is composing our function - this is so that we can be explicit about the LifecycleOwner that is being utilised here. Weâ€™ll start by adding this as an argument to our VideoPlayer function, passing this into the Playback composable as required.

@Composable
fun VideoPlayer(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    lifecycleOwner: LifecycleOwner = 
		LocalLifecycleOwner.current,
    videoState: VideoState,
    handleEvent: (event: VideoEvent) -> Unit
) {

	...
	
	Playback(
		modifier = Modifier
            .fillMaxSize()
            .clickable(
                onClickLabel = stringResource(
					id = controlsClickLabel)
                ) {
                    controlsVisible = !controlsVisible
                }
            .testTag(Tags.TAG_VIDEO_PLAYER),
        lifecycleOwner = lifecycleOwner,
        state = videoState.playerStatus, 
        context = context, 
        exoPlayer = exoPlayer
    )
}

Next, weâ€™ll want to provide this to our Video composable function as an argument, followed by passing it down into the VideoPlayer as an argument.

@Composable
fun Video(
    lifecycleOwner: LifecycleOwner = 	
		LocalLifecycleOwner.current
) {
    val viewModel: VideoViewModel = viewModel()

    VideoPlayer(
        modifier = Modifier.fillMaxSize(),
        videoState = viewModel.uiState.collectAsState().value,
        lifecycleOwner = lifecycleOwner,
        handleEvent = viewModel::handleEvent
    )
}

And finally, within the VideoActivity where we compose the content of our video feature, weâ€™ll pass the current reference to a LifecycleOwner using the activity that is performing the composition.

setContent {
	Video(lifecycleOwner = this)
}

With that in place weâ€™ve now built out a Player composable that allows us to effectively display video playback, with this weâ€™ve:

  • Learnt about the LaunchedEffect side-effect and how it can be used to trigger events on initial compositions (or if the provided key has changed)
  • Use a pre-existing Android View class inside of a composable function using interoperability features
  • Learnt about the DisposableEffect side-effect and how it can be used to handle decomposition and tidy-up of any composables and logic
  • Created our video player that reacts to state that is being passed into the composable function

Now that we have our video playback in place, we can move on to explore how we can control the playback of the video via user interaction.

Creating the Controls

So that the user can control the playback of the video media, weâ€™re going to implement some simple controls. For this composable, weâ€™re going to create a control bar that:

  • Displays Play/Pause button that allows the user to control media playback
  • Disables any user interaction until the video has loaded
  • Animates out of view when it has not been interacted with

While only supporting the ability to Play / Pause the video, weâ€™ll be implementing the other two points from above to make our composable controls a little bit more interesting. To get started weâ€™ll create a new file called Controls.kt, followed by a composable function called Controls:

// Controls.kt

@Composable
fun Controls(
	modifier: Modifier = Modifier
) {
    
}

Even though weâ€™re only going to be displaying a single control in our control bar, weâ€™re going to need a parent container. This is because we want the control bar to fill the width of our video player - as well as give the bar some styling that is independent of the controls inside of it. For this, weâ€™ll go ahead and declare a Box - the Box composable will stack the children in the order that they are provided to it. If providing multiple children then there may be overlap with the composables that you define, but because we are only using a single child composable we are safe from that happening.

@Composable
fun Controls(
	modifier: Modifier = Modifier
) {
    Box(modifier = modifier) {

	}
}

Creating the playback button

With the container in place, we can go ahead and define the composable that will be used for our Play/Pause control - for this, weâ€™ll use the IconButton composable. While there is a Button composable available that we could just provide an icon to as the body, the IconButton is specifically designed to display intractable icons as its minimum touch targets meet the required dimensions for accessibility standards. When using the IconButton you must provide its two required arguments, the onClick callback and content argument:

@Composable
fun Controls(
	modifier: Modifier = Modifier
) {
    Box(modifier = modifier) {
		IconButton(
            onClick = {
                
            }
        ) {

		}
	}
}

The onClick callback allows us to receive click events for the IconButton, while the content allows us to provide the composable body that we want to be composed inside of the IconButton. For now, weâ€™re going to leave the onClick function empty, but weâ€™ll go ahead and add the body for our IconButton in the form of an Icon composable.

@Composable
fun Controls(
	modifier: Modifier = Modifier
) {
    Box(modifier = modifier) {
		IconButton(
            onClick = {
                
            }
        ) {
			Icon(
                imageVector = ...,
                contentDescription = ...
            )
		}
	}
}

We can see here that the Icon composable has two required arguments. There are several variations of the Icon composable, depending on the format of the icon is that you are providing to it. For simplicities sake, weâ€™re going to provide an ImageVector, taken from the material-icons-extended library. This contains a lot of icons that we donâ€™t need in the project but allows us to just slot the icon in the place where we need it.

implementation "androidx.compose.material:material-icons-extended:$compose_version"

Before we go ahead and add the icon to our composable, weâ€™re going to need some extra information in our composable. Because we are using the same button for the Play/Pause action, weâ€™re going to need to know the current state of the playback so that we can set the icon based on that. For this weâ€™re going to need to provide the PlayerStatus into the composable, this will come from the current state of the screen.

@Composable
fun Controls(
	modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
	playerStatus: PlayerStatus
)

With this in place, we can go ahead and calculate the icon based on this information. If the PlayerStatus currently represents the PLAYING state then weâ€™ll use the Icons.Default.Pause icon (as when playing, the user will be able to toggle the state to paused), otherwise, weâ€™ll utilise the Icons.Default.PlayArrow to indicate that the user can set the video to the playing state. After creating a reference to an icon using this logic, weâ€™ll assign this to the imageVector argument of the Icon composable.

@Composable
fun Controls(
	modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
	playerStatus: PlayerStatus
) {
    Box(modifier = modifier) {
		IconButton(
            onClick = {
                
            }
        ) {
			val icon = if (playerStatus ==
				PlayerStatus.PLAYING
			) {
            	Icons.Default.Pause
            } else Icons.Default.PlayArrow


			Icon(
                imageVector = icon,
                contentDescription = ...
            )
		}
	}
}

Before our Icon composable is complete weâ€™ll need to add a contentDescription, as this is a required argument. While this is nullable, weâ€™ll want to provide a description so that the icon is accessible to users using a screen reader. If we donâ€™t provide a content description, the user will not be aware of what the icon is used for - therefore causing friction when trying to interact with the playback state of the video.

So that we can assign a description to our Icon, weâ€™ll go ahead and start by adding two new string resources in our strings.xml resource file - weâ€™ll add one for both the playing and paused states:

<string name="cd_play">Play video</string>
<string name="cd_pause">Pause video</string>

Now that we have these string resources in place, we can reference them from our composable. Similar to the logic used for the icon of our composable, weâ€™ll create a reference for the description paused on the current PlayerStatus that has been provided to our composable.

val description = 
	if (playerStatus == PlayerStatus.PLAYING) {
		stringResource(id = R.string.cd_pause)
	} else stringResource(id = R.string.cd_play)

When our PlayerStatus represents the PLAYING status our description will represent the â€œPause Videoâ€ string - this will be matched with the Pause icon that will be displayed at the time, as our video will be playing so that IconButton will be used to pause the video. With this logic in place, we can now assign our description reference to the contentDescription argument of the Icon composable.

@Composable
fun Controls(
	modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
	playerStatus: PlayerStatus
) {
    Box(modifier = modifier) {
		IconButton(
            onClick = {
                
            }
        ) {
			val icon = if (playerStatus ==
				PlayerStatus.PLAYING
			) {
            	Icons.Default.Pause
            } else Icons.Default.PlayArrow

			val description = if (playerStatus == PlayerStatus.PLAYING
			) {
                stringResource(id = R.string.cd_pause)
            } else stringResource(id = R.string.cd_play)

			Icon(
                imageVector = icon,
                contentDescription = description
            )
		}
	}
}

Toggling playback state

Now we have the above in place, we have an IconButton composable that will configure its icon and content description based on based on the current PlayerStatus that is provided to our composable. The only thing now is that our IconButton isnâ€™t triggering any events when itâ€™s clicked - which is kind of the whole reason for adding a button in the first place! When the IconButton is clicked weâ€™re going to want to toggle the playback status of the video - the only thing is that our composable doesnâ€™t have a reference to the player instance that needs controlling. This is a good thing though, as it means the controls of our video player are decoupled from the actual video player implementation. This just means that weâ€™re going to need to pass up any click events on the IconButton so that the parent composable can handle those click events and update the PlayerStatus accordingly. For this weâ€™ll need to add another argument to our Controls composable in the form of a callback - weâ€™ll call this togglePlayingState:

@Composable
fun Controls(
	modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    playerStatus: PlayerStatus,
    togglePlayingState: () -> Unit
)

Now when our IconButton is clicked we can trigger the callback to pass up the event to the parent composable. To do this weâ€™ll trigger our togglePlayingState callback with the onClick lambda of our IconButton:

@Composable
fun Controls(
	modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    playerStatus: PlayerStatus,
    togglePlayingState: () -> Unit
) {
    Box(modifier = modifier) {
        IconButton(
            onClick = {
                togglePlayingState()
            }
        ) {
			...
        }
    }
}

Styling the Control bar

Now that we have the body of our controls implemented, our control bar isnâ€™t yet going to look quite right within our UI. This is because we havenâ€™t configured how our composable should be composed onscreen, this means that by default our Controls composable is just going to be wrapping the size of the content that we have provided to it.

However, we want our Controls to fill the width of our video player, as well as use a background colour to make it prominent when displayed on top of our player. Here weâ€™re going to utilise the background modifier to do so. Weâ€™ll chain this onto our modifier declaration, using the surface colour from our theme when applying this.

@Composable
fun Controls(
	modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    playerStatus: PlayerStatus,
    togglePlayingState: () -> Unit
) {
    Box(
		modifier = modifier
            .background(MaterialTheme.colors.surface)
    ) {
        IconButton(
            onClick = {
                togglePlayingState()
            }
        ) {
			...
        }
    }
}

With these applied, we can see that our Controls composable fills the maximum width that it has available, along with using the surface colour from our application theme as the background:

You might notice here that the IconButton doesnâ€™t sit quite right inside of the Box - if we aligned it in the center, things would look a little more presentable. To align children inside of a Box we can use the contentAlignment argument, using one of the 2D Alignment values to declare how the alignment should be applied. Weâ€™ll use the Alignment.Center value to have our IconButton aligned in the center of our Box.

@Composable
fun Controls(
	modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    playerStatus: PlayerStatus,
    togglePlayingState: () -> Unit
) {
    Box(
		modifier = modifier
            .background(MaterialTheme.colors.surface),
        contentAlignment = Alignment.Center
    ) {
        IconButton(
            onClick = {
                togglePlayingState()
            }
        ) {
			...
        }
    }
}

With this contentAlignment applied we can now see how the IconButton is position inside of the Box:

Setting the enabled state of the controls

Now that our control bar is looking presentable, weâ€™re going to add the finishing touch to its expected functionality. Our Controls composable has a reference to the current PlayerStatus state - when we defined these values we did so in a way that allows it to not only just reflect the playing and paused state, but also the loading and idle state. The thing is, when the PlayerStatus is in the loading state, we donâ€™t want to allow the user to interact with the controls - this is because the video hasnâ€™t loaded yet, so we donâ€™t need to allow the user to play or pause the video (as this wouldnâ€™t have any effect anyway!).

What weâ€™ll do here is utilise the enabled argument of the IconButton composable. This will allow us to control whether or not the button can be interacted with by the user - which we donâ€™t want to allow if the video is currently being loaded. In this case, we will want only to enable the button if the PlayerStatus value is not equal to LOADING:

@Composable
fun Controls(
	modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    playerStatus: PlayerStatus,
    togglePlayingState: () -> Unit
) {
    Box(
		modifier = modifier
            .background(MaterialTheme.colors.surface),
        contentAlignment = Alignment.Center
    ) {
        IconButton(
            onClick = {
                togglePlayingState()
            },
            enabled = playerStatus != PlayerStatus.LOADING
        ) {
			...
        }
    }
}

With the logic of playerStatus != PlayerStatus.LOADING applied to the enabled argument, the IconButton composable will be disabled if the playerStatus is marked as loading - disallowing interaction while the video is being loaded.

With all of this in place, we have a fully functioning control bar that allows the user to play + pause video playback. All thatâ€™s left now is to piece our composables together to wrap up the video player UI.

Piecing things together

With all of the above composables in place, we now have the individual components that can be used to make up our video player - we just need to piece them together! At the start of this section, we defined the VideoPlayer composable, so weâ€™ll now use that as the parent composable for these individual components that weâ€™ve created.

Composing the Player and Controls

If we backtrack to the start of this section in the chapter, we created a new composable function called VideoPlayer:

@Composable
fun VideoPlayer(
	modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    videoState: VideoState,
    handleEvent: (event: VideoEvent) -> Unit
) {

	val context = LocalContext.current
    val exoPlayer = remember {
        val media: MediaItem =
            MediaItem.fromUri("https://
			commondatastorage.googleapis.com/
			gtv-videos-bucket/sample/BigBuckBunny.mp4")
        val exoPlayer = SimpleExoPlayer.Builder(context)
			.build()
        exoPlayer.setMediaItem(media)
        exoPlayer
    }
    exoPlayer.addListener(object : Player.Listener {
        override fun onPlaybackStateChanged(state: Int) {
            super.onPlaybackStateChanged(state)
            if (state == Player.STATE_READY) {
				handleEvent(VideoEvent.VideoLoaded)
			}
        }
    })
}

Within this composable function, we created a reference to an ExoPlayer instance and configured it with the required information for video playback. At this point though, the composable function does not do much else. With the composables that weâ€™ve created throughout this chapter, we can now slot those into our VideoPlayer composable so that they are composed as part of our player UI.

Weâ€™re going to start here by defining a Box composable. As we previously mentioned, this composable allows us to stack composables on top of one another - this is perfect for our video player, as we wish to display the control bar on top of our video playback composable. Weâ€™ll define this Box composable and give it a background color using Color.Black - using this will help to create an immersive experience, as any area our video does not fill will be visible as black space.

Box(
	modifier = modifier.background(Color.Black)
) {

}
