With this Box in place, we now have a parent composable that can be used to hold our player and control composables. Weâ€™ll first compose the Playback composable - this is because we want this to appear underneath the controls composable, so it gets declared first within the composable block. When composing this, weâ€™ll provide the fillMaxSize modifier to fill the available size on the screen.

Box(
	modifier = modifier.background(Color.Black)
) {
	Playback(
		modifier = Modifier.fillMaxSize(),
		context = ..., 
		exoPlayer = ...
    )
}

The Playback composable has three required arguments, a Context reference, ExoPlayer reference and PlayerStatus value. We already have a Context reference from where we are initialising our ExoPlayer reference just above here, so we can pass that directly into our Playback composable. At the same time, we have also initialised the ExoPlayer reference within this process, so we can pass that in too.

Box(
	modifier = modifier.background(Color.Black)
) {
	Playback(
		modifier = Modifier.fillMaxSize(),
		context = context, 
		exoPlayer = exoplayer
    )
}

For the PlayerStatus value, we can directly pass in the playerStatus value that we have available from our VideoState reference that is passed to the VideoPlayer composable function.

Box(
	modifier = Modifier.background(Color.Black)
) {
	Playback(
		modifier = Modifier.fillMaxSize(),
        state = videoState.playerStatus, 
		context = context, 
		exoPlayer = exoPlayer
    )
}

At this point, the Playback composable is being composed within our UI and now we need to compose the Controls, so the video playback of our Playback composable can be controlled.

Box(
	modifier = Modifier.background(Color.Black)
) {
	Playback(
		modifier = Modifier.fillMaxSize(),
        state = videoState.playerStatus, 
		context = context, 
		exoPlayer = exoPlayer
    )

	Controls(
		modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
		playerStatus = ...,
		togglePlayingState = ...
	)
}

The Controls composable has two required arguments, the playerStatus and togglePlayingState callback. For the playerStatus we can do the same as we did for the Playback composable, passing the value in directly from the VideoState reference.

Box(
	modifier = Modifier.background(Color.Black)
) {
	...

	Controls(
		modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
		playerStatus = videoState.playerStatus,
		togglePlayingState = ...
	)
}

When it comes to the togglePlayingState callback we need to trigger an event so that the playback state is toggled within our state. The VideoPlayer composable that we are composing inside of has a reference to a handleEvent function that takes a VideoEvent to be handled, allowing us to pass UI events up to the parent composable for handling. Earlier in this chapter, we defined these VideoEvent types, one of which being the ToggleStatus type. Weâ€™re going to trigger this event here so that when this togglePlayingState callback is triggered from within our Controls composable, it can be handled here and the event passed up to the parent composable using the event handler.

Box(
	modifier = Modifier.background(Color.Black)
) {
	Playback(
		modifier = Modifier.fillMaxSize(),
        state = videoState.playerStatus, 
		context = context, 
		exoPlayer = exoPlayer
    )

	Controls(
		modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
		playerStatus = videoState.playerStatus,
		togglePlayingState = {
			handleEvent(VideoEvent.ToggleStatus)
		}
	)
}

At this point, we can see that our video playback UI is composed, but the Controls composable doesnâ€™t appear to be sitting quite right within our UI.

To fix this, weâ€™re going to provide a Modifier to the Controls composable, utilising the align modifier to align the composable within the parent Box. Here weâ€™ll use the Alignment.BottomCenter so that the Controls composable is positioned at the bottom and in the center of the playback area, feeling like a more natural positioning for the controls bar.

Box(
	modifier = modifier.background(Color.Black)
) {
	Playback(
		modifier = Modifier.fillMaxSize(),
        state = videoState.playerStatus, 
		context = context, 
		exoPlayer = exoPlayer
    )

	Controls(
		modifier = Modifier
			.fillMaxWidth()
			.align(Alignment.BottomCenter),
		playerStatus = videoState.playerStatus,
		togglePlayingState = {
			handleEvent(VideoEvent.ToggleStatus)
		}
	)
}

With the above in place, we now have our video playback UI being composed, allowing our users to consume playback content while also having control over the current status of the playback. At this point though, the control bar is always visible - to create a better immersive experience we can hide the control bar from view, allowing our user to enjoy the full-screen video playback without the controls blocking any viewing space.

Managing the control bar visibility

While our video is playing, the control bar can block part of the playback area - so once the user has finished interacting with the control bar, weâ€™ll want to move it out of view so that the user can continue with the immersive full-screen experience. So when it comes to displaying the toolbar, weâ€™ll implement the behaviour in the following way:

  • The control bar will be displayed by default when the video player is first displayed
  • If the user does not interact with the control bar, then the control bar will dismiss after a specified amount of time
  • When the user interacts with the video player and the control bar is hidden, then the control bar will animate back into view

While these points outline the behaviour of the control bar, the control bar itself isnâ€™t going to care about all of these. The control bar is being used to compose controls on the screen, it doesnâ€™t need to know about when itâ€™s going to show and hide itself, that will be the responsibility of the current composable that we are working inside of, the parent of the Controls composable. What we can do here is define an animation that will be used to control the alpha of the Controls composable, passing this in via a modifier so that the alpha can be applied without the composable knowing anything about this logic.

Before we can start thinking about the animation logic, we need some form of state that can be used to represent whether or not the controls are currently visible. This doesnâ€™t need to be a part of our screen state, as currently, this logic is OK to be coupled to our VideoPlayer composable - as nothing else above this composable needs to know about this value. With the said, weâ€™ll go ahead and define a new piece of mutable state, controlsVisible.

Box(
	modifier = modifier.background(Color.Black)
) {

	var controlsVisible by remember {
		mutableStateOf(true)
    }

	Playback(
		modifier = Modifier.fillMaxSize(),
        state = videoState.playerStatus, 
		context = context, 
		exoPlayer = exoPlayer
    )

	Controls(
		modifier = Modifier
            .fillMaxWidth()
			.align(Alignment.BottomCenter),
		playerStatus = videoState.playerStatus,
		togglePlayingState = {
			handleEvent(VideoEvent.ToggleStatus)
		}
	)
}

We default this value to true so that when our video player is first composed and the state is initialised, the controls are visible on the screen.

Box(
	modifier = Modifier.background(Color.Black)
) {

	var controlsVisible by remember {
		mutableStateOf(true)
    }

	Playback(
		modifier = Modifier.fillMaxSize(),
        state = videoState.playerStatus, 
		context = context, 
		exoPlayer = exoPlayer
    )

	Controls(
		modifier = Modifier
			.fillMaxWidth()
			.align(Alignment.BottomCenter),
		playerStatus = videoState.playerStatus,
		togglePlayingState = {
			handleEvent(VideoEvent.ToggleStatus)
		}
	)
}

Now that we have this state in place, weâ€™re going to want to manipulate its value when certain interactions occur on screen. Letâ€™s start with when the control bar is interacted with, as we have the togglePlayingState callback that can be used to detect when playback change is triggered via the control bar. When this event does occur we are going to want to change the visibility of controls based on the current PlayerStatus value before the state is updated from the event change.

At a high level, weâ€™re going to want to hide the controls if the current state of the player does not represent the PLAYING state. This means that if the video is currently IDLE and moving to PLAYING then weâ€™ll hide the controls, and if the video is currently PAUSED and moving to PLAYING then weâ€™ll also want to hide the controls - this is because in both cases the player will be moving to the PLAYING state, so we donâ€™t want to block playback visibility. In any other cases, we will be moving away from the PLAYING state - so keeping the controller on the screen allows users to continue managing the video playback state until the video is playing again.

togglePlayingState = {
	handleEvent(VideoEvent.ToggleStatus)
	if (videoState.playerStatus != PlayerStatus.PLAYING) {
		controlsVisible = false
	}
}

While the above hides the control bar visibility by setting controlsVisible to false, weâ€™re going to want to somehow allow the user to display the control bar once it has been hidden. For simplicity sake, weâ€™re going to display the control bar whenever the user taps the playback area. This means we can add a click listener to our Player composable and toggle this controlsVisible value to display our controls. Weâ€™re going to add this functionality by utilising the Modifier that we are already providing to the Player composable, meaning we can directly chain on the clickable modifier and toggle the value of controlsVisible based on its current value.

Playback(
	modifier = Modifier
		.fillMaxSize()
		.clickable {
			controlsVisible = !controlsVisible
		},
	state = videoState.playerStatus, 
	context = context, 
	exoPlayer = exoPlayer
)

So now whenever the playback area is clicked, the controlsVisible will be toggled to the opposite state - allowing the control bar to be displayed (and also hidden) whenever the playback area is tapped.

One issue with this approach is that for users utilising accessibility features, the click functionality here will not be very accessible. While the click action is there, the screen reader has no clue what that click action does. To improve this weâ€™re going to add a click label - that way the screen reader can communicate the intention of our click action to the user. Before we add this label weâ€™re going to need to add some string resources to our project - weâ€™ll add one for displaying the video controls, as well as one for hiding the video controls:

<string name="label_display_controls">
	Display video controls
</string>

<string name="label_hide_controls">
	Hide video controls
</string>

Weâ€™ll then need to assign the label based on the current value of our controlsVisible reference. If the controls are currently visible then we want to set the description for hiding the controls, otherwise, weâ€™ll use the description for showing the controls.

val controlsClickLabel = if (controlsVisible) {
	R.string.label_hide_controls
} else {
	R.string.label_display_controls
}

We can then use this to apply a value to the onClickLabel of the clickable modifier. 

Playback(
	modifier = Modifier
		.fillMaxSize()
		.clickable(
        	onClickLabel = stringResource(
				id = controlsClickLabel)
        ) {
			controlsVisible = !controlsVisible
		},
	...
)

As we can see, this isnâ€™t a required property of the clickable modifier, but for minimal effort, we can increase the accessibility of our composable for screen readers.

Animating the control bar visibility

As a final piece of work for our video player, weâ€™re going to add a touch of animation so that the control bar can be displayed and hidden in an animated fashion. While at the moment our control bar is showing and hiding from interaction with the video player, adding animation gives it a nice little touch!

Because we want to animate the alpha of the Controls composable, weâ€™re going to need to utilise an animation function, in the form of animateFloatAsState. This only has a single required argument, the targetValue - this is the float value that we wish to animate to.

val alphaAnimation by animateFloatAsState(
	targetValue = if (controlsVisible) 0.7f else 0f
)

Weâ€™re going to want to set the alpha of our control bar based on whether the controls should currently be visible, in the context of our controlsVisible reference. So if our controls should currently be shown (as in, controlsVisible is true) then weâ€™ll animate to the value of 0.7f - this is because we donâ€™t want the control bar not to have any alpha at all, as visually itâ€™s nice to have it slightly transparent. On the other hand, if the controls are not to be shown, then we want to animate to the value of 0f - making our control bar completely translucent and not visible. This results in animating between 0f and 0.7f to show and hide the control bar from view - all we need to do now is apply this to our control bar using the alpha modifier, which we can chain onto the existing modifiers that we are passing to our Controls composable:

Controls(
	modifier = Modifier
    	.align(Alignment.BottomCenter)
    	.alpha(alphaAnimation),
	...
)

With this in place, we will be able to see our control bar animating between a visible and non-visible state.

While this now works and our control is animating its alpha state, we can go one step further here and customise the animation that is being used. We can do this by using the optional animationSpec argument of the animateFloatAsState function. By default the function will use a spring animation - weâ€™re going to switch this out for the tween animation. I think the animation feels a little nicer in this case (you can switch this out and try for yourself to see what you prefer!), but more importantly, the tween animation allows us to define a delay to be applied before the animation is started.

val alphaAnimation by animateFloatAsState(
	targetValue = if (controlsVisible) 0.7f else 0f,
	animationSpec = if (controlsVisible) {
		tween(delayMillis = 0) 
	} else tween(delayMillis = 750)
)

This is handy because in the case of the controls not being visible, animating the control bar out of view immediately after an interaction might feel a little bit sudden. So instead we can apply a delay here, allowing the existing animation to be applied slightly after the animation is triggered. We can see above that in the case of the controls being visible, we do not apply a delay and allow the controls to be shown instantly to the user.

This animation customisation is a small optional touch, so if you prefer the default animationSpec then there is no need to add this into your implementation!

With all of the above in place, weâ€™ve explored a collection of Compose APIs and constructed our own Video Player using existing Android View classes.

This serves as a great example of how we can mix the worlds of Jetpack Compose and the Android View system. While Jetpack Compose is likely to be our default for building apps, thereâ€™s going to be times when it feels more pragmatic to use solutions that already exist - and this is where the Jetpack Compose interoperability features will come in handy. ExoPlayer is a great example of this, where we can use things such as the AndroidView to plug the media implementation directly into our Composable UI.

Youâ€™ll likely encounter similar scenarios in the application that youâ€™re building. Whether itâ€™s ExoPlayer, Google Maps or your own existing UI components - be sure to explore the interoperability APIs that you can re-use existing components and continue delivering value to your users!

Testing the Video Player UI

Now that weâ€™ve built our Video player, weâ€™re going to take a look at how we can write tests for our composables. Weâ€™re going to be writing some instrumentation tests using the compose ui-test-junit package - allowing us to verify that our composables are displayed and functioning as expected.

Before we can get started with our tests, weâ€™re going to need to add a couple of test specific dependencies to our project:

androidTestImplementation "androidx.compose.ui:ui-test-junit4:$compose_version"
debugImplementation("androidx.compose.ui:ui-test-manifest:$compose_version")

Weâ€™re also going to need to add mocks to our test - this allows us to easily provide mock references to any listeners that are provided to our composable functions, allowing us to easily verify they are triggered whenever expected.

androidTestImplementation(
	"org.mockito.kotlin:mockito-kotlin:3.2.0")
androidTestImplementation("org.mockito:mockito-android:3.12.4")

With these in place, we now have access to the required rules and functionality that allow us to test our composable UI. However, alongside these dependencies, weâ€™re also going to need to add some rules to our build.gradle file that will fix some of the compilation errors that weâ€™d currently see when trying to run our tests. Here weâ€™ll add some packagingOptions that will exclude certain packages from the added dependencies. We wonâ€™t dive too much into this concept and itâ€™s usually dependant on the versions of dependencies that are being used, so this may be redundant if you come to updating versions.

android {
	packagingOptions {
		exclude "**/attach_hotspot_windows.dll"
		exclude "META-INF/AL2.0"
		exclude "META-INF/LGPL2.1"
		exclude "META-INF/licenses/ASM"
	}
}

Setting up the test class

Weâ€™ll start here by creating a new class, ControlsTest - this class will be used to contain the different tests that weâ€™re going to write.

class ControlsTest {

}

Inside of this class, we now need to define a reference to the ComposeContentTestRule class - this is what weâ€™re going to use to set the composable content on screen, allowing us to perform interactions and assertions from within our tests. 

@get:Rule
val composeTestRule = createComposeRule()

When using this rule, we donâ€™t need to specify any form of activity for our composables to be launched in, the test rule will handle that for us. So using this rule we will set the composable content to be composed, the test will then launch a host activity which will be used to compose our provided content inside of.

Testing the Controls

Weâ€™re going to start by writing a collection of tests for the behaviour of the control bar. In the previous chapter, we defined a collection of behaviour that configures the control bar based on the conditions of our video player state, so we must assert this behaviour through tests.

Testing the controls disabled state

Before the video has loaded we mark the playback button within the control bar as disabled - this is done via the use of the PlayerStatus flag that is provided to the Controls composable. To test this logic weâ€™ll start by writing a new test function:

@Test
fun Player_Control_Not_Enabled_When_Video_Not_Ready() {

}

Inside of this test, weâ€™re going to need to start by setting the composable content that is to be displayed on screen for us to assert against. Here weâ€™ll use the test rule that we previously defined, along with its setContent function. This function takes a composable function as an argument, allowing us to define what is to be composed on screen for our tests. Because weâ€™re wanting to test the Controls Composable that we defined in the previous sections of this chapter, weâ€™ll go ahead and pass this composable function for this composable argument.

@Test
fun Player_Control_Not_Enabled_When_Video_Not_Ready() {
	composeTestRule.setContent {
		Controls(
			playerStatus = PlayerStatus.LOADING,
			togglePlayingState = { }
		)
	}
}

While we arenâ€™t yet performing any assertions, running this test will launch an activity that displays the content of our Controls composable. With this now being displayed, we can next perform the required assertions to ensure that the playback button is disabled within our composable UI. However, before we can locate the node with our composed UI weâ€™re going to need to add a tag that allows us to do so. This tag will allow us to locate this composable within our UI regardless of the current state that the button is in - because the button has dynamic content based on our state, this helps to simplify things a bit. Weâ€™ll go ahead here and define a new tag within a Tags.kt file:

// Tags.kt

object Tags {
	const val TAG_CONTROL_BUTTON = "TAG_CONTROL_BUTTON"
}

Weâ€™ll then need to jump back into the composable function for our Controls composable, assigning our new tag to the playback IconButton using the testTag modifier:

IconButton(
    modifier = Modifier.testTag(TAG_CONTROL_BUTTON)
	...
)

Now that our button is locatable via this tag we can go ahead and locate it within our tests. For this weâ€™re going to use the onNodeWithTag function - this allows us to locate a composable within our composed UI that matches the provided tag. Once a node has been located, we can perform assertions on it. In this case, we want to assert that the button is not currently enabled, so weâ€™ll utilise the assertIsNotEnabled function for this.

@Test
fun Player_Control_Not_Enabled_When_Video_Not_Ready() {
	composeTestRule.setContent {
		Controls(
			playerStatus = PlayerStatus.LOADING,
			togglePlayingState = { }
		)
	}

	composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(
    	TAG_CONTROL_BUTTON
    ).assertIsNotEnabled()
}

If we run this test, weâ€™ll be able to see that our Controls composable is composed, followed by the defined assertion being performed and passing.

Testing the controls enabled state

On the flip side of the previous test, weâ€™re next going to want to assert that the button is enabled when the PlayerStatus does not represent the loading state.

@Test
fun Player_Control_Enabled_When_Video_Ready() {
	
}

We could write a collection of tests here to cover each of the PlayerStatus values that should reflect the enabled state, but for simplicities sake, weâ€™ll just use the IDLE value. Weâ€™ll again go ahead and compose our UI using the Controls composable, providing the PlayerStatus.IDLE as the current status of the player.

@Test
fun Player_Control_Enabled_When_Video_Ready() {
	composeTestRule.setContent {
		Controls(
			playerStatus = PlayerStatus.IDLE,
			togglePlayingState = { }
		)
	}
}

We can then go ahead and use our defined tag to perform the assertion on our button. This time we want to assert that the button is enabled, so weâ€™ll do this using the assertIsEnabled function.

@Test
fun Player_Control_Enabled_When_Video_Ready() {
	composeTestRule.setContent {
 		Controls(
			playerStatus = PlayerStatus.IDLE,
			togglePlayingState = { }
		)
	}

	composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(
		TAG_CONTROL_BUTTON
	).assertIsEnabled()
}

With this test in place, our Controls composable will be displayed - reflecting an enabled state based on the provided PlayerStatus which is verified by the defined assertion in our test.

Testing the Pause control display

Aside from the enabled state changing based on the provided state, the actual content of the playback button will change based on the current PlayerStatus that is provided to our Controls composable. Weâ€™re going to want to write some tests for some of this behaviour, so weâ€™ll start with ensuring that the pause control is displayed when our video is playing. 

@Test
fun Pause_Control_Displayed_When_Playing() {

}

Weâ€™re going to need to compose some UI for our test, which we can do using the same approach in the previous tests. The only difference is that we want to provide the PlayerStatus using the PLAYING value, this will indicate to our Controls composable that the video is currently playing.

@Test
fun Pause_Control_Displayed_When_Playing() {
	composeTestRule.setContent {
		Controls(
			playerStatus = PlayerStatus.PLAYING,
			togglePlayingState = { }
		)
	}
}

If the video is playing, then the controls bar should show the playback control button as the Pause option, this is done visually using an Icon. The only thing is that this is difficult to test, as we canâ€™t perform the test assertion on a visual element within our composed UI. Going back to the implementation of the Icon, we provided a content description for the Icon based on the current PlayerStatus value:

val description = if (playerStatus ==
	PlayerStatus.PLAYING
) {
	stringResource(id = R.string.cd_pause)
} else stringResource(id = R.string.cd_play)

Icon(
	imageVector = icon,
	contentDescription = description
)

Because we have this content description in place, weâ€™re going to utilise this within our tests to locate the node that we want to perform an assertion against. For this we can utilise the onNodeWithContentDescription function on our test rule reference, allowing us to locate a node using the provided content description.

When calling this function we need to provide a content description in the form of a string. While in our composable we use the stringResource composable function, we canâ€™t quite do this in our tests. For this reason, weâ€™re going to access the context through our test instrumentation, retrieving a content description string using the provided resource ID.

InstrumentationRegistry.getInstrumentation()
	.targetContext.getString(R.string.cd_pause)

With this, we can now utilise the onNodeWithContentDescription function with our retrieved string reference, which will locate a node for us to perform assertions against. In this case, we want to assert that the node is in fact displayed, which we can do using the assertIsDisplayed function.

@Test
fun Pause_Control_Displayed_When_Playing() {
	composeTestRule.setContent {
		Controls(
			playerStatus = PlayerStatus.PLAYING,
			togglePlayingState = { }
		)
	}

	composeTestRule.onNodeWithContentDescription(
		InstrumentationRegistry.getInstrumentation()
			.targetContext.getString(R.string.cd_pause)
	).assertIsDisplayed()
}

When this test runs, Controls will be composed based on the provided PlayerStatus value. The tests then assert that the expected node is displayed, using the stated content description - which in this case validates that the Pause icon is displayed while our video playback represents the playing state.

Testing the Play control display

While the above test asserts that the Pause icon is displayed while our video is playing, weâ€™re going to want to test the opposite scenario of that - the Play icon being displayed when the video is Paused.

@Test
fun Play_Control_Displayed_When_Paused() {

}

Similar to our previous tests, weâ€™ll need to compose our Controls for test assertions to be performed. Because we are expecting the Play icon to be displayed when the Controls the in the Paused state, weâ€™re going to need to provide the PlayerStatus as PAUSED.

@Test
fun Play_Control_Displayed_When_Paused() {
	composeTestRule.setContent {
		Controls(
			playerStatus = PlayerStatus.PAUSED,
			togglePlayingState = { }
		)
	}
}

When testing that the Pause icon was displayed, we used the expected content description to assert that the UI was being composed as expected. In this scenario, we need to take the same approach, except this time we are expecting the content description for the play state to be in place. For this reason, weâ€™ll still use the onNodeWithContentDescription function to locate a node using the provided description, except this time using the content description for the play icon.

@Test
fun Play_Control_Displayed_When_Paused() {
	composeTestRule.setContent {
		Controls(
			playerStatus = PlayerStatus.PAUSED,
			togglePlayingState = { }
		)
	}

	composeTestRule.onNodeWithContentDescription(
		InstrumentationRegistry.getInstrumentation()
			.targetContext.getString(R.string.cd_play)
	).assertIsDisplayed()
}

With this in place, we assert that the node is displayed using the assertIsDisplayed function, validating that the Play icon is composed when our Controls represents the PAUSED state.

Testing the control state toggle

Aside from the visual composition of our Controls, there is also a key piece of behaviour that would be important to assert - the toggling of the player status when the playback button is clicked. When the playback button is clicked, an event is triggered and propagated to the parent composable - this is used to toggle the playback status of the video. If this wasnâ€™t working as expected, then weâ€™d have some pretty big problems with our video player - so weâ€™ll write a test to ensure that this event is triggered as expected.

@Test
fun Toggle_Play_State_Triggered() {

}

Weâ€™ll also need to compose some UI for our tests to perform assertions against.

@Test
fun Toggle_Play_State_Triggered() {
	composeTestRule.setContent {
		Controls(
			playerStatus = PlayerStatus.PAUSED,
			togglePlayingState = { }
		)
	}
}

Now, because we want to assert that the togglePlayingState callback is triggered as expected, weâ€™re going to need to provide an implementation for this. Although we havenâ€™t been providing a value for this Iâ€™m previous tests, we canâ€™t perform assertions that this function is triggered without providing an implementation for it. So here weâ€™re going to provide a mock implementation of this callback - allowing us to verify that it is triggered as expected.

@Test
fun Toggle_Play_State_Triggered() {
	val togglePlayingState: () -> Unit = mock()
	composeTestRule.setContent {
		Controls(
			playerStatus = PlayerStatus.PAUSED,
			togglePlayingState = togglePlayingState
		)
	}
}

As previously mentioned, this callback is triggered whenever the playback button in the Controls is clicked. Weâ€™re going to need to simulate this behaviour within our tests so that the callback is triggered - so weâ€™ll retrieve the node for the playback button using the tag that we previously defined, followed by using the performClick function to perform a click interaction on the node.

@Test
fun Toggled_Play_State_Triggered() {
	val togglePlayingState: () -> Unit = mock()
	composeTestRule.setContent {
		Controls(
			playerStatus = PlayerStatus.PAUSED,
			togglePlayingState = togglePlayingState
		)
	}
	composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(
		TAG_CONTROL_BUTTON
	).performClick()
}

When this interaction takes place, it would be expected that our togglePlayingState callback is triggered - if itâ€™s not, then it would mean that our playback button isnâ€™t quite working as expected. We have a mock implementation of this callback in place, so we can use this to verify interactions.

For this weâ€™re going to utilise the mockito verify functionality - this allows us to assert that our callback has been triggered within the scope of our test.

@Test
fun Toggled_Play_State_Triggered() {
	val togglePlayingState: () -> Unit = mock()
	composeTestRule.setContent {
		Controls(
			playerStatus = PlayerStatus.PAUSED,
			togglePlayingState = togglePlayingState
		)
	}
	composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(
		TAG_CONTROL_BUTTON
	).performClick()

	verify(togglePlayingState).invoke()
}

Here this verify block will assert that our callback is invoked a single time. If this callback is not invoked, or if it is invoked multiple times from the single click event, then the test will fail. Otherwise, the test will be marked as a success as the callback will be triggered from the click event as expected.

Testing the Player

Now that we have tests in place for our Controls composable, weâ€™re going to need to write some tests for the top-level video player composable. This allows us to perform assertions to ensure that both the video player and controls are displayed on the screen as expected.

Weâ€™ll go ahead and start by creating a new test class, VideoTest, along with defining the test rule that will be used to launch our test composable and perform assertions against it.

// VideoTest.kt

class VideoTest {

	@get:Rule
	val composeTestRule = createComposeRule()

}

What we want to do in these tests is locate the nodes within our composable hierarchy that represent the controls and player, followed by asserting that they are displayed. So that we do this, weâ€™ll need to add some more tags that can be assigned to these composables.

// Tags.kt

object Tags {
    const val TAG_VIDEO_PLAYER = "TAG_VIDEO_PLAYER"
    const val TAG_CONTROLS = "TAG_CONTROLS"
}

In our first test, weâ€™re going to assert that the controls are being composed inside of our Video, so weâ€™ll need to start by assigning the TAG_CONTROLS tag to the parent container inside of the Controls composable.

// Controls.kt

Box(
	modifier = modifier
        .fillMaxWidth()
        .background(MaterialTheme.colors.surface)
        .testTag(TAG_CONTROLS),
    contentAlignment = Alignment.Center
)

With this tag in place, we can now locate the node that represents the controls using onNodeWithTag, followed by asserting that it is displayed on the screen using assertIsDisplayed.

@Test
fun Player_Controls_Displayed_By_Default() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        Video()
    }
    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(
        TAG_CONTROLS
    ).assertIsDisplayed()
}

For the next test, weâ€™re going to take a similar approach, asserting that the video player is displayed. Weâ€™ll need to start by adding the tag to the Playback composable - we can assign this via the modifier that is passed into this composable within the VideoPlayer composable.

// VideoPlayer.kt

Playback(
	Modifier
    	.fillMaxSize()
        .clickable(
        	onClickLabel = stringResource(
				id = controlsClickLabel)
        ) {
        	controlsVisible = !controlsVisible
        }
        .testTag(TAG_VIDEO_PLAYER),
    videoState.playerStatus, context, exoPlayer
)

Now that this tag is being assigned to our composable, we can take the same approach as the previous test. Here weâ€™ll use the TAG_VIDEO_PLAYER tag to locate the node, followed by asserting its visibility via the assertIsDisplayed function.

@Test
fun Video_Player_Is_Displayed() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        Video()
    }
    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(
        TAG_VIDEO_PLAYER
    ).assertIsDisplayed()
}

With all of these tests in place, weâ€™ve covered a lot of different cases that help to ensure our UI is working as expected. Weâ€™ve not only tested that composables are being composed based on the information that they are provided with, but also that they triggered the expected callbacks and trigger state manipulations within our composables. While the tests here arenâ€™t extensive, weâ€™ve been able to learn not only what options are available to us while testing composables, but also the approaches that we can take when doing so.

Building a Messaging UI

Messaging is a feature that we see in many applications - whether itâ€™s SMS apps, social media apps or any other kind of conversational tool, messaging provides ways for our users to communicate with one another. These types of UIs tend to have a lot of consistent features across them, providing an interesting implementation for us to tackle with Jetpack Compose. Not only do we need to think about the different types of messages that are being rendered on screen, but also provide support for the user to compose messages to be sent via the messaging feature.

With this in mind, weâ€™re going to build out a messaging feature using jetpack compose. Weâ€™ll not only display the different types of text/image messages from a conversation but also allow the user to send messages to be added to the conversation. Building this will give us a space to think about the different constraints that are involved when it comes to building a messaging UI, while also giving us some intricate logic to implement when it comes to specific messaging features (such as @ mentioning contacts).

When it comes to this screen, we need to configure and handle several different things.

  • Build out a list that supports the display of messages
  • Separate these messages by sent date via the use of sticky headers
  • Handle the state when there are no messages that exist in a conversation
  • Support both text and image message formats
  • Add clarity around message information, making it clear what is a sent/received message as well as allowing the sent time of a message to be revealed
  • Allow the user to compose messages to be added to the conversation
  • Allow the user to unsend messages that they have sent in the conversation
  • Support @ mentions so that users in the conversation can be tagged, while also supporting the highlighting of these tags within the UI
  • Ensure that all of the above features remain accessible for all users of our messaging application, specifically via the use of accessibility services

We can see here that thereâ€™s a collection of things here that weâ€™re going to want to tackle. Donâ€™t worry though, weâ€™ll approach this incrementally so that we will start with a functional messaging app, building out its feature set piece by piece to add value for our users. With all this in mind, letâ€™s get started with building out our messaging app!

Defining the Messaging State

Within our messaging screen, weâ€™re going to be displaying a list of grouped message items - each item will be used to represent the contents of a message item, with there being some similarities between how each is composed. While each of these items is going to be used to represent the messages from a conversation, the state of our screen is going to be made up of several different variables.

  • A list of items that represent that messages within the conversation
  • The list of contacts that are available to the user for tagging
  • The currently selected message within the conversation, if any

While there are going to be a few different things to build out in the UI, there isnâ€™t too much state for us to model at this point. Letâ€™s start to take the above requirements and build out a class that will represent the state of our composable UI. Weâ€™ll start by creating a new class to hold the state of our screen:

data class ConversationState()

Modelling Messages

With our messaging screen, weâ€™re going to be displaying a list of messages - each item will represent the same message UI component but will be tailored to the message that is being represented. Weâ€™re going to start here by creating a new class, Message, that will be used to hold the various pieces of information for a message item.

data class Message(
    val id: String,
    val direction: MessageDirection,
    val dateTime: Calendar,
    val sender: String,
    val message: String? = null,
    @DrawableRes val image: Int? = null,
    val altText: String? = null
)

We can see here that various fields are going to be holding information around any given message

  • id: the unique ID belonging to the message item
  • dateTime: the time which the message was sent
  • sender: the name of the contact that sent the message
  • message: the textual content of the message, if any
  • image: the image content of the message, if any
  • altText: the content description for describing the image

ðŸ’¡ In a real application youâ€™d likely use some form or URL or URI for an image - to keep the project focused, weâ€™re using a drawable resource here. This allows us to focus on some of the aspects involved with image loading within another project of the book.

We can see from this that there is sufficient information for us to be able to build out the content for each of the message items. When it comes to the representation of a message within our UI itâ€™ll also be helpful to know whether the message was received or sent. To define this within our Message weâ€™re going to create a new enum that will allow us to define the supported message directions to be used by a Message.

enum class MessageDirection {
    RECEIVED, SENT
}

With this in place, we can now slot this into our Message class.

data class Message(
    val id: String,
    val direction: MessageDirection,
    val dateTime: Calendar,
    val sender: String,
    val message: String? = null,
    @DrawableRes val image: Int? = null,
    val altText: String? = null
)

Now that the Message class is defined, we can go ahead and add a list of Message items to the state class that we defined earlier.

data class ConversationState(
    val messages: List<Message> = emptyList()
)

For this project, weâ€™re not going to focus too much on the different states of the screen (empty, error, content etc). Weâ€™re also going to want to have a collection of messages to be displayed in our UI - we donâ€™t have any form of web resource that we can query here (or want to implement that), so weâ€™re going to create a factory class that will build a list of Message items. Feel free to structure the content of these how you like, or simply copy this over from the sample project.

object MessageFactory {

    fun makeMessages(): List<Message> {
        return listOf(
            Message(
                "0",
                MessageDirection.SENT,
                Calendar.getInstance().also {
                    it.add(Calendar.DAY_OF_YEAR, -5)
                    it.set(Calendar.HOUR_OF_DAY, 5)
                },
                "Joe Birch",
                "Hey!"
            ),
            Message(
                "1",
                MessageDirection.RECEIVED,
                Calendar.getInstance().also {
                    it.add(Calendar.DAY_OF_YEAR, -5)
                    it.set(Calendar.HOUR_OF_DAY, 5)
                },
                "Joe Birch",
                "Hey!"
            ),
            Message(
                "2",
                MessageDirection.RECEIVED,
                Calendar.getInstance().also {
                    it.add(Calendar.DAY_OF_YEAR, -4)
                    it.set(Calendar.HOUR_OF_DAY, 4)
                },
                "Joe Birch",
                "How is Roxy? ðŸ˜Š"
            ),
            Message(
                "4",
                MessageDirection.SENT,
                Calendar.getInstance().also {
                    it.add(Calendar.DAY_OF_YEAR, -2)
                },
                "Joe Birch",
                "She is doing great!"
            ),
            Message(
                "5",
                MessageDirection.SENT,
                Calendar.getInstance().also {
                    it.add(Calendar.DAY_OF_YEAR, -2)
                },
                "Joe Birch",
                image = R.drawable.roxy
            )
        )
    }

}

ðŸ’¡ For the image resource of the last message, youâ€™ll find this over in the sample project drawable directory.

We can then use this factory directly within our state class, allowing a list of messages to be populated by default.

data class ConversationState(
    val messages: List<Message> = MessageFactory.makeMessages()
)

Modelling Contacts

Aside from the messages that represent the current state of the screen, we also want access to the contacts which the user has access - this is what will be used for the contact tagging functionality within the messaging feature. Weâ€™ll start here by creating a new class, Contact. This will hold a single field in the form of a contact name.

class Contact(
    val name: String
)

Similar to our Message items, weâ€™re going to want to have a list of contacts available for us to model our UI from. For this, weâ€™ll create another factory that will be used to generate a list of Contact items for us to plug into our state.

object ContactFactory {

    fun makeContacts(): List<Contact> {
        return listOf(
            Contact("Joe"),
            Contact("Ellie"),
            Contact("Anna"),
            Contact("Rachel"),
            Contact("Ross"),
            Contact("Mark"),
            Contact("Jake")
        )
    }
}

Weâ€™ll then use this to generate a list of Contact items for the contacts data within our state class.

data class ConversationState(
    val messages: List<Message> = MessageFactory.makeMessages(),
    val contacts: List<Contact> = 
		ContactFactory.makeContacts()
)

Modelling the Selected Message

When it comes to the various messaging features, one of the things weâ€™ll be supporting is the deletion of a message. This means that the user will need to be able to select a message so that we can display a collection of options for it. Weâ€™re going to make this a part of our global state, as these options are going to be something that blocks the current UI until the user decides to either execute an action (or dismiss the options). For this we can add a new field to our state, selectedMessage, which will represent the currently selected message from a conversation (if any).

data class ConversationState(
    val messages: List<Message> = 	
		MessageFactory.makeMessages(),
    val contacts: List<Contact> = 
		ContactFactory.makeContacts(),
    val selectedMessage: Message? = null
)

With this in place, we now support the selecting of a Message to execute an action. When the message is unselected, this state item can be marked as null to represent that there is no longer a selected message in the list.

With all of this in place, we now have a class that can be used to represent the state of our UI. Over the next few sections of this chapter, weâ€™ll utilise this state when building out our UI, modifying its values as interactions with composables take place, triggering recompositions to reflect any state changes.

Creating the Messaging ViewModel

Now that we have the state modelled for our Messaging screen, we can start thinking about the ViewModel that will be used to manage that state and provide a way to orchestrate it to the user interface.

Setting up the ViewModel

Before we can get started here, weâ€™re going to add a new dependency to our project that will give us access to the Android Lifecycle ViewModel class:

implementation "androidx.lifecycle:lifecycle-viewmodel-compose:2.4.0"

ðŸ’¡ You arenâ€™t required to use a ViewModel when working with compose. For the sake of these exercises, it helps us to keep things simple and follow an approach that many developers are familiar with.

Next, weâ€™ll create a new ViewModel, called ConversationViewModel.

class ConversationViewModel : ViewModel() {

}

This ViewModel is going to need to hold a reference to the state of our screen. For this weâ€™re going to utilise StateFlow - this allows us to create a state-holder observable flow that will emit the default state we provide to it, along with any updates that occur during its lifetime. Here weâ€™ll create a new MutableStateFlow instance, providing a reference to our ConversationState class as the default value for our StateFlow:

class ConversationViewModel : ViewModel() {

	val uiState = MutableStateFlow(ConversationState())

}

With this in place, we now have a StateFlow reference that is holding a reference to our authentication state, initialising it with a new instance of the state class and relying on the defaults that the constructor provides.

Manipulating state using events

While this state is now in place, we need to start thinking about the different ways in which it can be manipulated - whenever something is changed in our UI (message sent, message removed etc), weâ€™ll want to update the state within our ViewModel so that the observing UI can reflect those changes.

For when this is the case, weâ€™re going to model some events that can be triggered in our composable UI and in turn these events will be used to manipulate the state within the view model. This allows us to have a single way of our composable UI communicating with the ViewModel, rather than needing to pass the entire ViewModel or many references to separate functions which could be used to trigger state changes. Instead, we can pass a single function reference to our composable UI which can then be used to trigger these events in the ViewModel. For these events weâ€™re going to need to define different types that can be triggered, so weâ€™ll go ahead and create a new sealed class to represent these.

// ConversationEvent.kt
sealed class ConversationEvent {

}

Handling message sending

With this sealed class in place, we can start to think about using it to represent the different events that can occur. Weâ€™re going to start by handling the scenario where the user sends a message - weâ€™ll call this event SendMessage, declaring a message argument to be used for the content of the message.

sealed class ConversationEvent {

    data class SendMessage(val message: String) : 	
		ConversationEvent()

}

With this event in place, this can now be triggered from our composable UI to cause a state change within our view model. For that to happen though, we need to write this logic inside of our ViewModel. When a message is to be sent, weâ€™re going to want to create a new instance of the Message class that represents the data that has been provided. Weâ€™ll create a new function called buildMessage which will be used to build out our Message reference:

  • id: for the ID weâ€™ll simply use the number of messages in our list, this means that the ID will incrementally increase every time a message is sent
  • direction: because we are sending a message, the direction, in this case, will always be SENT
  • dateTime: for the sent time of the message, weâ€™ll fetch the current representation of time using the Calendar class to use the time from
  • sender: because we are sending a message, this is always going to represent the current user. So for this, weâ€™ll simply send â€œmeâ€
  • message: for the message content we are going to pass the message argument that is provided to our function
  • image: we are not going to be supporting the sending of image messages, so we donâ€™t send a value for this
  • altText: we are not going to be supporting the sending of image messages, so we donâ€™t send a value for this
private fun buildMessage(message: String): Message {
	return Message(
		uiState.value.messages.count().toString(),
		MessageDirection.SENT, 
		Calendar.getInstance(), 
		"me",
		message
	)
}

With this function in place, weâ€™re going to use this to create a Message to be added to the list of messages. In a real scenario, we would be sending this data to an API, so weâ€™re going to need to model this message list modification ourselves. Here weâ€™ll want to take the current list of messages, convert the list to a mutable list so that we can modify its contents, add the result of our buildMessage as an item of this list, followed by converting the list back to an immutable list. With this in place, we can now update the state of our screen, creating a modified version of the existing state using the kotlin copy function.

fun handleEvent(authenticationEvent: ConversationEvent) {
	when (authenticationEvent) {
		is ConversationEvent.SendMessage -> {
                uiState.value = uiState.value.copy(
                    messages = uiState.value.messages
						.toMutableList().apply {
                        	add(buildMessage(
								authenticationEvent.message))
                    }.toList()
                )
            }
	}
}

private fun buildMessage(message: String): Message {
	return Message(
		uiState.value.messages.count().toString(),
		MessageDirection.SENT, 
		Calendar.getInstance(), 
		"me",
		message
	)
}

ðŸ’¡ The copy function in Kotlin copies the existing class reference, replacing any values that have been provided as arguments to the function.

Handling message unsending

As well as having the ability to send a message, weâ€™re also going to allow a user to unsend any messages that they have sent. To support this weâ€™re going to add a new event, UnsendMessage. This is going to need to allow an id to be provided, which represents the id of the message that is being unsent.

sealed class ConversationEvent {

    data class SendMessage(val message: String) : 	
		ConversationEvent()

    class UnsendMessage(val id: String) : ConversationEvent()

}

When a message is unsent, weâ€™re going to want to remove it from the list of messages that is currently in our state. Again, this would be handled by an API in the real world, but weâ€™re going to need to model this ourselves. What weâ€™ll do here is take a similar approach as we did for sending a message, but instead we will need to remove the item whose id matches the specified id. We can do this by locating the index of the first item that satisfies those conditions, using the indexOfFirst kotlin function. This will give us the index of the first item that matches our check, which we can then use for the removeAt function to remove the item from the list.

private fun messagesExcluding(id: String): List<Message> {
	return uiState.value.messages
		.toMutableList().apply {
			removeAt(
				uiState.value.messages.indexOfFirst {
					it.id == authenticationEvent.id
				}
			)
		}.toList()
}

With this function in place, we can now hook this up to the UnsendMessage event. For this, weâ€™ll want to use our messagesExcluding function to create the new list of messages based on the removal, followed by updating the messages value in our state with the result.

fun handleEvent(authenticationEvent: ConversationEvent) {
	when (authenticationEvent) {
		...,
		is ConversationEvent.UnsendMessage -> {
                uiState.value = uiState.value.copy(
                    messages = messagesExcluding(
						authenticationEvent.id)
                )
            }
	}
}

Handling message selection

Alongside the sending and unsending of messages, weâ€™ll also need to add support for message selection via the ConversationEvent. This is so that a message can be selected and the options for that message can be invoked, which will allow the user to trigger the UnsendMessage event that we previously modelled. To select a message, weâ€™ll need to know the id of the message being selected - weâ€™ll allow this to be provided through a new SelectMessage event.

sealed class ConversationEvent {

    class UnsendMessage(val id: String) : ConversationEvent()

    data class SendMessage(val message: String) : 	
		ConversationEvent()

	class SelectMessage(val id: String) : ConversationEvent()
}

Weâ€™ll then want to handle this event inside of our handleEvent function. For this, weâ€™ll want to set the corresponding message as the selectedMessage within our state. For this, weâ€™ll use the existing list of messages to find the corresponding message whose id matches the one provided through the event. Once this is found, the result (which is the corresponding Message) will be assigned to the selectedMessage in our state.

fun handleEvent(authenticationEvent: ConversationEvent) {
	when (authenticationEvent) {
		...,
		is ConversationEvent.SelectMessage -> {
			uiState.value = uiState.value.copy(
				selectedMessage = uiState.value.messages.find { it.id == authenticationEvent.id }
            )
        }
	}
}

Handling message unselection

Because a message can be selected, weâ€™ll also need to support a message being unselected. When a message is selected, a dialog of options will be shown on the screen, this will be shown based on there being a selectedMessage value in the state. Weâ€™ll create a new UnselectMessage event type that can then be used to clear the selected message so that the dialog can be hidden.

sealed class ConversationEvent {

    class UnsendMessage(val id: String) : ConversationEvent()

    data class SendMessage(val message: String) : 	
		ConversationEvent()

	class SelectMessage(val id: String) : ConversationEvent()

    object UnselectMessage : ConversationEvent()
}

Then within our handleEvent function, weâ€™re going to want to handle this UnselectMessage event type. Within this block, weâ€™ll want to update our state so that there is no longer a selected message - which can be done by assigning a null value to the selectedMessage field.

fun handleEvent(authenticationEvent: ConversationEvent) {
	when (authenticationEvent) {
		...,
		is ConversationEvent.UnselectMessage -> {
            uiState.value = uiState.value.copy(
                selectedMessage = null
            )
        }
	}
}

With this implemented, we are now managing the state of our messaging screen and providing the required entry points for our UI layer to manipulate the state based on user interaction. Our view model is now ready to be plugged into a composable UI, which weâ€™ll create in the next section of this chapter!

Creating the Messaging UI

With the view model and state management all in place, weâ€™re ready to move on and start implementing the composable UI for our Messaging app.

When weâ€™re finished building this UI, weâ€™re going to end up with something that looks like the following:

This UI will give our users a screen that displays a list of pre-existing messages, grouped by sticky date headers - the user will also be able to send messages to be added to that list. Building this UI will allow us to work with a range of compose features while adding some subtle niceties to the UI in the process.

Setting up the entry point

Before we can get start building our project, weâ€™re going to need to add a couple of dependencies that weâ€™re going to need. Weâ€™ll start here by adding these to the build.gradle file for our new project:

implementation 
	"androidx.compose.foundation:foundation:$compose_version"
implementation "androidx.compose.ui:ui:$compose_version"
implementation 
	"androidx.compose.material:material:$compose_version"
implementation 
	"androidx.compose.material:material-icons-extended:$compose_version"
implementation "androidx.lifecycle:lifecycle-viewmodel-compose:2.4.0"

The current release of this book is building against 1.1.0 of compose - be sure to check compatibly if using a newer version.

  • foundation: provides foundational composables, such as layouts and commonly required modifiers
  • ui: provides access to ui related composables, such as drawing and general components
  • material: provides access to compose material UI components
  • material-icons-extended: provides access to an extended collection of iconography
  • lifecycle-viewmodel-compose: provides functionality for providing view models directly inside of composables

With these added to our project, weâ€™re now ready to start building out our UI. Weâ€™re going to start here by building the access point to our feature - this is how the messaging feature will initially be composed within our user interface. To make this an argument-less access point, weâ€™re going to start with a new composable function, Messaging.

// Messaging.kt

@Composable
fun Messaging()

While you wonâ€™t see anything visual just yet, youâ€™ll want to compose this Messaging composable within the setContent block of the activity that was created through the project wizard. Then as we build out the project, weâ€™ll be able to visualise the Messaging when running the project.

Before we get started with any composition of messaging specific UI, weâ€™re going to start by declaring the use of the MaterialTheme composable, this will be in place ready to wrap any composition and apply the expected material theming to our project. This isnâ€™t a requirement, but if not provided then you would need to manually style each composable to adhere to material requirements. Weâ€™re not going to be doing any theme customisation here, so this will be using the default colors.

// Messaging.kt

@Composable
fun Messaging() {
    MaterialTheme {
        ...
    }
}

We can see here that we currently have a blank content block, this means that nothing is currently going to be composed in our UI. A mentioned previously, this is just an argument-less entry point to our feature, but weâ€™re going to need access to the state configuration that we set up over the last few chapters. Here, weâ€™re going to utilise the ViewModel related dependency that we added to our project. Using its viewModel() function, weâ€™ll go ahead and retrieve an instance of the ConversationViewModel. This will return an existing reference to the ViewModel, creating a new one if it does not currently exist.

// Messaging.kt

@Composable
fun Messaging() {
    val viewModel: ConversationViewModel = viewModel()
    MaterialTheme {
        ...
    }
}

With this in place, we have our ViewModel, as well as access to our state through this ViewModel. Now though, we need to set ourselves up to be able to compose UI based on this state. Here weâ€™re going to create a separate composable function that takes the ConversationState class, composing UI from it.

// Conversation.kt

@Composable
fun Conversation(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    state: ConversationState
)

ðŸ’¡ Declaring a Modifier argument for your composable functions allows the layout constraints of the composable to be delegated to the parent. This helps to keep your composables reusable, as they are not being constrained for a specific scenario.

Not only does having this separate composable keep the responsibilities of our composable functions smaller, but it also will help us with testing later on. Having this separate Conversation composable with a ConversationState argument means that we can provide state within our tests, perform asserts based on the expected composition from our state. Testing against an argument-less composable function would require us to interact with the UI to manipulate the state, which adds friction during the testing process.

Now that we have this composable in place, weâ€™re ready to compose this inside of our Messaging composable. We can provide two arguments to our Conversation - modifier and state, which the second is required. For the modifier, weâ€™ll simply utilise the fillMaxSize modifier - which will instruct the contained composable to use all of the size that it has available to it.

Weâ€™ll also need to provide a reference to a ConversationState, which weâ€™ll access through our ConversationViewModel. Here weâ€™re going to use the collectAsState() - because our state is represented within our ViewModel as a StateFlow, weâ€™re going to want to collect the events from here. collectAsState() allows us to collect the emissions from our StateFlow as composable state, meaning that our composables can be recomposed accordingly whenever the state is changed. Weâ€™ll need to access the value from theStateFlow and pass this directly to the state argument of our Conversation composable.

@Composable
fun Messaging() {
    val viewModel: ConversationViewModel = viewModel()
    MaterialTheme {
        Conversation(
            modifier = Modifier.fillMaxSize(),
            state = viewModel.uiState.collectAsState().value
        )
    }
}

At this point, we wonâ€™t be able to see anything being composed within our UI, but weâ€™re all set up ready to start building out our messaging interface.

Setting up the Conversation feed

Now that we have our Conversation being composed at the root of our Messaging screen, we can start to think about building out the composables that are going to make up the different parts of our conversational UI. Within this UI weâ€™re going to display a vertical stack of composables, so weâ€™re going to start here by composing a Column, passing the Modifier that has been provided to our composable function. 

@Composable
fun Conversation(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    state: ConversationState
) {
    Column(
        modifier = modifier,
    ) {
        
    }
}

From within our Messaging composable we are passing the fillMaxWidth() modifier, meaning that our Conversation is going to fill all of the available space both horizontally and vertically.

Because weâ€™re using a Column, any children that we compose within the content area are going to be stacked horizontally. Letâ€™s start by taking a look at the first child weâ€™ll compose here.

Creating a header for our screen

Weâ€™re going to be adding an app bar to our screen in the form of a TopAppBar. While it would be more than OK to do so, wonâ€™t be using the Scaffold composable here - we donâ€™t have much of a need for the other functionality that compose offers, so weâ€™ll just rely on this being composed as the first child of our Column for now. We will also be exploring some animations later in this chapter, so relying on our own parent container implementation will make this simpler.

Weâ€™ll start here by defining a new composable that will house our app bar, Header, which will take Modifier and provide the default Modifier if one is not provided.

@Composable
fun Header(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier
)

Next, weâ€™re going to compose a TopAppBar inside of our composable function, using the Modifier argument from our composable as the modifier for this app bar.

@Composable
fun Header(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier
) {
    TopAppBar(
        modifier = modifier
    ) {
       
    }
}

ðŸ’¡ The TopAppBar provides us with an App Bar implementation for displaying key information and actions for the current context of the screen.

From this app bar weâ€™re going to be displaying two things:

  • A close icon that will exit the messaging app
  • A title that will represent the current conversation name (this will be static for examples sake)

Weâ€™ll start here with the close icon, which weâ€™ll need to add a content description for to our strings.xml file.

<string name="cd_close_conversation">
	Close Conversation
</string>

ðŸ’¡Content Descriptions allow us to provide a textual description for visual elements, used by accessibility services to provide additional context to users.

With this content description in place, we can add the composable that will both house the close icon, as well as provide the click functionality for closing the messaging screen. For this weâ€™re going to utilise the IconButton composable, this allows us to use built-in button support in the form of an icon. Weâ€™ll start here by providing a composable for the content of our IconButton, composing an Icon. Weâ€™ll use the Icons.Default.Close icon from the material package, along with setting the content description by retrieving the string resource we defined above via the stringResource composable function.

@Composable
fun Header(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier
) {
    TopAppBar(
        modifier = modifier
    ) {
        IconButton(onClick = {

        }) {
            Icon(
                imageVector = Icons.Default.Close,
                contentDescription = stringResource(
					id = R.string.cd_close_conversation)
            )
        }
    }
}

ðŸ’¡The IconButton allows us to provide clickable icons that adhere to minimum sizing constraints for intractable components, making them fully accessible for our users.

With the above in place, weâ€™ll also want to provide functionality for the onClick argument of our IconButton. Weâ€™ll want to pass this event up to the parent composable to be handled, so weâ€™ll pass in a lambda function to our Header composable.

@Composable
fun Header(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    onClose: () -> Unit
)

With this lambda function now in place, we can trigger this within the implementation of the IconButton onClick.

@Composable
fun Header(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier
) {
    TopAppBar(
        modifier = modifier.testTag(TAG_HEADER)
    ) {
        IconButton(onClick = {
            onClose()
        }) {
            Icon(
                imageVector = Icons.Default.Close,
                contentDescription = stringResource(
					id = R.string.cd_close_conversation)
            )
        }
    }
}

With this in place, we now have a TopAppBar implementation that is displaying a close icon at the start.

The icon alone leaves our app bar feeling kind of empty, so weâ€™re going to go ahead and add a title. Ideally, this would be a dynamic value that is provided by the current conversations, but for our project, weâ€™ll need to add a new string resource to represent this title.

<string name="title_chat">Group Chat</string>

With this resource in place, we can now compose this using the Text composable. Weâ€™ll again use the stringResource composable function to retrieve the string value from our resources to provide for the text argument, along with setting the size of this text using the fontSize argument, providing a value of 18.sp.

@Composable
fun Header(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    onClose: () -> Unit
) {
    TopAppBar(
        modifier = modifier
    ) {
        IconButton(onClick = {
            onClose()
        }) {
            Icon(
                imageVector = Icons.Default.Close,
                contentDescription = stringResource(
					id = R.string.cd_close_conversation)
            )
        }
        Text(
			text = stringResource(
				id = R.string.title_chat), 
			fontSize = 18.sp
		)
    }
}

Now that weâ€™ve completed the implementation of our Header composable, we just need to compose this within our UI. Weâ€™ll add this as a child of our column, passing the fillMaxWidth modifier so that our app bar fills the available width. For now, we wonâ€™t be implementing the closing of our messaging feature, so weâ€™ll leave this implementation blank for now.

@Composable
fun Conversation(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    state: ConversationState,
    handleEvent: (event: ConversationEvent) -> Unit
) {
    Column(
        modifier = modifier
    ) {
        Header(
            modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
            onClose = {
                // close messaging app
            }
        )
    }
}

With this Header now being composed in our UI, we can see an app bar implementation at the top of our screen, displaying the name of the current conversation.

Displaying Messages

Now that our header is being displayed, weâ€™re going to want to show the key part of our messaging feature - the message list! For our messaging list, weâ€™re going to need to build up a collection of different components:

  • An empty state that will be used when there are no messages
  • The list that will be used to display a collection of messages
  • The items that make up the messages within the list
  • Sticky headers that will be used to group messages by date

In order to build all of the above, weâ€™ll need to start by building out the composable that will be used to house all of the above, Messages. This is going to take a modifier argument, along with a list of Message instances - this will also be a nullable type, as there may not always be messages available to display.

@Composable
fun Messages(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    messages: List<Message>? = null
) {

}

Handling the Empty State

As mentioned above, we marked the messages argument as nullable. Aside from being null, this list of Message types could also be empty - in either of these scenarios, were going to want to display some form of empty state to the user. This is going to be a simple composable that displays a message to the user that there are no messages to display on the screen. Weâ€™ll add a string resource to our strings.xml file that will be used to represent this message.

<string name="label_no_messages">
	No messages to display
</string>

We can then create a new composable that will be used to represent our empty state. Weâ€™ll call this EmptyConversaton and again allow for a Modifier to be provided to the composable.

@Composable
fun EmptyConversation(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier
)

Weâ€™ll then use a Box composable as the container for the content of this empty view. We previously used the Column that is used to stack children vertically - when it comes to the Box composable, children are stacked on the z-axis which can allow for children to overlap. When working with single child containers, the Box is a great unsettled container.

Inside of this Box, weâ€™re going to place a single child composable in the form of a Text composable. For this weâ€™ll simply provide a value for the text argument, retrieving the string resource that we previously defined using the stringResource function.

@Composable
fun EmptyConversation(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier
) {
    Box(modifier = modifier) {
        Text(text = stringResource(
			id = R.string.label_no_messages))
    }
}

With this composable created, we now have a UI component that can be used to represent an empty state within our messaging UI.

The last thing left to do here is to compose this within our Messages composable. Weâ€™ll only want to do this when our messages reference is either null or empty, so weâ€™ll wrap the composition of this composable in an if check that will perform this conditional check.

@Composable
fun Messages(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    messages: List<Message>? = null
) {
    if (messages.isNullOrEmpty()) {
        EmptyConversation(
            modifier = Modifier.fillMaxSize()
        )
    }
}

When this is conditional check is satisfied, the EmptyConversation will be composed, otherwise, our Messages composable will display as blank.

Displaying message items

At this point we have our empty state being composed when required, but what about when we have messages to display? If the conditional check for null or empty messages is not satisfied, then weâ€™re going to want to compose the list of messages.

@Composable
fun Messages(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    messages: List<Message>? = null
) {
    if (messages.isNullOrEmpty()) {
        EmptyConversation(
            modifier = Modifier.fillMaxSize()
        )
    } else {
		// display messages
	}
}

At this point, weâ€™re going to focus on just displaying a list of messages with no further decorations or heading, but thereâ€™s going to be a couple of things that weâ€™re going to need to build this out. Essentially, weâ€™ll need to build a Message composable that takes a Message reference and composes the content of it - this could contain either text or an image for the message comment, as well as the time at which the message was received. Weâ€™ll need to start here by defining a new composable function, Message, that takes a Modifier as well as a Message to be used for composition.

@Composable
fun Message(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    message: Message
)

Our message is going to initially consist of two child composables - the body of the message (which will be either the text or an image), along with the time that the message was received. Weâ€™re going to want to stack these vertically, displaying the received time underneath the body of the message.

With those requirements, weâ€™ll need to use the Column composable, passing the modifier that was provided to our composable function.

@Composable
fun Message(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    message: Message
) {
    Column(modifier = modifier) {

    }
}

Creating the Message Body composable

Inside of this Message composable weâ€™re going to what to compose the body of the provided Message instances. This is going to contain a bit of conditional logic, so to help keep things a little tidier here weâ€™re going to split this out into a separate composable function, MessageBody.

@Composable
fun MessageBody(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    message: Message
)

Again, we allow a Modifier to be provided here to apply some constraints to the MessageBody, as well as providing the Message that we want to compose the body for. Inside of this composable function, weâ€™re going to want to compose the body that the message contains - this is going to be either text or an image. Weâ€™ll first focus on composing the text for our message body - if the message property of our Message instance is not null, then this means that there is some text to display. In this case, weâ€™ll compose a Text composable using this message property. 

@Composable
fun MessageBody(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    message: Message
) {
    if (message.message != null) {
        Text(
            modifier = modifier,
            text = message.message
        )
    }
}

When this message property is available, weâ€™ll be able to see this text composed within our UI.

In these cases that the message property is null, weâ€™re going to want to check if there is an image property that we can compose. When this image property is not null then weâ€™ll use the Image composable to display it within our message body. When composing this mage weâ€™ll:

  • Fix the size to 120dp
  • Set the bitmap of the composable to the image from our Message
  • Apply the content description using the altText of the Message
@Composable
fun MessageBody(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    message: Message
) {
    if (message.message != null) {
        Text(
            modifier = modifier,
            text = message.message
        )
    } else if (message.image != null) {
        Image(
            modifier = modifier.size(120.dp),
            bitmap = BitmapFactory.decodeResource(
                LocalContext.current.resources, message.image
            ).asImageBitmap(),
            contentDescription = message.altText
        )
    }
}

At this point, we can now also view a composed image within our UI when the image property has a value assigned to it.

Composing the Message Body composable

Now that we have this MessageBody composable created and ready to go, we can compose it inside of our Message composable - letâ€™s add it directly as a child of our Column composable.

@Composable
fun Message(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    message: Message
) {
    Column(modifier = parentModifier) {
        MessageBody(
            message = message
        )
    }
}

Within our Message composable, weâ€™ll now be able to see the content of our Message being composed inside of this composable, via the MessageBody composable. At this point, things donâ€™t look too different from what we previously saw in the screenshots for this composable, based on the Message being provided to the composable.

Weâ€™re going to want to style our Message a bit so that it sits within the list of messages quite nicely. We want to create a container effect for our message so that the message is sitting inside a kind of padded box - giving it more prominence within our UI. For this weâ€™re going to utilise the Box composable, using a couple of modifiers to apply this kind of styling.

Weâ€™ll make use of the background modifier to create a rounded box, followed by some padding to crate some visual spacing between the edges of the box and the content of our message. Now that our MessageBody is composed inside of this Box, weâ€™re going to want to ensure that this is aligned in the center of this parent container. For the MessageBody, we'll go ahead and use the align modifier to align this in the Center of the parent composable.

@Composable
fun Message(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    message: Message
) {

    Column(modifier = modifier) {
        Box(
            modifier = Modifier
                .background(
                    Color.LightGray,
                    RoundedCornerShape(6.dp)
                )
                .padding(8.dp)
        ) {
            MessageBody(
				modifier = Modifier.align(Alignment.Center)
                message = message
            )
        }
    }
}

At this point, we now have our MessageBody being composed inside of this rounded box, position in the center and now appearing more prominent as a UI component.

Displaying the message sent time

Weâ€™re currently using the Column composable to contain the content of our Message, but weâ€™re currently only composing a single child inside of it. As originally planned, we were going to utilise this Column to display the time that the message was sent. To do this weâ€™ll use the dateTime property on the Message reference that is being passed to our composable function.
