This reference is currently of the Calendar type, which we canâ€™t directly use to display information within our UI. Instead, weâ€™re going to need to take the time that this Calendar represents, and format it into a human-readable representation. Weâ€™re going to want to show this in an hour : minute format (e.g 12:00pm), so weâ€™ll need to utilise the SimpleDataFormat class which will allow us to parse our Calendar time into a string of this format.

SimpleDateFormat("hh:mm")

Within our composable, we donâ€™t want this to be instantiated upon every recomposition of a Message, so weâ€™re going to wrap this in remember 

val dateFormat = remember { SimpleDateFormat("hh:mm") }

ðŸ’¡ Remember allows us to persist values across compositions, avoiding classes being re-instantiated in cases where there has been no reason for change.

With this now in place we can use the format function to take the Date from our Calendar and parse it into the format that we have stated. We can then apply this directly to a Text composable.

Text(
	text = dateFormat.format(message.dateTime.time)
)

With this formatting now in place, we can slot this into our parent Column so that it is composed directly beneath our MessageBody content. In this process, weâ€™ll also apply some padding to the top of our Text composable, along with overriding the fontSize to a value of 12sp.

@Composable
fun Message(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    message: Message
) {
	val dateFormat = remember { SimpleDateFormat("hh:mm") }
    Column(modifier = modifier) {
        Box(
            modifier = Modifier
                .background(
                    Color.LightGray,
                    RoundedCornerShape(6.dp)
                )
                .padding(8.dp)
        ) {
            MessageBody(
                modifier = Modifier.align(Alignment.Center),
                message = message
            )
        }
        Text(
			modifier = Modifier.padding(top = 4.dp),
        	text = dateFormat.format(message.dateTime.time),
            fontSize = 12.sp
        )
	}
}

With this in place, we can now see the sent time of the message being set within our message content.

Composing the list of Messages

With all of the above in place, we now have a Message composable that can be used to display the content of the messages that are provided to the Messages composable function.

When these messages are provided to our composable function, we donâ€™t exactly know how many are going to be provided. If this is many, then we want to ensure that we can optimally provide this - if we compose this inside of a Column, weâ€™ll be composing all of these Message composables in one go, which isnâ€™t going to be a very optimal experience in our UI.

To compose this efficiently, weâ€™re going to use the LazyColumn composable. This allows us to compose items of a list in a way that ensure only what is needed at any time is actually composed. We can see this as a kind of smart composition, as messages wonâ€™t be composed until they are required (as in, coming into visibility) within our list. When composing this LazyColumn, weâ€™ll also need to provide a reference to a LazyListState - this holds information on the current state of our LazyColumn and can be retrieved using the rememberLazyListState composable function. For now, weâ€™ll pass this directly to the state argument, as we donâ€™t need to interact with this state in any other way.

LazyColumn(
	modifier = modifier,
	state = rememberLazyListState()
) {
            
}

We can then slot this into our Messages composable, where weâ€™ll also utilise the contentPadding argument to apply some padding to the top area of our LazyColumn content. Alongside this weâ€™ll also provide a value for the verticalArrangement - this will be in the form of spacedBy, which allows us to declare how much spacing should be applied between each child of the list.

@Composable
fun Messages(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    messages: List<Message>? = null
) {
    if (messages.isNullOrEmpty()) {
        EmptyConversation(
            modifier = modifier
        )
    } else {
        LazyColumn(
            modifier = modifier,
            state = rememberLazyListState(),
            contentPadding = PaddingValues(top = 8.dp),
			verticalArrangement = Arrangement.spacedBy(16.dp)
        ) {
            
        }
    }
}

With this LazyColumn defined, weâ€™re ready to compose our list of messages. When composing content inside of a LazyColumn, it needs to be done so within a LazyListScope - which can be achieved using one of the items extension functions. When using this items function we can provide a list that will then be used to build a collection of scoped items that are compatible with the LazyColumn.

items(messageList) { message ->
	// compose message content
}

Within this block we can then compose our Message composable, passing in the current Message reference that is being provided as the itemContent of the items function call. This will mean that now for every item in the messageList reference, a Message composable will be composed when required by our LazyColumn. Weâ€™ll instruct this composable to fill the maximum width that is available to it by using the fillMaxWidth modifier, along with adding a Spacer beneath this composable to create some visual space between the different items in our list.

@Composable
fun Messages(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    messages: List<Message>? = null
) {
    if (messages.isNullOrEmpty()) {
        EmptyConversation(
            modifier = modifier
        )
    } else {
        LazyColumn(
            modifier = modifier,
            state = rememberLazyListState(),
            contentPadding = PaddingValues(top = 8.dp),
			verticalArrangement = Arrangement.spacedBy(16.dp)
        ) {
            items(messageList) { message ->
                Message(
                    modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
                    message = message
                )
            }
        }
    }
}

Finally, weâ€™ll need to compose our Messages composable inside of our Conversation, adding this beneath the previously added Header composable. Alongside providing the message from our state reference to the messages argument, weâ€™ll assign a weight of 1f so that the composable fills all of the available space within the Conversation. 

@Composable
fun Conversation(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    state: ConversationState,
    handleEvent: (event: ConversationEvent) -> Unit
) {
    Column(
        modifier = modifier,
    ) {
        Header(
            modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
            onClose = {
                // finish activity
            }
        )
        Messages(
            modifier = Modifier.weight(1f),
            messages = state.messages
        )
    }
}

With this added to our composition, we will now be able to see the messages from our state being composed within our UI.

Adding clarity to Sent and Received messages

Now that we have a collection of messages being composed within our UI, we can start to think about how we can improve things visually. One thing that might stand out here is that itâ€™s quite hard to differentiate what is a sent message and what is a received message. A common pattern here is to have sent and received messages aligned to opposite sides of the screen - so weâ€™re going to adopt this here within our UI. To do so, weâ€™ll need to hop on back over to our Message composable. Because we are telling the parent Column composable to fill the maximum width that it has available, weâ€™ll want to align the child Box composable so that it will be aligned to either side of the parent Column. For this, we can use the direction of the current Message reference, along with the Alignment object which will allow us to align the composable accordingly. First, letâ€™s calculate an Alignment based on this direction. If our direction is equal to MessageDirection.SENT then weâ€™ll want to align the composable at the End of the Column, otherwise weâ€™ll position it at the Start.

val alignment = if (
	message.direction == MessageDirection.SENT
) {
	Alignment.End
} else Alignment.Start

With this alignment calculated, we can now apply it to our Box composable, using the align modifier. Weâ€™ll also need to apply this modifier to the Text composable that is displaying the sent time so that it is also aligned accordingly. With this applied to the composables, the elements will be aligned accordingly on the horizontal axis of the Column.

@Composable
fun Message(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    message: Message
) {

    val dateFormat = remember { SimpleDateFormat("hh:mm") }
    Column(modifier = modifier) {

		val alignment = if (message.direction == MessageDirection.SENT) {
            Alignment.End
        } else Alignment.Start

        Box(
            modifier = Modifier
				.align(alignment = alignment)
                .background(
                    Color.LightGray,
                    RoundedCornerShape(6.dp)
                )
                .padding(8.dp)
        ) {
            MessageBody(
                modifier = Modifier.align(Alignment.Center),
                message = message
            )
        }
        Text(
			modifier = Modifier
				.align(alignment = alignment)
				.padding(top = 4.dp),
        	text = dateFormat.format(message.dateTime.time),
            fontSize = 12.sp
        )
	}
}

With this alignment now applied, weâ€™ll be able to see our message content align to the corresponding side of the Column.

We may notice here though, our message items are pressed quite tightly against the edges of our composable - which doesnâ€™t look too great. What weâ€™ll do here is add some padding to the parent container on the horizontal axis. To calculate this padding weâ€™re going to again utilise the direction - because the SENT messages online need padding at the end and RECEIVED messages only need padding at the start. So here weâ€™ll build a new modifier reference by chaining onto the Modifier that is provided to our composable function, assign some padding to it and then continue to pass this as the modifier argument for our Column.

@Composable
fun Message(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    message: Message
) {

	val parentModifier = if (
		message.direction == MessageDirection.SENT
	) {
        modifier.padding(end = 16.dp)
    } else modifier.padding(start = 16.dp)

    val dateFormat = remember { SimpleDateFormat("hh:mm") }
    Column(modifier = parentModifier) {

		val alignment = if (message.direction == MessageDirection.SENT) {
            Alignment.End
        } else Alignment.Start

        Box(
            modifier = Modifier
				.align(alignment = alignment)
                .background(
                    Color.LightGray,
                    RoundedCornerShape(6.dp)
                )
                .padding(8.dp)
        ) {
            MessageBody(
                modifier = Modifier.align(Alignment.Center),
                message = message
            )
        }
        Text(
			modifier = Modifier
				.align(alignment = alignment)
				.padding(top = 4.dp),
        	text = dateFormat.format(message.dateTime.time),
            fontSize = 12.sp
        )
	}
}

With this padding applied, we can see that our Message items now sit nicely within our UI and are no longer pressed against the edges of our composable.

Showing and hiding the message sent time

Looking at our message feed, itâ€™s fair to say that some users might find it cluttered. While we have a couple of UI components that are showing for each message, some of those elements donâ€™t need to be displayed all of the time. For example, the sent time on our messages is always visible - this is something that we donâ€™t need to show all of the time. A common pattern in messaging apps is to only show the sent time when the message is tapped - weâ€™re going to implement this behaviour for our message items.

Weâ€™re going to need to start by adding some state to our composable function that will track whether the sent time should be shown or not. Weâ€™ll create a new mutable state reference for a simple boolean value, wrapping this in remember so that the value is persisted across recompositions. Weâ€™re going to need this at the highest point of our Message composable because it is going to need to be read by our Column.

@Composable
fun Message(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    message: Message,
    onLongPress: (id: String) -> Unit
) {
    val parentModifier = if (
		message.direction == MessageDirection.SENT
	) {
        modifier.padding(end = 16.dp)
    } else modifier.padding(start = 16.dp)

    var displaySentTime by remember { mutableStateOf(false) }

	...
}

With this state in place, weâ€™re going to need to add an interaction listener to our Column. For this weâ€™re going to utilise the pointerInput - this allows us to listen for common interaction events on our composables. Later on, in this chapter, weâ€™re going to require some functionality that is provided by these listeners, so weâ€™re also going to utilise this here to detect tap events. Within the pointer input block, weâ€™re now going to utilise the detectTapGestures extension function, allowing us to implement listeners for the events that we want to receive. Here weâ€™ll implement the listener for tap events on our composable, onTap.

Column(modifier = parentModifier
        .pointerInput(Unit) {
            detectTapGestures(
                onTap = {

                }
            )
        }
) {
	...
}

Within this onTap callback we can then toggle the state value that we previously defined to the opposite of itself.

Column(modifier = parentModifier
        .pointerInput(Unit) {
            detectTapGestures(
                onTap = {
                    displaySentTime = !displaySentTime
                }
            )
        }
) {
	...
}

With this value now being toggled when our composable is tapped, we can then simply wrap the composition of the sent time in a conditional check. This would result in the sent time only being composed when displaySentTime is true.

if (displaySentTime) {
	Text(
		modifier = Modifier.padding(top = 4.dp),
		text = dateFormat.format(message.dateTime.time),
		fontSize = 12.sp
     )
}

However, we can go one step further here. With the above, the change in the composition will appear suddenly to the user - if we could animate this in and out of view for the user, this would be a much nicer visual experience. To achieve this, weâ€™re going to utilise the AnimatedVisibility composable - this allows us to animate a composable in and out of visibility by utilising the visible argument. Here we are simply going to place our existing Text composable for the sent time into the body of our AnimatedVisibility composable, providing our displaySentTime state for the value of the visible argument.

AnimatedVisibility(
	visible = displaySentTime
) {
	Text(
		modifier = Modifier
			.align(alignment = alignment)
			.padding(top = 4.dp),
		text = dateFormat.format(message.dateTime.time),
		fontSize = 12.sp
	)
}

We also need to lift out the align modifier that we previously applied to our sent time composable. This is because the AnimatedVisibility composable is now the container for that, so any alignment will need to be applied to this parent instead of the child that is contained inside of it.

AnimatedVisibility(
	modifier = Modifier
		.align(alignment = alignment),
	visible = message.displaySentTime
) {
	Text(
		modifier = Modifier.padding(top = 4.dp),
		text = dateFormat.format(message.dateTime.time),
		fontSize = 12.sp
	)
}

We can now slot this into our Message composable, which will give us something that looks like the following.

@Composable
fun Message(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    message: Message
) {
    val parentModifier = if (
		message.direction == MessageDirection.SENT
	) {
        modifier.padding(end = 16.dp)
    } else modifier.padding(start = 16.dp)

    Column(modifier = parentModifier) {

        val alignment = if (
			message.direction == MessageDirection.SENT
		) {
            Alignment.End
        } else Alignment.Start

        Box(
            modifier = modifier
                .align(alignment = alignment)
                .background(
                    Color.LightGray,
                    RoundedCornerShape(6.dp)
                )
                .padding(8.dp)
        ) {
            MessageBody(
                modifier = Modifier.align(Alignment.Center),
                message = message
            )
        }

        val dateFormat = remember {
            SimpleDateFormat("hh:mm")
        }
        AnimatedVisibility(
            modifier = Modifier
                .align(alignment = alignment),
            visible = message.displaySentTime
        ) {
            Text(
				modifier = Modifier.padding(top = 4.dp),
                text = dateFormat.format(
					message.dateTime.time),
                fontSize = 12.s
            )
        }
    }
}

With this in place, weâ€™ll now be able to tap a message and see its sent time animate between visibilities.

Creating Sticky Date Headers

At this point, we have our messages displayed within the list, along with a nice animation to show/hide the time that the message was sent. Aside from using the sent time, we often see messaging apps collate messages into groups, using heading to depict the grouping for messages - for example, grouping messages by dates and then showing a header to indicate the date that that grouping of messages was received. This concept gives us a great opportunity to implement this behaviour in compose, so weâ€™re now going to display headings for message dates. For this, weâ€™re going to want to show a date header above the first message for a given date, but before we can do this weâ€™re going to need to group our messages by sent date.

For this weâ€™re going to create a new function, groupMessagesByDate. This keeps the logic outside of our composable function, also making it easier for us to test this code also. Here weâ€™re going to utilise the Kotlin groupBy function that allows us to take a list of items, followed by generating a Map that represents the grouped items. Each group will be represented by the key of the map entry and weâ€™ll want this key to also represent the date of the group, which we will then use for our header.

When using the groupBy function we need to implement a keySelector block, this is what is used to calculate the key for each item in the provided list - this key is what will then be used to generate the map for our list of items. An issue here though is that within our keySelector we canâ€™t just reference the dateTime of our message - this is because even if a message is on the same date, itâ€™s likely to have been sent at a different hour, minute or second than another. This would result in the grouping creating multiple Map entries for messages that were sent on the same date, but just at a different time within that date. To ensure that this comparison is only performed on the day, month and year of our Calendar, weâ€™re going to go ahead and clear the other properties that might be checked against.

fun groupMessagesByDate(
    messages: List<Message>
): Map<Calendar, List<Message>> {
    return messages.groupBy {
        it.dateTime.apply {
            set(Calendar.HOUR_OF_DAY, 0)
            set(Calendar.MINUTE, 0)
            set(Calendar.SECOND, 0)
            set(Calendar.MILLISECOND, 0)
        }
    }
}

In this function, weâ€™re taking a list of messages and grouping them by the dateTime property. When performing this grouping, weâ€™re setting the hour, minute, second and millisecond properties to 0 - this means that when performing the group, we are essentially only grouping based on the day, month and year. When displaying the sent time within the composable we are accessing the date time field from the Message instance, so resetting these values here does not interfere with the value that we are going to display.

With this function in place, weâ€™ll need to start by calling it and providing the list of messages from our state and keep a reference to this that can be used by our list.

val grouped = groupMessagesByDate(messages)

Now that we have this group, we can loop through each entry of the map, continuing to compose the Message values that are contained within the map entry, which would result in the same composition that we were previously seeing within our UI.

grouped.onEachIndexed { index, entry ->
	items(entry.value) { message ->
		Message(
			modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
			message = message
    	)
		Spacer(modifier = Modifier.height(16.dp))
	}
}

Now that weâ€™re looping through each entry with our map, weâ€™re looping through each group that contains messages grouped by date. This means that for each group, weâ€™re going to want to draw a header. This header is going to be represented by a composable, so weâ€™re going to need to create a new composable function, MessageHeader. When it comes to this header, there are going to be a couple of different ways that itâ€™s going to be represented.

  • When the date represents a day that is not the current date, the date that the message was sent will be displayed
  • When the date represents the current day, a â€œTodayâ€ label will be displayed

With that in mind, the composable is going to need to know the Calendar that it is composing a header for, along with a flag to signify whether the header is representing the date for today.

@Composable
fun MessageHeader(
	modifier: Modifier,
    isToday: Boolean,
    date: Calendar
}

Weâ€™ll start by configuring the label that is going to be displayed within the header. In the cases where we are working with todayâ€™s date, weâ€™re going to need to show a â€œTodayâ€ label. For this, weâ€™ll need to add a string to our strings.xml resources file.

<string name="label_today">Today</string>

Then if the isToday flag is represented as true, we can go ahead and assign this label to a variable reference, retrieving this using the stringResource composable function.

val label = if (isToday) {
	stringResource(id = R.string.label_today)
} else {
	
}

In these cases where we arenâ€™t working with todayâ€™s date, weâ€™ll need to show the actual date. Here weâ€™re going to show this in a day-month-year style, which weâ€™re going to need to use the SimpleDateFormat class to achieve. Weâ€™ll configure this class to format our date in the required format by using the â€œdd MMM yyyyâ€ pattern, followed by using this class to format the Date from the Calendar reference that is provided to our composable function.

val label = if (isToday) {
	stringResource(id = R.string.label_today)
} else {
	val dateFormat = remember { 
		SimpleDateFormat("dd MMM yyyy") 
	}
	dateFormat.format(date.time)
}

With this logic in place, we can now display this inside of our header using a Text composable. Weâ€™ll start by setting the value of our label to the Text composable, along with assigning a fontSize of 14sp.

Text(
	modifier = modifier,
    text = label,
    fontSize = 14.sp
)

Next, weâ€™ll need to enforce our header to use the full width of the composable, for which weâ€™ll use the fillMaxWidth modifier. Now that our composable is filling the whole with, weâ€™ll also need to ensure that our text value is aligned into the center of the composable. For this, weâ€™ll need to set the textAlign to TextAlign.Center, which will align the text into the center of the composable.

Text(
	modifier = modifier,
    text = label,
    fontSize = 14.sp,
    textAlign = TextAlign.Center
)

Alongside the sizing constraints, weâ€™ll also need to style the background color of our composable. For this weâ€™re going to use a modified version of the onSurface theme color - weâ€™ll modify this by copying the value of the color and overriding the alpha value that is used for it. This will help to ensure that our header remains within the theming of our application, while also adapting the color to our requirements.

Text(
	modifier = modifier,
    	.background(MaterialTheme.colors.onSurface.copy(
        	alpha = 0.05f
      	))
        .padding(vertical = 4.dp),
    text = label,
    fontSize = 14.sp,
    textAlign = TextAlign.Center
)

With this in place, we now have a MessageHeader composable function that can be used to display a header for a given Calendar reference.

@Composable
fun MessageHeader(
	modifier = modifier,
    isToday: Boolean,
    date: Calendar
) {
    val label = if (isToday) {
        stringResource(id = R.string.label_today)
    } else {
        val dateFormat = SimpleDateFormat("dd MMM yyyy")
        dateFormat.format(date.time)
    }

    Text(
        modifier = modifier
            .background(MaterialTheme.colors.onSurface.copy(
            	alpha = 0.05f
        	))
            .padding(vertical = 4.dp),
        text = label,
        fontSize = 14.sp,
        textAlign = TextAlign.Center
    )
}

Now that we have our composable defined, we can go ahead and compose it within our LazyColumn. The LazyColumn contains a stickyHeader which can be used to compose content that is to be used as a sticky header. Anything that is composed here will be pinned within the UI, even while the user is scrolling through the list - but when the next header is reached within the list, this will replace the currently pinned one. Weâ€™ll go ahead and use this function, composing our MessageHeader inside of it.

grouped.onEachIndexed { index, entry ->

	stickyHeader {
		MessageHeader(
			modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
			isToday = isToday(entry.key),
			date = entry.key
		)
	}

	items(entry.value) { message ->
		Message(
			modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
			message = message
    	)
		Spacer(modifier = Modifier.height(16.dp))
	}
}

We can now slot all of the content that weâ€™ve defined for sticky headers into our Messages composable, which should result in a composable that looks like the following.

@Composable
fun Messages(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    messages: List<Message>? = null
) {
    if (messages.isNullOrEmpty()) {
        EmptyConversation(
            modifier = modifier
        )
    } else {
        val state = rememberLazyListState()
        LazyColumn(
            modifier = modifier,
            state = state,
            contentPadding = PaddingValues(top = 8.dp),
			verticalArrangement = Arrangement.spacedBy(16.dp)
        ) {
			val grouped = groupMessagesByDate(messages)
            grouped.onEach { entry ->

                stickyHeader {
                    MessageHeader(
                        isToday = isToday(entry.key),
                        date = entry.key
                    )
                }

                items(entry.value) { message ->
                    Message(
                        modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
                        message = message
                    )
                }
            }
        }
    }
}

With this in place, we will now be able to see our list of messages within the UI, this time accompanied by sticky headers that represent the current dates of the messages.

Supporting Message Creation

While we are currently displaying messages within our UI, these ones are coming from our pre-existing state. In a real messaging app we would be receiving and sending messages in real-time, seeing our UI update as this happens. While weâ€™re not communicating with a remote API for our messaging app, we can simulate this locally. In this section weâ€™re going to add an input bar that allows our users to send text-based messages, seeing them appear within the message list once theyâ€™ve been sent.

For this weâ€™re going to create a new composable that allows us to support the input of text, weâ€™ll create a new file InputBar.kt and create a new composable function, InputBar. As well as taking a Modifier argument, this is going to take a sendMessage lambda that allows the send message event to be sent from our composable function.

// InputBar.kt

@Composable
fun InputBar(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    sendMessage: (message: String) -> Unit
)

The content of our composable is going to be quite minimal - itâ€™s going to display an input field that allows our user to input textual content. However, weâ€™re going to want this to have some separation with wherever this is placed within our UI, so weâ€™re also going to utilise a Divider composable to add a breaking line at the top of our input bar. Because of this, weâ€™ll need to have a parent Column composable that will be used to house this Divider along with the input bar that we will also add here shortly.

// InputBar.kt

@Composable
fun InputBar(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    sendMessage: (message: String) -> Unit
) {
    Column(modifier = modifier) {
        Divider()
		
    }
}

With this in place, we can now add the TextField composable that will enable input for our messaging feature. Before we define this input field, weâ€™re going to need to create a state object that will be used to hold the content that has been input by the user. For this weâ€™re going to explore using the TextFieldValue class - while we could use strings directly here, weâ€™re later going to need this TextFieldValue. This class not only holds the current text that is to be rendered inside of the composable, but also other information that is used for its composition. Weâ€™ll create a new piece of mutable state here, wrapping it in remember so that the state is persisted across compositions.

var textState by remember { 
	mutableStateOf(TextFieldValue()) 
}

Now that weâ€™ve defined this state we can go ahead and compose TextField within our InputBar composable. Weâ€™ll set the value to the textState reference that we previously defined, along with updating the value of our textState within the onValueChange implementation for our TextField.

@Composable
fun InputBar(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    sendMessage: (message: String) -> Unit
) {
    var textState by remember { 
		mutableStateOf(TextFieldValue()) 
	}
    Column(modifier = modifier) {
        Divider()
        TextField(
           	value = textState,
            onValueChange = {
                textState = it
            }
    	)
    }
}

At this point, we now have an input field being composed within our InputBar.

We might notice here though that things arenâ€™t looking quite right within our UI, the TextField is very narrow! To resolve this weâ€™re going to utilise the fillMaxWidth modifier so that the composable uses the full width that is available to it.

@Composable
fun InputBar(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    sendMessage: (message: String) -> Unit
) {
    var textState by remember { 
		mutableStateOf(TextFieldValue()) 
	}
    Column(modifier = modifier) {
        Divider()
        TextField(
			modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
           	value = textState,
            onValueChange = {
                textState = it
            }
    	)
    }
}

We can see now that our composable is filling the maximum width, resulting in a better visual representation for our UI.

When viewing our input bar, it isnâ€™t super clear what it is used for. We can improve things here slightly by adding a label for our input, this will help to give some context to the users as to what our input bar is to be used for - in this case, sending a message. For this, weâ€™ll add a new string to our strings.xml resource file.

<string name="hint_send_message">Send a messageâ€¦</string>

With this now defined we can go ahead and compose some text within the placeholder of our TextField. For this, weâ€™ll simply use a Text composable and apply the string resource that we have just defined. Because we are defining a label here, we donâ€™t need it to be so prominent within our UI - for this reason, we can take the color that would be used (onSurface) and override the alpha value. For the alpha weâ€™ll use the ContentAlpha.medium - which as per the documentation is:

A medium level of content alpha, used to represent medium emphasis text such as placeholder text in a TextField.

@Composable
fun InputBar(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    sendMessage: (message: String) -> Unit
) {
    var textState by remember { 
		mutableStateOf(TextFieldValue()) 
	}
    Column(modifier = modifier) {
        Divider()
        TextField(
            modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
            value = textState,
			onValueChange = {
                textState = it
            },
            placeholder = {
                Text(
					text = stringResource(id = R.string.hint_send_message), 
					color = MaterialTheme.colors.onSurface
						.copy(alpha = ContentAlpha.medium)
				)
            }
    	)
    }
}

At this point, we now have a placeholder within our TextField which adds some clarity as to what our input field is to be used for.

For the theming of the composable, you may have noticed that the background of the input bar is using a modified version of the onSurface color. Where weâ€™re using this input field within our UI, this doesnâ€™t look too great. Instead, weâ€™re going to override the color thatâ€™s being used so that instead the surface color is used.

To achieve this we need to provide a TextFieldColors reference to the colors argument of the TextField composable. To build an instance of this class we can utilise the TextFieldDefaults.textFieldColors function - this will apply the default TextField colors, allowing us to override the colors that we desire. Here weâ€™re going to override the backgroundColor value, using the surface color from our theme to do so.

@Composable
fun InputBar(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    sendMessage: (message: String) -> Unit
) {
    var textState by remember { 
		mutableStateOf(TextFieldValue()) 
	}
    Column(modifier = modifier) {
        Divider()
        TextField(
            modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
            value = textState,
			onValueChange = {
                textState = it
            },
            placeholder = {
                Text(
					text = stringResource(id = R.string.hint_send_message), 
					color = MaterialTheme.colors.onSurface
						.copy(alpha = ContentAlpha.medium)
				)
            },
            colors = TextFieldDefaults.textFieldColors(
                backgroundColor = MaterialTheme.colors.surface
            )
    	)
    }
}

Now, we can see that our input field has a bit more of a natural style, which will fit in nicer with the rest of our UI.

While at this point this user can enter content into our input field, they arenâ€™t able to do anything with that content. So that the user can send the message that theyâ€™ve entered, weâ€™re going to add an icon that allows the user to do so. For this, weâ€™ll utilise the trailingIcon argument of the TextField to compose an IconButton that will be used to send the message.

trailingIcon = {
	IconButton(
		onClick = {

		}
	) {
		
	}
}

So that our IconButton is functional, weâ€™re going to compose an Icon within the content of the IconButton. When doing so, weâ€™ll utilise the Icons.Default.Send icon to display a familiar icon for sending content.

trailingIcon = {
	IconButton(
		onClick = {

		}
	) {
		Icon(
			imageVector = Icons.Default.Send,
			contentDescription = ...
		)
	}
}

Weâ€™ll also need to add a content description for this composable. Weâ€™ll start by adding this to our strings.xml file.

<string name="cd_send_message">Send message</string>

Along with retrieving the string value for this using the stringResource function, followed by passing this to the contentDescription argument for our composable.

trailingIcon = {
	IconButton(
		onClick = {

		}
	) {
		Icon(
			imageVector = Icons.Default.Send,
			contentDescription = stringResource(
				id = R.string.cd_send_message)
		)
	}
}

Within our composable, weâ€™ll now be able to see a â€™sendâ€™ button.

However, at this point, the button isnâ€™t doing anything. When the onClick callback is triggered, weâ€™ll need to use the sendMessage lambda that is provided to our composable function. When using this, weâ€™ll pass the value of our textState reference - this will represent the current content of the input field. Weâ€™ll then want to essentially reset our textState - this is because once the message has been sent, the input content is redundant. So here weâ€™ll set our textState value to a new instance of the TextFieldValue class.

trailingIcon = {
	IconButton(
		onClick = {
			sendMessage(textState.text)
			textState = TextFieldValue()
		}
	) {
		Icon(
			imageVector = Icons.Default.Send,
			contentDescription = stringResource(
				id = R.string.cd_send_message)
		)
	}
}

While itâ€™s now possible to send messages, weâ€™re not going to want to allow the user to click this icon in all cases. For example, if no content has been entered into the field then we donâ€™t want to allow the user to hit the send button. This is going to involve two small tweaks to our composable code.

Weâ€™ll start by setting the enabled state of our IconButton. Here, the IconButton will only be enabled if the value of our state is not empty. For this we can utilise the Kotlin isNotEmpty() function to assert whether the input content is empty, followed by providing this for the enabled argument of the IconButton composable.

To make it visually clear to the user that the IconButton is disabled, weâ€™ll want to modify the color of the icon based on the enabled state. To implement this weâ€™ll need to provide a color value for the tint argument, which weâ€™ll do so conditionally based on the input content. Again using the isNotEmpty() check on our state value, weâ€™ll provide a color based on whether there is content that has been entered. If there is content then weâ€™ll use the primary color from our theme, otherwise, weâ€™ll use a modified version of the onSurface - applying the disabled alpha value from the material ContentAlpha.

trailingIcon = {
	IconButton(
		onClick = {
			sendMessage(textState.text)
			textState = TextFieldValue()
		},
		enabled = textState.text.isNotEmpty()
	) {
		Icon(
			imageVector = Icons.Default.Send,
			contentDescription = stringResource(
				id = R.string.cd_send_message),
			tint = if (textState.text.isNotEmpty()) {
				MaterialTheme.colors.primary
			} else {
				MaterialTheme.colors.onSurface
					.copy(alpha = ContentAlpha.disabled)
			}
		)
	}
}

With this in place, weâ€™ll now be able to see our IconButton enabled or disabled based on the current state of our content, along with the Icon themed accordingly. We just need to slot this into the TextField composable within our InputBar.

@Composable
fun InputBar(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    sendMessage: (message: String) -> Unit
) {
    var textState by remember { 
		mutableStateOf(TextFieldValue()) 
	}
    Column(modifier = modifier) {
        Divider()
        TextField(
            modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
            value = textState,
			onValueChange = {
                textState = it
            },
            placeholder = {
                Text(
					text = stringResource(id = R.string.hint_send_message), 
					color = Color.Gray
				)
            },
            colors = TextFieldDefaults.textFieldColors(
                backgroundColor = MaterialTheme.colors.surface
            ),
            trailingIcon = {
                IconButton(
                    onClick = {
						sendMessage(textState.text)
                        textState = TextFieldValue()
                    },
                    enabled = textState.text.isNotEmpty()
                ) {
                	Icon(
                		imageVector = Icons.Default.Send,
                		contentDescription = stringResource(
							id = R.string.cd_send_message),
                    	tint = if (
							textState.text.isNotEmpty()) {
                    		MaterialTheme.colors.primary
                   		} else {
                    		MaterialTheme.colors.onSurface
								.copy(alpha = ContentAlpha.disabled)
                  		}
                	)
            	}
        	}
    	)
    }
}

With this now being composed, weâ€™ll currently see our InputBar composed like so.

At this point, we just need to compose our InputBar inside of our Conversation composable. With our Messages composing using up the available pace, we can compose our InputBar underneath this and it will be pushed to the bottom of the screen. When composing our InputBar weâ€™ll use the fillMaxWidth modifier to fill the available width of the composable, along with implementing the sendMessage callback. Within this callback implementation, weâ€™ll want to trigger the handleEvent lambda that is provided to our Conversation composable, passing the SendMessage event when doing so.

@Composable
fun Conversation(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    state: ConversationState,
    handleEvent: (event: ConversationEvent) -> Unit
) {
    Column(
        modifier = modifier,
    ) {
        Header(
            modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
            onClose = {
                // finish activity
            }
        )
        Messages(
            modifier = Modifier.weight(1f),
            messages = state.messages,
            handleEvent
        )
        InputBar(
            modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
            sendMessage = { message ->		
				handleEvent(
					ConversationEvent.SendMessage(message))
			}
        )
    }
}

Our Conversation composable will now include the InputBar in its composition, allowing the user to send messages in the given conversation.

Supporting @ mentions

Now that our input bar has been created, weâ€™re going to add some support to allow users to @ mention their contacts. This means that a user will be able to type the @ character and see a list of contacts to select from, adding their name to the chat when clicked. For this, weâ€™re going to create a new composable function, Mentions that is going to need to take a couple of arguments.

  • modifier: used to apply modifiers from the point of composition
  • contacts: the list of contacts that are available to tag
  • query: the search query to use when displaying contacts
  • onMentionClicked: a lambda for handling the selection of a contact
Mentions.kt

@Composable
fun Mentions(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    contacts: List<Contact>,
    query: String?,
    onMentionClicked: (mention: String) -> Unit
)

Within this function, weâ€™re going to need to filter out the provided contacts based on the provided query. 

val mentions = contacts.filter {
	
}

For this, we can utilise the Contact name to do so, but to ensure this works correctly weâ€™re first going to need to strip the â€œ@â€œ mention symbol from the query string. This is because the user would have entered the â€œ@â€œ character to trigger the mention functionality, so if this is passed to out composable then weâ€™re going to need to remove it before comparisons (as the contact name wonâ€™t include this). Weâ€™ll create a new function, stripMentionSymbol, inside of a textUtil.kt file. This will take the provided string and remove any â€œ@â€œ from the string, returning a blank string if this provided text is null.

textUtil.kt

fun stripMentionSymbol(text: String?) = 
	text?.replace("@", "") ?: ""

With this function in place, we can now use this to generate a query string that does not include an â€œ@â€œ symbol. When calling this function weâ€™ll also convert our initial query string to lowercase, as this will avoid any discrepancies when performing comparisons.

val mentions = contacts.filter { contact ->
	val withoutMentionSymbol = stripMentionSymbol(
		query?.lowercase())
	...
}

Now that we have an equivalent of our query string without the â€œ@â€œ mention symbol, we can use this within the predicate of our filter. Here weâ€™ll simply want to assert whether the name of the Contact starts with our stripped query representation, again using lowercase here to avoid any discrepancies. So now for example, if the query is representative of â€œJoâ€, then contacts beginning with that will be returned and represented within our mentions list (for example, â€œJosephâ€, â€œJoleneâ€).

val mentions = contacts.filter { contact ->
	val withoutMentionSymbol = stripMentionSymbol(
		query?.lowercase())
	contact.name.lowercase().startsWith(withoutMentionSymbol)
}

Now that we have these filtered contacts to display as mentions, we can plug this logic into our composable function.

@Composable
fun Mentions(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    contacts: List<Contact>,
    query: String?,
    onMentionClicked: (mention: String) -> Unit
) {
	val mentions = contacts.filter {
        val withoutMentionSymbol = stripMentionSymbol(
			query?.lowercase())
        it.name.lowercase().startsWith(withoutMentionSymbol)
    }
}

At this point we donâ€™t have any visual representation of these contacts, so weâ€™ll want to take these mentions and display them within the composable for selection. Here weâ€™re going to use a LazyRow, which has the same implementation details as the LazyColumn that we used for composing the list of messages - the key difference is that the children are composed in a horizontal fashion, as opposed to vertical. Within our LazyRow weâ€™ll again use the items function to create a collection of LazyListScope scoped children from our mentions reference. For each item, weâ€™ll simply use Text composable to compose the contacts name within the UI component.

LazyRow(modifier = modifier) {
	items(mentions) { contact ->
		Text(
			text = contact.name
        )
    }
}

This will now be composing a collection of contact names inside of the LazyRow.

At this point, weâ€™re only displaying contact names to our users - they canâ€™t yet be interacted with. Here weâ€™re going to utilise the clickable modifier to handle click events on our composable, triggering the onMentionClicked lambda when the composable is clicked. When triggering this, weâ€™ll need to provide the @ mention string back to the parent composable - which weâ€™ll do by appending the selected contact name to the â€œ@â€œ symbol. Weâ€™ll also want to use the padding to ensure that the composable has a big enough touch target for user interaction.

LazyRow(modifier = modifier) {
	items(mentions) { contact ->
		Text(
			modifier = Modifier
            	.clickable {
                	onMentionClicked("@${contact.name}")
            	}
                .padding(16.dp),
			text = contact.name
        )
    }
}

With this in place, our composable is now showing clickable contacts within the LazyRow implementation.

While this click interaction is in place, itâ€™s not currently done so in a way that is accessible to all users. If a user has enabled accessibility services on their device, then talkback will not currently be able to describe what this click action will trigger - only that there is a click action available. Weâ€™re going to add a click action label here so that talkback will be able to communicate what this click interaction will do. Weâ€™re going to define a new resource in our strings.xml file, using a format argument that will allow us to format the string using the contact name.

<string name="cd_mention_contact">Mention %s</string>

Using this string resource, we can construct a string that uses the contact name to give context for the click action - shown below by the clickLabel variable. We can then pass this variable reference to the onClickLabel argument of the clickable modifier, which will then be used to describe the click interaction via accessibility services.

LazyRow(modifier = modifier) {
	items(mentions) { contact ->
		val clickLabel = stringResource(id = R.string.cd_mention_contact, contact.name)
		Text(
			modifier = Modifier
            	.clickable(onClickLabel = clickLabel) {
                	onMentionClicked("@${contact.name}")
            	}
                .padding(16.dp),
			text = contact.name
        )
    }
}

ðŸ’¡ Click labels do not change anything visually for our composable but are just used by accessibility services to describe the available action.

With this all in place, we should now have a Mentions composable function that is representative of the following composable function.

@Composable
fun Mentions(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    contacts: List<Contact>,
    query: String?,
    onMentionClicked: (mention: String) -> Unit
) {
    val mentions = contacts.filter {
        val withoutMentionSymbol = stripMentionSymbol(
			query?.lowercase())
        it.name.lowercase().startsWith(withoutMentionSymbol)
    }
 	LazyRow(modifier = modifier) {
		items(mentions) { contact ->
			val clickLabel = stringResource(id = R.string.cd_mention_contact, contact.name)
			Text(
				modifier = Modifier
            		.clickable(onClickLabel = clickLabel) {
                		onMentionClicked("@${contact.name}")
            		}
                	.padding(16.dp),
				text = contact.name
            )
        }
    }
}

At this point, our composable function will be composing a collection of contact names based on the current query that is provided to it.

Weâ€™re going to make a small tweak here so that there is some visual separation between the mentions bar and any content that might be displayed outside of it. Here weâ€™ll start by moving our LazyRow into a Column, along with the previously assigned Modifier so that this is at the higher point within our composable. Weâ€™ll then add a Divider as the first child of our Column, creating the visual separation that we are looking for.

@Composable
fun Mentions(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    contacts: List<Contact>,
    query: String?,
    onMentionClicked: (mention: String) -> Unit
) {
    val mentions = contacts.filter {
        val withoutMentionSymbol = stripMentionSymbol(
			query?.lowercase())
        it.name.lowercase().startsWith(withoutMentionSymbol)
    }
    Column(
        modifier = modifier
    ) {
        Divider()
        LazyRow {
            items(mentions) { contact ->
				val clickLabel = stringResource(id = R.string.cd_mention_contact, contact.name)
                Text(
					modifier = Modifier
            			.clickable(onClickLabel = clickLabel) {
                			onMentionClicked(
								"@${contact.name}")
            			}
                		.padding(16.dp),
					text = contact.name
            	)
            }
        }
    }
}

Composing the Mentions bar

Now that our Mentions composable has been implemented, weâ€™re ready to compose this within our Input bar.

When we created the Mentions bar we added support to pass a query value as an argument, this is what will be used to determine what contacts should be displayed. A complexity here with the mentions bar is that we canâ€™t just pass the current value of our input field state - as this would be the entire string that has been entered into the message bar. The mentions bar is essentially offering autocomplete functionality, so the query value will represent the current word that is currently being entered by the user. However, a user might not currently be entering a word - they might have moved the input cursor back to a previously entered word that begins with the â€œ@â€œ symbol, so we need to account for this case too. Both of these scenarios can be represented by the concept of the currently selected word, because if a word is currently being entered, then it is also going to be the currently selected word within the input bar. With this in mind, weâ€™re going to create a new function in our textUtils.kt file that allows us to fetch the currently selected word from a TextFieldValue reference.

The TextFieldValue contains everything that we need to be able to get the currently selected word. Not only does it contain the current value of the input, but it also contains information about the current selection within the TextFieldValue. This means that using the starting selection of the TextFieldValue we can loop through the individual words that make up the TextFieldValue text value, fetching the word whose position aligns with the current starting selection of our input field value. Weâ€™ll break this down to understand this further, but this function would be represented like so:

fun selectedWord(textState: TextFieldValue): String? {
    val startSelection = textState.selection.start
    var position = 0

    for (currentWord in textState.text.split(" ")) {
        position += currentWord.length + 1
        if (textPosition >= startSelection) return currentWord
    }
    return null
}

Weâ€™re going to start by pulling out the current start of the TextFieldValue selection and assigning this to a variable reference. This adds a bit of clarity to our function, allowing us to reference startSelection where applicable.

val startSelection = textState.selection.start

Next, weâ€™re going to set up some variables that will be used within our loop. While looping through the words of our string, weâ€™re going to need to keep a track of the current position that we are at within the over string value from our TextFieldValue. For example, if we are currently at the third word within our loop, the position of our text would be the sum of the word lengths before that third word. Weâ€™ll need to keep a track of this outside of our loop, so weâ€™ll define a new variable called textPosition .

var textPosition = 0

Next, weâ€™ll loop through each word that makes up the text representation of our TextFieldValue. Weâ€™ll use the Kotlin split function that will take our string and return us a list of words based on the delimiter that we provide. Here we split out string by a space (represented by â€œ â€œ), so weâ€™ll end up with a collection of words that make up our string.

for (currentWord in textState.text.split(" "))

When performing this loop weâ€™ll need to keep a track of where weâ€™re currently at within our TextFieldValue text value. This is because we canâ€™t guarantee that startSelection represents the start of a word (it could be in the middle) - textPosition will always represent the start of a word as the length of the previous word (+ 1 for the space) will always represent the start of the next word. We + 1 for a space here because weâ€™ve split out string into individual words, so we need to account for the spaces that have been removed.

textPosition += currentWord.length + 1

Now that we have the above in place, we can check whether the current textPosition is greater than or equal to the startSelection of our TextFieldValue. If this is the case, then it means that the current word that we are at the loop is the currently selected word.

For example, letâ€™s imagine we have the phrase â€œHello Joeâ€ - and the userâ€™s selection is currently between the O and the E of â€œJoeâ€. This would mean the startSelection would represent 8. During our loop, the first word would be represented by â€œHelloâ€ - at this point our textPosition would represent 6 (hello = 5 + 1 for the length of a space). This would mean that the start selected is greater than the current textPosition, so that word would be classified as selected by the user.

For the next word of our loop, we would end up with a textPosition of 9 because weâ€™ve added the length of the word â€œJoeâ€ and 1 for the space. Even though there is no space in the string after â€œJoeâ€, this does not matter for our checks and saves us unnecessarily complicating our logic. At this point, the current text position would be 9, which would be greater than the startSelection value - this would mean that we are currently at the word that is selected by the user, so we can return it.

if (textPosition >= startSelection) return currentWord

However, if no word is found that is selected then we still want to return a value - so weâ€™ll return null outside of our loop.

return null

Now that our composable is able to infer the selected word from our TextFieldValue reference, weâ€™re going to look at composing our Mentions composable. Before we can do this though, weâ€™re going to need a reference to a Contact list to pass to our Mentions. This is currently a part of our ConversationState, so weâ€™ll need to pass this in from our parent composable. Weâ€™ll start here by adding a new List<Contact> argument to our InputBar composable function.

InputBar.kt

@Composable
fun InputBar(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    sendMessage: (message: String) -> Unit,
    contacts: List<Contact>
)

Followed by passing the contacts value from our state within our Conversation composable.

Conversation.kt

InputBar(
	modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
	sendMessage = { message ->
		handleEvent(ConversationEvent.SendMessage(message))
	},
	contacts = state.contacts
)

With this in place, we can no compose a minimal implementation of our Mentions composable. Here we:

  • enforce the composable to fill the maximum width that is available to it using the fillMaxWidth modifier.
  • provide the list of Contact types that are passed in from the parent composable
  • use our selectedWord function to provide a query for the mentions bar
Mentions(
	modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
	contacts = contacts,
	query = selectedWord(textState)
) { result ->
                
}

We can then compose this inside of our InputBar composable above the Divider that is used for our TextField.

@Composable
fun InputBar(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    sendMessage: (message: String) -> Unit,
    contacts: List<Contact>
) {
    var textState by remember { 
		mutableStateOf(TextFieldValue()) 
	}
    Column(modifier = modifier) {
		Mentions(
			modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
            contacts,
            selectedWord(textState)
        ) { result ->
                
        }
        Divider()
        TextField(
            modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
            value = textState,
			onValueChange = {
                textState = it
            },
            placeholder = {
                Text(
					text = stringResource(id = R.string.hint_send_message), 
					color = Color.Gray
				)
            },
            colors = TextFieldDefaults.textFieldColors(
                backgroundColor = MaterialTheme.colors.surface
            ),
            trailingIcon = {
                IconButton(
                    onClick = {
						sendMessage(textState.text)
                        textState = TextFieldValue()
                    },
                    enabled = textState.text.isNotEmpty()
                ) {
                	Icon(
                		imageVector = Icons.Default.Send,
                		contentDescription = stringResource(
							id = R.string.cd_send_message),
                    	tint = if (
							textState.text.isNotEmpty()) {
                    		MaterialTheme.colors.primary
                   		} else {
                    		MaterialTheme.colors.onSurface
								.copy(alpha = ContentAlpha.disabled)
                  		}
                	)
            	}
        	}
    	)
    }
}

Weâ€™ll come to implementing the onMentionClicked shortly, weâ€™re first going to look at conditional composition for our Mentions composable. Weâ€™re not always going to want this to be composed within our UI, weâ€™re only going to want it shown when the user is entering (or has selected) a word that begins with the â€œ@â€œ character.

To show and hide the mentions bar accordingly, weâ€™re going to first need to define some logic that will depict the visibility of the bar. To start here, weâ€™re going to utilise derivedStateOf - this allows us to calculate some state based on the values of other state within our composable. Here weâ€™ll simply add a statement that will return whether or not the currently entered value in the input bar is empty or not. We donâ€™t want to show the mentions bar if there is no content currently entered, so this will ensure that the bar is always displayed when expected. 

val showMentions by derivedStateOf {
	textState.text.isNotEmpty()
}

This alone though isnâ€™t quite enough - our mentions bar will always compose the contacts that are provided to it but from our InputBar composable weâ€™re only going to want to display mentions under specific conditions. We're going to create a new function, inputShouldTriggerSuggestions inside of our textUtils.kt file that will help us with this.

textUtils.kt

fun inputShouldTriggerSuggestions(
    contacts: List<Contact>,
    query: String?
) = query != null && query.startsWith('@') && 
	!contacts.any { it.name == stripMentionSymbol(query) }

Here, the query will represent the currently selected word within our input field. Based on that input, we have a couple of checks to determine if the mentions bar should be displayed:

  • if the provided query is null then it means there is no input, so we donâ€™t want to show the mentions bar
  • if the query does not start with the â€œ@â€œ character, we donâ€™t want too how the mentions bar
  • if the query (without the â€œ@â€œ symbol), matches the name of the contact completely, then weâ€™re not going to want to show the mentions bar if the contact name has been fully entered. For example, if I have entered â€œ@Joeâ€ then I donâ€™t need the contacts bar to show me the autocomplete for the â€œJoeâ€ contact.

With this in place, we can now add this to our derived showMentions state. This means that now, showMentions will be calculated based on not only the empty state of the entered text but also whether the currently selected word matches the requirements that are defined by our inputShouldTriggerSuggestions function.

val showMentions by derivedStateOf {
	textState.text.isNotEmpty() && 
		inputShouldTriggerSuggestions(contacts, selectedWord(textState))
}

We can then place this state within our InputBar composable and use it to conditional compose our Mentions composable.

@Composable
fun InputBar(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    sendMessage: (message: String) -> Unit,
    contacts: List<Contact>
) {
    Column(modifier = modifier) {
		var textState by remember { 
			mutableStateOf(TextFieldValue()) 
		}
		val showMentions by derivedStateOf {
        	textState.text.isNotEmpty() && 
				matchesContact(contacts, selectedWord(textState))
    	}
		if (showMentions) {
			Mentions(
				modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
            	contacts = contacts,
            	query = selectedWord(textState)
        	) { result ->
            	   
        	}
		}
        Divider()
        ...
    }
}

At this point, we havenâ€™t implemented the onMentionClicked lambda which will be used to handle completing the input for the selected contact name within the input field. For this, weâ€™re going to need to adjust the content of our TextFieldValue and have this reflected in the composition of our TextField. Because weâ€™re autocompleting text for the selected contact, we canâ€™t simply just append the contact name to our text input - this could also happen at any point within our input string, not just necessarily at the end. Weâ€™re going to need to define a bit of logic here, so weâ€™ll go ahead and create a new extension function for TextFieldValue - using an extension function here allows us to directly manipulate the content of our TextFieldValue reference.

This function is going to need to know where it should start the replacement, where it should end it, as well as the content that should be used during the replacement. 

fun TextFieldValue.replaceText(
    start: Int,
    end: Int,
    replaceWith: String
): TextFieldValue {

}

Weâ€™re going to start here by replacing the text within the given range with the content that is to be used in the replacement process, replaceWith. Here weâ€™ll use the Kotlin replaceRange function to replace the content of our current text represented at the start value.

fun TextFieldValue.replaceText(
    start: Int,
    end: Int,
    replaceWith: String
): TextFieldValue {
    val newText = this.text.replaceRange(
        start,
        end,
        replaceWith
    )
}

Next ,we need to ensure that the selection of the TextFieldValue is set correctly. Weâ€™ve replaced some range of our text with a new value that could be longer than the previous text that existed, so weâ€™ll need to update the selection accordingly. For this weâ€™ll calculate what the selection would be for the end of the new word that was inserted - this will be equal to the start value with the addition of the length of the replaced text. Well then use this calculated value to create a TextRange instance to provide to our TextFieldValue.

fun TextFieldValue.replaceText(
    start: Int,
    end: Int,
    replaceWith: String
): TextFieldValue {
    val newText = this.text.replaceRange(
        start,
        end,
        replaceWith
    )
    val endOfNewWord = start + replaceWith.length
	val range = TextRange(endOfNewWord, endOfNewWord)
}

With the above in place, we can now use these calculated values to return a modified version of the TextFieldValue that is currently being accessed. Here weâ€™ll use the copy function so that we can create a copied installed, overriding the values that we desire. Here weâ€™ll pass our newText value that represents our modified version of the text value, along with the TextRange instance that we created above that will be used to state the currently selected from the TextFieldValue.

fun TextFieldValue.replaceText(
    start: Int,
    end: Int,
    replaceWith: String
): TextFieldValue {
    val newText = this.text.replaceRange(
        start,
        end,
        replaceWith
    )
    val endOfNewWord = start + replaceWith.length
    val range = TextRange(endOfNewWord, endOfNewWord)

    return this.copy(text = newText, selection = range)
}

With this in place, we now have a function that can be called when a Contact is selected from our Mentions composable to modify the current state of our input field.

@Composable
fun InputBar(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    sendMessage: (message: String) -> Unit,
    contacts: List<Contact>
) {
    Column(modifier = modifier) {
		var textState by remember { 
			mutableStateOf(TextFieldValue()) 
		}
		val showMentions by derivedStateOf {
        	textState.text.isNotEmpty() && 
				matchesContact(contacts, selectedWord(textState))
    	}
		if (showMentions) {
			Mentions(
				modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
            	contacts = contacts,
            	query = selectedWord(textState)
        	) { result ->
            	query?.let {
                    textState = textState.replaceText(
                        ...
                    )
                }   
        	}
		}
        Divider()
        ...
    }
}

We still need to provide values for the required arguments of our input.

  • start: this is going to be the start index of the current word that we want to replace
  • end: this is going to be the end index of the current word
  • replaceWith: this is going to represent the name of the contact that was selected

With the above in mind, this means that weâ€™ll be inserting a new word to replace the word within the provided start and end indexes. Even if the new word is longer than the one being replaced, the content outside of those indexes will be untouched.

Before we can do this weâ€™ll need to modify the onMentionClicked lambda for our Mentions composable. Weâ€™re going to need the currently selected word to calculate the indexes mentioned above (which are represented by the query argument), so weâ€™ll pass this back up to the parent to save us fetching it again.

@Composable
fun Mentions(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    contacts: List<Contact>,
    query: String?,
    onMentionClicked: (query: String?, mention: String) -> Unit
)

We can then modify the point where we call onMentionClicked to pass back the query value. Now even though the Mentions composable declares this as a nullable type, at the point where our lambda is triggered this will never be null. So here weâ€™ll use the !! operation as it saves the parent needing to add null safety that isnâ€™t required.

.clickable(onClickLabel = clickLabel) {
	onMentionClicked(query!!, "@${contact.name}")
}

Now within the implementation of onMentionClicked, we can satisfy the requirements for the replaceText function call. Weâ€™ll need to start by getting the index for the provided query value - this will return us the starting index of the selected word, which we can then pass to the start argument of the replaceText function. Next, the end is going to be calculated by using this startIndex and adding the length of the query value. These two calculations will give us the range of our selected word within the current representation of the TextFieldValue text. Finally, for replaceWith, we will simply pass result, which is the contact that was selected from our Mentions composable.

Mentions(
	modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
	contacts = contacts,
	query = selectedWord(textState)
) { query, result ->
	val startIndex = textState.text.indexOf(query)
	textState = textState.replaceText(
		start = startIndex,
		end = startIndex + query.length, 
		replaceWith = result
	)   
}

With the above implementation, we can slot this into our InputBar composable.

@Composable
fun InputBar(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    sendMessage: (message: String) -> Unit,
    contacts: List<Contact>
) {
    Column(modifier = modifier) {
		var textState by remember { 
			mutableStateOf(TextFieldValue()) 
		}
		val showMentions by derivedStateOf {
        	textState.text.isNotEmpty() && 
				matchesContact(contacts, selectedWord(textState))
    	}
		if (showMentions) {
			Mentions(
				modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
            	contacts = contacts,
            	query = selectedWord(textState)
        	) { query, result ->
            	val startIndex = textState.text.indexOf(query)
                textState = textState.replaceText(
                    start = startIndex,
                    end = startIndex + query.length, 
					replaceWith = result
                )   
        	}
		}
        Divider()
        ...
    }
}

With this in place, weâ€™ll now be able to view autocomplete options for our given Contact instances, allowing us to @ mention these contacts within our message input. Once the contacts are displayed, selecting a contact will now add this to the message content.

Supporting Mention Highlighting

Now that weâ€™ve added @ mentions to our InputBar composable, our user can mention contacts within the chat. In apps that support this kind of behaviour, itâ€™s usual to highlight these words that have been entered for @ mentions or similar things (such as hashtags). To be able to support this weâ€™re going to need to build a function that will take our string and format in a way that applies highlighting to words that start with the @ symbol.

Weâ€™ll create a new function, buildAnnotatedStringWithColor, that will take some text as well as a color that will be used when highlighting any @ mentions. The process to do this will involve using an AnnotatedString, which we will also need to return from the function. This AnnotatedString class is used to construct a text that contains multiple types of styling.

fun buildAnnotatedStringWithColor(
	text: String, 
	color: Color
): AnnotatedString {

}

Within this function weâ€™re going to need to loop through the words that are contained within text, this is so that we can check which ones are @ mentions and style them accordingly. Weâ€™ll start by using the kotlin split function to split up our text using a space delimiter.

fun buildAnnotatedStringWithColor(
	text: String, 
	color: Color
): AnnotatedString {
	val words: List<String> = text.split(" ")
}

Now that we have our list of words, we are ready to start building our styled string. We need to start here by creating a new AnnotatedString Builder - this will allow us to build a string word by word with the corresponding styling.

fun buildAnnotatedStringWithColor(
	text: String, 
	color: Color
): AnnotatedString {
	val words: List<String> = text.split(" ")

	val builder = AnnotatedString.Builder()
}

With this builder in place, we can loop through our words to start building the string. Weâ€™re going to use the forEachIndexed operation here, as weâ€™re going to need access to the current index of the loop soon. 

fun buildAnnotatedStringWithColor(
	text: String, 
	color: Color
): AnnotatedString {
	val words: List<String> = text.split(" ")

	val builder = AnnotatedString.Builder()
	words.forEachIndexed { index, word ->
        
    }
}

With this loop in place, we can append our first word to the builder instance. Here, weâ€™re going to check if the current word starts with an @ symbol - if so, this is an @ mention so weâ€™re going to want to style it accordingly. Here weâ€™re going to use the withStyle on our AnnotatedString.Builder that allows us to apply a style before appending a word. For the style of this function, weâ€™re going to provide an instance of the SpanStyle class, passing the color argument that was provided to our function. Then when we call append within the block of withStyle, our word will be appended to the builder with the SpanStyle styling applied to it.

fun buildAnnotatedStringWithColor(
	text: String, 
	color: Color
): AnnotatedString {
	val words: List<String> = text.split(" ")

	val builder = AnnotatedString.Builder()
	words.forEachIndexed { index, word ->
        if (word.startsWith("@")) {
            builder.withStyle(
				style = SpanStyle(color = color)
			) {
                append(word)
            }
        }
    }
}

Otherwise, if the word does not start with an @ symbol then we will simply use the append function to append the current word to our builder. Here we are not applying any kind of styling because the word is not an @-mention, so the word will be added un-styled.

fun buildAnnotatedStringWithColor(
	text: String, 
	color: Color
): AnnotatedString {
	val words: List<String> = text.split(" ")

	val builder = AnnotatedString.Builder()
	words.forEachIndexed { index, word ->
        if (word.startsWith("@")) {
            builder.withStyle(
				style = SpanStyle(color = color)
			) {
                append(word)
            }
        } else {
            builder.append(word)
        }
    }
}

After appending each word weâ€™re going to want to add back the spaces in-between each word that was removed during our split operation - this is where the index value is going to come in useful. If we are not at the last word within our words list during the loop, then weâ€™ll want to append a space (â€œ â€œ) to our builder.

fun buildAnnotatedStringWithColor(
	text: String, 
	color: Color
): AnnotatedString {
	val words: List<String> = text.split(" ")

	val builder = AnnotatedString.Builder()
	words.forEachIndexed { index, word ->
        if (word.startsWith("@")) {
            builder.withStyle(
				style = SpanStyle(color = color)
			) {
                append(word)
            }
        } else {
            builder.append(word)
        }
		if (index < words.count() - 1) builder.append(" ")
    }
}

At this point we have a function that is looping through each of the words in our text argument, styling each one accordingly. All that is left to do now is to return an AnnotatedString from the function, which we can do by calling toAnnotatedString() on our AnnotatedString.Builder reference that we have been using to construct our highlighted content.

fun buildAnnotatedStringWithColor(
	text: String, 
	color: Color
): AnnotatedString {
	val words: List<String> = text.split(" ")

	val builder = AnnotatedString.Builder()
	words.forEachIndexed { index, word ->
        if (word.startsWith("@")) {
            builder.withStyle(
				style = SpanStyle(color = color)
			) {
                append(word)
            }
        } else {
            builder.append(word)
        }
		if (index < words.count() - 1) builder.append(" ")
    }
	return builder.toAnnotatedString()
}

With this function in place, weâ€™re not going to apply it to two of our composables so that @ mentions can be highlighted. Weâ€™ll start by highlighting the content within the MessageBody composable that we created earlier. That way, any mentions will be highlighted in the messages that are shown with our UI. Instead of directly passing the message value from our Message into the Text composable, weâ€™re going to use our buildAnnotatedStringWithColor function to provide the value here instead. When calling this function weâ€™ll pass the message value from the Message reference, along with the primary color from the theme of our app.

MessageBody.kt

@Composable
fun MessageBody(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    message: Message
) {
    if (message.message != null) {
        Text(
            modifier = modifier,
            text = buildAnnotatedStringWithColor(
                text = message.message,
                color = MaterialTheme.colors.primary
            )
        )
    } else if (message.image != null) {
        Image(
            modifier = modifier.size(120.dp),
            bitmap = message.image.asImageBitmap(),
            contentDescription = message.altText
        )
    }
}

With this in place, we can now see @ mentions being highlighted within the body of our messages.

Next, weâ€™re going to highlight the @ mentions when they are being entered into the message input bar, so weâ€™ll need to hop over to our InputBar composable. Because weâ€™re working with a TextField composable here, things are going to look a little different. Instead, weâ€™ll need to provide a way to style the current input of the TextField using its visualTransformation argument, in the form of a VisualTransformation type. Here weâ€™re going to create our own implementation of a VisualTransformation that will allow us to apply our mention highlighting. Weâ€™ll create a new class, MentionHighlightTransformation, implementing the VisualTransformation interface. When implementing this interface, weâ€™ll need to override the filter function.

class MentionHighlightTransformation() : VisualTransformation {

    override fun filter(
		text: AnnotatedString
	): TransformedText {
        ...
    }
}

Before we can go on any further and add the use of our buildAnnotatedStringWithColors function, we know that this is going to need a color. To keep our new class flexible, weâ€™ll allow for a Color to be passed in via the class constructor.

class MentionHighlightTransformation(
	private val color: Color
)

Next, weâ€™ll need to implement the body of the filter function so that the instance of a TransformedText can be returned. For this, we need to provide the transformed text to be contained in the class. For this, weâ€™re going to use the buildAnnotatedStringWithColor function to build a value. The filter function provides us with the text from our input field as an argument, so weâ€™ll pass this directly to our buildAnnotatedStringWithColor function. Weâ€™ll also pass the color that is provided via the constructor of our MentionHighlightTransformation class.

class MentionHighlightTransformation(
	private val color: Color
) : VisualTransformation {

    override fun filter(
		text: AnnotatedString
	): TransformedText {
        return TransformedText(
            buildAnnotatedStringWithColors(
				text.toString(), color),
            OffsetMapping.Identity
        )
    }
}

With this in place, we can provide an instance of our MentionHighlightTransformation class to the visualTransformation argument, providing the primary color of our theme for the color argument in the MentionHighlightTransformation constructor.

// InputBar.kt

@Composable
fun InputBar(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
