    sendMessage: (message: String) -> Unit,
    contacts: List<Contact>
) {
    ...
    Column(modifier = modifier) {
        ...
        TextField(
            modifier = Modifier
                .fillMaxWidth()
                .weight(1f),
            visualTransformation = MentionHighlightTransformation(
				MaterialTheme.colors.primary),
            ...
        )
    }
}

class MentionHighlightTransformation(
	private val color: Color
) : VisualTransformation {

    override fun filter(
		text: AnnotatedString
	): TransformedText {
        return TransformedText(
            buildAnnotatedStringWithColors(
				text.toString(), color),
            OffsetMapping.Identity
        )
    }
}

Now when using @ mentions inside of our TextField, weâ€™ll be able to see these highlighted via our custom visualTransformation.

Deleting Messages

At this point, we have a pretty functional messaging UI that allows the user to view a collection of messages, as well as compose messages to send while also being able to tag contacts. After sending messages though, a user might want to remove what they sent, deleting their message from the chat. To support this weâ€™re going to add a small piece of functionality that allows that user to select a message and delete it from the conversation.

Within our ConversationState there is the selectedMessage field - this is what weâ€™re going to be using to allow the user to perform this delete action on a given message. Currently, though, weâ€™re never actually setting this field - before we can display the options that allow the user to perform actions on a message, theyâ€™ll need to be a message assigned to this selectedMessage property. To support this, weâ€™re going to add long-press gesture detection to the message items in our list

Weâ€™ll start here by adding a new lambda argument to our Message composable, allowing us to pass these long-press events up to the parent composable. When we trigger this, weâ€™ll simply pass the id of the message that has been selected by the user.

@Composable
fun Message(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    message: Message,
    onLongPress: (id: String) -> Unit
)

Then, weâ€™re going to need to modifier the pointerInput modifier implementation that we previously put in place. We are currently only providing an implementation for the onTap gesture, so weâ€™re going to extend this and also add an implementation for the onLongPress gesture. Weâ€™re going to only allow the user to trigger actions on messages that theyâ€™ve sent, as being able to delete a message that theyâ€™ve received isnâ€™t a common UX pattern. So here, if the given direction of the message is equal to MessageDirection.SENT, weâ€™ll trigger the provided onLongPress lambda and pass the id of the selected message.

// Message.kt

Column(modifier = parentModifier
	.pointerInput(Unit) {
		detectTapGestures(
			onLongPress = {
				if (
					message.direction == MessageDirection.SENT
				) {
                        onLongPress(message.id)
                    }
                },
                onTap = { ... }
            )
        }
) {
	...
}

The parent of the Message composable is the Messages composable - while we will be receiving this onLongPress event, there wonâ€™t be any way to handle it here. The Messages composable isnâ€™t hooked into the event functions that we have in place for other composables, so weâ€™ll again need to pass this up to the next parent where it can be handled. So here, weâ€™ll also need to add a new lambda argument to the Messages composable which will match what we previously added to Message.

// Messages.kt

@Composable
fun Messages(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    messages: List<Message>? = null,
    onMessageSelected: (messageId: String) -> Unit
)

With this in place, we can now implement the onLongPress lambda during the composition of our Message composable, followed by using this to trigger the onMessageSelected. Here weâ€™ll directly pass the id of the message that was received from the lambda.

// Messages.kt

items(entry.value) { message ->
	Message(
		modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
		message = message,
		onLongPress = { messageId ->
			onMessageSelected(messageId)
		}
	)
}

Finally, weâ€™ll then need to implement the onMessageSelected at the point we compose Messages, which is being done within the Conversation composable. Here within the body of onMessageSelected, weâ€™ll want to trigger the handleEvent lambda that the Conversation composable has access to, triggering the SelectMessage event which we instantiate using the received message id.

// Conversation.kt

Messages(
	modifier = Modifier.fillMaxSize().weight(1f),
	messages = state.messages,
	onMessageSelected = { messageId ->
    	handleEvent(ConversationEvent.SelectMessage(messageId))
    }
)

With all of the above in place, we now have an implementation that allows for a user to mark a message as selected - it is at this point that we will need to show some form of UI to reflect this. Here weâ€™re going to create a new composable function, MessageActions, which will be used to display the available actions to the user. Weâ€™ll add three arguments to our composable function here:

  • modifier: the modifier that will be used to apply modifications to the actions composable
  • onDismiss: a lambda that will be triggered when the dialog is dismissed. This will allow us to remove the currently selected message from our state
  • onUnsendMessage: for now, our dialog will only be supporting the ability to trigger an unsend message event. This lambda will allow us to pass this event up to the parent.
@Composable
fun MessageActions(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    onDismiss: () -> Unit,
    onUnsendMessage: () -> Unit
)

Inside of this, weâ€™re going to compose a Dialog. This is a composable from the compose UI package that allows us to show a system dialog to users, which is intended to sit on top of all other content on the screen. When composed in this way, an overlay will be used to bring focus to the dialog on the screen.

@Composable
fun MessageActions(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    onDismiss: () -> Unit,
    onUnsendMessage: () -> Unit
) {
    Dialog(
        onDismissRequest = {
            ...
        }
    ) {
        
    }
}

The Dialog composable has two required arguments, onDismissRequest and content. The second, content is used to provide a composable which we want to be used for the composition of the dialog body. On the other hand, onDismissRequest is used to handle any requests to dismiss the dialog - which must be handled to ensure that our UI is recomposed without the dialog. Here weâ€™ll simply trigger the onDismiss lambda that is provided to our MessageActions composable.

@Composable
fun MessageActions(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    onDismiss: () -> Unit,
    onUnsendMessage: () -> Unit
) {
    Dialog(
        onDismissRequest = {
            onDismiss()
        }
    ) {
        
    }
}

Next, we can move on to composing the content area of our Dialog. Weâ€™re only going to be showing a single child here, so it will suffice to compose a Box here. For this, weâ€™ll also want to set the background using the surface color from our application theme.

@Composable
fun MessageActions(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    onDismiss: () -> Unit,
    onUnsendMessage: () -> Unit
) {
    Dialog(
        onDismissRequest = {
            onDismiss()
        }
    ) {
        Box(
            modifier = modifier
                .background(MaterialTheme.colors.surface)
        ) {
            
        }
    }
}

Within this box, weâ€™re going to add a single button that will be used to trigger the unsend message event. This button is going to need to portray that action to the user, so weâ€™ll need to start by adding a new string to our strings.xml resource file to represent this.

<string name="action_unsend_message">Unsend Message</string>

Within our Box we can then go ahead and compose a TextButton. This button will be used to display an action to the user in the form of the unsend message action. Here weâ€™ll need to provide an implementation for onClick, along with the content for the composable body. Within onClick weâ€™ll simply want to trigger the onUnsendMessage lambda that is provided to our composable function.

Within the content weâ€™ll want to provide the composable that is to be composed inside of our TextButton. Here weâ€™re going to compose a Text composable, followed by providing the string resource that we defined above for the text argument of this. 

@Composable
fun MessageActions(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    onDismiss: () -> Unit,
    onUnsendMessage: () -> Unit
) {
    Dialog(
        onDismissRequest = {
            onDismiss()
        }
    ) {
        Box(
            modifier = modifier
                .background(MaterialTheme.colors.surface)
        ) {
            TextButton(onClick = {
                onUnsendMessage()
            }) {
                Text(text = stringResource(
					id = R.string.action_unsend_message))
            }
        }
    }
}

At this point, we have a Dialog composable that can be used to display the unsend message action within our UI.

As we can see though, the constraints of this dialog feel a little small within our UI. We can improve things here by applying some sizing modifiers to our Box composable. Weâ€™ll use the sizeIn modifier to apply some minimum constraints to our composable. Because we are now modifying the size of our composable, weâ€™ll also need to ensure that any content inside of it is correctly aligned. Here weâ€™ll use the contentAlignment argument of the Box to apply the Alignment.Center value to align the content into the center.

@Composable
fun MessageActions(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    onDismiss: () -> Unit,
    onUnsendMessage: () -> Unit
) {
    Dialog(
        onDismissRequest = {
            onDismiss()
        }
    ) {
        Box(
            modifier = modifier
                .background(MaterialTheme.colors.surface)
                .sizeIn(minWidth = 280.dp, minHeight = 80.dp),
            contentAlignment = Alignment.Center
        ) {
            TextButton(onClick = {
                onUnsendMessage()
            }) {
                Text(text = stringResource(
					id = R.string.action_unsend_message))
            }
        }
    }
}

We can see now that these additional sizing constraints complement the composition of ourDialog.

With the above built out, we can now add the composition of this inside of our Conversation composable. Weâ€™ll want to compose this outside of the existing Column composable so that it appears on top of the screen content. When composing our MessageActions this will need to be conditional, as we only want it to be displayed to the user if there is currently a selected message. Here weâ€™ll use the selectedMessage property from our ConversationState to have conditional composition, only composing our MessageActions if a message is currently selected.

When composing these MessageActions weâ€™ll need to implement both the onDismiss and onUnsendMessage arguments. Both of these are going to be minimal work, as weâ€™ll just need to call the handleEvent lambda that is provided to our Conversation composable.

For onDismiss weâ€™ll want to trigger the UnselectMessage event. We donâ€™t need to require any arguments to this object, as this will simply remove the currently selected message from the state. For onUnsendMessage weâ€™ll trigger the UnsendMessage event, passing the id of the currently selected message in our state. This will remove the message from our messages list, triggering recomposition and removing it from our UI.

@Composable
fun Conversation(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    state: ConversationState,
    handleEvent: (event: ConversationEvent) -> Unit
) {
    Column(
        modifier = modifier
    ) {
        Header(
            modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
            onClose = {
                // finish activity
            }
        )
        Messages(
            modifier = Modifier.weight(1f),
            messages = state.messages,
            handleEvent
        )
        InputBar(
            modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
            handleEvent,
            state.contacts
        )
    }
    if (state.selectedMessage != null) {
        MessageActions(
            onDismiss = {
                handleEvent(ConversationEvent.UnselectMessage)
            },
            onUnsendMessage = {
                handleEvent(ConversationEvent.UnsendMessage(
					state.selectedMessage.id))
            }
        )
    }
}

With this now added to the composition for our Conversation composable, our users will now be able to trigger message actions from the messages list - currently allowing them to unsend a message.

Improving the Message Accessibility

While weâ€™ve added support for unsending a message, as well viewing the sent time for a message in a conversation, these features arenâ€™t currently accessible to users who might interact with the project via accessibility services. In this section, weâ€™re going to spend a small amount of time improving the accessibility for these pieces of functionality.

Supporting Accessibility actions

Weâ€™re going to start here by adding support for a CustomAccessibilityAction to the messages in the conversation. This means that users who have talkback enabled will be able to trigger the Unsend Message action natively through the accessibility actions menu. We can provide these customActions via the semantics modifier.

When creating a CustomAccessibilityAction to show via the accessibility actions menu, we need to provide a label that will be displayed for the action. Weâ€™ll start here by retrieving the existing action_unsend_message string resource that weâ€™re using in our MessageActions composable.

// Messages.kt

items(entry.value) { message ->
	val unSendMessageLabel = stringResource(id = R.string.action_unsend_message)
	
	Message(
		...
    )
}

Next, weâ€™ll use this string resource to create a CustomAccessibilityAction instance, providing it to the semantics customActions property in the form of a list.

// Messages.kt

items(entry.value) { message ->
	val unSendMessageLabel = stringResource(id = R.string.action_unsend_message)
	
	Message(
		Modifier
			.semantics {
				customActions = listOf(
					CustomAccessibilityAction(
						unSendMessageLabel
					) {
                        ...
                        true
                    }
                )
            }
            .fillMaxWidth(),
        message = message,
        onLongPress = { messageId ->
        	onMessageSelected(messageId)
        }
    )
}

Youâ€™ll notice here that we havenâ€™t yet implemented the action of the CustomAccessibilityAction, we are just returning true to indicate that we have handled the action. To support the unsending of a message here, weâ€™ll need a new lambda argument for our Messages composable that can be used to pass this event up to the parent composable.

// Messages.kt

@Composable
fun Messages(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    messages: List<Message>? = null,
    onMessageSelected: (messageId: String) -> Unit,
    unSendMessage: (messageId: String) -> Unit
)

We canâ€™t hen trigger this lambda within the action of our CustomAccessibilityAction, passing the id of the message that the action has been invoked on.

// Messages.kt

items(entry.value) { message ->
	val unSendMessageLabel = stringResource(id = R.string.action_unsend_message)
	Message(
		Modifier
			.semantics {
				customActions = listOf(
					CustomAccessibilityAction(
						unSendMessageLabel
					) {
                        unSendMessage(message.id)
                        true
                    }
                )
            }
            .fillMaxWidth(),
        message = message,
        onLongPress = { messageId ->
        	onMessageSelected(messageId)
        }
    )
}

This wonâ€™t quite work yet, as weâ€™ll need to implement this lambda argument at the point we are composing our Messages composable. If we hop on over to the Conversation composable then we can implement this lambda, using the provided id of the message to trigger the UnsendMessage action through the handleEvent lambda.

// Conversation.kt

Messages(
	modifier = Modifier.fillMaxSize().weight(1f),
    messages = state.messages,
    onMessageSelected = { messageId ->
    	handleEvent(ConversationEvent.SelectMessage(messageId))
    },
    unSendMessage = { messageId ->
      	handleEvent(ConversationEvent.UnsendMessage(messageId))
    }
)

With this in place, our user will be able to access the unsend message action through the accessibility actions menu.

Communicating the Sent Time

Currently, weâ€™re supporting the toggling of the sent time by tapping the message. To reduce the number of interactions that need to be taken by accessibility services to achieve this, weâ€™re going to incorporate the sent time into the content that is read by talkback. To do this, weâ€™re going to need to reformat the message of the corresponding Message reference to include the sent time, only for use by talkback.

To incorporate this, weâ€™ll need to start by shifting around some of the things that weâ€™ve already defined within our Message composable. First of all, the dateFormat reference that we have will need to be pulled up to a higher point within the composable. Currently, this is only being used for the display of the sent time, which is quite nested within the composable. However, we now need this at a higher point in the composable to be able to utilise it as a semantic property for the Box composable that wraps our MessageBody. Weâ€™ll also need to pull out the format operation that was being directly used for the sent time Text composable, assigning this to a variable reference, formattedSentTime. We can now use this for the text argument of the sent time Text composable, as well as have it available for reuse by our MessageBody composable.

Column(...) {

		...

        val dateFormat = remember {
            SimpleDateFormat("hh:mm")
        }
        val formattedSentTime = 	
			dateFormat.format(message.dateTime.time)
        
        Box(...) {
            ...
        }
        
        AnimatedVisibility(
            modifier = Modifier.align(alignment = alignment),
            visible = displaySentTime
        ) {
            Text(
                modifier = Modifier.padding(top = 4.dp),
                text = formattedSentTime,
                fontSize = 12.sp
            )
        }
    }

Now that we have this formattedSentTime variable, we can utilise this to provide the sent time through the accessibility services. Weâ€™ll start here by defining a new string resource that will act as a template for our sent time and message content.

<string name="message_with_time">%s. %s</string>

Here, the first placeholder (%s) will be used for the sent time. Then after the period, weâ€™ll format the second placeholder as the message content. This way talkback will read out the sent time, followed by the message content. Weâ€™ll go ahead by building a string representation using this description. Weâ€™ll firsts the stringResource composable function to retrieve our resource, followed by providing two string values that will be used to populate the placeholders - these are the sentAt argument that is being provided to our composable, along with the message property of our Message reference.

val messageWithSentTime = stringResource(
	id = R.string.message_with_time,
	formattedSentTime, 
	message.message ?: message.altText ?: ""
)

Next, weâ€™ll override the text semantic property of our composable, creating a new instance of an AnnotatedString from our built messageWithSentTime variable.

Box(	
	modifier = Modifier
		.align(alignment = alignment)
        .semantics {
            text = AnnotatedString(messageWithSentTime)
        }
        .background(
            Color.LightGray,
            RoundedCornerShape(6.dp)
        )
        .padding(8.dp)
) {
	...
}

Now when this composable is described by talkback, our override that we provided to the text semantic will be used within the description of the content. Overall, we should have a composable function that represents something like the following.

@Composable
fun Message(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    message: Message,
    onLongPress: (id: String) -> Unit
) {
    val parentModifier = if (
		message.direction == MessageDirection.SENT
	) {
        modifier.padding(end = 16.dp)
    } else modifier.padding(start = 16.dp)

    var displaySentTime by remember { mutableStateOf(false) }

    Column(modifier = parentModifier
        .pointerInput(Unit) {
            detectTapGestures(
                onLongPress = {
                    if (
						message.direction == MessageDirection.SENT
					) {
                        onLongPress(message.id)
                    }
                },
                onTap = {
                    displaySentTime = !displaySentTime
                }
            )
        }) {

        val alignment = if (
			message.direction == MessageDirection.SENT
		) {
            Alignment.End
        } else Alignment.Start

        val dateFormat = remember {
            SimpleDateFormat("hh:mm")
        }
        val formattedSentTime = dateFormat.format(
			message.dateTime.time)

        val messageWithSentTime = stringResource(
			id = R.string.message_with_time,
            formattedSentTime, 
			message.message ?: message.altText ?: ""
		)
        Box(
            modifier = Modifier
                .align(alignment = alignment)
                .semantics {
                    text = AnnotatedString(messageWithSentTime)
                }
                .background(
                    Color.LightGray,
                    RoundedCornerShape(6.dp)
                )
                .padding(8.dp)
        ) {
            MessageBody(
                modifier = Modifier.align(Alignment.Center),
                message = message
            )
        }

        AnimatedVisibility(
            modifier = Modifier.align(alignment = alignment),
            visible = displaySentTime
        ) {
            Text(
                modifier = Modifier.padding(top = 4.dp),
                text = formattedSentTime,
                fontSize = 12.sp
            )
        }
    }
}

Always displaying the latest Message

At this point, we have a pretty functional messaging UI, but thereâ€™s one final tweak that I want us to make. Currently, when you send a message within the UI, youâ€™ll need to scroll to view that message when really, the UI should update to automatically scroll to the bottom of the message list. This means that the latest message will always be visible to the user. To achieve this, weâ€™re going to need to tweak some of the approaches that weâ€™ve previously put in place for the display of messages.

When it comes to always showing the latest message in the conversation, weâ€™re going to want to display the last item in the list. However, this isnâ€™t a straightforward operation - while we can perform a scroll event to the last item in the list, we donâ€™t know the height of that item, so we would need to calculate an offset to be applied after the scroll has taken place. This feels overly complex, so instead, weâ€™re going to utilise the reverseLayout argument of the LazyColumn composable to help us achieve this.

But why would we want to reverse the list of messages? Well, if the list of messages has been reversed, then we can scroll to the item position 0 in the list without needing to worry about any kind of offsetting based on height. 

LazyColumn(
	modifier = modifier,
	state = rememberLazyListState(),
	reverseLayout = true,
	contentPadding = PaddingValues(top = 8.dp, bottom = 8.dp),
	verticalArrangement = Arrangement.spacedBy(16.dp)
)

Now that the list is reversed, weâ€™ll notice that the message items within the conversation are now being displayed in the wrong order - this is because the reverseLayout argument is flipping the presentation of these items. To fix this, weâ€™re going to modify our groupMessagesByDate function so that the sortedByDescending operation is used to sort the messages by the time that the message was sent.

fun groupMessagesByDate(
    messages: List<Message>
): Map<Calendar, List<Message>> {
    return messages
        .sortedByDescending {
            it.dateTime.timeInMillis
        }
        .groupBy {
            it.dateTime.apply {
                set(Calendar.HOUR_OF_DAY, 0)
                set(Calendar.MINUTE, 0)
                set(Calendar.SECOND, 0)
                set(Calendar.MILLISECOND, 0)
            }
        }
}

At this point the messages will be displayed in the correct order, but because weâ€™ve now reversed the layout of our items the sticky headers are being displayed at the bottom of each message group. This is a simple fix as we just need to re-order the declarations of the items and stickyHeader - this means that now each of the header items will be displayed at the top of each message group, corresponding with the now reversed item layout.

grouped.onEach { entry ->

	items(entry.value) { message ->
		...
	}

	stickyHeader {
		...
	}

}

Now that the layout ordering of our list is in place, weâ€™re going to want to take a look at triggering the scrolling to the latest message whenever the messages that are provided to our composable function are changed. For this we can utilise the LaunchedEffect side-effect, allowing us to trigger some logic at the time of composition, conditionally.

When LaunchedEffect enters the composition, it will execute the block implementation that is provided to it. However, we only want to run this when the messages have changed - otherwise we might be executing this scroll action when it doesnâ€™t need to be. For this, the LaunchedEffect also takes a key - this allows us to provide a value that will be used to determine if the side-effect should be run, which will only be the case when the key value changes. For this, we can declare the LaunchedEffect side-effect, passing the messages reference for the key.

@Composable
fun Messages(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    messages: List<Message>? = null,
    onMessageSelected: (messageId: String) -> Unit
) {
    if (messages.isNullOrEmpty()) {
        EmptyConversation(
            modifier = Modifier.fillMaxSize()
        )
    } else {
        ...
        LaunchedEffect(messages) {
            ...
        }
    }
}

With this declared, we can now add the logic that will be used to trigger the scrolling of our list. For this, weâ€™ll need to access our LazyListState reference from within our side-effect, so weâ€™ll want to pull out the rememberLazyListState usage from our LazyColumn and store the result in a state variable reference. This means that we can then utilise the scrollToItem function from the LazyListState class, providing the index of the first item within the messages list - we use the first item here because the layout of our items has been reversed via the reverseLayout argument.

@Composable
fun Messages(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    messages: List<Message>? = null,
    onMessageSelected: (messageId: String) -> Unit
) {
    if (messages.isNullOrEmpty()) {
        EmptyConversation(
            modifier = Modifier.fillMaxSize()
        )
    } else {
        val state = rememberLazyListState()
        val grouped = groupMessagesByDate(messages)
        LazyColumn(
            modifier = modifier,
            state = state,
			reverseLayout = true,
            contentPadding = PaddingValues(
				top = 8.dp, 
				bottom = 8.dp
			),
            verticalArrangement = Arrangement.spacedBy(16.dp)
        ) { ... }
        LaunchedEffect(messages) {
            state.scrollToItem(0)
        }
    }
}

With this in place, weâ€™ll be able to send a message within our UI and see that the list is now automatically scrolled to the bottom, displaying the latest message. With this in place, our user will now always be viewing the latest message for the given conversation whenever a message is sent or received within the conversation feed.

Wrapping Up

Throughout this project, weâ€™ve now fully implemented our messaging feature - allowing our users to view the messages in a current conversation, manage those messages, as well as send new messages via the input bar. Weâ€™ve explored the composition of many different UI components, along with some intricate logic for handling @-mentions within our project.

With all of this in place, weâ€™ll want to ensure these components remain functional within our app. In the next chapter, weâ€™re going to explore writing automated UI tests for these composables.

Testing the Messaging UI

Now that weâ€™ve built our Messaging feature, weâ€™re going to take a look at how we can write tests for our composables. Weâ€™re going to be writing some instrumentation tests using the compose ui-test-junit package - allowing us to verify that our composables are displayed and functioning as expected.

Before we can get started with our tests, weâ€™re going to need to add a couple of test specific dependencies to our project:

androidTestImplementation(
	"androidx.compose.ui:ui-test-junit4:$compose_version")
debugImplementation(
	"androidx.compose.ui:ui-test-manifest:$compose_version")

Weâ€™re also going to need to add mocks to our test - this allows us to easily provide mock references to any listeners that are provided to our composable functions, allowing us to easily verify they are triggered whenever expected.

androidTestImplementation(
	"org.mockito.kotlin:mockito-kotlin:3.2.0")
androidTestImplementation("org.mockito:mockito-android:3.12.4")

With these in place, we now have access to the required rules and functionality that allow us to test our composable UI. However, alongside these dependencies, weâ€™re also going to need to add some rules to our build.gradle file that will fix some of the compilation errors that weâ€™d currently see when trying to run our tests. Here weâ€™ll add some packagingOptions that will exclude certain packages from the added dependencies. We wonâ€™t dive too much into this concept and itâ€™s usually dependant on the versions of dependencies that are being used, so this may be redundant if you come to updating versions.

android {
	packagingOptions {
		exclude "**/attach_hotspot_windows.dll"
		exclude "META-INF/AL2.0"
		exclude "META-INF/LGPL2.1"
		exclude "META-INF/licenses/ASM"
	}
}

Creating a Test Data Factory

Before we start writing our tests, weâ€™re going to define some functions that will provide data for us to use during our tests. Throughout our tests, weâ€™re going to need to create instances of the Message class that contains test data. Weâ€™ll create a randomString function that allows us to generate a random string for use in tests (such as message content), along with a makeMessage function that allows us to generate a Message instance. Having this factory allows us to simplify the use of test data in our tests, without needing to duplicate this logic throughout our project.

// TestDataFactory.kt

object TestDataFactory {

    fun randomString() = UUID.randomUUID().toString()

    fun makeMessage(
        text: String? = null,
        image: Bitmap? = null,
    ): Message {
        return Message(
            randomString(),
            MessageDirection.SENT,
            Calendar.getInstance().also {
                it.add(Calendar.DAY_OF_YEAR, -5)
            },
            randomString(),
            message = text,
            image = image
        )
    }
}

Testing the Conversation

At a high level of our feature is the Conversation composable. While we have a collection of focused composables that are responsible for specific parts of our UI, this composable acts as the parent container - composing each of the child composables that make up the different parts of the messaging feature. For this reason, weâ€™re going to write a collection of tests that will perform asserts to ensure the correct composables are displayed as expected. Weâ€™ll start here by creating a new test class, ConversationTest.

class ConversationTest {

}

Inside of this class, we now need to define a reference to the ComposeContentTestRule class - this is what weâ€™re going to use to set the composable content on screen, allowing us to perform interactions and assertions from within our tests. 

@get:Rule
val composeTestRule = createComposeRule()

When using this rule, we donâ€™t need to specify any form of activity for our composables to be launched in, the test rule will handle that for us. So using this rule we will set the composable content to be composed, the test will then launch a host activity which will be used to compose our provided content inside of.

With this test class configured, weâ€™re going to write some tests to assert that each of the expected composables is being displayed when required - which will be based on the state which is provided to the Conversation composable. Weâ€™ll start here by asserting that the header is being composed - the header should always be composed within the messaging screen, so we donâ€™t need to worry about passing any specific state to it.

To write this first test weâ€™ll use the @Test annotation and create a new function to test that the header is displayed by default within our UI.

@Test
fun Header_Displayed() {
    
}

Inside of this test, weâ€™re going to need to start by setting the composable content that is to be displayed on screen for us to assert against. Here weâ€™ll use the test rule that we previously defined, along with its setContent function. This function takes a composable function as an argument, allowing us to define what is to be composed on screen for our tests. Because weâ€™re wanting to test the Conversation Composable that we defined in the previous sections of this chapter, weâ€™ll go ahead and pass the Conversation composable function for this composable argument. When composing the Conversation weâ€™ll need to provide a reference to a ConversationState, along with an implementation of the handleEvent lambda - this will be blank as we donâ€™t need to use this callback within our test.

@Test
fun Header_Displayed() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        Conversation(
            state = ConversationState(),
            handleEvent = {}
        )
    }
}

So that we can locate the header within our test, weâ€™re going to need to add a tag to the composable that we wish to perform assertions against - this tag can then be used to locate our composable within our tests. Weâ€™ll need to start here by defining a tag reference that can be accessed from both our tests and our composable.

// Tags.kt

object Tags {
    const val TAG_HEADER = "TAG_HEADER"
}

With this tag defined, weâ€™ll then need to add this to our Header composable. Weâ€™ll assign this to the top-level composable within the function, using the testTag modifier to do so.

// Header.kt

TopAppBar(
	modifier = modifier.testTag(TAG_HEADER)
)

Next, weâ€™re going to locate the node within our composable hierarchy so that we can perform interactions and assertions on it. Here weâ€™ll utilise the onNodeWithTag function, providing the tag that we defined above. We can then utilise the assertIsDisplayed function to assert that the composable is being displayed as expected within the Conversation.

@Test
fun Header_Displayed() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        Conversation(
            state = ConversationState(),
            handleEvent = {}
        )
    }

    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(TAG_HEADER)
        .assertIsDisplayed()
}

Weâ€™re going to do the same for the other composable that are expected to be displayed within the Conversation. To do this weâ€™ll need to add 3 more tags to our Tags.kt file - one for Messages, one for InputBar and one for MessageActions.

object Tags {
    const val TAG_HEADER = "TAG_HEADER"
    const val TAG_MESSAGES = "TAG_MESSAGES"
    const val TAG_INPUT_BAR = "TAG_INPUT_BAR"
    const val TAG_MESSAGE_ACTIONS = "TAG_MESSAGE_ACTIONS"
}

Weâ€™ll then need to assign each of these to the top-level composable in each of the corresponding composable functions.

// Messages.kt
LazyColumn(
	modifier = modifier.testTag(TAG_MESSAGES),
	state = state,
	contentPadding = PaddingValues(top = 8.dp, bottom = 8.dp),
	verticalArrangement = Arrangement.spacedBy(16.dp)
)

// InputBar.kt
Column(modifier = modifier.testTag(TAG_INPUT_BAR))

// MessageActions.kt
Box(
	modifier = modifier
		.background(MaterialTheme.colors.surface)
		.sizeIn(minWidth = 280.dp, minHeight = 80.dp)
		.testTag(TAG_MESSAGE_ACTIONS),
	contentAlignment = Alignment.Center
)

With these tags in place, we can now proceed to write corresponding tests for each of the expected composables. Weâ€™ll start with the display of Messages, for which weâ€™ll need to compose the Conversation and then assert that the node with the TAG_MESSAGES tag is displayed.

@Test
fun Messages_Displayed() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        Conversation(
            state = ConversationState(),
            handleEvent = {}
        )
    }

    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(TAG_MESSAGES)
        .assertIsDisplayed()
}

Weâ€™ll next do the same for the input bar, utilising the TAG_INPUT_BAR tag to locate the node to perform assertions against.

@Test
fun Input_Bar_Displayed() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        Conversation(
            state = ConversationState(),
            handleEvent = {}
        )
    }

    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(TAG_INPUT_BAR)
        .assertIsDisplayed()
}

Finally, weâ€™ll do the same for the MessageActions, using the TAG_MESSAGE_ACTIONS tag to locate and assert the corresponding composable. When doing this weâ€™ll need to provide a Message for the selectedMessage value within our state - this is because the MessageActions will only be displayed when a message item has been marked as selected.

@Test
fun Message_Actions_Displayed() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        Conversation(
            state = ConversationState(
                selectedMessage = TestDataFactory.makeMessage()
            ),
            handleEvent = {}
        )
    }

    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(TAG_MESSAGE_ACTIONS)
        .assertIsDisplayed()
}

On the flip side, this means that the MessageActions should not be displayed when there is no selected message within our state. For this reason, weâ€™ll go ahead and write another test, this time to assert that the MessageActions are , not displayed when there is no selected message. Weâ€™ll use the same TAG_MESSAGE_ACTIONS tag to locate the node, followed by using the assertDoesNotExist function to assert that the node does not exist.

@Test
fun Message_Actions_Not_Displayed() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        Conversation(
            state = ConversationState(),
            handleEvent = {}
        )
    }

    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(TAG_MESSAGE_ACTIONS)
        .assertDoesNotExist()
}

Testing the Header

Now that we have some tests in place to assert each of the composables being displayed inside of a Conversation, weâ€™re going to go a step deeper and add some tests for each of the composables that make up our messaging screen. Weâ€™re going to start here by writing some tests for the Header composable, which weâ€™ll need to create a new test class for, HeaderTest.

class HeaderTest {

    @get:Rule
    val composeTestRule = createComposeRule()

}

The Header serves two purposes - display a title and provide a way to exit the conversation. Weâ€™re going to start here by testing that the title is displayed as expected - so weâ€™ll create a new test called Title_Displayed.

@Test
fun Title_Displayed() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        Header(onClose = {})
    }
}

Here we compose the Header, providing an empty implementation for the onClose lambda - we donâ€™t need to use this lambda within this test, so an empty callback is fine. When it comes to the expected title within the Header, in our cases this is always going to be the title_chat string resource. For this reason, weâ€™re going to fetch the string representation of this using the InstrumentationRegistry class from the android test package. This class allows us to retrieve the instrumentation that is currently running, giving us access to the current context which in turn allows us to fetch string resources.

Using this string value we can then locate a node that has the corresponding text, using the onNodeWithText function to do so. Once this returns us the SemanticsNodeInteraction, we can utilise the assertIsDisplayed function to assert that there is a node displayed that contains the specific title resource.

@Test
fun Title_Displayed() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        Header(onClose = {})
    }
    composeTestRule.onNodeWithText(
        InstrumentationRegistry.getInstrumentation()
            .targetContext.getString(R.string.title_chat)
    ).assertIsDisplayed()
}

Alongside this, we also want to assert that the close icon is displayed and triggers the expected callback. Weâ€™ll write a single test here to assert that the callback is triggered as expected - as if the close icon did not exist, then the callback would not be triggered. When composing the Header, weâ€™ll pass in a mock lambda function for the onClose argument. This means that we can use this mock to verify that interactions have taken place based on composable events.

With the Header being composed, weâ€™ll now be able to use the retrieve the node that represents the close icon by using the cd_close_conversation content description. Weâ€™ll then use the performClick function to perform a click action on this node. When this click action is triggered, this is the point that we would expect the onClose to be invoked so that the parent composable can handle the authentication event. We can verify this within our test by using mockito and its verify function to assert that the lambda has been invoked. If this is the case, the test will succeed - otherwise, the lambda not being triggered will mean that our verification will not be satisfied and the test will fail.

@Test
fun Close_Listener_Triggered() {
    val onClose: () -> Unit = mock()
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        Header(onClose = onClose)
    }
    composeTestRule.onNodeWithContentDescription(
        InstrumentationRegistry.getInstrumentation()
            .context.getString(R.string.cd_close_conversation)
    ).performClick()

    verify(onClose).invoke()
}

Testing the Empty State

When there are no messages to display, the EmptyConversation composable is used to portray this state to the user. Weâ€™re going to write a quick test to ensure that the EmptyConversation displays the correct information - otherwise this could result in causing some confusion for the user. Weâ€™ll start here by creating a new test class, EmptyConversationTest.

class EmptyConversationTest {

    @get:Rule
    val composeTestRule = createComposeRule()

}

Within this test class, weâ€™re going to write a single test, which will be used to assert that the expected message is displayed to the user. Weâ€™ll call this test Empty_Message_Displayed and start by composing the EmptyConversation for its content.

@Test
fun Empty_Message_Displayed() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        EmptyConversation()
    }
}

Weâ€™ll then use a similar approach that we took for retrieving a node by its textual content. Here weâ€™ll use the label_no_messages string resource to locate the node that has the empty message text, asserting that it is displayed via the assertIsDisplayed function.

@Test
fun Empty_Message_Displayed() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        EmptyConversation()
    }
    composeTestRule.onNodeWithText(
        InstrumentationRegistry.getInstrumentation().context
            .getString(R.string.label_no_messages)
    ).assertIsDisplayed()
}

With this test in place, we now know that the EmptyConversation composable is displaying the expected message - avoiding any confusion for the user when the conversation is in an empty state.

Testing the display of Messages

The main purpose of our messaging feature is to display messages to the user, so weâ€™re going to want to write some tests to ensure that messages are being displayed as expected. Weâ€™ll start by creating a new class to hold these tests, MessagesTest.

class MessagesTest {

    @get:Rule
    val composeTestRule = createComposeRule()

}

The Messages composable is responsible for two things:

  • Displaying the empty state when the list of messages is empty
  • Displaying a feed of messages when there are messages to display

Testing the Empty state

Weâ€™re going to want to cover both of these scenarios, so weâ€™ll continue with the theme of empty states by first putting together some tests to assert that the empty state is only composed under the specified conditions. Weâ€™ll start with the condition where the empty state should be composed within the Messages composable. Here weâ€™ll need to compose the Messages, providing an empty list for the messages argument. We can prove empty lambda blocks for the remaining arguments, as we donâ€™t need any implementations there for this test.

@Test
fun Empty_Messages_Displayed() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        Messages(
            messages = emptyList(),
            onMessageSelected = { },
            unSendMessage = { }
        )
    }
}

Weâ€™ll need to be able to locate the node that represents the empty state, so weâ€™ll start by adding a new tag that can be assigned to our composable.

// Tags.kt
object Tags {
	...
	const val TAG_EMPTY = "TAG_EMPTY"
}

With this tag in place, weâ€™ll now need to assign this tag to the EmptyConversation composable, weâ€™ll use the testTag modifier to apply this to the top-level composable within the function.

// EmptyConversation.kt
Box(modifier = modifier.testTag(TAG_EMPTY))

With this tag in place, we can now use this to assert that the composable is being displayed under the expected conditions. In this first test, we are providing an empty list to the Messages composable, so it would be expected that the node with the TAG_EMPTY tag is being displayed. In this case, we can locate the node using this tag, followed by verifying that it is being displayed via the use of the assertIsDisplayed function.

@Test
fun Empty_Messages_Displayed() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        Messages(
            messages = emptyList(),
            onMessageSelected = { },
            unSendMessage = { }
        )
    }

    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(TAG_EMPTY)
        .assertIsDisplayed()
}

As well as asserting that the empty state is displayed, weâ€™re also going to want to be sure that it is never displayed when messages are being provided. In this case, weâ€™ll take the same approach as the previous test, but use our MessageFactory to provide a list of messages to the Messages composable. With this in place, we can now locate the node and use the assertDoesNotExist function to assert that the composable does not exist.

@Test
fun Empty_Messages_Never_Displayed() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        Messages(
            messages = MessageFactory.makeMessages(),
            onMessageSelected = { },
            unSendMessage = { }
        )
    }

    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(TAG_EMPTY)
        .assertDoesNotExist()
}

Testing the message list display

Alongside the display of the empty state, weâ€™re also going to want to check that the list of messages is being displayed inside of the message list - along with the respective data separator. Currently, there doesnâ€™t seem to be a reliable way to test the expected order of sticky headers and items within a LazyColumn - so for now weâ€™re just going to test that the expected content is present within the composed UI, ignoring the ordering of items for now. When this changes in the compose APIs in future, we can circle back and improve our tests here.

For this test, weâ€™re going to start by composing Messages, when doing so weâ€™ll want to pass in a list of Message references that weâ€™ll create using our MessageFactory.

@Test
fun Messages_Displayed() {
    val messages = MessageFactory.makeMessages()
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        Messages(
            messages = MessageFactory.makeMessages(),
            onMessageSelected = { },
            unSendMessage = { }
        )
    }
}

Weâ€™ll next want to replicate whatâ€™s happening within our composable function - this is the grouping of messages by date. When this grouping occurs we get access to not only the messages but also the date labels that represent the groupings. This means that we can assert that both of these different kinds of information are being displayed to the user.

After using this groupMessagesByDate function weâ€™re going to want to loop through each of the entries in the generated map. Weâ€™re first going to want to assert that each of the generated date labels is being composed within the LazyColumn. Using the TAG_MESSAGES tag to locate the node that represents the list of messages, weâ€™ll use the onChildren function to obtain a SemanticsNodeInteraction reference that represents the children of that node. Next, weâ€™re going to want to assert that the expected date label is contained within this list of children. So that we can locate this node, weâ€™re going to start by adding a new testTag to the MessageHeader composable. For this, weâ€™ll use the timeInMillis value for the Calendar that is the key of the current entry.

// Messages.kt
MessageHeader(
	modifier = Modifier
		.fillMaxWidth()
		.testTag(entry.key.timeInMillis.toString()),
	isToday = isToday(entry.key),
	date = entry.key
)

Then we can use the assertAny function on the list of children to assert that any of those children match the specified matcher. For this matcher, weâ€™ll use the hasTestTag function to provide a tag that we expect any of the children to have - which in this case is the timeInMillis value for the current entry.

@Test
fun Messages_Displayed() {
    val messages = MessageFactory.makeMessages()
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        Messages(
            messages = MessageFactory.makeMessages(),
            onMessageSelected = { },
            unSendMessage = { }
        )
    }
    groupMessagesByDate(messages).forEach { entry ->
        composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(TAG_MESSAGES)
            .onChildren()
            .assertAny(hasTestTag(
				entry.key.timeInMillis.toString()))
    }
}

At this point, we know that the list of children contains each of the expected date header entries, but we still need to know about each of the Message items. Within this current forEach loop weâ€™re also going to want to loop through each of the Message references that are represented for the value of the current map entry. Within this additional loop, weâ€™re going to approach this the same way as the previous assertions, except this time we want to assert that the corresponding Message is contained within the list of children.

To be able to assert this, weâ€™ll want to provide a testTag to the Message. Weâ€™ll need to start by adding a new tag to our Tags.kt file in the form of TAG_MESSAGE_ - we include an _ as a suffix so that we can append the id of the message onto the tag.

// Tags.kt
object Tags {
	const val TAG_MESSAGE = "TAG_MESSAGE_"
}

With this tag in place, we can now assign it to our Message composable. Here weâ€™ll use this TAG_MESSAGE and append the id of the current message onto it.

// Messages.kt

Message(
	Modifier
		.semantics {
			customActions = listOf(
				CustomAccessibilityAction(unSendMessageLabel) {
                	unSendMessage(message.id)
                	true
                }
            )
		}
		.fillMaxWidth()
		.testTag(TAG_MESSAGE + message.id),
	...
)

Now that this tag has been assigned e can use the hasTestTag function to assert that the list of children contains a node that has the expected message tag.

@Test
fun Messages_Displayed() {
    val messages = MessageFactory.makeMessages()
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        Messages(
            messages = MessageFactory.makeMessages(),
            onMessageSelected = { },
            unSendMessage = { }
        )
    }
    groupMessagesByDate(messages).forEach { entry ->
        composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(TAG_MESSAGES)
            .onChildren()
            .assertAny(hasTestTag(
				entry.key.timeInMillis.toString()))

        entry.value.forEach { message ->
            composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(TAG_MESSAGES)
                .onChildren()
                .assertAny(
					hasTestTag(TAG_MESSAGE + message.id))
        }
    }
}

Testing the Message

When it comes to displaying a list of messages in a conversation, these are made up of individual Message composables. In this section, weâ€™re going to write some separate tests to assert that the Message composes the provided content as expected. Weâ€™ll house these tests inside of a new test class, MessageTest.

class MessageTest {

    @get:Rule
    val composeTestRule = createComposeRule()

}

Weâ€™ll start here by creating a new test to assert that the textual content of a Message is displayed as expected. Composing the Message weâ€™ll need to provide a reference to a Message instance - for this weâ€™ll also need to pass a value for the text argument so that the textual content can be composed.

@Test
fun Text_Content_Displayed() {
	val message = randomString()
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        Message(
			message = TestDataFactory.makeMessage(
            	text = message
        	), 
			onLongPress = { }
		)
    }
}

So that we can locate this text within the composable, specific to the composable that is meant to be displaying it, weâ€™re going to add another tag.

// Tags.kt
object Tags {
	...
	const val TAG_TEXT = "TAG_TEXT"
}

Weâ€™ll then want to assign this to the Text composable inside of our Message using the testTag modifier.

// Message.kt
Text(
	modifier = modifier.testTag(TAG_TEXT),
	text = buildAnnotatedStringWithColors(
		message.message,
		MaterialTheme.colors.primary
	)
)

We can then proceed to locate the composable using this TAG_TEXT tag, followed by the assertTextEquals function to assert that the text of this composable is equal to the content that we defined when constructing the Message instance.

@Test
fun Text_Content_Displayed() {
    val message = randomString()
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        Message(
			message = TestDataFactory.makeMessage(
            	text = message
        	), 
			onLongPress = { }
		)
    }

    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(
        TAG_TEXT
    ).assertTextEquals(message)
}

Other than text, our Message can also display an image if one is present. Weâ€™re going to take the same approach here as the previous test, so weâ€™ll start by adding another tag.

// Tags.kt
object Tags {
	...
	const val TAG_IMAGE = "TAG_IMAGE"
}

Followed by assigning this to the Image composable within the Message composable, using the testTag modifier.

// Message.kt
Image(
	modifier = modifier
		.size(120.dp)
        .testTag(TAG_IMAGE),
    bitmap = BitmapFactory.decodeResource(
		LocalContext.current.resources, message.image
	).asImageBitmap(),
    contentDescription = message.altText
)

We can then go ahead and use this tag to locate the node within our tests, followed by performing the assertIsDisplayed check to assert that the Image composable is being displayed.

@Test
fun Image_Body_Displayed() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        Message(
			message = TestDataFactory.makeMessage(
            	image = R.drawable.roxy
        	), 
			onLongPress = { }
		)
    }

    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(
        TAG_IMAGE
    ).assertIsDisplayed()
}

On the flip side, this Image should only be composed when there is an image present in the Message. So in the case when there is no image but only text, weâ€™re going to want to test that the node tagged with TAG_IMAGE does not exist. In this next test, weâ€™ll compose the content using a Message that only contains textual content, followed by using the assertDoesNotExist check to assert that the Image is not being composed under this condition.

@Test
fun Image_Body_Never_Displayed() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        Message(
			message = TestDataFactory.makeMessage(
            	text = randomString()
        	), 
			onLongPress = { }
		)
    }

    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(
        TAG_IMAGE
    ).assertDoesNotExist()
}

Similarly, when there is only image content within the Message and not any text, we would also expect the Text composable to not exist within the composable. For this reason, weâ€™ll write a similar test to the previous, except this time using the assertDoesNotExist function to assert that the node with the TAG_TEXT tag does not exist.

@Test
fun Text_Body_Never_Displayed() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        Message(
			message = TestDataFactory.makeMessage(
            	image = R.drawable.roxy
        	), 
			onLongPress = { }
		)
    }

    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(
        TAG_TEXT
    ).assertDoesNotExist()
}

Aside from the content that is composed inside of the Message, there is also a lambda that is provided to the composable - this is in the form of the onLongPress lambda. Weâ€™ve been passing an empty block for this in the previous tests as we didnâ€™t require any kind of interaction with it.

Other than providing a mock implementation of the onLongPress callback, weâ€™re going to need to provide a tag to be assigned to the parent composable within the function. This is the only place we currently need to use this tag, which also allows us to demonstrate how to apply test tags without needing to define them explicitly within the composable function. So when we compose the Message weâ€™ll pass the testTag modifier, along with the mock onLongPress lambda.

@Test
fun Long_Pressed_Triggered() {
    val parentTag = "parent"
    val onLongPress: (id: String) -> Unit = mock()
    val message = TestDataFactory.makeMessage(
        text = randomString()
    )
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        Message(
            modifier = Modifier.testTag(parentTag),
            message = message,
            onLongPress = onLongPress
		)
    }
}

With this in place, weâ€™re now going to utilise the test tag that was provided to our composable. Here weâ€™ll use this to invoke a click event on the composable, using the performTouchInput function to do so. Within the block for this weâ€™ll want to trigger the longClick function - when this long-click event is triggered on our composable it is expected that the onLongPress lambda is triggered. With this in place, we can utilise the mockito verify function to assert that the onLongPress lambda was invoked using the id of the Message that was provided to the composable function.

@Test
fun Long_Pressed_Triggered() {
    val parentTag = "parent"
    val onLongPress: (id: String) -> Unit = mock()
    val message = TestDataFactory.makeMessage(
        text = randomString()
    )
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        Message(
            modifier = Modifier.testTag(parentTag),
            message = message,
            onLongPress = onLongPress
		)
    }

    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(
        parentTag
    ).performTouchInput {
        longClick()
    }

    verify(onLongPress).invoke(message.id)
}

Testing the Message Actions

In the tests above we touched on the ability to long-press a message to view the actions that can be performed. Those actions are composed via a separate composable function, MessageActions - which weâ€™re going to write some tests for also. Weâ€™ll start by creating a new test class, MessageActionsTest.

class MessageActionsTest {

    @get:Rule
    val composeTestRule = createComposeRule()

}

When it comes to the message actions, weâ€™re currently only displaying a single action - which is used to unsend a message. Weâ€™ll start by writing a new test here, Unsend_Action_Displayed, to assert that this action is being displayed within the MessageActions composable. Within this test weâ€™ll start by composing the MessageActions, providing empty blocks for both of the onDismiss and onUnsendMessage arguments.

Weâ€™ll then want to check that the unsend message action is being displayed. Here weâ€™ll use the action_unsend_message resource to locate a node within our composition whose text matches this resource. Weâ€™ll then use the assertIsDisplayed function to assert that this node is displayed.

@Test
fun Unsend_Action_Displayed() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        MessageActions(onDismiss = {}, onUnsendMessage = {})
    }
    composeTestRule.onNodeWithText(
        InstrumentationRegistry.getInstrumentation()
            .context.getString(R.string.action_unsend_message)
    ).assertIsDisplayed()
}

Weâ€™ll next want to assert that when this node is interacted with, the expected callback is triggered. Weâ€™ll again compose the MessageActions but this time weâ€™ll pass a mock implementation of the unsendListener lambda - this is so that we can verify this is involved when the composable is interacted with.

@Test
fun Unsend_Action_Triggers_Callback() {
    val unsendListener: () -> Unit = mock()
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        MessageActions(
			onDismiss = {}, 
			onUnsendMessage = unsendListener
		)
    }
}

Weâ€™ll again use the action_unsend_message string resource to locate the node that represents the unsend message action, followed by utilising the performClick function to invoke a click event on the located node. When this click event occurs we would expect the onUnsendMessage lambda to be invoked - so at this point we want to verify that this is the case by utilising the mockito verify function. This allows us to assert that the lambda is triggered as expected when the node is clicked.

@Test
fun Unsend_Action_Triggers_Callback() {
    val unsendListener: () -> Unit = mock()
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        MessageActions(
			onDismiss = {}, 
			onUnsendMessage = unsendListener
		)
    }
    composeTestRule.onNodeWithText(
        InstrumentationRegistry.getInstrumentation()
            .context.getString(R.string.action_unsend_message)
    ).performClick()

    verify(unsendListener).invoke()
}

Testing the Input Bar

Now that we know the messages and their surrounding content are being composed as expected, weâ€™re going to move on to testing the InputBar composable. This allows us to assert that the composable responsible for the input and sending of messages is displayed and functioning as expected. As if this broke, our messaging app would become pretty redundant to our users! Weâ€™ll start here by creating a new test class, InputBarTest.

class InputBarTest {

    @get:Rule
    val composeTestRule = createComposeRule()

}

Testing the message sending logic

Weâ€™re going to start by writing a test to assert that the Send Message icon is enabled when there is text entered. If this logic was broken, it would mean that users would be unable to send messages - so this must be working as expected. In our test, weâ€™ll start by composing the InputBar.

@Test
fun Send_Message_Enabled_With_Text() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        InputBar(
			sendMessage = {}, 
			contacts = emptyList()
		)
    }
}

When it comes to interacting with the composables for this test, weâ€™re going to need to be able to input text into the input field, along with asserting the enabled state of the send message icon. To be able to reference these composables, weâ€™ll need to add some tags to these composables - weâ€™ll start by defining some new tags within our tags.kt file.

// Tags.kt
object Tags {
	...
	const val TAG_MESSAGE_INPUT = "TAG_MESSAGE_INPUT"
	const val TAG_SEND_MESSAGE = "TAG_SEND_MESSAGE"
}

Next, weâ€™ll want to assign these tags to the corresponding composables within our InputBar. For the TextField itself weâ€™ll want to use the testTag function to assign the TAG_MESSAGE_INPUT tag. Weâ€™ll then also want to apply the TAG_SEND_MESSAGE tag to the IconButton that is being composed for the trailingIcon.

// InputBar.kt
TextField(
	modifier = Modifier
		.fillMaxWidth()
        .testTag(TAG_MESSAGE_INPUT),
	...,
	trailingIcon = {
		IconButton(
			modifier = Modifier.testTag(TAG_SEND_MESSAGE)
		)
	}
)

With these tags in place, we can now locate these composables inside of our test. Weâ€™ll want to start by utilising the TAG_MESSAGE_INPUT tag to locate the input field, utilising the performTextInput function to input some text into the TextField composable. When this text is input, it is expected that the Send Message icon will become enabled for interaction from the user. To assert this, weâ€™ll utilise the TAG_SEND_MESSAGE tag to locate the node that represents the Send Message icon, followed by the assertIsEnabled function to assert that this is enabled under these conditions.

@Test
fun Send_Message_Enabled_With_Text() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        InputBar(
			sendMessage = {}, 
			contacts = emptyList()
		)
    }

    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(TAG_MESSAGE_INPUT)
        .performTextInput("Hello there!")

    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(TAG_SEND_MESSAGE)
        .assertIsEnabled()
}

On the flip side, weâ€™ll also want to assert that the Send Message icon is disabled when there is no content entered into the input field. Weâ€™ll take the previous test that we wrote, but this time we wonâ€™t input any content into the TextField. Instead, after composing the InputBar weâ€™ll go straight into locating the node with the TAG_SEND_MESSAGE tag, followed by utilising the assertIsNotEnabled function to verify that the icon is, in fact, disabled when there is no content present in the TextField. 

@Test
fun Send_Message_Disabled_With_No_Text() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        InputBar(
			sendMessage = {}, 
			contacts = emptyList()
		)
    }

    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(TAG_SEND_MESSAGE)
        .assertIsNotEnabled()
}

In the case where the Send Message icon is enabled, clicking on the icon will invoke the sendMessage lambda that is provided to the InputBar composable. When composing this InputBar weâ€™re going to provide a mock implementation of the sendMessage lambda, meaning that we will then be able to verify any interactions. Weâ€™ll again perform the same interaction with the input field by inputting some content - weâ€™ll store this content in a message variable so that we can reference it during the verification step. Weâ€™ll then want to go ahead and click on the Send Message icon, when this happens the sendMessage lambda should be triggered. Weâ€™ll assert this via the use of the mockito verify function, asserting that this is invoked with the message content that was input into the TextField. With this in place, we are now able to verify that the send message logic is triggered as expected, hoisting the message content up to the parent composable.

@Test
fun Send_Message_Triggers_Callback() {
    val message = "Hello there!"
    val sendMessage: (message: String) -> Unit = mock()
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        InputBar(
			sendMessage = sendMessage, 
			contacts = emptyList()
		)
    }

	composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(TAG_MESSAGE_INPUT)
        .performTextInput(message)
    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(TAG_SEND_MESSAGE)
        .performClick()

    verify(sendMessage).invoke(message)
}

Testing the display of contacts

When the user is sending a message, we added support for contacts to be @-mentioned. The options for an @-mention are displayed when the user types the @ character, with the contacts being displayed based on what is currently typed for the current word in the input field.

When the requirements for showing the selectable contacts have not been met, we would expect the contacts to not be displayed above the input bar. So that we can ensure this is always the case, weâ€™ll write a test to cover this scenario. Weâ€™ll start here by composing the InputBar, providing a list of contacts using the ContactFactory that we are using in the implementation of our project.

@Test
fun Contacts_Not_Displayed_By_Default() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        InputBar(
			sendMessage = {}, 
			contacts = ContactFactory.makeContacts()
		)
    }
}

So that we can reference the composable that it displays the contacts that can be mentioned, weâ€™re going to need to add a new tag to our tags.kt file.

// Tags.kt
object Tags {
	...
	const val TAG_MENTIONS = "TAG_MENTIONS"
}

Then within the InputBar, weâ€™ll go ahead and assign this tag to the Mentions composable using the testTag modifier.

// InputBar.kt
if (showMentions) {
    Mentions(
        modifier = Modifier
            .fillMaxWidth()
            .testTag(TAG_MENTIONS),
        contacts = contacts,
        query = selectedWord(textState)
    ) { query, result ->
        val startIndex = textState.text.indexOf(query)
        textState = textState.replaceText(
            startIndex,
            startIndex + query.length, result
        )
    }
}

With this tag in place, we can now use this to reference the composable from within our test. Using this tag, weâ€™ll locate the corresponding node and utilise the assertDoesNotExist function to assert that the composable does not currently exist within our composition.

@Test
fun Contacts_Not_Displayed_By_Default() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        InputBar(
			sendMessage = {}, 
			contacts = ContactFactory.makeContacts()
		)
    }
    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(
        TAG_MENTIONS
    ).assertDoesNotExist()
}

On the other hand, weâ€™re going to want to assert that the mentions are displayed under the specified conditions. Using our pre-existing TAG_MESSAGE_INPUT tag weâ€™re going to use the performTextInput function to input the â€œ@â€œ character into the input field. When this is done we would expect that the contacts for mentioning are displayed above the input bar. To assert that this is the case weâ€™ll use the TAG_MENTIONS tag to locate the node that represents these selectable contacts, followed by using the assertIsDisplayed function to assert that this is displayed.

@Test
fun Mentions_Displayed() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        InputBar(
			sendMessage = {}, 
			contacts = ContactFactory.makeContacts()
		)
    }

    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(TAG_MESSAGE_INPUT)
        .performTextInput("@")

    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(
        TAG_MENTIONS
    ).assertIsDisplayed()
}

While we display the selectable contacts when the @ symbol is entered, there are going to be several conditions where we would then expect the contacts to be hidden from view. For example, if I type â€œ@Joeâ€ followed by a space and â€œhelloâ€, the selectable contacts should no longer be shown. To ensure that this is the case weâ€™re going to write a test that will simulate this behaviour.

After weâ€™ve entered this "@joe hello" text into our input field using the performTextInput function on the node with the TAG_MESSAGE_INPUT tag, we can continue to assert the expected state of the contacts. Here we expect that the contacts are not visible to the user, so weâ€™ll use the assertDoesNotExist function to assert that this is the case.

@Test
fun Mentions_Hidden() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        InputBar(
			sendMessage = {}, 
			contacts = ContactFactory.makeContacts()
		)
    }

    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(TAG_MESSAGE_INPUT)
        .performTextInput("@joe hello")

    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(
        TAG_MENTIONS
    ).assertDoesNotExist()
}

This would be just one of the cases where we would expect the selectable contacts to be hidden after a state change. If others come to mind for you, feel free to explore writing some tests for them also!

Testing Mentions

While we have tests in place for the display of contacts within the InputBar, weâ€™re now going to write some tests to assert the composition of the Mentions composable. Weâ€™ll start here by creating a new test class, MentionsTest.

class MentionsTest {

    @get:Rule
    val composeTestRule = createComposeRule()

}

Weâ€™re first going to want to assert that the expected contacts are composed within the Mentions composable. Here weâ€™ll need to compose Mentions, providing a list of Contact references when doing so - weâ€™ll also need to provide the start of the @ mention query to trigger the matching of contact tags.

@Test
fun Contacts_Displayed() {
    val contacts = ContactFactory.makeContacts()
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        Mentions(
            contacts = contacts,
            query = "@",
            onMentionClicked = { _, _ ->

            }
        )
    }
}

Before we can go ahead and perform our assertions, weâ€™re going to need to add a new tag to our tags.kt file.

// Tags.kt
object Tags {
	const val TAG_CONTACTS = "TAG_CONTACTS"
}

Weâ€™re then going to want to assert that each of the contacts within our contacts list is being composed inside of the Mentions composable. Here weâ€™ll start by looping through each of the Contact within this list - for each of these weâ€™ll want to assert that there is a composable that represents that contact. Here weâ€™ll use our tag to locate the contacts list, locating the node at the index of the current position in our loop. For the node at this index, we would expect the text of this to equal the name of the current Contact in the loop. So for this, weâ€™ll use the assertTextEquals function to assert that the text of this node is equal to the name. This check will occur for each of the contacts in the list, asserting that the row of contact composables is made up of the contacts that are provided to the Mentions composable.

@Test
fun Contacts_Displayed() {
    val contacts = ContactFactory.makeContacts()
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        Mentions(
            contacts = contacts,
            query = "@",
            onMentionClicked = { _, _ ->

            }
        )
    }

    contacts.forEachIndexed { index, contact ->
        composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(TAG_CONTACTS)
            .onChildAt(index)
            .assertTextEquals(contact.name)
    }
}

Now that we know the contacts are being displayed when the @-mention process is triggered, weâ€™re going to want to ensure that the contacts are filtered based on the provided query. So for example, if I provide â€œ@jâ€ to the composable, then only contacts starting with the letter â€œjâ€ should be composed. So that we can perform this assertion in our test, weâ€™re going to need to take our list of contacts and build a list of contacts that match our provided query. Here weâ€™ll filter out any contacts that do not match our provided query - weâ€™ll do this by utilising the stripMentionSymbol function that weâ€™re already using in the composable implementation, followed by defining the acceptance criteria for the filter predicate based on whether the name of the contact starts with the query that weâ€™ve provided.

@Test
fun Filtered_Contacts_Displayed() {
    val contacts = ContactFactory.makeContacts()
    val query = "@j"
    val mentions = contacts.filter {
        val withoutMentionSymbol = stripMentionSymbol(
				query.lowercase(Locale.getDefault())) ?: ""
        it.name.lowercase(Locale.getDefault())
			.startsWith(withoutMentionSymbol)
    }
}

With this logic in place, we can now go ahead and compose our Mentions just as we had done previously.

@Test
fun Filtered_Contacts_Displayed() {
    val contacts = ContactFactory.makeContacts()
    val query = "@j"
    val mentions = contacts.filter {
        val withoutMentionSymbol = stripMentionSymbol(
				query.lowercase(Locale.getDefault())) ?: ""
        it.name.lowercase(Locale.getDefault())
			.startsWith(withoutMentionSymbol)
    }
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        Mentions(
            contacts = contacts,
            query = query,
            onMentionClicked = { _, _ ->

            }
        )
    }
}

Now that Mentions are being composed, we can go ahead and loop through our mentions reference that weâ€™ve built. Weâ€™ll do the same thing as the previous test for the node with the TAG_CONTACTS tag, asserting that the child at the index of the current item in the loop has text equal to the name of the given contact.

@Test
fun Filtered_Contacts_Displayed() {
    val contacts = ContactFactory.makeContacts()
    val query = "@j"
    val mentions = contacts.filter {
        val withoutMentionSymbol = stripMentionSymbol(
				query.lowercase(Locale.getDefault())) ?: ""
        it.name.lowercase(Locale.getDefault())
			.startsWith(withoutMentionSymbol)
    }
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        Mentions(
            contacts = contacts,
            query = query,
            onMentionClicked = { _, _ ->

            }
        )
    }

    mentions.forEachIndexed { index, contact ->
        composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(TAG_CONTACTS)
            .onChildAt(index)
            .assertTextEquals(contact.name)
    }
}

This allows us to assert that the mentions which match the current query we are providing are all being composed within the Mentions bar. If we wanted to go even further here then we could test that the contacts which were filtered out from the initial list are not being composed.

So now that we know the contacts are being displayed as expected, weâ€™re going to want to assert that the onMentionClicked lambda is triggered with the selected contact. Weâ€™ll start here by creating a mock reference for our lambda, followed by using this for the composition of Mentions.

@Test
fun Contact_Triggers_Callback() {
    val onMentionClicked: 
		(query: String, mention: String) -> Unit = mock()
    val contacts = ContactFactory.makeContacts()
    val query = "@"
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        Mentions(
            contacts = contacts,
            query = query,
            onMentionClicked = onMentionClicked
        )
    }
}

Next, weâ€™ll want to use the TAG_CONTACTS tag to retrieve the child at the index 1, followed by performing a click action on this node via the use of the performClick function. When this occurs we are clicking on the second contact within the row of contacts, so we would expect the lambda function to be triggered using this contact. Weâ€™ll use the mockito verify function to assert that this is the case - verifying that the lambda is invoked, passing the query that was provided to the composable function along with the @-mention representation of the selected contact name. 

@Test
fun Contact_Triggers_Callback() {
    val onMentionClicked: 
		(query: String, mention: String) -> Unit = mock()
    val contacts = ContactFactory.makeContacts()
    val query = "@"
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        Mentions(
            contacts = contacts,
            query = query,
            onMentionClicked = onMentionClicked
        )
    }

    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(TAG_CONTACTS)
        .onChildAt(1)
        .performClick()
    verify(onMentionClicked).invoke(query, 
		"@" + contacts[1].name)
}

With all of these tests in place, weâ€™ve covered a lot of different cases that help to ensure our UI is working as expected. Weâ€™ve not only tested that composables are being composed based on the information that they are provided with, but also that they triggered the expected callbacks and trigger state manipulations within our composables.
