While the tests here arenâ€™t extensive, weâ€™ve been able to learn not only what options are available to us while testing composables, but also the approaches that we can take when doing so.

Building an Image Gallery

We see the use of Media in many different applications - whether itâ€™s displaying media for user interaction, or providing a choice of media for the user to select, media is a common aspect of mobile applications.

In this chapter, weâ€™re going to walk through an approach to building out an image viewer feature. Weâ€™ll be creating the above image gallery screen, which allows the user to load the media from their device into the gallery and select an item to enlarge it into a full-screen preview.

However, for our feature to load the device media contents into the UI, our application is going to need permission to access the device media. For this reason, our feature is going to need to request permission from the user, which is something we can do using the functionality of some additional compose libraries that are offered by Google. Using this approach weâ€™ll be able to:

  • Check if we have permission to access the media on the device
  • Request permission from the user to access the media on their device
  • Load the media from the device to display within our composables
  • Display specific UI components for when permission to access the media has been denied, prompting the user to adjust permission from the system settings

With these points, weâ€™ll learn how to approach common media access flows for applications using Jetpack Compose. With this experience, weâ€™ll be able to tackle media access in our applications, covering common feature sets found within the Android ecosystem. With this, letâ€™s get started with building this image gallery!

Defining the Gallery data classes

When it comes to displaying images with our image gallery feature, weâ€™re going to be displaying a grid of images - with each item in that grid representing an item of media from the storage of the device. While we arenâ€™t going to be defining a class representation for the state of our screen (which is for examples sake, as we are not dealing with a lot of state), weâ€™re going to define a class to hold the details for each of the retrieved items from the device storage.

When it comes to the modelling of this data class, weâ€™re not actually going to need much information to display these images in the gallery feed. All we will need is the Uri of the media item, along with the id - which will be used as the key identifier for the item within our feed. With this in mind, we can simply create a new class, Image, adding two properties to the constructor in the form of these two pieces of data.

data class Image(
    val id: Long,
    val uri: Uri
)

With this class in place, we can now utilise this within our feature to model the media that is retrieved from the media store. As mentioned above, we wonâ€™t be defining state class for this feature - so this class will also be used to form the state for our composable, allowing the grid of images to be composed based on a collection of Image references.

Creating the Gallery UI

With the data classes now in place, weâ€™re ready to move on and start implementing the composable UI for our Gallery.

When weâ€™re finished building this UI, weâ€™re going to end up with something that looks like the following:

This UI will give our users a screen that displays a grid of images from the device storage, allowing individual items to be selected and viewed in a full-screen format. Building this UI will allow us to work with several different features of compose, while also learning how to work with permission-based APIs in the compose world.

Setting up the entry point

Before we can get start building our project, weâ€™re going to need to add a couple of dependencies that weâ€™re going to utilise. Weâ€™ll start here by adding these to the build.gradle file for our new project:

// provides access to the `ComponentActivity` class that can be used to compose UI components
implementation 'androidx.activity:activity-compose:1.4.0'

// foundational classes from the Compose APIs
implementation 
	"androidx.compose.foundation:foundation:$compose_version"

// UI components from the Compose APIs
implementation "androidx.compose.ui:ui:$compose_version"

// Material Design components from the Compose APIs
implementation 
	"androidx.compose.material:material:$compose_version"

// Provides us with utilities for requesting permissions
implementation 'com.google.accompanist:accompanist-permissions:0.22.0-rc'

// Provides image loading utilies
implementation 'io.coil-kt:coil-compose:1.4.0'

// Tooling functionality for Composables, such as previews
implementation "androidx.compose.ui:ui-tooling-preview:$compose_version"
debugImplementation "androidx.compose.ui:ui-tooling:$compose_version"

With these added to our project, weâ€™re now ready to start building out our UI. Weâ€™re going to start here by building the access point to our feature - this is how the Gallery feature will initially be composed within our user interface. To make this an argument-less access point, weâ€™re going to start with a new composable function, Gallery.

// Gallery.kt

@Composable
fun Gallery() {
    
}

While we wonâ€™t see anything visual just yet, weâ€™ll want to compose this Gallery composable within the setContent block of the activity that was created through the project wizard. Then as we build out the project, weâ€™ll be able to visualise the Gallery composable.

Within our Gallery weâ€™re going to want to compose the content of our gallery feature. The Gallery itself is only going to be responsible for composing the root composable of our feature, this is so that we can keep all of the UI for our screen nested within our composable hierarchy - allowing the top-level composable to handle anything around media retrieval and system settings. For this purpose weâ€™ll create a new composable function, GalleryContent, that will be used to house the different UI components that make up our feature.

// GalleryContent.kt

@Composable
fun GalleryContent(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier
) {

}

Next, weâ€™ll hop on back over to the Gallery composable, composing the GalleryContent and enforcing it to fill the screen via the use of the Modifier.fillMaxSize() modifier. Weâ€™ll also wrap the composition of this using the MaterialTheme composable so that our composables adhere to any application theming that we apply.

@Composable
fun Gallery() {
    MaterialTheme {
        GalleryContent(
            modifier = Modifier.fillMaxSize()
        )
    }
}

With this in place, we now have a composable function that can be used to declare the UI for our feature.

Requesting storage permission

Before we can start displaying media items within our UI, we need to request permission from the user so that we can read the media from the external storage of the device. For this permission management, weâ€™re going to be utilising the accompanist-permissions package that we added to the dependencies for this module. This will allow us to check and request the required media access permission.

When it comes to this permission management, weâ€™re going to be using the PermissionState interface which is provided by the accompanist package. This interface provides us access to various pieces of details around the permissions that have been granted to our application, as well as allowing us to launch the permissions request flow for specific permissions.

interface PermissionState {

    val permission: String

    val hasPermission: Boolean

    val shouldShowRationale: Boolean

    val permissionRequested: Boolean

    fun launchPermissionRequest(): Unit
}

When it comes to media access, our GalleryContent composable is going to need access to this interface so that we can compose the UI based on the status of the required permissions. For example, if permission has not been granted to access the media on the device, then we arenâ€™t going to want to compose the grid of images (as we wonâ€™t have access to load the images within the grid). To be able to perform the required checks, weâ€™ll provide a reference to this interface as an argument to the GalleryContent composable.

@Composable
fun GalleryContent(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
	permissionState: PermissionState
) {
    
}

With this now specified as an argument for the GalleryContent, weâ€™re going to need to provide this during composition. Within the implementation of the Gallery composable weâ€™re going to need to utilise the rememberPermissionState composable function - this allows us to specify a permission that is required within our composables, along with remembering it across compositions. For this permission weâ€™re going to useREAD_EXTERNAL_STORAGE - this will grant us access to the external storage on the userâ€™s device. When calling this rememberPermissionState function, we will be provided with a reference to a permissionState, which we can then provide when composing the GalleryContent.

@Composable
fun Gallery() {
	
	val permissionState = rememberPermissionState(
    	Manifest.permission.READ_EXTERNAL_STORAGE
	)

    MaterialTheme {
        GalleryContent(
            modifier = Modifier.fillMaxSize(),
			permissionState = permissionState
        )
    }
}

Weâ€™ll also need to add this permission to our manifest file.

<manifest xmlns:android="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/android"
    package="academy.compose.gallery">

    <uses-permission android:name="android.permission.READ_EXTERNAL_STORAGE"/>
	...
</manifest>

Within our GalleryContent composable, weâ€™re then going to want to check if the specified permission (defined by the provided PermissionState) needs to be requested. Weâ€™re going to do this by utilising the permissionRequested property - this will allow us to know if the permission has not previously been requested by our application, and it would be at this point that we want to request permission from the user.

@Composable
fun GalleryContent(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
	permissionState: PermissionState
) {
    when {
        !permissionState.permissionRequested -> {
         		
        }
    }
}

With this in place, we can now trigger the permission request by calling the launchPermissionRequest() function on the provided PermissionState reference.

permissionState.launchPermissionRequest()

Weâ€™ll then want to slot this into the GalleryContent composable so that the permission flow is triggered when required.

@Composable
fun GalleryContent(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
	permissionState: PermissionState
) {
    when {
        !permissionState.permissionRequested -> {
        	permissionState.launchPermissionRequest()	
        }
    }
}

When this point in the code is reached, the system permission request will be displayed to the user - allowing them to grant the application permission to access media on the device.

Displaying Gallery Images

Now that we have access to the images that we want to display within our gallery, weâ€™re going to need to create the composables that will be used to display them.

Creating the Image item

Weâ€™ll start here by creating the composable which represents the selectable image within the gallery. This composable is going to take the Uri representing the image that is to be displayed, followed by loading it into an Image composable which will be displayed within the grid of images onscreen. Weâ€™ll create a new composable function, GalleryImage, that will take this required Uri as an argument.

@Composable
fun GalleryImage(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
	uri: Uri
) {

}

While we have this Uri, we donâ€™t have anything for it to be loaded into. For this, weâ€™re going to use the Image composable. There are several functions available for the Image composable - but because weâ€™re using Coil to handle our image loading, weâ€™re going to use the function that accepts an ImagePainter as an argument, as that is what our Coil usage will provide us with.

When composing our image, weâ€™re going to start by assigning the provided Modifier to our Image composable, along with a null value for the contentDescription argument - this is because we wonâ€™t have access to anything that will be able to provide us with a corresponding description for each image.

@Composable
fun GalleryImage(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    uri: Uri
) {
    Image(
		modifier = modifier,
        painter = ...,
        contentDescription = null
    )
}

ðŸ’¡ Content descriptions help to improve the accessibility of visual elements. In the case of photos, content descriptions will usually be provided by where the image is sourced from, or generated using machine learning. We donâ€™t have access to either of these solutions here, meaning a content description is not available for the images in our gallery.

The only thing that we need to provide now is the painter argument. For this, weâ€™re going to utilise the rememberImagePainter composable function from the Coil library.

@Composable
inline fun rememberImagePainter(
    data: Any?,
    onExecute: ExecuteCallback = ExecuteCallback.Default,
    builder: ImageRequest.Builder.() -> Unit = {}
)

This allows us to provide the Uri of the image that we wish to load, resulting in the image being displayed inside of our composable.

@Composable
fun GalleryImage(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    uri: Uri
) {
    Image(
		modifier = modifier,
        painter = rememberImagePainter(uri),
        contentDescription = null
    )
}

We can go a few steps further here though - for example, the image might not load right away, or might not even load at all (as in, fail to load). We can also use Coil to fade the image in once it has finished loading, as opposed to it being displayed suddenly on the screen. To achieve these desired behaviours, weâ€™re going to utilise the builder block, as seen in the function definition defined above. This builder allows us to provide a collection of properties that will be used to control how the content of the composable is loaded.

To begin with, weâ€™re going to apply a placeholder that will be loaded into the composable before our image media has been loaded. This provides a nice effect to our UI, as the user will see this placeholder as opposed to an empty space within the composable. We need to provide a resource to be used for this placeholder, so weâ€™ll use the asset study to create a new resource using the vector asset wizard.

Here Iâ€™ve used the ic_baseline_image_24 resource, providing this to the placeholder within the builder block.

rememberImagePainter(
	data = uri,
	builder = {
		placeholder(R.drawable.ic_baseline_image_24)
	}
)

At this point, weâ€™ll now have a placeholder being displayed within our composable before the image is loaded. Now, when that image has been loaded, the placeholder will instantly switch to the loaded image. While this works, it doesnâ€™t look as nice of a transition as it could. To improve this weâ€™re going to utilise the crossfade function, providing true as the argument to depict that the crossfade effect should be applied when the image is being loaded.

rememberImagePainter(
	data = uri,
	builder = {
		placeholder(R.drawable.ic_baseline_image_24)
		crossfade(true)
	}
)

At this point, we now have a placeholder for while our image is loading, along with the crossfade effect applied when the transitioning between the placeholder and requested image occurs. However, this is all assuming that the image succeeds to load - if something goes wrong, then the placeholder will remain in place and the user will be unaware of what has happened. To improve this, weâ€™re going to utilise the error function within the builder block - this allows us to provide a resource to be displayed when this scenario does occur.

Weâ€™ll again need to reference an image resource, so weâ€™ll again create a new one using the vector asset wizard (Iâ€™ve used the ic_baseline_error_24 resource). Weâ€™ll then provide this to the error function as the resource to be used when the image fails to load.

rememberImagePainter(
	data = uri,
	builder = {
		placeholder(R.drawable.ic_baseline_image_24)
		crossfade(true)
		error(R.drawable.ic_baseline_error_24)
	}
)

With this configured, we can slot this into our Image composable usage, allowing us to now experience the defined behaviour while the image data of the composable is loaded into view.

@Composable
fun GalleryImage(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    uri: Uri,
    scaleType: ContentScale
) {
    Image(
        painter = rememberImagePainter(
            data = uri,
            builder = {
                crossfade(true)
                placeholder(R.drawable.ic_baseline_image_24)
                error(R.drawable.ic_baseline_error_24)
            }
        ),
        contentDescription = null,
        contentScale = scaleType,
        modifier = modifier
    )
}

In the composable preview, youâ€™ll currently only be able to see the placeholder resources - but this allows us to preview how our composable is currently being represented.

Displaying a Grid of Images

Now that we have a composable that can be used to represent an individual image within our gallery, weâ€™re going to want to compose each of the individual images within a higher level gallery composable. Weâ€™re going to be displaying these images in a grid format, so weâ€™ll start by creating a new composable function, ImageGallery. Alongside the default modifier, this is also going to receive a list of Image references as an argument which will be used to compose the images for selection.

// ImageGallery.kt

@Composable
fun ImageGallery(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    images: List<Image>
)

To display the grid of images, weâ€™re going to utilise the LazyVerticalGrid composable which will only compose its children as they are required - making it much more efficient than composing everything at the same time, especially when items may not even be visible to the user. When composing the LazyVerticalGrid weâ€™ll pass the modifier that was provided to our ImageGallery composable, along with the required cells argument. This needs to be provided in the form of the GridCells type, which allows us to define how many columns should be applied to our grid. Weâ€™re going to use the Fixed type in the form of 2 columns.

@Composable
fun ImageGallery(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    images: List<Image>
) {
    LazyVerticalGrid(
        modifier = modifier,
        cells = GridCells.Fixed(2)
    ) {
            
    }
}

ðŸ’¡ Alongside the Fixed type, the Adaptive type allows us to define a minimum sizing for a column - meaning that we can create more adaptive layouts by allowing our grid columns to adjust based on the available space.

When it comes to the items to be composed within our grid, these need to be composed using the items function provided through the LazyListScope - this is so that a unique key can be provided for each item being composed, allowing the LazyVerticalGrid to correctly manage the current scroll position on the screen.

With that said, weâ€™ll go ahead and utilise the items function - this allows us to provide a list that we wish to compose items from. Along with this list of items being provided, the itemContent block will also be called - this is where we will declare the composition for each item that is being composed within our UI.

@Composable
fun ImageGallery(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    images: List<Image>
) {
    LazyVerticalGrid(
        modifier = modifier,
        cells = GridCells.Fixed(2)
    ) {
        items(images) { image ->
             
        }
    }
}

When it comes to the composition of each image item within our grid, weâ€™re going to utilise the GalleryImage composable that we previously defined. For this we need to provide 3 different arguments:

  • modifier: the constraints to be applied to the composable
  • uri: the uri to load the image from
  • scaleType: the scaling to be applied to the loaded image

For the modifier, weâ€™re going to want to provide a fixed size, which weâ€™ll assign via the height modifier at a size of 150.dp. Alongside this, weâ€™ll use the fillMaxWidth modifier to fill up all of the available width of the column the image is in.

GalleryImage(
	modifier = Modifier
		.height(150.dp)
		.fillMaxWidth(),
	uri = ...,
	scaleType = ...
)

ðŸ’¡ Using a fixed height here is OK because we are using a vertically scrolling grid. This means that while we are using a fixed height, theyâ€™ll always be available space to view the heights of each image. This wouldnâ€™t quite work the same for a fixed width in this case, as we are using a 2 column grid - so a fixed width would either result in the image width being too small, or extending outside of the visible area of the screen.

The only thing now is that realistically, our images are not going to match this sizing that we have applied to our composable. This results in an odd composition of our images, causing the images to either be too large or small.

For this reason, weâ€™re going to utilise the scaleType argument, providing a value of ContentScale.Crop - allowing the loaded image to be cropped to the size constraints of the composable that it is being loaded into.

GalleryImage(
	modifier = Modifier
		.height(150.dp)
		.fillMaxWidth(),
	scaleType = ContentScale.Crop,
	uri = ...
)

Finally, we need to provide the uri for the image that we wish to load. Weâ€™ll directly pass the uri property from the current Image item that we are composing for.

GalleryImage(
	modifier = Modifier
		.height(150.dp)
		.fillMaxWidth(),
	scaleType = ContentScale.Crop,
	uri = image.uri,
)

With this in place, we now have a GalleryImage being composed for each of the Image items that are within the images list.

@Composable
fun ImageGallery(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    images: List<Image>
) {
    LazyVerticalGrid(
        modifier = modifier,
        cells = GridCells.Fixed(2)
    ) {
        items(retrieveMedia) {
            GalleryImage(
                modifier = Modifier
                    .height(150.dp)
                    .fillMaxWidth(),
                uri = it.uri,
                scaleType = ContentScale.Crop
            )
        }
    }
}

At this point, weâ€™ll be able to preview a minimal grid of image composables being displayed.

Allowing image selection

Even though our grid of images is showing, weâ€™re yet to implement the selection of images. When an image is selected we want to display it full screen, allowing the user to then return to the grid of images at any time. For this, weâ€™re going to need to implement a couple of changes to our ImageGallery composable:

  • Weâ€™re going to need to allow an image to be clickable, followed by keeping track of what image has been selected via this click action
  • When there is a selected image, weâ€™ll want to display a fullscreen image composable over the top of the grid
  • When this fullscreen image is clicked (or back is pressed), then the image grid will be returned to

Weâ€™ll start by adding support for selecting an image from the gallery. This will involve applying the clickable modifier to our GalleryImage composable, enabling click interactions on this composable.

// ImageGallery.kt

@Composable
fun ImageGallery(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    images: List<Image>
) {
    LazyVerticalGrid(
        modifier = modifier,
        cells = GridCells.Fixed(2)
    ) {
        items(images) { image ->
            GalleryImage(
                modifier = Modifier
                    .clickable {

                    }
                    .height(150.dp)
                    .fillMaxWidth(),
                uri = it.uri,
                scaleType = ContentScale.Crop
            )
        }
    }
}

However, at this point, the click interaction isnâ€™t doing anything. So that we know an image has been selected (and that one has been selected), weâ€™re going to add a piece of internal state to our composable. While this could be a piece of global state, we havenâ€™t configured it for this feature - so weâ€™re going to keep it as an internal piece of state within this composable for now. Weâ€™ll call this piece of state selectedImage, wrapping it in remember so that the value is persisted across recompositions. The type for this state is going to be Uri and also be nullable, this is so that when an image is not currently selected then the state can be reflected as null. Weâ€™ll next implement the body of the clickable modifier, so that the value of the selectedImage is updated when the composable is clicked.

// ImageGallery.kt

@Composable
fun ImageGallery(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    images: List<Image>
) {
    var selectedImage by remember { 
		mutableStateOf<Uri?>(null) 
	}
    LazyVerticalGrid(
        modifier = modifier,
        cells = GridCells.Fixed(2)
    ) {
        items(images) { image ->
            GalleryImage(
                modifier = Modifier
                    .clickable {
                        selectedImage = image.uri
                    }
                    .height(150.dp)
                    .fillMaxWidth(),
                uri = it.uri,
                scaleType = ContentScale.Crop
            )
        }
    }
}

When there is an image that is selected, weâ€™re going to want to display this image over the top of the existing grid of images in an immersive fashion. To make this possible weâ€™re going to wrap the existing LazyVerticalGrid in a Box composable, which will allow us to stack composables on the z-axis (as in, on top of one another). This means that we can create a new composable to be displayed over the existing grid, which will allow our selected image to be presented to the user.

Weâ€™ll start here by defining this Box composable, using the contentAlignment argument to align its children in the center, followed by placing the existing LazyVerticalGrid within its content block.

@Composable
fun ImageGallery(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    images: List<Image>
) {
    var selectedImage by remember { 
		mutableStateOf<Uri?>(null) 
	}
    Box(
        contentAlignment = Alignment.Center
    ) {
        LazyVerticalGrid(
            modifier = modifier,
            cells = GridCells.Fixed(2)
        ) {
            items(images) { image ->
                GalleryImage(
                    modifier = Modifier
                        .clickable {
                            selectedImage = it.uri
                        }
                        .height(150.dp)
                        .fillMaxWidth(),
                    uri = it.uri,
                    scaleType = ContentScale.Crop
                )
            }
        }
    }
}

Now that this Box is in place, we can start to think about the composable that will be displayed when there is an image that has been selected. For this weâ€™re going to create a new composable function, GalleryPreview. This is going to take a nullable Uri that represents the currently selected image.

@Composable
fun GalleryPreview(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    selectedImage: Uri?
) {

}

When it comes to displaying this image, weâ€™re going to compose it inside of a Box. Because our image wonâ€™t necessarily fill the entire space inside of the box, weâ€™re going to chain the background modifier onto the modifier that is provided to the function. Weâ€™ll apply the Color.Black value to this, meaning that any space our image does not fill will appear as black space.

@Composable
fun GalleryPreview(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    selectedImage: Uri?
) {
    Box(
        modifier = modifier
            .background(Color.Black)
    ) {
        
    }
}

Weâ€™re next going to want to compose the selected image so that it is visible within the preview area. Here weâ€™ll compose our GalleryImage, providing the required values for the function arguments. For the uri weâ€™ll simply pass the image argument that is provided to the GalleryPreview composable function. When it comes to the constraints of the composable, weâ€™re going to pair the use of the fillMaxWidth modifier with ContentScale.None for the scaleType argument. Using ContentScale.None will mean that there will be no scaling applied to the image (compared to the cropping that was previously being applied), so in this case, we want to enforce the full width of the preview area is used. This is because the height of the image will then fill the required area and the original aspect ratio of the image will be retained.

@Composable
fun GalleryPreview(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    image: Uri
) {
    Box(
        modifier = modifier
            .background(Color.Black)
    ) {
        GalleryImage(
            modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
            uri = image,
            scaleType = ContentScale.None
        )
    }
}

At this point, we have a composable that can be used to display a preview of an image - all thatâ€™s left to do now is compose this within our ImageGallery. Weâ€™ll only want to compose this when the selectedImage does not represent a null value.

@Composable
fun ImageGallery(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    retrieveMedia: List<Image>
) {
    var selectedImage by remember { 
		mutableStateOf<Uri?>(null) 
	}
    Box(
        contentAlignment = Alignment.Center
    ) {
        LazyVerticalGrid(
            modifier = modifier,
            cells = GridCells.Fixed(2)
        ) {
            ...
        }
		selectedImage?.let {
        	GalleryPreview(
            	modifier = Modifier.fillMaxSize()
            	selectedImage = selectedImage
        	)
		}
    }
}

With this in place, our gallery preview will now be composed when there is a Uri value reflected within the selectedImage state. However, once the composition has taken place, thereâ€™s no way for the user to clear that state and remove the preview from view. For the first step here, weâ€™re going to utilise the clickable modifier - this will allow us to clear the selectedImage when the composable is clicked. We can chain this onto the existing fillMaxSize modifier, setting the selectedImage state value as null within the body of the click action.

@Composable
fun ImageGallery(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    retrieveMedia: List<Image>
) {
    var selectedImage by remember { 
		mutableStateOf<Uri?>(null) 
	}
    Box(
        contentAlignment = Alignment.Center
    ) {
        LazyVerticalGrid(
            modifier = modifier,
            cells = GridCells.Fixed(2)
        ) {
            ...
        }
		selectedImage?.let {
        	GalleryPreview(
            	modifier = Modifier.fillMaxSize()
					.clickable {
						selectedImage = null
					},
            	selectedImage = selectedImage
        	)
		}
    }
}

Now when this click event is triggered, the selectedImage state will be cleared, triggering a recomposition that will cause the GalleryPreview to no longer be displayed to the user - taking them back to the grid of images for selection.

One issue with this click modifier is that for users utilising accessibility features, the click functionality here will not be very accessible. While the click action is there, the screen reader has no clue what that click action does. To improve this weâ€™re going to add a click label - that way the screen reader can communicate the intention of our click action to the user. Before we add this label weâ€™re going to need to add a new string resources to our project for notifying the user that clicking an image will enlarge it on screen.

<string name="cd_enlarge_image">
	Enlarge Image
</string>

Weâ€™ll then need to retrieve the string value of the resource using the stringResource function. Weâ€™ll assign this to a variable reference, as the onClickLabel can only be provided as a string (and the stringResource function is a composable function).

val enlargeImageLabel = stringResource(id = R.string.cd_enlarge_image)
LazyVerticalGrid(
	modifier = modifier.testTag(TAG_IMAGE_GRID),
	cells = GridCells.Fixed(2)
)
...

We can then use this to apply a value to the onClickLabel of the clickable modifier. 

GalleryImage(
	modifier = Modifier
		.clickable(
			onClickLabel = enlargeImageLabel
		) {
        	selectedImage = it.uri
		}
	...
)

As we can see, this isnâ€™t a required property of the clickable modifier, but for minimal effort, we can increase the accessibility of our composable for screen readers.

Animating the image display

At the moment you may notice that the image preview is removed suddenly from composition. While this is working as expected, we can go one step further here to improve the transition that occurs during this recomposition. We can utilise the AnimatedVisibility composable that will allow us to animate the visibility of the composable, which we can do so based on the state of the selectedImage value.

We can define the use of this AnimatedVisibility composable, instructing it to fill the maximum available size. Weâ€™ll also assign the visibility of the composable based on whether there is currently a non-null value assigned for the selectedImage state.

AnimatedVisibility(
	modifier = Modifier.fillMaxSize(),
    visible = selectedImage != null
)

While this allows us to animate the visibility of the composable, we can improve the transition here by modifying the transitions that are used for the enter and exit values. Here weâ€™ll utilise both the fadeIn and fadeOut transitions, which will use a fade for each transition instead of instantly showing/hiding the composable during the transition.

AnimatedVisibility(
	modifier = Modifier.fillMaxSize(),
    visible = selectedImage != null,
    enter = fadeIn(),
    exit = fadeOut()
)

With this in place, we now have the AnimatedVisibility composable configured to animate any contained content in and out of composition. We can now slot this into our ImageGallery composable, placing the existing GalleryPreview composable as the content of the AnimatedVisibility composable. This means that now when the selectedImage state is changed, the contents of the AnimatedVisibility composable will be animated in and out of visibility.

@Composable
fun ImageGallery(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    images: List<Image>
) {
    var selectedImage by remember { 
		mutableStateOf<Uri?>(null) 
	}
    Box(
        contentAlignment = Alignment.Center
    ) {
        LazyVerticalGrid(
            modifier = modifier,
            cells = GridCells.Fixed(2)
        ) {
            ...
        }
        AnimatedVisibility(
            modifier = Modifier.fillMaxSize(),
            visible = selectedImage != null,
            enter = fadeIn(),
            exit = fadeOut()
        ) {
			selectedImage?.let {
            	GalleryPreview(
                	modifier = Modifier.fillMaxSize()
						.clickable {
							selectedImage = null
						},
                	selectedImage = selectedImage
            	)
			}
        }
    }
}

Retrieving media

Now that we have the composables in place to display the images on the device, weâ€™re going to need to implement the logic that will retrieve the images from the device media store. Weâ€™re going to delegate this to a separate function, which weâ€™ll call retrieveMedia. This function will handle the retrieval of media for us, returning a list of Image references that are generated from the media store results.

fun retrieveMedia(): List<Image> {

}

To be able to query the media store, weâ€™re going to need to define the information that we want to query for. For our usage, weâ€™re only going to query for a few pieces of information - the ID of the media item and the display name. This will give us most of the data that we need to construct an Image reference.

fun retrieveMedia(): List<Image> {
	val projection = arrayOf(
        MediaStore.Images.Media._ID,
        MediaStore.Images.Media.DISPLAY_NAME
    )
}

Next, weâ€™re going to want to use this array to query the media store. To do this weâ€™re going to need access to a Context reference, which weâ€™ll add as an argument for our function. With this context in place, we can now use this to access the content resolver and perform queries against it. As previously mentioned, weâ€™re only going to be querying for media information from the external content source, so weâ€™ll utilise the MediaStore.Images.Media.EXTERNAL_CONTENT_URI value to do so. The only other thing we need to pass here is the previously defined projection to specify the information that we want to query for. We can pass null values for the other arguments as we do not need these to perform our query.

fun retrieveMedia(context: Context): List<Image> {
    val projection = arrayOf(
        MediaStore.Images.Media._ID,
        MediaStore.Images.Media.DISPLAY_NAME
    )
    
    context.contentResolver.query(
        MediaStore.Images.Media.EXTERNAL_CONTENT_URI,
        projection, null, null, null
    )
    return images
}

Now that we have our query in place, weâ€™re going to want to massage the result that we get back. From this query, weâ€™re going to get back a Cursor reference that we can use to retrieve information regarding the media entries. To get this information from the Cursor, weâ€™re going to need to access the columns that contain the corresponding data. And to be able to do this, we need to know the index of each of those columns, so weâ€™re going to start by getting the column index for each projection that we defined within our projection array.

fun retrieveMedia(context: Context): List<Image> {
    val projection = arrayOf(
        MediaStore.Images.Media._ID,
        MediaStore.Images.Media.DISPLAY_NAME
    )

    context.contentResolver.query(
        MediaStore.Images.Media.EXTERNAL_CONTENT_URI,
        projection, null, null, null
    )?.use { cursor ->
        val idColumn = cursor.getColumnIndexOrThrow(
			MediaStore.Images.Media._ID)
        val nameColumn = cursor.getColumnIndexOrThrow(
			MediaStore.Images.Media.DISPLAY_NAME)
    }
}

With these indexes in place, we can now use these to retrieve the required information from each of the entries that are available from the Cursor reference. Using the moveToNext() function on our Cursor reference, we can move through the cursor entries that represent the different media items that have come back from our query. Within this while operation weâ€™ll use the Cursor, along with each of the column indexes that we just retrieved, allowing us to fetch both the id and name for the current media item from our Cursor.

fun retrieveMedia(context: Context): List<Image> {
    val projection = arrayOf(
        MediaStore.Images.Media._ID,
        MediaStore.Images.Media.DISPLAY_NAME
    )

    context.contentResolver.query(
        MediaStore.Images.Media.EXTERNAL_CONTENT_URI,
        projection, null, null, null
    )?.use { cursor ->
        val idColumn = cursor.getColumnIndexOrThrow(
			MediaStore.Images.Media._ID)
        val nameColumn = cursor.getColumnIndexOrThrow(
			MediaStore.Images.Media.DISPLAY_NAME)

        while (cursor.moveToNext()) {
            val id = cursor.getLong(idColumn)
            val name = cursor.getString(nameColumn)

        }
    }
    return images
}

Now that we have this id and name for the current cursor entry, we can go ahead and create the Uri reference for the media store entry using the retrieved id.

val contentUri = ContentUris.withAppendedId(
	MediaStore.Images.Media.EXTERNAL_CONTENT_URI, id)

Finally, we can now use this generated Uri to instantiate an Image reference. Here weâ€™ll create a new list reference that will be used to hold each of these generated Image references, followed by creating a new Image reference for each Cursor entry and adding it to this list.

fun retrieveMedia(context: Context): List<Image> {
    val projection = arrayOf(
        MediaStore.Images.Media._ID,
        MediaStore.Images.Media.DISPLAY_NAME
    )
    val images = mutableListOf<Image>()

    context.contentResolver.query(
        MediaStore.Images.Media.EXTERNAL_CONTENT_URI,
        projection, null, null, null
    )?.use { cursor ->
        val idColumn = cursor.getColumnIndexOrThrow(
			MediaStore.Images.Media._ID)
        val nameColumn = cursor.getColumnIndexOrThrow(
			MediaStore.Images.Media.DISPLAY_NAME)

        while (cursor.moveToNext()) {
            val id = cursor.getLong(idColumn)
            val name = cursor.getString(nameColumn)

            val contentUri = ContentUris.withAppendedId(
                MediaStore.Images.Media.EXTERNAL_CONTENT_URI,
                id
            )
            images.add(Image(id, contentUri, name))
        }
    }
    return images
}

Once all of our Cursor logic has been executed, we simply return this list of generated Image references from the function - these will then be used by the calling point to generate the grid of images.

Loading Media

Now that we have the logic in place to retrieve the images from the media store, weâ€™re going to want to add support for the triggering of this function - allowing media to be loaded and composed within our UI. Weâ€™re going to start here by modifying the GalleryContent composable so that a list of Image references can be provided to the composable.

@Composable
fun GalleryContent(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    media: List<Image>? = null,
    permissionState: PermissionState
)

Now, when this media reference is null, it will mean that media has not yet been provided to the composable function - signifying that the composable is in a loading state. So in this scenario, weâ€™re going to want to portray this to the user by displaying a progress indicator.

Here weâ€™ll utilise the CircularProgressIndicator composable, wrapping this inside of a Box so that the indicator can be placed in the center.

@Composable
fun GalleryContent(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    media: List<Image>? = null,
    permissionState: PermissionState
) {
    when {
        permissionState.hasPermission -> {
            if (media == null) {
                Box(
                    modifier = modifier,
                    contentAlignment = Alignment.Center
                ) {
                    CircularProgressIndicator()
                }
            }
        }
        ...
    }
}

Now, if the provided media is in fact null then the progress indicator will be composed. On the other hand, weâ€™ll also want to handle the case where there is in fact media that is provided to the GalleryContent composable. We previously built out the ImageGallery composable, so weâ€™re going to compose this here to allow the display of our image grid. 

@Composable
fun GalleryContent(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    media: List<Image>? = null,
    permissionState: PermissionState
) {
    when {
        permissionState.hasPermission -> {
            if (media == null) {
                Box(
                    modifier = modifier,
                    contentAlignment = Alignment.Center
                ) {
                    CircularProgressIndicator()
                }
            } else {
                ImageGallery(
                    modifier = modifier,
                    retrieveMedia = media
                )
            }
        }
        ...
    }
}

Now that our GalleryContent composable supports the display of media items, weâ€™re going to need to provide these media items to the composable function. Weâ€™re currently composing this inside of the Gallery composable, so weâ€™re going to hop over to that composable definition so that we can provide the required media items. These media items are going to need to be held in some form of state reference, so weâ€™ll declare a new piece of mutable state in the form of a nullable Image list. Weâ€™ll also wrap this in remember so that the state is remembered across compositions.

@Composable
fun Gallery() {
	val permissionState = rememberPermissionState(
        Manifest.permission.READ_EXTERNAL_STORAGE
    )
    var retrievedMedia by remember 	
		{ mutableStateOf<List<Image>?>(null) }
    ...
}

With this state in place, weâ€™ll now want to manipulate it so that the media for our composables can be set, allowing recomposition of the image grid once that has occurred. To be able to set this state, weâ€™ll need to load the media using the previously defined retrieveMedia function. When it comes to loading this media, there are going to be several constraints:

  • Weâ€™ll only want to attempt to load this media on the initial composition, otherwise the media will be loaded every single time a composition occurs
  • Weâ€™ll only want to attempt the loading of media if we have permission to access the media from the userâ€™s device
  • Weâ€™ll need to perform the loading of media on the correct threads, otherwise we would end up blocking the UI thread
  • Once the media has been loaded, weâ€™ll need to assign it to the state reference so that the image grid can be recomposed

Starting with the first point, for this we can utilise the LaunchedEffect side-effect, allowing us to trigger some logic at the time of composition, conditionally.

When LaunchedEffect enters the composition, it will execute the block implementation that is provided to it. However, we only want to run this when the hasPermission state has changed - otherwise, we might be executing this media loading task when it doesnâ€™t need to be. For this, the LaunchedEffect also takes a key - this allows us to provide a value that will be used to determine if the side-effect should be run, which will only be the case when the key value changes. For this, we can declare the LaunchedEffect side-effect, passing the hasPermission reference for the key.

@Composable
fun Gallery() {
    val context = LocalContext.current
	val permissionState = rememberPermissionState(
        Manifest.permission.READ_EXTERNAL_STORAGE
    )
    var retrievedMedia by remember 	
		{ mutableStateOf<List<Image>?>(null) }
    
    LaunchedEffect(
		key1 = permissionState.hasPermission
	) {
        
    }
    ...
}

Now, if we have permission to access the users media then weâ€™re going to want to trigger our retrieveMedia function. This is a suspending function, so weâ€™re going to need to execute this using a coroutine scope that wonâ€™t block the UI thread. Weâ€™ll define a new coroutine scope using rememberCoroutineScope(), followed by using this to launch the coroutine within the specified context. Here we use the IO dispatcher to keep the operation off of the main thread.

@Composable
fun Gallery() {
	val scope = rememberCoroutineScope()
    val context = LocalContext.current
	val permissionState = rememberPermissionState(
        Manifest.permission.READ_EXTERNAL_STORAGE
    )
    var retrievedMedia by remember 	
		{ mutableStateOf<List<Image>?>(null) }
    
    LaunchedEffect(
		key1 = permissionState.hasPermission
	) {
        if (permissionState.hasPermission) {
            scope.launch(Dispatchers.IO) {
                val retrieveMedia = retrieveMedia(context)
                
            }
        }
    }
    ...
}

At this point, weâ€™ve loaded the media and assigned it to a variable reference, all of which is happening off of the UI thread. All thatâ€™s left to do now is hop on back over to the Main thread and assigned this media to our retrievedMedia state reference.

@Composable
fun Gallery() {
	...
    val context = LocalContext.current
	val permissionState = rememberPermissionState(
        Manifest.permission.READ_EXTERNAL_STORAGE
    )
    var retrievedMedia by remember 	
		{ mutableStateOf<List<Image>?>(null) }
    
    LaunchedEffect(
		key1 = permissionState.hasPermission
	) {
        if (permissionState.hasPermission) {
            scope.launch(Dispatchers.IO) {
                val retrieveMedia = retrieveMedia(context)
                withContext(Dispatchers.Main) {
                    retrievedMedia = retrieveMedia
                }
            }
        }
    }
    ...
}

With the above in place, weâ€™re now retrieving the required media from the media store and assigning this to a state reference. When this state change occurs, recomposition will occur for the GalleryContent and the media will be composed within our UI.

Explaining permissions

Currently, in our composable permission flow, we are immediately requesting permission from the user. The issue with this is that itâ€™s not clear as to why we might be requesting such permission. So instead of doing this upfront, weâ€™re going to compose some UI that explains to the user why we need this permission - followed by giving them the option to grant the permission to our application. Weâ€™ll start here by creating a new composable function that will be used to compose this UI, PermissionExplainer. Because this will be used to trigger the permission request, weâ€™ll also add a lambda argument, requestPermission, that will be used to detect when the user has requested to grant our application permission to access the media on their device.

@Composable
fun PermissionExplainer(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    requestPermission: () -> Unit
)

Within this composable, weâ€™re going to be displaying a message to the user (to explain why we are requesting permission), along with a button that will be used to trigger the permission flow. Each of these is going to be displaying textual content, so weâ€™ll need to add a string resource for each to the resources.xml file for this feature module.

<string name="permission_explainer_message">
	To display media we need access to the storage on your 
	device
</string>
<string name="permission_explainer_action">
	Grant permission
</string>

With these resources in place, we can now build out the composable function that will be used to display this explainer.

As outlined in the diagram above, this is going to be a minimal composable that displays both a Text and Button composable to the user. This Text composable will be used to communicate to the user why we need permission, while the Button will allow us to navigate the user to system settings to trigger the permissions flow.

Before we start adding any of these composables for the display of content, weâ€™re going to add a parent container in the form of a Column. This will be used to display the Text and Button in a vertically stacked format. When it comes to this content displayed within the Column, weâ€™re going to want to position all of this in the center. For this, weâ€™ll utilise both the horizontalAlignment and verticalArrangement arguments to apply the corresponding centralised values.

@Composable
fun PermissionExplainer(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    requestPermission: () -> Unit
) {
    Column(
        modifier = modifier.padding(16.dp),
        verticalArrangement = Arrangement.Center,
        horizontalAlignment = Alignment.CenterHorizontally
    ) {
        
    }
}

Next, weâ€™re going to go ahead and compose the Text as a child of our Column, using the resource that we just defined for the text content of the composable.

@Composable
fun PermissionExplainer(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    requestPermission: () -> Unit
) {
    Column(
        modifier = modifier.padding(16.dp),
        verticalArrangement = Arrangement.Center,
        horizontalAlignment = Alignment.CenterHorizontally
    ) {
        Text(
            text = stringResource(id =
				R.string.permission_explainer_message),
            textAlign = TextAlign.Center
        )
    }
}

Alongside this message, weâ€™re also going to add the action that will be used to trigger the permission flow - this will be in the form of a Button. This composable is going to need to display its intent to the user, for which weâ€™ll use the previously defined string resource. At this point, we can now compose our Button. While doing this weâ€™ll also utilise the Spacer composable to create some visual spacing between the Text that is also being composed within the container.

@Composable
fun PermissionExplainer(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    requestPermission: () -> Unit
) {
    Column(
        modifier = modifier.padding(16.dp),
        verticalArrangement = Arrangement.Center,
        horizontalAlignment = Alignment.CenterHorizontally
    ) {
        Text(
            text = stringResource(id =
				R.string.permission_explainer_message),
            textAlign = TextAlign.Center
        )
        Spacer(modifier = Modifier.height(16.dp))
        Button(
            onClick = {

            }
        ) {
            Text(stringResource(id =
				R.string.permission_explainer_action))
        }
    }
}

Youâ€™ll notice that above while composing the Button we are not yet implementing the onClick argument. When the user clicks this action, weâ€™re going to want to take the user to the system settings so that they can toggle the permissions for our application. However, weâ€™re not going to be handling this navigation within this composable function - instead, weâ€™re going to delegate that responsibility to the parent composable. For this, weâ€™ll add a new lambda argument to our composable function, handleLaunchSettings. Then within the onClick implementation for our Button, weâ€™ll trigger this lambda, which will fire the event back up to the parent to be handled accordingly.

@Composable
fun PermissionExplainer(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    requestPermission: () -> Unit
) {
    Column(
        modifier = modifier.padding(16.dp),
        verticalArrangement = Arrangement.Center,
        horizontalAlignment = Alignment.CenterHorizontally
    ) {
        Text(
            text = stringResource(id =
				R.string.permission_explainer_message),
            textAlign = TextAlign.Center
        )
        Spacer(modifier = Modifier.height(16.dp))
        Button(
            onClick = {
                requestPermission()
            }
        ) {
            Text(stringResource(id =
				R.string.permission_explainer_action))
        }
    }
}

We can see here that when the button is interacted with, the requestPermission lambda is invoked. This means that at the point where we compose the PermissionExplainer, weâ€™ll want to trigger the permission request flow. This is where the user will be presented with the system permission dialog, allowing them to grant or deny our application permission to access the media stored on their device.

@Composable
fun GalleryContent(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
	permissionState: PermissionState
) {
    when {
        !permissionState.permissionRequested -> {
         	PermissionExplainer(
                modifier = Modifier.fillMaxSize()
            ) {
                permissionState.launchPermissionRequest()
            }
        }
    }
}

With the above in place, the PermissionExplainer composable will now be composed when the permission has not previously been requested by our application. If the user decides to interact with the â€œGrant Permissionâ€ action composed on the UI, then the system permission dialog will be displayed on the screen.

Handling denied permissions

Now that weâ€™ve handled the success states of our permission granting, weâ€™re going to want to handle the cases where the user might have been denied access to their external storage. In this scenario we wonâ€™t be able to load any of the media, so weâ€™ll want to display a message to the user that will reflect this state.

Creating the denied state

Weâ€™re going to start here by creating a new composable function that will be used to communicate this state to the user, weâ€™ll call this DeniedPermission.

@Composable
fun DeniedPermission(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier
)

We donâ€™t go too much into how this composable is made up (as weâ€™ve covered a lot of this already in previous composables for this project), but weâ€™ll simply be using a Column to stack a message and button which will be used to communicate the permission request and provide a way for the user to trigger it.

As outlined in the diagram above, this is going to be a minimal composable that displays both a Text and Button composable to the user. This Text composable will be used to communicate this state to the user, while the Button will allow us to navigate the user to system settings to alleviate the permissions issue. Weâ€™re going to need to start here by defining some new strings resources over in our strings.xml file.

<string name="permission_message">
	External Storage Permission denied. To be able to show you 
	images from the gallery, you need to grant this app 
	permission to access the external storage.
</string>

<string name="launch_settings">
	Grant Permission in Settings
</string>

With this resource in place, we can now think about the composable content. Weâ€™ve already covered a similar structure for the permission explainer composable, so weâ€™ll build out our DeniedPermission in the same way.

@Composable
fun DeniedPermission(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier
) {
    Column(
        modifier = modifier,
        horizontalAlignment = Alignment.CenterHorizontally,
        verticalArrangement = Arrangement.Center
    ) {
        Text(
            text = stringResource(id = 
				R.string.permission_message),
            textAlign = TextAlign.Center
        )
        Spacer(modifier = Modifier.height(12.dp))
        Button(onClick = { }) {
            Text(
                text = stringResource(id = 
					R.string.launch_settings)
            )
        }
    }
}

Youâ€™ll notice that above while composing the Button we are not yet implementing the onClick argument. When the user clicks this action, weâ€™re going to want to take the user to the system settings so that they can toggle the permissions for our application. However, weâ€™re not going to be handling this navigation within this composable function - instead, weâ€™re going to delegate that responsibility to the parent composable. For this, weâ€™ll add a new lambda argument to our composable function, handleLaunchSettings. Then within the onClick implementation for our Button, weâ€™ll trigger this lambda, which will fire the event back up to the parent to be handled accordingly.

@Composable
fun DeniedPermission(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    handleLaunchSettings: () -> Unit
) {
    Column(
        modifier = modifier,
        horizontalAlignment = Alignment.CenterHorizontally,
        verticalArrangement = Arrangement.Center
    ) {
        Text(
            text = stringResource(id = 
				R.string.permission_message),
            textAlign = TextAlign.Center
        )
        Spacer(modifier = Modifier.height(12.dp))
        Button(onClick = { handleLaunchSettings() }) {
            Text(
                text = stringResource(id = 
					R.string.launch_settings)
            )
        }
    }
}

Composing the denied state

With the above in place, we now have a composable that can be used to communicate the denied permission state to the user. All we need to do now is compose this within the GalleryContent that we previously created within this chapter. For this, weâ€™re going to utilise the else clause within the when block that is being used to compose our UI based on the current permission state. This is because if the user has not granted permission, and the permission is not currently being requested, then it means that we donâ€™t have permission to access the media right now.

@Composable
fun GalleryContent(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    media: List<Image>? = null,
    permissionState: PermissionState
) {
    when {
        permissionState.hasPermission -> {
            ...
        }
        !permissionState.permissionRequested -> {
            ...
        }
        else -> {
            DeniedPermission(
                modifier = modifier,
                handleLaunchSettings = {
                    
                }
            )
        }
    }
}

Youâ€™ll notice here though that the handleLaunchSettings implementation is currently empty. To launch the system settings, weâ€™re going to need access to a context reference. We already decided to not pass this reference when working with the Image for our composable, so weâ€™re going to do the same here. Weâ€™ll add a lambda as an argument for our composable function, allowing us to delegate the launching of the system settings to the parent composable where a context reference is already available for us. Weâ€™ll then trigger this lambda within the handleLaunchSettings implementation when composing our DeniedPermission. 

@Composable
fun GalleryContent(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    media: List<Image>? = null,
    permissionState: PermissionState,
    openSettings: () -> Unit
) {
    when {
        permissionState.hasPermission -> {
            ...
        }
        !permissionState.permissionRequested -> {
            ...
        }
        else -> {
            DeniedPermission(
                modifier = modifier,
                handleLaunchSettings = {
                    openSettings()
                }
            )
        }
    }
}

Weâ€™ll then need to hop back up to our Gallery composable and implement this required argument. For the implementation of openSettings, weâ€™ll want to create a new Intent that will allow us to launch the system settings for our application - which we can do using the ACTION_APPLICATION_DETAILS_SETTINGS. When creating an intent for this action, we must provide a URI that represents that package that we wish to show the settings screen for. In our case, this is package: academy.compose.gallery, which will differ per application that you are defining this for.

// Gallery.kt

@Composable
fun Gallery() {
	...
	GalleryContent(
        modifier = Modifier.fillMaxSize(),
        media = retrievedMedia,
        openSettings = {
            context.startActivity(
                Intent(
                    Settings.
						ACTION_APPLICATION_DETAILS_SETTINGS,
                    Uri.parse("package:${context.packageName}")
                )
            )
        }
    )
}

With this in place, we can direct the user to the system settings screen for our application, prompting them to tweak the permissions as required.

Wrapping Up

Throughout this project, weâ€™ve now fully implemented our gallery feature - allowing our users to view thumbnails for the images that are on their device storage, along with performing selection to view them in an immersive format. Weâ€™ve explored the composition of many different UI components, along with how to handle permissions in a composable environment.

With all of this in place, weâ€™ll want to ensure these components remain functional within our app. In the next chapter, weâ€™re going to explore writing automated UI tests for these composables.

Testing the Gallery UI

Now that weâ€™ve built our Gallery feature, weâ€™re going to take a look at how we can write tests for our composables. Weâ€™re going to be writing some instrumentation tests using the compose ui-test-junit package - allowing us to verify that our composables are displayed and functioning as expected.

Before we can get started with our tests, weâ€™re going to need to add a couple of test specific dependencies to our project:

androidTestImplementation(
	"androidx.compose.ui:ui-test-junit4:$compose_version")
debugImplementation(
	"androidx.compose.ui:ui-test-manifest:$compose_version")

Weâ€™re also going to need to add mocks to our test - this allows us to easily provide mock references to any listeners that are provided to our composable functions, allowing us to easily verify they are triggered whenever expected.

androidTestImplementation(
	"org.mockito.kotlin:mockito-kotlin:3.2.0")
androidTestImplementation("org.mockito:mockito-android:3.12.4")

With these in place, we now have access to the required rules and functionality that allow us to test our composable UI. However, alongside these dependencies, weâ€™re also going to need to add some rules to our build.gradle file that will fix some of the compilation errors that weâ€™d currently see when trying to run our tests. Here weâ€™ll add some packagingOptions that will exclude certain packages from the added dependencies. We wonâ€™t dive too much into this concept and itâ€™s usually dependent on the versions of dependencies that are being used, so this may be redundant if you come to updating versions.

android {
	packagingOptions {
		exclude "**/attach_hotspot_windows.dll"
		exclude "META-INF/AL2.0"
		exclude "META-INF/LGPL2.1"
		exclude "META-INF/licenses/ASM"
	}
}

Testing the Gallery Content

At a high level of our feature is the GalleryContent composable. While we have a collection of focused composables that are responsible for specific parts of our UI, this composable acts as the parent container - composing each of the child composables that make up the different parts of the gallery feature. For this reason, weâ€™re going to write a collection of tests that will perform asserts to ensure the correct composables are displayed as expected. Weâ€™ll start here by creating a new test class, GalleryContentTest.

class GalleryContentTest {

}

Inside of this class, we now need to define a reference to the ComposeContentTestRule class - this is what weâ€™re going to use to set the composable content on screen, allowing us to perform interactions and assertions from within our tests. 

@get:Rule
val composeTestRule = createComposeRule()

When using this rule, we donâ€™t need to specify any form of activity for our composables to be launched in, the test rule will handle that for us. So using this rule we will set the composable content to be composed, the test will then launch a host activity which will be used to compose our provided content inside of.

Testing the Image Gallery display

With this test class configured, weâ€™re going to write some tests to assert that each of the expected composables is being displayed when required - which will be based on the state which is provided to the GalleryContent composable. Weâ€™ll start here by asserting that the Image Gallery itself is being composed. To write this first test weâ€™ll use the @Test annotation and create a new function to test that the header is displayed by default within our UI.

@Test
fun Image_Gallery_Displayed() {

}

Inside of this test, weâ€™re going to need to start by setting the composable content that is to be displayed on screen for us to assert against. Here weâ€™ll use the test rule that we previously defined, along with its setContent function. This function takes a composable function as an argument, allowing us to define what is to be composed on screen for our tests. Because weâ€™re wanting to test the GalleryContent Composable that we defined in the previous sections of this chapter, weâ€™ll go ahead and compose the GalleryContent. When composing the GalleryContent weâ€™ll need to provide references for several different arguments.

  • media: the list of Image items that are to be displayed within the gallery. For this, we will simply pass a single item that does not represent any real media, as we donâ€™t need any real data within our test.
  • permissionState: for this, weâ€™ll need to provide an implementation of the PermissionState interface. When doing so we will need to implement the required members - when doing this it is important to note the constraints which will result in the gallery being composed. For this, the hasPermission flag must be marked as true, which will result in the composition of the gallery.
  • openSettings: we donâ€™t currently need to utilise this callback within the test, so weâ€™ll leave the implementation of this block empty.
@Test
fun Image_Gallery_Displayed() {
	val permissionState = object : PermissionState {
        override val hasPermission: Boolean
            get() = true
        override val permission: String
            get() = ""
        override val permissionRequested: Boolean
            get() = false
        override val shouldShowRationale: Boolean
            get() = false

        override fun launchPermissionRequest() { }
    }

	composeTestRule.setContent {
		GalleryContent(
        	media = listOf(Image(0, Uri.EMPTY, "")),
            permissionState = permissionState,
            openSettings = {}
        )
    }
}

With this in place, we now have the GalleryContent being composed within our test. Now, so that we can locate the Image Gallery within this test, weâ€™re going to need to add a tag to the composable that we wish to perform assertions against - this tag can then be used to locate our composable within our tests. Weâ€™ll need to start here by defining a tag reference that can be accessed from both our tests and our composable.

// Tags.kt

object Tags {
    const val TAG_IMAGE_GALLERY = "image_gallery"
}

With this tag defined, weâ€™ll then need to add this to the composition of the ImageGallery composable - weâ€™ll use the testTag modifier to do so.

// GalleryContent.kt

ImageGallery(
	modifier = modifier.testTag(TAG_IMAGE_GALLERY),
	...
)

Next, weâ€™re going to locate the node within our composable hierarchy so that we can perform interactions and assertions on it. Here weâ€™ll utilise the onNodeWithTag function, providing the tag that we defined above. We can then utilise the assertIsDisplayed function to assert that the composable is being displayed as expected within the GalleryContent.

@Test
fun Image_Gallery_Displayed() {
    val permissionState = object : PermissionState {
        override val hasPermission: Boolean
            get() = true
        override val permission: String
            get() = ""
        override val permissionRequested: Boolean
            get() = false
        override val shouldShowRationale: Boolean
            get() = false

        override fun launchPermissionRequest() { }
    }
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        GalleryContent(
            media = listOf(Image(0, Uri.EMPTY, "")),
            permissionState = permissionState,
            openSettings = {}
        )
    }
    composeTestRule
        .onNodeWithTag(TAG_IMAGE_GALLERY)
        .assertIsDisplayed()
}

With this in place, weâ€™ll be able to run this test and see that the Image Gallery is being composed as expected.

Testing the Progress display

Along with testing the visibility to the image gallery within the GalleryContent composable, weâ€™re going to want to assert that the progress is displayed when expected - this is when the images are being loaded from the media store. Before we can do this though, weâ€™re going to need to add another tag so that the composable can be located within the UI hierarchy.

// Tags.kt

object Tags {
    ...
	const val TAG_PROGRESS = "progress"
}

With this tag in place, we can now assign it to the corresponding composable using the testTag modifier - in this case, itâ€™ll be the progress container within the GalleryContent composable.

// GalleryContent.kt

Box(
	modifier = modifier.testTag(TAG_PROGRESS),
	contentAlignment = Alignment.Center
) {
	CircularProgressIndicator()
}

With this tag now assigned to a composable, we can use this within our tests to assert the visibility of the progress indicator within our UI. Within the GalleryContent composable, the progress indicator is displayed when the permission exists to access the media but the media has not yet been loaded - which would be signified by the media argument representing a null value. For this state within our tests, weâ€™ll also need to provide the same PermissionState state that represents a granted media permission, passing the null value for the media argument.

@Test
fun Progress_Displayed() {
    val permissionState = object : PermissionState {
        override val hasPermission: Boolean
            get() = true
        override val permission: String
            get() = ""
        override val permissionRequested: Boolean
            get() = false
        override val shouldShowRationale: Boolean
            get() = false

        override fun launchPermissionRequest() { }
    }
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        GalleryContent(
            media = null,
            permissionState = permissionState,
            openSettings = {}
        )
    }
}

With the above in place, weâ€™ll now need to assert that the progress composable is being displayed. Weâ€™ll use the TAG_PROGRESS tag that we defined to locate the desired node within our composable hierarchy, followed by utilising the assertIsDisplayed function to assert that the node is being displayed within our UI.

@Test
fun Progress_Displayed() {
    val permissionState = object : PermissionState {
        override val hasPermission: Boolean
            get() = true
        override val permission: String
            get() = ""
        override val permissionRequested: Boolean
            get() = false
        override val shouldShowRationale: Boolean
            get() = false

        override fun launchPermissionRequest() { }
    }
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        GalleryContent(
            media = null,
            permissionState = permissionState,
            openSettings = {}
        )
    }
    composeTestRule
        .onNodeWithTag(TAG_PROGRESS)
        .assertIsDisplayed()
}

Testing the Denied Permission display

When it comes to composable display, weâ€™re going to finally want to assert that the denied permissions composable is being displayed within our UI. For this, weâ€™re going to need to add another tag so that the composable can be located within the UI hierarchy.

object Tags {
    ...
    const val TAG_DENIED_PERMISSION = "denied_permission"
}

With this tag in place, we can now assign it to the corresponding composable using the testTag modifier - in this case, itâ€™ll be the DeniedPermission composable within the GalleryContent.

// GalleryContent.kt

DeniedPermission(
	modifier = modifier.testTag(TAG_DENIED_PERMISSION),
	handleLaunchSettings = {
		openSettings()
	}
)

With this tag now assigned to a composable, we can use this within our tests to assert the visibility of the DeniedPermisson composable within our UI. This composable is displayed when permission to access the media has previously been denied. For this state within our tests, weâ€™ll need to provide the PermissionState state that represents a denied media permission. Here we can use the hasPermission flag to state that the permission is not present, followed by the permissionRequested flag to state that the permission has been previously requested - these two flags together signify that the permission had previously been requested, but denied.

@Test
fun Denied_Permission_Displayed() {
	val permissionState = object : PermissionState {
		override val hasPermission: Boolean
            get() = false
        override val permission: String
            get() = ""
        override val permissionRequested: Boolean
            get() = true
        override val shouldShowRationale: Boolean
            get() = false

        override fun launchPermissionRequest() { }
    }
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        GalleryContent(
            media = null,
            permissionState = permissionState,
            openSettings = {}
        )
    }
}

With this PermissionState now configured, we can utilise the TAG_DENIED_PERMISSION tag to assert that the corresponding composable node is currently being displayed.

@Test
fun Denied_Permission_Displayed() {
	val permissionState = object : PermissionState {
		override val hasPermission: Boolean
            get() = false
        override val permission: String
            get() = ""
        override val permissionRequested: Boolean
            get() = true
        override val shouldShowRationale: Boolean
            get() = false

        override fun launchPermissionRequest() { }
    }
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        GalleryContent(
            media = null,
            permissionState = permissionState,
            openSettings = {}
        )
    }
    composeTestRule
        .onNodeWithTag(TAG_DENIED_PERMISSION)
        .assertIsDisplayed()
}

Testing the Permission Request trigger

Now that we are asserting the different visibilities within the GalleryContent composable, weâ€™re next going to want to assert that the permission is being requested as expected when the permission has not yet been granted or requested. Weâ€™re going to start here by creating a mock representation of the PermissionState - this will allow us to verify the expected interaction with this interface.

@Test
fun Permission_Request_Triggered() {
    val permissionState = mock<PermissionState>()
}

Next, weâ€™re going to want to compose the GalleryContent. Weâ€™ll pass a null value for the media to signify that the media has not yet been loaded, along with the mock representation of our PermissionState reference.

@Test
fun Permission_Request_Triggered() {
    val permissionState = mock<PermissionState>()
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        GalleryContent(
            media = null,
            permissionState = permissionState,
            openSettings = {}
        )
    }
}

When the GalleryContent is composed in this state, we would expect that the launchPermissionRequest function of our PermissionState interface is invoked. Weâ€™re going to utilise the verify functionality from mockito to assert that this is the case.

@Test
fun Permission_Request_Triggered() {
    val permissionState = mock<PermissionState>()
    whenever(permissionState.permissionRequested)
        .doReturn(false)
    whenever(permissionState.hasPermission)
        .doReturn(false)

    composeTestRule.setContent {
        GalleryContent(
            media = null,
            permissionState = permissionState,
            openSettings = {}
        )
    }
    val grantPermission =
		InstrumentationRegistry.getInstrumentation()
			.targetContext.getString(
				R.string.permission_explainer_action)
    composeTestRule
        .onNodeWithText(grantPermission)
        .performClick()
    verify(permissionState).launchPermissionRequest()
}

With this in place, once the composition has occurred, the verification will be run to assert that the launchPermissionRequest function is called on our PermissionState reference.

Testing the Denied State

As we saw in the previous tests, the DeniedPermission composable is composed within our UI when the permission to access media has been denied by the user. While we have tested that this is displayed under the expected conditions, weâ€™re also going to want to test that the contents of this composable are being composed as expected. Weâ€™re going to start here by creating a new test class, DeniedPermissionTest, configuring the test rule in the process. 

class DeniedPermissionTest {

    @get:Rule
    val composeTestRule = createComposeRule()

}

Within this composable, there are a couple of components being displayed. The first is a message that lets the user know about the denied permission - this is quite important and provides some context as to why the user is seeing this state. For this reason, weâ€™re going to want to test that it is being displayed as expected. Weâ€™ll need to start by composing the DeniedPermission composable, for which weâ€™ll provide an empty implementation of the handleLaunchSettings argument.

@Test
fun Message_Displayed() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        DeniedPermission(
            handleLaunchSettings = { }
        )
    }
}

With our composable now being available within our test, weâ€™re going to want to perform the assertion - here weâ€™ll want to check that the denied permission message is being composed.
