The message being displayed here is being referenced from the R.string.permission_message string resource, so weâ€™ll want to access this resource and assert that a node exists which is displaying this message.

Weâ€™ll start by utilising the onNodeWithText function on our test rule, providing a string value for the R.string.permission_message resource. Once a node has been located that matches the representation of this string value, weâ€™re going to want to assert that it is being displayed. Here weâ€™ll use the assertIsDisplayed function, allowing us to assert that this node is being fully displayed within the UI.

@Test
fun Message_Displayed() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        DeniedPermission(
            handleLaunchSettings = { }
        )
    }
    composeTestRule
        .onNodeWithText(
            InstrumentationRegistry
				.getInstrumentation()
					.targetContext.getString(
                    	R.string.permission_message)
        )
        .assertIsDisplayed()
}

At this point, we know that the denied permission message is being displayed to the user. Alongside this, a button is displayed which allows the user to trigger the system settings screen for our application. This is a pretty important component within the composable, so weâ€™re going to want to assert that itâ€™s being composed as expected. To assert that this is the case, weâ€™re going to need to add another tag that can be assigned to this button.

object Tags {
	...
    const val TAG_PERMISSIONS_BUTTON = 
		"permissions_button"
}

With this tag defined, weâ€™ll now need to assign this to our Button composable using the testTag modifier.

// DeniedPermission.kt

Button(
	modifier = Modifier
		.testTag(Tags.TAG_PERMISSIONS_BUTTON),
	onClick = { handleLaunchSettings() }
)

Weâ€™re now going to write a new test, Action_Displayed, which will contain the assertion for this button composable. Within this test weâ€™ll need to start by composing the DeniedPermission, again providing an empty implementation block for the handleLaunchSettings lambda.

@Test
fun Action_Displayed() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        DeniedPermission(
            handleLaunchSettings = { }
        )
    }
}

At this point, weâ€™re now ready to assert that the Button is being displayed as expected. Using the previously defined TAG_PERMISSIONS_BUTTON tag, weâ€™ll locate the node for the settings button and use the assertIsDisplayed function to assert that the button is being displayed as expected.

@Test
fun Action_Displayed() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        DeniedPermission(
            handleLaunchSettings = { }
        )
    }
    composeTestRule
        .onNodeWithTag(TAG_PERMISSIONS_BUTTON)
        .assertIsDisplayed()
}

With this test in place, we now know that the permissions button is being displayed as expected. This allows us to ensure that the user will always be able to grant media access permission to our app outside of the initial permissions request flow, as without this, this feature of our app will be pretty unusable.

Now that we know this settings button is being displayed as expected, weâ€™re going to want to assert that the handleLaunchSettings is being triggered when the button is clicked. If this wasnâ€™t behaving as expected, the button would never result in the user being navigated to the system settings screen for our application.

Within our test, weâ€™re going to need to start by composing the DeniedPermission composable. When composing this, weâ€™ll pass in a mock lambda function for the handleLaunchSettings argument. This means that we can use this mock to verify that interactions have taken place based on composable events.

@Test
fun Action_Triggers_Callback() {
    val handleLaunchSettings: () -> Unit = mock()
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        DeniedPermission(
            handleLaunchSettings = handleLaunchSettings
        )
    }
}

Using the previously defined TAG_PERMISSIONS_BUTTON tag, weâ€™ll locate the node for the settings button and use the performClick function to trigger a click event on the Button composable.

@Test
fun Action_Triggers_Callback() {
    val handleLaunchSettings: () -> Unit = mock()
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        DeniedPermission(
            handleLaunchSettings = handleLaunchSettings
        )
    }
    composeTestRule
        .onNodeWithTag(TAG_PERMISSIONS_BUTTON)
        .performClick()
}

When this click action is triggered, this is the point that we would expect the handleLaunchSettings to be invoked so that the parent composable can handle the event. We can verify this within our test by using mockito and its verify function to assert that the lambda has been invoked. 

@Test
fun Action_Triggers_Callback() {
    val handleLaunchSettings: () -> Unit = mock()
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        DeniedPermission(
            handleLaunchSettings = handleLaunchSettings
        )
    }
    composeTestRule
        .onNodeWithTag(TAG_PERMISSIONS_BUTTON)
        .performClick()
    verify(handleLaunchSettings).invoke()
}

When this lambda is invoked as expected, the test will succeed - otherwise, the lambda not being triggered will mean that our verification will not be satisfied and the test will fail.

Testing the Image Grid

The key part of our feature is the image gallery itself, used to display a grid of selectable images to the user. If this wasnâ€™t displaying the images as intended, then the feature would be pretty unusable! To ensure that this never occurs weâ€™re going to write some tests to assert the expected behaviours of the gallery.

Testing the Image Gallery

Weâ€™ll start here by creating a new test class, ImageGalleryTest.

class ImageGalleryTest {

    @get:Rule
    val composeTestRule = createComposeRule()

}

For our first test, weâ€™re going to assert that the images are correctly being displayed within the gallery grid.

@Test
fun Images_Displayed() {

}

Within these tests, weâ€™re going to need to interact with not only the grid, but also the individual images that make up our grid. For this reason, weâ€™re going to need to add two new tags to our Tags object.

// Tags.kt

object Tags {
    ...
	const val TAG_IMAGE_GRID = "image_grid"
	const val TAG_IMAGE = "image_"
}

With these tags in place, weâ€™re now going to want to apply them to the corresponding composables. Weâ€™ll start by using the testTag function to apply the TAG_IMAGE_GRID tag to the LazyVerticalGrid that represents the grid of images.

LazyVerticalGrid(
	modifier = modifier.testTag(TAG_IMAGE_GRID),
	cells = GridCells.Fixed(2)
)

Next, weâ€™re going to want to apply the TAG_IMAGE tag so that we can interact with each image within the gallery. When defining this tag we appended an underscore on the end, leaving space to append some form of id onto the tag. When using the testTag function to apply a tag to the GalleryImage composable, weâ€™re going to utilise the TAG_IMAGE tag while appending the id of the current Image item that is being composed. This means that from within our tests we can now reference the corresponding GalleryImage composable for a given Image.

GalleryImage(
	modifier = Modifier
		.clickable {
			selectedImage = it.uri
		}
		.height(150.dp)
		.fillMaxWidth()
		.testTag(TAG_IMAGE + it.id),
	uri = it.uri,
	scaleType = ContentScale.Crop
)

With these tags now in place, weâ€™re able to reference the corresponding composables to perform assertions on. Before we can do this though, weâ€™re going to want to start by composing our ImageGallery, providing a list of images to be composed for the image grid.

@Test
fun Images_Displayed() {
    val media = listOf(Image(0, Uri.EMPTY, ""),
		Image(1, Uri.EMPTY, ""))
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        ImageGallery(
            retrieveMedia = media
        )
    }
}

Now that the gallery is being composed we can go ahead and assert that the expected images are being displayed within the grid. Using our media list, weâ€™re going to want to loop through the Image references contained within this. Using our TAG_IMAGE_GRID tag we can locate the node for the image gallery itself, followed by using the onChildAt function to locate the node at the current index of our for loop. We expect that the current Image item within the media list will represent the child at the given index of the grid, so we can perform the assertion in this way. For each child weâ€™re going to want to assert that the tag matches the expected state, using the id of the given Image. To assert this weâ€™ll take the TAG_IMAGE tag, appending the id of the current Image item and using the hasTestTag function to verify that the tag of the current grid item matches this expected value.

@Test
fun Images_Displayed() {
    val media = listOf(Image(0, Uri.EMPTY, ""),
		Image(1, Uri.EMPTY, ""))
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        ImageGallery(
            retrieveMedia = media
        )
    }
    media.forEachIndexed { index, image ->
        composeTestRule
            .onNodeWithTag(TAG_IMAGE_GRID)
            .onChildAt(index)
            .assert(hasTestTag(TAG_IMAGE + image.id))
    }
}

Testing the Image Preview

Now that we can assert the display of gallery images within our UI, weâ€™re going to want to ensure that the image preview is composed when one of the gallery images has been selected. In this test, weâ€™re going to want to interact with a gallery image, followed by asserting that the preview has been displayed. Before we can perform this assertion, weâ€™ll need to add a new tag that can be used to locate this preview composable.

// Tags.kt

object Tags {
    ...
	const val TAG_IMAGE_PREVIEW = "image_preview"
}

With this tag in place, we can now assign this to the composition of the GalleryPreview composable within the ImageGallery.

GalleryPreview(
	modifier = Modifier
		.fillMaxSize()
		.testTag(TAG_IMAGE_PREVIEW),
	image = image,
	onDismiss = {
		selectedImage = null
	}
)

Before we can assert the composition of the preview, weâ€™re going to need to compose the ImageGallery so that we can trigger the preview and assert its existence. Similar to the previous tests, weâ€™ll compose this ImageGallery by providing a list containing a single Image item.

@Test
fun Preview_Displayed() {
	val media = listOf(Image(0, Uri.EMPTY, ""), Image(1, Uri.EMPTY, ""))
	composeTestRule.setContent {
		ImageGallery(
			retrieveMedia = media
		)
	}
}

Weâ€™re then going to utilise the previously added TAG_IMAGE_GRID tag to interact with the image gallery. Here weâ€™ll perform a click interaction on the first child - weâ€™ll locate this child node using the onChildAt function, followed by the performClick function to perform the click interaction. We retrieve the first child at index 0 here because there is only a single Image item in the media that we have provided to the composable.

@Test
fun Preview_Displayed() {
	val media = listOf(Image(0, Uri.EMPTY, ""), Image(1, Uri.EMPTY, ""))
	composeTestRule.setContent {
		ImageGallery(
			retrieveMedia = media
		)
	}
	composeTestRule
        .onNodeWithTag(TAG_IMAGE_GRID)
        .onChildAt(0)
        .performClick()
}

Now that the image gallery is being composed and we have clicked on an Image, weâ€™d expect the image preview to be displayed. We can now use the TAG_IMAGE_PREVIEW tag to locate the node that represents the GalleryPreview composable, followed by the assertIsDisplayed function to check that the preview is being displayed.

@Test
fun Preview_Displayed() {
	val media = listOf(Image(0, Uri.EMPTY, ""), Image(1, Uri.EMPTY, ""))
	composeTestRule.setContent {
		ImageGallery(
			retrieveMedia = media
		)
	}
	composeTestRule
        .onNodeWithTag(TAG_IMAGE_GRID)
        .onChildAt(0)
        .performClick()

    composeTestRule
        .onNodeWithTag(TAG_IMAGE_PREVIEW)
        .assertIsDisplayed()
}

With these interactions in place, weâ€™d expect that the image gallery would be composed, followed by the image preview once an item from the gallery is interacted with. With this test, we can now assert that this expected flow of operations is the case.

Building a Music Dashboard

Many multimedia focused applications offer an entire catalogue of media to their users. This catalogue is often split into multiple categories - be it user favourites, new additions or items that are currently featured. This can be a lot of information for users to take in, so these collections are often split into individual sections on a screen. This media dashboard allows the user to access the catalogue on offer, being able to focus on a specific kind of content and in turn making it easier to navigate through the catalogue on offer.

With the above in mind, weâ€™re going to be building out a media catalogue screen using Jetpack Compose.

While at first, this might just sound like a list of content, there is much more to it than that - there are many different layouts, components and interactions that we need to take into account when building out this dashboard.

  • Build a content list that supports 3 different kinds of layouts, as well as different scroll directions
  • Provide the ability to search for content in the catalogue, persisting the UI based on the current search queries
  • Utilise the backdrop scaffold to create layered content
  • A collapsed and full-screen media playback component that displays the currently playing track

We can see here that when it comes to the music dashboard screen, there is more to it than a simple list to display a catalogue of content. Alongside the state and event management that comes with this screen, we need to build out several different UI components using Jetpack Compose to bring our music catalogue to life.

Defining the Music Dashboard State

Within our music dashboard, weâ€™re going to be displaying a range of data that makes up the state of the screen. This data is going to be made up of music tracks but split up into a collection of different purposes.

  • A list of music tracks that are marked as featured
  • A list of music tracks that are marked as new
  • A list of music tracks that are marked as recent
  • The currently playing track
  • The current search query
  • The results from the current search

Along with the different UI components that are going to make up our screen, there are a few different pieces of state that make up the state of our screen. Letâ€™s start to take the above requirements and build out a class that will represent the state of our composable UI. Weâ€™ll start by creating a new class to hold the state of our screen:

// MusicDashboardState.kt

data class MusicDashboardState()

Modelling the screen status

When it comes to the data that is being displayed within our UI, in a real-world scenario this is going to be loaded. In this case of our project, weâ€™re going to be loading this from a data factory so that we can focus on building composable UI. So that we can have the current scenario of our screen represented within the state of our screen, weâ€™re going to model the possible scenarios in the form of an enum class, Status. Within this class, weâ€™re going to define two values that can be represented by our type, LOADING and SUCCESS.

// Status.kt

enum class Status {
    LOADING, SUCCESS, IDLE
}

Now that we have this enum class defined, weâ€™ll go ahead and add a representation of this to our state class. Weâ€™ll default this to the value of IDLE so that when the state is initialised it has a default value assigned to it.

// MusicDashboardState.kt

data class MusicDashboardState(
    val status: Status = Status.LOADING
)

Modelling the Music Track

Now that we have this screen status defined, weâ€™re going to move on to modelling the key part of our music feature, the track representation. Each track within our UI is going to be represented by a class which holds various properties used to describe a given track. For each track, weâ€™re going to need a collection of information.

  • id - a string representing the unique id used to identify the track
  • title - a string representing the title of the track
  • artist - a string representing the name of the artist
  • cover - the color value used as a visual representation of the track
  • length - a Long value representing the length of the track
  • isNew - a boolean value that represents whether the track is new
  • isFeatured - a boolean value that represents whether the track is featured

With the above properties and their respective type, we can go ahead and construct a data class to represent this structure.

// Track.kt

data class Track(
    val id: String,
    val title: String,
    val artist: String,
    val cover: Color,
    val length: Long,
    val isNew: Boolean,
    val isFeatured: Boolean
)

With this data class in place, we now have a Track class which can be used to represent the different tracks that are being displayed within our music dashboard. So that we can render these tracks within our UI, weâ€™re going to need to add a source of these tracks to our state class. Here weâ€™ll go ahead and add a new tracks property to our MusicDashboardState class, providing a default value of null for when no tracks have yet been set.

// MusicDashboardState.kt

data class MusicDashboardState(
    val status: ResultStatus = ResultStatus.LOADING,
    val tracks: List<Track>? = null
)

Modelling the Now Playing state

Now that we have the class modelled for each Track that is going to be rendered within our dashboard UI, we can start to think about modelling the playback state for the track that is currently being played. This allows us to compose this information to the user, giving awareness of the Track that is currently being played.

For this, weâ€™re going to need more information than the Track that is currently being played. Weâ€™re also going to need to know the current state of playback (is the track being played, has it been paused etc), as well as the current position of playback. To model this information weâ€™re going to create a new class, NowPlaying, which will be used to hold this information around the playback of our track. Weâ€™ll start here by adding a reference to the Track that is currently being played.

// NowPlaying.kt

data class NowPlaying(
    val track: Track
)

Alongside this, weâ€™re going to add a Long reference which will be used to hold the current playback position of the provided track.

// NowPlaying.kt

data class NowPlaying(
    val track: Track,
    val position: Long
)

When it comes to the NowPlaying track, weâ€™re also going to want to know the current state of playback - this is so that we can display the corresponding icon within the media player. For this representation weâ€™re going to create a new enum, NowPlayingState. This enum will have three values - playing, paused and stopped.

enum class NowPlayingState {    
	PLAYING, PAUSED, STOPPED
}

With this enum defined, weâ€™ll now want to add this to our NowPlaying class.

data class NowPlaying(
    val track: Track,
    val position: Long,
	val state: NowPlayingState
)

Weâ€™ll now add a representation of this NowPlaying class to our MusicDashboardState class. This value will be nullable, as there may not currently be any track selected for playback (such as when the feature is first opened).

// MusicDashboardState.kt

data class MusicDashboardState(
    val status: ResultStatus = ResultStatus.LOADING,
    val tracks: List<Track>? = null,
    val nowPlaying: NowPlaying? = null
)

With this value now added to our state, we can now store playback information for the currently playing track which is accessible from the state of our feature.

Modelling the Search state

Alongside the ability to manage playback for a track within the music dashboard, we also offer the ability to perform a search query against the contents of the tracks library. To utilise this feature, the user needs to input a query into the search bar component - and so that the value of this search query can be composed into our UI, the query that is entered here is going to need to be a part of our state.

Weâ€™ll start here by adding a new value to our MusicDashboardState state class in the form of a String. This value will represent the search query that has been entered by the user, so weâ€™ll call this searchTerm. Weâ€™ll also mark this field as nullable, as that will allow us to signify that a search is not currently taking place - and therefore the search state should not be composed within our UI.

// MusicDashboardState.kt

data class MusicDashboardState(
    val status: ResultStatus = ResultStatus.LOADING,
    val tracks: List<Track>? = null,
    val nowPlaying: NowPlaying? = null,
    val searchTerm: String? = null
)

Whenever the user enters or makes a change to the current search term, the music dashboard will display a list of search results based on the query. Because these search results are going to be composed within our UI, weâ€™ll need to have these results as a part of our state. Each of these results is going to be represented by an instance of a Track, so we can simply add a new field in the form of a List<Track> to our state class. Weâ€™ll call this searchResults, as well as making the field nullable - as there may not always be search results to be displayed within our UI.

// MusicDashboardState.kt

data class MusicDashboardState(
    val status: ResultStatus = ResultStatus.LOADING,
    val tracks: List<Track>? = null,
    val nowPlaying: NowPlaying? = null,
    val searchTerm: String? = null,
    val searchResults: List<Track>? = null
)

Modelling Track access

While we have the tracks defined as a value within our state, our tracks are going to need to be accessible in three different types of collections - new tracks, featured tracks and recent tracks. While we could have modelled this as three different collections within our state class, weâ€™re going to take a different approach and create three functions within our data class that will be used to filter out and provide the required track types.

Weâ€™re going to start here by creating a function that will be used to provide the collection of new tracks. For this, weâ€™ll create a new function, newTracks. This function is going to be used to filter out the tracks from our Track collection whose isNew flag represents the value of true. Weâ€™ll also utilise null safety here, so that if the tracks collection within our state is null, then a null value is simply returned from the function.

// MusicDashboardState.kt

data class MusicDashboardState(
    ...
) {

    fun newTracks() = tracks?.filter { it.isNew }

}

Weâ€™ll want to do a similar thing for retrieving featured tracks, so weâ€™ll start here by creating a new function, featuredTracks. For this, weâ€™ll do a similar thing as the newTracks implementation, except returning the track references whose isFeatured flag represents a true value.

// MusicDashboardState.kt

data class MusicDashboardState(
    ...
) {

    fun newTracks() = tracks?.filter { it.isNew }

    fun featuredTracks() = tracks?.filter { it.isFeatured }

}

Finally, weâ€™ll create a new function recentTracks that will be used to return tracks to be used for display in the â€˜libraryâ€™ feed. Here weâ€™ll simply only want to display tracks that are not currently being displayed in the â€˜newâ€™ and â€˜featuredâ€™ feeds. Weâ€™ll use the same approach to filter the tracks out from the collection, returning only tracks that have a false value for both the isFeatured and isNew flags. This will return us all of the Track references that have not been returned from the previous two functions, allowing us to display these tracks within the â€˜libraryâ€™ feed.

// MusicDashboardState.kt

data class MusicDashboardState(
    ...
) {

    fun newTracks() = tracks?.filter { it.isNew }

    fun featuredTracks() = tracks?.filter { it.isFeatured }

    fun libraryTracks() = tracks?.filter { 
		!it.isFeatured && !it.isNew 
	}

}

With all of this in place, we now have a class that can be used to represent the state of our UI. Over the next few sections of this chapter, weâ€™ll utilise this state when building out our UI, modifying its values as interactions with composables take place, triggering recompositions to reflect any state changes.

Creating the Music Dashboard ViewModel

Now that we have the state modelled for our Music Dashboard, we can start thinking about the ViewModel that will be used to manage that state and provide a way to orchestrate it to the user interface.

Setting up the ViewModel

Before we can get started here, weâ€™re going to add a new dependency to our project that will give us access to the Android Lifecycle ViewModel class:

implementation "androidx.lifecycle:lifecycle-viewmodel-compose:2.4.0"

ðŸ’¡ You arenâ€™t required to use a ViewModel when working with compose. For the sake of these exercises, helps us to keep things simple and follow an approach that many developers are familiar with.

Next, weâ€™ll create a new ViewModel, called MusicViewModel.

// MusicViewModel.kt

class MusicViewModel : ViewModel()

This ViewModel is going to need to hold a reference to the state of our screen. For this weâ€™re going to utilise StateFlow - this allows us to create a state-holder observable flow that will emit the default state we provide to it, along with any updates that occur during its lifetime. Here weâ€™ll create a new MutableStateFlow instance, providing a reference to our MusicDashboardState class as the default value for our StateFlow:

// MusicViewModel.kt

class MusicViewModel : ViewModel() {

    val uiState = MutableStateFlow(MusicDashboardState())

}

With this in place, we now have a StateFlow reference that is holding a reference to our authentication state, initialising it with a new instance of the state class and relying on the defaults that the constructor provides.

Manipulating state using events

While this state is now in place, we need to start thinking about the different ways in which it can be manipulated - whenever something is changed in our UI (track selected, search triggered), weâ€™ll want to update the state within our ViewModel so that the observing UI can reflect those changes.

For when this is the case, weâ€™re going to model some events that can be triggered in our composable UI and in turn these events will be used to manipulate the state within the view model. This allows us to have a single way of our composable UI communicating with the ViewModel, rather than needing to pass the entire ViewModel or many references to separate functions which could be used to trigger state changes. Instead, we can pass a single function reference to our composable UI which can then be used to trigger these events in the ViewModel. For these events weâ€™re going to need to define different types that can be triggered, so weâ€™ll go ahead and create a new sealed class to represent these.

// MusicDashboardEvent.kt

sealed class MusicDashboardEvent {

}

Handling content refresh

With this sealed class in place, we can start to think about using it to represent the different events that can occur. Weâ€™re going to start by handling the scenario where we are required to load content into the music dashboard - this will be either for the initial load of the screen or for any refreshes that might occur. Weâ€™ll go ahead and declare a new object for a MusicDashboardEvent type, in the form of RefreshContent.

// MusicDashboardEvent.kt

sealed class MusicDashboardEvent {

    object RefreshContent: MusicDashboardEvent()

}

With this in place, we now have an instance of the MusicDashboardEvent event that can be used to trigger refresh operations for the data of our dashboard. When this event is triggered, weâ€™re going to want to simulate the loading of dashboard data - so weâ€™re going to create a new function, loadContent. In this function, weâ€™re going to emit a new value to our state where weâ€™ll set several values to the state reference.

  • status - because the data has been loaded weâ€™ll set this to the SUCCESS value
  • tracks - weâ€™re not going to be loading data, so weâ€™ll use our ContentFactory to create a list of content, assigning the value of this to the tracks property within the state reference
  • nowPlaying - for the currently playing track, weâ€™re going to use the first track from the created list to create a NowPlaying reference. Again, using our ContentFactory to do so.
private fun loadContent() {
    val data = ContentFactory.makeContentList()
    uiState.value = uiState.value.copy(
        status = ResultStatus.SUCCESS,
        tracks = data,
        nowPlaying = ContentFactory.makeNowPlaying(data[0])
    )
}

With this function in place, we can now trigger this when the RefreshContentevent is triggered. For this weâ€™ll create a new function, handleEvent, that will be used to handle each of the MusicCatalogEvent references that are passed to it. Weâ€™ll start here by defining a new when block, triggering our loadContent function when the contentEvent is of the RefreshContent type.

class MusicViewModel : ViewModel() {

    ...

    fun handleEvent(contentEvent: MusicCatalogEvent) {
        when (contentEvent) {
            is MusicCatalogEvent.RefreshContent -> loadContent()
        }
    }

    private fun loadContent() {
    	val data = ContentFactory.makeContentList()
    	uiState.value = uiState.value.copy(
        	status = ResultStatus.SUCCESS,
        	tracks = data,
        	nowPlaying = ContentFactory.makeNowPlaying(data[0])
    	)
	}
}

Handling search queries

Alongside the need to refresh the dashboard content, weâ€™re going to be allowing users to search for content within this data. This search operation is also going to be represented by a MusicDashboardEvent event type, so weâ€™ll go ahead and declare a new event in the form of Search. Weâ€™re going to need to tie some data to this event, which will be the query which is being performed. This also means that our Search event needs to be in the form of a class, allowing us to declare a constructor with the required arguments.

// MusicDashboardEvent.kt

sealed class MusicDashboardEvent {

    object RefreshContent: MusicDashboardEvent()

    class Search(val searchTerm: String): MusicDashboardEvent()

}

ðŸ’¡ When you donâ€™t require arguments for a sealed class you can use an object for the type. On the other hand, using a class allows you to declare a constructor with any additional information that you require to be tied to that class.

With this even in place, we can now add to our handleEvent function so that the search event is handled accordingly. When it comes to searching through the catalogue, weâ€™re not going to be implementing a complex search method - weâ€™re simply going to check whether the title or artist of a track contains the provided search query. We can implement this using the kotlin filter function.

val results = uiState.value.tracks!!.filter {
    it.title.contains(
		searchTerm, 
		ignoreCase = true
	) ||
	it.artist.contains(
		searchTerm, 
		ignoreCase = true
	)
}

We can then take the result of this filter operation and emit it to our state along with the current searchTerm. This is so that we can persist the search term in the search bar of the UI, along with composing the list of tracks from the results of the search.

class MusicViewModel : ViewModel() {

    ...

    fun handleEvent(contentEvent: MusicCatalogEvent) {
        when (contentEvent) {
            is MusicCatalogEvent.Search -> 
				performSearch(contentEvent.searchTerm)
        }
    }

    private fun performSearch(searchTerm: String) {
        val results = uiState.value.tracks!!.filter {
            it.title.contains(
				searchTerm, 
				ignoreCase = true
			) ||
            it.artist.contains(
				searchTerm, 
				ignoreCase = true
			)
        }
        uiState.value = uiState.value.copy(
            searchTerm = searchTerm,
            searchResults = results
        )
    }
}

Handling search query clearing

Because the currently performed search query is going to be set within the state for our screen, itâ€™s going to need to be possible to clear this state from within the UI. When this state is cleared, the search will essentially be reset and the user can be displayed with the initial dashboard state that was in place before the search operation was first triggered. We donâ€™t require any additional information for this operation, so weâ€™ll define a new event ClearSearchQuery in the form of an object.

// MusicCatalogEvent.kt

sealed class MusicCatalogEvent {

    object RefreshContent: MusicCatalogEvent()

    class Search(val searchTerm: String): MusicCatalogEvent()

    object ClearSearchQuery: MusicCatalogEvent()

}

When it comes to handling this event, we can simply emit an updated version of our state that sets the value of the searchTerm property to null.

class MusicViewModel : ViewModel() {

    ...

    fun handleEvent(contentEvent: MusicCatalogEvent) {
        when (contentEvent) {
			...
           	MusicCatalogEvent.ClearSearchQuery -> {
                uiState.value = uiState.value.copy(
                    searchTerm = null
                )
            }
        }
    }

    ...
}

Handling track playback

Whether data is being loaded into the dashboard or the user has searched for music, each music item is going to be selectable so that it can be played. While we arenâ€™t going to be playing any audio within our project, weâ€™re going to simulate this behaviour so that we can create an audio playback functionality both within our UI and state. So that we can set the audio as playing within our state, weâ€™ll need to start by modelling some events to allow the manipulation of audio behaviour. Weâ€™ll start here by allowing an audio item to be played, for which weâ€™ll add a new event in the form of PlayTrack. When an item is being played, weâ€™ll need this information to be tied to an event. Here weâ€™ll do this via a constructor argument in the form of a Track reference. This means that when a track is selected, weâ€™ll have the required information for that track so that we can start the playback flow.

// MusicCatalogEvent.kt

sealed class MusicCatalogEvent {

    object RefreshContent: MusicCatalogEvent()

    class Search(val searchTerm: String): MusicCatalogEvent()

    object ClearSearchQuery: MusicCatalogEvent()

	class PlayTrack(val track: Track): MusicCatalogEvent()

}

When it comes to track playback, we arenâ€™t going to be supporting the playback of media - weâ€™ll instead be faking this within our UI so that we can focus on learning how to build these UI components with Jetpack Compose. To simulate media playback weâ€™re going to utilise a coroutine Job that will allow us to update the currently playing track position every second, simulating the playback of a track.

class MusicViewModel : ViewModel() {
    private var nowPlayingFlow: Job? = null
}

ðŸ’¡A coroutine Job allows us to execute a cancellable task as a background process within our application.

Weâ€™ll next need to handle the playback of a track, so weâ€™ll create a new function which will be used to trigger the playback of a track. Before we start playing the newly selected track, weâ€™ll want to begin by cancelling any currently playing track, so weâ€™ll take the current flow reference for media playback and trigger the cancel operation - this will cancel the flow reference and halt any playback process that is currently taking place.

private fun playMusic() {
    nowPlayingFlow?.cancel()  
}

Weâ€™ll next want to mark the current playback state as playing, so weâ€™ll emit a modified version of our state, setting the current status of the now playing reference to PLAYING.

private fun playMusic() {
    nowPlayingFlow?.cancel()
    val nowPlaying = uiState.value.nowPlaying!!

    uiState.value = uiState.value.copy(
        nowPlaying = nowPlaying.copy(
            state = NowPlayingState.PLAYING
        )
    )
   
}

Now that the state is set to playing, weâ€™re going to want to simulate some kind of audio playback.

private fun playMusic() {
    nowPlayingFlow?.cancel()
    val nowPlaying = uiState.value.nowPlaying!!

    uiState.value = uiState.value.copy(
        nowPlaying = nowPlaying.copy(
            state = NowPlayingState.PLAYING
        )
    )
    nowPlayingFlow = viewModelScope.launch {
        while (isActive) {
            val maxLength =
				uiState.value.nowPlaying!!.track.length
            val newPosition = 			
				uiState.value.nowPlaying!!.position + 1
            if (newPosition >= maxLength) {
                uiState.value = uiState.value.copy(
                    nowPlaying = nowPlaying.copy(
                        state = NowPlayingState.STOPPED,
                        position = 0
                    )
                )
                cancel()
            } else {
                uiState.value = uiState.value.copy(
                    nowPlaying = nowPlaying.copy(
                        state = NowPlayingState.PLAYING,
                        position = newPosition
                    )
                )
            }
            delay(1000)
        }
    }
}

With this function in place, we now can play the selected track. Weâ€™ll start here by updating the nowPlaying reference inside of our state reference, followed by triggering the playMusic function that we defined above.

class MusicViewModel : ViewModel() {

    ...

    fun handleEvent(contentEvent: MusicCatalogEvent) {
        when (contentEvent) {
			...
           	is MusicCatalogEvent.PlayTrack -> {
                uiState.value = uiState.value.copy(
                    nowPlaying = ContentFactory.makeNowPlaying(
						contentEvent.track
					)
                )
                playMusic()
            }
        }
    }

    ...
}

When the view model is torn down, weâ€™ll want to stop any currently playing track - which we can do by again utilising the cancel operation on the job reference. Weâ€™ll do this within the onCleared function of the view model, meaning that when the feature is exited, the currently playing track will be cleared.

class MusicViewModel : ViewModel() {

    ...

	private var nowPlayingFlow: Job? = null

    override fun onCleared() {
        nowPlayingFlow?.cancel()
        super.onCleared()
    }

    fun handleEvent(contentEvent: MusicCatalogEvent) {
        when (contentEvent) {
			...
           	is MusicCatalogEvent.PlayTrack -> {
                uiState.value = uiState.value.copy(
                    nowPlaying = ContentFactory.makeNowPlaying(
						contentEvent.track
					)
                )
                playMusic()
            }
        }
    }

    ...
}

As well as being able to select a track to be played, the user is also going to be able to toggle a track between the playing and paused state. Because we are going to be toggling between these two states, weâ€™re going to model this as a single ToggleNowPlayingState event. That way, this event can be triggered for either condition, with our state just being toggled to the opposite of what it is currently set to.

// MusicCatalogEvent.kt

sealed class MusicCatalogEvent {

    object RefreshContent: MusicCatalogEvent()

    class Search(val searchTerm: String): MusicCatalogEvent()

    object ClearSearchQuery: MusicCatalogEvent()

	class PlayTrack(val track: Track): MusicCatalogEvent()

    object ToggleNowPlayingState: MusicCatalogEvent()

}

With this event in place, weâ€™re going to create a function that will toggle the current playing status. In this function weâ€™ll want to pause the music when the current nowPlaying state represents the PLAYING state, otherwise the track is currently paused so weâ€™ll want to play the music.

private fun toggleNowPlayingState() {
    if (uiState.value.nowPlaying?.state == NowPlayingState.PLAYING) {
        pauseMusic()
    } else {
        playMusic()
    }
}

Within our handleEvent function we can now trigger this new function when the PlayTrack event is being handled.

class MusicViewModel : ViewModel() {

    ...

    fun handleEvent(contentEvent: MusicCatalogEvent) {
        when (contentEvent) {
			...
           	is MusicCatalogEvent.PlayTrack -> {
                toggleNowPlayingState()
            }
        }
    }

    ...
}

Along with managing the playback of a track, the user will also be able to perform a seek operation on a track. This means that by using the slider UI component, the user will be able to set the current position of a track by dragging the slider back or forward from the current position. Weâ€™ll model this using a SeekTrack class, providing a Float value to represent the current position that has been selected by the user.

// MusicCatalogEvent.kt

sealed class MusicCatalogEvent {

    object RefreshContent: MusicCatalogEvent()

    class Search(val searchTerm: String): MusicCatalogEvent()

    object ClearSearchQuery: MusicCatalogEvent()

	class PlayTrack(val track: Track): MusicCatalogEvent()

	object ToggleNowPlayingState: MusicCatalogEvent()

    class SeekTrack(val position: Float): MusicCatalogEvent()

}

When it comes to handling the seeking of a track, weâ€™re going to want to update the current state using the position value that is being provided via the SeekTrack event. Weâ€™ll use the kitting copy function to update the position value for the current NowPlaying reference, followed by emitting this updated state.

class MusicViewModel : ViewModel() {

    ...

    fun handleEvent(contentEvent: MusicCatalogEvent) {
        when (contentEvent) {
			...
           	is MusicCatalogEvent.SeekTrack -> {
                uiState.value = uiState.value.copy(
                    nowPlaying = 			
						uiState.value.nowPlaying!!.copy(
                    		position =
								contentEvent.position.toLong()
                   		)
                )
            }
        }
    }

    ...
}

With this Float value in place, this position can be used to set the current playback position of the track that is being played. Along with setting this playback position using the seek bar component, there is also going to be both a rewind and fast forward button within the user interface. These buttons will then be used to either skip forward within the currently playing track or go back to a previous playback position. For these two pieces of functionality, weâ€™re going to model two separate events. Neither of these requires additional information, as the event will just be used to manipulate the current playback position within our state. With this in mind weâ€™ll declare two more events, FastForwardNowPlaying and RewindNowPlaying.

// MusicCatalogEvent.kt

sealed class MusicCatalogEvent {

    object RefreshContent: MusicCatalogEvent()

    class Search(val searchTerm: String): MusicCatalogEvent()

    object ClearSearchQuery: MusicCatalogEvent()

	class PlayTrack(val track: Track): MusicCatalogEvent()

    class SeekTrack(val position: Float): MusicCatalogEvent()

    object ToggleNowPlayingState: MusicCatalogEvent()

    object FastForwardNowPlaying: MusicCatalogEvent()

	object RewindNowPlaying: MusicCatalogEvent()

}

With these events in place, we can now look at implementing the functions that will be triggered when needing to handle these events. Weâ€™ll start with the RewindNowPlaying event, creating a new function called rewindMusic. When it comes to rewinding the track, weâ€™re simply going to rewind by 10 seconds - weâ€™ll want to take the current track position for the track being played, followed by subtracting 10 from it. Weâ€™ll want to ensure that we never go below the value of 0, so weâ€™ll also add a safeguard to ensure this doesnâ€™t happen.

private fun rewindMusic() {
    val nowPlaying = uiState.value.nowPlaying!!
    val newPosition = nowPlaying.position - 10
    uiState.value = uiState.value.copy(
        nowPlaying = nowPlaying.copy(
            position = if (newPosition < 0) 0 else newPosition
        )
    )
}

Weâ€™ll then trigger this function whenever we need to handle this event.

class MusicViewModel : ViewModel() {

    ...

    fun handleEvent(contentEvent: MusicCatalogEvent) {
        when (contentEvent) {
			...
           	MusicCatalogEvent.RewindNowPlaying -> rewindMusic()
        }
    }

    ...
}

When it comes to fast-forwarding the current track, weâ€™re going to do the same as rewinding the track, except weâ€™ll add 10 seconds to the current playback time as opposed to the subtraction of 10 seconds when rewinding. Weâ€™ll also want to ensure that we never go above the length of the track when adding 10 seconds, so weâ€™ll also add a safeguard here to ensure that this isnâ€™t possible.

private fun fastForwardMusic() {
    val nowPlaying = uiState.value.nowPlaying!!

    val maxLength = nowPlaying.track.length
    val newPosition = nowPlaying.position + 10
    uiState.value = uiState.value.copy(
        nowPlaying = nowPlaying.copy(
            position = if (newPosition > maxLength) {
				maxLength 
			} else newPosition
        )
    )
}

Weâ€™ll then trigger this function when handling the fast forward event.

class MusicViewModel : ViewModel() {

    ...

    fun handleEvent(contentEvent: MusicCatalogEvent) {
        when (contentEvent) {
			...
           	MusicCatalogEvent.FastForwardNowPlaying ->
				fastForwardMusic()
        }
    }

    ...
}

With these two additional events in place, weâ€™ll now be able to support both the fast forward and rewind functionalities within our user interface.

With this implemented, we are now managing the state of our music dashboard screen and providing the required entry points for our UI layer to manipulate the state based on user interaction. Our view model is now ready to be plugged into a composable UI, which weâ€™ll create in the next section of this chapter!

Creating the Music Dashboard UI

With the view model and state management all in place, weâ€™re ready to move on and start implementing the composable UI for our Messaging app.

When weâ€™re finished building this UI, weâ€™re going to end up with something that looks like the following:

This UI will give our users a screen that displays a list of pre-existing messages, grouped by sticky date headers - the user will also be able to send messages to be added to that list. Building this UI will allow us to work with a range of compose features while adding some subtle niceties to the UI in the process.

Setting up the entry point

Before we can get start building our project, weâ€™re going to need to add a couple of dependencies that weâ€™re going to need. Weâ€™ll start here by adding these to the build.gradle file for our new project:

implementation 
	"androidx.compose.foundation:foundation:$compose_version"
implementation "androidx.compose.ui:ui:$compose_version"
implementation 
	"androidx.compose.material:material:$compose_version"
implementation 
	"androidx.compose.material:material-icons-extended:$compose_version"
implementation "androidx.lifecycle:lifecycle-viewmodel-compose:2.4.0"
implementation "dev.chrisbanes.snapper:snapper:0.2.0"
implementation "com.google.accompanist:accompanist-flowlayout:0.20.0"

The current release of this book is building against 1.1.0 of compose - be sure to check compatibly if using a newer version.

  • foundation: provides foundational composables, such as layouts and commonly required modifiers
  • ui: provides access to ui related composables, such as drawing and general components
  • material: provides access to compose material UI components
  • material-icons-extended: provides access to an extended collection of iconography
  • lifecycle-viewmodel-compose: provides functionality for providing view models directly inside of composables
  • snapper: provides utilities for building a collection of items that allows snapping to the nearest item
  • flowlayout: provides a layout that automatically spans children across multiple rows/columns as required

With these added to our project, weâ€™re now ready to start building out our UI. Weâ€™re going to start here by building the access point to our feature - this is how the messaging feature will initially be composed within our user interface. To make this an argument-less access point, weâ€™re going to start with a new composable function, Messaging.

// Messaging.kt

@Composable
fun Messaging()

While you wonâ€™t see anything visual just yet, youâ€™ll want to compose this Messaging composable within the setContent block of the activity that was created through the project wizard. Then as we build out the project, weâ€™ll be able to visualise the Messaging when running the project.

Before we get started with any composition of messaging specific UI, weâ€™re going to start by declaring the use of the MaterialTheme composable, this will be in place ready to wrap any composition and apply the expected material theming to our project. This isnâ€™t a requirement, but if not provided then you would need to manually style each composable to adhere to material requirements. Weâ€™re not going to be doing any theme customisation here, so this will be using the default colors.

// Messaging.kt

@Composable
fun Messaging() {
    MaterialTheme {
        ...
    }
}

We can see here that we currently have a blank content block, this means that nothing is currently going to be composed in our UI. As mentioned previously, this is just an argument-less entry point to our feature, but weâ€™re going to need access to the state configuration that we set up over the last few chapters. Here, weâ€™re going to utilise the ViewModel related dependency that we added to our project. Using its viewModel() function, weâ€™ll go ahead and retrieve an instance of the ConversationViewModel. This will return an existing reference to the ViewModel, creating a new one if it does not currently exist.

// Messaging.kt

@Composable
fun Messaging() {
    val viewModel: ConversationViewModel = viewModel()
    MaterialTheme {
        ...
    }
}

With this in place, we have our ViewModel, as well as access to our state through this ViewModel. Now though, we need to set ourselves up to be able to compose UI based on this state. Here weâ€™re going to create a separate composable function that takes the ConversationState class, composing UI from it.

// Conversation.kt

@Composable
fun Conversation(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    state: ConversationState
)

ðŸ’¡ Declaring a Modifier argument for your composable functions allows the layout constraints of the composable to be delegated to the parent. This helps to keep your composables reusable, as they are not being constrained for a specific scenario.

Not only does having this separate composable keep the responsibilities of our composable functions smaller, but it also will help us with testing later on. Having this separate Conversation composable with a ConversationState argument means that we can provide state within our tests, and perform asserts based on the expected composition from our state. Testing against an argument-less composable function would require us to interact with the UI to manipulate the state, which adds friction during the testing process.

Now that we have this composable in place, weâ€™re ready to compose this inside of our Messaging composable. We can provide two arguments to our Conversation - modifier and state, which the second is required. For the modifier, weâ€™ll simply utilise the fillMaxSize modifier - which will instruct the contained composable to use all of the size that it has available to it.

Weâ€™ll also need to provide a reference to a ConversationState, which weâ€™ll access through our ConversationViewModel. Here weâ€™re going to use the collectAsState() - because our state is represented within our ViewModel as a StateFlow, weâ€™re going to want to collect the events from here. collectAsState() allows us to collect the emissions from our StateFlow as composable state, meaning that our composables can be recomposed accordingly whenever the state is changed. Weâ€™ll need to access the value from the StateFlow and pass this directly to the state argument of our Conversation composable.

@Composable
fun Messaging() {
    val viewModel: ConversationViewModel = viewModel()
    MaterialTheme {
        Conversation(
            modifier = Modifier.fillMaxSize(),
            state = viewModel.uiState.collectAsState().value
        )
    }
}

At this point, we wonâ€™t be able to see anything being composed within our UI, but weâ€™re all set up and ready to start building out our messaging interface.

Setting up the Dashboard

Now that we have our MusicCatalog being composed at the root of our Music Catalog screen, we can start to think about building out the composables that are going to make up the different parts of our catalogue UI. Within this UI weâ€™re going to display a collection of different composable structures, all of which will be contained within a material style layout - consisting of a top bar, bottom bar and content area. As shown by the design of this feature, there are going to be two different content areas - one of which is displayed in a bottom layer, while the other will be displayed in a top layer. To achieve this kind of layout weâ€™re going to utilise the BackdropScaffold composable - this composable allows us to create a material structure, with layered content areas.

@Composable
fun BackdropScaffold(
    appBar: @Composable () -> Unit,
    backLayerContent: @Composable () -> Unit,
    frontLayerContent: @Composable () -> Unit,
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    scaffoldState: BackdropScaffoldState = rememberBackdropScaffoldState(Concealed),
    gesturesEnabled: Boolean = true,
    peekHeight: Dp = BackdropScaffoldDefaults.PeekHeight,
    headerHeight: Dp = BackdropScaffoldDefaults.HeaderHeight,
    persistentAppBar: Boolean = true,
    stickyFrontLayer: Boolean = true,
    backLayerBackgroundColor: Color = MaterialTheme.colors.primary,
    backLayerContentColor: Color = contentColorFor(backLayerBackgroundColor),
    frontLayerShape: Shape = BackdropScaffoldDefaults.frontLayerShape,
    frontLayerElevation: Dp = BackdropScaffoldDefaults.FrontLayerElevation,
    frontLayerBackgroundColor: Color = MaterialTheme.colors.surface,
    frontLayerContentColor: Color = contentColorFor(frontLayerBackgroundColor),
    frontLayerScrimColor: Color = BackdropScaffoldDefaults.frontLayerScrimColor,
    snackbarHost: @Composable (SnackbarHostState) -> Unit = { SnackbarHost(it) }
)

Within our Dashboard composable weâ€™re going to start by composing a BackdropScaffold.

// Dashboard.kt

@Composable
fun Dashboard(
    state: MusicDashboardState
) {
    BackdropScaffold()
}

When composing a BackdropScaffold, youâ€™ll notice that there are a collection of required arguments - these need to be provided so that we can compile our project. The most important of these required arguments are the BackdropScaffoldState reference - this state is used to hold the current status of the backdrop scaffold. Within this state youâ€™ll see a BackdropValue reference - this can be either the value of Concealed or Revealed, which is used to represent whether the back or front layer is currently in view. Weâ€™ll create a new reference to this piece of state using the rememberBackdropScaffoldState function, for which we are required to provide an initial value for the BackdropValue reference. This initial value is the state in which the background scaffold will start, which is a required argument when configuring the state reference.

Now that we have this state configured we can go ahead and provide it for the required scaffoldState argument.

@Composable
fun Dashboard(
    state: MusicDashboardState
) {
    val scaffoldState = rememberBackdropScaffoldState(
        initialValue = BackdropValue.Revealed
    )

    BackdropScaffold(
        scaffoldState = scaffoldState
    )
}

Aside from the required state value, we also need to provide composable implementations for the appBar, backLayerContent and frontLayerContent arguments. Weâ€™re not going to provide the body for these lambda functions just yet, but we need to provide at least empty implementations so that our code will compile.

@Composable
fun Dashboard(
    state: MusicDashboardState
) {
    val scaffoldState = rememberBackdropScaffoldState(
        initialValue = BackdropValue.Revealed
    )

    BackdropScaffold(
        scaffoldState = scaffoldState,
        appBar = {
            
        },
        backLayerContent = {
            
        },
        frontLayerContent = {
            
        }
    )
}

In the next section of this project chapter, weâ€™re going to be composing the track content to be displayed inside of the content area. Weâ€™ll want to ensure that the background of this content is the expected color, so weâ€™re going to utilise the backLayerBackgroundColor argument to configure the background color to be used for this content area. Here weâ€™ll use the MaterialTheme class to access the surface color from our theme and apply this to the back layer background color of the BackdropScaffold.

@Composable
fun Dashboard(
    state: MusicDashboardState
) {
    val scaffoldState = rememberBackdropScaffoldState(
        initialValue = BackdropValue.Revealed
    )

    BackdropScaffold(
        backLayerBackgroundColor =
			MaterialTheme.colors.surface,
        scaffoldState = scaffoldState,
        appBar = {
            
        },
        backLayerContent = {
            
        },
        frontLayerContent = {
            
        }
    )
}

Composing a Track

Before we go ahead and start composing the different sections of our music dashboard, weâ€™re going to need to compose a representation of each track that is going to be displayed. For this weâ€™ll create a new Track composable, declaring a required argument to pass the corresponding Track reference for the data that is to be composed.

@Composable
fun Track(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    track: Track
) {
    
}

For each track, weâ€™re going to create a container that contains the track cover, artist and name - for which weâ€™ll use a collection of different composables. Weâ€™ll start here with the container of the Track, for which weâ€™ll utilise the Surface composable.

@Composable
fun Track(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    track: Track
) {
    Surface(
        modifier = modifier
	) {
        
    }
}

ðŸ’¡ The Surface is an elevated Material component that is used to contain prominent information within a user interface. Itâ€™s ideal for items within a collection, as it creates a clear visual separation between each item.

When it comes to this Surface, weâ€™re going to shape this with rounded corners. To achieve this effect weâ€™ll utilise the RoundedCornerShape class, allowing us to apply rounding to each of the corners. Weâ€™ll apply a corner size of 8dp for this, assigning the reference of this shape to the shape argument of the Surface composable function.

@Composable
fun Track(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    track: Track
) {
    Surface(
        modifier = modifier.semantics(mergeDescendants = true) { },
        shape = RoundedCornerShape(8.dp)
    ) {
        
    }
}

Now that we have our Surface defined, weâ€™re going to go ahead and configure the contents of it. As we can see by the design, weâ€™re going to be showing the track data in a horizontal arrangement - with the track cover at the start of the surface, followed by the track details at the end. To achieve this layout weâ€™re going to utilise the Row composable, using the fillMaxWidth modifier to ensure this fills all of the horizontal space inside of the parent container.

@Composable
fun Track(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    track: Track
) {
    Surface(
        modifier = modifier.semantics(mergeDescendants = true) { },
        shape = RectangleShape
    ) {
        Row(
            modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth()
        ) {
            
        }
    }
}

Weâ€™re now going to build out each of the children that are going to be displayed inside of this Row, starting with the track cover. For this cover weâ€™re going to create a new composable function that can be reused in other parts of our UI, weâ€™ll call this CoverArt - this is also going to need to take a Color reference as an argument to display, which will be taken from the Track that is being composed.

@Composable
fun CoverArt(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    color: Color
)

For our cover art were simply going to take the provided color, and create a gradient color using another color taken from the theme of our application. Utilising the background modifier, weâ€™ll use the verticalGradient brush function to create this gradient. This function takes a colors argument, which needs to consist of the colors that the gradient is to be created from. Here weâ€™ll pass the primaryVariant color from our theme, along with the color reference that has been passed to our composable function.

@Composable
fun CoverArt(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    color: Color
) {
    Box(
        modifier = modifier
            .background(
                brush = Brush.verticalGradient(
                    colors = listOf(
                        MaterialTheme.colors.primaryVariant,
                        color
                    )
                ),
            )
    )
}

We can go one step further here and improve the visual representation of our cover slightly. Weâ€™ll again use the RoundedCornerShape class to apply a rounded corner effect to our cover art, assigning this to the shape argument of the background modifier.

@Composable
fun CoverArt(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    color: Color
) {
    Box(
        modifier = modifier
            .background(
                brush = Brush.verticalGradient(
                    colors = listOf(
                        MaterialTheme.colors.primaryVariant,
                        track.cover
                    )
                ),
                shape = RoundedCornerShape(6.dp)
            )
    )
}

We can see now that our cover art looks slightly more visually appealing when composed.

With this CoverArt composable now in place, we can go ahead and set this into our Track composable. Weâ€™ll add this here as the first child of the contained Row composable.

@Composable
fun Track(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    track: Track
) {
    Surface(
        modifier = modifier.semantics(mergeDescendants = true) { },
        shape = RectangleShape
    ) {
        Row(
            modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth()
        ) {
            CoverArt(
                modifier = Modifier.size(40.dp),
                track = track
            )
            
        }
    }
}

At this stage, there isnâ€™t too much to see here, but we can see the initial addition being composed inside of the defined Surface.

Next, we need to add the textual details for the Track reference. Weâ€™re going to stack these vertically on one another, so weâ€™ll need to utilise the Column composable. Here weâ€™ll use two Text composable to compose both the title and artist properties of the Track reference.

Column {
	Text(
		text = track.title,
		fontSize = 16.sp
	)
	Text(
		text = track.artist,
		fontSize = 12.sp
	)
}

Weâ€™ll then take this structure and compose it inside of our Track composable. Weâ€™ll also compose a Spacer above this to create some vertical spacing between the CoverArt and Column composable.

@Composable
fun Track(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    track: Track
) {
    Surface(
        modifier = modifier.semantics(mergeDescendants = true) { },
        shape = RectangleShape
    ) {
        Row(
            modifier = Modifier
                .fillMaxWidth()
        ) {
            CoverArt(
                modifier = Modifier.size(40.dp),
                track = track
            )
            Spacer(modifier = Modifier.width(12.dp))
            Column {
                Text(
                    text = track.title,
                    fontSize = 16.sp
                )
                Text(
                    text = track.artist,
                    fontSize = 12.sp
                )
            }
        }
    }
}

While we now have this information being composed, we can improve things here by creating some visual space within the Track card. Weâ€™ll use the padding modifier on the Row composable, creating some visual spacing on both the horizontal and vertical edges.

@Composable
fun Track(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    track: Track
) {
    Surface(
        modifier = modifier.semantics(mergeDescendants = true) { },
        shape = RectangleShape
    ) {
        Row(
            modifier = Modifier
                .padding(
                    horizontal = 16.dp,
                    vertical = 8.dp
                )
                .fillMaxWidth()
        ) {
            ...
        }
    }
}

Tracks Dashboard

Now that we have this Track composable in place, weâ€™re going to start to look at building out the different composables sections that will make up the content of our screen. This content area is going to display the various sections of tracks within our dashboard, which weâ€™ll define in the form of a TracksDashboard composable function.

@Composable
fun TracksDashboard(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier
)

All of the content within this dashboard is going to be displayed within a vertically scrolling container - so weâ€™ll go ahead and define the use of a new LazyColumn composable, assigning the Modifier that was provided to our TracksDasboard composable function.

@Composable
fun TracksDashboard(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier
) {
    LazyColumn(
        modifier = modifier
    ) {
        
    }
}

Recent tracks

With this vertical container composed, weâ€™re going to start to build out the different track sections that are going to be displayed inside of this. Weâ€™re going to start here by displaying a title for this section within the container, so weâ€™ll add a new string resource to be used for the title content.

<string name="heading_recently_played">
	Recently Played
</string>

With this string resource in place, we can go ahead and add a new item to our LazyColumn, defining the use of a new Text composable.

@Composable
fun TracksDashboard(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier
) {
    LazyColumn(
        modifier = modifier
    ) {
        item {
            Text(
                text = stringResource(id = 
					R.string.heading_recently_played),
                fontSize = 18.sp,
                fontWeight = FontWeight.Bold
            )
        }
    }
}

ðŸ’¡ The item function is used to add a new node to a LazyColumn. Each component added to a Lazy composable must be wrapped in this item function, this is so that the composable can be managed Lazily.

For this Text composable we provide the text to be used using the previously defined string resource, along with assigning a fontSize and fontWeight that correspond to that of a title.

ðŸ’¡ If you have configured a material theme for the project then you can also utilise the style argument to assign a title style to the text composable.

You may notice here that currently there is not any spacing around the content of our LazyColumn, things currently feel a little bit cramped. To alleviate this, weâ€™re going to utilise the contentPadding argument of our LazyColumn. This allows us to assign padding to the different edges of the container - which weâ€™ll want to assign specifically to the top and bottom.

@Composable
fun TracksDashboard(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier
) {
    LazyColumn(
        modifier = modifier,
        contentPadding = PaddingValues(
			top = 12.dp, 
			bottom = 8.dp
		)
    ) {
        item {
            Text(
                text = stringResource(id = 
					R.string.heading_recently_played),
                fontSize = 18.sp,
                fontWeight = FontWeight.Bold
            )
        }
    }
}

We can see here now that there is sufficient spacing for the content of the composable, removing that sense of the children cramped against the top and bottom edges of the composable. We donâ€™t need padding at the end of the composable, as per our designs the width of the tracks will be greater than the width of the text.

Alongside the padding of the parent container, weâ€™re always going to want to assign some spacing to the title Text. Not only can we see that the start of the composable is still pressed against the edge of the screen, but when we add content beneath the title there will also be no spacing present there. For this weâ€™re going to utilise the padding modifier, assigning some padding to both the start and bottom of the Text composable.

@Composable
fun TracksDashboard(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier
) {
    LazyColumn(
        modifier = modifier,
        contentPadding = PaddingValues(
			top = 12.dp, 
			bottom = 8.dp
		)   
	) {
        item {
            Text(
                modifier = Modifier.padding(
					start = 16.dp, 
					bottom = 8.dp
				),
                text = stringResource(id = 
					R.string.heading_recently_played),
                fontSize = 18.sp,
                fontWeight = FontWeight.Bold
            )
        }
    }
}

Now that we have the title being displayed for the Recent Tracks section, weâ€™re next going to want to display each of the corresponding Track items that come into this section.

@Composable
fun TracksDashboard(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    state: MusicDashboardState
) {
    LazyColumn(
        modifier = modifier,
        contentPadding = PaddingValues(
			top = 12.dp, 
			bottom = 8.dp
		)
    ) {
        ...
        items(state.recentTracks() ) {
            
        }
    }
}

Each of these tacks is again going to be represented by an item within our LazyColumn - so here weâ€™ll use the items function, providing the recent tracks from our state reference. To access this within our composable function, weâ€™ll need to start by adding support for a MusicDashboardState reference to be provided to our composable function.

@Composable
fun TracksDashboard(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    state: MusicDashboardState
) {
    ...
}

With this state reference now available we can go ahead and add an item to our LazyColumn for each of these tracks. Weâ€™ll go ahead here and use the items function, providing a reference to a list of recent Track references that are to be composed lazily.

@Composable
fun TracksDashboard(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    state: MusicDashboardState
) {
    LazyColumn(
        modifier = modifier,
        contentPadding = PaddingValues(
			top = 12.dp, 
			bottom = 8.dp
		)
    ) {
        ...
        items(state.recentTracks()) {
            
        }
    }
}

When composing this list of items, weâ€™re also going to provide a unique key value. This key is unique to each of the items in the list and is used in the mechanics for lazily composing the contents of the composable. For this key, weâ€™re going to use the id of each Track, as we initially configured this to always be unique.

items(state.recentTracks(), key = { it.id }) {
            
}

Next, weâ€™ll go ahead and compose the Track composable that we defined in the previous section. In the case of the recently played tracks, we want this content to fill the entire available space, so weâ€™ll pass in the fillMaxWidth modifier along with the Track reference for the details to be composed.

@Composable
fun TracksDashboard(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    state: MusicDashboardState
) {
    LazyColumn(
        modifier = modifier,
        contentPadding = PaddingValues(
			top = 12.dp, 
			bottom = 8.dp
		)   
    ) {
        ...
        items(state.recentTracks(), key = { it.id }) {
            Track(
                modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
                track = it
            )
        }
    }
}

At this point, weâ€™d now be able to see the vertical list of Track references being composed.

While these are available visually, there is currently no interaction available on the track items that are displayed within the list. When the user clicks one of these tracks, we want to trigger â€˜playbackâ€™ of the selected track - I saw â€˜playbackâ€™ here because we arenâ€™t going to be implementing the playback of audio, but just simulating the action. To account for this behaviour, weâ€™ll go ahead and add a new argument to the TracksDashboard in the form of a lambda function to pass up interaction events to the parent composable.

@Composable
fun TracksDashboard(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    state: MusicDashboardState,
    onTrackClicked: (track: Track) -> Unit
)

With this in place, we can no use the clickable modifier to trigger this lambda, passing up the selected track to the parent composable.

@Composable
fun TracksDashboard(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    state: MusicDashboardState,
    onTrackClicked: (track: Track) -> Unit
) {
    LazyColumn(
        modifier = modifier,
        contentPadding = PaddingValues(
			top = 12.dp, 
			bottom = 8.dp
		)
    ) {
        ...
        items(state.recentTracks(), key = { it.id }) {
            Track(
                modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth()
                    .clickable { onTrackClicked(it) },
                track = it
            )
        }
    }
}

While this is composing the Track items via accessing the recentTracks() function from our state reference, you might have noticed that the recent tracks list is a nullable field. Because of this, weâ€™re going to want to guard ourselves against any null exceptions occurring during composition. For this we can simply wrap the composition of the recent tracks in an isNullOrEmpty() check, ensuring that we only compose this content when we are not dealing with a null list.

@Composable
fun TracksDashboard(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    state: MusicDashboardState
) {
    LazyColumn(
        modifier = modifier,
        contentPadding = PaddingValues(
			top = 12.dp,
			bottom = 8.dp
		)
    ) {
		if (!state.recentTracks().isNullOrEmpty()) {
        	item {
            	Text(
                	text = stringResource(id = 
						R.string.heading_recently_played),
                	fontSize = 18.sp,
                	fontWeight = FontWeight.Bold
            	)
        	}
        	items(state.recentTracks(), key = { it.id }) {
				val playTrackDescription = stringResource(
                    id = R.string.cd_play_track,
                    it.title, it.artist
                )
            	Track(
                	modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth()
                    	.clickable(
							onClickLabel = playTrackDescription
						) { onTrackClicked(it) },
                	track = it
            	)
        	}
		}
    }
}

Improved the Featured Track accessibility

To ensure that the list of featured tracks is accessible to all users, weâ€™re going o go ahead and improve the accessibility of interaction events on our list of tracks. Weâ€™re going to do this by adding a Click Label to each track item - as currently when each item comes into focus by the screen reader, the user will not be aware of what the click action on the item will trigger.

To improve this weâ€™re going to add a click label - that way the screen reader can communicate the intention of our click action to the user. Before we add this label weâ€™re going to need to add a new string resource to our project for notifying the user that clicking a track will play it.

<string name="cd_play_track">Play %s, by %s</string>

Weâ€™ll then need to retrieve the string value of the resource using the stringResource function. Weâ€™ll assign this to a variable reference, as the onClickLabel can only be provided as a string (and the stringResource function is a composable function).

val playTrackDescription = stringResource(
	id = R.string.cd_play_track,
	it.title, it.artist
)

We can then use this to apply a value to the onClickLabel of the clickable modifier. 

@Composable
fun TracksDashboard(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    state: MusicDashboardState
) {
    LazyColumn(
        modifier = modifier,
        contentPadding = PaddingValues(
			top = 12.dp,
			bottom = 8.dp
		)
    ) {
		if (!state.recentTracks().isNullOrEmpty()) {
        	...
        	items(state.recentTracks(), key = { it.id }) {
				val playTrackDescription = stringResource(
                    id = R.string.cd_play_track,
                    it.title, it.artist
                )
            	Track(
                	modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth()
                    	.clickable(
							onClickLabel = playTrackDescription
						) { onTrackClicked(it) },
                	track = it
            	)
        	}
		}
    }
}

As we can see, this isnâ€™t a required property of the clickable modifier, but for minimal effort, we can increase the accessibility of our composable for screen readers.

Converting to a composable

Now that weâ€™ve got our recent tracks being composed inside of our TracksDashboard, we may notice that weâ€™ve now got a fair chunk of code and responsibility inside of this composable function. Weâ€™re yet to add the new and featured track sections, which is only going to add more responsibilities to this composable function. To get ourselves off to a good start, weâ€™re going to split out the work weâ€™ve carried out for the recent tracks into a separate and focused composable function.

Weâ€™re going to start here by creating a new file, RecentTracks.kt, and creating a new function, RecentTracks. Because weâ€™re going to be utilising the item functions inside of this new function, weâ€™re going to need to scope our function using the LazyListScope. While this means this function will only be used within this scope, itâ€™s a required implementation detail without making things more complicated than they need to be.

This function is going to need the list of Track references that are to be displayed, along with a callback to trigger the click event of a track.

// RecentTracks.kt

fun LazyListScope.RecentTracks(
    tracks: List<Track>,
    onTrackClicked: (track: Track) -> Unit
)

Weâ€™re then going to copy all of the code that is related to recent tracks into this function.

// RecentTracks.kt

fun LazyListScope.RecentTracks(
    tracks: List<Track>,
    onTrackClicked: (track: Track) -> Unit
) {
    item {
        Text(
            modifier = Modifier.padding(
				start = 16.dp, 
				bottom = 8.dp
			),
            text = stringResource(id = 
				R.string.heading_recently_played),
            fontSize = 18.sp,
            fontWeight = FontWeight.Bold
        )
    }
    items(tracks, key = { it.id }) {
        val playTrackDescription = stringResource(
            id = R.string.cd_play_track,
            it.title, it.artist
        )
        Track(
            modifier = Modifier
                .fillMaxWidth()
                .clickable(
					onClickLabel = playTrackDescription
				) { onTrackClicked(it) },
            track = it
        )
    }
}

With this in place, we can now replace the existing code from our TracksDashboard composable with our new RecentTracks function, passing in the required arguments.

@Composable
fun TracksDashboard(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    state: MusicDashboardState
) {
    LazyColumn(
        modifier = modifier,
        contentPadding = PaddingValues(
			top = 12.dp,
			bottom = 8.dp
		)
    ) {
		if (!state.recentTracks().isNullOrEmpty()) {
        	RecentTracks(
                tracks = state.recentTracks(),
                onTrackClicked = onTrackClicked
            )
		}
    }
}
