With this in place, we can see how weâ€™ve now split out the responsibility of recent tracks into a separate function. This puts us in a much better position when it comes to supporting the other track sections within our UI.

Building the New tracks section

As well as displaying the featured tracks within our dashboard, weâ€™re also going to be composing new tracks - these are tracks that are new to the userâ€™s library. Similar to the featured tracks, weâ€™re going to need to compose these as part of the LazyColumn within our TracksDashboard composable. Weâ€™ll start here by creating a new function, scoped using the LazyListScope. Similar to the RecentTracks function weâ€™ll need to allow a collection of Track references to be provided, along with a listener to detect click events on each of the tracks.

fun LazyListScope.NewTracks(
    tracks: List<Track>?,
    onTrackClicked: (track: Track) -> Unit
)

Inside of this function, weâ€™re going to also start by composing a title that will section out this New Tracks collection. Weâ€™ll start here by adding a new string resource that will be used to represent this heading.

<string name="heading_new">New Tracks</string>

Using the item function from the LazyListScope, we can use the Text composable to compose this piece of text as an item of the LazyColumn. Alongside styling this to appear as a title within our UI, weâ€™ll also assign some padding to the composable to ensure that there is sufficient spacing at the top and bottom of the composable.

fun LazyListScope.NewTracks(
    tracks: List<Track>?,
    onTrackClicked: (track: Track) -> Unit
) {
    item {
        Text(
            modifier = Modifier.padding(
				start = 16.dp, 
				bottom = 8.dp
			),
            text = stringResource(id = R.string.heading_new),
            fontSize = 18.sp,
            fontWeight = FontWeight.Bold
        )
    }
}

Now that we have this title in place, we can start to think about composing the items that make up the New Tracks section. Thereâ€™s going to be a bit of code that makes up this UI component, so weâ€™re going to split this out into it a separate composable function in the form of NewTracksRow. This composable is going to take the list of Track references that it needs to compose, along with a callback to be triggered when a Track is clicked.

@Composable
fun NewTracksRow(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    tracks: List<Track>?,
    onTrackClicked: (track: Track) -> Unit
)

Because weâ€™re going to compose these Track items in a horizontal fashion, weâ€™re going to utilise the LazyRow composable. We use the LazyRow here instead of the Row as we have no guarantee over the number of items that weâ€™re going to need to display, so being able to lazily compose these helps us to ensure that composition will occur efficiently. Weâ€™ll compose a LazyRow within this function, providing a reference to the required state argument using the rememberLazyListState() function.

@Composable
fun NewTracksRow(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    tracks: List<Track>?,
    onTrackClicked: (track: Track) -> Unit
) {
    LazyRow(
        modifier = modifier,
		state = rememberLazyListState()
    ) {
            
    }
}

You may have noticed that the tracks argument of our composable function is nullable, so weâ€™re going to only want to compose this list of new tracks if the list is not null (and also if it is not empty!). To ensure that these requirements are satisfied weâ€™re going to wrap the composition of this LazyRow in an isNullOrEmpty() check, meaning that the composition will only occur if the list is not null and is not empty.

@Composable
fun NewTracksRow(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    tracks: List<Track>?,
    onTrackClicked: (track: Track) -> Unit
) {
    if (!tracks.isNullOrEmpty()) {
        LazyRow(
            modifier = modifier,
            state = rememberLazyListState()
        ) {
            
        }
    }
}

Now that we have the container in place for the Track items, weâ€™re going to want to compose each of the items that are going to be displayed inside of it. Although we previously created a Track composable, weâ€™re now going to create a new composable function that creates the track representation for a New Track. 

// NewTrack.kt

@Composable
fun NewTrack(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    track: Track
) {

}

Weâ€™ll start here by creating a container in the form of a Column, this is going to display the children of our track in a vertical format. Alongside using padding to ensure that there is sufficient spacing within our composable, weâ€™re going to use the widthIn modifier to apply a maximum width that can be occupied by our composable. This is so that each of the NewTrack composables occupies equivalent space within the parent container,

// NewTrack.kt

@Composable
fun NewTrack(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    track: Track
) {
    Column(
        modifier = modifier.padding(8.dp)
            .widthIn(max = 120.dp),
    ) {
        
    }
}

Using the provided Track reference, weâ€™ll then compose a CoverArt. We previously set the maximum width of the parent container to 120dp, so weâ€™ll allow our CovertArt to fill this space, utilising the equivalent sizing for the height so that the cover art is square.

@Composable
fun NewTrack(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    track: Track
) {
    Column(
        modifier = modifier.padding(8.dp)
            .widthIn(max = 120.dp),
    ) {
        CoverArt(
            modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth().height(120.dp),
            track = track
        )
    }
}

With the CoverArt in place, we can now add a Text composable that will display the title of our Track reference. Weâ€™ll also use a Spacer to ensure that there is sufficient spacing between the composables.

@Composable
fun NewTrack(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    track: Track
) {
    Column(
        modifier = modifier.padding(8.dp)
            .widthIn(max = 120.dp),
    ) {
        ...
		Spacer(modifier = Modifier.height(6.dp))
		Text(
            text = track.title,
            fontWeight = FontWeight.Bold,
            maxLines = 1,
            overflow = TextOverflow.Ellipsis,
            fontSize = 16.sp
        )
    }
}

Beneath the title, weâ€™ll use another Text composable to display the artist of the track. Weâ€™ll use 12sp for the font size here, as the information will be less dominant in our component when compared to the title.

@Composable
fun NewTrack(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    track: Track
) {
    Column(
        modifier = modifier.padding(8.dp)
            .widthIn(max = 120.dp),
    ) {
        CoverArt(
            modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth().height(120.dp),
            track = track
        )
        Spacer(modifier = Modifier.height(6.dp))
        Text(
            text = track.title,
            fontWeight = FontWeight.Bold,
            maxLines = 1,
            overflow = TextOverflow.Ellipsis,
            fontSize = 16.sp
        )
        Text(
            text = track.artist,
            fontSize = 12.sp
        )
    }
}

When it comes to the accessibility services and the focus on our track component, each child node is going to be focused on and communicated individually. This could end up adding quite a bit of friction when navigating through the New Track row using the screen reader, so weâ€™re going to use the semantics modifier to merge the descendants of our composable. This means that when the New Track composable is in focus, the node will be focused and communicated as a single element.

@Composable
fun NewTrack(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    track: Track
) {
    Column(
        modifier = modifier.padding(8.dp)
            .widthIn(max = 120.dp)
            .semantics(mergeDescendants = true) { },
    ) {
        ...
    }
}

Hopping back over the parent NewTracksRow we can now compose a NewTrack for each of the Track references that are passed into our composable function.

@Composable
fun NewTracksRow(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    tracks: List<Track>?,
    onTrackClicked: (track: Track) -> Unit
) {
    if (!tracks.isNullOrEmpty()) {
        LazyRow(
            modifier = modifier,
            state = rememberLazyListState()
        ) {
            items(tracks) { track ->
                NewTrack(
                    modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth()
                    track = track
                )
            }
        }
    }
}

At this point, our Track references are being composed, but the user is not able to interact with them. When creating the NewTracksRow composable function, we allowed an onTrackClicked lambda function to be provided - allowing us to pass up click events on the track children. Weâ€™re going to want to trigger this lambda whenever any of the tracks are clicked, so weâ€™ll utilise the clickable modifier on each NewTrack composable, triggering the lambda function for the corresponding Track reference.

@Composable
fun NewTracksRow(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    tracks: List<Track>?,
    onTrackClicked: (track: Track) -> Unit
) {
    if (!tracks.isNullOrEmpty()) {
        val lazyListState = rememberLazyListState()
        LazyRow(
            ...
        ) {
            items(tracks) { track ->
                NewTrack(
                    modifier = Modifier
                        .fillMaxWidth()
                        .clickable {
                            onTrackClicked(track)
                        },
                    track = track
                )

            }
        }
    }
}

Improving the New Track accessibility

To ensure that the list of featured tracks is accessible to all users, weâ€™re going o go ahead and improve the accessibility of interaction events on our list of tracks. Weâ€™re going to do this by adding a Click Label to each track item - as currently when each item comes into focus by the screen reader, the user will not be aware of what the click action on the item will trigger.

To improve this weâ€™re going to add a click label - that way the screen reader can communicate the intention of our click action to the user. For this label, weâ€™ll utilise the existing string resource that we defined for the click label in the previous section. Weâ€™ll need to retrieve the string value of the resource using the stringResource function, which weâ€™ll then assign to a variable reference because the onClickLabel can only be provided as a string (and the stringResource function is a composable function).

val playTrackDescription = stringResource(
	id = R.string.cd_play_track,
	track.title, track.artist
)

We can then use this to apply a value to the onClickLabel of the clickable modifier. 

@Composable
fun NewTracksRow(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    tracks: List<Track>?,
    onTrackClicked: (track: Track) -> Unit
) {
    if (!tracks.isNullOrEmpty()) {
        LazyRow(
            modifier = modifier,
            state = rememberLazyListState()
        ) {
            items(tracks) { track ->
                val playTrackDescription = stringResource(
                    id = R.string.cd_play_track,
                    track.title, track.artist
                )
                NewTrack(
                    modifier = Modifier
                        .fillMaxWidth()
                        .clickable(
							onClickLabel = playTrackDescription
						) {
                            onTrackClicked(track)
                        },
                    track = track
                )

            }
        }
    }
}

Adding content spacing

Now that all of our content is being composed, we can see a visual representation of the New Tracks within our music catalogue. However, we might currently feel that there is not sufficient spacing around the content of our LazyRow.

To improve things here we can utilise the contentPadding argument, allowing us to provide padding to be applied around our content.

@Composable
fun NewTracksRow(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    tracks: List<Track>?,
    onTrackClicked: (track: Track) -> Unit
) {
    if (!tracks.isNullOrEmpty()) {
        LazyRow(
            modifier = modifier,
            state = rememberLazyListState(),
            contentPadding = PaddingValues(8.dp)
        ) {
            ...
        }
    }
}

With this padding in place, we can now see how there is sufficient spacing around the content of our LazyRow - resulting in a content row that feels less cramped.

Adding item snapping

When setting up this project, we declared a dependency for the snapper library - this allows us to create a snapping effect when scrolling through content lists. Currently, our New Tracks row has no snapping effects present, which results in content not always sitting right when scrolling is stopped or fling gestures are performed.

To improve the experience here, weâ€™re going to plug in the offerings of snapper, which is only a few lines of code with a high payoff.

The key to adding a basic implementation of snapper is the use of the rememberSnapperFlingBehavior function, this creates a FlingBehavior that defines how fling gestures are to be handled for our LazyRow. This function comes from snapper and implements the complexities of creating this snapping effect. When using this function weâ€™ll need to provide a reference to a LazyListState, which we are already providing to our LazyRow. Weâ€™ll pull up the use of this rememberLazyListState function to keep a reference to the LazyListState, passing in this reference when creating the FlingBehavior. We can then pass this FlingBehavior into our LazyRow composable.

@Composable
fun NewTracksRow(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    tracks: List<Track>?,
    onTrackClicked: (track: Track) -> Unit
) {
    if (!tracks.isNullOrEmpty()) {
		val lazyListState = rememberLazyListState()
        LazyRow(
            modifier = modifier,
            state = lazyListState,
			flingBehavior = rememberSnapperFlingBehavior(lazyListState),
            contentPadding = PaddingValues(8.dp)
        ) {
            ...
        }
        Spacer(modifier = Modifier.height(16.dp))
    }
}

Now when scroll and/or fling gestures are performed, we can see this snapping effect occur. This ensures that a NewTrack composable is always positioned at the start of the visible area for our LazyRow.

Composing the New Tracks

At this point, we have created our NewTracks composable, and itâ€™s ready to be composed inside of our tracks dashboard. Weâ€™ll hop on back over to this parent composable and compose the NewTracks inside of it. When composing NewTracks weâ€™ll need to provide the tracks argument, for which we can use the newTracks() function from our MusicDashboardState reference. Weâ€™ll also directly pass in the onTrackClicked lambda function that is being provided to our TracksDashboard.

@Composable
fun TracksDashboard(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    state: MusicDashboardState,
    onTrackClicked: (track: Track) -> Unit
) {
    LazyColumn(
        modifier = modifier,
        contentPadding = PaddingValues(
			top = 12.dp, 
			bottom = 8.dp
		)
    ) {
        NewTracks(
            tracks = state.newTracks(),
            onTrackClicked = onTrackClicked
        )
		...
    }
}

With this composition now taking place, we have our NewTracks being composed alongside the previously defined RecentTracks composable.

Building the Featured tracks section

As well as displaying the new and recent tracks within our dashboard, weâ€™re also going to be composing featured tracks - these are tracks that are currently featured within the music catalogue. Similar to the other track lists, weâ€™re going to need to compose these as part of the LazyColumn within our TracksDashboard composable. Weâ€™ll start here by creating a new function, scoped using the LazyListScope. Weâ€™ll need to allow a collection of Track references to be provided, along with a listener to detect click events on each of the tracks.

fun LazyListScope.FeaturedTracks(
    tracks: List<Track>?,
    onTrackClicked: (track: Track) -> Unit
)

Inside of this function, weâ€™re going to also start by composing a title that will section out this Featured Tracks collection. Weâ€™ll start here by adding a new string resource that will be used to represent this heading.

<string name="heading_featured">Featured Tracks</string>

Using the item function from the LazyListScope, we can use the Text composable to compose this piece of text as an item of the LazyColumn. Alongside styling this to appear as a title within our UI, weâ€™ll also assign some padding to the composable to ensure that there is sufficient spacing at the top and bottom of the composable.

fun LazyListScope.FeaturedTracks(
    tracks: List<Track>?,
    onTrackClicked: (track: Track) -> Unit
) {
    item {
        Text(
            modifier = Modifier.padding(
				start = 16.dp
			),
            text = stringResource(id = 									R.string.heading_featured),
            fontSize = 18.sp,
            fontWeight = FontWeight.Bold
        )
    }
}

Now that we have this title in place, we can start to think about composing the items that make up the Featured Tracks section. Thereâ€™s going to be a bit of code that makes up this UI component, so weâ€™re going to split this out into its own composable function in the form of FeaturedTracksGrid. This composable is going to take the list of Track references that it needs to compose, along with a callback to be triggered when a Track is clicked.

@Composable
fun FeaturedTracksGrid(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    tracks: List<Track>?,
    onTrackClicked: (track: Track) -> Unit
)

To display the grid of featured tracks, weâ€™re going to utilise the LazyVerticalGrid composable which will only compose its children as they are required - making it much more efficient than composing everything at the same time, especially when items may not even be visible to the user. When composing the LazyVerticalGrid weâ€™ll pass the modifier that was provided to our FeaturedTracksGrid composable, along with the required cells argument. This needs to be provided in the form of the GridCells type, which allows us to define how many columns should be applied to our grid. Weâ€™re going to use the Fixed type in the form of 2 columns.

@Composable
fun FeaturedTracksGrid(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    tracks: List<Track>?,
    onTrackClicked: (track: Track) -> Unit
) {
    if (!tracks.isNullOrEmpty()) {
        val itemSize = 
			(LocalConfiguration.current.screenWidthDp.dp / 2)
        FlowRow(
            modifier = modifier,
            mainAxisSize = SizeMode.Expand,
            mainAxisAlignment = 
				FlowMainAxisAlignment.SpaceBetween
        ) {
            tracks.forEach { track ->
                FeaturedTrack(
                    modifier = Modifier
                        .width(itemSize)
                        .clickable {
                            onTrackClicked(track)
                        },
                    track = track
                )
            }
        }
    }
}

ðŸ’¡ Alongside the Fixed type, the Adaptive type allows us to define a minimum sizing for a column - meaning that we can create more adaptive layouts by allowing our grid columns to adjust based on the available space.

When it comes to the items to be composed within our grid, these need to be composed using the items function provided through the LazyListScope - this is so that a unique key can be provided for each item being composed, allowing the LazyVerticalGrid to correctly manage the current scroll position on the screen.

With that said, weâ€™ll go ahead and utilise the items function - this allows us to provide a list that we wish to compose items from. Along with this list of items being provided, the itemContent block will also be called - this is where we will declare the composition for each item that is being composed within our UI.

@Composable
fun FeaturedTracksGrid(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    tracks: List<Track>?,
    onTrackClicked: (track: Track) -> Unit
) {
    if (!tracks.isNullOrEmpty()) {
        val itemSize = 
			(LocalConfiguration.current.screenWidthDp.dp / 2)
        FlowRow(
            modifier = modifier,
            mainAxisSize = SizeMode.Expand,
            mainAxisAlignment = 
				FlowMainAxisAlignment.SpaceBetween
        ) {
            tracks.forEach { track ->
                
            }
        }
    }
}

Currently, we donâ€™t have the component to be composed inside of our grid, so weâ€™re going to need to create a new composable. Weâ€™ll create this as FeaturedTrack.

@Composable
fun FeaturedTrack(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    track: Track
) {
    
}

For each track, weâ€™re going to create a container that contains the track cover, artist and name - for which weâ€™ll use a collection of different composables. Weâ€™ll start here with the container of the Track, for which weâ€™ll utilise the Surface composable.

@Composable
fun FeaturedTrack(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    track: Track
) {
    Surface(
        modifier = modifier
    ) {
        
    }
}

ðŸ’¡ The Surface is an elevated Material component that is used to contain prominent information within a user interface. Itâ€™s ideal for items within a collection, as it creates a clear visual separation between each item.

When it comes to this Surface, weâ€™re going to shape this with rounded corners. To achieve this effect weâ€™ll utilise the RoundedCornerShape class, allowing us to apply rounding to each of the corners. Weâ€™ll apply a corner size of 8dp for this, assigning the reference of this shape to the shape argument of the Surface composable function. Weâ€™ll also apply some elevation to the Surface so that it appears raised within the grid.

@Composable
fun FeaturedTrack(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    track: Track
) {
    Surface(
        modifier = modifier,
        shape = RoundedCornerShape(8.dp),
        elevation = 4.dp
    ) {
        
    }
}

Now that we have our Surface defined, weâ€™re going to go ahead and configure the contents of it. As we can see by the design, weâ€™re going to be showing the track data in a horizontal arrangement - with the track cover at the start of the surface, followed by the track title at the end. To achieve this layout weâ€™re going to utilise the Row composable, using the fillMaxWidth modifier to ensure this fills all of the horizontal space inside of the parent container. Weâ€™ll also want the contents of the Row to be centered vertically, so weâ€™ll utilise the verticalAlignment argument of the Row, passing the CenterVertically value.

@Composable
fun FeaturedTrack(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    track: Track
) {
    Surface(
        modifier = modifier.padding(8.dp),
        shape = RoundedCornerShape(4.dp),
        elevation = 4.dp
    ) {
        Row(
            modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
            verticalAlignment = Alignment.CenterVertically
        ) {
            
        }
    }
}

At the start of the FeaturedTrack weâ€™re going to display the cover of the track, so weâ€™ll utilise the CoverArt composable that we created earlier. Weâ€™ll use the size modifier to fix this to the size of 50dp, followed by passing in the current Track reference for the required track argument.

@Composable
fun FeaturedTrack(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    track: Track
) {
    Surface(
        modifier = modifier.padding(8.dp),
        shape = RoundedCornerShape(4.dp),
        elevation = 4.dp
    ) {
        Row(
            modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
            verticalAlignment = Alignment.CenterVertically
        ) {
            CoverArt(
                modifier = Modifier.size(50.dp),
                track = track
            )
        }
    }
}

At the end of the CoverArt, weâ€™re going to display the title of the track, so weâ€™ll utilise the Text composable. Alongside providing the title of the current track for the text argument, weâ€™re going to provide a couple of extra properties here.

  • modifier - weâ€™ll utilise the padding modifier to ensure that there is sufficient spacing around the composable. This also ensures there is always going to be space between the CoverArt and Text composables, as well as ensuring the Text is not pressed against the end of the Row
  • fontSize - we donâ€™t need this text to appear too large, so weâ€™ll set a custom font size of 14sp
  • fontWeight - the title of the track is the key piece of information for the item, so weâ€™ll want to bolden this text to have it stand out on its surface
  • maxLines - weâ€™ll only want to have the title displayed on a single line within the Row, so weâ€™ll fix this at 1
  • overflow - because weâ€™ve fixed the maxLines to 1, weâ€™ll want to provide a method to be used when this single line is exceeded. Weâ€™ll use the TextOverflow.Ellipsis value here so that ellipsis is used for any text that exceeds this single line
@Composable
fun FeaturedTrack(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    track: Track
) {
    Surface(
        modifier = modifier.padding(8.dp),
        shape = RoundedCornerShape(4.dp),
        elevation = 4.dp
    ) {
        Row(
            modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
            verticalAlignment = Alignment.CenterVertically
        ) {
            CoverArt(
                modifier = Modifier.size(50.dp),
                track = track
            )
            Text(
                modifier = Modifier.padding(8.dp),
                maxLines = 1,
                overflow = TextOverflow.Ellipsis,
                text = track.title,
                fontWeight = FontWeight.Bold,
                fontSize = 14.sp
            )
        }
    }
}

When it comes to the accessibility services and the focus on our track component, each child node is going to be focused on and communicated individually. This could end up adding quite a bit of friction when navigating through the Featured Track row using the screen reader, so weâ€™re going to use the semantics modifier to merge the descendants of our composable. This means that when the FeaturedTrack composable is in focus, the node will be focused and communicated as a single element - resulting in the track title being read with a single focus gesture.

@Composable
fun FeaturedTrack(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    track: Track
) {
    Surface(
        modifier = modifier.padding(8.dp),
        shape = RoundedCornerShape(4.dp),
        elevation = 4.dp
    ) {
        Row(
            modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth()
                .semantics(mergeDescendants = true) { },
            verticalAlignment = Alignment.CenterVertically
        ) {
            ...
        }
    }
}

Composing the Featured Track

Now that weâ€™ve created the FeaturedTrack composable, weâ€™re going to want to compose it within our FeaturedTracksGrid. Hopping back over to the FeaturedTracksGrid composable we can compose the FeaturedTrack within the items block of the LazyVerticalGrid. When composing the FeaturedTrack weâ€™ll pass the current Trackreference for the item being composed, along with the fillMaxWidth modifier to have the item fill the entire available space on the horizontal axis.

@Composable
fun FeaturedTracksGrid(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    tracks: List<Track>?,
    onTrackClicked: (track: Track) -> Unit
) {
    if (!tracks.isNullOrEmpty()) {
        val itemSize = 
			(LocalConfiguration.current.screenWidthDp.dp / 2)
        FlowRow(
            modifier = modifier,
            mainAxisSize = SizeMode.Expand,
            mainAxisAlignment = 
				FlowMainAxisAlignment.SpaceBetween
        ) {
            tracks.forEach { track ->
                FeaturedTrack(
                    modifier = Modifier
                        .width(itemSize),
                    track = track
                )
            }
        }
    }
}

Now that each FeaturedTrack is being composed, weâ€™re going to need to trigger the onTrackClicked lambda that is being provided to our FeaturedTracksGrid. Here weâ€™ll utilise the clickable modifier on each FeaturedTrack composable, triggering the onTrackClicked lambda for the corresponding Track.

@Composable
fun FeaturedTracksGrid(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    tracks: List<Track>?,
    onTrackClicked: (track: Track) -> Unit
) {
    if (!tracks.isNullOrEmpty()) {
        val itemSize = 
			(LocalConfiguration.current.screenWidthDp.dp / 2)
        FlowRow(
            modifier = modifier,
            mainAxisSize = SizeMode.Expand,
            mainAxisAlignment = 
				FlowMainAxisAlignment.SpaceBetween
        ) {
            tracks.forEach { track ->
                FeaturedTrack(
                    modifier = Modifier
                        .width(itemSize)
                        .clickable {
                            onTrackClicked(track)
                        },
                    track = track
                )
            }
        }
    }
}

Composing the Featured Tracks Grid

At this point, we now have a FeaturedTracksGrid composable that will display each of the featured track items. If we hop on back over to our FeaturedTracks function, we can now compose the FeaturedTracksGrid within the defined item block. When composing this, weâ€™ll use the fillMaxWidth() modifier to have the grid fill the maximum available width, along with providing the required tracks and onTrackClicked references.

// FeaturedTracks.kt

fun LazyListScope.FeaturedTracks(
    tracks: List<Track>?,
    onTrackClicked: (track: Track) -> Unit
) {
    item {
        Text(
            modifier = Modifier.padding(start = 16.dp),
            text = stringResource(id = 
				R.string.heading_featured),
            fontSize = 18.sp,
            fontWeight = FontWeight.Bold
        )
        FeaturedTracksGrid(
            modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
            tracks = tracks,
            onTrackClicked = onTrackClicked
        )
    }
}

With the FeaturedTracks composable implementation now complete, we can now compose this within the parent LazyColumn. Here weâ€™ll need to hop on back over to our TracksDashboard, composing the FeaturedTracks using the featuredTracks() from the MusicDashboardState state references and the onTrackClicked lambda provided to the TracksDashboard composable function.

// TracksDashboard.kt

@Composable
fun TracksDashboard(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    state: MusicDashboardState,
    onTrackClicked: (track: Track) -> Unit
) {
    LazyColumn(
        modifier = modifier,
        contentPadding = PaddingValues(
			top = 12.dp, 
			bottom = 8.dp
		)
    ) {
        FeaturedTracks(
            tracks = state.featuredTracks(),
            onTrackClicked = onTrackClicked
        )
        ...
    }
}

With the featured tracks now in place, we now have three different categories of tracks being composed inside of our Dashboard. These three tracks together give us a combination of different nested layouts, with multiple scroll directions being supported while browsing the catalogue.

Adding a Search bar

Now that we have tracks being composed inside of our dashboard, we can see that there could be a lot of content on display. We could help users find a track in the catalogue quicker by supporting search - this would allow the user to search for a track and have the results displayed within the UI. For this weâ€™re going to need to build two parts - the search bar used to enter a search query, along with the list which will display the search results.

Weâ€™re going to start by creating the search bar which will be used to enter the search query. Weâ€™ll create a new composable function, SearchBar.

// SearchBar.kt

@Composable
fun SearchBar(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier
) {

}

When it comes to the search query that has been input by the user, this is going to affect multiple parts of our UI.

  • The search bar itself will need to display the query that has been input by the user
  • The results list within the dashboard will need to display the results based on the query that has been entered

Because this search query affects multiple children within our feature, we previously defined this query string within the global screen state, which is our MusicDashboardState reference. For this reason, weâ€™re going to declare an argument for our composable function in the form of this query string.

// SearchBar.kt

@Composable
fun SearchBar(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
	query: String?
)

Using this query string, weâ€™re then going to compose a TextField, assigning its value to the query string that is being provided to this function. Because this query value is also nullable in our state, weâ€™ll assign a default value of an empty string for when this is null.

// SearchBar.kt

@Composable
fun SearchBar(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
	query: String?
) {
   TextField(
		modifier = modifier,
        value = query ?: "",
        onValueChange = {

        }
    )
}

While we are composing the search query value within our TextField, typing into this field wonâ€™t currently have any effect - this is because we currently have an empty onValueChange block. Because this query string is being managed at the global level for our screen, weâ€™re going to need to pass up any change events so that the state can be updated accordingly. Weâ€™ll add a new lambda function argument to our composable function, triggering this within the onValueChange block and passing up the updated value to be assigned to our state.

@Composable
fun SearchBar(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    query: String?,
	handleQuery: (query: String) -> Unit
) {
    TextField(
        modifier = modifier,
        value = query ?: "",
        onValueChange = {
            handleQuery(it)
        }
    )
}

Limiting the line length

Currently, when entering text into the input field, a new line will be started once the input text reaches the width of the input field. When this happens, the height of the input field will be expanded to adapt to the number of lines that have been entered.

This isnâ€™t an expected behaviour for search bars, so weâ€™re going to use the singleLine argument of the TextField to limit this input to a single line. This wonâ€™t prevent the user from typing as much content as theyâ€™d like, but instead, it will keep the input on a single line instead of breaking onto new lines once the width has been reached.

@Composable
fun SearchBar(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    query: String?,
	handleQuery: (query: String) -> Unit
) {
    TextField(
        modifier = modifier,
		singleLine = true,
        value = query ?: "",
        onValueChange = {
            handleQuery(it)
        }
  	)
}

Styling the Search Bar

Weâ€™re going to add a few modifications to the search bar that weâ€™ve created, in the form of the colors argument. Using this we can style how the search bar is composed - weâ€™ll pass values for the following arguments to style the bar:

  • backgroundColor - the color to be used for the background of the search bar
  • focusedIndicatorColor - the door to be used for the indicator when in focus
  • unfocusedIndicatorColor - the color to be used for the indicator when the bar is not in focus

So that our theme is adhered to, weâ€™ll use a modified version of the onSurface color from our theme for the indicator colors. Weâ€™ll also modify the background of the bar so that the surface color of our theme is applied.

@Composable
fun SearchBar(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    query: String?,
	handleQuery: (query: String) -> Unit
) {
        TextField(
            modifier = modifier,
            colors = TextFieldDefaults.textFieldColors(
                backgroundColor = MaterialTheme.colors.surface,
                focusedIndicatorColor = 	
					MaterialTheme.colors.onSurface.copy(
						alpha = 0.6f),
                unfocusedIndicatorColor = 									MaterialTheme.colors.onSurface.copy(
						alpha = 0.4f),
            ),
            ...
        )
}

Trailing Icon

Currently, our TextField is being used to display the search query that has been entered by the user.

During performing a query, it might be the case that the user wants to clear the query from the input field. To offer this functionality (and to avoid the user having to manually delete the input via the keyboard), weâ€™re going to add a trailing icon to the input field so that the text can be cleared upon request. This clear operation is being handled within our ViewModel which manages the global state, so weâ€™ll need to pass up this clear event to the parent composable. For this purpose, weâ€™ll add a new lambda function, clearQuery, as an argument for our composable function.

@Composable
fun SearchBar(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    query: String?,
    handleQuery: (query: String) -> Unit,
    clearQuery: () -> Unit
)

With this in place, we can now move on to composing the component that will be used to trigger this function. For the trailingIcon block weâ€™re going to compose an IconButton, this will be used to provide an interactable component to clear the search query. For the onClick argument of this composable, weâ€™ll simply want to trigger the onClick lambda that is provided to the SearchBar composable function.

@Composable
fun SearchBar(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    query: String?,
    handleQuery: (query: String) -> Unit,
    clearQuery: () -> Unit
) {
    TextField(
        ...,
        trailingIcon = {
        	IconButton(onClick = {
            	clearQuery()
            }) {

            }
        }
    )
}

While weâ€™ve implemented the required onClick argument, this IconButton composable currently has an empty body, so it has no visual representation on-screen. We can change this by composing a new Icon within our IconButton, using the Icons.Default.Clear icon for the imageVector argument. This gives us an icon that represents a â€˜clearâ€™ action.

@Composable
fun SearchBar(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    query: String?,
    handleQuery: (query: String) -> Unit,
    clearQuery: () -> Unit
) {
    TextField(
        ...,
        trailingIcon = {
        	IconButton(onClick = {
            	clearQuery()
            }) {
            	Icon(
                	imageVector = Icons.Default.Clear,
                    contentDescription = null
                }
            }
        }
    )
}

Weâ€™ve initially provided a null value for the contentDescription of our Icon, but weâ€™ll want to provide an actual description resource here so that the component is accessible for all users. Weâ€™ll start here by adding a new string to our strings.xml file that describes the action to be triggered by this icon. 

<string name="cd_clear_query">Clear query</string>

ðŸ’¡Content Descriptions allow us to provide a textual description for visual elements, used by accessibility services to provide additional context to users.

We can then use the stringResource function to retrieve the string representation of this resource value, assigning it to the contentDescription of our Icon composable.

@Composable
fun SearchBar(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    query: String?,
    handleQuery: (query: String) -> Unit,
    clearQuery: () -> Unit
) {
    TextField(
        ...,
        trailingIcon = {
        	IconButton(onClick = {
            	clearQuery()
            }) {
            	Icon(
                	imageVector = Icons.Default.Clear,
                    contentDescription =
						stringResource(id = R.string.cd_clear_query)
                    )
                }
            }
        }
    )
}

At this point, weâ€™ve added the clear action to our input field, but it wonâ€™t always be appropriate for us to display this action. For example, if there is no content currently present as a search query, then it wouldnâ€™t make sense for us to display that as an action to the user. For when there is no content present, weâ€™re going to want to display a different icon to the user - this will be when there is no content currently input as a search query, which will be when there is currently no focus on the input field.

Weâ€™re going to start here by using the provided query argument to depict which icon should be composed, as weâ€™ll only want to compose the existing â€˜clearâ€™ IconButton if there is currently no search query present.

@Composable
fun SearchBar(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    query: String?,
    handleQuery: (query: String) -> Unit,
    clearQuery: () -> Unit
) {
    TextField(
        ...,
        trailingIcon = {
            if (query.isNullOrEmpty()) {
                
            } else {
                IconButton(onClick = {
            		clearQuery()
            	}) {
            		Icon(
                		imageVector = Icons.Default.Clear,
                    	contentDescription =
							stringResource(id = R.string.cd_clear_query)
                    	)
                	}
            	}
            }
        }
    )
}

Now that we have this conditional logic configured, weâ€™re ready to compose the Icon to represent the empty search state. Weâ€™ll utilise the Icons.Default.Search icon here, passing it to our composable for composition. Because our icon is purely for decoration, in this case, we donâ€™t need to provide a content description so weâ€™ll pass null for this argument.

@Composable
fun SearchBar(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    query: String?,
    handleQuery: (query: String) -> Unit,
    clearQuery: () -> Unit
) {
    TextField(
        ...,
        trailingIcon = {
            if (query.isNullOrEmpty()) {
                Icon(
                    imageVector = Icons.Default.Search,
                    contentDescription = null
                )
            } else {
                ...
            }
        }
    )
}

ðŸ’¡Content Descriptions are used to provide descriptions for components that provide value to users. We donâ€™t need to provide descriptions for components that are purely for decoration unless they provide some form of value to the user.

With this in place, we now have a search icon being composed when there is no search query present in the input field.

Managing Focus

When the user interacts with the search bar, it gains focus - this means that it is currently in the state of being selected by the user. When this happens, the input field enters â€˜inputâ€™ mode and the user can enter a search query. When the component loses focus, the expectation would be that the component changes its visual state, no longer displaying the â€˜clearâ€™ action that we previously configured. However, when composing this, we only configured this to check whether the search query was currently empty or not. To match the expected behaviour here, weâ€™re also going to take into account the current focus state of the component. This means that when the component comes out of focus, the search icon will be displayed

To implement this behaviour, weâ€™re going to need to start by configuring a couple of variables.

  • First of all, we need to keep track of whether our search bar currently has focus. For this, weâ€™ll create a mutable piece of state that will be persisted across compositions. This state can remain local to this composable, as it is not required by any other components.
  • Secondly, weâ€™ll need to create a new reference for the FocusRequester class. This will allow us to manage the focus state of our search bar.
@Composable
fun SearchBar(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    query: String?,
    handleQuery: (query: String) -> Unit,
    clearQuery: () -> Unit
) {
    val inputHasFocus = remember { mutableStateOf(false) }
    val focusRequester = FocusRequester()
    ...
}

With these fields in place, we now need to configure both of these within our composable. Weâ€™ll use the focusRequester modifier to assign this FocusRequester reference to our composable, along with utilising the onFocusChanged modifier - this will be used to listen for focus changes on our composable. Whenever there is a focus change weâ€™ll want to set the current focus value to our inputHasFocus state, allowing us to keep a reference to whether the composable is currently in focus. 

@Composable
fun SearchBar(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    query: String?,
    handleQuery: (query: String) -> Unit,
    clearQuery: () -> Unit
) {
    var inputHasFocus by remember { mutableStateOf(false) }
    val focusRequester = FocusRequester()
    TextField(
        modifier = modifier
            .focusRequester(focusRequester)
            .onFocusChanged {
                inputHasFocus.value = it.hasFocus
            },
        ...
    )
}

Now that we have the current focus state of our composable configured, we can go ahead and use it within the composition of the search bar. We previously added some conditional logic that means the trailingIcon will only display the â€˜clearâ€™ icon when the query argument is null or empty. Weâ€™re going to modify this logic so that the above outcome will also occur if the input field does not currently have focus - as well as adding the behaviour to clear the focus when the user clicks the â€˜clearâ€™ icon. We want this behaviour because without removing the current focus from the input field, the component will always appear focused and in â€˜searchâ€™ mode - even when the user is interacting with other components on the screen.

To implement this focus clearing, weâ€™ll need to retrieve a reference to the current FocusManager - this will allow us to perform operations related to focus management. We need to change two things here when it comes to the TextField.

  • Weâ€™ll first need to modify the conditional logic for the trailingIcon so that alongside the query being null or empty, the â€˜searchâ€™ icon will also only show if the input field does not currently have focus. If the field currently has focus, we want to show the â€˜clearâ€™ icon so that the focus can be manually cleared.
  • Next up weâ€™ll want to modify the onClick implementation for the â€˜clearâ€™ IconButton. When this button is clicked, weâ€™ll want to clear the focus from the input field. For this weâ€™ll use the FocusManager reference that weâ€™ve retrieved, utilising the freeFocus function to clear the focus from the input field.
@Composable
fun SearchBar(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    query: String?,
    handleQuery: (query: String) -> Unit,
    clearQuery: () -> Unit
) {
    var inputHasFocus by remember { mutableStateOf(false) }
    val focusRequester = FocusRequester()
	val focusManager = LocalFocusManager.current

    TextField(
        ...
        trailingIcon = {
            if (
				query.isNullOrEmpty() && 
					!inputHasFocus
			) {
                ...
            } else {
                IconButton(onClick = {
                    focusRequester.freeFocus()
                    clearQuery()
                }) {
                    ...
                }
            }
        }
    )
}

With the above in place, we have better focus management in place for the input field. This configuration now allows the user to remove focus from the field when they are no longer performing a search query, providing better clarity for the current state of the screen.

Search Hint

Now that we have the focus management in place, we can utilise this to add a hint to the search field. While the TextField composable supports a label to describe the required input, weâ€™re going to implement this ourselves so that the label does not toggle between a floating state.

Weâ€™re going to implement this by having a Text composed on top of the existing TextField, this will allow us to show/hide the overlaying Text composable based on whether it needs to be displayed or not. So that we can have this overlapping effect, weâ€™re going to start by defining the use of a Box composable and wrapping the existing TextField. Because weâ€™re placing multiple child nodes inside of the Box weâ€™re going to want to ensure that these are aligned correctly - so weâ€™ll utilise the contentAlignment argument to align the components at the horizontal start and vertical centre of the container space.

@Composable
fun SearchBar(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    query: String?,
    handleQuery: (query: String) -> Unit,
    clearQuery: () -> Unit
) {
	...
    Box(
        contentAlignment = Alignment.CenterStart
    ) {
        ...
        TextField(
			...
		)
    }
}

With this Box now in place, we can add the hint message to be displayed to the user. Weâ€™re going to start by adding a new string to our strings.xml file that will represent this hint.

<string name="hint_search">
	Search for a track, artist or albumâ€¦
</string>

Now that we have this hint, we can go ahead and compose it inside of the Box. After the composition of the TextField, weâ€™ll compose a Text when the input field does not currently have focus and there is no search query present. This is because if the user is already focused on the input field, or they have already started entering a search query, then they donâ€™t need to see the hint. When composing the Text weâ€™ll provide the previously defined hint_search resource for the text argument.

@Composable
fun SearchBar(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    query: String?,
    handleQuery: (query: String) -> Unit,
    clearQuery: () -> Unit
) {
    val inputHasFocus = remember { mutableStateOf(false) }
    val focusRequester = FocusRequester()
    Box(
        contentAlignment = Alignment.CenterStart
    ) {
        TextField(...)
        if (!inputHasFocus.value && query.isNullOrEmpty()) {
            Text(
                text = stringResource(
					id = R.string.hint_search)
            )
        }
    }
}

While the hint is being composed, it feels as though we are missing a few stylistic properties. First of all, there is insufficient spacing around the composable, as well as the hint being too prominent within the component. A hint should be subtle, so as not to take all of the attention within the user interface. So aside from providing the text value to be composed, weâ€™ll also provide some padding using the corresponding padding modifier, along with overriding the default color of the composed text. For this color, weâ€™re going to take the existing onSurface color from our theme and apply a new alpha value. We want to keep the text color of the hint with the theme of our application, but applying this alpha helps to make it a less prominent part of our UI.

@Composable
fun SearchBar(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    query: String?,
    handleQuery: (query: String) -> Unit,
    clearQuery: () -> Unit
) {
    val inputHasFocus = remember { mutableStateOf(false) }
    val focusRequester = FocusRequester()
	val onSurfaceWithAlpha = MaterialTheme.colors.onSurface.copy(alpha = 0.4f)
    Box(
        contentAlignment = Alignment.CenterStart
    ) {
        TextField(...)
        if (!inputHasFocus.value && query.isNullOrEmpty()) {
            Text(
                modifier = Modifier.padding(start = 16.dp),
                color = onSurfaceWithAlpha,
                text = stringResource(
					id = R.string.hint_search)
            )
        }
    }
}

ðŸ’¡Even though we are modifying the alpha of a color from our theme, we are still accessing the color from the theme of our application. This helps to ensure that the color of the text for our hint remains consistent with the rest of the text color within our application.

Composing the Search Bar

Our search bar is now implemented in a visual sense, but itâ€™s not yet functional within our UI. Here we first need to compose this within our Dashboard composable, plugging it into the appBar of our BackdropScaffold. Here weâ€™ll compose the SearchBar, providing the following for each of its functions arguments.

  • For the modifier, weâ€™ll utilise the fillMaxWidth modifier, as this will allow the search bar to fill the maximum available width.
  • The query to be displayed within the search bar is going to come from our MusicDashboardState reference, so weâ€™ll pass this directly in for the query argument.
  • The handleQuery implementation is used to handle when the search query input is changed. When this is triggered, weâ€™ll want to utilise the MusicCatalogEvent.Search event to update the state contained within our ViewModel.
  • The clearQuery implementation is being triggered when the â€˜clearâ€™ icon within our SearchBar is interacted with. In this case, weâ€™ll want to clear the search query from our state, so weâ€™ll trigger the MusicCatalogEvent.ClearSearchQuery event in these cases to update the state within our ViewModel.
@Composable
fun Dashboard(
    state: MusicDashboardState
) {
    val scaffoldState = rememberBackdropScaffoldState(
        initialValue = BackdropValue.Revealed
    )

    BackdropScaffold(
        backLayerBackgroundColor =
			MaterialTheme.colors.surface,
        scaffoldState = scaffoldState,
        appBar = {
        	SearchBar(
                modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
                query = state.searchTerm,
                handleQuery = {
                    handleEvent(MusicCatalogEvent.Search(it))
                },
                clearQuery = {
                    handleEvent(
						MusicCatalogEvent.ClearSearchQuery)
                }
            )
        },
        backLayerContent = {
			...
        },
        frontLayerContent = {
            
        }
    )
}

Now with the SearchBar being composed, we can see the input bar being composed at the top of our Scaffold.

Displaying search results

Alongside the user being able to utilise the search bar to find content within the music catalogue, weâ€™re going to want to display the search results based on the query that has been entered into the input field. Weâ€™re going to show these search results within our TracksDashboard composable - as here weâ€™re either going to want to display the music catalogue content or the results of the search query.

Weâ€™ll start here by adding a conditional statement to our TracksDashboard. If there is currently no search term within the MusicDashboardState then this means that there has been no search query entered. In this case, weâ€™ll want to compose the LazyColumn that represents the music catalogue, otherwise, weâ€™ll want to compose the results of the search.

// TracksDashboard.kt

@Composable
fun TracksDashboard(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    state: MusicDashboardState,
    onTrackClicked: (track: Track) -> Unit
) {
    if (state.searchTerm.isNullOrEmpty()) {
        LazyColumn {
            ...
        }
    } else {
        
    }
}

In this else block weâ€™re going to want to compose the search results for the current query. Weâ€™re going to house this within a new compose, so weâ€™ll create a new composable function called SearchResults. This is going to take a list of tracks that represents the results of the current search, along with a lambda function that will be used to handle click events on any of the track items.

@Composable
fun SearchResults(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    results: List<Track>?,
    onTrackClicked: (track: Track) -> Unit
)

Handling Empty results

When there are tracks present in the list, weâ€™re going to want to compose the results within this SearchResults composable, otherwise, weâ€™re going to want to compose an empty results message on-screen. To account for these rules, weâ€™ll start by adding a null/empty check for the provided tracks list.

@Composable
fun SearchResults(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    results: List<Track>?,
    onTrackClicked: (track: Track) -> Unit
) {
    if (results.isNullOrEmpty()) {
        
    }
}

When the results list is null or empty, weâ€™ll compose a message on-screen to let the user know that no results were found for the given query. Weâ€™ll start by adding a new resource that represents this message to our strings.xml file.

<string name="message_search_results">
	No results to display
</string>

Next, weâ€™ll compose a Text composable that will compose this message. Weâ€™ll also wrap this composition in a Box that utilises the modifier passed to the SearchResults composable function, aligning the Text child node in the center of its space.

@Composable
fun SearchResults(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    results: List<Track>?,
    onTrackClicked: (track: Track) -> Unit
) {
    if (results.isNullOrEmpty()) {
        Box(
            modifier = modifier,
            contentAlignment = Alignment.Center
        ) {
            Text(text = stringResource(id = 
				R.string.message_search_results))
        }
    } else {
        
    }
}

Composing the Search results

Now that we have the empty case handled, weâ€™re next going to want to compose the search results using the provided list of Track references.

@Composable
fun SearchResults(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    results: List<Track>?,
    onTrackClicked: (track: Track) -> Unit
) {
    if (results.isNullOrEmpty()) {
        Box(
            modifier = modifier,
            contentAlignment = Alignment.Center
        ) {
            Text(text = stringResource(id = 
				R.string.message_search_results))
        }
    } else {
        LazyColumn(
            modifier = modifier
        ) {
            
        }
    }
}

For the search results, weâ€™re going to re-use the Track composable that we created previously for this project.

This Track composable is going to be used to make up the results of the query, so weâ€™ll utilise this within the items block of the specified LazyColumn. When composing each Track weâ€™ll utilise the fillMaxWidth modifier to ensure that the entire available width is occupied, along with providing the current Track search result reference for the track argument.

@Composable
fun SearchResults(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    results: List<Track>?,
    onTrackClicked: (track: Track) -> Unit
) {
    if (results.isNullOrEmpty()) {
        Box(
            modifier = modifier,
            contentAlignment = Alignment.Center
        ) {
            Text(text = stringResource(id = 
				R.string.message_search_results))
        }
    } else {
        LazyColumn(
            modifier = modifier
        ) {
            items(results) {
                Track(
                    modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
                    track = it
                )
            }
        }
    }
}

With the above in place, we now have the search results being composed within our SearchResults composable, along with a message when there are no results to display.

The last thing to do here is to add click support to the search results, allowing the user to play a track when selecting one of the results. Similar to how weâ€™ve approached other click events in this project, weâ€™ll start by adding a click action description to our strings.xml resources file.

<string name="action_select_track">Play %s</string>

Next up weâ€™ll go ahead and utilise the clickable modifier to allow click events to be triggered on each of the Track references. When this click action is triggered, weâ€™ll go ahead and trigger the onTrackClicked lambda that is provided to our SearchResults composable.

@Composable
fun SearchResults(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    results: List<Track>?,
    onTrackClicked: (track: Track) -> Unit
) {
    if (results.isNullOrEmpty()) {
        Box(
            modifier = modifier,
            contentAlignment = Alignment.Center
        ) {
            Text(text = stringResource(id = 
				R.string.message_search_results))
        }
    } else {
        LazyColumn(
            modifier = modifier
        ) {
            items(results) {
                val selectTrackAction = stringResource(id = 
					R.string.action_select_track, it.title)
                Track(
                    modifier = Modifier
                        .fillMaxWidth()
                        .clickable(
							onClickLabel = selectTrackAction
						) {
                            onTrackClicked(it)
                        },
                    track = it
                )
            }
        }
    }
}

As a final tweak to the search results list, weâ€™ll go ahead and utilise the contentPadding argument for the LazyColumn - allowing us to apply some padding to the displayed content, which now has sufficient spacing around its edges.

@Composable
fun SearchResults(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    results: List<Track>?,
    onTrackClicked: (track: Track) -> Unit
) {
    if (results.isNullOrEmpty()) {
        Box(
            modifier = modifier,
            contentAlignment = Alignment.Center
        ) {
            Text(text = stringResource(id = 
				R.string.message_search_results))
        }
    } else {
        LazyColumn(
            modifier = modifier,
            contentPadding = PaddingValues(
				top = 8.dp, 
				bottom = 8.dp
			)
        ) {
            items(results) {
                val selectTrackAction = stringResource(id = 
					R.string.action_select_track, it.title)
                Track(
                    modifier = Modifier
                        .fillMaxWidth()
                        .clickable(
							onClickLabel = selectTrackAction
						) {
                            onTrackClicked(it)
                        },
                    track = it
                )
            }
        }
    }
}

With this in place, we now have a SearchResults composable that will display a list of given tracks on-screen, based on the current search query that is within our state.

All thatâ€™s left to do now is to compose this SearchResults within our dashboard. Hopping back over to our TracksDashboard composable, we will compose the SearchResults in the else block of the conditional check that we implemented based on the current search term from our MusicDashboardState reference.

// TracksDashboard.kt

@Composable
fun TracksDashboard(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    state: MusicDashboardState,
    onTrackClicked: (track: Track) -> Unit
) {
    if (state.searchTerm.isNullOrEmpty()) {
        LazyColumn(
            ...
        ) {
            ...
        }
    } else {
        SearchResults(
            modifier = modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
            results = state.searchResults,
            onTrackClicked = { track ->
                onTrackClicked(track)
            }
        )
    }
}

Building the Music Playback components

At this point, we have a music dashboard that will display a catalogue of tracks to the user, along with allowing them to search for a track within the catalogue. While these tracks can be viewed, there isnâ€™t any other functionality - weâ€™ve added click listeners to each of the tracks that are composed within our UI, but the result of those click listeners doesnâ€™t currently trigger anything within our UI. In this section, weâ€™re going to create a fake music player component, which will show the currently playing track to the user.

This music player component is going to take two different forms - both a full-screen form and a collapsed form, representing a bottom bar player while the user is browsing the music catalogue.

Creating the Player Bottom Bar

When the user is browsing the music catalogue, weâ€™re going to be displaying a collapsed music player at the bottom of the screen. This bottom bar allows us to display the current media playback, while still enabling the user to browse through the catalogue at the same time. This results in a non-blocking audio playback UX, which is something we often see in media applications.

Weâ€™re going to start here by creating a new composable, PlayerBar. This composable is going to take a nullable reference to the NowPlaying class that we defined earlier in this chapter - this will represent the track that is currently being played, with a null value representing the state where no media is currently being played. Alongside this, weâ€™ll also require a lambda that can be used to toggle the playback state for the currently playing track.

@Composable
fun PlayerBar(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    nowPlaying: NowPlaying?,
    toggleNowPlayingState: () -> Unit
)

When this NowPlaying reference is not null, weâ€™re going to want to display the details for the currently playing track. As per the designs, weâ€™re going to be displaying the following details for a track that is currently being played:

  • The cover art for the track
  • The name of the track
  • The artist of the track
  • The current playback position of the track

To contain these details, weâ€™re going to start by defining a new Row composable - this is going to need to fill the maximum width of the parent container, as well as position all of its children in the center of the vertical axis.

@Composable
fun PlayerBar(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    nowPlaying: NowPlaying?,
    toggleNowPlayingState: () -> Unit
) {
    nowPlaying?.let {
		Row(
            modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
            verticalAlignment = Alignment.CenterVertically
        ) {
            
        }
	}
}

With this Row in place, we can now compose the cover art for the given track. For this weâ€™ll utilise the CoverfArt composable that we previously created, using the size modifier to assign a sizing of 32dp. Weâ€™ll also provide the Track reference from the NowPlaying state that is being provided to the composable function.

@Composable
fun PlayerBar(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    nowPlaying: NowPlaying?,
    toggleNowPlayingState: () -> Unit
) {
    nowPlaying?.let {
		Row(
            modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
            verticalAlignment = Alignment.CenterVertically
        ) {
            CoverArt(
                modifier = Modifier.size(32.dp),
                track = nowPlaying.track
            )
        }
	}
}

Alongside the cover art, weâ€™re also going to be showing the title and artist for the given track. Weâ€™ll compose a column here to contain this information, using the weight modifier to ensure that it takes up the remaining available width outside of the CoverArt composable. Using the Spacer composer weâ€™ll also ensure that there is sufficient space between the cover art and track information.

@Composable
fun PlayerBar(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    nowPlaying: NowPlaying?,
    toggleNowPlayingState: () -> Unit
) {
    nowPlaying?.let {
		Row(
            modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
            verticalAlignment = Alignment.CenterVertically
        ) {
            CoverArt(
                modifier = Modifier.size(32.dp),
                track = nowPlaying.track
            )
            Spacer(modifier = Modifier.width(16.dp))
            Column(
                modifier = Modifier.weight(1f)
            ) {
                Text(
                    text = nowPlaying.track.title,
                    fontWeight = FontWeight.Bold,
                    fontSize = 12.sp
                )
                Text(
                    text = nowPlaying.track.artist,
                    fontSize = 10.sp
                )
            }
        }
	}
}

For the track information within the Column composable, weâ€™re going to use the mergeSemantics flag within the semantics modifier. This means that the content of the composable will be communicated as a single item, as opposed to two individually focusable elements.

@Composable
fun PlayerBar(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    nowPlaying: NowPlaying?,
    toggleNowPlayingState: () -> Unit
) {
    nowPlaying?.let {
		Row(
            modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
            verticalAlignment = Alignment.CenterVertically
        ) {
            ...
            Column(
                modifier = Modifier.weight(1f)
                    .semantics(mergeDescendants = true) { }
            ) {
                ...
            }
        }
	}
}

Allowing playback

Outside of displaying the track information for the currently playing item, weâ€™re going to want to allow the user to toggle the playback of this track - enabling the user to pause/resume playback after a music track has been selected from the catalogue. For this, weâ€™re going to place an icon at the end of the Row within the PlayerBar.

For this component weâ€™re going to compose an IconButton, this button will be used to trigger the toggleNowPlayingState lambda that is being provided to the composable function.

// PlayerBar.it

@Composable
fun PlayerBar(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    nowPlaying: NowPlaying?,
    toggleNowPlayingState: () -> Unit
) {
    nowPlaying?.let {
		Row(
            modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
            verticalAlignment = Alignment.CenterVertically
        ) {
            ...
            IconButton(
                onClick = {
                    toggleNowPlayingState()
                }
            ) {
               
            }
        }
	}
}

All we need to do now is compose the body of this IconButton, this composition will consist of an Icon composable.

// PlayerBar.it

@Composable
fun PlayerBar(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    nowPlaying: NowPlaying?,
    toggleNowPlayingState: () -> Unit
) {
    nowPlaying?.let {
		Row(
            modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
            verticalAlignment = Alignment.CenterVertically
        ) {
            ...
            IconButton(
                onClick = {
                    toggleNowPlayingState()
                }
            ) {
               	Icon(
                    ...
                )
            }
        }
	}
}

This Icon is going to need to represent the action regarding the current playback state. To keep this logic outside of our composable, as well as make it reusable in other components weâ€™ll be building later in this chapter, weâ€™re going to create a small utility file. This file will define two functions, iconForPlayingState and descriptionForNowPlayingState - these will be used to retrieve both the icon and content description based on the current playback state. Weâ€™ll start by using the NowPlayingState to calculate the icon to be used.

// playerUtils.kt

fun iconForPlayingState(state: NowPlayingState): ImageVector {
    return if (state == NowPlayingState.PLAYING) {
        Icons.Default.Pause
    } else Icons.Default.PlayArrow
}

Weâ€™ll also want a corresponding content description for these icons, so weâ€™ll start by adding two new strings to our resources file.

<string name="cd_play">Play</string>
<string name="cd_pause">Pause</string>

Followed by creating a second function to retrieve a resource based on the NowPlayingState reference.

// playerUtils.kt

fun iconForPlayingState(state: NowPlayingState): ImageVector {
    return if (state == NowPlayingState.PLAYING) {
        Icons.Default.Pause
    } else Icons.Default.PlayArrow
}

fun descriptionForNowPlayingState(state: NowPlayingState): Int {
    return if (state == NowPlayingState.PLAYING) {
        R.string.cd_pause
    } else R.string.cd_play
}

We can then utilise these functions within our composable to complete the composition of the Icon.

// PlayerBar.it

@Composable
fun PlayerBar(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    nowPlaying: NowPlaying?,
    toggleNowPlayingState: () -> Unit
) {
    nowPlaying?.let {
		Row(
            modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
            verticalAlignment = Alignment.CenterVertically
        ) {
            ...
            IconButton(
                onClick = {
                    toggleNowPlayingState()
                }
            ) {
               	Icon(
                    imageVector = iconForPlayingState(
						nowPlaying.state),
                    contentDescription = stringResource(
                        id = descriptionForNowPlayingState(
                            nowPlaying.state
                        )
                    )
                )
            }
        }
	}
}

Creating the SeekBar

Within this player bar, weâ€™re also going to want to display information regarding the current playback status of the track. While the bar currently indicates whether the track is currently being played, there is no information as to the position of the current playback. For this weâ€™re going to create a new component, a seek bar which will be used to display the current playback -weâ€™ll start here by creating a new composable, PlayerSeekBar. This composable is going to take a reference to NowPlaying, which will be used to compose the current playback status.

@Composable
fun PlayerSeekBar(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    nowPlaying: NowPlaying
)

To compose the current playback, weâ€™re going to utilise the LinearProgressIndicator. This is because we are wanting to communicate the current progress of the playing track to the user, which can be achieved via the use of a linear progress bar. However, to be able to display the playback progress, we first need to calculate what this progress is based on the current NowPlaying reference. To do so, weâ€™ll take the playback position of the currently playing track, diving it by the length of the track - this will give us the percentage of the playback position in relation to its length.

@Composable
fun PlayerSeekBar(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    nowPlaying: NowPlaying
) {
    val currentPosition = nowPlaying.position.toFloat() / 
		nowPlaying.track.length.toFloat()
}

With this calculation in place, we can then apply this value to the progress argument of the LinearProgressIndicator composable.

@Composable
fun PlayerSeekBar(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    nowPlaying: NowPlaying
) {
    val currentPosition = nowPlaying.position.toFloat() / 
		nowPlaying.track.length.toFloat()
    LinearProgressIndicator(
        modifier = modifier,
        progress = currentPosition
    )
}

While we have a seek bar that can be used to display the current playback for a track, it doesnâ€™t yet support a piece of functionality that weâ€™re going to need in another part of our music catalogue feature - audio scrubbing, which allows the user to change the current playback position. While weâ€™re not using this functionality just yet, weâ€™re going to implement this here so that we have a reusable component ready to plug in later on in this chapter.

To support this functionality weâ€™re going to add two new arguments to our composable function:

  • canSeekTrack - this allows us to define whether the current composition supports the ability to scrub the audio. In the case of our player bottom bar, we donâ€™t want to support this functionality.
  • onSeekChanged - when the audio is scrubbed weâ€™ll need to update the current playback position within our global state, this callback will be used to propagate this state back up to the parent composable
@Composable
fun PlayerSeekBar(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    nowPlaying: NowPlaying,
    canSeekTrack: Boolean,
    onSeekChanged: ((value: Float) -> Unit)? = null
)

We have these new arguments applied, weâ€™re going to adjust the composition of the previously defined LinearProgressIndicator - as weâ€™ll only want to compose this when canSeekTrack is provided as a value of false.

@Composable
fun PlayerSeekBar(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    nowPlaying: NowPlaying,
    canSeekTrack: Boolean,
    onSeekChanged: ((value: Float) -> Unit)? = null
) {
    val currentPosition = nowPlaying.position.toFloat() / 
		nowPlaying.track.length.toFloat()
    if (canSeekTrack) {
       ...
    } else {
        LinearProgressIndicator(
            modifier = modifier.testTag(TAG_SEEK_BAR),
            progress = currentPosition
        )
    }
}

On the other hand, weâ€™re going to want to compose a different component when the user can perform the scrubbing of audio. In these cases weâ€™re going to want to compose a Slider, this component enables the user to slide between values. When composing this, weâ€™ll want to provide a seek position for the value argument, which will consist of the existing currentPosition value that we previously calculated. Weâ€™ll also need to handle the cases where seeking is performed, so here weâ€™ll utilise the onValueChange block, triggering the onSeekChanged lambda that is being provided to the composable function. When calling this weâ€™ll need to pass the current position of the track - so weâ€™ll calculate this using the length of the track, diving it by the current seek position. This calculation will give us the current playback time of the audio, which can then be assigned within the state of our screen.

@Composable
fun PlayerSeekBar(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    nowPlaying: NowPlaying,
    canSeekTrack: Boolean,
    onSeekChanged: ((value: Float) -> Unit)? = null
) {
    val currentPosition = nowPlaying.position.toFloat() / 
		nowPlaying.track.length.toFloat()
    if (canSeekTrack) {
        Slider(
            modifier = modifier,
            value = currentPosition,
            onValueChange = {
                onSeekChanged?.invoke(
					nowPlaying.track.length * it)
            }
        )
    } else {
        LinearProgressIndicator(
            modifier = modifier,
            progress = currentPosition
        )
    }
}

At this point, weâ€™re now going to compose the PlayerSeekBar that weâ€™ve just created. Within our PlayerBar, weâ€™ll compose this at the bottom of the Column that is holding the playback information. When composing this, weâ€™re going to provide a couple of pieces of information for composition.

  • Weâ€™ll use the fillMaxWidth modifier to have the composable fill the maximum available width within the container
  • Weâ€™ll need to provide the NowPlaying reference so that the playback position can be calculated
  • In this collapsed version of the PlayerBar the user is not able to perform the seek operation, so weâ€™ll pass a false flag here to prevent this gesture from occurring
@Composable
fun PlayerBar(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    nowPlaying: NowPlaying?,
    toggleNowPlayingState: () -> Unit
) {
    nowPlaying?.let {
        Column(
            modifier = modifier
                .padding(horizontal = 8.dp, vertical = 4.dp)
        ) {
            ...
            PlayerSeekBar(
                modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
                nowPlaying = nowPlaying,
                canSeekTrack = false
            )
        }
    }
}

With this now being composed, we can see that we now have some visual playback information being composed within the player bar. Weâ€™ll wrap things up here by adding some padding to the container of our player bar, helping to create some visual spacing on both the horizontal and vertical axis.

@Composable
fun PlayerBar(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    nowPlaying: NowPlaying?,
    toggleNowPlayingState: () -> Unit
) {
    nowPlaying?.let {
        Column(
            modifier = modifier
                .padding(horizontal = 8.dp, vertical = 4.dp)
        ) {
            ...
        }
    }
}

Building the Fullscreen Player

Now that we have the player bottom bar in place, we have a way to communicate audio playback through the dashboard of our music catalogue. In audio applications that mimic the same kind of layout, a fullscreen player can often be launched by interacting with this bottom bar audio component. In this part of the chapter, weâ€™re going to mimic this by creating a version of our PlayerBar that fills the entire screen with playback information.

From this design we can see that the fullscreen player will support:

  • Information on the track that is currently being played
  • A button is used to toggle between the playing and paused state
  • Buttons that allow the user to rewind and fast-forward playback
