  • A seek bar that shows the current position of playback
  • An icon that allows the user to close the fullscreen player

To implement this, weâ€™ll start here by creating a new composable function.

@Composable
fun Player(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    nowPlaying: NowPlaying,
    toggleNowPlayingState: () -> Unit,
    rewindTrack: () -> Unit,
    fastForwardTrack: () -> Unit,
    onSeekChanged: (position: Float) -> Unit,
    onClose: () -> Unit
)

We can see that this composable function takes a collection of arguments to satisfy the requirements that are outlined above.

  • nowPlaying - a reference to the track that is currently being played
  • toggleNowPlayingState - a lambda triggered when the play/pause button is interacted with to toggle the playback state
  • rewindTrack - a lambda to be triggered when the rewind button is pressed
  • fastForwardTrack - a lambda to be triggered when the fast forward button is pressed
  • onSeekChanged - a lambda to be triggered when the seek bar is used to change the current playback position
  • onClose - a lambda triggered when the close icon is clicked

With these arguments in place, we can start building out the UI components that will make up our composable. As we can see from our design, the components are made up of a mixture of vertically and horizontally stacked elements. Weâ€™re going to need to start here by defining a container which will be used to hold our UI components - this parent container is going to take the form of a Column, whose children are aligned to the center of both the vertical and horizontal axis. Weâ€™ll also apply some padding here to ensure that there is always sufficient spacing around the outside edges of the container.

@Composable
fun Player(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    nowPlaying: NowPlaying,
    toggleNowPlayingState: () -> Unit,
    rewindTrack: () -> Unit,
    fastForwardTrack: () -> Unit,
    onSeekChanged: (position: Float) -> Unit,
    onClose: () -> Unit
) {
    Column(
        modifier = modifier.padding(16.dp),
        horizontalAlignment = Alignment.CenterHorizontally,
        verticalArrangement = Arrangement.Center
    ) {

    }
}

With this container in place, we can now start adding the children that make up the user interface of our player. Weâ€™re going to reuse the CoverArt composable that we created earlier, fixing this to a size of 240dp.

@Composable
fun Player(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    nowPlaying: NowPlaying,
    toggleNowPlayingState: () -> Unit,
    rewindTrack: () -> Unit,
    fastForwardTrack: () -> Unit,
    onSeekChanged: (position: Float) -> Unit,
    onClose: () -> Unit
) {
    Column(
        modifier = modifier.padding(16.dp),
        horizontalAlignment = Alignment.CenterHorizontally,
        verticalArrangement = Arrangement.Center
    ) {

        CoverArt(
            modifier = Modifier.size(240.dp),
            track = nowPlaying.track
        )

    }
}

With the cover art for the track now being displayed, we can start to compose more information for our track. Next, weâ€™re going to compose the artist name and title underneath the cover art, using a Spacer to ensure there is sufficient space between the cover and track details.

@Composable
fun Player(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    nowPlaying: NowPlaying,
    toggleNowPlayingState: () -> Unit,
    rewindTrack: () -> Unit,
    fastForwardTrack: () -> Unit,
    onSeekChanged: (position: Float) -> Unit,
    onClose: () -> Unit
) {
    Column(
        modifier = modifier.padding(16.dp),
        horizontalAlignment = Alignment.CenterHorizontally,
        verticalArrangement = Arrangement.Center
    ) {

        CoverArt(
            modifier = Modifier.size(240.dp),
            track = nowPlaying.track
        )

        Spacer(modifier = Modifier.height(16.dp))

        Column(
            modifier = Modifier.semantics(mergeDescendants = true) { }
        ) {
            Text(
                fontSize = 22.sp,
                text = nowPlaying.track.title
            )

            Text(,
                fontSize = 18.sp,
                text = nowPlaying.track.artist,
                fontWeight = FontWeight.Bold
            )
        }
       
    }
}

Here we also use the mergeDescendants flag for the composable semantics to have the track details communicated to the user as a single item.

Alongside the track title and artist, weâ€™re also going to want to display some information around the current playback state - as well as allow the user to change this playback information. We previously created the PlayerSeekBar composable, so weâ€™ll compose this here with the difference of allowing the user to perform seek operations for the current track.

@Composable
fun Player(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    nowPlaying: NowPlaying,
    toggleNowPlayingState: () -> Unit,
    rewindTrack: () -> Unit,
    fastForwardTrack: () -> Unit,
    onSeekChanged: (position: Float) -> Unit,
    onClose: () -> Unit
) {
    Column(
        modifier = modifier.padding(16.dp),
        horizontalAlignment = Alignment.CenterHorizontally,
        verticalArrangement = Arrangement.Center
    ) {

        CoverArt(
            modifier = Modifier.size(240.dp),
            track = nowPlaying.track
        )

        Spacer(modifier = Modifier.height(16.dp))

        Column(
            modifier = Modifier.semantics(mergeDescendants = true) { }
        ) {
            ...
        }
        Spacer(modifier = Modifier.height(36.dp))

        PlayerSeekBar(
            modifier = Modifier
                .fillMaxWidth()
                .padding(horizontal = 32.dp),
            nowPlaying = nowPlaying,
            canSeekTrack = true
        ) {
            onSeekChanged(it)
        }

    }
}

During composition, we utilise both the canSeekTrack and onSeekChanged arguments that were provided to the parent composable. These arguments allow us to compose the playback position for the current track, along with propagating seek events back up to the parent composable for state modification.

As it is, the seekbar doesnâ€™t provide an exact representation of the current playback position of the playing track. Because we are in a fullscreen player, we have the space to show additional information that is useful to the user. To improve things here, weâ€™re going to display the current playback time at the start of the seekbar, followed by the length of the track at the end of the seekbar.

@Composable
fun Player(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    nowPlaying: NowPlaying,
    toggleNowPlayingState: () -> Unit,
    rewindTrack: () -> Unit,
    fastForwardTrack: () -> Unit,
    onSeekChanged: (position: Float) -> Unit,
    onClose: () -> Unit
) {
    val dateFormat = remember { 
		SimpleDateFormat("mm:ss", Locale.getDefault()) 
	}
    Column(
        modifier = modifier.padding(16.dp),
        horizontalAlignment = Alignment.CenterHorizontally,
        verticalArrangement = Arrangement.Center
    ) {

        ...

        val horizontalPadding = 32.dp
        PlayerSeekBar(
            modifier = Modifier
                .fillMaxWidth()
                .padding(horizontal = horizontalPadding),
            nowPlaying = nowPlaying,
            canSeekTrack = true
        ) {
            onSeekChanged(it)
        }

        Spacer(modifier = Modifier.height(6.dp))

        Row(
            modifier = Modifier
                .padding(horizontal = horizontalPadding)
        ) {
            Text(text = dateFormat.format(
				Date(nowPlaying.position * 1000L)))
            Spacer(modifier = Modifier.weight(1f))
            Text(text = dateFormat.format(
				Date(nowPlaying.track.length * 1000L)))
        }

    }
}

Here we compose this information using the NowPlaying reference that is being provided to the composable. Because we want these times formatted in a minute-minute:second-second format (e.g. 01:20), we need to utilise the SimpleDateFormat class so that we can format the track times. Using the position and track length properties, we can create two formatted time stamps that can be composed at either side of the seek bar. We have these times composed at either end by utilising the Spacer composable, using a weight of 1f to force it to use all available space between the timestamps.

While we have a seekbarseek bar in place, weâ€™re also going to add some buttons that will allow the playback state to be managed by the user. Here weâ€™ll create three different buttons - one to allow the toggling between a playing/paused state, and two others than can be used to both rewind and fast-forward the playing track. Weâ€™re going to want to compose these buttons in a horizontal arrangement, having them spaced evenly within the container. With this in mind, weâ€™ll utilise the Row composable, along with the SpaceEvenly value for the horizontalArrangment property.

Row(
    horizontalArrangement = Arrangement.SpaceEvenly
) {

}

ðŸ’¡Using SpaceEvenly will ensure that all child composable is spread evenly through the available space of the parent container.

The first child of this container is going to be the rewind button. Weâ€™ll compose an IconButton for this, triggering the rewindTrack lambda that is being provided to the composable function. For the body of this composable, weâ€™ll utilise the FastRewind icon, along with adding a new value to our strings resources to represent the content description for the icon.

<string name="cd_rewind">Rewind</string
Row(
    horizontalArrangement = Arrangement.SpaceEvenly
) {
    IconButton(
        onClick = {
            rewindTrack()
        }
    ) {
        Icon(
        	imageVector = Icons.Default.FastRewind,
                contentDescription = 
					stringResource(id = R.string.cd_rewind)
        )
    }
}

Weâ€™ll then add the second button for the play/pause toggle. Here weâ€™ll trigger the toggleNowPlayingStatethat is provided to our composable function, along with utilising the previously created functions for the playing state icon and content descriptions.

Row(
    horizontalArrangement = Arrangement.SpaceEvenly
) {
    ...
    IconButton(
        onClick = {
            toggleNowPlayingState()
        }
    ) {
        Icon(
            imageVector = iconForPlayingState(
				nowPlaying.state),
            contentDescription = stringResource(
                id = descriptionForNowPlayingState(
					nowPlaying.state))
        )
    }
}

Finally, weâ€™ll add the final button for the fast-forward operation. For this IconButton weâ€™ll trigger the fastForwardTrack lambda, along with the FastForward icon for the body of the button. Weâ€™ll also need to add a string to our resources file that will be used for the content description of the icon.

<string name="cd_fast_forward">Fast Forward</string>
Row(
    horizontalArrangement = Arrangement.SpaceEvenly
) {
    ...
    IconButton(
        onClick = {
            fastForwardTrack()
        }
    ) {
        Icon(
            imageVector = Icons.Default.FastForward,
            contentDescription = stringResource(id =
				R.string.cd_fast_forward)
        )
    }
}

With this in place, we now have the playback buttons displayed within the fullscreen playback composable.

@Composable
fun Player(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    nowPlaying: NowPlaying,
    toggleNowPlayingState: () -> Unit,
    rewindTrack: () -> Unit,
    fastForwardTrack: () -> Unit,
    onSeekChanged: (position: Float) -> Unit,
    onClose: () -> Unit
) {
    val dateFormat = remember { 
		SimpleDateFormat("mm:ss", Locale.getDefault()) 
	}
    Column(
        modifier = modifier.padding(16.dp),
        horizontalAlignment = Alignment.CenterHorizontally,
        verticalArrangement = Arrangement.Center
    ) {

        ...

        Spacer(modifier = Modifier.height(16.dp))

        Row(
            horizontalArrangement = Arrangement.SpaceEvenly
        ) {
            IconButton(
                onClick = {
                    rewindTrack()
                }
            ) {
                Icon(
                    imageVector = Icons.Default.FastRewind,
                    contentDescription = 
						stringResource(id = R.string.cd_rewind)
                )
            }
            IconButton(
                onClick = {
                    toggleNowPlayingState()
                }
            ) {
                Icon(
                    imageVector = 		
						iconForPlayingState(nowPlaying.state),
                    contentDescription = stringResource(
                        id = descriptionForNowPlayingState(
							nowPlaying.state)
                    )
                )
            }
            IconButton(
                onClick = {
                    fastForwardTrack()
                }
            ) {
                Icon(
                    imageVector = Icons.Default.FastForward,
                    contentDescription = stringResource(id = 		
						R.string.cd_fast_forward)
                )
            }
        }
    }
}

At this point, we have a fullscreen music player that can be used to show information regarding the current audio playback. We also previously created a collapsed version of this music player in the form of a bottom bar, which we will soon use to provide a way for the user to switch between the collapsed and expanded versions. To allow for this implementation, weâ€™re going to need to provide a way for the user to collapse the expanded player - which weâ€™ll do so in the form of a dismiss icon.

For this component weâ€™re going to compose an Icon, aligning it to the start of the parent container. For the icon itself, weâ€™ll use the Cancel icon for the content of the composable, along with triggering the onClose lambda within the clickable body.

Icon(
	modifier = Modifier
		.align(Alignment.Start)
       	.clickable {
			onClose() 
		},
    imageVector = Icons.Default.Cancel,
    contentDescription = null
)

To ensure this component is accessible, weâ€™ll use a click label that describes what interacting with this icon will do. Weâ€™ll start by adding a new string to the resources file of our application.

<string name="cd_close_now_playing">Minimise player</string>

We can then add this string as the onClickLabel of the clickable modifier.

val closeAction = stringResource(id = 
			R.string.cd_close_now_playing)
        Icon(
            modifier = Modifier
                .align(Alignment.Start)
                .clickable(
					onClickLabel = closeAction) { 
						onClose() 
					},
            imageVector = Icons.Default.Cancel,
            contentDescription = null
        )

Now when the component is focused by screen readers, the action of the component will be communicated. We can then compose this Icon within the Player composable, at the top of the Column.

@Composable
fun Player(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    nowPlaying: NowPlaying,
    toggleNowPlayingState: () -> Unit,
    rewindTrack: () -> Unit,
    fastForwardTrack: () -> Unit,
    onSeekChanged: (position: Float) -> Unit,
    onClose: () -> Unit
) {
    val dateFormat = remember { 
		SimpleDateFormat("mm:ss", Locale.getDefault())
	}
    Column(
        modifier = modifier.padding(16.dp),
        horizontalAlignment = 
			Alignment.CenterHorizontally,
        verticalArrangement = Arrangement.Center
    ) {
        val closeAction = stringResource(id = 
			R.string.cd_close_now_playing)
        Icon(
            modifier = Modifier
                .align(Alignment.Start)
                .clickable(
					onClickLabel = closeAction) { 
						onClose() 
					},
            imageVector = Icons.Default.Cancel,
            contentDescription = null
        )

        Spacer(modifier = Modifier.weight(1f))

        ...

        Spacer(modifier = Modifier.weight(1f))
    }
}

Switching between players

Now that we have both of the player composables implemented, weâ€™re going to want to write some logic that will conditionally compose the player based on the current state of the screen - this will decide whether the player is currently collapsed or expanded. Weâ€™re going to house this composition logic inside of a new composable function, MusicPlayer.

@Composable
fun MusicPlayer(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier
)

Within the body of this composable, weâ€™re going to start by composing the PlayerBar that we previously defined. Along with having this fill the maximum available width, weâ€™ll need to provide the NowPlaying reference from our MusicDashboardState, along with implementing the toggleNowPlayingState lambda for which weâ€™ll trigger the ToggleNowPlayingState event. Youâ€™ll notice that to implement these requirements weâ€™ve added two arguments to the composable function in the form of a MusicDashboardState reference and lambda to handle any MusicCatalogEvent triggers.

@Composable
fun MusicPlayer(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    state: MusicDashboardState,
    handleEvent: (event: MusicCatalogEvent) -> Unit
) {
    PlayerBar(
		modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
        nowPlaying = state.nowPlaying,
        toggleNowPlayingState = {
        	handleEvent(
				MusicCatalogEvent.ToggleNowPlayingState)
        }
    )
}

When the PlayerBar is clicked, weâ€™re going to want to trigger the conceal action on the parent composable, which is the BackdropScaffold. Here weâ€™ll start by modifying the function arguments so that a BackdropScaffoldState reference is being provided to our composable. With this in place, we can now utilise the clickable modifier to trigger the conceal function from this state reference. This function is a suspending function, so itâ€™ll need to be launched from a coroutine - this doesnâ€™t add too much overhead for us though as we can utilise the rememberCoroutineScope function to create a CoroutineScope that can be used to launch this suspending function. As per the documentation, this function will:

Return a CoroutineScope bound to this point in the composition using the optional CoroutineContext provided by getContext.

@Composable
fun MusicPlayer(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    scaffoldState: BackdropScaffoldState,
    state: MusicDashboardState,
    handleEvent: (event: MusicCatalogEvent) -> Unit
) {
    val coroutineScope = rememberCoroutineScope()
    PlayerBar(
		modifier = Modifier
 			.fillMaxWidth()
            .clickable {
            	coroutineScope.launch {
                	scaffoldState.conceal()
                }
            },
        nowPlaying = state.nowPlaying,
        toggleNowPlayingState = {
        	handleEvent(
				MusicCatalogEvent.ToggleNowPlayingState)
        }
    )
}

Weâ€™re going to make one small tweak here to improve the clickable action on our composable and make it more accessible, which weâ€™ll do by adding an onClickLabel to the clickable modifier. Weâ€™ll start by adding a new string resource that will be used to describe the action of the click event.

<string name="action_show_player">Show Player</string>

Followed by assigning this message to the onClickLabel argument of the clickable modifier.

@Composable
fun MusicPlayer(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    scaffoldState: BackdropScaffoldState,
    state: MusicDashboardState,
    handleEvent: (event: MusicCatalogEvent) -> Unit
) {
    val coroutineScope = rememberCoroutineScope()
	val onClickLabel = stringResource(id = R.string.action_show_player)
    PlayerBar(
		modifier = Modifier
 			.fillMaxWidth()
            .clickable(
				onClickLabel = onClickLabel
            ) {
            	coroutineScope.launch {
                	scaffoldState.conceal()
                }
            },
        nowPlaying = state.nowPlaying,
        toggleNowPlayingState = {
        	handleEvent(
				MusicCatalogEvent.ToggleNowPlayingState)
        }
    )
}

While the PlayerBar is now being composed, weâ€™re going to add the use of a Divider composable to create some visual separation between the composable content and the space outside of it. Weâ€™ll style the color of this divider using a modified version of the onSurface theme color - weâ€™ll modify this by copying the value of the color and overriding the alpha value that is used for it. This will help to ensure that our divider remains within the theming of our application, while also adapting the color to our requirements.

Because weâ€™re adding another child that is coupled to our PlayerBar, weâ€™re going to need to use a nested parent container to link these two composables together. For this we can simply wrap the two composables in a Column, ensuring that they are vertically stacked.

@Composable
fun MusicPlayer(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    scaffoldState: BackdropScaffoldState,
    state: MusicDashboardState,
    handleEvent: (event: MusicCatalogEvent) -> Unit
) {
    Column {
        Divider(
            modifier = Modifier.height(2.dp),
            color = MaterialTheme.colors
				.onSurface.copy(alpha = 0.4f)
        )
		val coroutineScope = rememberCoroutineScope()
        val onClickLabel = stringResource(
			id = R.string.action_show_player)
        PlayerBar(
            modifier = Modifier
                .fillMaxWidth()
                .clickable(
                    onClickLabel = onClickLabel
                ) {
                    coroutineScope.launch {
                        scaffoldState.conceal()
                    }
                },
            nowPlaying = state.nowPlaying,
            toggleNowPlayingState = {
                handleEvent(MusicCatalogEvent
					.ToggleNowPlayingState)
            }
        )
    }
}

Next, weâ€™re going to compose the Player which we previously defined, which is the full-screen music player. When there is a NowPlaying reference available in our state, weâ€™ll compose this Player - to do so though weâ€™ll need to implement all of its required arguments. For most of these, we can trigger the corresponding MusicCatalogEvent references. For the onClose implementation weâ€™ll simply want to pull out our coroutineScope reference that we defined for the PlayerBar composable, using this to trigger the reveal function on the BackdropScaffoldState reference that is provided to our MusicPlayer.

@Composable
fun MusicPlayer(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    scaffoldState: BackdropScaffoldState,
    state: MusicDashboardState,
    handleEvent: (event: MusicCatalogEvent) -> Unit
) {
    val coroutineScope = rememberCoroutineScope()
    state.nowPlaying?.let { nowPlaying ->
        Player(
            modifier = Modifier.fillMaxSize(),
            nowPlaying = nowPlaying,
            rewindTrack = {
                handleEvent(
					MusicCatalogEvent.RewindNowPlaying)
            },
            fastForwardTrack = {
            	handleEvent(
					MusicCatalogEvent
						.FastForwardNowPlaying)
            },
            onSeekChanged = {
                handleEvent
					MusicCatalogEvent.SeekTrack(it))
            },
            toggleNowPlayingState = {
                handleEvent(
					MusicCatalogEvent
						.ToggleNowPlayingState)
            },
            onClose = {
                coroutineScope.launch {
                    scaffoldState.reveal()
                }
            }
        )
    }
    Column {
        ...
    }
}

As things currently are, both of these composables are going to be composed on-screen. What weâ€™ll need to do now is add some conditional logic so that only a single one of these is displayed at any given time. During this process, we can also go a step further here and improve the transition that occurs between the two composables. For this we can utilise the AnimatedVisibility composable, this will allow us to show and hide composables in an animated fashion. Here weâ€™re going to use an AnimatedVisibility composable for each of the players, setting their visibility state based on the current state of the provided BackdropScaffoldState. If the state is currently represented as the Concealed value, then weâ€™ll want to display the Player composable, which is our fullscreen player. On the other hand, if the state is represented as Revealed then weâ€™ll want to display the player bottom bar.

@Composable
fun MusicPlayer(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    scaffoldState: BackdropScaffoldState,
    state: MusicDashboardState,
    handleEvent: (event: MusicCatalogEvent) -> Unit
) {
    val coroutineScope = rememberCoroutineScope()
    AnimatedVisibility(
        modifier = modifier,
        visible = scaffoldState.targetValue == 
			BackdropValue.Concealed,
        enter = fadeIn(),
        exit = fadeOut()
    ) {
        state.nowPlaying?.let { nowPlaying ->
            ...
        }
    }
    AnimatedVisibility(
        modifier = Modifier.wrapContentHeight(),
        visible = scaffoldState.targetValue == 
			BackdropValue.Revealed,
        enter = fadeIn(),
        exit = fadeOut(animationSpec = snap())
    ) {
        Column {
            ...
        }
    }
}

Finally, weâ€™ll want to compose this within our BackdropScaffold. Weâ€™ll provide this MusicPlayer as part of the frontLayerContent content, passing in each of the required arguments during its composition.

@Composable
fun Dashboard(
    state: MusicDashboardState,
    handleEvent: (contentEvent: MusicCatalogEvent) -> Unit
) {
    val scaffoldState = rememberBackdropScaffoldState(
        initialValue = BackdropValue.Revealed
    )

    BackdropScaffold(
        scaffoldState = scaffoldState,
        appBar = {
            SearchBar(
                modifier = Modifier
                    .fillMaxWidth(),
                query = state.searchTerm,
                handleQuery = {
                    handleEvent(MusicCatalogEvent.Search(it))
                },
                clearQuery = {
                    handleEvent(
						MusicCatalogEvent.ClearSearchQuery)
                }
            )
        },
        backLayerContent = {
            TracksDashboard(
                modifier = Modifier
                    .fillMaxSize()
                    .testTag(Tags.TAG_DASHBOARD),
                state = state,
                onTrackClicked = { track ->
                    handleEvent(
						MusicCatalogEvent.PlayTrack(track))
                }
            )
        },
        frontLayerContent = {
            MusicPlayer(
                modifier = Modifier.fillMaxSize(),
                scaffoldState = scaffoldState,
                state = state,
                handleEvent = handleEvent
            )
        }
    )
}

With this in place, we now have the music player composed within our UI, allowing the user to switch between both the collapsed and full-screen player formats. Now that the components of our Ui are now in place, weâ€™re going to need to make a few adjustments so that things are displayed correctly. Weâ€™ll do this by providing some values for the arguments of our BackdropScaffold.

headerHeight - this is the height of the front layer content, which in our case is the collapsed player, the PlayerBar. Weâ€™ll need this to be a specific height, otherwise, the content of the bar will not be displayed - so weâ€™ll set this to 65dp.

peekHeight - this is the height of the visible part of the back layer when concealed. We donâ€™t want the back layer visible when the full-screen player is shown, so weâ€™ll set this as 0dp

gesturesEnabled - weâ€™ve added click listeners to the player bar so that the full-screen player can be displayed, as well as the close action within the full-screen player to dismiss this from view. So that our UI behaves as expected, weâ€™re going to disable gestures on the BackdropScaffold using this argument.

frontLayerShape - by default a rounded rectangle shoe will be used for the front layer content. We want to use a solid rectangle shape for this container, so weâ€™ll override this default styling using the RectangleShape value.

frontLayerScrimColor - by default, a color is applied to the scrim of the front layer. When this color is set, interaction with the front layer is blocked while the back layer is revealed. To prevent this behaviour weâ€™re going to pass the Color.Unspecified value, allowing the click events on the PlayerBar to be detected, allowing the user to reveal/collapse the player components.

BackdropScaffold(
	headerHeight = 65.dp,
	peekHeight = 0.dp,
	gesturesEnabled = false,
    backLayerBackgroundColor = 
		MaterialTheme.colors.surface,
    scaffoldState = scaffoldState,
    frontLayerShape = RectangleShape,
    appBar = {
        ...
    },
    backLayerContent = {
        ...
    },
    frontLayerContent = {
        ...
    },
    frontLayerScrimColor = Color.Unspecified
)

Loading initial data

When the music dashboard feature is launched, weâ€™re going to want to trigger an initial load of data so that the catalogue is populated. Weâ€™re going to want to load this data during the initial composition of our UI, so weâ€™ll use the LaunchedEffect side-effect - this is a block of code that will only be run based on the key that is provided to it (so if the key changes, the block will be re-run). In our case we can simply provide a Unit as the key, meaning that the block will only be run on the initial composition. Within this we can trigger the RefreshContent event, meaning that on the initial composition of our UI the music catalogue data will be loaded.

@Composable
fun Dashboard(
    state: MusicDashboardState,
    handleEvent: (contentEvent: MusicCatalogEvent) -> Unit
) {
    val scaffoldState = rememberBackdropScaffoldState(
        initialValue = BackdropValue.Revealed
    )

    LaunchedEffect(Unit) {
        handleEvent(MusicCatalogEvent.RefreshContent)
    }

    BackdropScaffold(
        ...
    )
}

With this project complete, we now have a dashboard that is used to display a catalogue of available music, allowing the user to search for and select tracks to be displayed - along with viewing playback information.

@Composable
fun Dashboard(
    state: MusicDashboardState,
    handleEvent: (contentEvent: MusicCatalogEvent) -> Unit
) {
    val scaffoldState = rememberBackdropScaffoldState(
        initialValue = BackdropValue.Revealed
    )

	LaunchedEffect(Unit) {
        handleEvent(MusicCatalogEvent.RefreshContent)
    }

    BackdropScaffold(
        peekHeight = 0.dp,
        headerHeight = 65.dp,
        gesturesEnabled = false,
        backLayerBackgroundColor = 
			MaterialTheme.colors.surface,
        scaffoldState = scaffoldState,
        frontLayerShape = RectangleShape,
        appBar = {
            SearchBar(
                modifier = Modifier
                    .fillMaxWidth(),
                query = state.searchTerm,
                handleQuery = {
                    handleEvent(MusicCatalogEvent.Search(it))
                },
                clearQuery = {
                    handleEvent(
						MusicCatalogEvent.ClearSearchQuery)
                }
            )
        },
        backLayerContent = {
            TracksDashboard(
                modifier = Modifier
                    .fillMaxSize()
                    .testTag(Tags.TAG_DASHBOARD),
                state = state,
                onTrackClicked = { track ->
                    handleEvent(
						MusicCatalogEvent.PlayTrack(track))
                }
            )
        },
        frontLayerContent = {
            MusicPlayer(
                modifier = Modifier.fillMaxSize(),
                scaffoldState = scaffoldState,
                state = state,
                handleEvent = handleEvent
            )
        },
        frontLayerScrimColor = Color.Unspecified
    )
}

Wrapping Up

Throughout this project, weâ€™ve now fully implemented our music dashboard feature - allowing our users to view the catalogue of tracks, select a track to play, view playback information, as well as search for tracks to be played. Weâ€™ve explored the composition of many different UI components, along with how to handle nested scrolling for different layouts inside a list of items.

With all of this in place, weâ€™ll want to ensure these components remain functional within our app. In the next chapter, weâ€™re going to explore writing automated UI tests for these composables.

Testing the Music Dashboard UI

Now that weâ€™ve built our Music Dashboard feature, weâ€™re going to take a look at how we can write tests for our composables. Weâ€™re going to be writing some instrumentation tests using the compose ui-test-junit package - allowing us to verify that our composables are displayed and functioning as expected.

Before we can get started with our tests, weâ€™re going to need to add a couple of test specific dependencies to our project:

androidTestImplementation(
	"androidx.compose.ui:ui-test-junit4:$compose_version")
debugImplementation(
	"androidx.compose.ui:ui-test-manifest:$compose_version")

Weâ€™re also going to need to add mocks to our test - this allows us to easily provide mock references to any listeners that are provided to our composable functions, allowing us to easily verify they are triggered whenever expected.

androidTestImplementation(
	"org.mockito.kotlin:mockito-kotlin:3.2.0")
androidTestImplementation("org.mockito:mockito-android:4.5.1")

With these in place, we now have access to the required rules and functionality that allow us to test our composable UI. However, alongside these dependencies, weâ€™re also going to need to add some rules to our build.gradle file that will fix some of the compilation errors that weâ€™d currently see when trying to run our tests. Here weâ€™ll add some packagingOptions that will exclude certain packages from the added dependencies. We wonâ€™t dive too much into this concept and itâ€™s usually dependent on the versions of dependencies that are being used, so this may be redundant if you come to updating versions.

android {
	packagingOptions {
		resources {
            excludes += '/META-INF/{AL2.0,LGPL2.1}'
            excludes += "**/attach_hotspot_windows.dll"
            excludes += "META-INF/licenses/ASM"
        }
	}
}

Creating a Test Data Factory

Before we start writing our tests, weâ€™re going to define some functions that will provide data for us to use during our tests. Throughout our tests, weâ€™re going to need to create instances of the various music classes that contain test data. Weâ€™ll create a randomString function that allows us to generate a random string for use in tests (such as message content), along with some functions that allow us to create instances of the NowPlaying and Track classes that contain mock data for use in our tests. Having this factory allows us to simplify the use of test data in our tests, without needing to duplicate this logic throughout our project.

// TestDataFactory.kt

object TestDataFactory {

    fun randomString() = UUID.randomUUID().toString().substring(0, 10)

    fun makeNowPlaying(
        track: Track = makeTrack(),
        state: NowPlayingState = NowPlayingState.PAUSED,
        progress: Long = track.length / 3
    ): NowPlaying {
        return NowPlaying(
            track,
            progress,
            state
        )
    }

    fun makeTrack(
        isFeatured: Boolean = Math.random() < 0.5,
        isNew: Boolean = Math.random() < 0.5
    ): Track {
        return Track(
            randomString(),
            randomString(),
            randomString(),
            Color.Red,
            length = nextLong(500),
            isFeatured = isFeatured,
            isNew = isNew
        )
    }

    fun makeContentList(count: Int): List<Track> {
        return (0..count).map { makeTrack() }
    }

    fun makeMixedContentList(): List<Track> {
        return listOf(
            makeTrack(false, false),
            makeTrack(true, true),
            makeTrack(true, false),
            makeTrack(false, true),
            makeTrack(true, true),
            makeTrack(false, false),
            makeTrack(false, true),
            makeTrack(true, false)
        )
    }
}

Testing the Dashboard

At a high level of our feature is the Dashboard composable. While we have a collection of focused composables that are responsible for specific parts of our UI, this composable acts as the parent container - composing each of the child composables that make up the different parts of the messaging feature. For this reason, weâ€™re going to write a collection of tests that will perform asserts to ensure the correct composables are displayed as expected. Weâ€™ll start here by creating a new test class, DashboardTest.

class DashboardTest {

}

Inside of this class, we now need to define a reference to the ComposeContentTestRule class - this is what weâ€™re going to use to set the composable content on screen, allowing us to perform interactions and assertions from within our tests. 

@get:Rule
val composeTestRule = createComposeRule()

When using this rule, we donâ€™t need to specify any form of activity for our composables to be launched, the test rule will handle that for us. So using this rule we will set the composable content to be composed, the test will then launch a host activity which will be used to compose our provided content inside.

With this test class configured, weâ€™re going to write some tests to assert that each of the expected composables is being displayed when required - which will be based on the state which is provided to the Dashboard composable. Weâ€™ll start here by asserting that the header is being composed - the header should always be composed within the messaging screen, so we donâ€™t need to worry about passing any specific state to it.

Testing the display of Content

To write this first test weâ€™ll use the @Test annotation and create a new function to test that the header is displayed by default within our UI.

@Test
fun Content_Area_Displayed() {

}

Inside of this test, weâ€™re going to need to start by setting the composable content that is to be displayed on the screen for us to perform assertions against. Here weâ€™ll use the test rule that we previously defined, along with its setContent function. This function takes a composable function as an argument, allowing us to define what is to be composed on screen for our tests. Because weâ€™re wanting to test the Dashboard Composable that we defined in the previous sections of this chapter, weâ€™ll go ahead and pass the Dashboard composable function for this composable argument. When composing the Dashboard weâ€™ll need to provide a reference to a MusicDashboardState, along with an implementation of the handleEvent lambda - this will be blank as we donâ€™t need to use this callback within our test.

@Test
fun Content_Area_Displayed() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        Dashboard(
            state = MusicDashboardState(),
            handleEvent = { }
        )
    }

}

So that we can locate the header within our test, weâ€™re going to need to add a tag to the composable that we wish to perform assertions against - this tag can then be used to locate our composable within our tests. Weâ€™ll need to start here by defining a tag reference that can be accessed from both our tests and our composable.

object Tags {
	const val TAG_DASHBOARD = "TAG_DASHBOARD"
}

With this tag defined, weâ€™ll then need to add this to our Dashboard composable. Weâ€™ll assign this to the top-level composable within the function, using the testTag modifier to do so.

BackdropScaffold(
    modifier = Modifier.testTag(Tags.TAG_DASHBOARD),
	...
)

Next, weâ€™re going to locate the node within our composable hierarchy so that we can perform interactions and assertions on it. Here weâ€™ll utilise the onNodeWithTag function, providing the tag that we defined above. We can then utilise the assertIsDisplayed function to assert that the composable is being displayed as expected within the Dashboard.

@Test
fun Content_Area_Displayed() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        Dashboard(
            state = MusicDashboardState(),
            handleEvent = { }
        )
    }

    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(TAG_DASHBOARD)
        .assertIsDisplayed()
}

Testing the Search Bar display

Weâ€™re next going to test that the search bar is displayed at the top of the Dashboard composable. So that we can do this, weâ€™ll again need to add a new tag to our Tags file.

object Tags {
	...
	const val TAG_SEARCH_BAR = "TAG_SEARCH_BAR"
}

Within the Dashboard composable weâ€™ll next use the testTag function to assign the TAG_SEARCH_BAR tag to the SearchBar composable.

SearchBar(
	modifier = Modifier
		.fillMaxWidth()
		.testTag(TAG_SEARCH_BAR),
    ...
)

With this tag in place, we can now use it to locate the node within our composable, followed by asserting that the composable is being displayed as expected.

@Test
fun Search_Bar_Displayed() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        Dashboard(
            state = MusicDashboardState(),
            handleEvent = { }
        )
    }

    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(TAG_SEARCH_BAR)
        .assertIsDisplayed()
}

Testing the Player display

Within the dashboard, the user can interact with the player bar to display a fullscreen music player. Weâ€™re going to want to test this functionality so that we can ensure the player is being displayed and hidden as expected, so weâ€™ll start by defining two new tags - one for the player bar (the collapsed version of the player) and another for the fullscreen player.

// Tags.kt

object Tags {
	...
	const val TAG_PLAYER_BAR = "TAG_PLAYER_BAR"
    const val TAG_PLAYER = "TAG_PLAYER"
}

Weâ€™ll then need to hop into the MusicPlayer composable and assign these tags to the corresponding composables.

// MusicPlayer.kt

Player(
	modifier = Modifier
		.fillMaxSize()
		.testTag(TAG_PLAYER)
)


PlayerBar(
	modifier = Modifier
		.fillMaxWidth()
		.clickable(
			onClickLabel = onClickLabel
        ) {
			coroutineScope.launch {
				scaffoldState.conceal()
            }
		}
		.testTag(TAG_PLAYER_BAR)
)

With these tags in place, we can now start with the first test for this functionality, here weâ€™re going to assert that the fullscreen player is revealed as expected. So that the player bar is displayed, weâ€™ll need to use our test data factory to assign some data to the nowPlaying property within our MusicDashboardState.

@Test
fun Full_Screen_Player_Revealed() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        Dashboard(
            state = MusicDashboardState(
                nowPlaying = TestDataFactory.makeNowPlaying()
            ),
            handleEvent = { }
        )
    }
}

Next, weâ€™ll want to locate the player bar using the TAG_PLAYER_BAR tag, followed by using the TAG_PLAYER to assert that the fullscreen player is displayed after the player bar has been clicked.

@Test
fun Full_Screen_Player_Revealed() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        Dashboard(
            state = MusicDashboardState(
                nowPlaying = TestDataFactory.makeNowPlaying()
            ),
            handleEvent = { }
        )
    }

    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(TAG_PLAYER_BAR)
        .performClick()

    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(TAG_PLAYER)
        .assertIsDisplayed()
}

Now that weâ€™ve asserted that the fullscreen player is being displayed as expected, weâ€™re next going to want to assert that the fullscreen player is collapsed when the dismiss icon is clicked. So that we can interact with the dismiss icon within our tests, weâ€™ll need to add a new tag.

// Tags.kt

object Tags {
	...
	const val TAG_DISMISS_PLAYER = "TAG_DISMISS_PLAYER"
}

Weâ€™ll then want to assign this tag to the dismiss Icon within the fullscreen player.

// Player.kt

Icon(
	modifier = Modifier
        .align(Alignment.Start)
        .clickable(onClickLabel = closeAction) { onClose() }
        .testTag(TAG_DISMISS_PLAYER),
	...
)

Weâ€™ll then start by creating a new test, Player_Dismissed_Hides_Player, that will start by taking the same form as our previous test - composing the dashboard in a playing state and launching the fullscreen player by clicking on the player bar.

@Test
fun Player_Dismissed_Hides_Player() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        Dashboard(
            state = MusicDashboardState(
                nowPlaying = TestDataFactory.makeNowPlaying()
            ),
            handleEvent = { }
        )
    }

    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(TAG_PLAYER_BAR)
        .performClick()
}

Next, weâ€™ll use the TAG_DISMISS_PLAYER tag to locate the node for the dismiss icon, performing a click action to collapse the player. To assert that the player has collapsed, weâ€™ll use the TAG_PLAYER tag to an asset that the fullscreen player no longer exists via the use of the assertDoesNotExist assertion.

@Test
fun Player_Dismissed_Hides_Player() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        Dashboard(
            state = MusicDashboardState(
                nowPlaying = TestDataFactory.makeNowPlaying()
            ),
            handleEvent = { }
        )
    }

    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(TAG_PLAYER_BAR)
        .performClick()

    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(
        TAG_DISMISS_PLAYER
    ).performClick()

    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(TAG_PLAYER)
        .assertDoesNotExist()
}

Weâ€™ll also want to assert that when the fullscreen player has been dismissed, the collapsed player bar is displayed onscreen. Weâ€™ll create a new test, Player_Dismissed_Shows_Player_Bar, that will perform the same operations as the previous test - but instead of asserting that the TAG_PLAYER node does not exist, weâ€™ll now assert that the collapsed player bar is displayed on the screen (via the use of the TAG_PLAYER_BAR tag).

@Test
fun Player_Dismissed_Shows_Player_Bar() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        Dashboard(
            state = MusicDashboardState(
                nowPlaying = TestDataFactory.makeNowPlaying()
            ),
            handleEvent = { }
        )
    }

    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(TAG_PLAYER_BAR)
        .performClick()

    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(TAG_DISMISS_PLAYER)
        .performClick()

    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(TAG_PLAYER_BAR)
        .assertIsDisplayed()
}

At this point, we now have a collection of tests that perform assertions to ensure that the dashboard displays the expected states - both in the initial load state of the composable, as well as when there are interactions performed with the player components.

Tracks Dashboard

Now that we have the dashboard being tested, weâ€™re going to jump a step into the Dashboard composable and write some tests for the back layer content, the TracksDashboard. These tests will be contained in a new test class, TracksDashboardTest.

class TracksDashboardTest {

    @get:Rule
    val composeTestRule = createComposeRule()

}

Testing the Track feeds display

Within the TracksDashboard there can be two main states - either the tracks are displayed, or the search results for the current query in the Dashboard. Weâ€™ll start by writing a test to assert that the expected track feeds are displayed by default when there are no search results present in the state. Weâ€™ll need to start here by adding a new tag, TAG_TRACKS_DASHBOARD.

object Tags {
	...
    const val TAG_TRACKS_DASHBOARD = "TAG_TRACKS_DASHBOARD"
}

This tag can then be assigned to the tracks feed within the TracksDashboard composable.

// TracksDashboard.kt

LazyColumn(
	modifier = modifier.testTag(TAG_TRACKS_DASHBOARD),
	contentPadding = PaddingValues(top = 12.dp, bottom = 8.dp)
)

Within the test, we can compose the TracksDashboard and then use the TAG_TRACKS_DASHBOARD tag to locate the node representing the tracks feed, followed by using the assertIsDisplayed to assert that it is being displayed.

@Test
fun Content_Area_Displayed() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        TracksDashboard(
            state = MusicDashboardState(),
            onTrackClicked = {}
        )
    }

    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(TAG_TRACKS_DASHBOARD)
        .assertIsDisplayed()
}

Testing the Recently Played Tracks display

Within the TracksDashboard there are 3 different types of track feeds displayed. Weâ€™re going to want to write tests for each, but weâ€™ll start with the Recently Played tracks. Weâ€™ll first test that the title for the recently played tracks is being displayed as expected in a new test, Recently_Played_Tracks_Header_Displayed. Within this, weâ€™re going to need to start by composing the TracksDashboard, providing a MusicDashboardState that contains a collection of tracks to be composed.

@Test
fun Recently_Played_Tracks_Header_Displayed() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        TracksDashboard(
            state = MusicDashboardState(
            	tracks = TestDataFactory.makeMixedContentList()
         	),
        	onTrackClicked = {}
    	)
    }
}

Next, weâ€™re going to need to assert that the expected node contains the title for the recently played tracks. This part of the tracks feed contains multiple children, so weâ€™re going to need to perform assertions against a specific child within the content list. We can retrieve the child of a node using the onChildAt function - within the tracks dashboard the recently played tracks title is at the 4th position in the list, so we can retrieve this directly from the node tagged using TAG_TRACKS_DASHBOARD.

@Test
fun Recently_Played_Tracks_Header_Displayed() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        TracksDashboard(
            state = MusicDashboardState(
            	tracks = TestDataFactory.makeMixedContentList()
         	),
        	onTrackClicked = {}
    	)
    }

    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(TAG_TRACKS_DASHBOARD)
        .onChildAt(4)
}

Now that weâ€™ve located this node, we can assert that the text of this child is the expected text from the heading_recently_played resource. We expect the child at the 4th position in the list to represent the recently played title, so if this string resource matches the textual content of that child then the test will succeed.

@Test
fun Recently_Played_Tracks_Header_Displayed() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        TracksDashboard(
            state = MusicDashboardState(
            	tracks = TestDataFactory.makeMixedContentList()
         	),
        	onTrackClicked = {}
    	)
    }

    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(TAG_TRACKS_DASHBOARD)
        .onChildAt(4)
        .assertTextEquals(
            InstrumentationRegistry.getInstrumentation()
				.targetContext.getString(
					R.string.heading_recently_played))
}

With this in place, we can now confirm that the Recently Played title is being displayed at the correct position, so now we need to test that the track items themselves are being shown. For this, weâ€™ll create a new test called Recently_Played_Tracks_Displayed. Within this test, weâ€™ll need to start by configuring the composable to display a list of tracks

@Test
fun Recently_Played_Tracks_Displayed() {
    val tracks = TestDataFactory.makeMixedContentList()
    val state = MusicDashboardState(
        tracks = tracks
    )
    val recentTracks = state.recentTracks()
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        TracksDashboard(
            state = state,
            onTrackClicked = {}
        )
    }
}

Next, weâ€™ll want to loop through these tracks and assert that theyâ€™re being displayed. Using the TAG_DASHBOARD node to perform these assertions against, weâ€™ll again use the onChildAt function to iterate through the nodes that should reflect the recently played tracks.

To be able to assert the expected tracks are displayed, weâ€™ll want to provide a testTag to the Track composable within the recently played tracks. Weâ€™ll need to start by adding a new tag to our Tags.kt file in the form of TAG_TRACK - we include an _ as a suffix so that we can append the id of the track onto the tag.

object Tags {
	const val TAG_TRACK = "TAG_TRACK_"
}

With this tag in place, we can now assign it to our Track composable. Here weâ€™ll use this TAG_TRACK and append the id of the current message onto it.

// RecentTracks.kt

Track(
    modifier = Modifier
		...
        .testTag(TAG_TRACK + it.id),
    track = it
)

Starting from the index of 5 (which is one after the title at index 4), weâ€™ll assert that the node at the current position has the tag that matches the expected track ID. Because weâ€™re working in a scrolling list, weâ€™ll need to utilise the performScrollTo function so that the item in the list is scrolled to and composed on screen, otherwise our test will not be able to locate composables past an index that is off-screen. When running this test, each of the provided recent tracks will be looped through, performing the assertion that each is being composed as an item within the content list.

@Test
fun Recently_Played_Tracks_Displayed() {
    val tracks = TestDataFactory.makeMixedContentList()
    val state = MusicDashboardState(
        tracks = tracks
    )
    val recentTracks = state.recentTracks()
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        TracksDashboard(
            state = state,
            onTrackClicked = {}
        )
    }

    recentTracks!!.forEachIndexed { index, track ->
        composeTestRule
            .onNodeWithTag(TAG_DASHBOARD)
            .onChildAt(5 + index)
            .performScrollTo()
            .assert(hasTestTag(TAG_TRACK + track.id))
    }
}

Aside from the content being displayed, weâ€™ll also want to assert that the track listener provided to the composable function is being triggered on a click event. For the next test weâ€™ll again compose the TracksDashboard but this time weâ€™ll pass a mock implementation of the onTrackClicked lambda - this is so that we can verify this is involved when the composable is interacted with.

Weâ€™ll again use the onChildAt function to locate a node at a given position, followed by utilising the performClick function to invoke a click event on the located node. When this click event occurs we would expect the onTrackClicked lambda to be invoked - so at this point we want to verify that this is the case by utilising the mockito verify function. This allows us to assert that the lambda is triggered as expected when the node is clicked. Because we are interacting with the node at the fifth position in the parent, this represents the first track in the featured tracks collection - therefore we expect the lambda to be involved with this track reference.

@Test
fun Clicking_Recently_Played_Track_Plays_Selected_Track() {
    val content = TestDataFactory.makeMixedContentList()
    val state = MusicDashboardState(
        tracks = content
    )
    val trackToSelect = state.recentTracks().first()
    val trackListener: (track: Track) -> Unit = mock()
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        TracksDashboard(
            state = state,
            onTrackClicked = trackListener
        )
    }

    composeTestRule
        .onNodeWithTag(TAG_DASHBOARD)
        .onChildAt(5)
        .performClick()

    verify(trackListener).invoke(trackToSelect)
}

In the supporting code for this course, youâ€™ll also find the tests that cover the cases above for the New and Recent tracks, as well as the Search Results. We wonâ€™t cover these tests here as the code is almost identical to what weâ€™ve covered above.

Featured Tracks

Now that weâ€™ve covered the higher-level testing of the dashboard composables, we can start to dive into the more fine-grained composable functions - weâ€™ll start here with the Featured Track related composables.

Testing the Title display

The FeaturedTrack composable is used to display Featured Tracks in a content feed, so weâ€™ll want to assert that this content is being composed correctly. The FeaturedTrack consists of a title which is taken from the provided track reference. For this, weâ€™ll create a simple test class that composes the FeaturedTrack, followed by asserting that a node is being displayed that contains the title for the composed track.

class FeaturedTrackTest {

    @get:Rule
    val composeTestRule = createComposeRule()

    @Test
    fun Title_Displayed() {
        val track = TestDataFactory.makeTrack()
        composeTestRule.setContent {
            FeaturedTrack(track = track)
        }
        composeTestRule.onNodeWithText(
            track.title
        ).assertIsDisplayed()
    }

}

Alongside testing the FeaturedTrack, weâ€™re also going to want to write tests for the grid that is used to display the featured tracks - weâ€™ll contain these tests in a new test class, FeaturedTracksGridTest.

class FeaturedTracksGridTest {

    @get:Rule
    val composeTestRule = createComposeRule()


}

For the first test, weâ€™re going to assert that the featured tracks are not displayed when an empty list is provided to the composable function. Weâ€™ll start here by composing the FeaturedTracksGrid, providing an empty list for the tracks argument.

@Test
fun Featured_Tracks_Not_Displayed_When_Empty() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        FeaturedTracksGrid(
			tracks = emptyList(), 
			onTrackClicked = {}
		)
    }
}

Before we can perform assertions, weâ€™ll need to add a new tag for locating the featured tracks node.

object Tags {
	const val TAG_FEATURED_TRACKS = "TAG_FEATURED_TRACKS"
}

Within the FeaturedTracksGridFeaturedTracksGrid we can then assign this to the composable that is displaying the grid of tracks.

// FeaturedTracksGrid.kt

FlowRow(
    modifier = modifier
        .testTag(TAG_FEATURED_TRACKS),
    ...
)

With this in place, we can now locate this node within our tests, followed by using the assertDoesNotExist function to assert that the composable does not exist when there are no tracks provided.

@Test
fun Featured_Tracks_Not_Displayed_When_Null() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        FeaturedTracksGrid(
			tracks = emptyList(), 
			onTrackClicked = {}
		)
    }
    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(
        TAG_FEATURED_TRACKS
    ).assertDoesNotExist()
}

On a similar note, the tracks argument is a nullable type - so we can write a similar test to assert that the featured tracks grid is not composed when a null value is passed for the tracks argument.

@Test
fun Featured_Tracks_Not_Displayed_When_Null() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        FeaturedTracksGrid(tracks = null, onTrackClicked = {})
    }
    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(
        TAG_FEATURED_TRACKS
    ).assertDoesNotExist()
}

Now that we have covered these empty states, the most important state of our featured tracks is where itâ€™s displaying the tracks. To perform assertions that the tracks are being displayed as expected, weâ€™ll start by creating a new test, Featured_Tracks_Displayed. Here weâ€™ll compose the FeaturedTracksGrid, passing a collection of tracks generated using our test data factory.

@Test
fun Featured_Tracks_Displayed() {
    val tracks = TestDataFactory.makeContentList(5)

    composeTestRule.setContent {
        FeaturedTracksGrid(
			tracks = tracks, 
			onTrackClicked = {}
		)
    }
}

Using the TAG_TRACK tag that we defined for a previous test, weâ€™ll now assign this to the FeaturedTrack being composed within the FeaturedTracksGrid, using the id of the track being composed.

// FeaturedTracksGrid.kt

FeaturedTrack(
	modifier = Modifier
		...
        .testTag(TAG_TRACK + track.id),
    track = track
)

With this tag in place, we can now locate the tracks inside of the grid. Using the TAG_FEATURED_TRACKS tag to locate the node representing the grid, weâ€™ll assert that the child at the current position in our tracks list correctly represents the expected tag using TAG_TRACK.

@Test
fun Featured_Tracks_Displayed() {
    ...

    tracks.forEachIndexed { rowIndex, track ->
        composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(TAG_FEATURED_TRACKS)
            .onChildAt(rowIndex)
            .assert(hasTestTag(TAG_TRACK + track.id))
    }
}

With this test in place, we can now assert that the featured tracks are being composed as expected in the grid of items.

New Tracks

Similar to the testing of the composables for the Recent Tracks, weâ€™re going to want to perform similar assertions against the composables used to represent the New Tracks within the music dashboard.

Testing the New Track composable

Weâ€™ll start here by writing some tests for the NewTrack composable - similar to the RecentTrack composable, this simply shows some textual information for the provided track. Weâ€™ll write two separate tests here - one to test the display of the track title and another to assert the artist is displayed as expected.

class NewTrackTest {

    @get:Rule
    val composeTestRule = createComposeRule()

    @Test
    fun Title_Displayed() {
        val track = TestDataFactory.makeTrack()
        composeTestRule.setContent {
            NewTrack(track = track)
        }
        composeTestRule.onNodeWithText(
            track.title
        ).assertIsDisplayed()
    }

    @Test
    fun Artist_Displayed() {
        val track = TestDataFactory.makeTrack()
        composeTestRule.setContent {
            NewTrack(track = track)
        }
        composeTestRule.onNodeWithText(
            track.artist
        ).assertIsDisplayed()
    }
}

Testing the New Tracks Row

Now that we have tests in place for the individual NewTrack composable, we can look at putting some tests together for the row used to display the collection of new track references. Weâ€™ll start here by creating a new test class to hold these tests, NewTracksRowTest.

class NewTracksRowTest {

    @get:Rule
    val composeTestRule = createComposeRule()

}

Before we start writing tests inside of this class, weâ€™ll need to be able to locate the New Track container using a tag. Weâ€™ll start by adding a new tag to our Tags object.

object Tags {
	const val TAG_NEW_TRACKS = "TAG_NEW_TRACKS"
}

Followed by assigning this to the row containing the tracks via the testTag modifier.

// NewTracksRow.kt

LazyRow(
	modifier = modifier
		.testTag(TAG_NEW_TRACKS),
	...
 )

With this in place, we can now locate the New Tracks row using the TAG_NEW_TRACKS tag. Similar to the Recent Tracks tests, weâ€™ll add some tests to assert that the New Tracks row is not displayed when the provided tracks is either an empty list or a null value.

@Test
fun New_Tracks_Not_Displayed_When_Empty() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        NewTracksRow(tracks = emptyList(), onTrackClicked = {})
    }

    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(TAG_NEW_TRACKS)
        .assertDoesNotExist()
}

@Test
fun New_Tracks_Not_Displayed_When_Null() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        NewTracksRow(tracks = null, onTrackClicked = {})
    }

    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(TAG_NEW_TRACKS)
        .assertDoesNotExist()
}

Alongside these tests, weâ€™ll also want to assert that each of the track references is being composed inside of the row. Weâ€™ll again utilise the TAG_TRACK tag that we created earlier, assigning this to the NewTrack composable using the corresponding track id.

// NewTracksRow.kt

NewTrack(
	modifier = Modifier
		...
		.testTag(TAG_TRACK + track.id),
	track = track
)

We can then use this tag to locate the corresponding track node inside the New Tracks row. Here weâ€™ll utilise the performScrollToNode to scroll to the node that represents the current track, followed by assertIsDisplayed to assert that the track is being composed as expected.

@Test
fun New_Tracks_Displayed() {
	val tracks = ContentFactory.makeContentList()
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        NewTracksRow(tracks = tracks, onTrackClicked = {})
    }

    tracks.forEach { track ->
        composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(TAG_NEW_TRACKS)
            .performScrollToNode(
				hasTestTag(TAG_TRACK + track.id))
            .assertIsDisplayed()
    }
}

As well as having the new tracks displayed, users can click on those tracks to trigger playback. Weâ€™ll want to assert that the track listener provided to the composable function is being triggered on a click event. For the next test weâ€™ll again compose the NewTracksRow but this time weâ€™ll pass a mock implementation of the onTrackClicked lambda - this is so that we can verify this is involved when the composable is interacted with.

Weâ€™ll again use the onNodeWithTag function to locate the node that has a tag for the track that weâ€™re wanting to trigger the click event for, followed by utilising the performClick function to invoke the click event on the located node. When this click event occurs we would expect the onTrackClicked lambda to be invoked - so at this point we want to verify that this is the case by utilising the mockito verify function. This allows us to assert that the lambda is triggered as expected when the node is clicked, with the expected track reference that has been clicked.

@Test
fun Selecting_New_Track_Triggers_Listener() {
    val trackListener: (track: Track) -> Unit = mock()
    val tracks = ContentFactory.makeContentList()
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        NewTracksRow(
			tracks = tracks, 
			onTrackClicked = trackListener
		)
    }

    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(TAG_TRACK + tracks[2].id)
        .performClick()

    verify(trackListener).invoke(tracks[2])
}

Search Bar

Outside of displaying tracks, we also allow the user to search for tracks in the music catalogue using the search bar. So that we can ensure this search bar is working as expected, weâ€™re going to write some tests to assert this expected functionality. Weâ€™ll start here by creating a new test class, SearchBarTest.

class SearchBarTest {

    @get:Rule
    val composeTestRule = createComposeRule()

}

Testing the Hint

To assist users in awareness of what the search bar is used for, we display a hint message. We built our custom hint mechanism for the search bar, so weâ€™re going to want to test that this is displayed and hidden in the expected scenarios. By default when there is no search query entered, this hint is going to be displayed. So that we can test this, weâ€™ll start by composing the SearchBar, providing an empty string value for the query argument.

Using the string resource that represents the search bar hint, weâ€™ll want to assert that the node that has this text as its content is displayed.

@Test
fun Hint_Displayed_By_Default() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        SearchBar(
			query = "", 
			handleQuery = {}, 
			clearQuery = {}
		)
    }
    composeTestRule.onNodeWithText(
        InstrumentationRegistry.getInstrumentation()
			.targetContext.getString(R.string.hint_search)
    ).assertIsDisplayed()
}

When the search bar is in focus, this hint shouldnâ€™t be displayed. Weâ€™ll want to test this behaviour, so weâ€™ll need to start by composing the SearchBar with a blank query argument. Next, weâ€™ll want to perform a click event on the search bar, as this will bring the component into focus. We previously added the TAG_SEARCH_BAR tag for some earlier tests, so weâ€™ll want to assign this to the TextField composable within the Search bar.

// SearchBar.kt

TextField(
	modifier = modifier
		.testTag(TAG_SEARCH_BAR),
	...
)

With this tag in place, we can now locate this node and use the performClick function to perform a click event on the search bar.

@Test
fun Hint_Hidden_When_Focused() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        SearchBar(
			query = "", 
			handleQuery = {}, 
			clearQuery = {}
		)
    }

    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(TAG_SEARCH_BAR)
    	.performClick()
}

Now that this click event has been performed, the search bar should now be in focus. With this focus, it also means that the hint should no longer be displayed in the search bar, so weâ€™ll assert this by using the assertDoesNotExist function.

@Test
fun Hint_Hidden_When_Focused() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        SearchBar(
			query = "", 
			handleQuery = {}, 
			clearQuery = {}
		)
    }

    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(TAG_SEARCH_BAR)
    	.performClick()

    composeTestRule.onNodeWithText(
        InstrumentationRegistry.getInstrumentation()
			.targetContext.getString(
                R.string.hint_search
            )
    ).assertDoesNotExist()
}

Testing the search Icon

As well as the dynamic hint, we also have an icon displayed in the SeachBar that changes based on the current state of the composable. By default, a search icon is displayed as the trailing icon of the field, so weâ€™ll want to assert this is the case. This search icon has a content description, so we can assert that this icon is being displayed by locating the node that has this content description applied. After composing the SearchBar composable for our test, weâ€™ll use the onNodeWithContentDescription function to locate the node with this content description, followed by using the assertIsDisplayed function to assert that the node with this description is being displayed - in this case, it means that the search icon is being displayed as expected.

@Test
fun Search_Icon_Displayed_By_Default() {
	composeTestRule.setContent {
		SearchBar(
			query = "", 
			handleQuery = {}, 
			clearQuery = {}
		)
    }
    composeTestRule.onNodeWithContentDescription(
        InstrumentationRegistry.getInstrumentation()
			.targetContext.getString(
                R.string.cd_search
            )
    ).assertIsDisplayed()
}

On the other hand, when a search query has been entered we expect the â€˜clearâ€™ icon to be displayed - this allows the user to clear the currently entered search content, resetting the search state. This clear icon will only ever be displayed when there is a query entered, so weâ€™ll want to compose the SearchBar with a valid query argument. Next, weâ€™ll use the content description that is applied to the â€˜clearâ€™ icon to locate the corresponding node, followed by using the assertIsDisplayed function to assert that it is being displayed as expected.

@Test
fun Close_Icon_Displayed_When_Query_Entered() {
	composeTestRule.setContent {
        SearchBar(
			query = "Test", 
			handleQuery = {}, 
			clearQuery = {}
		)
    }

    composeTestRule.onNodeWithContentDescription(
        InstrumentationRegistry.getInstrumentation()
			.targetContext.getString(
                R.string.cd_clear_query
            )
    ).assertIsDisplayed()
}

In the sample code, youâ€™ll also find tests that assert the Search icon is hidden when a query is entered, as well as the clear icon, which is hidden when there is no query entered. We havenâ€™t covered these in writing here as the tests are very similar to what weâ€™ve already covered.

Search Results

When the search bar is used to perform a search operation, the corresponding search results are displayed using the SearchResults composable. So that we can ensure the search results are being displayed as expected, letâ€™s write a few tests that will assert this display of results. Weâ€™ll start by creating a new test class, SearchResultsTest.

class SearchResultsTest {

    @get:Rule
    val composeTestRule = createComposeRule()

}

When there are no search results to display, we display a message that represents an empty state. Weâ€™re going to write a test to assert that this is displayed as expected, so weâ€™ll start by composing SearchResults and passing an empty list for the results argument.

@Test
fun Empty_State_Displayed() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        SearchResults(
			results = emptyList(), 
			onTrackClicked = {}
		)
    }
}

Next, weâ€™ll use the string resource that represents the empty state, asserting that this is displayed within the composable using the assertIsDisplayed function. When this test is run and succeeds, we know that the empty state message is being displayed when there are no results provided to the composable.

@Test
fun Empty_State_Displayed() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        SearchResults(
			results = emptyList(), 
			onTrackClicked = {}
		)
    }
    composeTestRule.onNodeWithText(
        InstrumentationRegistry.getInstrumentation()
			.targetContext.getString(
                R.string.message_search_results
            )
    ).assertIsDisplayed()
}

On the other hand, when results have been provided to the composable function, we expect this message to not be displayed. Weâ€™re going to write a similar test to the previous, except this time asserting that the message does not exist on-screen when search results have been provided to the composable.

@Test
fun Empty_State_Not_Displayed_When_ResultsExist() {
	composeTestRule.setContent {
		SearchResults(
			results = ContentFactory.makeContentList(),
			onTrackClicked = {}
		)
    }
    composeTestRule.onNodeWithText(
        InstrumentationRegistry.getInstrumentation()
			.targetContext.getString(
                R.string.message_search_results
            )
    ).assertDoesNotExist()
}

Aside from the empty state, weâ€™re going to want to ensure that the search results are being composed as expected - this will be a case of checking that each of the tracks that are provided to the composable function is being displayed within the results list. Weâ€™ll need to start by tagging the Track composable using the TAG_TRACK that we previously defined, along with the id of the corresponding track.

//SearchResults.kt

Track(
	modifier = Modifier
		...
		.testTag(TAG_TRACK + it.id),
    track = it
)

With this tag in place, we can now test for the display of search results. In this test, weâ€™ll want to compose the SearchResults, passing a collection of track references.

@Test
fun Search_Results_Displayed() {
    val tracks = TestDataFactory.makeContentList(5)
	composeTestRule.setContent {
        SearchResults(
			results = tracks, 
			onTrackClicked = {}
		)
    }
}

So that we can check the contents of the search container, weâ€™ll need to add a new tag TAG_SEARCH_RESULTS to our Tags object.

object Tags {
    ...
    const val TAG_SEARCH_RESULTS = "TAG_SEARCH_RESULTS"
}

With this tag in place, weâ€™ll now want to add it to the LazyColumn that is used for composing the collection of tracks.

// SearchResults.kt

LazyColumn(
	modifier = modifier.testTag(TAG_SEARCH_RESULTS),
	...
)

With this tag in place, we can now loop through the collection of tracks and assert that each one is being composed inside of the column. After locating the node using the TAG_SEARCH_RESULTS tag, weâ€™ll use onChildAt to get the current child for the corresponding index of the loop. Once we have a reference for this child weâ€™ll use the performScrollTo function to ensure that it is composed and visible on screen, followed by using the TAG_TRACK tag and corresponding track id to ensure the track is being displayed as expected.

@Test
fun Search_Results_Displayed() {
    val tracks = TestDataFactory.makeContentList(5)
	composeTestRule.setContent {
        SearchResults(
			results = tracks, 
			onTrackClicked = {}
		)
    }

    tracks.forEachIndexed { index, track ->
        composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(TAG_SEARCH_RESULTS)
            .onChildAt(index).apply {
                performScrollTo()
                assert(hasTestTag(TAG_TRACK + track.id))
            }
    }
}

Testing the Seeker

Now that weâ€™ve set up tests for each of the track feeds, weâ€™re going to start looking into the various player components - weâ€™ll start here with the SeekBar. Because weâ€™ve created a custom composable for this, we must test its functionality.

class SeekBarTest {

    @get:Rule
    val composeTestRule = createComposeRule()

}

So that we can retrieve the node that represents the seeker, weâ€™re going to define a new tag within our Tags object.

object Tags {
	const val TAG_SEEK_BAR = "TAG_SEEK_BAR"
}

We can then assign this tag to the Slider composable inside of the PlayerSeekBar. 

// PlayerSeekBar.kt

Slider(
	modifier = modifier.testTag(TAG_SEEK_BAR),
	...
)

Testing the current progress

Within the first test, weâ€™re going to check that this Slider composable is displaying the expected progress, based on the information that is provided to it. Weâ€™ll create a new NowPlaying reference, followed by using this to compose a PlayerSeekBar. Because we want to test the Slider composable inside of this, weâ€™re going to go ahead and provide a true value for the canSeekTrack argument.

@Test
fun Track_Progress_Displayed_When_Can_Seek() {
    val nowPlaying = TestDataFactory.makeNowPlaying()
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        PlayerSeekBar(
            nowPlaying = nowPlaying,
            canSeekTrack = true
        )
    }
}

We can now use the previously assigned tag to locate the Seekbar and perform assertions against it. In this test weâ€™re going to want to check that the progress bar is displaying the expected progress, so weâ€™re going to use the assertRangeInfoEquals function to test that the progress range matches the expected range, based on the provided track information. For this, we need to provide a ProgressBarRangeInfo instance that represents the expected progress state of the Seekbar, this has three values:

  • current - this represents the current progress value within the seek bar. In our case this is going to be calculated using the currently playing track - so weâ€™ll need to work out the expected percentage using the position of the provided now playing track, dividing it by the length to give us the current percentage value.
  • range - the range that is available within the seeker, which is simply between 0f and 1f
  • steps - the number of steps available within the seek bar. Seeing as we donâ€™t support steps, this is simply 0
@Test
fun Track_Progress_Displayed_When_Can_Seek() {
    val nowPlaying = TestDataFactory.makeNowPlaying()
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        PlayerSeekBar(
            nowPlaying = nowPlaying,
            canSeekTrack = true
        )
    }

    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(TAG_SEEK_BAR)
        .assertRangeInfoEquals(
            ProgressBarRangeInfo(
                current = nowPlaying.position.toFloat() / 
					nowPlaying.track.length.toFloat(),
                range = 0f..1f,
                steps = 0
            )
        )
}

With this in place, we are now able to assert that the currently displayed information within the Seekbar correctly represents the NowPlaying reference that is provided to the PlayerSeekBar composable.

Alongside the progress being displayed in the canSeekTrack state, we also want to make sure that this is still composed as expected when the canSeekTrack flag has been provided as false. Weâ€™ll write a new test, Track_Progress_Displayed_When_Cannot_Seek, which takes exactly the same form as the previous, except the PlayerSeekBar composable is composed with the canSeekTrack provided as false.

@Test
fun Track_Progress_Displayed_When_Cannot_Seek() {
    val nowPlaying = TestDataFactory.makeNowPlaying()
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        PlayerSeekBar(
            nowPlaying = nowPlaying,
            canSeekTrack = false
        )
    }

    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(TAG_SEEK_BAR)
        .assertRangeInfoEquals(
            ProgressBarRangeInfo(
                current = nowPlaying.position.toFloat() / 
					nowPlaying.track.length.toFloat(),
                range = 0f..1f,
                steps = 0
            )
        )
}

Testing progress modification

Alongside the display of the current progress, the Seekbar also supports the seeking of audio via touch gestures on the composable. When this occurs, the onSeekChanged lambda that is provided to the PlayerSeekBar composable should be triggered with the updated progress. Weâ€™re going to start by writing a test to assert that this lambda is triggered when expected. Weâ€™ll compose the PlayerSeekBar in a similar way to the previous tests, except this time weâ€™re going to provide a mock implementation of the onSeekChanged lambda

@Test
fun Track_Progress_Updated_When_Can_Seek() {
    val seekListener: (progress: Float) -> Unit = mock()
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        PlayerSeekBar(
            nowPlaying = TestDataFactory.makeNowPlaying(),
            canSeekTrack = true,
