            onSeekChanged = seekListener
        )
    }

    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(TAG_SEEK_BAR)
        .performTouchInput {
            swipeLeft()
        }

    verify(seekListener, atLeastOnce()).invoke(any())
}

Weâ€™re next going to want to perform a touch gesture on the Seekbar, so weâ€™ll locate the node using the TAG_SEEK_BAR, followed by using the performTouchInput function to trigger the swipeLeft action. When this happens, the gesture should trigger the onSeekChanged lambda which we can verify using mockitos verify function.

@Test
fun Track_Progress_Updated_When_Can_Seek() {
    val seekListener: (progress: Float) -> Unit = mock()
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        PlayerSeekBar(
            nowPlaying = TestDataFactory.makeNowPlaying(),
            canSeekTrack = true,
            onSeekChanged = seekListener
        )
    }

    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(TAG_SEEK_BAR)
        .performTouchInput {
            swipeLeft()
        }

    verify(seekListener, atLeastOnce()).invoke(any())
}

In the case where the canSeekTrack argument is provided to our composable as false, we wouldnâ€™t expect the same outcome as the test above. Weâ€™ll execute the same test code as above with this modified flag, except this time asserting that the provided onSeekChanged lambda is never triggered when the swipe gesture is performed on the Seekbar.

@Test
fun Track_Progress_Not_Updated_When_Cannot_Seek() {
    val seekListener: (progress: Float) -> Unit = mock()
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        PlayerSeekBar(
            nowPlaying = TestDataFactory.makeNowPlaying(),
            canSeekTrack = false,
            onSeekChanged = seekListener
        )
    }

    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(TAG_SEEK_BAR)
        .performTouchInput {
            swipeLeft()
        }

    verify(seekListener, never()).invoke(any())
}

Testing the Player Bar

Now that weâ€™ve tested the seek bar composable, weâ€™re going to go up one level and test the composables that utilise this - starting at the PlayerBar. For this, weâ€™ll start by creating a new test class, PlayerBarTest.

class PlayerBarTest {

    @get:Rule
    val composeTestRule = createComposeRule()


}

Testing the track title

Within the player bar, we display information regarding the track that is currently playing. To ensure that the correct information is being displayed for a track, weâ€™re going to assert that the composables are displaying the expected information.

Weâ€™ll start here by testing the display of the track title. So that we can perform these assertions, weâ€™re going to need to add a new tag for use in our tests.

// Tags.kt
object Tags {
	const val TAG_TRACK_TITLE = "TAG_TRACK_TITLE"
}

We next need to assign this tag to the Text composable using the testTag modifier.

// PlayerBar.kt
Text(
	modifier = Modifier.testTag(TAG_TRACK_TITLE),
	...
)

With this tag in place, we can now move on to writing a test to assert the information is displayed as expected. Weâ€™ll start here by composing a PlayerBar, passing in a reference to a Track

@Test
fun Track_Title_Displayed() {
    val track = TestDataFactory.makeTrack()
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        PlayerBar(
            nowPlaying = TestDataFactory.makeNowPlaying(
                track = track
            ),
            toggleNowPlayingState = {}
        )
    }
}

Testing the track artist

Next, we need to locate the node that is tagged using TAG_TRACK_TITLE. When locating the node, we need to utilise the useUnmergedTree flag - this is because within the PlayerBar composable we are merging the descendants, so we need to use the unmerged tree in-order to locate the specific node. When we have this node, we can then assert that the text equals the expected state of the track title value.

@Test
fun Track_Title_Displayed() {
    val track = TestDataFactory.makeTrack()
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        PlayerBar(
            nowPlaying = TestDataFactory.makeNowPlaying(
                track = track
            ),
            toggleNowPlayingState = {}
        )
    }
    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(
		TAG_TRACK_TITLE, 
		useUnmergedTree = true
	)
    .assertTextEquals(track.title)
}

Weâ€™re next going to do the same for the artist of the Track. Weâ€™ll need to start here by adding another tag for use in our tests.

// Tags.kt
object Tags {
	const val TAG_TRACK_ARTIST = "TAG_TRACK_ARTIST"
}

Next, weâ€™ll apply this tag to the corresponding composable.

// PlayerBar.kt

Text(
	modifier = Modifier.testTag(TAG_TRACK_ARTIST),
	...
)

Weâ€™ll then go and write a similar test that was used to assert the display of the track title, except this time validating that the track artist is being displayed as expected.

@Test
fun Track_Artist_Displayed() {
    val track = TestDataFactory.makeTrack()
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        PlayerBar(
            nowPlaying = TestDataFactory.makeNowPlaying(
                track = track
            ),
            toggleNowPlayingState = {}
        )
    }
    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(
		TAG_TRACK_ARTIST, 
		useUnmergedTree = true
	).assertTextEquals(track.artist)
}

Testing the track playback state

Alongside testing the title and artist information is displayed correctly, weâ€™re going to want to assert that the playback state is being displayed correctly. This means that:

  • if the track is currently being played, the pause button should be shown
  • if the track is currently paused, the play button should be shown

To be able to assert these expected cases, weâ€™re going to start by adding a new tag for use in our tests:

// Tags.kt
object Tags {
	const val TAG_PLAY_PAUSE = "TAG_PLAY_PAUSE"
}

Next, weâ€™ll add this tag to the IconButton used to display the playback state.

// PlayerBar.kt

IconButton(
	modifier = Modifier.testTag(TAG_PLAY_PAUSE),
	onClick = {
		toggleNowPlayingState()
	}
)

With this tag in place, weâ€™re going to start with asserting that the playing state is being composed as expected. Weâ€™ll need to compose the PlayerBar, providing the information for the currently playing state.

@Test
fun Playing_State_Displayed() {
    val track = TestDataFactory.makeTrack()
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        PlayerBar(
            nowPlaying = TestDataFactory.makeNowPlaying(
                track = track,
                state = NowPlayingState.PLAYING
            ),
            toggleNowPlayingState = {}
        )
    }
}

Next, weâ€™ll use this tag to assert that the content description matches the description for the pause action. Because we canâ€™t easily test the visual content of the IconButton composable, we can instead test against the content description applied to the composable. Because when the playback state is PLAYING, the icon will display the pause action which will, in turn, have the pause content description which we can test for using the assertContentDescriptionEquals function.

@Test
fun Playing_State_Displayed() {
    val track = TestDataFactory.makeTrack()
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        PlayerBar(
            nowPlaying = TestDataFactory.makeNowPlaying(
                track = track,
                state = NowPlayingState.PLAYING
            ),
            toggleNowPlayingState = {}
        )
    }
    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(TAG_PLAY_PAUSE)
        .assertContentDescriptionEquals(
            InstrumentationRegistry.getInstrumentation()
				.targetContext.getString(R.string.cd_pause)
		)
}

Similarly, we also want to test that the correct state is displayed when the player is in the PAUSED state.

@Test
fun Paused_State_Displayed() {
    val track = TestDataFactory.makeTrack()
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        PlayerBar(
            nowPlaying = TestDataFactory.makeNowPlaying(
                track = track,
                state = NowPlayingState.PAUSED
            ),
            toggleNowPlayingState = {}
        )
    }
    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(TAG_PLAY_PAUSE)
        .assertContentDescriptionEquals(
            InstrumentationRegistry.getInstrumentation()
				.targetContext.getString(R.string.cd_play)
        )
}

When it comes to the Player composable, youâ€™ll find tests that match the above within the sample code - we wonâ€™t go through these here as the content is duplicated for each composable test.

Testing the Music Player

Now that we have tests in place for the individual player composables, weâ€™re going to add some test coverage for the MusicPlayer. This composable has the responsibility of composing either the PlayerBar or Player based on the current state, so weâ€™ll want to test that things are being composed as expected. Weâ€™re going to hold these tests in a new test class, MusicPlayerTest.

class MusicPlayerTest {

    @get:Rule
    val composeTestRule = createComposeRule()

}

Weâ€™re going to first test that the player bar is displayed when the backdrop state represents the Revealed state. Weâ€™ll start here by composing the MusicPlayer, providing a BackdropScaffoldState that represents the Revealed state.

@Test
fun Collapsed_Player_Bar_Displayed() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        val scaffoldState = rememberBackdropScaffoldState(
            initialValue = BackdropValue.Revealed
        )
        MusicPlayer(
            scaffoldState = scaffoldState,
            state = MusicDashboardState(
                nowPlaying = TestDataFactory.makeNowPlaying()
            ),
            handleEvent = {}
        )
    }
}

With this composition in place, we can use the previously assigned TAG_PLAYER_BAR tag to perform the assertIsDisplayed check. When this test runs, a successful result will mean that the collapsed player bar is being displayed in the expected scenario.

@Test
fun Collapsed_Player_Bar_Displayed() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        val scaffoldState = rememberBackdropScaffoldState(
            initialValue = BackdropValue.Revealed
        )
        MusicPlayer(
            scaffoldState = scaffoldState,
            state = MusicDashboardState(
                nowPlaying = TestDataFactory.makeNowPlaying()
            ),
            handleEvent = {}
        )
    }
    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(TAG_PLAYER_BAR)
        .assertIsDisplayed()
}

When the collapsed player is displayed, we expected the full-screen player to not be composed on the screen. Weâ€™re going to write a test to assert that this is the case. To do this, weâ€™ll need to start by adding a new tag for our tests.

// Tags.kt

object Tags {
	const val TAG_PLAYER = "TAG_PLAYER"
}

We can then assign this to the corresponding composable in the MusicPlayer composable.

// MusicPlayer.kt

Player(
	modifier = Modifier
		.fillMaxSize()
		.testTag(TAG_PLAYER),
	...
)

With this in place, we can now use this tag to assert that the Player composable is not being composed when the backdrop scaffold is in a Revealed state.

@Test
fun Player_Never_Revealed_While_Player_Bar_Collapsed() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        val scaffoldState = rememberBackdropScaffoldState(
            initialValue = BackdropValue.Revealed
        )
        MusicPlayer(
            scaffoldState = scaffoldState,
            state = MusicDashboardState(
                nowPlaying = TestDataFactory.makeNowPlaying()
            ),
            handleEvent = {}
        )
    }
    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(TAG_PLAYER)
        .assertDoesNotExist()
}

Along with asserting the correct state for the collapsed player, weâ€™re also going to want to be sure that the full-screen player is composed when expected. These tests are going to look very similar to the previous tests - weâ€™ll start with ensuring that the full-screen player is composed when the backdrop scaffold is in the Concealed state. Once this has been composed, we can use the TAG_PLAYER tag to assert that the composable is displayed when in this state.

@Test
fun Revealed_Player_Bar_Displayed() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        val scaffoldState = rememberBackdropScaffoldState(
            initialValue = BackdropValue.Concealed
        )
        MusicPlayer(
            scaffoldState = scaffoldState,
            state = MusicDashboardState(
                nowPlaying = TestDataFactory.makeNowPlaying()
            ),
            handleEvent = {}
        )
    }
    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(TAG_PLAYER)
        .assertIsDisplayed()
}

Weâ€™ll also want to ensure that when the fullscreen player is composed, the PlayerBar composable is not. While still composing in the Concealed state, weâ€™ll use the TAG_PLAYER_BAR tag to locate the node for the player bar, along with the assertDoesNotExist function to assert that the composition for the player bar has not taken place.

@Test
fun Player_Bar_Never_Displayed_When_Player_Revealed() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        val scaffoldState = rememberBackdropScaffoldState(
            initialValue = BackdropValue.Concealed
        )
        MusicPlayer(
            scaffoldState = scaffoldState,
            state = MusicDashboardState(
                nowPlaying = TestDataFactory.makeNowPlaying()
            ),
            handleEvent = {}
        )
    }
    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(TAG_PLAYER_BAR)
        .assertDoesNotExist()
}

Building a Graphs Dashboard

When it comes to building mobile applications, there is a vast range of UI components available for it to build out features. While in most cases these UI components provide us with the elements we need to build features, there are sometimes going to be things that we need to create ourselves - some of these things will be at a lower level, often involving custom drawing on a canvas. Knowing how to draw and manage a canvas is an invaluable skill in Android development, something which is just as important when it comes to Jetpack Compose.

To help us learn more about drawing on the Canvas with Jetpack Compose weâ€™re going to build out a small Graphing application. Weâ€™ll completely draw the data for these graphs using the Canvas composable, while also utilising some of the compose animation APIs to allow us to animate the drawing of our datasets.

Defining the State

When it comes to the display of graphs, weâ€™re going to need to model the state, as well as the classes that make up the information held within it. In this section of the chapter, weâ€™re going to create these different models, as well as construct the state class used to represent the graphs screen.

Modelling the Graph Types

Within this feature, weâ€™re going to be displaying a collection of different graphs. Each of these graphs is going to use the same dataset, but this dataset will be communicated to the user in a different way (based on the currently selected graph type). Weâ€™re going to be supporting six different types of graphs, so weâ€™ll define a new enum class that will allow us to model the different graph types.

enum class GraphType {
    PIE(R.string.graph_pie),
    LINE(R.string.graph_line),
    BAR(R.string.graph_bar),
    COLUMN(R.string.graph_column),
    DOUGHNUT(R.string.graph_doughnut),
    AREA(R.string.app_name)
}

While this allows us to define the types of graphs that are available, weâ€™ll also want a corresponding way to communicate these graph types back to the user. For this reason, weâ€™re also going to assign a human-readable string to each of the graph enum values. Weâ€™ll start by adding these strings to the strings.xml resources for this feature.

<string name="graph_pie">Pie</string>
<string name="graph_line">Line</string>
<string name="graph_bar">Bar</string>
<string name="graph_column">Column</string>
<string name="graph_doughnut">Doughnut</string>
<string name="graph_area">Area</string>

Weâ€™ll then need to allow a resource reference to be provided for each enum value, which weâ€™ll define via the GraphType constructor.

enum class GraphType(@StringRes val label: Int)

Finally, we can take each of the human-readable strings and assign them to the corresponding GraphType value.

enum class GraphType(@StringRes val label: Int) {
    PIE(R.string.graph_pie),
    LINE(R.string.graph_line),
    BAR(R.string.graph_bar),
    COLUMN(R.string.graph_column),
    DOUGHNUT(R.string.graph_doughnut),
    AREA(R.string.app_name)
}

Modelling the Graph Data

Alongside the different types of graphs that are going to be supported by our feature, weâ€™re going to need to allow the definition of the different data entries for our graph. As per the screenshots in the introduction, each graph entry is going to have a:

  • label - the label used to represent the entry in the graph
  • value - the value for the entry in the graph
  • color - the color to be used when drawing the entry

To model this information, weâ€™ll create a new class, GraphData. Weâ€™ll define a property to represent each of these values, making them all required when instantiating a GraphData instance.

class GraphData(
    val label: String,
    val value: Int,
    val color: Color
)

Modelling the Screen State

When it comes to the screen for our feature, several pieces of information are going to need to be persisted at a global level. At a high-level, our composable UI needs to know

  • the currently selected chart
  • whether the chart picker should currently be shown
  • the data to be drawn on the graph

To model this, weâ€™ll create a new class, GraphsState.

data class GraphsState()

For the currently selected graph, weâ€™ll define a new property, assigning this a default value of the LINE chart type.

data class GraphsState(
    val selectedChart: ChartType = ChartType.LINE
)

When it comes to knowing whether or not the chart picker should be displayed, we can model this using a simple Boolean value

data class GraphsState(
    val selectedChart: ChartType = ChartType.LINE,
    val showChartPicker: Boolean = false
)

In regards to the chart data, weâ€™re going to need to model this as a list of ChartData references. As we donâ€™t have any â€˜realâ€™ data coming from any source, weâ€™ll create a factory class that will allow us to create some fake data.

// GraphsDataFactory.kt

object GraphsDataFactory {

    fun makeChartData(): List<GraphData> {
        return listOf(
            GraphData("2016", 20, Color.Red),
            GraphData("2017", 10, Color.Blue),
            GraphData("2018", 2, Color.Yellow),
            GraphData("2019", 42, Color.Green),
            GraphData("2020", 7, Color.Magenta),
            GraphData("2021", 5, Color.Cyan),
        )
    }
}

With this in place, we can now add this chart data to our model in the form of a GraphData list, providing a default set of data using this factory class. We wonâ€™t be modifying this state value at any point, so the factory will always be used to provide the graph data as the state.

data class GraphsState(
    val selectedChart: ChartType = ChartType.LINE,
    val showChartPicker: Boolean = false,
    val chartData: List<ChartData> = 
		GraphsDataFactory.makeChartData()
)

With this in place, we now have the required data that can be used to make up the state of our screen.

Creating the View Model

Now that we have the state modelled for our Graphs Dashboard, we can start thinking about the ViewModel that will be used to manage that state and provide a way to orchestrate it to the user interface.

Setting up the ViewModel

Before we can get started here, weâ€™re going to add a new dependency to our project that will give us access to the Android Lifecycle ViewModel class:

implementation "androidx.lifecycle:lifecycle-viewmodel-compose:2.4.0"

ðŸ’¡ You arenâ€™t required to use a ViewModel when working with compose. For the sake of these exercises, it helps us to keep things simple and follow an approach that many developers are familiar with.

Next, weâ€™ll create a new ViewModel, called GraphsViewModel.

// GraphsViewModel.kt

class GraphsViewModel : ViewModel()

This ViewModel is going to need to hold a reference to the state of our screen. For this weâ€™re going to utilise StateFlow - this allows us to create a state-holder observable flow that will emit the default state we provide to it, along with any updates that occur during its lifetime. Here weâ€™ll create a new MutableStateFlow instance, providing a reference to our GraphsState class as the default value for our StateFlow:

// MusicViewModel.kt

class GraphsViewModel: ViewModel() {

    val uiState = MutableStateFlow(GraphsState())

}

With this in place, we now have a StateFlow reference that is holding a reference to our authentication state, initialising it with a new instance of the state class and relying on the defaults that the constructor provides.

Manipulating state using events

While this state is now in place, we need to start thinking about the different ways in which it can be manipulated - whenever something is changed in our UI (such as a graph type selected), weâ€™ll want to update the state within our ViewModel so that the observing UI can reflect those changes.

For when this is the case, weâ€™re going to model some events that can be triggered in our composable UI and in turn these events will be used to manipulate the state within the view model. This allows us to have a single way of our composable UI communicating with the ViewModel, rather than needing to pass the entire ViewModel or many references to separate functions which could be used to trigger state changes. Instead, we can pass a single function reference to our composable UI which can then be used to trigger these events in the ViewModel. For these events weâ€™re going to need to define different types that can be triggered, so weâ€™ll go ahead and create a new sealed class to represent these.

// GraphsEvent.kt

sealed class GraphsEvent

In this class, weâ€™re next going to define the different events that can be triggered to update the state of our UI. Within our GraphsState state we defined a showChartPicker property - this is used to depict whether the chart picker component should be composed. So that this state can be updated accordingly, weâ€™ll need to add some event types. Weâ€™ll add two new events here - one for the display of the chart picker, and another that can be used to dismiss the picker.

sealed class GraphsEvent {

    object ShowPicker: GraphsEvent()

    object DismissPicker: GraphsEvent()
}

With these events in place, weâ€™re going to need to handle these within ourGraphsViewModel, updating the state accordingly. So that we can handle the different event types represented by our GraphsEvent class, weâ€™re going to add a new function to our GraphsViewModel.

class GraphsViewModel: ViewModel() {

    val uiState = MutableStateFlow(GraphsState())

    fun handleEvent(event: GraphsEvent) {
        
    }
}

Within this function, weâ€™re now going to want to handle the event types that weâ€™ve declared so far. Whenever the ShowPicker or DismissPicker events are triggered, weâ€™re going to want to update our state reference so that the showChartPicker property is set to the corresponding value - this will be true when the picker is to be shown, and false when otherwise.

class GraphsViewModel: ViewModel() {

    val uiState = MutableStateFlow(GraphsState())

    fun handleStocksEvent(event: GraphsEvent) {
        when (event) {
			GraphsEvent.ShowPicker -> {
                uiState.value = uiState.value.copy(
                    showChartPicker = true
                )
            }
            GraphsEvent.DismissPicker -> {
                uiState.value = uiState.value.copy(
                    showChartPicker = false
                )
            }
        }
    }
}

Alongside the display of the chart picker, we also need to be able to handle the case where the user selects a graph from this picker - as this will need to change the graph being displayed on-screen. To handle this case weâ€™re going to add a new event, SetChartType. This class will take a GraphType in its constructor which can be used to update our state.

sealed class GraphsEvent {

    object ShowPicker: GraphsEvent()

    object DismissPicker: GraphsEvent()

	class SetCharType(chart: GraphType): GraphsEvent()
}

Weâ€™ll then handle this event within our handleEvent function. Here weâ€™ll simply set the selectedChart property in our state, while at the same time dismissing the chart picker (as we no longer want to show the picker when a new graph type has been selected).

class GraphsViewModel: ViewModel() {

    val uiState = MutableStateFlow(GraphsState())

    fun handleEvent(event: GraphsEvent) {
        when (event) {
            ...
            is GraphsEvent.SetChartType -> {
                uiState.value = uiState.value.copy(
                    selectedChart = event.chart,
                    showChartPicker = false
                )
            }
        }
    }
}

With this implemented, we are now managing the state of our graphs dashboard screen and providing the required entry points for our UI layer to manipulate the state based on user interaction. Our view model is now ready to be plugged into a composable UI, which weâ€™ll create in the next section of this chapter!

Building the Graphs UI

With the view model and state management all in place, weâ€™re ready to move on and start implementing the composable UI for our Graphs app. With this UI weâ€™re going to be building out 6 different kinds of graphs, with each taking the provided data and animating the dataset onto the screen. When weâ€™re finished building this UI, weâ€™re going to end up with something that looks like the following:

Setting up the entry point

Before we can get start building our project, weâ€™re going to need to add a couple of dependencies that weâ€™re going to need. Weâ€™ll start here by adding these to the build.gradle file for our new project:

implementation 
	"androidx.compose.foundation:foundation:$compose_version"
implementation "androidx.compose.ui:ui:$compose_version"
implementation 
	"androidx.compose.material:material:$compose_version"
implementation "androidx.lifecycle:lifecycle-viewmodel-compose:2.4.0"

The current release of this book is building against 1.1.0 of compose - be sure to check compatibly if using a newer version.

  • foundation: provides foundational composables, such as layouts and commonly required modifiers
  • ui: provides access to ui related composables, such as drawing and general components
  • material: provides access to compose material UI components
  • lifecycle-viewmodel-compose: provides functionality for providing view models directly inside of composables

With these added to our project, weâ€™re now ready to start building out our UI. Weâ€™re going to start here by building the access point to our feature - this is how the messaging feature will initially be composed within our user interface. To make this an argument-less access point, weâ€™re going to start with a new composable function, Graphs.

// Graphs.kt

@Composable
fun Graphs()

While you wonâ€™t see anything visual just yet, youâ€™ll want to compose this Graphs composable within the setContent block of the activity that was created through the project wizard. Then as we build out the project, weâ€™ll be able to visualise the Graphs when running the project.

Before we get started with any composition of messaging specific UI, weâ€™re going to start by declaring the use of the MaterialTheme composable, this will be in place ready to wrap any composition and apply the expected material theming to our project. This isnâ€™t a requirement, but if not provided then you would need to manually style each composable to adhere to material requirements. Weâ€™re not going to be doing any theme customisation here, so this will be using the default colors.

// Graphs.kt

@Composable
fun Graphs() {
    MaterialTheme {
        ...
    }
}

We can see here that we currently have a blank content block, this means that nothing is currently going to be composed in our UI. As mentioned previously, this is just an argument-less entry point to our feature, but weâ€™re going to need access to the state configuration that we set up over the last few chapters. Here, weâ€™re going to utilise the ViewModel related dependency that we added to our project. Using its viewModel() function, weâ€™ll go ahead and retrieve an instance of the GraphsViewModel. This will return an existing reference to the ViewModel, creating a new one if it does not currently exist.

// Graphs.kt

@Composable
fun Graphs() {
    val viewModel: GraphsViewModel = viewModel()
}

With this in place, we have our ViewModel, as well as access to our state through this ViewModel. Now though, we need to set ourselves up to be able to compose UI based on this state. Here weâ€™re going to create a separate composable function that takes the GraphsState class, composing UI from it.

// GraphsDashboard.kt

@Composable
fun GraphsDashboard(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    state: GraphsState
)

ðŸ’¡ Declaring a Modifier argument for your composable functions allows the layout constraints of the composable to be delegated to the parent. This helps to keep your composables reusable, as they are not being constrained for a specific scenario.

Not only does having this separate composable keep the responsibilities of our composable functions smaller, but it also will help us with testing later on. Having this separate GraphsDashboard composable with a GraphsState argument means that we can provide state within our tests, and perform assertions based on the expected composition from our state. Testing against an argument-less composable function would require us to interact with the UI to manipulate the state, which adds friction during the testing process.

Now that we have this composable in place, weâ€™re ready to compose this inside of our Graphs composable. We can provide two arguments to our GraphsDashboard - modifier and state, which the second is required. For the modifier, weâ€™ll simply utilise the fillMaxSize modifier - which will instruct the contained composable to use all of the size that it has available to it.

Weâ€™ll also need to provide a reference to a GraphsState, which weâ€™ll access through our GraphsViewModel. Here weâ€™re going to use the collectAsState() - because our state is represented within our ViewModel as a StateFlow, weâ€™re going to want to collect the events from here. collectAsState() allows us to collect the emissions from our StateFlow as composable state, meaning that our composables can be recomposed accordingly whenever the state is changed. Weâ€™ll need to access the value from the StateFlow and pass this directly to the state argument of our Graphs composable.

// Graphs.kt

@Composable
fun Graphs() {
    val viewModel: GraphsViewModel = viewModel()
    GraphsDashboard(
        state = viewModel.uiState.collectAsState().value,
        handleEvent = viewModel::handleStocksEvent
    )
}

At this point, we wonâ€™t be able to see anything being composed within our UI, but weâ€™re all set up and ready to start building out our messaging interface.

Building the Arc Chart

Within our Graphs dashboard, there are two graphs that take the form of an arc - these are the pie and doughnut charts. The logic used to build both of these charts is very similar, so weâ€™re going to be writing a reusable composable that will allow us to compose both a pie and doughnut chart using mostly the same code. Weâ€™re going to place this reusable code inside a new composable function, ArcChart.

// ArcChart.kt

@Composable
fun ArcChart(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier
)

When it comes to drawing the chart, weâ€™re going to be utilising the Canvas composable. This allows us to have complete control over what we are drawing on screen - allowing us to draw the custom shapes and labels that make up the graph. When composing this weâ€™ll utilise the size modifier to fix the size of the Canvas.

// ArcChart.kt

@Composable
fun ArcChart(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier
) { 
    Canvas(
        modifier = Modifier.size(240.dp)
    ) {
        
    }
}

ðŸ’¡ We use the size modifier here so that we can define how much space the composable needs to occupy on the screen. Because we are custom drawing the contents of the canvas, the composition does not know how much space is required. For this reason, we need to manually define the space to be occupied.

Now that we have the Canvas defined, we can start to think about what weâ€™re going to be drawing inside of it. For this, weâ€™re going to utilise the GraphData class that was previously defined - this class contains the value for a graph entry, so weâ€™re going to modify our composable function to take a list reference for the GraphData type. Weâ€™ll then want to loop through this data list so that we can draw the visual representation for the data entry.

// ArcChart.kt

@Composable
fun ArcChart(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    chartData: List<GraphData>
) {

    Canvas(
        modifier = Modifier.size(240.dp)
    ) {
        chartData.forEach { chartData ->

        }
    }
}

Within this loop, weâ€™re going to want to draw the information for the corresponding data point. In the case of the circular graphs, weâ€™re going to need to draw an arc for each of the data entries, for which we can utilise the drawArc function.

chartData.forEach { chartData ->        
	drawArc(
		...
	)
}

This function allows us to draw an arc inside of the corresponding Canvas. While weâ€™re now making a call to this function, things arenâ€™t going to compile yet because weâ€™re missing some of the information that is required by the function.

fun drawArc(
	color: Color,
    startAngle: Float,
    sweepAngle: Float,
    useCenter: Boolean,
    topLeft: Offset = Offset.Zero,
    size: Size = this.size.offsetSize(topLeft),
    /*@FloatRange(from = 0.0, to = 1.0)*/
    alpha: Float = 1.0f,
    style: DrawStyle = Fill,
    colorFilter: ColorFilter? = null,
    blendMode: BlendMode = DefaultBlendMode
)

To satisfy the requirements of the drawArc function, as well as be able to draw the arc for the corresponding data point, weâ€™re going to need to calculate the angles to be used for the drawing of the arc.

When it comes to working out the angle that each graph entry is going to occupy, weâ€™re going to need to calculate this using the information that we have available to us. We know that the total angle of a circle is 360 degrees - so given the data set that we have, we need to calculate the angle of each data entry. We can calculate this using the following formula:

(data value divided by total sum of data) multiplied by 360

We first need the sum of the entire data set that is provided to the function - here we can use the sumOf Kotlin function to calculate the complete sum of values from our data set. Next, weâ€™re going to take the above formula and use this to calculate the angle for each entry within the data set, so weâ€™ll place this within the loop of our GraphData collection.

// ArcChart.kt

@Composable
fun ArcChart(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    chartData: List<GraphData>
) {

    val sumOfDataSet = remember(chartData) { 
		chartData.sumOf { it.value } 
	}

    Canvas(
        modifier = Modifier.size(240.dp)
    ) {
        chartData.forEach { chartData ->
            val segmentAngle = 360 * 
				chartData.value / sumOfDataSet
        }
    }
}

As we loop through the data set, weâ€™re going to be drawing an arc for each entry. For this reason, weâ€™re going to need to keep a track of the angle of the circle that has been drawn so far - this means we will be drawing the circle segment by segment, building on the segments that were drawn before the current entry.

So that we can keep track of this, weâ€™re going to add a new variable outside of the GraphData loop, modifying its value each time the segmentAngle value has been calculated.

// ArcChart.kt

@Composable
fun ArcChart(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    chartData: List<GraphData>
) {

    val sumOfDataSet = remember(chartData) { 
		chartData.sumOf { it.value } 
	}

    Canvas(
        modifier = Modifier.size(240.dp)
    ) {
        
        val radius = size.width / 2
		var currentSegment = 0f

        chartData.forEach { chartData ->
            val segmentAngle = 360 * 
				chartData.value / sumOfDataSet

			// draw segment

            currentSegment += segmentAngle
        }
    }
}

Now that we have both the current segment angle and the total drawn angle, we can use these values to draw the segment. Weâ€™re going to be provided 4 different values to the drawArc function to draw the segment:

  • color - the Color to be used when drawing the arc. For this, weâ€™ll provide the Color value for the corresponding GraphData entry.
  • startAngle - the starting angle for drawing the arc, is going to be equal to the end of the previously drawn arc. We previously declared the currentSegment variable which is being used to keep a track of the total angle of the graph that has currently been drawn. Weâ€™re always going to want to start drawing at this value, as it represents the end of the previously drawn segment.
  • sweepAngle - the angle of the arc to be drawn. We are currently calculating the angle of the corresponding GraphData in the form of the segmentAngle variable - so for this, weâ€™ll directly pass this value.
  • useCenter - this value is used to declare whether the arc should close at the center of the corresponding area. 
// ArcChart.kt

@Composable
fun ArcChart(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    chartData: List<GraphData>,
    useCenter: Boolean
) {

    val sumOfDataSet = remember(chartData) { 
		chartData.sumOf { it.value } 
	}

    Canvas(
        modifier = Modifier.size(240.dp)
    ) {
        var currentSegment = 0f
        val radius = size.width / 2
        val totalAngle = 360

        chartData.forEach { chartData ->
            val segmentAngle = totalAngle * 
				chartData.value / sumOfDataSet
            drawArc(
				color = chartData.color,
                startAngle = currentSegment,
                sweepAngle = segmentAngle.toFloat(),
                useCenter = useCenter
            )
            currentSegment += segmentAngle
        }
    }
}

With the above in place, weâ€™ll be able to see a graph being drawn, but it is currently not looking quite like how we would expect.

We can see that a circular graph is being drawn, but the segments donâ€™t quite match up to what weâ€™d expect. The values we have calculated for the graph are correct, but weâ€™re missing some information for the drawArc function that will help to ensure the graph is being drawn correctly. This information is to be provided in the form of the DrawStyle class, which is used to declare how a shape should be drawn within a canvas. This information is going to look different depending on the type of circular graph that is being drawn, so weâ€™re going to allow this to be passed into the ArcChart composable function. Weâ€™ll then want to pass this value directly to the drawArc function.

// ArcChart.kt

@Composable
fun ArcChart(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    chartData: List<GraphData>,
    style: DrawStyle
) {
    val sumOfDataSet = remember(chartData) { 
		chartData.sumOf { it.value } 
	}

    Canvas(
        modifier = Modifier.size(240.dp)
    ) {
        var currentSegment = 0f
        val totalAngle = 360

        chartData.forEach { chartData ->
            val segmentAngle = totalAngle * 
				chartData.value / sumOfDataSet
            drawArc(
                color = chartData.color,
                startAngle = currentSegment,
                sweepAngle = segmentAngle.toFloat(),
                useCenter = useCenter,
                style = style
            )
            currentSegment += segmentAngle
        }
    }
}

Within the preview of our composable, we can now provide a reference to a DrawStyle to be used for the composition of the graph. For this first type of arc graph, weâ€™re going to be drawing a doughnut chart - this means that each segment should only have a specific width, as opposed to it filling the whole circle area within the canvas. To create this effect weâ€™re going to use the Stroke style, this allows us to draw each segment of the graph as a stroke. Because weâ€™re drawing a graph, weâ€™re going to want this to be quite thick - so weâ€™ll provide a value of 150dp for the width argument of the Stroke. Weâ€™ll then be able to view a doughnut graph within Android Studio for the preview of our composable.

@Preview(showBackground = true)
@Composable
fun Preview_DoughnutChart() {
    MaterialTheme {
		ArcChart(
        	chartData = chartData,
        	useCenter = true,
        	style = Stroke(width = 150f)
    	)
	}
}

Displaying data labels

Now that we have the visuals of the graph drawn on the canvas, weâ€™re next going to want to display the data values as labels on the graph - this allows us to communicate the actual values of the data set, as opposed to relying on the visual representation. So that we can draw this text on the canvas, weâ€™re going to start by defining the Paint reference that will be used for this drawing. Sot that this is persisted across compositions weâ€™ll go ahead and wrap this in a remember block.

val labelTextPaint = remember { Paint() }

Weâ€™re going to want to apply some specific styling to how the text is drawn on the canvas, so weâ€™ll configure both the textAlign and typeface properties. Weâ€™ll want to align the text in the center wherever it is drawn, along with applying a BOLD weighting to the applied typeface.

val labelTextPaint = remember {
	Paint().apply {
		textAlign = Paint.Align.CENTER
        typeface = Typeface.create(Typeface.DEFAULT, 				Typeface.BOLD)
    }
}

Weâ€™re also going to want to apply a specific sizing to the label, so weâ€™ll start by adding this font size to our dimens.xml file.

<dimen name="label_size">12sp</dimen>

We can then retrieve this from our resources and assign the value directly to the textSize property.

val labelTextSize = LocalContext.current.resources
	.getDimensionPixelSize(R.dimen.label_size)

val labelTextPaint = remember {
	Paint().apply {
		textSize = labelTextSize.toFloat()
		textAlign = Paint.Align.CENTER
        typeface = Typeface.create(Typeface.DEFAULT, 				Typeface.BOLD)
    }
}

We donâ€™t need to configure this information for every different label that is being drawn in the canvas, so we can place this code at the very top of our composable.

// ArcChart.kt

@Composable
fun ArcChart(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    chartData: List<GraphData>,
    useCenter: Boolean,
    style: DrawStyle,
    outerMargin: Float = 0f
) {
    val labelTextSize = LocalContext.current.resources
		.getDimensionPixelSize(R.dimen.label_size)

    val labelTextPaint = remember {
        Paint().apply {
            textSize = labelTextSize.toFloat()
            textAlign = Paint.Align.CENTER
            typeface = Typeface.create(Typeface.DEFAULT, 				Typeface.BOLD)
        }
    }

    ...
}

Now that we have the Paint reference configured for the drawing of the label, weâ€™re going to move on to drawing the data labels onto the canvas - allowing us to show information next to the visual representation of the data set. When it comes to drawing these labels, weâ€™re going to be displaying them outside of the radius of the graph, central to each corresponding segment.

To start, weâ€™re going to need to first calculate how we are going to be drawing the text outside of the graph. For this, we need to know the radius, as well as define a border (in the form of padding) that will ensure our text is not pressed up against the graph (as to keep it readable for the user).

When it comes to defining the border, weâ€™re going to use a dp value to represent this padding, but weâ€™ll need it in a pixel format as we are drawing on the canvas. For this, weâ€™ll utilise the LocalDensity provider which will provide us with a pixel value in relation to the corresponding density on the device.

val radius = size.width / 2
val radiusBorder = with(LocalDensity.current) { 24.dp.toPx() }
val radiusWithBorder = radius + radiusBorder

So that we can calculate where the label is to be drawn, weâ€™re going to need to write some mathematical logic to calculate the required positions. We wonâ€™t go too much into the how/why of this logic as weâ€™ll stray from the focus of Jetpack Compose specifics.

To start, we need to find the median angle of the segment - this is the halfway point for the current segment that we are drawing the label for. To calculate this we can take the current total segment value that was previously being calculated, followed by subtracting the 1/2 of the current segment that is being drawn (this is because we want to draw in the middle of this current segment). We then multiple this by PI and divide it by 180 (half of the radius of a circle). This calculation gives us the median angle that we need to draw at.

val medianAngle = (currentSegment - (segmentAngle / 2)) * Math.PI / 180f

Now that we have this median angle, we need to calculate the x and y coordinates that we are drawing the label at. When it comes to working out these coordinates for the edge of a circle, we can utilise the concept of Sine and Cosine. Using the built-in Kotlin functions for this math theory, we can use the cos function to calculate the x-coordinate, along with the sin function for the y-coordinate. Weâ€™ll use our already calculated radius values in the calculation for this logic, giving us the required coordinates for drawing the labels in their respective place on the canvas. The radius values will ensure that we are drawing on the outside of the graph, while the cos and sin calculated angles will ensure we are drawing at the correct angle for the corresponding segment.

val drawAtX =
	(radiusWithBorder * cos(medianAngle)).toFloat() + radius
val drawAtY =
	(radiusWithBorder * sin(medianAngle)).toFloat() + radius

So that we can draw, weâ€™re going to need to drop into the NativeCanvas - text cannot be drawn directly into the Canvas within compose, so retrieving the NativeCanvas reference gives us access to the drawText function. For this we need to provide:

  • text - the label that is being drawn onto the canvas
  • x - the x-coordinate of the label, this is always going to equal 0 as we are always drawing at the start of the canvas
  • y - the y-coordinate of the label, this is going to be the drawAtY that we just calculated
  • paint - the Paint reference used to draw the label, which is the textPaint being provided to the function
// ArcChart.kt

@Composable
fun ArcChart(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    chartData: List<GraphData>,
    useCenter: Boolean,
    style: DrawStyle
) {
   
    val radiusBorder = with(LocalDensity.current) { 
		24.dp.toPx() 
	}

    ...

    Column(
        modifier = modifier,
        horizontalAlignment = Alignment.CenterHorizontally,
        verticalArrangement = Arrangement.SpaceEvenly
    ) {
        Canvas(
            modifier = Modifier.size(240.dp)
        ) {
            var currentSegment = 0f
            val radius = size.width / 2
            val totalAngle = 360

            chartData.forEach { chartData ->
                ...

                drawIntoCanvas {
                    val medianAngle = (currentSegment - 
						(segmentAngle / 2)) * Math.PI / 180f
                    val radiusWithBorder = 
						radius + radiusBorder
                    val drawAtX = (radiusWithBorder * 							cos(medianAngle)).toFloat() + radius
                    val drawAtY = (radiusWithBorder * 							sin(medianAngle)).toFloat() + radius
                    it.nativeCanvas.drawText(
                        chartData.value.toString(),
                        drawAtX,
                        drawAtY,
                        labelTextPaint
                    )
                }
            }
        }
    }
}

Weâ€™re going to make one small tweak here so that a composable utilising the ArcChart can provide its margin to be applied outside of the graph - weâ€™re going to be creating a Pie and Doughnut chart using this composable, so the spacings for each will need to be different. To account for this weâ€™ll add a new argument to the composable function in the form of a Float called outerMargin. Weâ€™ll then slot this value into the drawAtX and drawAtY values that we calculated for the drawing of our labels.

val drawAtX = ((radiusWithBorder + outerMargin) * 		
	cos(medianAngle)).toFloat() + radius
val drawAtY = ((radiusWithBorder + outerMargin) * 
	sin(medianAngle)).toFloat() + radius

We can now update this code within the ArcChart composable, giving us a complete composable function for drawing Arc graphs.

// ArcChart.kt

@Composable
fun ArcChart(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    chartData: List<GraphData>,
    useCenter: Boolean,
    style: DrawStyle,
    outerMargin: Float = 0f
) {
    val labelTextSize = LocalContext.current.resources
		.getDimensionPixelSize(R.dimen.label_size)

    val radiusBorder = with(LocalDensity.current) { 
		24.dp.toPx() 
	}

    val labelTextPaint = remember {
        Paint().apply {
            textSize = labelTextSize.toFloat()
            textAlign = Paint.Align.CENTER
            typeface = Typeface.create(Typeface.DEFAULT, 				Typeface.BOLD)
        }
    }

    val sumOfDataSet = remember(chartData) { 
		chartData.sumOf { it.value } 
	}

    Column(
        modifier = modifier,
        horizontalAlignment = Alignment.CenterHorizontally,
        verticalArrangement = Arrangement.SpaceEvenly
    ) {
        Canvas(
            modifier = Modifier.size(240.dp)
        ) {
            var currentSegment = 0f
            val radius = size.width / 2
            val totalAngle = 360

            chartData.forEach { chartData ->
                val segmentAngle = totalAngle * 							chartData.value / sumOfDataSet
                drawArc(
                    color = chartData.color,
                    startAngle = currentSegment,
                    sweepAngle = segmentAngle.toFloat(),
                    useCenter = useCenter,
                    style = style
                )
                currentSegment += segmentAngle

                drawIntoCanvas {
                    val medianAngle = (currentSegment - 
						(segmentAngle / 2)) * Math.PI / 180f
                    val radiusWithBorder = radius + 							radiusBorder
                    val drawAtX =
                        ((radiusWithBorder + outerMargin) * 					cos(medianAngle)).toFloat() + radius
                    val drawAtY =
                        ((radiusWithBorder + outerMargin) * 					sin(medianAngle)).toFloat() + radius
                    it.nativeCanvas.drawText(
                        chartData.value.toString(),
                        drawAtX,
                        drawAtY,
                        labelTextPaint
                    )
                }
            }
        }
    }
}

Animating the Arc

Now that the arc graph is being drawn, we can look at going one step further here and animating the values when they are being drawn. For this, weâ€™re going to be utilising the Animatable class. This class allow us to animate between values, which is perfect for when we are drawing at a set of given coordinates on the canvas. This function is going to take a list of GraphData references for drawing the data, along with returning an Animatable reference that contains the Float value that is being animated. The Animatable type defines two contained types, of which weâ€™ll define AnimationVector1D for the second - this class is used to define a single float value during the animation, which in our case is all we need when working with animated values. 

//animationUtil.kt

@Composable
fun configureAnimation(
    chartData: List<GraphData>
): Animatable<Float, AnimationVector1D> {
    
}

Next, weâ€™ll need to define the animation itself. Here weâ€™ll instantiate the Animatable class, providing an initial value of 0f for the starting point of the animation. Weâ€™ll also wrap this in the remember function, using the provided chartData reference as the key.

//animationUtil.kt

@Composable
fun configureAnimation(
    chartData: List<GraphData>
): Animatable<Float, AnimationVector1D> {
    val transitionAnimation = remember(chartData) {
        Animatable(
            initialValue = 0f
        )
    }
    return transitionAnimation
}

ðŸ’¡ Passing a key value here allows us to define that the contained block should be remembered across compositions, only needing to change if the value of the provided key is changed.

Now that the animation is defined weâ€™re going to want to start the animation. When it comes to the animated value, weâ€™re simply going to want to animate from the initial value of 0f up until a value of 1f. Weâ€™ll start this animation using the animateTo function, for which weâ€™ll also override the default AnimationSpec. Here weâ€™ll use the TweenSpec class with an animation duration of 750 milliseconds - this allows us to achieve a smoother animation effect compared to the default SpringSpec. Weâ€™ll also wrap this animation in a LaunchedEffect block, meaning that the animation is only launched within the initial composition, only ever relaunching if the provided key has changed (which we are again using the provided chartData reference for.

//animationUtil.kt

@Composable
fun configureAnimation(
    chartData: List<GraphData>
): Animatable<Float, AnimationVector1D> {
    val transitionAnimation = remember(chartData) {
        Animatable(
            initialValue = 0f
        )
    }
    LaunchedEffect(chartData) {
        transitionAnimation.animateTo(
            1f,
            animationSpec = TweenSpec(durationMillis = 750)
        )
    }
    return transitionAnimation
}

With this animation defined, we can now plug this into our ArcChart composable.

// ArcChart.kt

@Composable
fun ArcChart(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    chartData: List<GraphData>,
    useCenter: Boolean,
    style: DrawStyle,
    outerMargin: Float = 0f
) {
    val transitionAnimation = configureAnimation(chartData)
}

Weâ€™re going to utilise this in a few places, but weâ€™ll start by animating the text that is being drawn onto the canvas. For the Paint reference being created for the graph labels, weâ€™re going to apply an alpha value using the calculated animation value. The alpha value of the text can be any value between 0 and 255, so weâ€™re going to need to calculate this value based on the current transition value. Weâ€™ll want this to be calculated as a percentage representation - so weâ€™ll start by dividing the maximum value of 255 by 100. Next, because our transition value is going to be between 0 and 1, weâ€™ll want to multiply this by 100 to get a 0-100 percent representation. We can then take this value and use it to multiple the initial division that we performed. The result of this gives us the alpha that is to be applied to the painted text.

// ArcChart.kt

@Composable
fun ArcChart(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    chartData: List<GraphData>,
    useCenter: Boolean,
    style: DrawStyle,
    outerMargin: Float = 0f
) {
    val transitionAnimation = configureAnimation(chartData)
    val labelTextSize = LocalContext.current.resources
		.getDimensionPixelSize(R.dimen.label_size)
    val radiusBorder = with(LocalDensity.current) { 
		24.dp.toPx() 
	}
    val labelTextPaint = remember {
        Paint().apply {
            textSize = labelTextSize.toFloat()
            textAlign = Paint.Align.CENTER
            typeface = Typeface.create(Typeface.DEFAULT, 				Typeface.BOLD)
        }
    }.apply {
        alpha = ((255 / 100) * 
			(transitionAnimation.value * 100)).toInt()
    }
	...
}

Next, weâ€™ll want to modify the drawing logic so that this animated value is also being applied when the segments of the graph are being drawn. To calculate this value, we can reuse the existing logic that we had defined for the segmentAngle value - the only difference here is going to be that the value is drawn from the corresponding GraphData reference needs to be modified to take the transition value into account. Because our transition value is going to represent an animated value between 0 and 1, we can multiple the GraphData value by this, which will, in turn, animate the overall size of the angle that is being drawn.

val angleToDraw = totalAngle * (chartData.value * transitionAnimation.value) / sumOfDataSet

Now that we have this animated segment size in place, weâ€™re going to need to make a few more adjustments to the values passed to the drawArc function. Now, we need to keep the previous segmentAngle variable in place because weâ€™re going to need this later when it comes to drawing labels on the graph, so weâ€™ll continue to add the calculated variables to currentSegment. So that we have an animated tracker variable for the segments, weâ€™ll create a new variable currentStartAngle which will be used to keep a track of the total segment sizes that have been drawn, but in an animated fashion. This means that the drawing of the whole graph will be animated and the segments will be drawn one by one, filling up the arc graph as the animation is seen through. After the drawing of every arc, weâ€™ll add the calculated value of angleToDraw to this currentStartAngle tracker variable. With this in place, weâ€™ll need to update the value that is being passed for the startAngle argument - this is now going to be passed as the currentStartAngle variable. This means that the startAngle for each segment will now be animated.

With this new angleToDraw variable, we can now pass this for the sweepAngle argument of the drawArc function. This will define the size of the arc, using the animated value that we previously defined. This means that when the transition is running, the sweepAngle property will animate to its final state.

// ArcChart.kt

@Composable
fun ArcChart(
    ...
) {
    ...

    Column(
        modifier = modifier,
        horizontalAlignment = Alignment.CenterHorizontally,
        verticalArrangement = Arrangement.SpaceEvenly
    ) {
        Canvas(
            modifier = Modifier.size(240.dp)
        ) {
            var currentSegment = 0f
            var currentStartAngle = 0f
            val radius = size.width / 2
            val totalAngle = 360

            chartData.forEach { chartData ->
                val segmentAngle = totalAngle * 							chartData.value / sumOfDataSet

                val angleToDraw = totalAngle * 
					(chartData.value * transitionAnimation.value) / sumOfDataSet

                drawArc(
                    color = chartData.color,
                    startAngle = currentStartAngle,
                    sweepAngle = angleToDraw,
                    useCenter = useCenter,
                    style = style
                )
                currentSegment += segmentAngle
                currentStartAngle += angleToDraw
            }
        }
    }
}

With these variables in place, the values of the arc and arc segments are now being completely animated. While you wonâ€™t be able to see this in the composable preview, running this on a device will show the arc graph filling up its entire radius in an animated fashion, drawing each segment as the arc is filled.

Creating a Graph Legend

Now that we have the data being displayed within the circular graph, weâ€™re next going to create a legend that will be used to display the labels for the corresponding data in the graph.

Weâ€™re going to start here by creating a new composable function, LegendItem, which will be used to represent each of the items within the legend. This composable will take a reference to a GraphData which will be used to compose the corresponding label.

// LegendItem.kt

@Composable
fun LegendItem(
	modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
	data: GraphData
) {

}

As seen in the design above, weâ€™re going to be showing a box representing the color of the item in the graph along with the Text composable to display the label for the GraphData reference. To contain these components weâ€™re going to define a Row so that we can compose these items alongside one another, weâ€™ll also want to center these on the vertical axis using CenterVertically.

// LegendItem.kt

@Composable
fun LegendItem(
	modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
	data: GraphData
) {
    Row(
        modifier = modifier.padding(12.dp),
        verticalAlignment = Alignment.CenterVertically
    ) {
        
    }
}

Weâ€™ll start by adding the small square that represents the color of the data entry for our graph - this is so that the representation in the graph can be matched against the information being displayed in the legend. For this, we can use a Box composable, fixing the size as 12dp and setting the background of the composable to the color in the provided GraphData reference.

// LegendItem.kt

@Composable
fun LegendItem(
	modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
	data: GraphData
) {
    Row(
        modifier = Modifier.padding(12.dp),
        verticalAlignment = Alignment.CenterVertically
    ) {
        Box(
            modifier = Modifier
                .size(12.dp)
                .background(data.color)
        )
    }
}

Next, weâ€™ll compose a Text that will be used to represent the information for the GraphData entry. For this weâ€™ll simply use the label property from the reference, using a Spacer to create a visual separation between the Box and Text composables.

// LegendItem.kt

@Composable
fun LegendItem(
	modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
	data: GraphData
) {
    Row(
        modifier = Modifier.padding(12.dp),
        verticalAlignment = Alignment.CenterVertically
    ) {
        Box(
            modifier = Modifier
                .size(12.dp)
                .background(data.color)
        )
        Spacer(modifier = Modifier.width(8.dp))
        Text(text = data.label)
    }
}

As the last step here, weâ€™ll go ahead and utilise the semantics modifier and merge the descendants of the container using the mergeDescendants flag. This means that when the composable is focused by screen readers, a single element will be communicated as opposed to the individual children, making it smoother to navigate around our UI when using accessibility services.

// LegendItem.kt

@Composable
fun LegendItem(
	modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
	data: GraphData
) {
    Row(
        modifier = modifier.padding(12.dp)
			.semantics(mergeDescendants = true) { },
        verticalAlignment = Alignment.CenterVertically
    ) {
        Box(
            modifier = Modifier
                .size(12.dp)
                .background(data.color)
        )
        Spacer(modifier = Modifier.width(8.dp))
        Text(text = data.label)
    }
}

Now that we have the LegendItem composable in place, we can think about composing a collection of these for the corresponding GraphData list.

For this weâ€™re going to compose a new component in the form of a Legend composable, this will take a collection of GraphData as an argument.

// Legend.kt

@Composable
fun Legend(
	modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
	chartData: List<GraphData>
)

Weâ€™re next going to want to create a grid layout for the GraphData items. While we have solutions like the LazyGrid available (that is currently in an experimental state), weâ€™re working with a very simple dataset and layout so weâ€™re going to recreate this using a simple Column and Row solution.

Starting by composing a Column, we can use the Kotlin chunked function to split our chartData into a collection of sized groups. For each of these groups, weâ€™re going to compose a Row with 2 LegendItem composables, one for each of the items in our chunked set.

// Legend.kt

@Composable
fun Legend(
	modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
	chartData: List<GraphData>
) {
    Column(modifier = modifier) {
        chartData.chunked(2).forEach { row ->
            Row {
                LegendItem(row[0])
                LegendItem(row[1])
            }
        }
    }
}

With this in place, we now have a Legend composable that can be used to show the data for a provided GraphData collection.

Applying the Legend to the Arc Graph

Now that we have our Legend composable, weâ€™re going to hop on back over to the ArcChart composable and modify it to display the legend for a given dataset. Here weâ€™ll simply compose the Legend as the last child of the Column container, passing in the collection of GraphData references that are provided to the ArcChart composable. Weâ€™ll also use the Spacer composable to create some visual space between the legend and the chart.

// ArcChart.kt

@Composable
fun ArcChart(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    chartData: List<GraphData>,
    useCenter: Boolean,
    style: DrawStyle,
    outerMargin: Float = 0f
) {
    ...

    Column(
        modifier = modifier,
        horizontalAlignment = Alignment.CenterHorizontally,
        verticalArrangement = Arrangement.SpaceEvenly
    ) {
        ...
        Spacer(modifier = Modifier.height(36.dp))
        Legend(chartData = chartData)
    }
}

Composing the Doughnut Chart

Now that our arc composable is complete, we can go ahead and configure this specifically for the different circular graph types that we want to create. For the preview of the composable we previously composed a doughnut graph, so weâ€™re going to transfer this preview code into a composable that can be plugged directly into our UI. For this, weâ€™re going to need to create a new composable function that can take the provided GraphData and compose the graph from it.

// DoughnutChart.kt

@Composable
fun DoughnutChart(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    chartData: List<GraphData>
)

Weâ€™ll then take the ArcChart composition that we previously used to preview the graph, composing it inside of this new DoughnutChart composable.

// DoughnutChart.kt

@Composable
fun DoughnutChart(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    chartData: List<GraphData>
) {
    ArcChart(
        modifier = modifier,
        chartData = chartData,
        useCenter = false,
        style = Stroke(150f, cap = StrokeCap.Butt),
        outerMargin = 70f
    )
}

With this, we now have a DoughnutChart composable that can be used to compose a doughnut chart for a given data set.

Composing the Pie Chart

While we now have the doughnut chart in place, weâ€™re going to reuse the existing ArcChart composable to create a similar kind of chart - a pie chart. Weâ€™ll create a new composable function, PieChart, that will again take the provided GraphData and compose the graph from it. 

// PieChart.kt

@Composable
fun PieChart(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    chartData: List<GraphData>
)

Within this composable, weâ€™re then going to want to compose an ArcChart. Similar to the doughnut chart, weâ€™re going to directly pass in the provided modifier and chartData arguments. When it comes to the pie chart, there are going to be a couple of key differences:

  • useCenter - for this weâ€™re going to pass a value of true, instead of false. This is because the segments of a pie chart fill the available space, so weâ€™re going to want the bounds to close at the center of the canvas.
  • style - unlike the doughnut chart, the segments of the pie chart fill the available space. While the useCenter flag implies that we draw to the center of the canvas, we want the styling we use to fill all of that available space. For this reason we pass the Fill draw style to declare that the segment should be drawn filled with the specified color.
// PieChart.kt

@Composable
fun PieChart(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    chartData: List<GraphData>
) {
    ArcChart(
        modifier = modifier,
        chartData = chartData,
        useCenter = true,
        style = Fill
    )
}

With this, we now have a PieChart composable that can be used to compose a doughnut chart for a given data set.

Line Graph

Now that weâ€™ve covered the pie and doughnut charts, weâ€™re going to move on to a different kind of visual representation for our data - the line graph. This composable will take our data set, composing a line graph based on the data that is provided to it.

Weâ€™ll start here by creating a new composable function, LineChart. Similar to our previously created composable functions, this is going to take a collection of GraphData references that will be used to compose the graph data.

// LineChart.kt

@Composable
fun LineChart(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    chartData: List<GraphData>
)

For the previous chart types, we composed a Canvas using predefined sizing - this was due to the canvas being unaware of the size of its contents (and therefore not knowing how much space to occupy). Weâ€™ll do a similar thing for our line graph, filling the maximum available width and hardcoding the occupied height.

// LineChart.kt

@Composable
fun LineChart(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    chartData: List<GraphData>
) {
    Canvas(
        modifier = modifier
            .height(320.dp)
            .fillMaxWidth()
            .padding(36.dp)
    ) {
       
    }
}

Drawing axis lines

Now that we have the Canvas in place, weâ€™re going to start by drawing the X and Y axis of our graph. The line graph is just one type of graph we will be drawing that uses the X and Y axis, so weâ€™re going to place this logic inside of a reusable function that can be utilised by the other graphs that we are going to be creating. Because we are only going to be utilising this function inside of the canvas, we can scope this using DrawScope. This function is going to take a startPadding argument, that will be used to ensure the axis is drawn after the text label.

// drawingUtil.kt

fun DrawScope.drawAxis(startPadding: Float = 0f) {

}

With this scope in place, it means that we can utilise the functions that are available to the Canvas via this scoping. When it comes to drawing the axis, this means that we can utilise the DrawScope scoped drawLine function.

// drawingUtil.kt

fun DrawScope.drawAxis(startPadding: Float = 0f) {
    drawLine(
        ...
    )
    drawLine(
        ...
    )
}

This function takes a collection of arguments to draw a line, several of which are required.

  • color - this required argument specifies the color to be used when drawing the line
  • start - this required argument specifies the Offset at which the drawing should begin
  • end - this required argument specifies the Offset at which the drawing should end

When it comes to the color of the line, weâ€™re simply going to be using the color black. For this argument, weâ€™ll pass in the Color.Black reference.

// drawingUtil.kt

fun DrawScope.drawAxis(startPadding: Float = 0f) {
    drawLine(
        color = Color.Black,
		...
    )
    drawLine(
        color = Color.Black,
		...
    )
}

Next up weâ€™re going to define the start position for drawing the axis. This argument requires an Offset which defines the X and Y coordinates to be used for the drawing. For both axis, the start position is going to be identical - this is because both drawing points are going to start at the bottom left corner of the graph. For each Offset weâ€™re going to provide the following values:

  • x - for the x coordinate weâ€™re going to want to start at the beginning of the canvas x-axis. The start of the canvas has a coordinate value of 0, but we donâ€™t want to draw right against the edge of the canvas so that we allow for the text label to be drawn before the axis. For this, we can pass the startPadding value for the x-coordinate of the Offset.
  • y - for the y coordinate weâ€™re going to need to provide a value that starts the drawing again at the bottom left corner of the canvas, minus the previously defined padding value. For the y-axis of the canvas, the top is equal to 0 - so weâ€™re going to take the height of the canvas and subtract the defined padding value.
// drawingUtil.kt

val padding = 16.dp.value

fun DrawScope.drawAxis(startPadding: Float = 0f) {
    drawLine(
        color = Color.Black,
        start = Offset(
            x = startPadding + padding,
            y = size.height - padding
        ),
		...
    )
    drawLine(
        color = Color.Black,
        start = Offset(
            x = startPadding + padding,
            y = size.height - padding
        ),
        ...
    )
}

With the start positions in place, we can now go ahead and define the end Offset for each of the lines. For the first drawLine operation we are drawing the x-axis, so the end is going to need to represent a value at the end of the horizontal axis of the canvas. Because this line is horizontal along the axis, the y value is going to remain the same as what we defined for the start Offset. However, the x coordinate used for the end Offset is going to need to represent a value at the end of the horizontal axis of the canvas. This value is going to equal the width of the canvas, minus the padding that we defined for our graph.

// drawingUtil.kt

val padding = 16.dp.value

fun DrawScope.drawAxis(startPadding: Float = 0f) {
    drawLine(
        color = Color.Black,
        start = Offset(
            x = startPadding + padding,
            y = size.height - padding
        ),
        end = Offset(
            x = size.width - padding,
            y = size.height - padding
        )
    )
    ...
}

For the second drawLine operation weâ€™re going to be drawing the line for the y-axis. For the end Offset weâ€™re simply going to want to be drawing a vertical line up until the top left-hand corner of the canvas. For this Offset the x coordinate is going to be the same as the starting offset coordinate, which is the padding value that we previously defined. For the y-coordinate weâ€™re going to want to draw up until the padding of the canvas top, so we will also need to use the padding value for the y-coordinate.

// drawingUtil.kt

val padding = 16.dp.value

fun DrawScope.drawAxis(startPadding: Float = 0f) {
    ...
    drawLine(
        color = Color.Black,
        start = Offset(
            x = startPadding + padding,
            y = size.height - padding
        ),
        end = Offset(
            x = padding,
            y = padding
        )
    )
}

At this point we have a function that will allow us to draw the axis lines onto our canvas, weâ€™re just going to make one small change before moving forward. The drawLine function also allows us to provide the width to be used for the stroke of the line, so weâ€™re going to define a custom value here to use for this. Weâ€™ll create a new variable strokeThickness, followed by passing this to each of the drawLine calls for its strokeWidth argument.

// drawingUtil.kt

val padding = 16.dp.value
val strokeThickness = 2.dp.value

fun DrawScope.drawAxis(startPadding: Float = 0f) {
    drawLine(
        strokeWidth = strokeThickness,
        color = Color.Black,
        start = Offset(
            x = startPadding + padding,
            y = size.height - padding
        ),
        end = Offset(
            x = size.width - startPadding,
            y = size.height - padding
        )
    )
    drawLine(
        strokeWidth = strokeThickness,
        color = Color.Black,
        start = Offset(
            x = startPadding + padding,
            y = size.height - padding
        ),
        end = Offset(
            x = startPadding + padding,
            y = padding
        )
    )
}

We can now utilise this drawAxis operation inside of the Canvas. When calling this weâ€™ll need to pass a value to be used for the startPadding, so weâ€™ll need to calculate the width of the longest text label. Weâ€™ll do this by fetching the longest label from our chartData collection, followed by measuring it. We can then pass the result of this directly to the drawAxis call.

// LineChart.kt

@Composable
fun LineChart(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    chartData: List<GraphData>
) {

	val longestLabel = chartData.maxByOrNull { 
		it.label.length 
	}!!.label
    val labelTextPaint = labelTextPaint(context.resources)
    val labelWidth = labelTextPaint.measureText(longestLabel)

    Canvas(
        modifier = modifier
            .height(320.dp)
            .fillMaxWidth()
            .padding(36.dp)
    ) {
        drawAxis(labelWidth)
    }
}

Drawing y-axis labels

Now that we have the axis being drawn on the canvas, we now have a frame to draw the data labels against. These labels will help to correlate the drawn lines of our graph against the data set that is being used to draw it.

Weâ€™re going to start here by drawing the data labels for the y-axis, for which weâ€™ll create a new function drawValueLabelsOnYAxis again scoped using DrawScope. Weâ€™re again placing this logic into a reusable function so that it can be reused for other graphs that weâ€™ll be creating.

// drawingUtil.kt

fun DrawScope.drawValueLabelsOnYAxis() {

}

Here weâ€™re going to want to draw the value for each data entry so that the points in our line graph have a corresponding value on the vertical axis. So that we know how many data labels we need to draw weâ€™re going to need to pass in the count of the labels to be drawn (this will essentially be the count for the number of entries in the data set). With this value, weâ€™re then going to want to draw a label on the canvas for each of these, so weâ€™ll need to perform a loop on the provided value. Weâ€™re also going to utilise the drawIntoCanvas function so that we have access to text drawing capabilities for the Canvas composable.

// drawingUtil.kt

fun DrawScope.drawValueLabelsOnYAxis(
	labelCount: Int
) {
    for (value in labelCount downTo 0) {
        drawIntoCanvas {
            
        }
    }
}

When it comes to the drawing of graph values on the y-axis, we arenâ€™t going to be drawing the values that are contained within our data set. Instead, as outlined in the screenshot from above, weâ€™re going to be displaying evenly spaced values that the graph points will be plotted against. Using the provided label count, weâ€™re going to calculate these values that are to be drawn for the y-axis.

For this calculation, weâ€™re going to need to add another argument to our function. This value is going to represent the highest value from our graph dataset, as this will be used to know the highest point that is going to be displayed on our graph axis. Using this alongside the provided label count, we can calculate the position of the label to be drawn on the y-axis.

// drawingUtil.kt

fun DrawScope.drawValueLabelsOnYAxis(
    maximumValueToDisplay: Int,
    labelCount: Int
) {
    for (value in labelCount downTo 0) {
        drawIntoCanvas {
            val valueToDraw =
                ((maximumValueToDisplay / labelCount) * 			(labelCount - value)).toString()
        }
    }
}

Now that we have the above calculation in place, we can start to think about the drawing of the labels. For this, weâ€™re going to need to configure a Paint instance, similar to how we did for the arc chart. Weâ€™re going to be using similar Paint references throughout our graphs, so weâ€™ll create a new function inside of a utility file that will allow us to reuse this logic throughout our code. 

// drawingUtils.kt

fun labelTextPaint(resources: Resources) = Paint().apply {
    textSize = resources.getDimensionPixelSize(
		R.dimen.label_size).toFloat()
    typeface = Typeface.create(Typeface.DEFAULT, Typeface.BOLD)
}

With this in place, we can also go back and update the code for our arc graph to reuse this logic. We can also now move on to the actual drawing of the label on the canvas. To do this weâ€™re going to need to calculate a couple of different values so that we can tell the canvas where the text is to be drawn.
