  • text bounds - weâ€™re going to need to know the space that the label is going to occupy on the canvas. This is so that we know how to space out the labels on the axis when they are being drawn.
  • y-coordinate to drawn at - once we have the bounds and the available height of the canvas, weâ€™ll be able to calculate exactly where on the canvas the label is to be drawn

Before we can move on to the actual placement of the text on the canvas, weâ€™ll need to calculate the bounds that the text will occupy. For this, we need the Resource reference that will be used to obtain the text Paint reference, so weâ€™ll add this as a new argument to our function.

// drawingUtil.kt

fun DrawScope.drawValueLabelsOnYAxis(
    maximumValueToDisplay: Int,
	labelCount: Int,
    resources: Resources
) {
	val textPaint = labelTextPaint(resources)
	...
}

Next, weâ€™ll use this to calculate the bounds for the label that is being drawn. For this, we can use the getTextBounds function to calculate the bounds for the entire label content.

// drawingUtil.kt

fun DrawScope.drawValueLabelsOnYAxis(
    maximumValueToDisplay: Int,
	labelCount: Int,
    resources: Resources
) {
	val textPaint = labelTextPaint(resources)
    for (value in labelCount downTo 0) {
        drawIntoCanvas {
            val valueToDraw =
                ((maximumValueToDisplay / labelCount) * 			(labelCount - value)).toString()

			val bounds = Rect().also { rect ->
                textPaint.getTextBounds(
					valueToDraw, 
					0, 				
					valueToDraw.length, 
					rect
				)
            }
        }
    }
}

Now that we have these bounds we can use these to calculate the y coordinate for each label that is being drawn. We want the drawn labels to be evenly spaced on the y-axis, starting at the very top of the y-axis line, until we hit 0 at the bottom. For this calculation, we first need to know the height that is available for this label drawing - this is going to be the height of the y-axis line, which is equivalent to the height of the canvas, subtracting two amounts of the value for the graph padding.

val availableHeight = size.height - (padding * 2)

Using this value we can now calculate the y-coordinate on the canvas where we going to be drawing the text. Because we are drawing this value within a loop, we need to have a calculation that will use the current loop value to evenly space the text labels on the y-axis. We can calculate this value by taking the available height that was calculated, dividing it by the labelCount that is provided to the function (this creates evenly sized segments based on the number of labels being displayed), and then multiplying this result by the current value of the loop. While we are initially calculating evenly sized segments here, we are using the current value of the loop to create the drawing position for the current label.

So that the label is drawn central to the current bounds, weâ€™ll add half of the label height to the calculated value, as well as the value of our padding so that the padding at the top of the canvas is accounted for.

// drawingUtil.kt

fun DrawScope.drawValueLabelsOnYAxis(
    maximumValueToDisplay: Int,
	labelCount: Int,
    resources: Resources
) {
	val textPaint = labelTextPaint(resources)
    for (value in labelCount downTo 0) {
        drawIntoCanvas {
            val valueToDraw =
                ((maximumValueToDisplay / labelCount) * 			(labelCount - value)).toString()

			val bounds = Rect().also { rect ->
                textPaint.getTextBounds(valueToDraw, 0, 				valueToDraw.length, rect)
            }
            val availableHeight = size.height - (padding * 2)
            val drawAtY = (
				(availableHeight / labelCount) * value) + padding + (bounds.height() / 2)
        }
    }
}

Now that we have the y-coordinate of our label calculated, we can go ahead and draw the text label onto the canvas. So that we can do this, weâ€™re going to need to drop into the NativeCanvas - text cannot be drawn directly into the Canvas within compose, so retrieving the NativeCanvas reference gives us access to the drawText function. For this we need to provide:

  • text - the label that is being drawn onto the canvas
  • x - the x-coordinate of the label, this is always going to equal 0 as we are always drawing at the start of the canvas
  • y - the y-coordinate of the label, this is going to be the drawAtY that we just calculated
  • paint - the Paint reference used to draw the label, which is the textPaint being provided to the function
// drawingUtil.kt

fun DrawScope.drawValueLabelsOnYAxis(
    maximumValueToDisplay: Int,
	labelCount: Int,
    resources: Resources
) {
	val textPaint = labelTextPaint(resources)
    for (value in labelCount downTo 0) {
        drawIntoCanvas {
            val valueToDraw =
                ((maximumValueToDisplay / labelCount) * 			(labelCount - value)).toString()

			val bounds = Rect().also { rect ->
                textPaint.getTextBounds(valueToDraw, 0, 				valueToDraw.length, rect)
            }
            val availableHeight = size.height - (padding * 2)
            val drawAtY = ((availableHeight /
				heightPointsToShow) * value) + padding + (bounds.height() / 2)
			it.nativeCanvas.drawText(
                valueToDraw,
                0f,
                drawAtY,
                textPaint
            )
        }
    }
}

Weâ€™re almost ready to draw the labels on our canvas, weâ€™ll just need to define the last few pieces of information so that we can call our new drawValueLabelsOnYAxis function. Weâ€™ll first need to calculate the highest value within the provided chartData, which we can do so using the kotlin maxOf function. 

val maximumValue = chartData.maxOf { it.value }

Next, we need to configure the Paint reference that will be used for the drawing of the text label. Weâ€™ll need to define a new Paint reference to be remembered across the composition, followed by assigning a textSize using the previously defined label_size (that we created for the previous graphs), followed by assigning a BOLD typeface for the styling of the text.

val labelTextSize = LocalContext.current.resources
	.getDimensionPixelSize(R.dimen.label_size)
val labelTextPaint = remember {
	Paint().apply {
		textSize = labelTextSize.toFloat()				
		typeface = Typeface.create(
			Typeface.DEFAULT, Typeface.BOLD)
	}
}

Along with the previously calculated maximumValue and data set size, this Paint reference can then be passed directly to the drawValueLabelsOnYAxis function. With this in place, we can now plug this function into our Canvas and see the labels drawn along the y-axis.

// LineChart.kt

@Composable
fun LineChart(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    chartData: List<GraphData>
) {
	val context = LocalContext.current
    Canvas(
        modifier = modifier
            .height(320.dp)
            .fillMaxWidth()
            .padding(36.dp)
    ) {
		val labelTextSize = LocalContext.current.resources
			.getDimensionPixelSize(R.dimen.label_size)
		val labelTextPaint = remember {
		    Paint().apply {
		        textSize = labelTextSize.toFloat()				typeface = Typeface.create(
					Typeface.DEFAULT, Typeface.BOLD)
		    }
		}
        val highestData = chartData.maxOf { it.value }

        drawAxis(labelWidth)

        drawValueLabelsOnYAxis(
			highestData, 
			chartData.count(), 
			context.resources
		)
    }
}

Drawing x-axis labels

With the labels for the y-axis in place, weâ€™re next going to want to draw the labels for the x-axis. Weâ€™re going to again start here by creating a reusable function for drawing labels on the x-axis, as we will be able to reuse this for other graphs. When it comes to the drawing of the x-axis labels, this is going to be done at the same time as drawing the data points on the graph - this makes the drawing of the labels simpler, as it can be done at the same time as drawing the data points on the graph.

Weâ€™re going to start here by creating a new function, drawDataLabelsOnXAxis, which will take three arguments:

  • label - the label to be drawn on the x-axis
  • widthSegment - the width of the segment being drawn in
  • index - the index of the current label being drawn
  • resources - a resources reference used for string operations
  • padding - padding to be applied to the drawing
// drawingUtil.kt

fun DrawScope.drawDataLabelsOnXAxis(
    label: String,
    widthSegment: Float,
    index: Int,
    resources: Resources,
    padding: Float
) {
    

}

With this information, we can now calculate the x-coordinate for the label to be drawn at. Because weâ€™re drawing our information segment-by-segment, we are going to be drawing in each segment one at a time using the index that is provided to the drawDataLabelsOnXAxis function. We can calculate this by taking the provided widthSegment value, and multiplying it by the provided index. Along with any providing padding/spacing values, we will also subtract half of the widthSegment value so that our coordinate is in the center of the segment.

val drawAtX = padding + strokeThickness + (widthSegment * index) + (widthSegment / 2)

For drawing the label weâ€™re again going to use the drawIntoCanvas function, this is where weâ€™ll handle the drawing of the label. When it comes to drawing, while we have the x-coordinate to be used for the label, weâ€™re going to need to modify this value so that we can draw the label at the center of its bounds. We can calculate this by subtracting half of the label width from the calculated drawAtX value.

// drawingUtil.kt

fun DrawScope.drawDataLabelsOnXAxis(
    label: String,
    widthSegment: Float,
    index: Int,
    resources: Resources,
    padding: Float
) {	
	val drawAtX = padding + strokeThickness + (widthSegment * index) + (widthSegment / 2)
    drawIntoCanvas {
        val textPaint = labelTextPaint(resources)
        val textWidth = textPaint.measureText(label)
        val centerX = drawAtX - (textWidth / 2)
    }
}

We can then again use the drawText function to draw the label onto the canvas. For this weâ€™ll need to provide several argument values:

  • text - the label to be drawn onto the canvas
  • x - the x-coordinate the label is to be drawn at. The is the half-point value that we just calculated
  • y - the y-coordinate the label is to be drawn at. We want to draw the label at the bottom of the y-axis, so for this, we can use the height of the canvas
  • paint - the Paint reference used to draw the label, which is being provided to the function
// drawingUtil.kt

fun DrawScope.drawDataLabelsOnXAxis(
    label: String,
    widthSegment: Float,
    index: Int,
    resources: Resources,
    padding: Float
) {
	val drawAtX = padding + strokeThickness + (widthSegment * index) + (widthSegment / 2)
    drawIntoCanvas {
        val textPaint = labelTextPaint(resources)
        val textWidth = textPaint.measureText(label)
        val centerX = drawAtX - (textWidth / 2)
        it.nativeCanvas.drawText(
			label, 
			centerX, 
			size.height, 
			textPaint
		)
    }
}

With this function now in place, we can plug this directly into our LineChart composable. Once the axis has been drawn, we can loop through the provided GraphData and draw each of the labels from the data set.

// LineChart.kt

@Composable
fun LineChart(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    chartData: List<GraphData>
) {
    ...

    Canvas(
        modifier = modifier
            .height(320.dp)
            .fillMaxWidth()
            .padding(36.dp)
    ) {
        val highestData = chartData.maxOf { it.value }

        val widthSegment = (size.width - (padding * 2)) / 
			chartData.count()

        drawAxis(labelWidth)

        chartData.forEachIndexed { index, chartData ->
            drawDataLabelsOnXAxis(
				chartData.label,
                widthSegment,
                index,
                context.resources,
                labelWidth + padding
			)
        }

        drawValueLabelsOnYAxis(
			highestData, 
			chartData.count(), 
			labelTextPaint
		)
    }
}

Drawing data values on the graph

Now that we have the axis and corresponding labels drawn, we can start to think about drawing the dataset values onto the graph. For our line graph, each entry in the data set is going to be represented by a circle, and then these circles will be joined together using a line. Weâ€™re going to start here by tackling the drawing of the circles for the set entries.

When it comes to drawing the circles, weâ€™re going to be utilising the drawCircle function when drawing inside the Canvas. For this function, weâ€™re going to need to provide several different values to the function.

  • color - the color to be used when drawing the circle. For this, weâ€™ll simply pass the Color value from the corresponding GraphData reference.
  • radius - the radius to be used when drawing the circle
  • center - the center point to be used when drawing the circle

For the radius and center values, weâ€™re going to need to provide some calculated values for drawing the circle. The center value takes the form of the Offset class - this class takes both an x and y coordinate to be used for drawing. For the x value we can utilise the drawAtX value that we previously calculated for the drawing of our data labels. For the y coordinate, weâ€™re going to need to calculate where on this axis our data value corresponds. We can calculate this by calculating how many equal segments there are within the height of the canvas - this can be calculated by taking the height of the canvas (minus the padding at the top of the bottom), and dividing this value by the highest value into the data set that we previously calculated. Now that we have the height of the segment, we can multiply this by the value within the corresponding GraphData reference to know how many segments the current value should occupy.

val heightSegment = (size.height - (padding * 2)) / highestData

Offset(
	drawAtX,
	heightSegment * chartData.value
)

With this calculation in place, we can now slot this into the drawCircle function call. The last thing we need to calculate now is the radius value.

drawCircle(
	chartData.color,
	radius = ...,
	center = Offset(
		drawAtX,
		heightSegment * chartData.value
	)
)

For the radius, weâ€™re going to have a statically defined circle size, which we will animate using the same transition logic that we defined earlier. Weâ€™ll start by using the configureAnimation function to instantiate and create a reference to the transition, followed by defining a size for the radius of the circle - weâ€™ll again use LocalDensity for this to create a density specific sizing.

@Composable
fun LineChart(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    chartData: List<GraphData>
) {
    val transitionAnimation = configureAnimation(chartData)
    val pointRadius = with(LocalDensity.current) { 
		10.dp.toPx() 
	}

    ...
}

With these in place, we can then calculate the radius by multiplying the pointRadius value by the current value of the transition.

radius = pointRadius * transitionAnimation.value

We can then slot this into the drawCircle function call, completing the logic used to draw and animate the circle points onto the canvas.

@Composable
fun LineChart(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    chartData: List<GraphData>
) {
    val transitionAnimation = configureAnimation(chartData)
    val pointRadius = with(LocalDensity.current) { 
		10.dp.toPx() 
	}

	...

    Canvas(
        modifier = modifier
            .height(320.dp)
            .fillMaxWidth()
            .padding(36.dp)
    ) {
        ...
        val heightSegment = (size.height - (padding * 2)) / 					highestData

        drawAxis(labelWidth)

        chartData.forEachIndexed { index, chartData ->
            val drawAtX = padding + strokeThickness + 
				(widthSegment * index) + (widthSegment / 2)

            drawCircle(
                chartData.color,
                radius = pointRadius * 
					transitionAnimation.value,
                center = Offset(
                    drawAtX,
                    heightSegment * chartData.value
                )
            )

            ...
        }

        ...
    }
}

Joining the circles

Now that we have these circles being drawn on the graph, the last thing to do now is to connect the dots and draw a line on the graph. When it comes to drawing these lines, the logic is going to be quite similar to how the circles are being drawn on the canvas. To draw these lines weâ€™re going to need a collection of Offset references that represent the points on the graph where the lines should be connected, these are going to be the same points that the circles are being drawn - so weâ€™re going to start by extracting the previous drawAtX logic and using it to create a collection of Offset references.

val pointsToDraw = chartData.mapIndexed { 
	index, chartData ->
	Offset(
    	padding + labelWidth + strokeThickness + 
			(widthSegment * index) + (widthSegment / 2),
        heightSegment * chartData.value
    )
}

We can then start by updating the drawCircle logic to access the Offset at a given index from this collection.

@Composable
fun LineChart(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    chartData: List<GraphData>
) {
    val transitionAnimation = configureAnimation(chartData)
	val context = LocalContext.current

    val longestLabel = chartData.maxByOrNull { 
		it.label.length 
	}!!.label

    val labelTextPaint = labelTextPaint(context.resources)
    val labelWidth = labelTextPaint.measureText(longestLabel)

    val pointRadius = with(LocalDensity.current) { 
		10.dp.toPx() 
	}

    Canvas(
        modifier = modifier
            .height(320.dp)
            .fillMaxWidth()
            .padding(36.dp)
    ) {
        val highestData = chartData.maxOf { it.value }

        val widthSegment = (size.width - (padding * 2)) / 
			chartData.count()
        val heightSegment = (size.height - (padding * 2)) / 
			highestData

        drawAxis(labelWidth)

        val pointsToDraw = chartData.mapIndexed { 
			index, chartData ->
            	Offset(padding + strokeThickness + labelWidth +
					(widthSegment * index) + 
					(widthSegment / 2),
                heightSegment * chartData.value
            )
        }

        chartData.forEachIndexed { index, chartData ->
            drawCircle(
                chartData.color,
                radius = pointRadius * 
					transitionAnimation.value,
                center = pointsToDraw[index]
            )

            drawDataLabelsOnXAxis(
				chartData.label, 
				drawAtX, 
				labelTextPaint
			)
        }

        drawValueLabelsOnYAxis(
			highestData, 
			chartData.count(), 
			labelTextPaint
		)
    }
}

When it comes to drawing the line, weâ€™re going to need to loop through this collection of Offset references and use the drawLine function to connect the circles within our graph. When it comes to calling this function, we need to provide a few values:

  • color - the color to be used when drawing the line, weâ€™re simply going to pass the Color.Black value here.
  • start - the starting Offset of the line, representing where the drawing of the line should start
  • end - the end Offset of the line, representing where the drawing of the line should finish
pointsToDraw.forEachIndexed { index, startOffset ->
    drawLine(
        ...
    )
}

From the arguments of the drawLine function, we can see that we need to know two of the data values - one for the start position and one for the end so that we can draw a line between the two. Using the index of the current item in the loop, weâ€™ll increment this to retrieve the next point to draw. Weâ€™ll then use this to create the end offset by using the start/end values to calculate the coordinates for the Offset reference. Weâ€™ll multiple both of these values by the current value for the transition, allowing the calculation to be animated.

pointsToDraw.forEachIndexed { index, startOffset ->
	val nextPoint = pointsToDraw[index + 1]
	val endOffset = nextPoint.copy(
        x = startOffset.x + 
			((nextPoint.x - startOffset.x) * transitionAnimation.value),
        y = startOffset.y + 
			((nextPoint.y - startOffset.y) * transitionAnimation.value)
    )
}

Weâ€™ll then use this calculated Offset to call the drawLine function to draw a line between the start and end Offset values.

pointsToDraw.forEachIndexed { index, startOffset ->
	val nextPoint = pointsToDraw[index + 1]
	val endOffset = nextPoint.copy(
        x = startOffset.x + 
			((nextPoint.x - startOffset.x) * transitionAnimation.value),
        y = startOffset.y + 
			((nextPoint.y - startOffset.y) * transitionAnimation.value)
    )
	drawLine(
        color = Color.Black,
        start = startOffset,
        end = nextOffset,
        strokeWidth = 8f
    )
}

As this is, weâ€™ll see a crash when trying to run this code. This is because of the index + 1 operation - this will result in an IndexOutOfBounds exception because weâ€™ll be trying to access an index greater than the size of the list. To prevent this from happening, weâ€™ll wrap our logic in a check to ensure that the current index is less than the index of the second to last item in the list. We donâ€™t need to perform the operations for the last item in the list as our logic is already taking into account the next offset point.

pointsToDraw.forEachIndexed { index, startOffset ->
	if (index < pointsToDraw.count() - 1) {
		val next = pointsToDraw[index + 1]
		val nextOffset = next.copy(
        	x = startOffset.x + 
				((next.x - startOffset.x) * transitionAnimation.value),
        	y = startOffset.y + 
				((next.y - startOffset.y) * transitionAnimation.value)
        )
        drawLine(
            color = Color.Black,
            start = startOffset,
            end = nextOffset,
            strokeWidth = 8f
       	)
    }
}

We can then slot this logic into our LineChart composable, resulting in our data set being drawn and animated on the canvas.

@Composable
fun LineChart(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    chartData: List<GraphData>
) {
    val transitionAnimation = configureAnimation(chartData)
	val context = LocalContext.current

    val longestLabel = chartData.maxByOrNull { 
		it.label.length 
	}!!.label

    val labelTextPaint = labelTextPaint(context.resources)
    val labelWidth = labelTextPaint.measureText(longestLabel)

    val pointRadius = with(LocalDensity.current) { 
		10.dp.toPx() 
	}

    Canvas(
        modifier = modifier
            .height(320.dp)
            .fillMaxWidth()
            .padding(36.dp)
    ) {
        val highestData = chartData.maxOf { it.value }

        val widthSegment = (size.width - (padding * 2)) / 
			chartData.count()
        val heightSegment = (size.height - (padding * 2)) / 
			highestData

        drawAxis(labelWidth)

        val pointsToDraw = chartData.mapIndexed { 
			index, chartData ->
            	Offset(padding + strokeThickness + labelWidth +
					(widthSegment * index) + 
					(widthSegment / 2),
                heightSegment * chartData.value
            )
        }

        chartData.forEachIndexed { index, chartData ->

            drawCircle(
                chartData.color,
                radius = pointRadius * 
					transitionAnimation.value,
                center = pointsToDraw[index]
            )

            drawDataLabelsOnXAxis(
				chartData.label, 
				drawAtX, 
				labelTextPaint
			)
        }

        pointsToDraw.forEachIndexed { index, startOffset ->
            if (index < pointsToDraw.count() - 1) {
                val next = pointsToDraw[index + 1]
                val nextOffset = next.copy(
                    x = startOffset.x + 
						((next.x - startOffset.x) * transitionAnimation.value),
                    y = startOffset.y + 
						((next.y - startOffset.y) * transitionAnimation.value)
                )
                drawLine(
                    color = Color.Black,
                    start = startOffset,
                    end = nextOffset,
                    strokeWidth = 8f
                )
            }
        }

        drawValueLabelsOnYAxis(
			highestData, 
			chartData.count(), 
			labelTextPaint
		)
    }
}

Building the Bar Chart

Moving on from the Line Chat, we can start to look at bar-style graphs to present our dataset. Weâ€™ll start by exploring the bar chart - this composable will take our data set, composing a bar graph based on the data that is provided to it.

@Composable
fun BarChart(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    chartData: List<GraphData>
)

Similar to the other graphs that weâ€™ve composed, weâ€™re going to start by setting up our drawing area in the form of a Canvas. This is going to fill the maximum available height while taking a hardcoded height so that the canvas knows how much space is being occupied.

@Composable
fun BarChart(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    chartData: List<GraphData>
) {
   
    Canvas(
        modifier = modifier
            .height(280.dp)
            .fillMaxWidth()
            .padding(
				start = 16.dp, 
				end = 36.dp, 
				bottom = 36.dp
			)
    ) {
    
	}
}

Drawing the axis

Weâ€™re going to start here by drawing the axis of the graph. For this, weâ€™re going to reuse the drawAxis function that we previously created. So that we can provide the required spacing when drawing the axis, weâ€™re going to need to calculate the width of the text that is going to be drawn for the y-axis labels. Here weâ€™ll use our labelTextPaint function that we previously defined, followed by measuring the text. We can then pass this calculated value when calling the drawAxis function.

@Composable
fun BarChart(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    chartData: List<GraphData>
) {
    val context = LocalContext.current	
	val longestLabel = chartData.maxByOrNull { 
		it.label.length 
	}!!.label
	val labelTextPaint = labelTextPaint(context.resources)
    val labelWidth = labelTextPaint.measureText(longestLabel)

    Canvas(
        modifier = modifier
            .height(280.dp)
            .fillMaxWidth()
            .padding(
				start = 16.dp, 
				end = 36.dp, 
				bottom = 36.dp
			)
    ) {
        drawAxis(labelWidth)
    }
}

Drawing the y-axis labels

Now that we have the axis in place, we can start to draw the labels along each side of the axis - weâ€™ll start here with the labels for the y-axis. Compared to how the labels were drawn on the y-axis for the other graphs, things are going to look slightly different here. This is because for the other graphs we were drawing calculated values that represent the value of the data being drawn - in the case of their chart we want to draw the label of each entry on the y-axis, so we canâ€™t re-use the code that we previously created. Some of the maths is going to be very similar here, so letâ€™s break down what we need to do.

Weâ€™ll start by calculating the height segments that are available for us to draw within. Because weâ€™re working with a fixed data set, weâ€™ll want to split the height of our chart up into equal segments. This is going to equal:

((chart height) - (padding) - (axis stroke thickness) - (spacing between each bar)) / (number of graph entries)

This calculation will take the available drawing area of the graph and split it into a collection of equally sized segments. Using the information that we have available within our composable, we can recreate this like so:

val columnSpacing = 6f
val numberOfValues = chartData.count()
val heightSegment = (size.height - strokeThickness - 		(padding * 2) - (columnSpacing * (numberOfValues + 1))) / numberOfValues

One key point here is this columnSpacing reference. We define this as the spacing that will be left between each bar - otherwise, our bars would be touching each other (and make the graph a bit more difficult to read). There is going to be spacing at the top of every bar, as well as at the bottom of the last one - so we need to take this value and multiply it by the number of graph entries + 1.

Now that we have the segment size calculated, we start writing the code to draw each label. Weâ€™ll start by defining a loop for the information in our chartData collection, followed by calculating the y position for each label that is going to be drawn. We can calculate this by taking the padding and columnSpacing values (as there is always going to be a final spacing at the bottom of the graph), followed by the calculating where we are at in regards to the current height segment - taking the sum of the columnSpacing and heightSegment in regards to the current index will give us this position.

chartData.forEachIndexed { index, chartData ->
	val drawAtY = padding + columnSpacing + 
		((columnSpacing + heightSegment) * index)
}

Now that we have this y-coordinate calculated, we can move on to the drawing of the label. While we have the y-coordinate that we can draw at, weâ€™re going to need to tweak this so that we are drawing the label in the center of the bounds - this will allow us to align the label with the vertical centre of the bar. We can get this value by calculating the current bounds of the text, followed by using this value to modify the calculated drawAtY and give us a central location to draw at.

chartData.forEachIndexed { index, chartData ->
	val drawAtY = padding + columnSpacing + 
		((columnSpacing + heightSegment) * index) + textPadding
	drawIntoCanvas {
		val bounds = Rect().also { rect ->
			labelTextPaint.getTextBounds(
				chartData.label, 0,
				chartData.label.length, rect)
            }
        val centerY = drawAtY + (heightSegment / 2) + 
			(bounds.height() / 2)
        it.nativeCanvas.drawText(
			chartData.label, 
			0f, centerY, 
			labelTextPaint
		)
    }
}

We can then slot this code into our composable and see our y-axis labels being drawn.

@Composable
fun BarChart(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    chartData: List<GraphData>
) {
    
    ...

    Canvas(
        modifier = modifier
            .height(280.dp)
            .fillMaxWidth()
            .padding(
				start = 16.dp, 
				end = 36.dp, 
				bottom = 36.dp
			)
    ) {
        val columnSpacing = 6f
        val numberOfValues = chartData.count()
        val heightSegment = (size.height - strokeThickness - 		(padding * 2) - 
			(columnSpacing * (numberOfValues + 1))) / numberOfValues

        chartData.forEachIndexed { index, chartData ->
            val drawAtY = padding + columnSpacing + 
				((columnSpacing + heightSegment) * index) + textPadding
            drawIntoCanvas {
                val bounds = Rect().also { rect ->
                	labelTextPaint.getTextBounds(
						chartData.label, 0,
						chartData.label.length, rect)
                }
                val centerY = drawAtY + (heightSegment / 2) + 
					(bounds.height() / 2)
                it.nativeCanvas.drawText(
					chartData.label, 
					0f, centerY, 
					labelTextPaint
				)
            }
        }

        drawAxis(labelWidth)
    }
}

Drawing the x-axis labels

With the y-axis labels in place, we can naturally move on to drawing the labels for the x-axis of the graph. Similar to the y-axis labels, weâ€™re unable to re-use any code that we defined earlier - this is because weâ€™re drawing the calculated values for the graph value properties to be mapped against, as opposed to labels that were drawn for the previous graph x-axis.

repeat(numberOfValues + 1) { value ->
	drawIntoCanvas {

	}
}

Within this loop, weâ€™re going to want to start by calculating the value that is going to be drawn for the label. Weâ€™ll first need to calculate the value of each segment along the x-axis. Because these are going to be of equal width, weâ€™ll need to start by retrieving the highest value from the chartData collection.

val highestValue = chartData.maxOf { it.value }

We can then take this value and divide it by the number of values that are present in the chartData - this is going to be the distance between each width segment. Multiplying this value by the current index of the loop will give us the label to be drawn at the current point on the x-axis.

repeat(numberOfValues + 1) { value ->
	drawIntoCanvas {
		val points = (highestValue / numberOfValues) * value
    }
}

Weâ€™ll next need to calculate where this is going to be drawn on the x-axis of the canvas. This value is going to be equal to:

(the current width segment) + (half of the label width) + (graph padding)

The point of the current width segment gives us the starting point of where the segment area begins, followed by adding on any additional padding that is being used for our graph.

repeat(numberOfValues + 1) { value ->
	drawIntoCanvas {
		val points = (highestValue / numberOfValues) * value
        
		val width = size.width - (padding * 2) - labelWidth

        val xPosition = ((width / numberOfValues) * value) + 		labelWidth + padding
    }
}

With these values calculated, we can now make a call to the drawText function within our Canvas. Along with passing the label to be drawn, we need to provide the calculated xPosition, along with the Paint reference used to draw the label. Weâ€™ll also pass the height of the Canvas for the y-coordinate to be drawn, as we want to draw the labels at the bottom of the Canvas.

repeat(numberOfValues + 1) { value ->
	drawIntoCanvas {
		val points = (highestValue / numberOfValues) * value
        val width = size.width - (padding * 2) - labelWidth

        val textWidth = labelTextPaint.measureText(
			points.toString())

        val xPosition = ((width / numberOfValues) * value) + 		labelWidth + labelWidth + padding - 
			(textWidth / 2)
		
		it.nativeCanvas.drawText(
            points.toString(),
            xPosition,
            size.height,
            labelTextPaint
        )
    }
}

We can then slot this code into our BarChart composable to see the x-axis labels being drawn.

@Composable
fun BarChart(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    chartData: List<GraphData>
) {
    val context = LocalContext.current
    val highestValue = chartData.maxOf { it.value }
    val transitionAnimation = configureAnimation(chartData)
    val longestLabel = chartData.maxByOrNull { 
		it.label.length 
	}!!.label

    val labelTextPaint = labelTextPaint(context.resources)
    val labelWidth = labelTextPaint.measureText(longestLabel)

    Canvas(
        modifier = modifier
            .height(280.dp)
            .fillMaxWidth()
            .padding(
				start = 16.dp, 
				end = 36.dp, 
				bottom = 36.dp
			)
    ) {
        val columnSpacing = 6f
        val numberOfValues = chartData.count()

        ...

        repeat(numberOfValues + 1) { value ->
            drawIntoCanvas {
                val points = (highestValue / numberOfValues) * 				value
                val width = size.width - (padding * 2) - 
					labelWidth

                val textWidth = labelTextPaint.measureText(
					points.toString())
                val xPosition =
                    ((width / numberOfValues) * value) + 					labelWidth + labelWidth + 
					padding - (textWidth / 2)

                it.nativeCanvas.drawText(
                    points.toString(),
                    xPosition,
                    size.height,
                    labelTextPaint
                )
            }
        }
    }
}

Drawing the bars

Now that we have the axis labels in place, we can move on to drawing the main part of the graph - the bars that represent the value for each graph entry. To draw these bars, weâ€™re going to need to loop through the provided chartData collection. When making this call weâ€™ll need to provide three values:

  • color - the color to be used when drawing the shape
  • topLeft - the Offset used to start drawing the shape from the top left-hand corner
  • size - the Size instance is used to define the sizing of the drawn shape
chartData.forEachIndexed { index, chartData ->
	drawRect(
		chartData.color,
        topLeft = ...,
        size = ...
    )
}

Weâ€™ll start by defining the Size of the shape. For this, the height is going to be equal to the previously calculated heightSegment value for the current chartData entry. When it comes to the width, weâ€™re going to need to calculate this based on the current entry. This is going to be equal to the previously calculated widthSegment value, multiplied by the value for the current chartData entry. After adding on the stroke thickness of the axis, weâ€™ll multiply this result by the current transition value so that the bar is animated when being drawn.

chartData.forEachIndexed { index, chartData ->
	val width = ((widthSegment * chartData.value) - 
		strokeThickness) * transitionAnimation.value
	...
}

With this value calculated, we can now provide a Size reference to our drawRect call.

chartData.forEachIndexed { index, chartData ->	val width = ((widthSegment * chartData.value) - 
		strokeThickness) * transitionAnimation.value
	...
	drawRect(
		chartData.color,
        topLeft = ...,
        size = Size(
			width = width, 
			height = heightSegment
		)
    )
}

Next, we need to provide an Offset reference to the topLeft argument. We already have all of the data we need for the x-axis, we just need to calculate the value to be provided for the topLeft y-coordinate of our drawing operation. The y-coordinate for the top-left of our drawing operation is going to be equivalent to the number of height segments that the current index of the loop represents, plus any additional padding values that we have defined for our graph. Because we are drawing multiple bars in our graph, starting from the top, the index 0 through to the number of items in the chartData collection, allows us to draw the bars one by one.

chartData.forEachIndexed { index, chartData ->
	val drawAtY = padding + columnSpacing + textPadding
		((columnSpacing + heightSegment) * index)
	val width = ((widthSegment * chartData.value) - 
		strokeThickness) * transitionAnimation.value
	...
}

With these values in place, we can now pass this directly to the topLeft argument in the form of an Offset instance. For the x-coordinate of this, weâ€™ll simply pass the labelWidth plus any defined padding values that we need to take into account - this will ensure that the drawing takes place at the start of the x-axis of our graph.

chartData.forEachIndexed { index, chartData ->
	val drawAtY = padding + columnSpacing + 
		((columnSpacing + heightSegment) * index) + textPadding
	val width = ((widthSegment * chartData.value) - 
		strokeThickness) * transitionAnimation.value
	...
	drawRect(
		chartData.color,
        topLeft = Offset(
            x = labelWidth + padding + textPadding + 					strokeThickness,
            y = drawAtY
        ),
        size = Size(
			width = width, 
			height = heightSegment
		)
    )
}

We can then slot this code into our BarChart composable, finishing up the drawing of this graph type.

@Composable
fun BarChart(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    chartData: List<GraphData>
) {
    val transitionAnimation = configureAnimation(chartData)
    ...

    Canvas(
        modifier = modifier
            .height(280.dp)
            .fillMaxWidth()
            .padding(
				start = 16.dp, 
				end = 36.dp, 
				bottom = 36.dp
			)
    ) {
        val columnSpacing = 6f
        val numberOfValues = chartData.count()
        val heightSegment = 
			(size.height - strokeThickness - (padding * 2) -
          	(columnSpacing * (numberOfValues + 1))) / 
			numberOfValues
        val widthSegment = (size.width - (padding * 2)) / 
			highestValue

        chartData.forEachIndexed { index, chartData ->
            val drawAtY = padding + columnSpacing + 
				((columnSpacing + heightSegment) * index) + textPadding
            val width =
                ((widthSegment * chartData.value) - 
					strokeThickness) * transitionAnimation.value
            ...
            drawRect(
                chartData.color,
                topLeft = Offset(
                    x = labelWidth + padding + textPadding + 					strokeThickness,
                    y = drawAtY
                ),
                size = Size(
					width = width, 
					height = heightSegment
				)
            )
        }

        ...
    }
}

Building the Column Chart

Similar to the other graphs that weâ€™ve composed, weâ€™re going to start by setting up our drawing area in the form of a Canvas. This is going to fill the maximum available height while taking a hardcoded height so that the canvas knows how much space is being occupied.

@Composable
fun ColumnChart(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    chartData: List<GraphData>
) {
  
    Canvas(
        modifier = modifier
            .height(320.dp)
            .fillMaxSize()
            .padding(36.dp)
    ) {

    }
}

Drawing the axis

Weâ€™re going to start here by drawing the axis of the graph. For this, weâ€™re going to reuse the drawAxis function that we previously created. Weâ€™ll need to provide a value for the labelWidth argument, so weâ€™ll again calculate the bounds of our text to satisfy this argument.

@Composable
fun ColumnChart(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    chartData: List<GraphData>
) {
	
	val context = LocalContext.current
    val longestLabel = chartData.maxByOrNull { 
		it.label.length 
	}!!.label
    val labelTextPaint = labelTextPaint(context.resources)
    val labelWidth = labelTextPaint.measureText(longestLabel)
  
    Canvas(
        modifier = modifier
            .height(320.dp)
            .fillMaxSize()
            .padding(36.dp)
    ) {
        drawAxis(labelWidth)
    }
}

With the padding and height that has been applied to the Canvas we can see the axis being drawn with sufficient spacing around the bounds.

Drawing the y-axis labels

When it comes to the axis labels of our graph, weâ€™re going to start by drawing the labels for the y-axis. For this, weâ€™re going to be reusing the drawValueLabelsOnYAxis function that we previously created, but we first need some information that we can provide to the function. The function needs to know the maximum value that is going to be drawn for the y-axis labels, which is going to be the highest value in the GraphData collection that is provided to our AreaChart composable. We can calculate this value using the kotlin maxOf function on the provided chartData reference.

@Composable
fun ColumnChart(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    chartData: List<GraphData>
) {
    val maximumValue = chartData.maxOf { it.value }
    ...
}

We also need to provide two other values to the function:

  • labelCount - the number of labels to be displayed, this will be the number of items in the chartData collection
  • resources - this is a Resources reference that is used by the function to retrieve application resource values
@Composable
fun ColumnChart(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    chartData: List<GraphData>
) {
    val maximumValue = chartData.maxOf { it.value }
	val context = LocalContext.current
	...

    Canvas(
        modifier = modifier
            .height(320.dp)
            .fillMaxSize()
            .padding(36.dp)
    ) {

        drawAxis(labelWidth)

        drawValueLabelsOnYAxis(
			maximumValue, chartData.count(), context.resources)
    }
}

With this function call being made, we can now see the y-axis label being drawn onto the canvas alongside the y-axis line.

Drawing the x-axis labels

With the y-axis labels now in place, we can move on to drawing the labels for the x-axis. When it comes to drawing the labels and data points onto the x-axis of the graph, weâ€™re going to need to split the width of the graph into equal segments that can be drawn into - this allows us to evenly space the pieces of information that are being drawn onto the Canvas.

Weâ€™re going to start here by calculating the width of these segments. This is going to look a little different from the previously calculated width segments because each column in the chart is going to have spacing between one another, so we need to account for this when calculating how much width is available for each segment.

This calculation is going to be the width of the x-axis line, minus the width that is occupied by blank space between each of the columns (the number of separators is always going to be one more than the number of columns in the graph). We can then take this calculated value and divide it by the number of entries in our chartData collection - as this will give us an equal-sized segment for each entry in this collection. 

val numberOfValues = chartData.count()
val occupiedSeparatorSpacing = columnSpacing * 
	(numberOfValues + 1)
val widthSegment = (size.width - (padding * 2) - 
	occupiedSeparatorSpacing) / numberOfValues

Next, weâ€™re going to want to loop through each entry within our chartData reference and utilise the drawDataLabelsOnXAxis function to draw a label on the x-axis. When calling this function we simply need to pass in this calculated widthSegment, the index of the current item within the loop, along with the label and resources reference.

@Composable
fun ColumnChart(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    chartData: List<GraphData>
) {
    val maximumValue = chartData.maxOf { it.value }
	...
    
    val columnSpacing = with(LocalDensity.current) { 
		4.dp.toPx() 
	}

    Canvas(
        modifier = modifier
            .height(320.dp)
            .fillMaxSize()
            .padding(36.dp)
    ) {
        val numberOfValues = chartData.count()
		val occupiedSeparatorSpacing = columnSpacing * 
			(numberOfValues + 1)
		val widthSegment = (size.width - (padding * 2) - 
			occupiedSeparatorSpacing - labelWidth) / numberOfValues

        drawAxis(labelWidth)

        chartData.forEachIndexed { index, chartData ->
			drawDataLabelsOnXAxis(
                chartData.label,
                widthSegment + columnSpacing,
                index,
                context.resources,
				labelWidth + padding
            )
        }

        drawValueLabelsOnYAxis(
			maximumValue, chartData.count(), context.resources)
    }
}

Drawing the Columns

Now that we have the axis labels in place, we can move on to drawing the columns that represent the data within the provided GraphData collection. To draw these columns weâ€™re going to be utilising the drawRect within the Canvas composable.

fun drawRect(
 	color: Color,
	topLeft: Offset = Offset.Zero,
	size: Size = this.size.offsetSize(topLeft),
	/*@FloatRange(from = 0.0, to = 1.0)*/
    alpha: Float = 1.0f,
    style: DrawStyle = Fill,
    colorFilter: ColorFilter? = null,
    blendMode: BlendMode = DefaultBlendMode
)

When it comes to using this to draw the columns on the graph, weâ€™re going to be provided several values for the available arguments.

  • color - the color to be used when drawing the rectangle
  • topLeft - the offset of the shape from the origin of 0,0
  • size - the dimensions of the rectangle being drawn

Weâ€™re going to be calling this function from within the existing loop for the chartData collection, so for the color argument, we can simply pass the color reference from the current GraphData value in the loop.

drawRect(
	chartData.color,
	topLeft = ...,
	size = ...
)

Next, weâ€™re going to define the Size of the rectangle that weâ€™re drawing. Weâ€™ve already calculated the width of this in the form of the widthSegment variable that we previously calculated, so we just need to calculate the height. Weâ€™re going to split the height of the graph area up into equal segments so that for each data entry we can fill the corresponding height against the y-axis.

This segment value can be calculated by taking the available drawing space on the canvas (the height of the canvas minus the applied padding), dividing this result by the maximum value within the graph data set. This gives us the drawing height of equally sized segments for the y-axis.

val heightSegment = (size.height - (padding * 2)) /
	maximumValue

Using this, weâ€™re then going to want to calculate the height for each of the graph data entries, which is going to be equal to the calculated heightSegment multiplied by the current value within our GraphData loop.

val height = heightSegment * chartData.value

Finally, because we want to animate the height of the columns as they are drawn onto the canvas, weâ€™re next going to utilise the previously created configureAnimation to create an animated value for our chartData reference.

val transitionAnimation = configureAnimation(chartData)

We can then modify the height value calculation so that the result of the previous calculation is multiplied by the animation value. This will take the height of the graph entry and multiply it from 0f to 1f, allowing the height of the column to be animated to its full height.

val height = (heightSegment * chartData.value) *
	transitionAnimation.value

We can then slot this code into the corresponding places inside of the ColumnChart composable.

@Composable
fun ColumnChart(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    chartData: List<GraphData>
) {
    ...

    val transitionAnimation = configureAnimation(chartData)

    Canvas(
        modifier = modifier
            .height(320.dp)
            .fillMaxSize()
            .padding(36.dp)
    ) {
        ...
        val widthSegment = (size.width - (padding * 2) - 			occupiedSeparatorSpacing - labelWidth) / 		
			numberOfValues

        val heightSegment = (size.height - (padding * 2)) / 
			maximumValue

        drawAxis(labelWidth)

        chartData.forEachIndexed { index, chartData ->
			val height = ((heightSegment * chartData.value) - strokeThickness) * transitionAnimation.value

            drawRect(
                chartData.color,
                topLeft = ...,
                size = Size(
					width = widthSegment, 
					height = height
				)
            )

            ...
        }

        ...
    }
}

At this point, we now only need to provide a value for the topLeft argument of the drawRect function. While we have the size of the rectangle that is being drawn, this value will represent the starting point for where the rectangle is to be drawn. Weâ€™re going to start here by calculating the x-coordinate for where each of the columns is going to be drawn.

Taking into account all of the padding and spacing that has been defined so far, the x-coordinate drawing location is going to start from the point where the x-axis starts within the canvas, which is going to be equivalent to the defined padding and textPadding values, plus an initial columnSpacing value.

Then, weâ€™re going to want to take the columnSpacing and widthSegment values and multiply them by the current index within the chartData loop. This will mean that as we loop through the chartData values, the x-coordinate that is to be drawn at will be positioned at each segment along the x-axis of the graph.

val drawAtX = padding + columnSpacing + 				
	((columnSpacing + widthSegment) * index)

With this in place, we now need to calculate the starting y-coordinate that the rectangle is to be drawn at. This is going to be the height of the canvas, subtracting both the padding and strokeThickness values - as this will ensure that the y-coordinate for drawing is positioned at the base of the y-axis and above the line that is being drawn for the x-axis.

size.height - padding - strokeThickness

As it is, this wonâ€™t work. Because we are animating the height of the rectangle, the y position of the offset is also going to need to be animated. To achieve the desired value for the y-axis we subtract the height value from the result of the calculation above. This means that the y-coordinate will now be calculated based on the current animated position of the height value.

size.height - padding - strokeThickness - height

We can now slot this code into the chartData loop, meaning that the requirements for the drawRect function call have now been satisfied.

chartData.forEachIndexed { index, chartData ->
	val drawAtX = padding + columnSpacing + 				
		((columnSpacing + widthSegment) * index) + textPadding
	val height = (heightSegment * chartData.value) * transitionAnimation.value

	drawRect(
		chartData.color,
		topLeft = Offset(
            x = drawAtX,
            y = size.height - padding - strokeThickness - 
				topLeft
        ),
        size = Size(
			width = widthSegment, 
			height = height
		)
    )
}

With this in place, we now have a complete ColumnChart composable that is drawing the provided GraphData collection, animating the data set onto the Canvas when it is being drawn.

@Composable
fun ColumnChart(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    chartData: List<GraphData>
) {
    val maximumValue = chartData.maxOf { it.value }
    val transitionAnimation = configureAnimation(chartData)
    val columnSpacing = with(LocalDensity.current) { 
		4.dp.toPx() 
	}
    val context = LocalContext.current
	val longestLabel = chartData.maxByOrNull { 
		it.label.length 
	}!!.label
    val labelTextPaint = labelTextPaint(context.resources)
    val labelWidth = labelTextPaint.measureText(longestLabel)

    Canvas(
        modifier = modifier
            .height(320.dp)
            .fillMaxSize()
            .padding(36.dp)
    ) {
        val numberOfValues = chartData.count()
        val occupiedSeparatorSpacing = columnSpacing *
            (numberOfValues + 1)
        val widthSegment = (size.width - (padding * 2) - 
			occupiedSeparatorSpacing - labelWidth) / numberOfValues

        val heightSegment = (size.height - (padding * 2)) / 		maximumValue

        drawAxis(labelWidth)

        chartData.forEachIndexed { index, chartData ->
            val drawAtX = padding + columnSpacing + 					((columnSpacing + widthSegment) * index) + 				textPadding
            val height = ((heightSegment * chartData.value) - 			strokeThickness) * transitionAnimation.value
            val topLeft = (heightSegment * chartData.value) * 			transitionAnimation.value

            drawRect(
                chartData.color,
                topLeft = Offset(
                    x = drawAtX,
                    y = size.height - padding - strokeThickness 
						- topLeft
                ),
                size = Size(
					width = widthSegment, 
					height = height
				)
            )

            drawDataLabelsOnXAxis(
                chartData.label,
                widthSegment + columnSpacing,
                index,
                context.resources,
				labelWidth + padding
            )
        }

        drawValueLabelsOnYAxis(
			maximumValue, 
			chartData.count(), 
			context.resources
		)
    }
}

Building the Area Chart

Next up in our collection of graphs is the Area Graph - this allows us to display a graph similar to that of a line graph, but with a filled area.

Weâ€™ll start here by creating a new composable function, AreaChart.

@Composable
fun AreaChart(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    chartData: List<GraphData>
)

Similar to the other graphs that weâ€™ve composed, weâ€™re going to start by setting up our drawing area in the form of a Canvas. This is going to fill the maximum available height while taking a hardcoded height so that the canvas knows how much space is being occupied.

@Composable
fun AreaChart(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    chartData: List<GraphData>
) {

    Canvas(
        modifier = modifier
            .height(320.dp)
            .fillMaxWidth()
            .padding(36.dp)
    ) {

    }
}

Drawing the axis

Weâ€™re going to start here by drawing the axis of the graph. For this, weâ€™re going to reuse the drawAxis function that we previously created. Weâ€™ll again need to calculate the labelWidth value using the bounds of the longest graph label.

@Composable
fun AreaChart(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    chartData: List<GraphData>
) {

	val context = LocalContext.current
    val longestLabel = chartData.maxByOrNull { 
		it.label.length 
	}!!.label
    val labelTextPaint = labelTextPaint(context.resources)
    val labelWidth = labelTextPaint.measureText(longestLabel)

    Canvas(
        modifier = modifier
            .height(320.dp)
            .fillMaxWidth()
            .padding(36.dp)
    ) {
        drawAxis(labelWidth)
    }
}

With the padding and height that has been applied to the Canvas we can see the axis being drawn with sufficient spacing around the bounds.

Drawing the y-axis labels

When it comes to the axis labels of our graph, weâ€™re going to start by drawing the labels for the y-axis. For this, weâ€™re going to be reusing the drawValueLabelsOnYAxis function that we previously created, but we first need some information that we can provide to the function. The function needs to know the maximum value that is going to be drawn for the y-axis labels, which is going to be the highest value in the GraphData collection that is provided to our AreaChart composable. We can calculate this value using the kotlin maxOf function on the provided chartData reference.

@Composable
fun AreaChart(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    chartData: List<GraphData>
) {
	...

    Canvas(
        modifier = modifier
            .height(320.dp)
            .fillMaxWidth()
            .padding(36.dp)
    ) {
        val maximumValue = chartData.maxOf { it.value }

        ...
    }
}

We also need to provide two other values to the function:

  • labelCount - the number of labels to be displayed, this will be the number of items in the chartData collection
  • resources - this is a Resources reference that is used by the function to retrieve application resource values
@Composable
fun AreaChart(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    chartData: List<GraphData>
) {
	val context = LocalContext.current
	...

    Canvas(
        modifier = modifier
            .height(320.dp)
            .fillMaxWidth()
            .padding(36.dp)
    ) {
        ...

        drawValueLabelsOnYAxis(
			maximumValue, 					
			chartData.count(), 
			context.resources
		)
    }
}

With this function call being made, we can now see the y-axis label being drawn onto the canvas alongside the y-axis line.

Drawing the x-axis labels

With the y-axis labels now in place, we can move on to drawing the labels for the x-axis. When it comes to drawing the labels and data points onto the x-axis of the graph, weâ€™re going to need to split the width of the graph into equal segments that can be drawn into - this allows us to evenly space the pieces of information that are being drawn onto the Canvas.

Weâ€™re going to start here by calculating the width of these segments. This calculation is going to be the width of the x-axis line, divided by the number o entries in our chartData collection - as this will give us an equal-sized segment for each entry in this collection. 

val widthSegment = (size.width - (padding * 2)) / 
	chartData.count()

Next, weâ€™re going to want to loop through each entry within our chartData reference and utilise the drawDataLabelsOnXAxis function to draw a label on the x-axis. When calling this function we simply need to pass in this calculated widthSegment, the index of the current item within the loop, along with the label and resources reference.

@Composable
fun AreaChart(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    chartData: List<GraphData>
) {
	val context = LocalContext.current
	val longestLabel = chartData.maxByOrNull { 
		it.label.length 
	}!!.label
    val labelTextPaint = labelTextPaint(context.resources)
    val labelWidth = labelTextPaint.measureText(longestLabel)

    Canvas(
        modifier = modifier
            .height(320.dp)
            .fillMaxWidth()
            .padding(36.dp)
    ) {
        val maximumValue = chartData.maxOf { it.value }
        val widthSegment = (size.width - (padding * 2)) / 			chartData.count()

        drawAxis(labelWidth)

        chartData.forEachIndexed { index, current ->
            drawDataLabelsOnXAxis(
				current.label, 
				widthSegment,
				index,			
				context.resources,
				labelWidth + padding
			)
        }

		...
    }
}

Drawing the data set

Now that we have the axis and the corresponding labels in place, we can move on to drawing the data points onto the graph. Because weâ€™re going to be drawing a continual line with a filled area, we can utilise the Path class to define the area and shape that we want to draw for our graph.

val pathToDraw = Path()

Weâ€™re going to need to look through each entry within the GraphData list and create the shape that we want to draw using this Path reference. Weâ€™ll need to start by defining the start of the graph, this is where the drawing is going to be started. Using the moveTo function on our Path reference, we can define the starting point for the Path. The starting point of the graph is always going to be at the bottom left-hand corner of the graph, so weâ€™ll need to define the coordinates that reflect this. For the x-coordinate, this will just be equal to any spacing/padding that has been applied to the graph. In terms of the y-coordinate, this is going to be the height of the canvas with any spacing/padding subtracted from it.

chartData.forEachIndexed { index, current ->
    if (index == 0) {
        pathToDraw.moveTo(
            labelWidth + strokeThickness + padding,
            size.height - padding - strokeThickness
        )
    }
}

When it comes to drawing the rest of the path, the points to be drawn in the Path are going to consist of a collection of Offset references, so weâ€™ll need to map each value in the dataset to an Offset value. For each offset value, weâ€™ll need to provide values for both the x and y coordinates.

  • x - Similar to the other graphs weâ€™ve drawn, weâ€™ll need to account for the previously calculated labelWidth, along with the defined padding and strokeThickness. We can then use the calculated widthSegment and index values to calculate what segment we are drawing in on the x-axis, along with half of the original widthSegment to draw the coordinate in the center of the segment.
  • y - for this position weâ€™ll again need to split the available drawing area into equal segments, followed by using the current value in the loop to calculate the corresponding y position
chartData.forEachIndexed { index, current ->
	...

    if (index == 0) {
        ...
    } else {
		val offsetToDraw = Offset(
			padding + strokeThickness + (widthSegment * index) + (widthSegment / 2),
        	heightSegment * current.value
		)
    }
}

Now that we have this Offset in place, we can use this to create a line within our Path. While we could just assign the x and y coordinates directly from this Offset reference, we want to keep up the theme of animated graph values, so weâ€™re going to animate the y coordinate so that our graph grows into place from the bottom of the y-axis. Weâ€™ll need to start by configuring the animation at the top of our composable function, using the chartData reference that is provided to our composable.

val transitionAnimation = configureAnimation(chartData)

Next, weâ€™ll need to animate the value from the bottom of the y-axis to the value that was calculated and assigned in the Offset reference. We can calculate the bottom of the graph by using the height of the canvas, subtracting our defined padding and strokeThickness values.

val availableHeightFromBottom = size.height - padding - strokeThickness

We can now use this to calculate the y-coordinate that we wish to draw to, using the defined animation transition. Weâ€™ll do this by working out the distance from the bottom of the graph to the y-coordinate from the Offset, followed by multiplying this by the current value of the transition - this will allow us to animate from 0 (the bottom of the y-axis) to the y-coordinate for the corresponding entry in the graph data.

Once this has been calculated, we can utilise the lineTo function on the Path class to draw a line to the coordinates for this entry in the graph.

val availableHeightFromBottom = size.height - padding - strokeThickness

chartData.forEachIndexed { index, current ->
	...

    if (index == 0) {
        pathToDraw.moveTo(
            padding + strokeThickness + padding,
            size.height - padding - strokeThickness
        )
    } else {
		val offsetToDraw = Offset(
			padding + strokeThickness + (widthSegment * index) + (widthSegment / 2),
        	heightSegment * current.value
		)
        val y = availableHeightFromBottom - 						((availableHeightFromBottom - offsetToDraw.y) * 
			transitionAnimation.value)
        pathToDraw.lineTo(offsetToDraw.x, y)
    }
}

This lineTo operation is going to take place from index 1 up until the end of the graph being drawn. When the graph has reached the end of its drawing, weâ€™re going to need to draw down to the bottom of the Canvas to finish off the area of the graph. We can do this by again using the lineTo operation, reusing the x value for the last item of the chartData collection, followed by using the height of the Canvas (minus any padding/spacing) to draw down to the bottom of the y-axis.

chartData.forEachIndexed { index, current ->
    if (index == 0) {
        pathToDraw.moveTo(
            padding + strokeThickness + padding,
            size.height - padding - strokeThickness
        )
    } else {
		val offsetToDraw = Offset(
			padding + strokeThickness + (widthSegment * index) + (widthSegment / 2),
        	heightSegment * current.value
		)
		val height = (heightSegment * current.value)  * transitionAnimation.value
        val y = availableHeightFromBottom - 						((availableHeightFromBottom - offsetToDraw.y) * 
			transitionAnimation.value)
        pathToDraw.lineTo(offsetToDraw.x, y)
        if (index == chartData.count() - 1) {
            pathToDraw.lineTo(
            	offsetToDraw.x, 
                size.height - padding - strokeThickness
            )
        }
    }
}

Now that we have our Path defined and all the instructions in place, we can utilise the drawPath operation to draw the contents of our Path. For this, we simply pass the Path reference, followed by the Color that we wish to use when drawing the path.

@Composable
fun AreaChart(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    chartData: List<GraphData>
) {
    val transitionAnimation = configureAnimation(chartData)
	val context = LocalContext.current
	val longestLabel = chartData.maxByOrNull { 
		it.label.length 
	}!!.label
    val labelTextPaint = labelTextPaint(context.resources)
    val labelWidth = labelTextPaint.measureText(longestLabel)

    Canvas(
        modifier = modifier
            .height(320.dp)
            .fillMaxWidth()
            .padding(36.dp)
    ) {
        val maximumValue = chartData.maxOf { it.value }
        val widthSegment = (size.width - (padding * 2)) / 			chartData.count()
        val heightSegment = (size.height - (padding * 2)) / 		highestData.value
        val availableHeightFromBottom = size.height - padding - 		strokeThickness

        drawAxis(labelWidth)

        val pathToDraw = Path()

        chartData.forEachIndexed { index, current ->
            ...
        }

        drawPath(
            pathToDraw,
            Color.Black
        )

        ...
    }
}

With the above in place, we can now slot the drawing logic into our composable, giving us a completed area graph to display the provided data set.

@Composable
fun AreaChart(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    chartData: List<GraphData>
) {
    val transitionAnimation = configureAnimation(chartData)
	val context = LocalContext.current
	val longestLabel = chartData.maxByOrNull { 
		it.label.length 
	}!!.label
    val labelTextPaint = labelTextPaint(context.resources)
    val labelWidth = labelTextPaint.measureText(longestLabel)

    Canvas(
        modifier = modifier
            .height(320.dp)
            .fillMaxWidth()
            .padding(36.dp)
    ) {
        val maximumValue = chartData.maxOf { it.value }
        val widthSegment = (size.width - (padding * 2)) / 			chartData.count()
        val heightSegment = (size.height - (padding * 2)) / 		highestData.value
        val availableHeightFromBottom = size.height - padding - 		strokeThickness

        drawAxis(labelWidth)

        val pathToDraw = Path()

        chartData.forEachIndexed { index, current ->
            drawDataLabelsOnXAxis(
				current.label, 
				widthSegment,
				index,			
				context.resources,
				labelWidth + padding
			)

            val offsetToDraw = Offset(padding + strokeThickness 			+ (widthSegment * index) + (widthSegment / 2),
                heightSegment * current.value)

            if (index == 0) {
                pathToDraw.moveTo(
                    padding + strokeThickness + padding,
                    size.height - padding - strokeThickness
                )
            } else {
                val y = availableHeightFromBottom - 						((availableHeightFromBottom - 							offsetToDraw.y) * 										transitionAnimation.value)
                pathToDraw.lineTo(offsetToDraw.x, y)
                if (index == chartData.count() - 1) {
                    pathToDraw.apply {
                        lineTo(size.width - padding, y)
                        lineTo(
							size.width - padding,
							size.height - padding - strokeThickness)
                        lineTo(
							padding + strokeThickness,
							size.height - padding - strokeThickness)
                    }
                }
            }
        }

        drawPath(
            pathToDraw,
            Color.Black
        )

        drawValueLabelsOnYAxis(
			maximumValue, 					
			chartData.count(), 
			context.resources
		)
    }
}

Composing the selected Graph

Now that we have all our graphs and charts composed using individual functions, weâ€™re going to create a composable that will be used to compose a graph based on the GraphType that is provided to it. Because our global state reference is holding a value that refers to the currently selected GraphType, this value can then be used to compose the corresponding graph. Weâ€™ll create a new composable function, Graph, that will take a GraphType along with the collection of GraphData that is to be used when composing a graph.

@Composable
fun Graph(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    chart: GraphType,
    chartData: List<GraphData>
)

Weâ€™ll then use a when block to compose a graph based on the provided GraphType. Weâ€™ll add a clause for each of the different GraphType values, passing the provided modifer and chartData values for composition.

@Composable
fun Graph(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    chart: GraphType,
    chartData: List<GraphData>
) {
    when (chart) {
        GraphType.PIE -> 
			PieChart(
				modifier = modifier, 
				chartData = chartData
			)
        GraphType.LINE -> 
			LineChart(
				modifier = modifier, 
				chartData = chartData
			)
        GraphType.BAR -> 
			BarChart(
				modifier = modifier, 
				chartData = chartData
			)
        GraphType.COLUMN -> 
			ColumnChart(
				modifier = modifier, 
				chartData = chartData
			)
        GraphType.DOUGHNUT -> 
			DoughnutChart(
				modifier = modifier, 
				chartData = chartData
			)
        GraphType.AREA -> 
			AreaChart(
				modifier = modifier, 
				chartData = chartData
			)
    }
}

With this in place, we now have a composable that can be used to compose the graph for a given GraphType, which will be based on the currently selected graph within our GraphsState reference. Weâ€™re not going to use this just yet, but itâ€™s now ready to plug into our UI when it comes to the composition of the currently selected graph.

Building the Chart Picker

Now that have a composable that can compose any given GraphType, weâ€™re going to want to allow the user to select a graph from the available list of GraphType values. This selection will in turn update the GraphsState, causing the newly selected graph to be composed within our UI. Weâ€™ll start by creating a new composable function, ChartPicker.

@Composable
fun ChartPicker(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    chart: GraphType
)

Weâ€™re going to start by displaying the name of the currently selected chart. Weâ€™ll use a Text composable for this, using the stringResource function to retrieve the label for the provided GraphType. Because we are working with a range of text lengths for the GraphType values, weâ€™re going to use the widthIn modifier to apply a minimum width to the text component - in most cases, this will stop the width of the composable constantly changing with the different text values. Weâ€™ll also apply some padding to increase the touch area of the composable, as weâ€™re eventually going to make this a clickable component. Because weâ€™re modifying the spacing of the composable, weâ€™re going to use the textAlign argument to ensure that the composed text is always displayed in the center of the available space.

@Composable
fun ChartPicker(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    chart: GraphType
) {
	Text(
	    modifier = Modifier
            .padding(16.dp)
            .widthIn(min = 60.dp),
        text = stringResource(id = chart.label),
        textAlign = TextAlign.Center
    )
}

Now that we have this Text in place, we can see the currently selected graph name. This component is going to be used to change the currently selected graph, so we need to make it clear to the user that this is possible using this component. To indicate this to the user, weâ€™re going to add a chevron - this implies a dropdown selection is available for the current component.

Weâ€™ll need to start by wrapping the existing content in a Row, aligning the child composables of this container in the vertical center. Next, weâ€™ll compose an Icon, providing the ArrowDropDown icon for the required image argument.

@Composable
fun ChartPicker(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    chart: GraphType
) {
    Row(
        modifier = modifier,
        verticalAlignment = Alignment.CenterVertically
    ) {
        ...
        Icon(
            imageVector = Icons.Default.ArrowDropDown,
            contentDescription = null
        )
    }
}

Weâ€™re also going to provide a content description for this Icon, so that screenreader can communicate the intent of the icon. Weâ€™ll start by adding a new string resource to our feature module.

<string name="cd_select_chart">Select Chart Type</string>

Followed by assigning the value of this reason to the contentDescription argument of the Icon composable.

@Composable
fun ChartPicker(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    chart: GraphType
) {
    Box {
        Row(
            modifier = modifier,
            verticalAlignment = Alignment.CenterVertically
        ) {
            ...
            Icon(
                imageVector = Icons.Default.ArrowDropDown,
                contentDescription = stringResource(
					id = R.string.cd_select_chart)
            )
        }
    }
}

With the visuals now in place, we can go ahead and apply the clickable modifier to our composable. Weâ€™ll apply this to the parent Row, using the modifier to trigger a lambda function that weâ€™ll add as an argument for our composable.

@Composable
fun ChartPicker(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    chart: GraphType,
    onPickerRequested: () -> Unit
) {
	val clickLabel = stringResource(id = R.string.cd_select_chart)
    Row(
        modifier = modifier
            .clickable { onPickerRequested() },
        verticalAlignment = Alignment.CenterVertically
    ) {
        ...       
	}
}

We can go one step further here to improve the accessibility of our composable, and thatâ€™s by lifting the content description of the Icon out and using it as the click action description for the clickable modifier that we just added to our Row composable. This means that now when the composable is focused, the action for the click event will be communicated to the user, as opposed to them needing to navigate the screen reader to the individual Icon composable.

@Composable
fun ChartPicker(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    chart: GraphType,
    onPickerRequested: () -> Unit
) {
	val clickLabel = stringResource(id = R.string.cd_select_chart)
    Row(
        modifier = modifier
            .clickable(onClickLabel = clickLabel)
				{ onPickerRequested() },
        verticalAlignment = Alignment.CenterVertically
    ) {
        ...       
	}
}

Now that we have the foreground of the selected graph in place, weâ€™re going to implement the dropdown menu that will be used to select the graph to be displayed. For this, weâ€™re going to use the DropdownMenu composable - this allows us to display a popup menu to allow selection from a set of items. For the composition of this we need to provide three required arguments:

  • expanded - whether the dropdown menu is currently expanded, with the options visible to the user
  • onDismissRequest - lambda triggered when the dropdown is requested to be dismissed
  • content - the composable content of the dropdown menu

For the first two arguments we currently have these being managed by the state of our screen, so we can simply pass these values into the composable function and use them directly within the composition of the DropdownMenu.

@Composable
fun ChartPicker(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    chart: GraphType,
	expanded: Boolean,
    dismiss: () -> Unit,
    onPickerRequested: () -> Unit
) {
    Box(modifier = modifier) {
        ...
        DropdownMenu(
            expanded = expanded,
            onDismissRequest = { dismiss() }
		) {
            
        }
    }
}

Currently, we arenâ€™t composing anything for the content of our DropdownMenu, so weâ€™re going to use the defined values of GraphType to show the available options for the user. For each of these values, weâ€™ll map to a composable in the form of a DropdownMenuItem. Weâ€™ll need to provide two arguments to this DropdownMenuItem:

  • onClick - the lambda function to be triggered when the item is clicked
  • content - the content to be composed for the item

For the content of each DropdownMenuItem weâ€™re simply going to compose a Text that uses the label of the corresponding GraphType.

@Composable
fun ChartPicker(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    chart: GraphType,
    expanded: Boolean,
    dismiss: () -> Unit,
    onPickerRequested: () -> Unit
) {
    Box(modifier = modifier) {
        ...
        DropdownMenu(
            expanded = expanded,
            onDismissRequest = { dismiss() }
		) {
            GraphType.values().map {
                DropdownMenuItem(onClick = { 

				}) {
                    Text(text = stringResource(id = it.label))
                }
            }
        }
    }
}

Now that each DropdownMenuItem has a visual representation in the form of the graph name, we now need to let the parent composable know that a new graph type has been selected. Here weâ€™ll define a new argument for our composable function, onItemSelected, in the form of a lambda that can be used to pass the selected GraphType up to the parent.

@Composable
fun GraphPicker(
    modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
    chart: GraphType,
    expanded: Boolean,
    dismiss: () -> Unit,
    onItemSelected: (chart: GraphType) -> Unit,
    onPickerRequested: () -> Unit
) {
    Box(modifier = modifier) {
        ...
        DropdownMenu(
            expanded = expanded,
            onDismissRequest = { dismiss() }
		) {
            GraphType.values().map {
                DropdownMenuItem(onClick = { 
					onItemSelected(it) 
				}) {
                    Text(text = stringResource(id = it.label))
                }
            }
        }
    }
}

With this in place, the user now has a way to change the currently selected graph.

Composing the Dashboard

Now that weâ€™ve created both the Graph and GraphPicker composables, weâ€™re ready to slot these into our dashboard so that the graph and picker are composed in our UI. Weâ€™ll start by composing the ChartPicker, for which weâ€™re going to need to provide a couple of arguments:
