  • chart - the currently selected graph, referencing the selectedGraph value from the GraphsState reference
  • expanded - whether or not the picker should be displayed as expanded, which will be provided as the showGraphPicker from the GraphsState reference
  • dismiss - callback used to receive events for when the picker is to be dismissed. Weâ€™ll need to pass this up to the parent composable so that the corresponding event can be handled in the ViewModel. Weâ€™ll add a new argument to the composable function, handleEvent, which can then be used to trigger the DismissPicker event
  • onItemSelected - callback used to receive events for when an item in the picker is selected. Also using the handleEvent lambda, we can use this to trigger the SetChartType event, passing the selected item as the argument
  • onPickerRequested - callback used to receive events for when the display of the picker is requested. Again using the handleEvent lambda we can trigger the ShowPicker event to update the state for our screen

Alongside the composition of the ChartPicker, weâ€™ll also compose this with a Spacer inside of a Column - we need to use a Column here as weâ€™re going to be displaying multiple composables, stacked vertically.

@Composable
fun GraphsDashboard(
	modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
	state: GraphsState, 
	handleEvent: (event: GraphsEvent) -> Unit
) {
    Column(
        modifier = modifier,
        horizontalAlignment = Alignment.CenterHorizontally,
    ) {
        Spacer(modifier = Modifier.height(16.dp))
        ChartPicker(
            chart = state.selectedGraph,
            expanded = state.showGraphPicker,
            dismiss = {
                handleEvent(GraphsEvent.DismissPicker)
            },
            onItemSelected = {
                handleEvent(GraphsEvent.SetChartType(it))
            },
            onPickerRequested = {
                handleEvent(GraphsEvent.ShowPicker)
            }
        )
    }
}

Now that the chart picker is in place we can look at composing the currently selected chart, done so using the Chart composable. Weâ€™ll provide value for the three arguments of this composable:

  • modifier - weâ€™ll use the fillMaxWidth modifier to have the composable fill the available width, along with the weight modifier to have the composable fill the remaining space
  • chart - the chart to be composed, which will be the selectedChart from the state reference
  • chartData - the data to be used for graph composition, which is referenced from the chartData value of the state reference

Before composing this weâ€™ll also utilise the Spacer to ensure that there is sufficient spacing between the ChartPicker and Chart composables.

@Composable
fun GraphsDashboard(
	modifier: Modifier = Modifier,
	state: GraphsState, 
	handleEvent: (event: GraphsEvent) -> Unit
) {
    Column(
        modifier = modifier,
        horizontalAlignment = Alignment.CenterHorizontally,
    ) {
        Spacer(modifier = Modifier.height(16.dp))
        ChartPicker(
            chart = state.selectedChart,
            expanded = state.showChartPicker,
            dismiss = {
                handleEvent(GraphsEvent.DismissPicker)
            },
            onItemSelected = {
                handleEvent(GraphsEvent.SetChartType(it))
            },
            onPickerRequested = {
                handleEvent(GraphsEvent.ShowPicker)
            }
        )
        Spacer(modifier = Modifier.height(16.dp))
        Chart(
            modifier = Modifier
                .fillMaxWidth()
                .weight(1f),
            chart = state.selectedChart,
            chartData = state.chartData
        )
    }
}

With this in place, we can see that the picker and graph composables are now being composed, with the Chart representing the currently selected GraphType from the ChartPicker.

Wrapping Up

Throughout this project, weâ€™ve now fully implemented our graphs feature - allowing our users to view a provided data set in several different graph formats. Weâ€™ve explored the composition of data onto a canvas, not only learning how to draw different kinds of information onto a canvas but also animating it in the process.

Testing the Graphs UI

Now that weâ€™ve built our Music Dashboard feature, weâ€™re going to take a look at how we can write tests for our composables. Weâ€™re going to be writing some instrumentation tests using the compose ui-test-junit package - allowing us to verify that our composables are displayed and functioning as expected.

Before we can get started with our tests, weâ€™re going to need to add a couple of test specific dependencies to our project:

androidTestImplementation(
	"androidx.compose.ui:ui-test-junit4:$compose_version")
debugImplementation(
	"androidx.compose.ui:ui-test-manifest:$compose_version")

Weâ€™re also going to need to add mocks to our test - this allows us to easily provide mock references to any listeners that are provided to our composable functions, allowing us to easily verify they are triggered whenever expected.

androidTestImplementation(
	"org.mockito.kotlin:mockito-kotlin:3.2.0")
androidTestImplementation("org.mockito:mockito-android:3.12.4")

With these in place, we now have access to the required rules and functionality that allow us to test our composable UI. However, alongside these dependencies, weâ€™re also going to need to add some rules to our build.gradle file that will fix some of the compilation errors that weâ€™d currently see when trying to run our tests. Here weâ€™ll add some packagingOptions that will exclude certain packages from the added dependencies. We wonâ€™t dive too much into this concept and itâ€™s usually dependent on the versions of dependencies that are being used, so this may be redundant if you come to updating versions.

android {
	packagingOptions {
		exclude "**/attach_hotspot_windows.dll"
		exclude "META-INF/AL2.0"
		exclude "META-INF/LGPL2.1"
		exclude "META-INF/licenses/ASM"
	}
}

Testing the Graph Picker

A key component in our UI is the chart picker - this allows the user to change the graph that is currently being displayed on the screen. To ensure that this component is operating as expected, weâ€™ll start here by creating a new test class, ChartPickerTest.

class ChartPickerTest {

}

Inside of this class, we now need to define a reference to the ComposeContentTestRule class - this is what weâ€™re going to use to set the composable content on screen, allowing us to perform interactions and assertions from within our tests. 

class ChartPickerTest {

    @get:Rule
    val composeTestRule = createComposeRule()

}

When using this rule, we donâ€™t need to specify any form of activity for our composables to be launched, the test rule will handle that for us. So using this rule we will set the composable content to be composed, the test will then launch a host activity which will be used to compose our provided content inside.

With this test class configured, weâ€™re going to write some tests to assert that each of the expected composables is being displayed when required - which will be based on the properties that are provided to the ChartPicker composable. Weâ€™ll start here by asserting that the selected chart is being composed - the header should always be composed within the messaging screen, so we donâ€™t need to worry about passing any specific state to it.

Weâ€™ll create a new test case, Selected_Chart_Displayed. Inside of this test, weâ€™re going to need to start by setting the composable content that is to be displayed on the screen for us to perform assertions against. Here weâ€™ll use the test rule that we previously defined, along with its setContent function. This function takes a composable function as an argument, allowing us to define what is to be composed on screen for our tests. 

class ChartPickerTest {

    @get:Rule
    val composeTestRule = createComposeRule()

    @Test
    fun Selected_Chart_Displayed() {
        composeTestRule.setContent {
            ChartPicker(
                chart = GraphType.AREA,
                expanded = false,
                dismiss = { },
                onItemSelected = { },
                onPickerRequested = { }
            )
        }

    }
}

So that we can locate the selected chart within our test, weâ€™re going to need to add a tag to the composable that we wish to perform assertions against - this tag can then be used to locate our composable within our tests. Weâ€™ll need to start here by defining a tag reference that can be accessed from both our tests and our composable.

// Tags.kt

object Tags {
	const val TAG_SELECTED_CHART = "selected_chart"
}

With this tag defined, weâ€™ll then need to add this to our ChartPicker composable. Weâ€™ll assign this to the Text composable within the function that represents the selected chart, using the testTag modifier to do so.

// ChartPicker.kt

Text(
	modifier = Modifier
		...
		.testTag(TAG_SELECTED_CHART),
	...
)

Next, weâ€™re going to locate the node within our composable hierarchy so that we can perform interactions and assertions on it. Here weâ€™ll utilise the onNodeWithTag function, providing the tag that we defined above. We can then utilise the assertTextEquals function to assert that the composable is displaying the expected text within the ChartPicker.

class ChartPickerTest {

    @get:Rule
    val composeTestRule = createComposeRule()

    @Test
    fun Selected_Chart_Displayed() {
        composeTestRule.setContent {
            ChartPicker(
                chart = GraphType.AREA,
                expanded = false,
                dismiss = { },
                onItemSelected = { },
                onPickerRequested = { }
            )
        }

		composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(TAG_SELECTED_CHART)
            .assertTextEquals(
                InstrumentationRegistry.getInstrumentation()
                    .targetContext.getString(
						GraphType.AREA.label)
            )
    }
}

Now that we are asserting that the selected chart is being displayed, weâ€™re going to assert that all available charts are being displayed within the picker. Weâ€™ll need to start here by composing the ChartPicker, passing in a state reference that marks the expanded flag as true.

@Test
fun Chart_Types_Displayed() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
    	ChartPicker(
            chart = GraphType.AREA,
            expanded = true,
            dismiss = { },
            onItemSelected = { },
            onPickerRequested = { }
        )
    }
}

When the picker is composed, the charts available for selection should now be displayed. To test this weâ€™re going to want to loop through the available values, asserting that each of the graph type names is being displayed. Using the TAG_CHART_TYPES tag that we previously defined, we can use the onChildAt function to locate the child node at the current index within our loop. At this position, there should be corresponding text content that matches the name of the chart. We can asset this by using hasText, passing in the string representation of the chart label.

@Test
fun Chart_Types_Displayed() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
    	ChartPicker(
            chart = GraphType.AREA,
            expanded = true,
            dismiss = { },
            onItemSelected = { },
            onPickerRequested = { }
        )
    }

    GraphType.values().forEachIndexed { index, chartType ->
        composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(TAG_CHART_TYPES)
            .onChildAt(index)
            .assert(hasText(
				InstrumentationRegistry.getInstrumentation()
                    .targetContext.getString(chartType.label))
			)
    }
}

Now that we know all of the expected data is being displayed, weâ€™re going to want to assert that the interactions with the components are being triggered - as otherwise, the user wonâ€™t be able to change the chart that is being displayed on-screen. Weâ€™ll start here by asserting that the request to display the picker is being triggered - we pass this event unto the parent composable via the onPickerRequested lambda argument, so weâ€™ll want to test this in a new test case, Picker_Requested_Triggered. When composing the ChartPicker weâ€™ll pass a mock implementation of the onPickerRequested lambda - this is so that we can verify this is involved when the composable is interacted with.

@Test
fun Picker_Requested_Triggered() {
    val onPickerRequested: () -> Unit = mock()
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        ChartPicker(
            chart = GraphType.AREA,
            expanded = false,
            dismiss = { },
            onItemSelected = { },
            onPickerRequested = onPickerRequested
        )
    }
}

Weâ€™ll then use the TAG_SELECTED_CHART tag to locate our ChartPicker, utilising the performClick function to invoke a click event on the located node. When this click event occurs we would expect the onPickerRequested lambda to be invoked - so at this point we want to verify that this is the case by utilising the mockito verify function. This allows us to assert that the lambda is triggered as expected when the node is clicked.

@Test
fun Picker_Requested_Triggered() {
    val onPickerRequested: () -> Unit = mock()
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        ChartPicker(
            chart = GraphType.AREA,
            expanded = false,
            dismiss = { },
            onItemSelected = { },
            onPickerRequested = onPickerRequested
        )
    }

    composeTestRule
		.onNodeWithTag(TAG_SELECTED_CHART)
		.performClick()

    verify(onPickerRequested).invoke()
}

Alongside asserting that the onPickerRequested lambda is being triggered, weâ€™re also going to want to cover the onItemSelected lambda. Weâ€™ll do the same here again by creating a mock to provide to the composable and composing the ChartPicker for our test.

@Test
fun Item_Selected_Triggered() {
    val chartToSelect = GraphType.DOUGHNUT
    val onItemSelected: (type: GraphType) -> Unit = mock()
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        ChartPicker(
            chart = GraphType.AREA,
            expanded = true,
            dismiss = { },
            onItemSelected = onItemSelected,
            onPickerRequested = { }
        )
    }
}

Youâ€™ll notice here that weâ€™ve defined a chartToSelect variable, assigning a GraphType reference to it. We do this so that we have a GraphType to click on within the list of graphs - which we can then use to assert that the selected function is triggered. Using the onNodeWithText function weâ€™ll locate the node with the corresponding graph label, followed by performing a click action on this node using the performClick function.

When this click event occurs, we would expect the onItemSelected lambda function to be invoked with the GraphType that was selected by the user. In our test, we used the label from the chartToSelect reference, so we would also expect the onItemSelected lambda to be triggered with this reference. Weâ€™ll use the mocktio verify function to assert that the lambda is invoked with the expected GraphType value.

@Test
fun Item_Selected_Triggered() {
    val chartToSelect = GraphType.DOUGHNUT
    val onItemSelected: (type: GraphType) -> Unit = mock()
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        ChartPicker(
            chart = GraphType.AREA,
            expanded = true,
            dismiss = { },
            onItemSelected = onItemSelected,
            onPickerRequested = { }
        )
    }

    composeTestRule.onNodeWithText(
        InstrumentationRegistry.getInstrumentation()
            .targetContext.getString(chartToSelect.label)
    ).performClick()

    verify(onItemSelected).invoke(chartToSelect)
}

Testing the Legend

Now that weâ€™ve got tests in place to cover the display of the graphs, weâ€™re next going to add some tests to ensure that the legend is being displayed as expected. Weâ€™ll place these tests inside of a new test class, LegendTest.

// LegendTest.kt

class LegendTest {

    @get:Rule
    val composeTestRule = createComposeRule()

}

In this test, weâ€™re going to want to assert that the labels of the legend are being composed. So that we can perform these assertions, weâ€™re going to start by using our test rule to compose the Legend. 

// LegendTest.kt

@Test
fun Chart_Data_Labels_Displayed() {
    val chartData = GraphsDataFactory.makeChartData()
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        Legend(chartData = chartData)
    }
}

Before we can perform assertions on this composable, weâ€™re going to need to add a tag to the composable - this will allow us to locate the node representing the legend from within our tests.

// Tags.kt

object Tags {
	const val TAG_LEGEND = "TAG_LEGEND"
}

With this tag defined, weâ€™ll go ahead and apply this tag to the parent composable within our Legend, using the testTag modifier to do so.

// Legend.kt
Column(modifier = modifier.testTag(TAG_LEGEND))

Now that this tag is in place, we can locate the Legend node within our tests. Weâ€™re going to want to assert that each of the labels is being displayed within the legend. To test this, weâ€™ll start by looping through the chartData that the Legend is being composed with. For each item in this loop, weâ€™ll use the current index of the loop to retrieve the child using the onChildAt function - we use the index here because we expect the chart data labels to be composed in the same order that they are in within the list. Now that we have the child node at the given index, we can use the assert function to check that the label is displayed.

@Test
fun Chart_Data_Labels_Displayed() {
    val chartData = GraphsDataFactory.makeChartData()
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        Legend(chartData = chartData)
    }

    chartData.forEachIndexed { index, data ->
        composeTestRule
			.onNodeWithTag(TAG_LEGEND)
			.onChildAt(index)
			.assert(hasText(data.label))
    }
}

Testing the Graphs Dashboard

Now that we have the lower-level components being tested, weâ€™re going to hop up to a higher level in our composable tree - the GraphsDashboard. Weâ€™re going to test that the expected graphs are being composed based on the current state of our composable. Weâ€™ll start here by creating a new test, GraphsDashboardTest, with a supporting test rule.

class GraphsDashboardTest {

    @get:Rule
    val composeTestRule = createComposeRule()

}

Within this dashboard, we allow the user to change the graph that is currently being displayed - if this component isnâ€™t visible, then our feature becomes quite broken. Weâ€™re going to write a quick test to assert that the ChartPicker is being displayed on-screen as expected. In this test, weâ€™ll simply need to compose the GraphsDashboard and pass a default GraphsState state reference.

@Test
fun Chart_Picker_Displayed() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        GraphsDashboard(
            state = GraphsState(),
            handleEvent = {}
        )
    }
}

Next, weâ€™ll need to add a new tag to our Tags object so that we can locate the ChartPicker composable.

// Tags.kt

object Tags {
    const val TAG_CHART_TYPE_TOGGLE = "chart_type_toggle"
}

Weâ€™ll then want to apply this tag to the corresponding composable using the testTag modifier.

// GraphsDashboard.kt

ChartPicker(
    modifier = Modifier.testTag(TAG_CHART_TYPE_TOGGLE),
    ...
)

We can then utilise this in a test to assert that the ChartPicker composable is being composed. Weâ€™ll utilise the onNodeWithTag function to locate the corresponding node, followed by assertIsDisplayed to assert that the composable is being displayed as expected.

@Test
fun Chart_Picker_Displayed() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        GraphsDashboard(
            state = GraphsState(),
            handleEvent = {}
        )
    }

    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(TAG_CHART_TYPE_TOGGLE)
        .assertIsDisplayed()
}

Now that we have the ChartPicker being tested, weâ€™ll want to assert that each of the expected graph types is being composed. So that we can locate these graphs, weâ€™re going to need to add tags that can be used to locate each of these. Weâ€™ll add a new tag for each of the graph types:

// Tags.kt

object Tags {
	const val TAG_CHART_BAR = "chart_bar"
    const val TAG_CHART_COLUMN = "chart_column"
    const val TAG_CHART_PIE = "chart_pie"
    const val TAG_CHART_DOUGHNUT = "chart_doughnut"
    const val TAG_CHART_AREA = "chart_area"
    const val TAG_CHART_LINE = "chart_line"
}

Then for each Canvas within the corresponding graph composables weâ€™ll need to assign the tag using the testTag modifier. We wonâ€™t cover this for each graph as the code is the same, but in the case of the line graph, this will look like so:

Canvas(
	modifier = modifier
		.height(320.dp)
		.fillMaxWidth()
        .padding(36.dp)
        .testTag(TAG_CHART_LINE)
)

We can then write a test to assert that the expected graph is being displayed upon composition. Weâ€™ll start here by creating a new test case, Line_Chart_Displayed. In this weâ€™re going to want to compose the GraphsDashboard, passing in a GraphsState that defines the selectedChart as the GraphType.LINE type. When this is the case, we would expect the line chart to be composed - so we can assert this using the TAG_CHART_LINE tag.

@Test
fun Line_Chart_Displayed() {
    composeTestRule.setContent {
        GraphsDashboard(
            state = GraphsState(
                selectedChart = GraphType.LINE
            ),
            handleEvent = {}
        )
    }
    composeTestRule.onNodeWithTag(TAG_CHART_LINE)
        .assertIsDisplayed()
}

In the project code, youâ€™ll find the rest of the tests for each graph type, we havenâ€™t included them here as the code is almost identical!
